Heuerman is an insurance pick, as Daniels has had problems saying healthy and Casey's production has dipped over the past two seasons.

What he brings: He has the size and strength to set a hard edge against the run. He is a disruptive pass-rusher with the strength to collapse the pocket when he reduces inside, and he gets his hands in throwing lanes even when he can't get to the QB. He's a limited athlete but an effective, hard-nosed player.

How he fits: Corey Redding and Ricky Jean-Francois departed in free agency and DT Arthur Jones has struggled to stay healthy, so there is a need to add bodies along the front line. Anderson fits the mold, as he has the length to line up at 5-technique and create disruption within defensive coordinator Greg Manusky's base 3-4 scheme.

What he brings: Montgomery is at his best when he has the ball in his hands regardless if that's after the catch, in the return game or on a carry thanks to his blend of vision, elusiveness and balance in space. His timed top-end speed is just average, and he's not an elite vertical threat who regularly takes the top off the coverage, but he flashes the ability to turn on the jets when he gets a seam as a ball carrier. The biggest area of concern is his hands. He drops passes he should catch and fights the ball too much despite the fact that he has a big hand span.

How he fits: Receiver isn't a pressing need after re-signing Randall Cobb, but Green Bay makes a value pick here and gives Aaron Rodgers yet another weapon by taking Montgomery. In addition, Montgomery is a dangerous return man who should give the Packers' kickoff return unit a much-needed boost.

What he brings: Jones has excellent size at 6-2 and 230 pounds. He is a determined runner that possesses quality pad level, power and balance to pick up yards after contact. While he isn't a dynamic runner, Jones has quick feet, adequate lateral agility and flashes the versatility as a receiving threat to provide quality depth at the position.

How he fits: Jones is a little bit of a reach here, but not by a lot and he fills a need for Washington. While Alfred Morris became the first Redskins player to rush for 1,000 in each of his first three seasons, his 4.1-yard average was lowest of career and he's entering a contract season. Plus, Roy Helu left in free agency.

What he brings: He's a very effective interior speed rusher with his quickness, but he struggles to get pressure when the offensive lineman is able to lock on. He's a disruptive run defender with excellent range, but he needs to win with quickness.

How he fits: The Browns continue to stockpile bodies along the front seven. Cooper provides the quickness with enough size and versatility to fit within their hybrid front. He brings quality upside as a pass-rusher and should have an impact early as a rotational backup.

What he brings: Grissom plays with great effort on tape and has strong point-of-attack skills setting the edge against the run. While he lacks an elite first step as a pass-rusher, he comes off with quality leverage and has the ability to convert speed to power. Grissom will have limitations if asked to consistently play in space as a 3-4 OLB.

How he fits: The Patriots covet versatility on defense and Grissom fits the bill. He has experience playing with his hand in the dirt and in a two-point stance, which plays well into defensive coordinator Mattt Patricia's hands. Grissom has a chance to make an impact as an edge defender, where he is stout against the run and brings upside as a pass-rusher.

What he brings: He could struggle against bigger outside receivers in man-to-man coverage due to his lack of ideal speed, height and length. But his short-area burst makes him a good fit in the slot, and his recognition skills and instincts for the position are excellent.

How he fits: After selecting Marcus Peters in the first round, the Chiefs continue to build depth in the back end. Nelson lacks ideal size but has quality balance and quickness and projects in the slot, where the Chiefs could use an upgrade. CB Sean Smith is a free agent after next season, and general manager John Dorsey is making sure they are prepared in case he moves on.

What he brings: Blackson isn't going to fill up the stat sheet and he projects as a two-down player who isn't expected to make a substantial impact rushing the passer. He is still an intriguing Day 3 prospect because of his versatility and his ability to defend the run. He controls blockers one-on-one and flashes the ability to occupy double teams when he plays with sound technique. He has the frame, foot speed and length to play nose tackle regardless of the front and line up at defensive end in a base three-man front.

What he brings: He's one of our favorite prospects in this class for how hard he plays, and he has the versatility to fill multiple roles in different defensive fronts. He's also a very good run defender with his combination of length and power. He won't win as a pass-rusher with pure speed, but he's effective at pressuring the quarterback with his quick step and relentless motor.

What he brings: He has excellent length and power, and when he locks on against pass-rushers he can keep them at bay. But he has athletic limitations that show up against speed rushers and could make him a liability in the NFL. He can overpower people as a run-blocker with his massive frame and raw power.

What he brings: Petty is a naturally accurate passer with very good arm strength and a clean, compact stroke. He displayed a very good command of Baylor's up-tempo spread offense, but he faces a steep learning curve as he transitions to an NFL system. He has above-average mobility in the pocket.

What he brings: He is an aggressive run defender with very good closing burst and pop at the point of attack. He doesn't have much experience in man-to-man coverage but has good range in zone, and displayed good ball skills in his one season as a starter.

What he brings: Crowder is a pint-sized receiver who projects as a slot wideout at the next level. He has a nice feel for the position and the quickness to create separation. Crowder also shows the ability to manufacture yards after the catch and brings versatility as a returner on special teams.

What he brings: He is very sudden with the ability to make defenders miss once he finds a crease. He isn't very powerful, but he runs behind his pads and gets stronger as the game goes on, unlike most other smaller backs. He needs to get more consistent as a pass-catcher and in pass protection.

What he brings: He won't create separation based on speed or suddenness, but some guys just have a knack for separating, and Hardy is one of them. He catches everything, and while he isn't a big-play threat, purely in terms of his ball skills and competitiveness he's one of the top wideouts in this class.

What he brings: Fowler is a heat-seeking missile who knocks defenders back on contact both as a run-blocker and in pass protection. The 2014 team captain is also versatile and willing to do whatever it takes to help the team. He is an effective between-the-tackles runner, is a reliable safety valve in the passing game and a potential core special-teams contributor.

What he brings: Geathers isn't a ball hawk, and he hasn't realized his considerable upside as a run defender. He takes too many poor angles and fails to break down in space too much at this point. On the other hand, the three-year starter has the frame, toughness and stopping power to develop into an effective run-stopper at the NFL level. He also shows functional range and flashes good route recognition in coverage.

What he brings: He only played two years at offensive tackle after moving over from the defensive side of the ball, and that lack of experience showed up in his play at college, particularly in pass protection. But he has the raw tools to develop into a very good tackle or guard, and he could be an overpowering run-blocker early on.

What he brings: You're not going to beat Jackson by running through him. He's a thick, wide-bodied guy who dominates in the running game. You need to protect him on passing plays, as a quick 3-technique defensive tackle could give him trouble, but he plays with an edge.

What he brings: Kouandjio's subpar three-cone and short shuttle times suggest he struggles to change directions quickly yet he graded out as an above-average pass-blocker for a guard thanks to in large part to his ability to lock on and lock out. He has big hands and long arms. While he is not a mauler and he plays high, he does well enough getting into position and walling off assignments in the run game. He would have graded out higher if it weren't for multiple knee surgeries and concerns about his durability.

What he brings: Wright isn't a massive space-eater, but his heavy hands and powerful punch make it tough to block him one-on-one. The 2014 team captain also has the motor and enough range to make plays outside the tackle box. While he's not a powerful bull rusher and he has average closing speed, he has the agility, hands and enough quickness to develop into a disruptive interior pass-rusher who moves quarterbacks off their spots.

What he brings: Douglas moved from guard to left tackle in 2014, and he'll likely move back to guard because of pass pro concerns. He struggles with speed-to-power off the edge and his below-average arm length raises concerns about his ability to prevent NFL speed rushers from turning the corner. He doesn't have the power base to drive defenders off the ball in the run game, either. However, he has the frame, size and enough foot speed to provide depth at guard in a zone-heavy scheme.

What he brings: Campbell is a team captain who is at his best defending the run. He takes sound angles closing from the high slot, shows he can shed blocks quickly when he lines up in the box and is a reliable tackler who is better than average making one-on-one plays in space. He doesn't have the burst to regularly stay with NFL slot receivers in man, and his shorter arms raise concern about his ability to match up with tight ends, but he has enough range to cover a deep half and he flashes the ability to play the ball.

What he brings: Gunter has a quality combination of size, strength and point-of-attack skills. He is at his best against the run where he displays heavy hands and above-average upper-body power. He has adequate quickness that provides him with upside as a pass-rusher. However he is raw in this area and needs to improve his technique.

What he brings: Bell moved from quarterback to tight end in 2014 and his inexperience shows at times. He's a raw route runner who is still learning how to tempo his breaks and use his upper body to create separation. He also needs to get stronger at the point as a blocker. That said, he has the frame and toughness to grow into an effective inline blocker. He already flashes the ability to get his hands inside and sustain. He also has big hands and catches the ball well. It doesn't hurt that his father and an uncle played in the NFL, either.

What he brings: Wilson is an active and instinctive linebacker who is at his best defending the run. While he can improve his strength at the point of attack, he is savvy getting through traffic and is a very reliable tackler. Wilson has average athleticism and overall range, though, and may have limitations in coverage at the next level.

What he brings: Donnal is a one-year starter at tackle who struggles to mirror quicker edge rushers when they work inside. He may be a better fit at guard, where he started three games in 2012. However, he does an adequate job of masking his weaknesses in pass protection with sound hand placement and effort. Additionally, he has the nasty disposition, frame and strength to develop into an effective drive blocker regardless of the position.

What he brings: Shaw has experience lining up at both safety and corner, but projects as a safety at the next level. He has some tightness in his hips and will labor when having to quickly transition out of breaks. However, he has an above-average closing burst once pointed in the right direction and is a physical defender both at the catch point and in run support. Character concerns do exist.

What he brings: He has the speed and fluidity to turn and run with most receivers, but he can get pushed around against bigger receivers in coverage and when attempting to shed blocks. He has good awareness in zone but needs to play with better patience.

What he brings: Smith is not a great athlete and won't pose a threat as a speed rusher in the NFL, but he can still pressure the quarterback with his impressive power and relentless motor. He has the size and strength to set the edge against the run, and he can contribute at multiple spots along the defensive line.

What he brings: Mayle doesn't have great speed and has some tightness coming out of breaks with underneath routes. However, he is an above-average athlete with plus size (6-2, 224) and strength and flashes the ability to win in contested situations. Mayle has a chance to develop into a No. 4 or No. 5 possession-type receiver on the back end of a roster.

What he brings: He lacks ideal size and power against the run, but makes up for it with excellent short-area burst and top-end speed to defend sideline to sideline. His instincts are just average, but he's an effective tackler and has the athleticism to cover a lot of ground in coverage.

What he brings: Davis possesses a well-rounded skill set. At 5-9 and 217 pounds, he runs with a low center of gravity and has quality power as an inside runner. Davis also shows very good patience and vision as a runner and brings versatility as a receiver in the passing game.

What he brings: Wilson has an above-average blend of height, weight, length and top-end speed. His range against the run is the first thing that stands out on tape. He's an instinctive run defender with the quickness to beat backs to the edge when he makes a sound read, he's above average at slipping blocks on the move and his motor is almost always running at a high level. Wilson also gets good depth and covers enough ground to hold up in zone. The downside is he takes too long to get off blocks when teams run at him and he's far too inconsistent as a tackler at this point.

What he brings: While he started at guard and tackle during his time at Miami, Feliciano projects as a guard because he doesn't have the length or lateral quickness to protect the edge at the NFL level. He doesn't do a good enough job of pressing and steering as a run-blocker, either. On the positive side, he finds a way to get the job done more times than not thanks to his tenacity, footwork and outstanding overall awareness.

What he brings: Ryan is a two-time team captain with a good blend of height, weight and straight-line speed. He's an instinctive run defender who closes well chasing down backs and he limits production after contact as a tackler. While he doesn't change directions well in space, he shows above-average awareness in underneath zones and he's a better pass-rusher than his sack numbers suggest.

What he brings: Poole was a two-year starter at San Diego State and has an above-average blend of height, weight and top-end speed. He has starting experience at left and right tackle, but his arms are on the shorter side and he struggles with athletic edge rushers, so he may be a better fit on the inside at the next level. While he needs to improve his footwork and initial hand placement, he's aggressive and he blocks to the echo of the whistle on almost every snap.

What he brings: Mason's biggest obstacle to climb at the next level will be in pass protection. He comes from a triple-option offense that didn't throw the ball a lot and had vanilla protection schemes when it did. In addition, he lacks ideal height and length, which hampers his ability to recover when initially caught out of position. However, he is a solid run-blocker, plays with natural leverage and displays an above-average inline power base.

What he brings: Smelter is coming off a season-ending injury (torn ACL) and will need some time developing the full route tree coming from the triple-option scheme. However, he has a lot of upside to work with due to his size, raw athleticism and ability to create after the catch.

What he brings: Garcia isn't a bulldozer who regularly drives defenders off the ball, but his ability to get into position, shoot his hands inside, lock on and wall off his assignment stood out on tape and the week of the Senior Bowl. The 2014 team captain also does a good job of using his hands, smarts and effort to overcome his considerable athletic limitations in pass protection.

What he brings: Glowinski checks all the boxes in terms of height, weight and length, plus he tested well at the combine both on the bench and during agility drills. The upper-body strength shows up at times on tape, as he flashes a violent punch and the ability to latch on to defenders' frames. However, there's room for improvement when it comes to pressing defenders off his frame in the run game, and he doesn't move quite as well in pass protection or space as you'd expect based on his test results.

What he brings: Hardison has an above-average blend of weight, initial quickness and upper-body strength for a 4-3 defensive tackle prospect. He's also athletic and versatile enough to line up at 3-4 defensive end or 4-3 left defensive end. He flashed considerable upside on tape and the week of the Senior Bowl but he's inconsistent with technique and effort. Plus the fact that he only had one productive season at the FBS level raises a red flag.

What he brings: Walker is a long cornerback with adequate fluidity and very good range. He is at his best in press technique where he can use his length to get his hands on receivers and disrupt their timing. He needs work with technique, but has a high ceiling as a developmental prospect.

What he brings: His quickness is his best asset, as he can utilize his snap anticipation and initial burst to be disruptive in the running game and as an interior pass-rusher from the 3-technique defensive tackle position. He can get blown off the ball by bigger offensive linemen, but not as often as you'd think given his size.

What he brings: Cobb is a big back (5-11, 229) who runs behind his pads and has above-average power and balance. He also has nimble feet for a bigger back and flashes adequate lateral agility. However, he lacks explosiveness and ideal instincts as a runner at this point. He is too much of an east-west runner and must learn to play to his strength as an inside runner and do a better job of locating and hitting creases vertically with more consistency.

What he brings: He isn't much of a run-after-catch threat but can be a good NFL slot receiver or possession receiver because of his separation skills and very good ball skills. He's a natural at breaking open at just the right time, and is very good at finding openings in zone coverage.

What he brings: Heeney is a two-time team captain and sideline-to-sideline run defender. His angles are a little inconsistent but he closes well on a straight line and he has an above-average motor. He also covers enough ground to hold up in zone and flashes the ability to play the ball. He's light even for an outside linebacker prospect, however, and gets pushed around when teams run at him and at times in coverage.

What he brings: Spaight is high-motor player who plays faster on tape than he timed at the combine, but he doesn't have the closing burst to chase down backs on a straight line or threaten as a pass-rusher. He's also tight in space so he doesn't match up well in man and he's an inconsistent open-field tackler. He'll likely have to make an impact on special teams to make a roster.

What he brings: Amos has prototypical height, weight, length and top-end speed for a safety prospect. He's a former corner with above-average cover skills and range in addition to average ball skills for a safety. He needs to clean up his angles and tackling technique, but he's also an aggressive run-stuffer who closes well and flashes above-average stopping power.

What he brings: Pruitt posted the fastest 40 for the tight ends at the combine, and that speed shows up on tape where he flashes a second gear tracking the deep ball and is a threat to pick up chunk yards after the catch when he catches the ball in stride. He also has the length, leaping ability and big hands to compete for 50-50 balls. The rub is he doesn't offer as much as an inline blocker and he has limited upside in that area.

What he brings: Thompson has adequate size and good versatility to line up at the last line of defense, and has experience dropping into the slot at the nickelback position. He is very effective in run support, but lacks ideal instincts in coverage at this point and didn't have great production throughout his career.

What he brings: McCain lacks ideal length and doesn't have great overall range and long speed. However, he is a good fit in a heavy-zone scheme due to his above-average short-area quickness, change-of-direction skills and adequate instincts and anticipation skills. He also will step up in run support.

What he brings: Diggs has the second gear to outrun pursuit after the catch and occasionally take the top off the coverage, in addition to the ability to break long kickoff and punt returns. There's room for improvement when it comes to his footwork as a route runner but he improved his practice habits under wide receiver coach Keenan McCardell last year and he's an explosive athlete with the natural ability to improve. There are concerns about his long-term durability stemming from his injury history and leaner frame.

What he brings: At 6-3 and 225 pounds, Hundley has a sturdy build with above-average arm strength and athleticism to put stress on a defense with his feet. When able to set his feet, he also shows accuracy at all three levels. However, while Hundley has a strong physical skill set, he has a lot of work to do in terms of pocket awareness -- particularly keeping his eyes downfield under pressure -- which will need to be corrected quickly in order for him to succeed in the NFL.

What he brings: Tull is a team captain and former walk-on who turned heads with the way he jumped through the roof at the combine and ran at his pro day. That explosiveness shows up on tape where he flashes the ability to beat offensive tackles around the corner and generates speed to power rushing off the edge. However, his shorter arms hinder his ability to keep blockers off his frame and he's not big enough to hold ground when he doesn't play with leverage. Far more importantly, he's coming off shoulder surgery and his overall injury history raises a red flag.

What he brings: He's not as powerful as you'd expect from a guy his size, but he has good overall vision, patience and agility. He is a natural pass-catcher who can be productive in this area early in his NFL career. He needs to get a little better in pass protection, and he isn't the most explosive back, but he should be valuable on third down.

What he brings: Thompson has adequate measureables with a thick frame and above-average strength. He caught our eye at the NFLPA bowl where he showed good range and was very efficient in run support. Thompson has a chance to make an immediate impact on special teams while he develops as a player early in his career.

What he brings: Parry has had some problems staying healthy over the past two seasons, and he lacks the explosive burst to regularly generate pressure as a pass-rusher at the NFL level. He doesn't have the mass to consistently occupy double teams between the tackles or the arm length to play 3-4 DE at the NFL level, either. However, he has the low center of gravity and enough size to anchor one-on-one. He also jars blockers with a violent initial punch and has the heavy hands to shed quickly. He fits best providing depth at nose tackle in a base four-man front.

What he brings: Concerns about work ethic and -- to a lesser degree -- injury history have hurt Harrison's draft stock. If he works hard and stays healthy, he has the ability to compete for a starting guard job early in his career. He's an above-average pass-blocker and run-blocker who shows good overall awareness on tape. Though he has shorter arms for a tackle prospects, he has played there and could fill in at right tackle in a pinch.

What he brings: Emanuel is a team captain who played on four consecutive FCS championship teams and started at least eight games in each of those seasons. He projects as a 3-4 OLB, where he has the size to anchor against the run as well as the quick hands and feet to make an impact rushing the passer. He also has the motor and tenacity to make plays in pursuit and cover kicks on special teams.

What he brings: Davison has adequate size (6-1, 316) and quality length and is stout against the run when playing with leverage. He also flashes adequate quickness and active hands that give him upside as a pass-rusher.

What he brings: Williams is a converted safety who has a strong combination of size (6-1, 230), speed and power. Williams is a highly competitive runner who runs behind his pads, but he is an entry-point runner who lacks elite lateral agility and elusiveness to make defenders miss and pick up yards on his own. Williams does bring good versatility in the passing game.

What he brings: Lippett primarily lined up at receiver at Michigan State, but the fact that he started five games at corner in 2011 and two in 2014 makes him an intriguing Day 3 prospect. There's a lot to like about his height, length and ball skills, but he's on the leaner side so he gets pushed around at times regardless of the position. He doesn't project as a vertical threat as a receiver despite averaging 18.4 yards per catch last season, and he will need help over the top at times if he lines up at corner. While he ran better at his pro day than he did at the combine, he has only average top-end speed.

What he brings: Uzomah didn't get many chances to showcase his abilities as a receiver playing in Auburn's run-heavy scheme and his lack of polish as a route runner showed the week of the Senior Bowl. He needs to improve his technique as a blocker, but he's got long arms and big hands in addition to the size-speed combination to stretch the seam.

What he brings: Riddick projects as an outside linebacker who has excellent length (6-6, 244) and brings quality athleticism. He has upside as a pass-rusher with a quick first step and adequate flexibility bending the edge. However, he is a bit lean in his lower half, will struggle in a phone booth against more powerful blockers and lacks ideal speed to power.

What he brings: Nelson lacks ideal size (5-10, 156), is extremely raw as a route runner and has inconsistent ball skills on tape. However, he has world-class speed and is extremely dangerous with the ball in his hands, particularly as a returner on special teams, which is where he will need to excel if he wants to stick in the league.

What he brings: At 6-7 and 261 pounds, James is the prototype in terms of physical measurables. However, he has average athleticism, needs a lot of refining with his routes and doesn't always create adequate separation. In addition, he needs to play with a much more aggressive demeanor especially as a run-blocker.

What he brings: Ball comes with some durability issues and needs to continue to get stronger at the point of attack. However, he is an above-average athlete who shows good fluidity and overall range in space as a weakside linebacker. Ball also shows adequate awareness in coverage and does a nice job of breaking down to secure tackles in the open field.

What he brings: He is better at separating from zone coverage than man coverage, but he has deceptive top-end speed to get behind a defense and outstanding leaping ability to come down with contested catches. He doesn't have elite elusiveness but is shifty enough to turn a short catch into a long gain.

What he brings: Russell is a team captain who has an excellent blend of height, weight, length and top-end speed for a base 4-3 left defensive. He's also capable of kicking inside to rush the passer and lining up at defensive end in a base one-gap 3-4 scheme. However, there is room for improvement when it comes to technique. He tends to play too high defending the run, and he takes too long to counter when he doesn't win with his first move rushing the passer. It's also worth noting that he is a bit of an underachiever and has shown an inconsistent work ethic in the past.

What he brings: Doss has average size (5-10, 203) but has good fluidity and top-end speed. He needs to continue to develop his instincts in terms of reading routes and has to become much more aggressive in run support.

What he brings: Pinion is an underclassman who has exceptional size and quality leg strength. He gets good hang time with his punts and shows above-average directional skills and touch landing the ball inside the 20-yard line. He also has experience handling the kickoff duties.
What he brings: Cardona is an accurate snapper who does a nice job of getting downfield and covering thanks in large part to his effort and toughness.

How he fits: Swann's best fit is inside the hashes where he has quality instincts and good short-area quickness. He also is a savvy blitzer who times his pressures well and has a knack for getting home and creating turnovers.

What he brings: Burton has adequate size and power as a lead blocker. He isn't a hammer at the point of attack, but he quickly locates his targets and takes quality angles to engage. He also does a nice job of moving his feet to sustain blocks. Although he doesn't have great production, he flashes as a receiver in the passing game.

What he brings: Mayo has good size, a nose for the football and strong point-of-attack skills. He also displays adequate instincts and is a reliable tackler who does a nice job of wrapping upon contact to finish. Mayo is an average athlete and will have some limitations in space.

What he brings: Smith needs seasoning with his technique and awareness. However, he is a taller and rangy press corner with a lot of raw athleticism to work with. He has quick feet, fluid hips and flashes an above-average closing burst. With proper development, Smith has the skill set to develop into a quality starter and could end up being one of the bigger steals in this year's cornerback class.

What he brings: Boyle is a team captain whose toughness and physicality jumped out during the week of the Senior Bowl and on the 2014 Pittsburgh tape. He's a throwback Y or blocking tight end that gets his hands inside, presses defenders off his frame and flashes the ability to move his assignment off the ball. He also gets into position and anchors well enough in pass protection. While he's not a big-play threat, he has the frame, wide catching radius and big hands to develop into a reliable target underneath.

What he brings: Alexander is a rangy outside linebacker who started 32 games at Oregon State and has the potential to make an immediate impact on special teams, but he's undersized and has had problems staying healthy.

What he brings: O'Shaughnessy has average size and good top-end speed with an average hand span for an F (or receiving) tight end. He's an above-average route runner who shows good suddenness at the top of his stem and the ability to locate seams in zone looks. He flashes the ability to make tough catches over the middle, but he doesn't aggressively snatch the ball out of the air and he has shorter arms. He's a better receiver than blocker.

What he brings: Artis-Payne has adequate size and is a fluid runner with excellent instincts and a quick short-area burst. However, he has average lateral agility and lacks an extra gear to run away from pursuit. While he doesn't have a ton of production in the passing game, he did show some upside at the Senior Bowl, where he caught the ball well.

What he brings: Mumphery has the toughness over the middle and the ability to produce after the catch to contribute working out of the slot, but he struggles to separate from underneath man coverage at times. Although he shows adequate ball skills on tape, he didn't play the ball nearly as well the week of the East-West Shrine game.

What he brings: Myers is a relatively raw prospect who didn't play football until his junior year of high school and didn't have to play with sound technique to excel at the FCS level. He'll have to play with better leverage, improve his ability to pick up pressure packages in pass protection and improve his hand placement as a run-blocker to succeed at the NFL level. However, he has the long arms, big frame and enough foot speed to turn into a starter if a team is willing to take the time to develop him.

What he brings: Mount possesses a good combination of size, speed and initial quickness, in addition to above average upper-body strength. He has the potential to develop into an effective edge rusher, but he needs to get stronger against the run. He never started more than five games in a season.

What he brings: Wells lacks ideal size and will never be a strong take-on guy. He does have good instincts, which is impressive because he is legally blind in one eye. He is at his best in space, where he shows quality closing burst. Wells should have a chance to make an impact on special teams early in his career.

What he brings: Valles is a decent hand fighter who flashes the ability to get off blocks whether he's rushing the passer or defending the run. He's on the taller and leaner side with just adequate top-end speed and he didn't test well in agility drills. He also needs to improve as a tackler, as he slips off the ball carrier at times and he allows too much production after contact.

What he brings: He is one of the best interior pass-rushers in this draft class, with excellent initial quickness and good length to keep blockers off of his pads. He won't overpower any offensive linemen, so he needs to win with his quickness and savvy. He projects best as a 3-technique D-tackle in a 4-3 defense.

What he brings: Jarrett is a three-year starter with above-average instincts, who he has the potential to develop into a core special teams player. However, he has a below-average blend of height, weight and top-end speed, so he doesn't project as an every-down safety at the NFL level.

What he brings: Mitchel has adequate size and overall fluidity. He also flashes anticipation skills and does a nice job of locating the ball when in position. Mitchel must work on becoming more consistent in run support.

What he brings: Fabuluje is massive and has long arms, making it tough for pass-rushers to get around him. He has the potential to develop into a strong run-blocker. On the other hand, the weight is a blessing and a curse, as he's had a hard time keeping it down in the past and he doesn't move well on tape. He's not a consistent finisher at this point either.

What he brings: Clay is at his best with the ball in his hands and he excels as a returner on special teams, where he has four returns for touchdowns in his career. As a receiver he lacks ideal size, needs refining as a route runner and has some inconsistencies with his hands.

What he brings: Thompson has quality size (6-5, 324) and length (35-inch arms) for the position. He is light on his feet and shows above-average lateral agility as a left tackle prospect. However, he must continue to develop his strength at the point of attack and learn to play with more consistent pad level. In addition, we would like to see him play with more aggression and do a better job of finishing with better consistency.

What he brings: Davis is a team captain who has an above-average blend of height, weight, length and top-end speed. It's also worth noting that poor pass protection and instability at the quarterback position played a role in his lack of ideal production last season. However, he doesn't change directions as well as expected based on his agility testing, and he occasionally loses his footing making crisp cuts at the top of his stem. He's also a long-strider who is faster than quick and doesn't show the ability to regularly separate underneath.
What he brings: Spencer has quality size and adequate top-end speed. He needs to continue to add polish as a route runner and become more consistent in contested situations finishing.

What he brings: Steward comes with some durability issues but has a chance to develop into a quality backup. He has adequate instincts and very good overall range. He also tackles with natural leverage and flashes explosive power. Steward was one of the better special-teams players we've studied this year. The Georgia tape in which he notched four tackles on the punt coverage unit stood out.

What he brings: He's a very good athlete who can stick with most receivers, but his technique in coverage needs some polish and he can have trouble against bigger receivers on contested catches because of his lack of ideal size.

What he brings: Silberman is a Florida transfer who lined up at right tackle but will likely have to kick inside because he doesn't have the length to protect the edge at the NFL level. While he moves well, he has to get stronger as a run blocker and improve his ability to anchor in pass pro.

What he brings: Shepherd comes with some tightness in off-man coverage but possesses fast eyes and is always aware in coverage. He also flashes the ability to anticipate and jump routes and has one of the best sets of ball skills we've evaluated in the 2015 cornerback class.

What he brings: Philon is an undersized (6-1, 298) one-gap defender. He flashes explosive twitch on the inside and is at his best when he can win with initial quickness to create penetration and disruption in the backfield. However, he lacks ideal point-of-attack skills and if he doesn't win initially with quickness, he can quickly be erased from the play. Philon also brings good upside as a pass-rusher with his lateral quickness, active hands and a good closing burst.

What he brings: Dubose comes with some character issues, and scouts have expressed concerns about his commitment at times. However, he has exceptional size (6-4, 280) and length as a prototypical 5-technique. He has above-average upper body power and heavy hands at the point of attack as a run defender. Dubose isn't a dynamic pass-rusher, but he flashes the ability to collapse the pocket with a bull rush.

What he brings: The grandson of legendary golfer Jack Nicklaus, O'Leary is a savvy route runner and natural pass-catcher. He plays with a chip on his shoulder, consistently blocking to the echo of the whistle and showing the willingness to do the dirty work over the middle as a receiver. He doesn't have great upside, though, and isn't a big-play threat. He has a maxed-out frame with short arms and though he plays faster on tape, his timed top-end speed is alarming.
What he brings: Johnson lacks ideal size but brings a lot of versatility. He lines up at multiple spots and has quality receiving skills. Johnson reminds us a little of Buffalo Bills TE Charles Clay.

What he brings Evans has exceptional size and length and brings above-average range. He has some tightness in off man coverage and is at his best in press, where he can utilize his length to turn and run with receivers. Evans also has the size to compete with bigger receivers in contested situations.

What he brings: Smith's production dipped as a senior because of a poor supporting cast. While he needs to continue to get stronger and become more consistent with his angles as a run defender, Smith shows quality instincts and playmaking ability. He does a nice a job of maintaining leverage in coverage and flashes the anticipation and quality ball skills to manufacture turnovers.

What he brings: Telfer has excellent measureables and brings good value as an inline blocker. While he isn't a dynamic threat in the passing game, he is tough and willing to do the dirty work the position requires, including working the middle of the field.

What he brings: A team captain in 2014, Walton has a high center of gravity and he's not an ideal 3-4 nose tackle candidate, but he keeps his pads down for the most part and he's tough to move off the ball with one blocker when he plays with sound technique. He's also a better pass-rusher than you'd expect for a player with average initial quickness and marginal closing speed -- the reason is he's an above-average hand fighter with the heavy hands to keep blockers off his frame and even knock blockers off balance.

What he brings: Diggs lacks ideal size (5-9, 196), which can hurt him in contested situations against bigger wide receivers at times. However, he is a scrappy player who has a knack for playing bigger than his measurables indicate. Diggs shows quality movement skills and flashes the anticipation to jump and break on routes. He also holds up well for his size defending the run.

What he brings: Sasser has good size, a wide catching radius and displays excellent body control adjusting to throws outside of his frame. While he lacks ideal quickness to consistently create separation, Sasser has the size and strength to create late separation and win in contested situations.

What he brings: The son of John Derby and nephew of Glenn Derby -- both former NFL players -- has taken a unique path. He started off playing quarterback at Iowa but he was moved to linebacker following an arrest for public intoxication that led to a two-game suspension his redshirt freshman year. He transferred to Coffeyville Community in 2012 and then walked on at Arkansas in 2013, playing quarterback both seasons. He then moved to tight end as a senior, so he's obviously raw. However, he plays with more of an edge than you'd expect from a former quarterback, he's willing to do the dirty work over the middle and he's fast enough to make plays down the seam.

What he brings: Kilgo has quality size and natural power. He must learn to play with more consistent pad level and lacks ideal range, but he has strong point-of-attack skills when playing with leverage.

What he brings: At 6-6 and 238 pounds, Waller has exceptional size and length to create mismatches down the field in one-on-one contested situations. Coming from the triple-option scheme, he will need time developing the full route tree and has the size to potentially transition to a tight end position at the next level.

What he brings: Robinson is built low to the ground, making it tough for defenders to track him behind his blocks and knock him to the ground when they fail to wrap and drive. He doesn't have the top-end speed to run away from pursuit but he's quicker than fast and there is a noticeable burst when he accelerates on tape. One area of concern is third down, as he is a smaller target and limited route runner with inconsistent ball skills.

What he brings: Ripkowski is an effective positional blocker in the run game and flashes the ability to anchor in pass pro, but it's troubling that he lost 17 pounds between weighing in at the East-West Shrine game and his pro day. In addition, he finished his college career with a total of 14 touches, so he's a fairly one-dimensional blocker at this point.

What he brings: Herrera covers more ground against the run than inside linebackers with similar timed speed because of his ability to diagnose quickly, sound pursuit angles and above-average effort. He flashes the ability to stack and shed in a phone booth, but he's inconsistent in this area and takes too long to get off some blocks. He may also be a two-down linebacker at the NFL level. He doesn't show great fluidity in coverage, and he tends to grab when assignments start to separate.

What he brings: Gallik is a team captain and three-year starter who has a nasty disposition and blocks to the echo of the whistle. He generates above-average initial surge as a run-blocker and he flashes the ability to stay in front of his defenders once he locks on in pass protection. However, he lunges and gets caught off balance too much. And while he performed well during agility tests at that combine, it doesn't show up on tape where he struggles when he is forced to change directions quickly.

What he brings: Gwacham is an intriguing prospect considering he moved from wide receiver to defensive end as a senior. He's lean and he needs to get stronger against the run. He also needs to develop his arsenal of moves and improve as a hand fighter rushing the passer, but he's got enough quickness and closing speed to contribute as a situational pass-rusher early on. It's also worth noting that he has extensive special-teams experience and he can help out there as he develops as a defender.
What he brings: Ringo has above-average measureables and very good upside. He is raw but has an excellent combination of quickness, strength and agility to work with.

What he brings: Cliett is a 2014 team captain who started 27 games over the past three seasons. He's listed at linebacker but he's vastly undersized for the position and will likely have to move to safety. The good news is he played safety in high school and has the top-end speed to make the transition, plus he has the potential to develop into a core special teams player and contribute in that area as he grows into a defensive role.

What he brings: Chickillo has good size and quality point-of-attack skills against the run. He also has the versatility to reduce inside in pass rushing situations. We also love the motor and edge Chickillo plays with.

What he brings: Backman has good strength and quality point of attack skills as an inline blocker. He lacks ideal length and athleticism as a pass catcher but is a reliable short-to-intermediate target.

What he brings: Sokoli caught our eye at the Medal of Honor Bowl. He has above-average measureables with natural power and strong point-of-attack skills. He also has active hands to win early as a pass-rusher.

What he brings: Wichmann is a four-year starter who has to get stronger at the point and improve his power base as a run blocker, but he has the height, weight and length to provide depth early and eventually develop into a starting guard.

What he brings: Covington is an above-average run-stopper even though he weighs just 289 pounds. His short-area quickness, power and low center of gravity make him tough to handle one-on-one. He has the heavy hands, burst and motor to develop into an effective interior pass-rusher. He's also versatile enough to play 4-3 defensive tackle or 3-4 defensive end. The biggest reason he didn't grade out as an earlier pick outside of his weight is the medical: He dislocated his knee early in the 2014 season, and though he ended up starting seven games he eventually underwent season-ending surgery.

What he brings: Nunez-Roches' perseverance is noteworthy, as he worked part-time jobs to help his mother make ends meet in high school and bounced back from a 2013 season-ending knee injury to turn in his most productive season in 2014. That determination translates to his tape, as he plays with a chip on his shoulder and his motor is a notch below elite. He is at his best using his initial burst and quick hands to shoot gaps and disrupt plays in the backfield. He doesn't close or change directions well enough to regularly finish as a pass-rusher, but flashes the ability to move the quarterback off his spot.

What he brings: Morris is raw, must improve his technique and needs to show more consistency with his pad level. However, he has an adequate combination of length and athleticism to work with as a developmental prospect.

What he brings: Pullard has above-average instincts and overall range as a run defender. In addition, he shows strong awareness in coverage and does a nice job of marking targets in his territory in underneath zone coverage. Pullard is a reliable tackler but must continue to get stronger and improve his take-on skills. He will add initial depth as a middle or weakside linebacker and has the skill set to potentially develop into a starter down the road.

What he brings: Sterling is a big receiver with a wide catching radius and the frame to compete for 50-50 balls, but he doesn't have the top-end speed to regularly take the top off the coverage or threaten after the catch at the NFL level.

What he brings: Debose lacks ideal size and strength and needs polish as a route runner. He also has inconsistent ball skills and needs to show better focus at times. However, Debose is dangerous with the ball in his hands, as he has excellent top-end speed to exploit a crease. Debose will need to make a big impact on special teams as a returner to stick in the league.
What he brings: Reiter is a three-year starter who moves well, but he has shorter arms, and he's not an overpowering run blocker.

What he brings: Simon has had a hard time keeping his weight down, missed the final five games of the 2014 season with a knee injury and suffered a serious knee injury, so there are concerns about his long-term durability. In addition, academic issues prevented him from playing his first two seasons out of high school, and he will be a 25-year-old rookie. He's still an intriguing prospect, though, because he has the size, length and upper-body strength to develop into an effective 3-4 nose tackle.

What he brings: The son of former Texas All-American and Eagles linebacker Britt Hager is a sideline-to-sideline inside linebacker with the closing speed to chase backs down on a straight line and the range to get to depth in a Tampa 2 scheme. The downside is he's light with shorter arms, so he gets engulfed when teams run at him. Although he's quick on a straight line, he's got tighter hips, so he's not as effective matching in man as he is dropping into zone.

What he brings: Rodgers caught our eye at the NFLPA Bowl in January. He has adequate size and length. He doesn't have ideal lateral agility and needs to continue to get stronger to anchor down against power moves.

What he brings: Hart is a two-year starter at right tackle who lined up at guard earlier in his career and projects better at guard, considering his below-average lateral agility and inability to stay in front of NFL pass-rushers in pass protection. He rarely takes false steps, and he has the wide body to wall off defensive tackles, plus he's big and strong enough to anchor against bull rushers. It's important that he improve his hand placement and increase is upper-body strength if he is to play a substantial role, though.

What he brings: Ifedi has a thick frame with natural power in his upper body. He has strong point-of-attack skills defending the run, and though he has some developing to do as a pass-rusher, he possesses adequate quickness and active hands.

What he brings: As a run-blocker, Shepherd rarely takes false steps, and he drives his legs once in position. He also takes sound angles and flashes the ability to cut off linebackers at the second level, despite his limited range. On the downside, his hand placement is inconsistent, and he slips off blocks because of that. He's also a better run-blocker than pass-blocker. He struggles with speed off the edge and struggles to counter when defenders cross his face, which is why he is one of many offensive tackles in this class that fits better at guard in the NFL.

What he brings: There is a lot to like about Koyack's skill set. He has the frame, length and big hands to make contested catches underneath and compete for 50-50 balls downfield. He is fast enough and big enough to make plays down the seam and pick up some yards after the catch. Although he isn't a mauler, he's an adequate positional blocker. On the downside, he doesn't excel in any one area, and there's plenty of room for improvement when it comes to his route running.

What he brings: Murphy lacks prototypical size for a running back (5-foot-8, 193 pounds) but brings excellent versatility, both in the passing game and on special teams as a returner. His best quality is his quickness and body control to maintain balance when making a cut at top-gear with the ball in his hands.

What he brings: Brown possesses a lot of raw athleticism and has one of the better sets of ball skills of any receiver we've studied in this class. He also brings added value as a contributor on special teams, which can buy him time on a roster as he continues to hone his craft as a route runner early in his career.

What he brings: Lewis has an above-average combination of size (6-foot-4, 214 pounds) and strength to go along with adequate top-end speed. Although he needs to add polish with his routes and do a better job of finishing at the top of his stem, he does flash the ability to create late separation and win in one-on-one contested battles.

What he brings: Hilliard is a between-the-tackles runner who has exceptional size, power and balance to churn out yards after contact. Although he improved his 40-yard dash time at his pro day from the combine, he lacks the top-end speed to run away from pursuit and won't make many defenders miss in a confined area.

What he brings: Nzeocha is a German native and former rugby player who lacks ideal experience and instincts at this point. However, he is an above-average athlete who holds up well in space and shows quality range, which buys him time to contribute on special teams early in his career.

What he brings: Mihalik is on the taller side, so he has problems staying low at times, and he doesn't offer much as a pass-rusher. But he's got the length, toughness and strength to set the edge against the run. He fits best at defensive end in a base 3-4 defense.

What he brings: Alford is a pint-sized receiver (5-foot-9, 180 pounds) who possesses world-class speed. He lacks ideal strength as a route runner and suffered from some focus drops this past season. Alford's best attribute might come as a returner on special teams, where he has the ability to take the distance if he catches a seam.

What he brings: No FBS player intercepted more passes last year than Holliman, who has the instincts and ball skills to develop into a ball hawk at the next level. However, he lacks the fluidity to regularly match up with slot receivers in man and the second gear to regularly play center field. Plus, he is a marginal run defender, and multiple NFL scouts have indicated concerns about his work ethic.

What he brings: Robinson has the mass and length teams covet at offensive tackle. He is a powerful run-blocker and an effective pass-blocker when he plays with sound technique, but his tape is frustrating to watch because of the inconsistencies. The two biggest concerns are his pad level -- he frequently plays too high -- and inconsistent hand placement. There are also concerns about his work ethic, inconsistent killer instinct and ability to control his weight.

What he brings: The biggest concern with him relates to his durability, as he's recovering from a torn ACL suffered in December. He possesses the agility and explosive burst to hold up in man coverage on the outside or move inside to nickel corner. His football instincts are very good.

What he brings: McDonald has excellent size, length and overall range. He has some tightness in off-man coverage and lacks ideal instincts at this point. However, McDonald fits as press cornerback, where he can use his length to disrupt receivers at the line of scrimmage and has the size to match up with bigger receivers in contested situations.

What he brings: Gibson is a work in progress whose footwork, hand placement and pad level all need to get better if he is to play a substantial role in the NFL. On the other hand, there's no questioning his potential, as he has everything teams are looking for in a left tackle prospect, in terms of natural ability. He has a quick first step, changes directions well, has excellent arm length and has bulked up to 312 pounds.

What he brings: Brown, at 6-foot-8 and 355 pounds, is massive. He engulfs defensive tackles and flashes the ability to drive them off the ball in the run game, plus his rare arm length and wide frame make it tough to get around him in pass protection. The problem is he started just 11 games over the past two seasons, and he didn't play football until his junior year of high school. He lunges and ends up on the ground too much at this point. In addition, his weight is a blessing and a curse. His ability to control it and stay in shape will be crucial to his success.

What he brings: At 6 feet tall and 210 pounds, McBride is a smooth athlete who transitions well getting out of the stem to create separation. He also has the speed to threaten the vertical seams. His best attribute is his ball skills, as he consistently catches the ball away from his frame and flashes excellent body control.

What he brings: Swaim is a developmental prospect who has the frame, length, leaping ability and top-end speed to develop into a productive receiver, but he's a JUCO transfer who caught a total of 13 passes in his two seasons at Texas. He'll also have to fill out that frame to develop into an in-line blocker at the NFL level. The good news is he can contribute on special teams as he develops as a tight end.

What he brings: Roberts needs some fine-tuning with his technique and awareness, but he has a lot of raw athleticism. Roberts possesses quick feet, fluidity and an explosive closing burst that provide him with a lot of developmental upside.

What he brings: King didn't crack the starting lineup until his senior year, plus he's got smaller hands, and he failed to record an interception. But he's got some upside, thanks to his size and top-end speed. He can also contribute on special teams.

Goff is an early-entry prospect, but he did start 37 games at Cal, taking the program from 1-11 in 2013 to 8-5 in 2015. In his final two seasons completed 63.8 percent of his throws with 78 TDs compared to 20 INTs (3.9-1 ratio). Goff has first-round physical tools, as well as high-level football intelligence and work ethic, which is why he might be the top QB selected in 2016. But in order to sustain success in the NFL, Goff must improve his consistency with lower-body mechanics (which will lead to better ball placement) and continue to add bulk his frame. -April 1, 2016 What he brings: Goff is an experienced three-year starter who is one of the most natural passers in this class. He has excellent pocket presence and feels pressure naturally to buy time while going through progressions. Goff shows accuracy and touch with the ability to deliver from an uneven platform. He has added weight and that eases concerns about his durability. He might need time adjusting to an NFL playbook coming from a wide-open system. He is one of the top two quarterbacks in this class and has the tools and acumen to develop into an above-average starter.
How he fits: Goff is more NFL-ready than Carson Wentz with more starts and experience against a higher level of competition, which likely factored into the Rams' decision. Coming from Cal's "Bear Raid" spread system, Goff will need time adapting and learning an NFL playbook. The good news for Goff is that the Rams have an excellent defense and a Pro Bowl RB in Todd Gurley they can lean on while Goff develops in the early going. -- Kevin Weidl

In 2014, Wentz led the Bison to a fourth-straight FCS Championship while throwing for 3,111 yards and 25 TDs. In 2015, he broke his right wrist in Game 7 and was sidelined for eight games (12 weeks) before returning for the FCS National Championship, in which he led the Bison to its fifth-straight title (37-10 over Jacksonville State). Wentz only started 23 games at the FCS level, but he earned a 20-3 record. There's no questioning his football intelligence, maturity and leadership skills. Wentz projects as a first-round pick and could be the first QB selected in 2016. --February 1, 2016. What he brings: One of the top two quarterbacks in this class, Wentz is blessed with a strong combination of size and athleticism. He has very good arm strength to make all the necessary throws. He displays quality accuracy at all three levels. There are some concerns about his lack of experience and making the jump from the FCS level. However, Wentz has the tools, football intelligence, maturity and leadership skills to develop into a quality starting QB in the NFL.
How he fits: Wentz comes with an excellent physical skill set and overall makeup, but he has just 23 career starts and will be making a significant jump coming from the FCS level to the NFL. Similar to Goff, Wentz goes to an ideal situation -- assuming the Sam Bradford situation works itself out -- where he can have the luxury of being developed the proper way by sitting and learning from head coach Doug Peterson, who has been an excellent mentor at the position. -- Kevin Weidl

Bosa dominated the highest level of college football for most of his three seasons at Ohio State. His sack production dipped in 2015 (8.5 sacks versus 13.5 in '14), while being double-or-triple teamed nearly every snap. But he finished his 41-game career with 50.5 TFLs, 26 sacks and 5 FFs, while notching a Power-5 best 101 total pressures the last two seasons. Bosa lacks elite speed off the edge (verified by 4.86 40 at Combine) but the rest of his physical traits range from good to elite, and he shows the relentlessness and instincts shared by most top-level NFL pass rushers. -April 5, 2016 What he brings: He's the best edge defender and arguably one of the top two prospects in this class. Bosa displays heavy and active hands and possesses excellent core strength, along with the instincts to find the ball and finish plays as a run stopper. While he doesn't have elite quickness or bend, he is a relentless pass rusher who brings strong speed-to-power ability and the versatility to kick inside and cause disruption. He brings a great motor and approach to the game and will instantly upgrade a defensive front.
How he fits: We felt Bosa's best fit was as a DE in a base 4-3 scheme, but he has the size, power and versatility to line up in multiple spots along their 3-4 scheme. His best scenario may be to continue to try and bulk to line up at the 5-technique where he can help improve a 27th-ranked rush defense and provide some pass rush with his power and hands. -- Kevin Weidl

Elliott burst onto the national scene during Ohio State's national championship run during the 2014 season, and in two seasons, he racked up 3,699 yards and 41 touchdowns on 562 carries (6.6 ypc), while also catching 55 passes. In addition to his well-rounded skills in the run game, Elliott shows natural pass-catching ability, and he brings elite toughness to the field as a blocker. Elliott is the top running back prospect in the 2016 class and he projects as a top-15 pick. --March 8, 2016 What he brings: Elliott is a highly competitive runner with an excellent combination of agility, power and top-end speed for a bigger back. He also shows natural pass-catching ability, and he brings elite toughness to the field as a blocker. Elliott is the best running back in the class, and while he's not as dynamic of a runner as Adrian Peterson or Todd Gurley, his well-rounded skill set makes him the rare RB prospect who's actually worth a first-round pick. -- Kevin Weidl
How he fits: This may not appear to be a pressing need considering the Cowboys finished fifth in yards per rush last year, but Elliott has the vision, power and speed to immediately leapfrog Darren McFadden and Alfred Morris to take over as the primary ball carrier. He should also become quarterback Tony Romo's best friend as he catches the ball well and he's an effective pass-blocker. -- Steve Muench

Ramsey is an elite athlete who also competed on FSU's track team (2015 ACC Indoor Long Jump Champion 25 feet, 2.75"). Ramsey has exceptional length and rare versatility line up any where in the secondary. Biggest knock right now is his lack of elite ball skills. Ramsey also comes with outstanding makeup. Raised in a supportive and disciplined 2-parent home. Father Lamont is a fire fighter in Nashville. Highly competitive individual that loves the game and with excellent leadership and preparation habits. Team captain. Ramsey is a top-5 player in this class with All-Pro potential. April 3, 2016 What he brings: An explosive athlete with the rare versatility to line up in multiple spots in the secondary, Ramsey has exceptionally long arms and the most natural movement skills of any defensive back in this class. He also plays with a physical edge in run support. Minor concerns include inconsistent ball skills and the fact that he does not always finish when provided the opportunity. Still, whether he lines up at cornerback or safety, he's the top defensive back in this class and will serve as an instant upgrade in the secondary.
How he fits: Ramsey is an ideal fit within Jacksonville's press-zone scheme, which should enable them to keep at cornerback if they wish. He also brings excellent versatility to provide defensive coordinator Todd Walsh a weapon to be a matchup in multiple rolls in the back end. Ramsey, along with the free-agent signing of Prince Amukamara, should instantly help improve the Jaguars' pass defense, which was 29th in the NFL last season. -- Kevin Weidl

Stanley is a three-year starter who didn't test as well at the Combine as we had expected but he's one of the top three offensive tackles in this class when you throw on the tape. He's an outstanding pass blocker with a prototypical frame and he projects best at left tackle where has the ability to compete for a starting role as a rookie. That said, it's worth noting that he's a versatile player who could play on the right side as he played right tackle in 2013 before moving to left tackle for his last two seasons at Notre Dame. --April 5, 2016 What he brings: A left tackle prospect with three years of starting experience and quality awareness, Stanley excels in pass protection with natural feet, good agility and the length to keep edge rushers at bay. At this point, he's more of a positional run-blocker who will need to continue to get stronger and play with more aggression in this area. The second-best offensive tackle in this class, Stanley should be ready to step into a starting role from day one. -- Kevin Weidl
How he fits: We had Ole Miss offensive tackle Laremy Tunsil ranked ahead of Stanley, but this is an excellent pick nonetheless. The Ravens need an upgrade at left offensive tackle, where Eugene Monroe has missed 15 games over the past two seasons. Stanley isn't an elite run-blocker but he's effective enough to help improve a ground game that finished 26th in the league last year, and he's an outstanding pass-blocker. -- Steve Muench

Buckner's ceiling is a notch below former teammate and 2014 first-round pick Arik Armstead (49ers) but he has similar measureables and was a more consistent player during his career at Oregon. Buckner had just 7.5 sacks during his first three seasons but he racked up 10.5 sacks in 2016. He played in all 54 games during his four-year career and totaled 30 TFLs as a fulltime starter the last two (2014-15). Buckner has been durable and productive, and his versatility is appealing for teams that like to be multiple on defense. Buckner is a top-10 prospect. -March 22, 2016 What he brings: Buckner is a top-five prospect with outstanding measurables, raw power and above-average athleticism. He's a long-levered run defender who has the ability to create penetration and hold the point of attack. He needs some refining as a pass rusher and has to learn to play with lower pad level, but Buckner has the quickness, heavy hands and speed-to-power capability to add value getting after the QB. The bottom line? He is a durable and productive defender, whose versatility will allow him to play multiple spots along the D-line.
How he fits: The 49ers are still looking to replenish the talent along the front seven and Buckner fits the mold. He needs to continue to get stronger but he has the ideal frame to fit as 5-technique. Buckner will instantly be an upgrade for their 29th-ranked rush defense and provides upside as a pass-rusher, if he gets the proper coaching. -- Kevin Weidl

Conklin was a former walk-on who was not highly recruited out of high school. Started 38 out of 39 career games over the past 3 seasons. He has ideal length (35-inch arms), who is a powerful run blocker that plays with a nasty disposition to quickly compete for a starting spot at right tackle. He tested extremely well at the combine including a 5.00 in the 40-yard dash while his jump and agility testing were all above-average as well. Conklin is the third best offensive tackle in the 2016 class who should come off board within the top-20 picks of the first round. --April 8, 2016 What he brings: Conklin is a former walk-on who plays with a chip on his shoulder. A powerful run-blocker, he has good inline power and is constantly working to finish blocks. He is not an elite athlete, but he has ideal length and enough athleticism to keep blockers at bay when his technique is sound. Conklin played left tackle in college, but he projects as a right tackle in the NFL. He has the physicality and toughness that is coveted at the position. -- Kevin Weidl
How he fits: Most felt that Titans first-year general manager Jon Robinson would target an offensive tackle had he not traded out of the first pick, considering Tennessee surrendered a league-high 54 sacks last year. Now he trades back into the top 10 to get one of the top three tackles in this draft. We projected Conklin as a right tackle but he tested better than expected and he could stay at left tackle, which would allow Taylor Lewan to shift over to the right side. -- Steve Muench

Floyd is a long-levered versatile LB with experience playing in multiple spots along the front 7. His sack production dropped in 2015 (4.5 sacks) but Floyd spent far more time working as an off the ball LB where he showcased his ability to play in space. He needs to continue to improve his strength and consistency versus the run, but Floyd has a unique skill set with explosive athleticism (39.5 VJ, 10-7 BJ). Unofficial 4.60 forty at combine (pulled hamstring on 1st run) and did not fully participate at pro day due to an illness. Floyd projects as a mid 1st round selection. April 7, 2016 What he brings: Floyd is arguably the most versatile edge defender in this class who has an outstanding combination of length and athleticism. He displays natural instincts as a pass-rusher with quality first-step quickness and flexibility to gain the edge while also flashing an effective inside changeup move. Though his sack production dipped in 2015, he played as more of an off linebacker where he showcased his range as a space player in coverage. He will bring immediate help on third downs and should quickly push for a starting job.
How he fits: After helping find help at the inside linebacker position by signing Jerrell Freeman and Danny Trevathan in free agency, the Bears add the most versatile edge rusher in this class for defensive coordinator Vic Fangio's 3-4 defense. Floyd will add another pass-rushing option across from OLB Pernell McPhee, while also providing quality athleticism and range as a space player. -- Kevin Weidl

Apple played in all 28 games (27 starts) during his two seasons at Ohio State, notching 18 PBUs and 4 INTs. Apple has an outstanding size-speed combination; his 4.40 40-yard dash is the 4th-fastest by a DB 6-1 or taller at the NFL Combine since 2006. While he's strong in run support, Apple will get pushed around at times by bigger WRs when in coverage and his ball skills are a work in progress. If utilized and coached properly, Apple can develop into a good starter in the NFL. He grades out as an early 2nd round prospect that could be drafted in Round 1 due to positional value. -April 5, 2016 What he brings: Apple's 4.40 40-yard dash is the fourth-fastest by a defensive back 6-foot1 or taller at the NFL scouting combine since 2006. He's not only an athlete, though. He does an above-average job of reading routes in man coverage and reading quarterbacks' eyes in zone coverage on tape. He has to get stronger and improve his ability to match up with bigger receivers, but he has the frame to bulk up and develop into an excellent press corner.
How he fits: The Giants didn't have a pressing need at corner considering they signed Janoris Jenkins in free agency and Dominique Rodgers-Cromartie went to the Pro Bowl last year. Apple is a reach this early, but he has the frame, top-end speed and instincts to develop into an effective starter in defensive coordinator Steve Spagnuolo's scheme and he should provide quality depth early on. -- Steve Muench

Vernon Hargreaves (HAR-graves) is a coaches son, who comes with excellent football make-up. (His father Vernon II is currently the LB coach for Arkansas.) He has outstanding instincts and possesses the most natural movement skills in the this year's CB class. He is undersized and can be susceptible to an occasional big play down the field. But he has the aggressiveness and confidence to overcome his lack of ideal measureables, which will allow him to develop into a quality starting CB on the outside. He projects as an early first round selection. --March 23, 2016 What he brings: Hargreaves is an undersized cornerback who is one of the most instinctive and natural man coverage cornerbacks in this class. He shows smooth and balanced movement skills to mirror receivers, and he displays excellent anticipation and ball awareness. On the flip side, he lacks ideal measurables and doesn't have elite top-end speed, which brings up some concerns about his downfield range against elite receivers at the next level. Overall, he has the football intelligence, the movement skills and the willingness in run support to develop into a quality starting cornerback outside the hashes or become one of the better nickelbacks in the NFL.
How he fits: First-year defensive coordinator Mike Smith's heavy zone scheme is a good fit for Hargreaves. This scheme will allow him to minimize the downfield range concerns and allow him to line up outside the hashes, while also letting him maximize his playmaking anticipation and ball skills to manufacture turnovers. Hargreaves provides the versatility to bump inside to the slot where he could ultimately end up and be most effective as a player. -- Kevin Weidl

Rankins played four seasons and started his final two (2014-15), racking up 25.5 TFLs and 14 sacks. He is an undersized defensive tackle with very good quickness (confirmed with 4.59 short shuttle) and lower-body explosiveness (34.5-inch vertical jump). He played multiple spots along Louisville's front and can potentially do the same in the NFL, although we believe his best fit is as a 4-3 nose tackle. He's a better run defender than pass rusher, but he's capable of developing into an every-down player. Rankins grades out as a first-round prospect. --March 9, 2016 What he brings: One of the more disruptive interior defenders in this class, Rankins is an undersized defensive tackle with very good quickness and lower-body explosiveness. He played multiple spots along Louisville's front and can potentially do the same in the NFL, although his best fit is as a 4-3 nose tackle. Rankins is a better run defender than pass-rusher at this point, but he's capable of developing into an every-down player. -- Kevin Weidl
How he fits: It should come as no surprise that the Saints went defense with their top pick considering they finished dead last in points allowed per game in addition to 31st in rushing, passing and total defense last year. Rankins is a plug-and-play starter who should make an immediate impact both as a pass-rusher and run defender. -- Steve Muench

Tunsil started at LOT in all 26 games that he played at Ole Miss, but he missed time in all three seasons. A knee injury kept him out of the Rebels' 2013 bowl game. In the 2014 season, he missed two games with a partially torn biceps and the Peach Bowl with a dislocated ankle/broken leg. In 2015, he was suspended by the NCAA for seven games due to impermissible benefits and failing to be forthcoming with investigators. If comfortable with his durability and character issues, Tunsil is the clear-cut top offensive lineman in this draft. He has perennial Pro Bowl potential. --March 25, 2016 What he brings: Born to protect the quarterback, Tunsil is blessed with an outstanding combination of natural athleticism and length. He also has natural flexibility in his lower half to sink and anchor against power moves, displaying quality awareness in pass protection. Durability is a bit of concern, as Tunsil missed time because of injury in his first two seasons at Ole Miss. While he isn't a road-grading run-blocker, he has enough inline power and agility to cover up defenders and sustain blocks. One of the elite prospects in this class, Tunsil has the makings of a franchise left tackle for the next decade.
How he fits: This appears to be more as a value pick as it wasn't as big a need for Miami after signing Jermon Bushrod in free agency. However, left tackle Branden Albert turns 32 and Tunsil has the talent to quickly develop into a franchise left tackle if he is able to maintain his focus on and off the field. This pick makes sure they continue to help provide protection to enable the opportunity for QB Ryan Tannenhill to take more steps forward. -- Kevin Weidl

Joseph had started in all 42 career games before suffering non-contact torn ACL in his right knee during practice in early Oct. He is an interchangeable safety who brings a physical presence in run support and showed improved instincts and ball production (5 INTs) the 4 games he appeared in last year. He was also a two-time team captain who comes with excellent overall makeup and football character. Joseph is the most complete true safety in this class and assuming his medical checks on his knee are positive, he could very well be off the board within the top-40 picks. April 7, 2016 What he brings: Joseph is coming off a season-ending knee injury, but he's a difference-maker when he's healthy and is the most complete safety in this class. He's rangy, he showed much improved diagnostic skills in coverage last season and he's a ball hawk. He's also an outstanding run defender with above average stopping power even though he doesn't have great size. Finally, he was a two-time team captain at West Virginia.
How he fits: The Raiders signed Reggie Nelson to help replace Charles Woodson but they need a safety capable of starting opposite him, as a torn MCL limited Nate Allen to five games in 2015. Joseph is the top safety on our board so he's a good value in addition to filling a need. The Raiders finished 13th in interceptions last year and Joseph has the potential to be a playmaker. -- Steve Muench

Coleman is a gamebreaker at wide receiver and as a return specialist. He has average size and outstanding speed (verified by 4.38 at Pro Day), but he's a raw route runner with a concerning career drop percentage (6.6%). In 2015, Coleman caught 74 passes for 1,363 yards (18.4) and 20 TDs.
