However, Prescott has a strong tool box to work with in terms of size, arm strength and mobility. He projects as a mid-round pick. March 8, 2016 What he brings: Prescott improved his accuracy and ability to make plays within the pocket during his time at Mississippi State. Though he was arrested on a DUI charge in March, he had shown strong leadership and football makeup before the arrest. Prescott has to continue to work on his footwork, release and anticipation, but he has the frame, pocket mobility and enough arm strength to develop into an effective backup and spot starter. He's also a threat to take off and run.
How he fits: Tony Romo turns 36 in April, broke his left collarbone twice in 2015 and played in just two full games. He hasn't played in all 16 games since 2012. Prescott is a developmental prospect but he has enough raw talent to push Kellen Moore for the backup job and potentially develop into an effective starter under the tutelage of Jason Garrett. -- Steve Muench

A 2015 team captain Booker is a junior college transfer who is one of just two Utah players to record back-to-back 1,000-yard rushing seasons plus he caught 80 passes in his two seasons with the Utes despite tearing his meniscus late in the 2015 season. He has the potential to develop into an effective third down back but he's coming off a season-ending knee injury that prevented him from running at the Combine as well as his pro day, he's put the ball in the ground too much and he's on the older side as he turns 24 before the start of the season. April 8, 2016 What he brings: Booker is a highly competitive and determined runner who brings versatility in the passing game. He has adequate vision and patience as a runner, but he doesn't have elite elusiveness or power as a runner. He is shifty enough and runs with good pad level, however, to churn out yards after contact. Booker comes with durability concerns after a season-ending knee injury last year and also has some ball security issues. But he could develop into a change-of-pace back for a team. -- Kevin Weidl
How he fits: Denver signed C.J. Anderson to a four-year deal and brought Ronnie Hillman back, but Hillman's deal is only through 2016 and Denver finished 17th in rushing yards per game last year. A knee injury likely caused Booker to drop, but we gave him a third-round grade based on his tape. He should contribute on third down early in his career and he has the potential to develop into a starter for the Broncos down the road. -- Steve Muench

Lowry is a three-year starter who brings a blue-collar work ethic to the table. A two-down space eater, he has quality size and strength to anchor against the run. Lowry projects as a potential late-round selection for a team looking to add size and depth to its front line. --March 4, 2016 What he brings: A three-year starter, Lowry has quality measureables but shorter arms for his size. He is at his best as a run defender, but has underrated athleticism to work with as a pass-rusher. He will fit well as a 5-technique within Green Bay's base 3-4 scheme. -- Kevin Weidl

Sharp is a four year starter that is coming off of highly productive 2015 campaign. He led the FBS in receptions with 111 and his 1,319 yards were 12th overall while adding five touchdowns. He has reliable ball skills despite smaller hands (8 3/8"). Sharp needs to continue to get stronger but he is polished route runner who is reliable enough to develop into a number three or four receiver at the next level. Vertical jump (33.5") is nearing red flag territory (32") for the position. He projects as mid-day three selection in the 2016 NFL draft. -- April 8, 2016 What he brings:Sharpe is a four-year starter who led the FBS in receptions in 2015 with 111. He is a smooth athlete with a long and lean frame. He displays very good polish as a route runner and also possesses solid body control when adjusting to throws and has reliable hands. He lacks ideal top-end speed, which puts limitations on his ability to stretch the field vertically. Sharpe has the chance to develop into a No. 3 or No. 4 possession receiver. -- Kevin Weidl

Sanchez is a fourth year junior that has three years of starting experience. While he isn't elite in any one area, Sanchez is an instinctive cover corner who has adequate size to go along with fluid movement skills.Sanchez also flashes as a playmaker and has quality career production with 28 PBUs and 15 INTs including 7 in 2015 (Tied for 5th in the FBS). Tested well at combine, but short-shuttle time at pro day (4.51) is well below the red flag thresh hold line for the position (4.35). He currently holds a fringe day two grade in the 2016 draft. April 8, 2016 What he brings: Sanchez, who intercepted seven passes last season, is an instinctive cover corner with above-average ball skills and good top-end speed. While he left school early, he's a redshirt junior and three-year starter. He has just adequate size and length, and he doesn't play as fast as his timed top-end speed on tape. He also needs to get stronger and improve his ability to match up with bigger receivers. -- Steve Muench

Blair is a four year starter who comes with some minor durability and character concerns early in his career. But sources have told us that Blair has matured the past few seasons and made strides in his approach to the game. On the field, he plays a violent game and has a strong combination of quickness, power and length. Significantly improved 40-yard dash and jumps at his pro-day. Blair has the ability to add depth as a versatile reserve up front and could potentially find a home inside as a 3-technique. He projects as an early day 3 pick. --April 8, 2016 What he brings: Blair possesses a nice combination of quickness, power and length. He plays with quality leverage and flashes a powerful upper body but lacks ideal size and will get engulfed by bigger linemen at times. He has adequate first-step quickness as a pass-rusher, displays heavy and active hands and flashes quality speed-to-power capabilities. Blair plays with a physical edge but doesn't have an ideal fit at the next level. He might end up being best suited to line up inside as an undersized three-technique, where he can use his initial quickness to his advantage. -- Kevin Weidl

Washington is a productive back who rushed for over 2,500 yards and caught 71 passes over the course of his last two seasons at Texas Tech. He has the natural ability to develop into an effective change-of-pace third-down back who could compete for a kickoff return role. However, he's a smaller back with durability concerns as he tore an ACL in 2011 and he put the ball on the ground too much last year. He projects as a late round pick as a result. April 3, 2016 What he brings: Washington runs bigger than his measurables indicate with quality balance and a lower center of gravity. However, he's a smaller back with durability concerns as he tore an ACL in 2011, and he put the ball on the ground too much last season. He has the natural ability to develop into an effective change-of-pace third-down back who could compete for a kickoff return role. -- Kevin Weidl

McGovern has starting experience a both tackle spots as well as offensive guard and he has the potential to develop into an effective center so there's a lot to like about his versatility. That said he projects better on the inside than he does at tackle.. His arm length raises concerns about his ability to protect the edge at the NFL level whereas he has the frame, quickness and toughness to develop into a starter on the inside. April 10, 2016 What he brings: McGovern has experience playing both tackle spots at Missouri but projects as a guard at the next level. Physically, he does not have an elite trait but he brings quality awareness and plays with an edge. McGovern is more of a positional blocker who is best fit for a zone-blocking scheme. He has the potential to become a versatile reserve and could potentially end up being a starter with the proper development. -- Kevin Weidl

Theus is a former walk-on who has four years of starting experience at the SEC level. He has adequate measureables and good overall awareness. However, he needs to continue to get stronger, refine his technique and play with more of finisher's mentality. The positive news is that Theus has steadily improved throughout his career. Senior Bowl participate that had some struggles against upper echelon competition. He projects as a developmental day three prospect who has the potential to add depth to an offensive line. -- April 8, 2016 What he brings: A former walk-on, Theus steadily improved over the course of his career. He has a good frame and length for an offensive tackle prospect. However, he needs to continue to improve his technique and get stronger at the point of attack. He's not a mauler, either, and you'd like to him play with more of an edge.

Jefferson took over as a full-time starter during his sophomore season in 2013, finishing with 45 total tackles, 7.5 TFL and three sacks. He got off to a fast start in 2014, but he suffered a torn right ACL versus West Virginia. He returned for his redshirt junior season in 2015, when he racked up 39 total tackles, 12.5 TFL and 6.5 sacks. Jefferson, who has three daughters, elected to leave early for this year's draft. He's a three-technique with quickness to penetrate and disrupt on occasion, but he lacks ideal strength for the position. Jefferson is a Day 3 prospect. -April 11, 2016 What he brings: Jefferson is a three-technique tackle with quickness to penetrate and disrupt on occasion, but he lacks ideal strength and will get engulfed if he doesn't win with initial quickness. He brings more upside as a pass-rusher than a run defender. Jefferson has some durability issues as well, but he has the chance to develop into a quality backup for a base four-man front. -- Kevin Weidl

Benenoch (ben-en-KNOCK) likely would have benefitted from returning to school based on the tape. As well as he moves in a straight line, his short shuttle time (5.11 seconds) raises a red flag. That said, he has the prototypical right-tackle frame, he plays hard and he has experience playing guard as well as tackle. Benenoch has the potential to provide depth at multiple positions early in his career. --March 6, 2016 What he brings: A versatile player with experience at tackle and guard, Benenoch gets good initial surge as a run blocker and he's tough to beat when his technique is sound in pass protection. He also flashes the nasty disposition that teams covet in their offensive linemen. That said, Benenoch hasn't realized his potential, as he needs to do a better job of sinking his hips and consistently shooting his hands inside. -- Steve Muench

Perkins played in all 39 games during three seasons at UCLA but durability is a concern given smaller frame and heavy workload (702 career offensive touches). He may never be a featured back because of his size/power limitations but Perkins can be a valuable contributor in a rotation and might contribute as a punt returner (despite one career return). He is shifty and creates yards on his own. He is a natural pass catcher, he protects the football, he's small but physical in pass pro, and he plays the game with great passion. Perkins could be an early Day 3 steal. -April 6, 2016 What he brings: Perkins is a highly competitive and instinctive runner who does a nice job setting up and utilizing blocks. He shows quick feet and is shifty enough to create yards on his own in a confined area. In addition, he brings quality value on third down, where he shows natural hands and takes pride with his pass protection. Perkins may never be a featured back due to his size and power limitations, but he has a chance to add quality depth as a rotational runner for a backfield. -- Kevin Weidl

Howard lost his father and two grandparents in a six-month span at age of 12. He transferred to Indiana after UAB lost its football program. In 2015 at Indiana, he rushed for 1,213 yards (6.2) and 9 TDs in just 9 games (after 2,468 rushing yards in two years at UAB). He lacks elite speed/agility and durability is a concern (missed four games in '15 with knee/ankle, and multiple injuries in high school). But he has the tools (size, power, vision, competitiveness) to develop into a bell-cow starter in the NFL, and he can play immediately because of pass pro skills. Day 2 grade. -April 10, 2016 What he brings: This big back isn't much of a breakaway threat, and Howard is a relatively unproven receiver who finished his college career with just 24 catches. On the other hand, he's an efficient runner with outstanding vision and good patience. It usually takes multiple defenders to tackle him and he has the power to push the pile when he doesn't get a seam on goal line and short-yardage carries. In addition, Howard takes care of the football. -- Steve Muench
How he fits: The Bears found great value with rookie RB Jeremy Langford last year and he will take over as the feature back for Matt Forte, who left in free agency. Howard is a big and powerful runner who will provide depth behind Langford to shoulder some workload and keep him fresh. The Bears will now have a thunder-and-lightning element in the backfield with Howard's physical style as a runner. -- Kevin Weidl

Dahl's short arms raise questions about his ability to play tackle (where he started the past two seasons), and his weight raises questions about his ability to play guard (where he started in 2013 and lined up at the Senior Bowl). In addition, he's battled through injuries including a broken foot that forced him to miss the final four games of the 2015 season. On the other hand, the Montana transfer and former walk-on at Washington State has the smarts, athletic ability and technique to develop into a valuable reserve with the ability to step in and start if called upon. April 10, 2016 What he brings: A Montana transfer and former walk-on at Washington State, Dahl's arm length raises concerns about his ability to line up at offensive tackle where he started the past two seasons. He also doesn't have great size or power for a guard, which is where he played in 2013 and lined up at the Senior Bowl. However, he's a technician with the football smarts and effort to potentially develop into an effective starter in a zone-heavy scheme. -- Steve Muench

Ioannidis (I-an-NYE-dis) is a tall defensive lineman with a great work ethic and passion for the game. He gives great effort and is a tough player. He's at his best as a one-gap penetrator. He can be disruptive in the run game (22.5 TFL last two seasons) but he's very hit or miss because he gets pushed around too easily when reached. As an inside pass rusher he frequently gains some penetration and he has the initial quickness and hands to improve, but he has not been a good finisher throughout his career. Ioannidis grades out as an early-to-mid Day 3 prospect -April 11, 2016 What he brings: Ioannidis is a disruptive interior run stopper who has the quick first step to shoot gaps and the instincts to locate the ball quickly. He also chases the run and rushes the passer with great effort, but he tends to get pushed around when he doesn't win with quickness. He's light and frequently fails to keep his pads down. He doesn't show the ability to collapse the pocket with any kind of regularity either. -- Steve Muench

The Big 12's leading rusher Smallwood is coming off a breakout junior season rushing for over 1,500 yards and nine touchdowns. His future didn't appear nearly as bright when he was arrested on a witness tampering charge in the summer of 2014 but he was cleared of any wrongdoing and those charges were dropped. While he needs to get stronger and improve in pass pro he has the potential to be a productive receiver, dangerous change-of-pace back and contribute on kickoff returns. April 3, 2016 What he brings: Smallwood is an undersized runner who led the Big 12 in rushing last season. He displays a nice combination of vision, lateral quickness and speed. While Smallwood needs to get stronger and improve in pass protection, he has the potential to be a productive receiver, dangerous change-of-pace back and contributor on kickoff returns. -- Kevin Weidl

Payton started 43 games at UCLA, where he averaged 14.2 yards per catch and caught a total of 12 touchdown passes over the past two seasons. There's a lot to like about his upside, considering the way he worked out at the NFL Combine and his Pro Day. He also has the worth ethic to realize his potential. In addition, there's a lot to like about his toughness and strength after the catch. With that said, he's not quite as explosive on tape as the test results would suggest and he projects as a No. 2 receiver and a Day 2 pick. --April 4, 2016 What he brings: At 6-foot-1 and 207 pounds, Payton is a physical route runner with the strength and quickness to separate underneath. He has the big hands to snatch the ball out of the air. Payton finished the 2015 season with the best "drop percentage" (1.3 percent) out of the top 15 receivers on our board. He's also a powerful open-field runner after the catch. He still needs polish as a route runner, and he doesn't play quite as fast as his timed top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

Haeg is a four-year starter who was a member of five FCS national championship teams and started his career at right tackle before moving to left tackle his last two seasons at North Dakota State. His arm length (33 ') is a red flag for an offensive tackle and he's not an ideal candidate to move inside considering his below average power base so position fit is a concern. However, he could still get drafted late because of his experience, athletic ability and potential to develop into an effective swing tackle or possibly reserve guard for a zoneheavy offense. March 21, 2016 What he brings: A four-year starter and a member of five FCS national championship teams, Haeg started his career at right tackle and lined up at left tackle over the past two seasons. His arm length (33-3/4) is a red flag for offensive tackles, and he's a better pass-blocker than run-blocker. However, he's an above-average athlete with good football smarts. There's a chance he gets stronger and develops into an effective No. 3 offensive tackle or possibly moves inside to guard in a zone-heavy scheme. -- Steve Muench

Williams comes with some durability after missing the entire 2015 season with a left broken ankle suffered during a preseason scrimmage in August that required surgery. He has outstanding make-up and stayed heavily involved with the program despite not being on the field. Based off of 2014 film evaluation, he is a bigger back with natural power and quick feet to potentially add depth in a rotational backfield. Participated at the Senior but did not take part in any contact drills. Williams projects as mid-day three selection. -- April 9, 2016 What he brings: Williams missed the entire 2015 season after breaking his left ankle during a preseason scrimmage, so there are concerns about his health and long-term durability. He's a bigger back who has quick feet and shows good natural power on his 2014 tape. He only caught 26 passes at Arkansas, but he flashes good ball skills given the opportunity, and he shows good awareness in pass protection. He also has great football makeup, and he stayed heavily involved in the program despite not playing last season. -- Steve Muench

Sims is has four years of starting experience (46 career starts) and comes with a quality make-up and solid work ethic. He has plus size to go along with good strength, range and he is physical in run support. His best fit will be for a heavy press-man or press-zone team that can mask some tightness he displays when forced to transition in space. Sims projects as a late developmental prospect that has the potential to add depth and contribute on special teams as he develops early in his career. March 15, 2016 What he brings: Sims is a four-year starter who comes with a quality makeup and solid work ethic. He has plus size to go along with good strength and range and is physical in run support. Sims' best fit will be for a heavy press-man or press-zone team that can mask some tightness that he displays when forced to transition in space. He is a late-developmental prospect who has the potential to add depth and contribute on special teams as he progresses early in his career. -- Kevin Weidl

A 2015 team captain and the nephew of Hall of Fame offensive lineman Art Shell is a four-year starter with a prototypical frame for a right tackle prospect. Plus the 10-yard split and broad jump are historically strong indictors in terms of an offensive tackle's potential success in the NFL and his results were outstanding. However, his tape doesn't come close to matching his talent and a history of shoulder injuries is reason for concern making him high risk high reward prospect. March 15, 2016 What he brings: Shell is a four-year starter with a prototypical frame for a right tackle prospect who comes with upside due to his raw athleticism. However, his tape doesn't come close to matching Shell's talent, and a history of shoulder injuries is reason for concern, easily making him a high-risk-high-reward prospect. -- Kevin Weidl

Dillon is a versatile safety who lined up all over the field in his first full year as a starter in 2015. A physical and reliable run defender, Dillon has adequate range but is most effective lining up near the box. Solid week at the senior bowl. Aside from short-shuttle tested well across the board. Dillon will need to be a heavy special teams contributor early in his career while he develops as a player. He currently projects as an early-to-mid Day 3 selection who should add depth within a secondary. -- April 8, 2016 What he brings: Dillon is an outstanding run defender with the instincts and enough size to hold up when he lines up near the box. He's an above average tackler with good stopping power and the ability to make one-on-one tackles when he's the last line of defense. The former Mountaineer has enough range to cover the deep half of the field, but he's not a ball hawk and there are concerns about his ability to match up in man coverage. -- Steve Muench

Brothers was a highly productive SEC linebacker leading Missouri with 152 tackles, 12 tackles-for-loss and 2.5 sacks in addition to blocking three kicks and intercepting two passes in 2015 alone. Yet his tape is underwhelming considering his production and there are concerns about his top-end speed as well as his shorter arms. With all of that in mind he grades out as a Day 3 pick that projects as a backup inside linebacker and special teams' contributor early in his career. April 10, 2016 What he brings: A highly productive SEC linebacker, Brothers is an instinctive run-defender who does a nice job of squaring and wrapping between the tackles. He also shows good awareness and flashes the ability to play the ball in coverage. Below-average, top-end speed is a concern for Brothers. He's not a sideline-to-sideline run-defender and he has limitations in coverage. He also has short arms and struggles to counter when blockers get into his frame. -- Steve Muench

Westerman is an Auburn transfer who started the past two seasons for Arizona State and whose father was an offensive lineman for Cal. He had some problems staying healthy earlier in his career, he's on the lighter side for an offensive guard and there's still room for improvement in terms of technique both as a run blocker and in pass pro. But he's a hard nosed player with the nasty disposition, football smarts and violent hands to provide quality depth and even push for a starting job early in his career. He projects as a late Day 2 early Day 3 pick. --March 8, 2016 What he brings: Westerman is a transfer from Auburn who started the past two seasons for the Sun Devils. Though he has room to improve with his technique, he has quality first-step quickness as a run-blocker and does a nice job of keeping his feet moving to sustain blocks. Westerman shows good overall awareness in pass protection, flashes a powerful punch and has good short-area quickness to keep rushers at bay. He also plays with a nasty disposition that is coveted for interior offensive lineman. Westerman has the potential to develop into a starting guard, ideally for a heavy zone-blocking scheme. -- Kevin Weidl

Hogan was a three-year starter and team captain in 2015. He finished with a 36-10 career record as a starter and had his best season as a senior, completing 67.8 percent of his throws with 27 TDs compared to just eight INTs. His throwing motion is unorthodox and he has limitations due to below-average arm strength. But Hogan has the size, mental makeup, accuracy and pocket mobility to develop into a solid backup QB in the NFL. Hogan grades out as an early-to-mid Day 3 prospect. -April 11, 2016 What he brings: Hogan is a three-year starter who finished his career at Stanford with a record of 36-10. He improved in every season and had his best year as a senior. He has an unorthodox throwing motion and has limitation due to below-average arm strength. Hogan, however, has the size, mental makeup, accuracy and pocket mobility to develop into a solid backup.
How he fits: Kansas City is a great fit for Hogan who lacks ideal physical tools, particularly arm strength, but is a cerebral quarterback who can make quick decisions within Andy Reid's West Coast system. Reid has a history of collecting quarterbacks to develop, and after losing Chase Daniel to free agency, Hogan will add depth behind Alex Smith and battle with Aaron Murray for the No. 2 role. -- Kevin Weidl

Davis began his career at Hawaii but left after two seasons (Norm Chow's departure) and elected to return home to Cal-Berkeley, where he grew up nearby (Martinez, CA) He sat out 2013 (NCAA transfer rules), before emerging as a productive slot-WR and return specialist for the Bears. As a senior in 2015, he caught 40 passes for 672 yards (16.8) and two TDs. Davis, who grades out as a Day 3 prospect, will likely need to contribute in the return game to earn a roster spot in the NFL, which will buy him time to develop his route-running skills. --March 17, 2016 What he brings: Davis is a transfer from Hawaii who brings upside with big-play potential. He has the top-end speed to stretch the field vertically thanks to his athleticism and long, lean frame. Davis needs to continue to get stronger and add polish as a route runner. He has quality ball skills and adequate body control to make the tough catch outside the frame. He has a chance to add depth as a No. 4 or No. 5 receiver who will likely need to contribute as a returner on special teams to make it at the next level. -- Kevin Weidl

Halapoulivaati Vaitai (hah-lah-poo-li-VAH-tee VIE-tie) is a three-year starter with experience at right and left tackle. He's a developmental prospect who needs to improve his technique before playing a substantial role. There are also some durability concerns as he underwent shoulder surgery last spring and he missed time with a knee injury last year. That said, he tested well, he's a hard worker who flashes the potential to develop into a starting right tackle on tape and his versatility makes him a candidate to play a No. 3 swing tackle role early in his career. April 2, 2016 What he brings: Vaitai is a three-year starter with experience at right and left tackle. He needs to improve his technique and there are some durability concerns, but he tested well and he has the potential to develop into an effective No.3 swing tackle or possibly starting right tackle. -- Steve Muench

What he brings: An Oklahoma State transfer, Hill comes with some character red flags. He is a versatile weapon who can line up in the slot as a receiver and in the backfield as a change-of-pace runner. Hill is dynamic with the ball in his hands and brings excellent value as a returner on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

On one hand, Reader hasn't always made sound decisions off the field, there are concerns about his ability to keep his weight down and teams are going to want to know if the personal problems that caused him to leave the team early in the 2015 season won't be an issue going forward. On the other, his tape is impressive, there aren't many players at his size that move as well as he does, and it's worth noting that he was named a permanent team captain at the end of the 2015 season. With all of that in mind he projects as a late Day 2 pick. --April 10, 2016 What he brings: At 6-foot-3 and 327 pounds, Reader is an outstanding run-stuffer with the size and strength to clog up the middle and anchor a three or four-man front. While he's not overly explosive, he is a powerful bull-rusher who pushes the pocket. There are a couple of red flags attached to Reader, though, as he left Clemson with the support of the coaching staff to attend to personal issues in August and missed the first six games of the 2015 season. He also needs to keep his weight down. -- Steve Muench

Drango was a four-year starter at left tackle for Baylor (missed four games in 2013 with back injury but started other 35 games). He has a good height-weight combo but below average arm length and hand span. He's a hard worker with very good intangibles. On the field, he's highly competitive, he has quick reaction skills and adequate strength. But is is limited athletically and he lacks explosive power. Drango projects as a backup OT (best suited to play ROT) in the NFL and he should be a mid-Day 3 pick. --April 11, 2016 What he brings: A four-year starter at Baylor, Drango's experience shows in his awareness. He lined up at left tackle for the Bears, but he projects as a right tackle or guard due to athletic limitations. He is a good hand fighter in pass protection but lacks ideal flexibility in his lower half and struggled to redirect against quicker pass-rushers. He has adequate short-area quickness to get into quality position as a run-blocker but needs to improve balance to sustain and finish with more consistency. -- Kevin Weidl

What he brings: Williams brings a quality size and speed combination. He has improved throughout the past two seasons and was playing his best football at the end of his career. He fits as a potential outside linebacker who can contribute as a special teams player early in his career. -- Kevin Weidl

Toner was a four-year starter at the Ivy League level, where he played well enough to receive an invitation to the Senior Bowl. But there are substantial concerns about his ability to make the jump to the NFL, and they start with position fit. His arm length raises questions about his ability to develop into an effective tackle, and he'll need to get stronger to play on the inside if he's moved there. His pad level and inconsistent footwork are also reasons for concern. As result, he projects as a late round pick or rookie free agent. --April 10, 2016 What he brings: A four-year starter, Toner flashes the kind of nasty disposition teams covet in their offensive linemen and shows good football smarts on tape. Position fit is a concern, though. His arm length (33 1/8") is a red flag for offensive tackles and he had some problems handling speed off the edge the week of the Senior Bowl. He's also on the lighter side for an offensive guard and plays too high on tape. -- Steve Muench

Collins stepped into a full-time starting role in 2015 with the absence of Jonathan Williams (broken leg) and turned in a career year, rushing for 1,577 yards and 20 TDs. He joined Herschel Walker and Darren McFadden as just the third SEC RB to eclipse the 1,000 yard rushing mark in each of his first three seasons. Collins has the skill set to potentially develop into a No. 1 RB, but he does come with some ball security (2.3%) and off-the-field accountability issues. He projects as a top-100 selection. --April 8, 2016 What he brings: Only three SEC running backs have eclipsed 1,000 rushing yards in each of their first three seasons. They are Herschel Walker, Darren McFadden and Collins. Collins reads his keys well, gives his blockers time to get into positon and recognizes cutback lanes. He's quick and flashes the ability to shake defenders in confined areas, but he's not fast enough to pull away. In addition, ball security is an issue at times and he's an unproven receiver who has just 27 career catches. -- Steve Muench

A true junior Higgins came back down to earth after leading the nation in receiving yards (1,750) and touchdowns (17) in 2015 but still managed to eclipse the 1,000 receiving yard mark and catch eight touchdown-passes. His 40 time (4.64), three-cone time (7.19) and vertical jump (32") all raise red flags. However, we expected him to test better based on his tape and believe that his route running in addition to his ability to produce after the catch make him worth the risk on Day 3. April 8, 2016 What he brings: Higgins isn't a burner, but he is a smooth and polished route runner with value after the catch. He does a nice job of utilizing tempo and setting up defenders to create separation. He shows quality body control but needs to be more consistent finishing catches at times. Higgins has a chance to develop into an adequate No. 3 or No. 4 receiver. -- Kevin Weidl

What he brings: Caldwell is an undersized corner with shorter arms and he wasn't much of a playmaker at the college level, but he has enough top-end speed and athletic ability to develop into an effective sub-package corner and contribute on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

Cooper took a circuitous route to the NFL draft, as he began at Bowling Green where he started for a year, transferred to a junior college where he started for a year and then transferred to Ole Miss where he started at right and left tackle the past two years. He is a developmental prospect who doesn't always play with sound technique and needs to get stronger. However, he has the experience, frame and toughness to develop into an effective swing tackle. March 22, 2016 What he brings: Cooper started at Bowling Green before transferring to a junior college and then to Ole Miss, where he started at right and left tackle over the past two seasons. His technique is erratic both as a run- and pass-blocker, but he has the frame, arm length and experience to provide quality depth as a No. 3 swing tackle early in his career and possibly develop into a starter down the road. -- Steve Muench

Brown was the MAC Defensive Player of the Year and broke the school's single season sack record (12) that he previously shared with Jason Taylor. He is undersized and will have limited scheme and position fits at the NFL level. But he is an explosive athlete with playmaking instincts, and he comes with great overall makeup. Tested extremely well at pro day including 4.42 forty yard dash and 33 reps on bench. Brown is in the mold of a Cato June or Stephen Tulloch. MVP of NFLPA game who stood on special teams coverage unit. Brown could be one of the bigger day 3 sleepers. --April 8, 2016 What he brings: The MAC defensive player of the year, Brown broke Akron's single-season sack record, which he had previously shared with Jason Taylor. He tested well at his pro day, where he ran a 4.42 40-yard dash and benched 225 pounds 33 times. He's a fundamentally sound tackler. He has outstanding range as a run defender. And in addition to his ability to rush the passer, he moves well in coverage. The problem revolves around his frame and position fit, as he weighs just 227 pounds. -- Steve Muench

Janovich (JAN-oh-vitch) is a former walk-on who started ten of the 50 games he played in at Nebraska and gets the most of out of his natural ability. He's an effective lead blocker and between-the-tackles runner. While he didn't play a big role in Nebraska's passing attack, he's shown upside as a receiver given the opportunity. Finally and arguably most importantly, he made 13 special teams tackles in 2015 and has the tenacity to develop into a core special teams' player at the NFL level. March 14, 2015 What he brings: A former walk-on, Janovich is an effective lead blocker and between-the-tackles runner. While he didn't play a big role in Nebraska's passing attack, he's shown upside as a receiver given the opportunity and he has the potential to develop into a core special teams player. -- Steve Muench

Hemingway is a raw but athletic player with developmental upside. He has added over 15 pounds of healthy weight since 2014 and has a long and well-proportioned frame to continue to add bulk and strength. Hemingway will need time to continue to develop his feel for routes and can continue to get stronger as a blocker. However, he moves extremely well for the position and has quality ball skills to become a formidable receiving TE that can stretch the field. He also comes with great make up and a strong work ethic. Hemingway projects as a mid-to-late day 3 selection. March 16, 2016 What he brings: A developmental small-school prospect, Hemingway isn't a powerful run-blocker or polished route runner, but he has the potential to materialize into an effective move tight end who makes his biggest impact as a receiver at the NFL level. He's a natural pass-catcher with good hand-eye coordination and body control. Hemingway is fast enough to make plays down the seam, and he's above average after the catch. -- Steve Muench

White is a three year starter (34 career starter) who comes with strong football character. An invite to the East-West Shrine game, White is an athletic CB with a nice combination of instincts, strength and balance and fits best for a heavy zone coverage scheme. He should add immediate depth with the potential to push for a starting position within a few years time. He also has the capability to be an early contributor on special teams. White projects to come off the board within the top-100 selections. April 2, 2016 What he brings: A better football player than athlete, White isn't the most fluid corner in this class and doesn't have the second gear to consistently recover when he gets caught out of position. However, he's an instinctive corner who rarely gets caught out of positon, limits production after the catch and flashes the ability to play the ball. He's an above-average run-stopper who doesn't shy away from contact and chases with good effort. -- Steve Muench

Kaser is a three year starter who strictly handled the punting duties for the Aggies. He comes with good overall make-up. However, he lost some focus heading into his junior campaign (2014) and saw his numbers dip a bit. He returned back to form in 2015. Kaser projects as a late round to undrafted free agent. April 6, 2015 What he brings: Kaser has quality length strength and directional skills. He has ability to tighten up his delivery but should develop into a quality starter. -- Kevin Weidl

What he brings: Holmes is an undersized defensive end with shorter arms and there are concerns about the level of competition he faced on a weekly basis at Montana. However, he tested extremely well at his pro day and he has the potential to develop into a disruptive edge rusher. -- Steve Muench

Reynolds is four year starter who ended his career as the most decorated QB to play at the school. Led the school to their first ever 11 win season in 2015 while finishing fifth in the Heisman voting. FBS record for career TDs from scrimmage (88) and rushing yards for a QB (4,559). Navy has already retired his No. 19 jersey. He will need to make a position change at the next level and has toughness, work ethic and enough athleticism to potentially develop into a utility weapon whether it be at WR, RB and/or as a returner on special teams. Reynolds holds a late round grade. April 8, 2016 What he brings: A four-year starter and the most decorated quarterback in Navy history, Reynolds holds the FBS records for career touchdowns from scrimmage (88) and rushing yards (4,559) for a quarterback. Navy has already retired his No. 19 jersey. He will need to make a position change at the next level, but he has he toughness, work ethic and enough athleticism to potentially develop into a utility weapon whether it be at receiver, running back and/or on special teams. -- Steve Muench

Bond is a juco transfer (Sierra CC) that has just seven starts in his two seasons at Oklahoma. He missed four games in 2015 while dealing with a left ankle injury. Bond lacks an ideal fit as he lacks ideal size and length for 34-OLB and is still developing instincts as an 43 WLB. He does come with solid make-up and plays with a great motor to potentially contribute on special teams early in his career while he develops. Bond projects as a late day three selection. March 17, 2016 What he brings: Bond is a smaller linebacker and junior college transfer who started just seven games at the FBS level and missed five games with an ankle injury last year. He is above-average range as a run defender and his test results were encouraging when it comes to his ability to develop his cover skills. However, he lacks ideal length for a 3-4 outside linebacker and instincts for a 4-3 weakside linebacker. -- Steve Muench

Adams was an under-utilized target at South Carolina. After two seasons as mostly a backup, Adams earned the full-time starting job at tight end and caught 49 passes for 700 yards (14.3 ypc) with four TDs in 2014-15. He has bulked up nearly 20 pounds in the past year and has always been a physical, tough competitor. Adams is a big target with elite speed to stretch the field. He also can develop into a solid in-line blocker and good space blocker with improved hand usage. One of the most underrated players in this class, Adams is worth a second round pick. --March 5, 2016 What he brings: Adams' production over the past two seasons isn't all that impressive -- he caught only 49 passes for 700 yards and four touchdowns. That said, Adams has the potential to be a more productive pro. He has outstanding separation skills and is productive after the catch. He stretches the field, plus he has long arms and above average ball skills. He also has the potential to develop into an effective blocker if he continues to bulk up and get stronger. -- Steve Muench

Houston-Carter iis a four year starter that started his career at CB before switching to DS in 2015. He is a better football player than pure athlete and has a knack for finding the ball (Career: 34 PBU, 10 INT). In addition, he is a stand-out on special teams including nine career blocked kicks that teams will covet from his position. He does come with some minor durability after suffering a season ending wrist injury in the ninth game of the 2014 season. Carson-Houston projects as a fringe day-2 prospect that should add depth and immediate help on special teams. March 27, 2016 What he brings: Houston-Carson is a four-year starter who started his career at cornerback before switching to safety in 2015. He did not test well, but he is a better football player than athlete on tape. Houston-Carson shows quality instincts and recognition skills and has good ball awareness and hands to finish when in position. He also brings excellent value on special teams and had nine blocked kicks throughout his career. He has a chance to add immediate depth in a secondary and help on special teams while he develops. -- Kevin Weidl

Grant has three years of starting experience (32 total starts) and ended his career as the school's all time leader in receiving yards (3, 289 yards). He is an undersized potential-slot WR who is at his best with the ball in his hand. His best value in the NFL could be as a kickoff returner where he has 4 career KO returns for TD's throughout his career including 2 this year. Grant was injured in an off-campus shooting in October of 2014 but was treated and released that night and played the following week vs TCU. He projects as a late round pick or free. April 8, 2016 What he brings: Grant is a pint-sized receiver with excellent separation quickness. He also is dangerous with the ball in his hand with a combination of elusiveness and speed. He will need to be a heavy contributor on special teams if he wants to make it at the next level. -- Kevin Weidl

Sudfeld's brother Zach is a TE for the Jets. Nate played 37 games (30 starts) during four seasons at Indiana and finished with a 60.3 career completion percentage and a 3-1 TD-to-INT ratio. He dealt with a nagging lower-body injury during the middle of 2015, and suffered a season-ending shoulder injury (non-throwing) in Game 6 (Iowa) of 2014. Sudfeld can be inconsistent with ball placement and decision making, but he's a big, strong-armed QB that flashes anticipatory accuracy and sneaky pocket mobility. If developed properly he could surprise as a capable NFL backup from Day 3. -April 9, 2016 What he brings: Although he dealt with a few injuries throughout his career, Sudfeld played in 37 games (30 starts) during four seasons at Indiana. He can be inconsistent with ball placement and decision-making, but he's a big, strong-armed QB who flashes anticipatory accuracy. A QB with sneaky pocket mobility, Sudfeld could surprise as a capable NFL backup. -- Kevin Weidl
How he fits: Kirk Cousins and Colt McCoy are the only two quarterbacks on the roster, so adding a developmental No. 3 makes sense. Sudfeld is a good value pick at this point.

What he brings: Morgan lacks ideal speed and separation quickness but has quality size, a big catch radius and reliable hands as a short-to-intermediate target. He needs to hone his technique as a blocker, but he has the inline power to work with. -- Kevin Weidl

Brown is a three year starter who started his career at DS before switching to CB. He has a nice combination of size, strength and speed to fit in a heavy press-technique scheme. After failing to produce an INT in his first three season he notched 4 as a senior (Note: 3 of 4 INTs came against Nebraska with a back-up QB). Brown must become more reliable in run support as he projects as a late round developmental prospect that will need to be a heavy special teams contributor early in his career to survive on a roster. March 14, 2016 What he brings: Brown is a big and physical cornerback with quality range and who showed improved ball skills in 2015. He can become more consistent with his pursuit angles and tackle with better balance in run support. -- Kevin Weidl

Forrest led the Wildcats in tackles each of the past two years and there's a lot to like about his frame but he is a former wide receiver who needs to continue to improve his diagnostic skills and get stronger at the point of attack plus he has below average top-end speed. Bench pressing 225 just 11 times and running a 4.88 40 at the Combine raises two red flags. At this point, he projects as a sub-package linebacker and special teams' contributor with some upside, making him a Day 3 value. --April 11, 2016 What he brings: Forrest is an athletic and rangy linebacker who was recruited to Kentucky as a wide receiver. He has above-average change-of-direction skills and holds up well in space. Forrest also brings good value on third downs, in which he has ample range in underneath coverage and is an underrated blitzer. He can quicken up his recognition skills, though. -- Kevin Weidl

Rudock started his career at Iowa starting two seasons (2013-14') before ending up at Michigan in 2015 as a graduate transfer. He has 38 career starts (24-14 starting record) within pro-style systems both at Iowa and Michigan. His growth throughout his career is a classic example of how valuable experience is for the development at the position. Still, Rudock needs work with mechanics, accuracy and has room for growth as a decision maker. He holds a fringe draftable grade that would do well with a year or two on a practice squad to hone craft and add bulk/strength to his frame. April 2, 2016 What he brings: A two-year starter at Iowa, Rudock went to Michigan as a graduate transfer, so he has ample experience running pro-style offenses. He finished his career with a 24-14 record. His mechanics are erratic and his accuracy suffers as a result, plus he has room to improve as a decision-maker. It's also important that he adds some bulk to his frame, but he has the potential to develop into an effective backup. -- Steve Muench
How he fits: Matt Stafford and 32-year-old Dan Orlovsky are the only two quarterbacks on the roster, so adding depth and youth makes sense. -- Steve Muench

Listenbee is a former high school quarterback who also sprinted on TCU's track team and his lack of ideal experience plus the time spent focusing on track has likely hindered his progress at receiver. In addition, he's a lean receiver who has had some problems staying healthy, as he played hurt for much of the 2015 season and didn't run at his Pro Day because of a sports hernia injury. He still projects as a Day 3 pick because he's a vertical threat who averaged 19.4 yards per catch at TCU and ran the second fastest 40 (4.35) at the Combine. April 4, 2016 What he brings: Listenbee is a vertical receiver who was also a sprinter on the school's track team. He is a quick starter who can eat up cushions to get behind defenders. He had the second-fastest 40-yard dash at the NFL combine. Listenbee shows an extra gear running down vertical throws and also shows very good focus tracking and completing the catch. He still needs to add polish to his game. There are also some durability issues for Listenbee because of a sports hernia injury. -- Kevin Weidl

Tretola is a double transfer who started his career at Nevada before finding his way to Arkansas where he started 23 of 25 games over two seasons. He has natural power and is more effective in the run game than in pass pro at this point (Very short arms 30 7/8). Lost over 30 pounds from 2014 to the 2015 season showed improved agility. Has weighed as much as 370 pounds so weight and diet will need to be monitored. Tretola projects as an early day 3 pick who should add depth and could develop into a starter at OG ideally for a power-man blocking scheme. April 8, 2016 What he brings: Tretola is a mauler who has a massive lower half and excellent inline power. He is a bit heavy footed, however, and doesn't have exceptional athleticism. But he has the size and power to drive defenders off the ball when he is able to establish position. Tretola has shorter arms and can show more patience in pass protection, but he has enough short-area quickness to hold up. He has a chance to add depth on the interior and potentially develop into a starter for a power-man blocking scheme. -- Kevin Weidl

A four year starter James lined up at outside linebacker, inside linebacker and defensive end in addition to playing in base three-man and base-four man fronts at Colorado State. That said he's not so much versatile as he doesn't have a true fit. He's undersized for a weak side linebacker let alone a defensive end and though he has good top-end speed the more space he's in the less effective he is on tape. A team could take a chance on him late and use him on special teams with the hope he develops into an effective reserve. April 6, 2016 What he brings: A four-year starter, James lined up at outside linebacker, inside linebacker and defensive end in addition to playing in base three-man and base-four man fronts at Colorado State. He's undersized for a weakside linebacker -- let alone a defensive end -- and he has better speed than athletic ability. He projects as a core special teams player who could develop into an adequate reserve on defense. -- Steve Muench

What he brings: A three-year starter and team captain, Schweitzer lined up at right and left tackle at San Jose State. He tested well at his pro day but he'll likely have to move inside to guard because of his shorter arms and he's on the lighter side for a guard prospect.
What he brings: A Michigan transfer who is instinctive, tough and has quality range and athleticism in coverage. He also brings quality value on special teams coverage units. -- Kevin Weidl

A four-year starter Vitale (vy-TAL-ee) lined up at tight end, fullback and in the slot for Northwestern. His lack of production as a runner is a concern and he's not big enough to develop into into an effective in-line blocker. However, he turned in an impressive showing at the Combine where he tested notably well in several key categories for running backs and he's a tough positional blocker on tape. He has the potential to develop into a productive receiver and adequate lead blocker who also develops into a core special teams' player. He projects as a Day 3 pick. April 10, 2016 What he brings: A four-year starter and the top fullback on our board, Vitale is a versatile player who has lined up in the backfield, in the slot and at tight end. He's a reliable receiver with enough quickness to separate from linebackers and the football acumen to locate pockets in zone looks. He does an above-average job of locating assignments and getting into position as a blocker. Vitale has the potential to develop into a core special-teams contributor. -- Steve Muench

Watt's older brother is Houston defensive end J.J. Watt and his younger brother T.J. plays outside linebacker for the Badgers. Derek is a lighter fullback prospect who needs to get stronger at the point of attack. But he's tough for his size and he has the potential to develop into an effective check-down receiver who also helps out in pass pro. Plus, he has experience covering kicks and the temperament to contribute on special teams in the NFL. --March 1, 2016 What he brings: A lighter fullback prospect, Watt needs to get stronger at the point of attack but he's a tough positional blocker for his size and he has the potential to develop into an effective check-down receiver. Plus, he has experience covering kicks and the potential to contribute on special teams.

Core is two year starter that comes with outstanding make-up and work ethic. He is a straight line receiver that needs polish as a route runner but has the size, speed and ball skills to potentially develop into a vertical threat outside the hashes at the next level. Very good 40-time at combine (4.47) and improved his vertical jump by six inches at the his pro day (37.5") from the combine. Core currently projects as a late round selection in the 2016 NFL draft. -- April 9, 2016 How he fits: Core is a straight-line receiver who needs to add polish as a route runner and improve his ability to separate underneath. But he has the size, speed and ball skills to develop into a vertical threat. He ran a 4.47 40 at the combine and improved his vertical jump (37.5 inches) by six inches between the combine and his pro day. -- Steve Muench

A 2015 team captain Murphy is a two-year starter who lined up at right tackle in 2014 and then moved to left tackle in 2015. His older brother Kevin went to Harvard and spent some time with the Vikings. He could develop into an adequate No. 3 tackle but there are concerns about his ability to protect the edge. He has short arms (33 1/2") and though he shows above average lateral mobility on tape a hamstring injury prevented him from working out at the Combine and his Pro Day. In addition, he doesn't appear to be a good fit at guard either as he doesn't have great core strength. April 8, 2015 What he brings: A team captain with starting experience at both tackle spots, Murphy has the potential to develop into an effective swing tackle. He's smart, gets good initial push in the run game and flashes above average lateral mobility in pass pro. He's not an overpowering drive blocker, however, and his shorter arms could prevent him from developing into a starter. -- Steve Muench

Allen started in 34 consecutive games to end career over the past 3 seasons. One of the most improved QB throughout 2015 (Led the Hogs to wins in final 6 of 7 games, 20 TD-4INTs in that span). Allen doesn't have elite physical tools and his hand size is a concern (8 7/8"). He also has been through a lot of adversity and scrutiny from fans early in career (Had his truck egged and set on fire) and showed the mental toughness to work through it. He has a chance to develop into a quality back-up (Matt Flynn - Brian Hoyer) and spot starter. He projects as a fringe day 2 pick. April 8, 2016 What he brings: Allen is a three-year starter who ended his career with 34 straight starts in a pro-style scheme. He lacks elite measurables and his smaller hands are a slight concern. However, he has very good pocket presence and quality rush awareness to slide and buy time within the pocket while working through progressions. He also is a highly competitive player who brings the mental toughness to handle demands of the position. Allen is one of the most underrated quarterbacks in this year's class. He has a chance to stick in the league as a quality backup with the ability to develop into an adequate starter in the right situation.
How he fits: Allen brings the mental toughness, decision-making and pocket awareness to quickly push and eventually surpass Chad Henne as Blake Bortles' back-up. The Jaguars got a steal here with Allen, who compares favorably to Philadelphia QB Chase Daniel with the ability to be a spot starter and win a game in a pinch. -- Kevin Weidl

A 2015 team captain Zettel was a durable, versatile, reliable and productive college defensive lineman that played in all 50 games (38 starts) during four seasons and finished with 120 total tackles, 38 TFLs, 20 sacks, 15 PBUs, 4 INTs, and 2 FFs. There's a lot to like about his toughness, motor and playmaking instincts, but the team that drafts Zettel has to find good situational fits for him. Zettel is an early-Day 3 prospect who can earn sub-package playing time on defense while also contributing on special teams (some teams even worked him out at TE). -March 30, 2016 What he brings: Position fit is the best biggest concern when it comes to Zettel. At 6-foot-4, 277 pounds, he has short arms for a defensive end and is on the smaller side for a defensive tackle. Yet he still has the potential to develop into a valuable player for a team willing to find a good situational fit for him. He's an effective hand fighter with experience playing on the inside and the outside, plus his motor never stops running. -- Steve Muench

Nicolas played out of position as a undersized 5-technique for a big portion of 2015 and had just 2.5 sacks compared to nine in 2014. Nicolas lacks an ideal fit at the next level as he is undersized as a traditional DE within a 43 scheme and is even on the lighter side as a 34-OLB. He is a long and explosive athlete (41-inch VJ and 7.04 3C critical tests for edge rushers) that brings upside as a situational pass rusher. However, he must continue to add bulk and will need time acclimating to playing in space to become a 3-down linebacker. He projects as a mid-round selection. April 2, 2016 What he brings: Nicolas is a long, lean and explosive athlete who needs polish. He has upside as a speed rusher due to an excellent combination of first-step quickness, length and flexibility bending the edge. He possesses a linear lower half, lacks ideal bulk and must continue to get stronger as a run defender. Nicolas also doesn't have great reaction instincts and is at his best when in attacking mode. He has a chance to add help as a pass-rushing specialist and contributor on special teams, but he has the potential to develop into a three-down player if he is able to add weight and get stronger. -- Kevin Weidl

Lucas is a three year starter that started his career at CB before switching to safety in 2015. He missed four games in 2015 including the final three games with an undisclosed right arm injury. Lucas did not workout at the combine but tested well at his pro-day (4.45 40, 38-inch VJ, 10-foot-10-inch BJ, 6.78 3C). Lucas projects as day three developmental prospect that has the potential to develop into a versatile reserve who can add depth in a secondary at the next level while also contributing on special teams early in his career. March 21, 2016 What he brings: Lucas is a versatile defensive back who started his career at cornerback before switching to safety in 2015. He tested extremely well, and his athleticism shows up on tape, but he needs to continue to refine his instincts and become a more consistent tackler. Lucas is a developmental prospect who has the potential to become a versatile reserve and can add depth in a secondary while also contributing on special teams early in his career. -- Kevin Weidl

Miller is a two-year starter that has adequate size, natural movement skills and has improved his ball skills in 2015. Miller needs to show better eye discipline at times and can continue to add strength and bulk to become more consistent in run support. Stood out as a small prospect at the senior bowl. Short-shuttle time (4.42 ) is a concern and is below the red flag thresh hold time (4.35) for the position. Improved 40 time from 4.65 at combine to a 4.56 at pro day. He projects as a mid-round pick that can add depth and potentially push for a starting job in a few years. -- April 8, 2016 What he brings: A small-school prospect who stood out at the Senior Bowl, Miller has the ball skills and instincts to develop into a playmaker. He also shows good balance and body control transitioning in and of breaks on tape, but he didn't test well at the scouting combine. There are concerns about his ability to make the jump from FCS SE Louisiana to the NFL, even though he played well in Mobile, Alabama. There's also room for improvement when it comes to Miller's ability to defend the run. -- Steve Muench
What he brings: A possession type receiver who had excellent production in college. He has a quality feel as a route runner and shows reliable hands. -- Kevin Weidl

Driskel played in 29 games (21 starts) during four seasons at Florida, including 2013 when he suffered a season-ending broken leg in Game 3 (medical redshirt). He transferred to Louisiana Tech in 2015 and thrived in its passer-friendly spread offense, completing 62.4 percent of his throws with 24 touchdowns compared to eight INTs. He has a long way to go in terms of reading defenses and his deep accuracy must improve, but he has the arm, mobility, size and short-intermediate accuracy to develop into a quality backup. Driskel grades out as a Day 3 prospect. --March 22, 2016 What he brings: Driskel started 21 games in his four seasons at Florida and then transferred to Louisiana Tech, where he thrived in the Bulldogs' passer-friendly offense. He has a long way to go in terms of reading defenses, and his downfield accuracy is below average. There are some concerns about his durability too. But he has the frame, arm strength, short-to-intermediate accuracy and athletic ability to develop into a valuable backup. How he fits: It doesn't appear that San Francisco will trade Colin Kaepernick at this point, but he is recovering from multiple surgeries. Plus, Blaine Gabbert went 3-5 in eight starts last year, and he's entering the final year of his contract. Driskel has the size, quick release and mobility to develop into an effective backup and possibly develop into a starter in head coach Chip Kelly's scheme. -- Steve Muench

What he brings: An undersized small school linebacker with short arms, Grugier-Hall projects as a safety at the next level. He tested exceptionally well at his pro day, and he has the athletic ability to make the transition though he'll likely make his biggest contributions on special teams early in his career. -- Steve Muench

Canady is a bigger cornerback that has three years of starter's experience working both outside the hashes and in the slot for the Cavaliers.He has above-average instincts, anticipation and is technically sound. Canady has taken advantage of the post-season process starting with a strong week at the Senior Bowl. Also tested well at the combine which helps ease some concerns about some stiffness shown on tape. Canady's best fit will be for heavy cover-2 or press-zone scheme at the next level. He projects as an early-to-mid day three selection. -- April 8, 2016 What he brings: Canady is a three-year starter with experience playing both outside the hashes and in the slot. He has above-average measurables with very good technique and instincts. While he tested well, he shows some tightness on tape, and his best fit will be for a heavy zone-coverage scheme. Canady has the chance to add quality depth and potentially push for a starting position down the road. -- Kevin Weidl

Landes is a three year starter who has 36 total starts. He is a former dual-sport athlete who played on the baseball team early in career. Handled the snapping duties as a freshman in 2011 before taking the 2012 season off to focus on baseball. Returned to the team in 2013 in a reserve role before regaining his starting position the past two seasons (2014-'15). Good overall make-up and quality student. Landes has the chance to develop into a quality long snapper at the NFL level. He projects as a late round pick or free agent in the 2016 draft. April 8, 2016 What he brings: He is a fundamentally sound long snapper that has quality accuracy and velocity. Also showed the ability to handle inclement weather against Oklahoma this past year. -- Kevin Weidl

Kelvin's father, Fred, was a standout RB at Florida and in the NFL (13 seasons; Jaguars, Patriots). Kelvin broke the Florida HS rushing yards record (12,121). He rushed for 1,073 yards in his first two seasons as a backup for the Gators before becoming the starter in 2015, when he rushed for 1,035 yards (4.0 ypc) and 13 TDs. Taylor lacks power as a runner, but he has great lateral agility, he never fumbled in college, he has been durable and he's willing in pass pro. Similar to Devonte Freeman (Falcons 4th rd '14), Taylor is underrated and should outplay his draft slot. April 8, 2016 What he brings: Taylor is an instinctive and elusive runner. He doesn't have ideal size and didn't test well, but he plays faster on tape than his timed speed indicates. He has good overall vision and does a nice job of setting up and utilizing his blocks. In addition, he has very good tempo as a runner with the ability to string together multiple cuts weaving in and out of traffic. He also has excellent ball security and did not fumble in 510 career touches. Taylor may never be a full-time back, but he has the ability to develop into a quality change-of-pace runner for a backfield. -- Kevin Weidl

Frazier comes with a nice combination of size, athleticism, instincts and brings a physical presence to the position. He caught some eyes with a strong pro day workout (4.52:40YD -- 40.5What he brings: Frazier is an exceptional athlete with quality football intelligence. He has a strong combination of size and strength, along with the range to handle responsibilities in the middle of the field. Frazier also shows quality ball awareness and has the leaping ability to hold up against bigger receivers in jump-ball situations. In addition, he is a technically sound and reliable tackler who stands out on special teams. He is one of the most underrated safeties in this class. He could end up developing into a quality starter. -- Kevin Weidl

Burbridge posted moderate numbers his first three seasons at Michigan State but broke out with a strong senior year when he caught 85 passes for 1,258 yards and seven touchdowns. While he is not much of a big-play threat and his small hands (8 1/4") are reason for concern he's a tough competitor with the strength and savvy to get open working against sub-package defensive backs. --April 10, 2016 What he brings: Burbridge is coming off a breakout senior season catching 85 passes for 1,258 yards and seven touchdowns. He has small hands and lacks the second gear to regularly take the top off the coverage. Burbridge does have the toughness and body control to come down with the occasional 50-50 ball downfield. He's also a physical route runner who is willing to do the dirty work over the middle and he picks up some yards after the catch. -- Steve Muench

What he brings: Roberts came on strong as a senior and caught some scouts' eyes late in the year. He is an undersized linebacker with average athleticism but has a nose for the football and is active on special teams. -- Steve Muench

What he brings: An undersized center with short arms, Hunt missed three games with an injury last year. He's a three-year starter with good upper-body strength and he moves well on tape. -- Steve Muench

What he brings: At 6-foot and 220 pounds, Jackson turned heads with an outstanding performance at his pro day and he's coming off a breakout senior season. He also flashes the ability to contribute on third down despite small hands, but his lack of production before his senior season raises a red flag considering his talent. -- Steve Muench

Seymour's had an inconsistent senior campaign where he had just 4 starts and saw his production dip after a preseason knee injury hampered him for the first part the year including missing two games (Stanford/ASU). Seymour needs some work with his technique, can improve his ball awareness and become more consistent against the run. However, he has quality size and a lot of raw athleticism to work with -- tested extremely well at the combine -- to add depth as an outside CB and potentially fight for a starting spot down the road. He projects as a mid-day 3 selection. April 3, 2016 What he brings: The 2015 season didn't unfold as hoped for Seymour; a knee injury that caused him to miss two games hampered him early in the year and an ankle injury sidelined him for the Holiday Bowl. In addition, his technique needs work, and he wasn't a ball hawk at Southern Cal. Seymour, however, tested well at the combine, and he shows above-average cover skills on tape. He has the tools to provide quality depth early in his career and could develop into a starter. -- Steve Muench
What he brings: He brings a physical element to his game with the ability to strike as tackler. He has average instincts and needs become more consistent in coverage. -- Kevin Weidl

What he brings: Wallace started just 11 games at UCLA but he has the size, top-end speed and athletic ability to make an immediate impact on special teams and develop into an effective backup outside linebacker. -- Steve Muench

Doughty dealt with injuries early in his career including a season ending knee injury (ACL) in 2011 that he was eventually granted a sixth year of eligibility. He was 28-12 as starter and led the FBS in passing yards the past two seasons including throwing for 5,055 yards in 2015 becoming just the 14th QB to eclipse the 5,000 yard mark for a single season in FBS history. Doughty shows the mental capacity and enough of a physical skill set to potentially develop into a serviceable back-up. He projects as late round selection or priority free agent in the 2016 NFL draft. -- April 8, 2016 What he brings: Doughty led the FBS in passing yards the past two seasons and became just the 14th quarterback to eclipse the 5,000-yard mark for a single season in FBS history last year. However, he played in a quarterback-friendly spread scheme and he will need to get used to dropping from under center. Plus, he doesn't have great size and sustained a season ending knee injury (ACL) in 2011.
How he fits: The Dolphins don't have a pressing need at quarterback but Doughty has the mental capacity and enough of a physical skill set to potentially develop into a serviceable backup in Miami's scheme. -- Steve Muench

What he brings: Clark started 18 games at right guard, nine games at right tackle and six games at left tackle at Michigan State. He doesn't have the length to protect the edge at the NFL leve,l but he has the size, strength and enough athletic ability to provide depth at guard and possibly develop into a starter down the road.-- Steve Muench
What he brings: A UCLA transfer, Lucien lacks suddenness but has a good feel for routes and brings quality ball skills.
What he brings: Woodard isn't overly explosive and there are concerns about the level of competition he faced at Central Arkansas, but he has good size and above-average length. -- Steve Muench

Weatherley's production doesn't match his talent and he could have greatly improved his stock had he stayed in school. As it stands now he projects a late round pick based on his tape. That said he's a unique talent with considerable upside. He has a prototypical frame for a 34OLB/43DE, he has some experience lining up at middle linebacker and he flashes outstanding closing burst regardless of where he lines up. It's a risk but it wouldn't be a surprise to see a team take a chance on him early Day 3 as a result. March 28, 2016 What he brings: There aren't many 6-foot-4, 267-pound players who run a 4.61 40-yard dash and are versatile enough to line up at inside linebacker, outside linebacker or defensive end. His best fit is as a 3-4 outside linebacker, though he could play defensive end in a base four-man front. However, the production and tape don't match up with the talent, raising concerns he'll never realize his considerable potential. -- Steve Muench

Dixon was a senior bowl invite that handled the punting duties 37 straight games over the final three seasons of his career. He comes with quality make-up who blends in well with a locker room. Dixon has improved his leg strength and placement throughout his career but needs to continue to quicken up his delivery process. He projects as a late round to free agent prospect. April 7, 2016 What he brings: Dixon was a senior bowl invite and hard worker who has improved his leg strength and placement throughout his career but needs to continue to quicken his delivery process.-- Steve Muench

Ayers played all 39 games during his three seasons at Houston but only had 44 catches during his first two years. Ayers excelled in first-year coach Tom Herman's system (and more disciplined program), experiencing a breakout season as a junior in 2015 (98-1,222-12.5-6). Then he made a surprise decision to leave early for the 2016 NFL Draft. Ayers is an undersized slot-receiver/return specialist whose tape is better than his poor workout results (Combine and Pro Day). It won't be surprising if Ayers outplays his draft slot, but he's expected to be a mid-to-late Day 3 pick. -April 9, 2016 What he brings: Ayers is an undersized slot receiver/return specialist whose tape is better than his poor workout results. He is a quick player and is dangerous with the ball in his hand. While Ayers had some drops at Houston, he has the toughness to work the middle of the field and can show good focus in traffic. It won't be surprising if he ends up being one of the bigger bargains in this receiver class. -- Kevin Weidl

Braverman lacks prototypical size and comes with some durability concerns missing the entire 2013 season with a knee injury (ACL). In 2015, he was second in the FBS with 108 catches while adding 1,371 yards and 13 touchdowns. He also showed well against top-tier competition recording a combined 23 catches for 231 yards and a touchdown against Michigan State and Ohio State. Braverman projects a day three developmental Slot-WR prospect whose game is cut from the same cloth as a Wes Welker or Danny Amendola type. April 9, 2015 What he brings: Braverman is a tough, highly competitive and undersized slot receiver who is a quick athlete. He has a strong feel as a route runner and has excellent elusiveness to create yards after the catch. He played very well in games against Michigan State and Ohio State last season. His game is cut from the same cloth as a Wes Welker or Danny Amendola, and Braverman could end up being one of the bigger steals in this receiver class. -- Kevin Weidl

Duarte is a hybrid wide receiver-tight end prospect who improved every season at UCLA. He had his best season as a junior in 2015 (53-872-16.5-10) and elected to leave school early for the 2016 NFL Draft. He missed two games in 2014 with a hamstring injury but has been otherwise durable. Duarte's measurables are almost identical to Redskins H-Back Jordan Reed from the 2013 NFL Combine.Reed played a bit faster on tape but Duarte is a more polished receiver at the same point in their respective careers. Duarte grades out as an early Day-3 pick. April 8, 2016 What he brings: Duarte is an athletic hybrid wide receiver-tight end who improved every season at UCLA. He has identical measurables to Washington Redskins H-back Jordan Reed and a similar game with the athleticism and size to line up in multiple spots and create matchup problems. Reed was a bit faster on tape, but Duarte is more polished as a receiver at the same point of their careers. The former Bruin has a chance to thrive in the passing game in a multiple offensive system that mixes up personnel packages and uses a lot of shifts and motions. -- Kevin Weidl

Daniels is a three-year starter who played at the same high school as Boston College great and current Panther linebacker Luke Kuechley. He's a limited athlete with below average top-end speed and limited upside but he's a better football player than athlete. He has the potential o develop into an effective situational inside linebacker in a base 4-3 or 3-4 and a valuable special teams' contributor. March 20, 2016 What he brings: A three-year starter, Daniels played at the same high school as former Boston College and current Panthers linebacker Luke Kuechly. He's a limited athlete with below average top-end speed and limited upside, but he's a better football player than athlete. -- Steve Muench

Mills appeared in only 6 games (5 starts) in 2015 after suffering a broken fibula in preseason camp. He is an instinctive and versatile defender who lined up at DS and NB throughout his final two seasons at LSU. He also has experience at CB early in his career and lined up there during the week of the SR Bowl where he held up well. Mills does come with some character (Misdemeanor battery charge eventually dropped in summer of 2014). Mills should add immediate depth as a versatile defender who could quickly compete for a starting job. April 7, 2016 What he brings: Mills broke his fibula during the preseason and appeared in just six games last season, so there are durability concerns. Also, a misdemeanor battery charge that was ultimately dropped raises some concerns about Mills' off-the-field decision-making. On the field, Mills is an instinctive and versatile defender who has lined up at safety, corner and nickelback. He has above-average cover skills and is an adequate run defender. -- Steve Muench

Alexander started at left guard (adjacent to La'El Collins) for two seasons before moving to right tackle as the fulltime starter in 2015. He has great size, good game experience and above average strength, but he is heavy-footed and really struggles in space. Collins is frequently late getting into position and he lunges/leaves his feet far too often. Alexander's size/strength give him early-Day 3 value -- as a guard, not a tackle -- but he will need to significantly improve his footwork, balance and hands in order to win a starting job in the NFL. --March 15, 2016 What he brings: LSU's starting left guard for two seasons, Alexander moved to right tackle in 2015, and it's clear he's a better fit on the inside despite his long (35 inch) arms; he doesn't have the quickness or foot speed to protect the edge.
