Alexander, however, is a powerful run-blocker with the size and strength to develop into an effective reserve and possibly starting guard if he improves his footwork, balance and hand placement. -- Steve Muench
What he brings: Intriguing blend of size, power and top-end speed but comes with some durability concerns. -- Kevin Weidl

A two-time team captain Lasco appeared poised for a productive senior season after rushing for 1,115 yards and 12 touchdowns in 2014. Unfortunately a hip injury limited him early and an ankle injury limited him later in the season. The medical isn't the only issue either as he's had a hard time holding onto the ball. That said he recorded the fourth fastest 40, the top broad jump and the top vertical jump amongst the backs at the Combine so there's a lot to like about his upside. He's also effectively covered kicks and should help out special teams as he develops as a back. April 8, 2016 What he brings: Lasco is a two-time team captain with quality size and explosiveness for the position. He brings a strong combination of vision, lateral agility and versatility as a receiver in the passing game. Lasco has durability concerns due to hip and ankle injuries that limited him this past year. He has ball security issues that could ultimately affect his draft position, but he has a chance to add quality depth as a strong No. 2 back at the next level. -- Kevin Weidl
What he brings: Fuller is a leaner receiver with shorter arms and he's had some problems staying healthy, but he has intriguing top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

What he brings: He has an intriguing combination of size and athleticism that showed during his pro day testing. Has the potential be an early contributor on special teams while he develops as a player. -- Kevin Weidl

McCalister comes with some off-field baggage after being dismissed from the program in December before their bowl game for undisclosed reasons. As a prospect, he comes with upside as an edge defender due to his length and the athleticism he put on display during his workout at the combine in February. However, McCalister is a developmental project who doesn't have great instincts, needs a lot of technical work and must continue to add bulk and strength to become a consistent contributor at the next level. --April 8, 2016 What he brings: McCalister is a developmental edge-rushing prospect who is a better athlete than football player at this point. He has a long and lean frame with a nice combination of first quickness and flexibility bending the edge. However, he needs polish with hand usage and lacks ideal bulk and strength as a run defender. In addition, he comes with some character red flags that may affect his draft position. He has the potential to become a situational pass-rusher who will need to be a heavy contributor on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

A 2015 team captain Charone (shuh-RAHN) Peake's production doesn't match his talent in due in large part to knee injuries that forced him to miss almost all of the 2013 season and troubled him during the 2014 season. While he's a tough player who battled back and played in all 15 games last year, the medical will still have a substantial impact on where he's drafted. That said his blend of speed, length and size translates into rare upside making him an intriguing fringe Day 2 prospect. April 6, 2016 What he brings: A team captain, Peake missed almost all of the 2013 season after tearing his ACL in a practice and he appeared in just seven games after tearing his meniscus during the 2014 preseason, so durability is an obvious concern. He has an above-average blend of size and speed and he's underrated after the catch. His hands are inconsistent but he flashes the ability to pluck the ball out of the air and has a wide catching radius (34-inch arms and a 35 -inch vertical). -- Steve Muench

Marshall was a highly productive backup to Todd Gurley (Rams) as a freshman in 2012, rushing for 759 yards and 8 TDs on 117 carries (6.5) and catching 11 passes for 91 yards and one score. But a torn ACL in his right knee forced him to miss most of the next two seasons (2013-14). He played 10 games as a senior (2015) but was limited with just 68 carries and four catches. Marshall has an elite combo of size and straight-line speed, and he is a capable pass catcher. But he lacks lateral agility and durability is a major question mark. High upside for a late-round pick. -March 31, 2016 What he brings: He was a highly productive backup to Todd Gurley (Rams) as a freshman in 2012 at Georgia, but a torn ACL in his right knee forced him to miss most of the next two seasons (2013-14). He has an elite combination of size and straight-line speed, and he is a capable pass-catcher. But he lacks lateral agility, and durability is a major question mark. Marshall projects as a potential rotational back who could contribute on special teams if he can stay healthy. -- Kevin Weidl

Lawler elected to leave school after his junior season in 2015, when he finished with a team-high 52 receptions for 658 yards (12.7) and also led the team with 13 receiving touchdowns. Lawler has a long frame but needs to continue to add bulk and strength. He's a possession receiver who runs sharp routes and has outstanding ball skills. With just decent top-end speed, Lawler will never be a home run hitter. He grades out as a mid-round draft prospect. --March 17, 2016 What he brings: Lawler is a long and athletic receiver who possesses a wide catching radius. He lacks ideal top-end speed, but he is a quick, sharp route runner who is able to create separation out of cuts. Lawler possesses long arms, big hands and quality body control to adjust to throws outside of his frame. He needs to continue to add bulk and improve strength to become more consistent in contested situations. The former Jared Goff target has a chance to develop into a reliable No. 3 or No. 4 possession receiver. -- Kevin Weidl

Kearse is a versatile safety that lined up all over the field for the Tigers and holds up well near the box. The underclassmen probably could have used another year in school though particularly to develop his instincts. Average speed and he has some tightness (4.60 short-shuttle well below the 4.22 average for the position) which brings up concerns limiting separation in coverage. There are also efforts concerns on tape. Kearse currently projects as an early day three prospect that should add depth in a secondary with the potential to develop into a starter over time. April 8, 2016 What he brings: A versatile safety, Kearse lined up at the high point and near the box where he's big and strong enough to hold up. He flashes above-average straight-line burst when the ball is in the air, plus he has the size, length and athletic ability to match up with tight ends. Kearse also flashes above-average stopping power but he doesn't always seek out contact. His effort defending the run is inconsistent, and he has average instincts and ball skills. -- Steve Muench

Fejedelem (FEJ-uh-lem) transferred from little known St. Xavier in Chicago where he was on scholarship to walk on at Illinois in 2013. After redshirting in 2013 he played well enough in 2014 to earn a scholarship. He rewarded Illinois for its faith in him by breaking out for 140 tackles and he was named a team captain last year. He has the toughness and determination to develop into a core special teams' player and possibly provide depth at safety. However, he's an overachiever who could struggle to make an NFL roster, which is why he projects as a late round pick. April 10, 2016 What he brings: Fejedelem transferred from St. Xavier to walk on at Illinois where he finished fifth in the FBS in total tackles and was named a team captain last year He's also on the smaller side and his arm length (30.75 inches) is a red flag, but he's downhill run stopper and he shows average range in coverage. Fejedelem also tested better than expected at his pro day. He has the toughness, determination and athletic ability to develop into an effective backup and core special teams' player. -- Steve Muench

The former walk-on emerged as a four-year starter and finished his career with ridiculous production numbers (493 total tackles, 40 TFL, 7 sacks, 11 PBUs and 7 INTs) and was awarded the Nagurski and Bednarik trophies in 2015.Matakevich has outstanding intangibles and football character. His instincts and recognition skills are elite, which allows him to play much faster than his below-average timed speed (4.81 40-yard dash and 4.51 short shuttle at the NFL Combine). Still, he has physical limitations and will need to carve out a niche as a special teamer and reserve LB. -April 11, 2016 What he brings: We put Matakevich in the same category as linebacker Luke Kuechly and Sean Lee when it comes to instincts and recognition skills. That's high praise. A former walk-on, he is an above average tackler who shows good range on tape. However, he projects as a valuable situational linebacker who contributes on special teams -- his athletic limitations and below average third-down capabilities will likely prevent him from developing into an every-down player. -- Steve Muench
What he brings: An undersized runner who has a nice blend of quickness, speed and versatility in the passing game to develop into a change-of-pace back. -- Kevin Weidl

A 2015 team captain and four-year starter Blythe is a former high school wrestler who has lined up at all three interior offensive line positions for the Hawkeyes. He is light with short arms and he gets overwhelmed at times but he tests well in other key categories for centers most notably the short shuttle (4.53) and more importantly he's an overachiever who almost always finds a way to get the job done despite his deficiencies. He has the potential to develop into a quality starter in a zone heavy scheme and he projects as an early Day 3 pick as a result. April 8, 2016 What he brings: Blythe is an experienced, intelligent and tough player. He doesn't have elite size or athleticism, but he makes up for it by playing with quality leverage and displaying good technique. He takes sound angles as a run-blocker and does a nice job of moving his feet upon contact to stay engaged with blocks. Blythe has enough short-area quickness to mirror rushers in pass protection but will occasionally get rocked back by bigger, more powerful defensive tackles. He has a chance to add depth and potentially develop into a starter, ideally for a heavy zone-blocking team. -- Kevin Weidl

What he brings: Iworah is an undersized corner with excellent top-end speed, and he flashed signs of developing into a playmaker, intercepting four passes last year. He also has the potential to develop into an effective cover man on special teams. -- Steve Muench

A three-year starter and true junior Wright won the Bronko Nagurski Trophy, the Rotary Lombardi Award and the Chuck Bednarik Award in 2014 when he finished with 163 tackles, 29 tackles-for-loss and 14 sacks. Unfortunately injuries robbed him off the chance to duplicate those numbers in 2015 as a torn meniscus in his left knee and a sprained right foot limited him to three appearances. In addition to the medical concerns he hasn't tested well. However, he has the instincts, motor and toughness to develop into an effective reserve if not a reliable starter if he stays healthy. April 8, 2016 What he brings: It's impossible to talk about Wright without talking about his true sophomore season as he finished it with 163 tackles, 29 tackles for loss and 14 sacks. He gets an early break on the ball thanks to his above-average instincts, he does a good job of getting off blocks and he plays with great effort. However, he's an undersized inside linebacker who didn't test well at the NFL scouting combine, and there are concerns about his ability to stay healthy as a torn meniscus and foot injury limited him to three appearances last season. -- Steve Muench
What he brings: An instinctive linebacker with adequate point of attack skills and good balance as a tackler. -- Kevin Weidl

Sandland is a juco double transfer has limited playing experience with just 11 career starts all coming at Montana State in 2015 -- 2011-'12 Pierce CC - 2013 Miami - 2014-'15 Montana St. (RS in 2014) --. While he doesn't have an elite trait he an intriguing physical tool box due to his size, athleticism and strength as a blocker to develop into a functional Y at the next level. Sandland projects as a day 3 developmental prospect that could end up out performing his draft slot. March 17, 2016 What he brings: Sandland is a double transfer from Miami who lacks ideal experience (11 career starts) but has intriguing size (6-4, 253). He tested well at the combine, and that also transfers to the tape, in which he shows a nice speed-and-agility combination to create separation as a route runner. Sandland also flashes adequate run-after-the-catch ability. While he needs to work on his technique, he has adequate strength and power as an inline blocker. From a physical standpoint, Sandland has a chance to become a quality starting Y tight end if he is developed the right way. -- Kevin Weidl
What he brings: An instinctive cornerback with quality size and athleticism who shows very good ball awareness and production. -- Kevin Weidl

Briean Boddy-Calhoun (BREE-in, BOD-ee) is an undersized corner who comes with some durability issues after sustaining a season-ending knee injury (ACL) in 2013 and missed two games in 2015 with a minor knee injury. However, he improved as a tackler in 2015 and possesses the FBIs, short-area mirror skills and playmaking ability (10 career INT) to add quality depth as a sub-package nickel-back. Boddy-Calhoun also comes with good overall make-up and was selected as one of four team captains in 2015. He currently projects as a fringe day two selection. April 2, 2016

Cash was the 2015 ACC defensive player of the year who started 38 consecutive games the past three seasons before having wrist surgery in mid-December forcing him to miss the Pinstripe Bowl vs Indiana. He did participate at the Senior Bowl but did not work out at the combine or at his pro day (Hamstring). He is scheduled to work out on April 13th. Cash is in the mold of Deonne Buchanan as a hybrid LB/DS who is best fit near the box and should develop into a core special teams player. He projects as a mid-to-late day two selection. April 2, 2016

Powell graduated in three years and elected to leave early for the 2016 NFL draft. He underwent surgery to repair a sports hernia injury in the summer of 2014, but played in all 42 games during his career and finished with 195 total tackles, 9 PBUs and 8 INTs. Powell has ideal size and he's a clutch performer (including Defensive MVP in National Championship Game 2014) but he has some athletic limitations and doesn't quite play to timed speed (4.46). He projects as an early-Day 3 pick, and may need to be a core special teams player to secure a roster spot early in his career. -April 6, 2016

Braunecker is coming off a breakout senior season at Harvard catching eight touchdown passes in 10 games and averaging 17.7 yards per catch. His ability to make the jump to the NFL from the Ivy League is obviously a concern. He's a raw route runner and -- to an even greater degree -- blocker at this point. But there's a lot to like about his frame, competitiveness and upside, making him an intriguing Day 3 prospect. --April 11, 2016

Cajuste redshirted after tearing his ACL in 2011. He was a four-year player and three-year contributor on offense, averaging 17.7 yards on 90 career catches with 14 for touchdowns. He missed multiple games during his career due to multiple injuries (concussion, ankle and illness). He's a possession receiver with excellent size and good ball skills. He can create some mismatches from the inside WR spot, but he lacks the toughness and strength to block as a converted H-back. Cajuste carries Day 3 grade. -April 12, 2016

Elston is a four year starter (46 total starts) who played multiple roles in the Rebel's secondary. In 2015, he switched from his rover spot to replace Cody Prewitt at FS where he had more opportunities and had career highs in INTs (4) and PBUs (14). While he lacks ideal size he brings a physical element to his game. Elston did not get an invite to the combine but tested well at his pro day. He does come with some minor character (Disorderly conduct arrest) but has quality football make-up. He holds a mid-round grade with the potential to push for a starting job at FS. April 8, 2016

A 2015 team captain Ferguson rushed for over 700 yards in each of the last three seasons and caught a total of 137 passes during that span. He's undersized, he doesn't project as an every-down back and he has had some problems staying healthy. He missed three games with a shoulder injury last year, he received a medical redshirt after missing most of the 2011 season with a hamstring injury and he appeared to pull up with a hamstring injury at the Combine. He still projects as a Day 3 pick though and the reason is he has the potential to develop into a productive third down back. April 9, 2016

Fanaika played his first two years at Utah State (2010-'11) before taking 2012 off to fulfill a church mission. Enrolled at Utah where he RS in 2013 season before making 13 starts over his final 2 seasons (2014-'15). Fanaika plays a physical game and is at his best setting the edge as a run defender. However, while he has quality speed to power ability as an edge rusher, he may struggle to become an impact rusher at the NFL level due to lack of height and initial quickness. Improved forty from 4.92 to 4.84 at pro day. Fanaika projects as a day three developmental edge defender. April 5, 2016

Woods played 50 of 54 games (33 starts) during four seasons at USC. He tore his pectoral muscle in 2014 and missed the Holiday Bowl (and spring practice). But he fully recovered and had his best year as a senior in 2015, starting 13 games (missed ASU, shoulder) and finishing with 41 tackles, 7 TFLs and 3 sacks. He stood out as the top player at the NFLPA game but then re-injured his pec at the Combine (bench press). Woods lacks ideal measurables and will never be a great pass rusher but he can develop into a contributing NFL backup. He grades out as an early Day 3 prospect. -March 27, 2016

Brown took steps as a route runner this year and had a career high in catches (48), receiving yards (597) and touchdowns (4) in 2015. He has above-average play speed for the position but needs to continue to develop his strength and become more consistent catching the ball. Jones also showed well at the East-West Shrine Bowl. He projects as a mid-day 3 selection. March 16, 2016

Cowser was a three-time team captain at Southern Utah and a highly productive FCS player who broke Jared Allen's Big Sky Conference records for career sacks and tackles for loss. While he's light with shorter arms for a DE prospect, he has the tools to make an impact as a situational pass rusher regardless of the scheme and the potential to develop into an every-down 3-4 OLB. --April 10, 2016

Jones lacks ideal size but has a nice combination quickness and elite top-end speed. He needs to play with more eye discipline and he is vulnerable against bigger receivers in one-on-one jump ball situations due to his size deficiency. Jones has taken advantage of the post-season process with a strong showing at the Senior Bowl and the NFL Scouting Combine (4.33 40-yard dash and 36-inch vertical jump). He has the mirror skills to add depth in a secondary as a nickel-back at the next level. Jones holds an early Day 3 grade heading into April's draft. February 29, 2016

Jones is the son of former East Carolina All-American and NFL linebacker Robert Jones. He has the frame to make contested catches underneath and the catching radius to develop into a productive red zone target. While he also plays faster on tape, his timed top-end speed (4.65 40) and 10-yard split raise substantial red flags. Plus, there are character concerns. He started his college career at Texas, where he was arrested for assault and suspended in 2013. He transferred to Arizona later that summer. He projects as a Day 3 pick. --March 26, 2016.

A two-year starter at Indiana and a true junior, Latham got suspended twice in 2015, raising concerns about his maturity and commitment to the team. With that said, he makes an impact when you throw on the tape and he finished last year with ten tackles-for-loss and four sacks . Plus, he's versatile enough to line up on the inside or outside of a four-man front and his best fit may be at defensive end in a base three-man front. He projects as a Day 3 pick. --April 10, 2016

Team captain and four-year starter Allen is a former high school wrestler who has lined up at center and left guard. He's an undersized interior offensive lineman with average athletic ability and he's missed time with injuries in each of the last three seasons. He may never develop into an NFL starter but he's an overachiever that has the smarts, toughness and enough strength to develop into an effective backup. He projects as a Day 3 pick. April 8, 2016

Scott is under-the-radar prospect that was never able to fully maximize his potential due to some accountability and character issues including being benched against Georgia Tech this past year for being late for a practice. That said, he is highly competitive player that has a good feel for the position along with the physical skill set to potentially develop into a quality number three receiver. Teams will need to weigh where the risk is worth the reward and while Scott's tape warrants a fringe day two grade, he could very fall into the mid-to-late day 3 range. March 15, 2016

A true junior North is a classic high risk high reward player. On one hand, he tore his labrum at the end of the 2014 season then sprained a knee and sustained a back injury last year limiting him to seven games so the medical is obviously a concern. It doesn't help that those injuries played a big role in North catching just six passes last year. As far as the potential reward is concerned few receivers have his blend of size, top-end speed, length and hand size. if he stays healthy and realizes his considerable potential he could be the biggest steal in this draft. April 8, 2016

Ochi (OH-chee) is a small school prospect who recorded 13 sacks last year and manhandles FCS tackles at times on tape. However, in addition to the level of competition he faced at Stony Brook there are other issues that could prevent him from getting drafted. He's an undersized defensive end whose top-end speed and testing raises concerns about his ability to transition to outside linebacker. Finally, he's a hard worker with good football character but there are some concerns about his maturity away from football. -March 28, 2016

Keyaris (Key-AIR-is) Garrett is a vertical receiver who poses as a one-on-one mismatch due to his size and ability to create late separation. He led the FBS in receiving yards in 2015 with 1,588 yards on 96 catches and 8 touchdowns. He has strong intangibles but does come with durability after breaking his leg in the 2013 season opener and receiving a medical hardship. Impressive combine test results for size. Garrett has a specific skill set that will appeal to teams looking for red zone help. He currently projects as a mid-day three prospect. -- April 9, 2016

Harris is a former defensive lineman who moved to the offensive line in 2012 and only started 18 games at offensive tackle while facing weaker competition that he would have faced had he played for a power-5 conference school. He is a project who is unlikely to make substantial contributions early in his career. In addition, a 2011 season-ending head injury raises concern about his longterm durability. He still projects as a potential Day 3 pick because of upside, as he has the frame, length and athletic ability to develop into an effective swing tackle. March 17, 2016

Marshall was a versatile weapon at Oregon where he rushed for over 1,000 yards in 2013, finished with over 1,000 receiving yards after moving to receiver in 2014 and flashed as a kickoff return man last year. He flashes above average burst with and without the ball in his hands on tape. However, he missed most of 2015 after undergoing season-ending ankle surgery, the injury prevented him from working out at the Combine and it may have played a role in him not testing as well as expected at his Pro Day. He's an intriguing Day 3 prospect with all of that in mind. March 23, 2016

Lawrence-Stample was an oft-injured underachiever for most of his career (missed all but four games with a pectoral injury in 2014 and failed to record a sack in first three seasons). But he had his best year in 2015 (played in all 13 games and finished with 36 total tackles, 3.5 TFL, 2.5 sacks), emerging as a hard-nosed one-gap run defender for the Seminoles. Lawrence-Stample won't offer much as a pass rusher but he can contribute in a rotation and he has some scheme versatility. He grades out as a mid-Day 3 prospect. -March 30, 2016

Norris was a team captain who has three years of starting experience (32 total starts) and comes with a relentless work ethic. He doesn't excel in any one area but he is an instinctive run defender (24 career TFLs) that good overall range. He comes with some minor durability including missing 2 games in 2013 with an unknown injury while sitting out the USC this past fall with a knee injury. Improved his 40-time from 4.80 to 4.73 at his pro day. Norris projects as a day 3 developmental prospect who has the mentality/athleticism to contribute on special teams early on. April 5, 2016

The cousin of Chiefs' inside linebacker Derrick Johnson Sharp is a junior college transfer who put up good albeit not spectacular numbers in his two seasons at Utah State catching 137 passes for total of 1,774 yards and 16 touchdowns. He projects as a sub-package slot receiver who could also compete for a kickoff return role as he returned a kickoff 96 yards for a touchdown against Nevada last year. However, his average blend of size, speed and burst makes him a Day 3 value. April 8, 2016

Addison missed 2014 with an ACL tear but he was productive for the Ducks during his three seasons on the field, especially 2013 (61-890-14.6-7) and 2015 (63-804-12.8-10). In addition to his production as a receiver those two years, he rushed for 105 yards and two TDs on 20 carries and averaged 13.6 yards per punt return with three more scores. Addison is a slippery runner but he's a raw offensive weapon with marginal combination of size and speed. We're just not sure he's explosive enough to spend time trying to manufacture touches, which is the reason for his Day 3 grade. -March19, 2016

Elliott is a three year starter that has a strong combination of length and athleticism to work with (Tested well at the combine particularly with jumps). He needs to continue to add bulk and strength and can become more discipline in coverage. Elliott also comes with some off the field baggage (Arrested for unlawful sexual contact and two counts of second degree criminal trespassing in an on campus sorority as a freshman in 2012). He currently projects as a mid-to-late round selection with the potential to add depth to a secondary. April 8, 2016

A team captain Skura was a three-year starter at Duke where he primarily lined up at guard as a backup early in his career and then moved to center fulltime in 2013. He is a big-bodied center who isn't flashy on tape and has athletic limitations. However, he's a better football player than athlete and he almost always finds a way to get the job done thanks in large part to his effort and football smarts. He projects as a backup center with the ability to play guard in a pinch and the potential to develop into an adequate starter. March 20, 2016

Turner is a four-year starter and the nephew of 1970s Buffalo Bills fullback Jim Braxton. He has the size and strength to develop into an effective backup and possibly start for an offense that features a power running game. However, he's a below average pass blocker and the way he tested at the Combine is a concern. In addition to having shorter arms his top-end speed and broad jump raise substantial red flags. March 20, 2016

The younger brother of Bears' outside linebacker Willie Young and cousin of Panthers' outside linebacker Thomas Davis Avery Young started 36 games at Auburn where he predominantly lined up at right tackle but also played both guard spots. He has the potential to develop into a versatile reserve with that in mind. However, he doesn't excel in any one area on tape, his injury history raises concern about long-term durability and he didn't test as well as expected at the Combine or his pro day. March 12, 2016

A 2015 team captain Foster changed his primary positon from running back to a receiver in 2015 and caught fewer passes than he did in 2014. In addition, he's on the smaller side and his 4.57 40-time at the Combine was underwhelming. However, he's a versatile player who ran better at his Pro Day, flashes quick-twitch explosiveness on tape and plays a number of different roles. It's also worth noting that his ability to run between the tackles out of spread sets thanks to his vision and burst is comparable to San Diego RB Danny Woodhead's ability to do the same. March 10, 2016

Greene is a three-year starter who is big and strong enough to make an NFL roster but that's far from a lock considering he's a marginal athlete  his 4.98 short shuttle time is a red flag  with shorter arms and erratic tape. In addition, San Diego State suspended him for six games in 2015 for testing positive for marijuana and he missed the Hawaii Bowl because he was academically ineligible so there are concerns about his off-the-field decision making and maturity. March 11, 2016

Johnson is a junior college transfer who led the Wildcats in tackles-for-loss and tied for second on the team in total tackles with 67 last year. At times, he jumps out on tape and he would have graded out higher had he regularly played the way he did against Missouri and Eastern Kentucky last year. But his inconsistent play, his diminutive frame and his suspension for the 2015 season opener are all red flags. Plus he's not scheme versatile, as his best fit is clearly at defensive tackle in a base four-man front. As a result, he projects as a Day 3 pick. --April 11, 2016

Longa is a highly productive three-year starter who lined up on the inside and the outside at Rutgers and declared for the draft following his redshirt junior season. His testing raises red flags as he ran a 4.56 short shuttle and 7.50 three-cone at the Combine. He performed better at his pro day but he had lost five pounds and there were already concerns about his ability to anchor between the tackles. It's unclear where he fits best as a result but he's a tough and disciplined player with the motor to provide depth and contribute on special teams. April 1, 2015

Okwara doubled his sack total from 2014 (8 sacks in 2015) and became a more consistent run defender in 2015. He possesses a strong work ethic and has added 10 pounds at his pro day from the prior spring. His game is predicated more on physicality and power than athleticism. While he's a 34OLB conversion candidate he's not as effective in space as he is attacking upfield. He projects as a Day 3 pick that could add quality depth as an edge defender along the front seven. April 3, 2016

Shumate has three years of starting experience and is a strong safety prospect with an above average blend of height, weight and speed. He's at his best defending the run, and lacks ideal playmaking ability in the back end (11 PBUs and 2 INTs in 25 career starts). Suspended for the Stanford game in 2013 after reportedly showing up late for a team meeting but overall character is not a big concern. Shumate has the ability to add depth but will need to be a heavy contributor on special teams early in his career while he develops. He projects as a mid-round selection. April 2, 2016

There's a lot to like about Wilds' size-speed combination and ability to impact third down but injuries prevented him from realizing his potential in college and the concern is durability will prevent him from doing the same in the pros. There are also concerns about maturity that stem in part from him reportedly telling the coaching staff he wasn't going to play against LSU the day of the game even though he had been medically cleared and had returned to practice. March 15, 2016

Williams, a two-time walk-on at Marshall and ECU, played all 38 games during three seasons for the Pirates. He caught 38 passes in his first two seasons, but his production spiked in 2015, finishing second on the team with 58 catches for 588 yards (10.1) and four TDs. Williams has ideal size, he's a reliable target and has potential as a blocker. He's also durable and has outstanding football character. But Williams is speed deficient and lacks lower-body explosiveness, so he has a low ceiling as a pass catcher in the NFL. He grades out as a Day 3 prospect. -March 1, 2016

McRoberts is three year starter and two time team captain that was also a member of the schools' basketball team early in his career. He has intriguing length, range and ball skills to create late separation but lacks prototypical speed and quickness on tape, and must continue to hone his craft as a route runner. He led the Red Hawks in 2015 with 76 catches for 940 yards (12.4) and nine touchdowns. Senior Bowl participant. Missed five games in 2014 while dealing with a Liisfranc injury on his right foot. He projects as a mid-to-late day three selection in April's draft. -April 9, 2016

Ufomba Kamalu (oo-FAHM-buh) is a junior college transfer (Butler CC) who was a rotational starter in his three season at Miami (10 career starts). He is still very raw in terms of technique and instincts but has exceptional size, length and raw strength combination to go along with quality athleticism. Kamalu also comes with very good intangibles, work ethic and is very coachable which is a positive sign for his ability to develop. He projects as a mid-to-late day three selection who has the potential to develop into a rotational back-up. March 11, 2016

A three-year starter and the cousin of Texans receiver DeAndre Hopkins Smith has had to overcome great family tragedy and the loss of his father former Clemson wide receiver Terry at a young age. His injury history including an ankle injury that forced him to miss four games last year raises concerns about his medical and he may never develop into a fulltime starter at the NFL level but he has the potential to develop into an effective backup and core special teams' player. April 8, 2016

Beniquez (ben-KNEE-quez) Brown is an undersized linebacker who started for two years and declared for the draft following a productive redshirt junior season. He's an above average tackler who plays with a good motor and has adequate range but last year was by far his most productive season and there are concerns about his frame even after weighing in at 236 pounds at his Pro Day. He projects as backup weak side linebacker who provides quality depth and makes valuable contributions on special teams. March 28, 2016

Johnstone is a three-year starter who missed the 2014 season with a knee injury. The injury raises concerns about his medical even though he started all 13 games for Oregon last year and he looked rusty early on in 2015. However, his tape improved as the season progressed and he tested well at the combine. He has the potential to develop into an effective starter with improved strength and technique plus he should provide quality depth early in his career if he stays healthy. March 23, 2016

Striker was a team captain that started in 38 consecutive games over his final 3 seasons and had a highly productive career (46.5 TFLs, 23.5 sacks). He is a tweener that doesn't have an ideal fit in the NFL. On a positive note he has natural FBI's and with the NFL game implementing more spread concepts he has a chance to contribute as sub-package nickel-LB who could provide some help as a speed rusher and has enough range to hold up in coverage. He projects as day 3 pick who will need to thrive on special teams to have longevity at the next level. April 7, 2016

Lewis is a true sophomore that spent a year at a prep school before joining Bowling Green prior to the 2013 season. He has quality measureables, a good feel for the position and is coming off of a highly productive season where he was second in the FBS in receiving yards with 1,544 on 85 catches (18.2 YPC) and 16 touchdowns. Teams will need to do some investigating on a pair of rape allegations that were later dropped back in 2011 and 2012 when Lewis was in high school. Lewis projects as a mid-day three developmental prospect with a chance to add depth to receiver corps. April 8, 2016

Marshall finished his two-year career with 74 catches for 976 yards (13.2 ypc) and 11 TDs. He also averaged 12.7 yards on 52 punt returns, including one touchdown. He had knee surgery (torn meniscus) the spring of 2014 season and was suspended for the 2015 opener vs. Virginia Tech (marijuana). Marshall was a surprise early-entree whose sub-par combine 40-yard dash time did not help his cause. He's a raw slot receiver with the ability to create with the ball in his hands. His best asset might be punt returning if he proves reliable fielding the ball. Marshall has Day 3 value. -March 6, 2016

Heath is a tweener who played defensive end before moving to defensive tackle at Michigan State. He's on the taller side with below average bulk for a DT prospect and he doesn't have ideal quickness for a LDE prospect. His best fit may be at 34DE with that in mind. He's also got limited upside as a pass rusher but he has the potential to develop into an effective run stopper whether he lines up at 34DE or DT. He projects as a Day 3 pick. April 11, 2016

Aziz Shittu (uh-ZEEZ, SHITT-too) comes with some durability issues after appearing in only five games in 2014 before suffering a season ending knee injury in practice. As a prospect he is a versatile run defender who has a chance to add depth along a defensive line but needs to develop more as a pass rusher. Did not test well at pro day and 40-time (5.40) and vertical jump (29.5") are near or below the red flag thresh hold line for the position. As it stands now he projects as a late round to undrafted free agent. -- April 8, 2016

Thompson was recruited as a TE before switching to the defensive side of the ball after his redshirt year in 2012. He brings upside as an edge rusher due to his first-step quickness and active hands. But he must continue to improve his overall power and become more consistent as a run defender to become a three-down player. 40-yard dash (4.95 below red flag line of 4.88) and broad jump (8'10") were both well below average test results. Thompson projects as a potential late round selection who may need a year or two on a practice squad to add bulk and improve his strength. --April 8, 2016

Wallace is a fourth year junior who started his career at Washington before electing to transfer to San Jose State after the 2013 season. He has good overall instincts to go along with good short-area quickness (6.87 3-cone, 4.25 SS), so he fits best in a heavy zone-coverage scheme. Improved 40-yard dash from 4.68 at combine to 4.58 at pro day. Wallace must continue to get stronger so he can improve as a run defender and hold up better in one-on-one contested situations against more physical receivers. He projects as a mid-to-late Day 3 selection.-- April 8, 2016

Lee played in all 39 games during his final three seasons at Baylor. He was a big-play weapon for Baylor, averaging 20.2 yards per catch with eight of 36 catches for touchdowns in 2015. He won't be as much of a vertical weapon in the NFL but he does possess a good combination of size and speed, and he has developed into a savvier receiver when the ball is in the air. Lee improved during his senior season and had a strong showing at the Senior Bowl. He grades out as a Day 3 prospect. -April 9, 2016

McGee had been expected to play an important role when he transferred from Virginia to Florida in 2014 but broke the tibia and fibula in his left leg in the season opener. He bounced back by catching 41 passes for 381 yards and four touchdowns while playing in 13 of 14 games. That said, he's an F prospect who flashes some upside as a receiver and he has the work ethic to get better but gets pushed around at times as a blocker and whose injury history raises concerns about his long-term durability. He projects as a late round pick as a result. March 4, 2016

Vanhoose is an experienced four year starter that flashes quality instincts and awareness for the position. He needs some technical work with his footwork but shows good explosiveness and short-area quickness. The biggest questions for him as a prospect is his top-end speed and overall range which makes him a better fit in a heavy cover-two or zone scheme. Missed 2015 Outback Bowl (Hand). Did not workout for teams as he did not receive an invite at the combine and was not at pro day for personal reasons. Vanhoose projects as a mid-to-late day three developmental prospect. April 8, 2016

Anderson played tight end at Cal but projects as a big wide receiver in the NFL, where he might be best suited to work out of the slot. The former walk-on was a productive pass catcher during 37 games (25 starts), finishing with 101 catches for 1,260 yards and seven touchdowns. Anderson projects as a late-round pick and will need to find a niche in the right offense (and on special teams) in order to stick on a roster. --March 17, 2016

Nicknamed Rockhead Johnson is a former linebacker and tight end who moved to running back in 2014 and ran for 1,767 yards despite missing most of three games with a torn labrum. Unfortunately, injuries including a back injury limited him to 94 carries last year. Hs medical will play a big role in whether or not he gets drafted and his lack of experience raises another red flag. However, he's a powerful short-yardage runner with excellent football character, the frame to move to fullback and the potential to develop into a core special teams' player. April 4, 2016

Kirkland is an underclassmen who could have used another year in school. After starting his career on the interior offensive line at OG, he kicked out to LOT in 2015. He's not a great fit at tackle, due to a lack of overall athleticism confirmed by poor test results (5.22 short-shuttle is well below the red flag line of 4.82). Kirkland has a massive frame and quality core strength for an OG, but he bends at his waist far too often. He has to learn to play with better leverage if he is going to stick on a roster. He currently projects as a late-round developmental prospect. -- April 8, 2016

An Arkansas transfer Mekale McKay (muh-KALE muh-KAY) has good size and flashes above average athleticism making him an intriguing Day 3 prospect. However, he's coming off an underwhelming senior season from a production standpoint, his tape is erratic and he drops far too many passes he should catch. Plus he didn't run as well as expected and his frame is somewhat misleading considering he has short arms. March 15, 2016

Bentley has three years of starting experience and brings added value on special teams as a returner. He shows adequate instincts and change of direction skills on tape. However, his short-shuttle time is below the red flag line (4.35) for the position which gets magnified with his lack of ideal size. Just average top-end speed and he's not a playmaker at this point (2 career INTs) . Bentley best fit will be with in a heavy zone or cover-2 scheme or potentially in the slot as a nickel. He currently projects as a late round selection or free agent. April 6, 2016

A combine snub Kreiger-Coble (KRAY-gurr CO-bull) has the tenacity to develop into an adequate positional blocker and enough talent to develop into a reliable check down receiver but there are two concerns. He caught a total of seven passes heading into 2016 and he didn't exactly break loose as a senior when he caught 32 passes for 385 yards and one touchdown. He is also a slightly undersized tight end prospect who projects as strictly an F or move blocker and he sustained a season-ending shoulder injury in 2014. March 4, 2016

A three-year starter McKinzy lined up at weak side linebacker, middle linebacker and Buck at Auburn finishing his career with 263 tackles. He's at his best stuffing the inside run and flashed some upside as a pass rusher in 2015 when he recorded five sacks. However, his athletic limitations will likely prevent him from developing into an every-down player and he's had recent problems staying healthy as he sustained a concussion early in the season and sprained his knee against Memphis in the bowl game. He also injured his hamstring while recovering from the knee injury. April 8, 2016

Oakman has exceptional measureables who is a better athlete than football player at this point. After 11 sacks in 2014 sack total dropped to 4.5 in 2015 (4 sacks early in year vs sub-par competition and only 1/2 sack over the final 6 games when getting into meat of the Big 12). Off-the-field baggage is a red flag as he was dismissed from PSU in 2012, suspended for 2015 opener vs SMU (violation of team rules), and recently had sexual assault charges brought against him in the beginning of April. Oakman is a mid-day 3 pick who will need major development to reach potential. April 7, 2016

Treggs, whose father Brian played for the Seahawks and 49ers, was a surprising non-invite to the NFL Combine. He was highly productive four-year slot receiver for Cal, finishing tied for third in school history with 195 catches for 2,506 yards and 15 touchdowns. As a senior, he led Cal with 45 catches and averaged 21.2 ypc. He's undersized but played in every game during his final three seasons at Cal. Based off his tape, production and workout results at Cal's Pro Day; Treggs has big play ability and could be a late-round value pick. --March 17, 2016

Allison is a junior college transfer (Iowa Western) and two year starter for Illinois. He recorded 85 catches for 882 yards and three touchdowns in 2015 but saw his production dip late in the year where he had just 17 catches for 182 yards over the final five games. Allison has upside with quality length and athleticism but needs to continue to get stronger in order to play to his size. Improved 40-yard dash from 4.67 at combine to 4.54 at pro day. He projects as a late round developmental prospect. -- April 9, 2016

A three-time team captain and four-year starter Brendel (BREN-dul) has impressive intangibles and he tested well at the Combine. He flashes the potential to develop into an effective starter in a zone heavy scheme but the tape doesn't match his natural ability. He's not as fundamentally sound as you'd expect from a four-year starter plus he doesn't have great versatility as his below average power base and average size raise questions about his ability to line up at guard. March 26, 2016

Craddock is from Australia where he learned to kick playing Australian rules football. He is coming off a season-ending hand injury and he doesn't have elite leg strength but he's an accurate place kicker with the ability to fill in at punter in a pinch. He projects as a Day 3 pick or rookie free agent as a result. April 11, 2016

Malleck isn't as much of a threat in the passing game as teams would prefer for an F prospect and he's undersized for a Y prospect. Plus his frame and injury history raise concern about his long-term durability. On the other hand, he's a reliable receiver and he has the tenacity to develop into an adequate positional blocker. He's also a 2015 team captain with good work ethic. As a result, he projects as a late Day 3 pick. March 3, 2016

Born in Cameroon Stephane Nembot (steff-on name-bot) didn't start playing football until his junior year of high school and the redshirt senior still started for four years at Colorado. He made substantial progress both physically as he added substantial weight to his frame and as a player in college. In addition he has the frame length and the experience lining up on both sides to develop into an effective swing tackle. However, his footwork, hand fighting and strength are still works in progress so he'll need time and coaching to unlock his considerable upside. March 17, 2016

Pettway was a fifth-year senior that redshirted in 2011 and spent 2013 at East Mississippi CC after his arrest for second degree robbery. He was never a fulltime starter at Alabama and finished his three seasons (2012, 2014, 2015) with 48 total tackles, 12.5 TFLs and 7 sacks. He was a rotational defensive end that also kicked inside to defensive tackle (4-3) and five-technique (3-4). He had early behavioral issues but did a lot of maturing during his career at Alabama and has developed into a solid worker with adequate football intelligence. Pettway could be a late-round value. -April 8, 2016

Wujciak (Woe-JACK) started 38 games at Boston College where he helped anchor a defense that gave up fewer yards per game than any other FBS defense last year and his father Alan played offensive guard on Notre Dame's 1973 national championship team. He's unlikely to develop into a fulltime starter but he has enough ability to become an effective reserve 43 nose tackle in an aggressive one-gap scheme which is why he projects as a Day 3 pick. April 11, 2016

Green started his career at Nebraska before transferring to TCU to be closer to home. He lacks ideal size and power but has the quickness, speed and enough versatility in the passing game to develop into a rotational change of pace runner at the next level. Green comes with quality make-up including a strong work ethic and passion for the game. He also showed well during the Senior Bowl game back in Janurary. Green projects as a mid-to-late round selection. March 17, 2016

Leblanc is a two-year starter who has made strides from early in his career in terms of preparation. He lacks ideal measurables and appears quicker than fast on tape (4.66 40-yard dash at pro-day), making him more of a fit as a potential nickel back at the next level. Leblanc does show above average instincts and plays bigger than his size indicates when battling for the ball (21 PBU's, 6 INTs for career). Leblanc projects as a mid-to-late Day 3 developmental prospect in the 2016 NFL draft. --April 8, 2016

A 2015 team captain Maddy started 46 games at Virginia Tech and bounced back from a 2014 season-ending knee injury to finish fourth on the team in tackles last year. He's at his best making plays in the backfield and his highlight reel is impressive. That said his frame raises a significant red flag about his ability to hold up against the run and stay healthy. He's not scheme versatile either, as he projects as a reserve defensive tackle in an aggressive one-gap base four-man front. He grades out as a late round pick or rookie free agent as a result. April 11, 2016

Mehdi Abdesmad (Meh-DEE Ab-des-MAHD) is a Canadian-born defensive lineman who was injury riddled for most of his career (played just seven games with five starts in 2013 and 2014 combined) at Boston College but finally had a breakout season as a senior in 2015, finishing with 59 total tackles, 15 TFLs and 5 sacks. His best fit will be as a five-technique DE in a base 3-4 front. He needs to continue improve his leverage and continue to develop his hands (as a pass rusher and run defender) to win a spot on a team's 53-man roster. Abdesmad grades out as a late-round prospect. March 31, 2016

Cheek is looking to follow in the footsteps of his father Louis who played offensive tackle for the Aggies and was an eighth round selection of the Miami Dolphins in 1988. He has the potential to develop into a reliable reserve guard but he needs to get stronger at the point and fill out of his frame if he's to play a significant role at the NFL level. March 9, 2016

Coprich is a highly productive FCS back who rushed for 50 touchdowns and more than 4,000 yards over the past two seasons. He has the potential to develop into an effective change-of-pace back who pushes for a kickoff return role but he doesn't project as an every-down back and he needs to make strides in pass pro to regularly contribute on third down. There are also concerns about his off-the-field decision making as he was arrested for allegedly trying to sell marijuana to an undercover police officer during the 2015 off-season. April 4, 2016

Friend and inside linebacker Tyler Matakevich are the first three-time captains in Temple history. He's an overachiever who found ways to get the job done via effort and upper body strength at the college level but his frame and length (30 7/8' arms) raise concerns about his ability to contribute at the NFL level. That said a team looking for depth at center could take a chance on him late or sign him as a rookie free agent. March 8, 2016

Gronkowski would be the fourth Gronkowski brother to play in the NFL if he were to make it. Though he hasn't sustained any serious injuries to the best of our knowledge, he told Sports Illustrated that seeing his brothers battle injuries factored into his decision to leave school early. He's an effective blocker with the potential to develop into an adequate receiver in time, but he'll likely have to make an impact on special teams to make an NFL roster. As a result, he projects as a late-round pick or rookie free agent. --February 29, 2016

Peterson is a two year starter who have average measureables for the position. He has adequate quickness but he lacks ideal range and is vulnerable against bigger receivers who can stretch the field. Average career ball production (23 PBUs, 5 INTs). Played in the Senior Bowl. Peterson ideal fit is for a heavy zone scheme at the next where he also brings experience playing in the slot.He projects as a late round developmental prospect at the next level. -- April 8, 2016

Wilson is a two-year starter that also was a member of the Bulldog's basketball team in 2013-14 before focusing on football in 2014 spring drills. His basketball background shows up on tape where in contested 50/50 situations where he has the size and body control to create late separation. However, he is limited route tree runner and his forty-yard dash (4.85) and vertical jump (28") are well below the red flag line for the position. Wilson will need to be an exceptional red zone target to have longevity at the next level. He projects as mid-to-late day three pick. March 8, 2016

Alexander, whose father played defensive tackle at Oklahoma State, started 34 games at Oklahoma and eclipsed the 100-tackle mark each of the past two seasons before declaring for the draft as a junior. While he flashes the potential to develop into an effective backup on tape, his testing raises red flags about where he might fit. He weighed in at 224 pounds at his pro day plus his short-shuttle and three-cone times raised flags abut ability to hold up in space. A team could take chance on him late in Day 3 because of his production and potential to contribute on special teams. April 1, 2016

Tra (TREY) Carson is an Oregon transfer whose sub-par burst will likely prevent him from developing into a primary ball carrier and you'd like to see him pick up more yards after contact considering his size. However he's still an intriguing late-round pick or rookie free agent considering he has the skill set to help a team in a number of ways. He's a tough runner with good vision, he can help out as a check-down receiver or blocker on passing downs and he has the potential to develop into a core special teams' player. March 9, 2016

Maggitt is a high-effort player with an adequate skill set. However, durability is a major concern after suffering a season ending hip injury in the 2nd game against Oklahoma in 2015 (also missed 2013 - ACL injury and missed 2015 spring practice - shoulder surgery). While Maggitt has excellent football character he was named in a pending lawsuit by 6 females against the University where he allegedly assaulted a former teammate who was friends with one of the women. Maggitt has upside as a pass rushing 34 OLB but his durability could have an affect on his draft stock. April 5, 2016

Mayes is a massive nose tackle prospect with the frame to develop into a space eater who clogs up the middle and helps keep his linebackers clean. However, he'll need to learn to play with better pad level against the run and he doesn't offer much as a pass rusher. In addition, his ability to keep his weight down and his ability to stay healthy are concerns. He projects a s a late round pick or rookie free agent consequently. April 11, 2016

Crawley is a four-year starter (48 career starts) who has above-average size and tested well at the combine in February. He is most effective in press-technique where he can use his size and range to his advantage. Crawley has a knack for getting his hands on throws (31 career PBUs) but doesn't always attack the ball in the air and needs to become more of a finisher (3 career INTs). He grew up in a rough part of southeast Washington DC where his best friend was murdered prior to him enrolling at Colorado which he uses as motivation. He projects as a late round selection. March 14, 2016

Frost is a two year starter (22 total) starts who comes with good football character and a steady approach to the game. While he has adequate instincts he did not have as many impact plays as a senior (2014: 10 TFLs, 2015: 3 TFLs). In addition, he did not test well at the combine and his 4.97 forty-yard dash time is a red flag that is well below the threshold line (4.85) for predicting success at the position for the next level. Frost projects as a late round to free agent prospect. April 7, 2016

A combine snub Juhrell (juh-RELL) Pressley rushed for 23 touchdowns and just under 2,000 yards over the past two seasons. He reportedly ran in the 4.3s at his Pro Day and it's not just track speed. He's an explosive runner with the potential to develop into a dangerous weapon in the passing game. He also had eight special teams' tackles in 2013. However, he played in an offense that simplified his reads and didn't ask a lot of him as a receiver or blocker. He's a developmental change-of-pace back that projects as a late Day 3 pick. April 6, 2016

Slater started for two seasons after he transferred from El Camino College in Torrance, California to San Diego State in 2014 and he was named a team captain in 2015. There's a lot to like about his size, length, disposition and work ethic but he's heavy footed and his high center of gravity makes it tough for him regularly to win the leverage battle. He projects as a late round pick or rookie free agent as a result. March 11, 2016

Thomas is two-year starter who also lined up at linebacker and fullback for the Spartans throughout his career. He comes with durability concerns (missed half of the 2013 season with a back injury). Thomas has a limited ceiling as a pass rusher, but he plays with a consistent motor and has the ability to get depth as an edge defender against the run. He projects as a potential late-round developmental prospect. --March 4, 2016

Barber drew national attention when he told reporters at the Combine that he declared for the draft because his mother is homeless. The big back is at his best between the tackles and picking up yards after contact. That said, he faces an uphill battle and not just because of his mediocre speed. He sustained minor injuries despite getting limited touches at Auburn and he's a relatively unknown as a receiver. In addition, he has learning disorders that he's admirably fought hard to overcome but raise concerns about his ability to digest the playbook and game plans. March 14, 2016

Bean is behind the eight ball after suffered a season ending torn ACL against Texas Tech in late October. As a prospect he brings adequate strength and point of attack skills as a run defender. However, he isn't a difference maker as a pass rusher at this point. He can become more efficient in this area (hand usage) but has a limited ceiling due to lack of explosiveness and flexibility. Bean projects as a fringe draft pick or free agent where a team will likely need to redshirt him in 2016. February 22, 2016

Grinnage (GRINN edge) deciding to declare for the draft as a redshirt junior is perplexing from a football standpoint. While there's a lot to like about his frame he'll need to get bigger and stronger to develop into an effective blocker especially if teams want to use him as in-line blocker. He is a big target who poses matchup problems for defensive backs when he flexes out wide as a receiver but he's not a big-play threat. With all of that in mind he projects as a late round pick or rookie free agent. March 3, 2016

Harris has four-years of starting experience (37 career starts).He has is an instinctive player that flashes very good short-area explosiveness. However, he lacks ideal height with short-arms and combined with average top-end speed will force him inside as a nickel at the next level. Harris also comes with some minor durability and character issues including a 2-game suspension in 2013 for violation of athleticism department policy. His father (Rod Harris) was a stand out for the school in the 80's.Harris projects as a late day three developmental pick. March 12, 2016

Maye turned in the most productive season of his career as a senior in 2015 (73 catches - 773 yards - 5 TD). He has experience at running back, receiver and returning kicks throughout his career. While he lacks ideal length he has the strength, quickness and toughness to potentially develop into a number four or five working from the slot while also contributing on special teams. Vertical jump (33") is nearing the red flag line (32") for the position. Maye projects as a late round developmental prospect in the 2016 NFL draft. -- April 9, 2016

Having a young daughter likely impacted Redmond's decision to declare for the draft and that's admirable. The way he handled that decision, however, could raise concerns for some teams. He left UCLA the week of its bowl game and hired an agent after he was declared academically ineligible. More importantly, he's an undersized guard with athletic limitations and underwhelming 2015 tape. As a result he projects as a late round pick or rookie free agent. March 6, 2016

Woodrum was a three-time captain at Liberty and has outstanding personal/football character. He took over as the starter three games into his freshman year and started 44 of the next 46 games (missed two in 2014 due to injury). He had good but not elite production for the small school level, completing 64-percent of his throws with a 2-1 TD-INT ratio. Woodrum (28-16 as starter) has prototypical size and he has enough arm strength and smarts to consider as a priority free agent. But slower eyes, inconsistent accuracy and inability to improvise put a low ceiling on his potential. -April 2, 2016

Simone is a transfer from Washington State who started in 22 straight games over the past two years before suffering a season-ending knee injury in the 10th game of the season. He was a team captain that comes with strong football make-up. He is a reliable tackler that improved his ball production in 2015. However, he has average fluidity and range in the back end which puts a lower ceiling on him as a prospect. Simone has a chance to develop into a back-up who will need to be a heavy contributor on special teams. He projects as a late round pick or free agent. April 12, 2016

TRUH-von Boykin had 40 starts at QB and ended his career with the school record for passing yards, completion and TD passes. However, he will have a steep climb transitioning as a QB and will likely need to make a position change to WR who can serve as an emergency QB and will also need to contribute on special teams potentially as a returner. Boykin comes with character concerns after being suspended the Alamo Bowl this past January after being arrested charged with assault on public official 3 nights before the game in San Antonio. Boykin holds a late round grade. April 7, 2016

Littleton has 31 career starts and comes with solid overall make-up and football character. He has quality athleticism to hold up as a space player and flashes some upside as a speed rusher. However, he has a linear build and has struggled to keep on weight in the past and must continue to add strength and bulk to ever become a full-time contributor. The good news is that Littleton has experience as an effective special teams contributor that could buy him some time early in his career while he continues to develop. He projects as a later day three developmental prospect. March 24, 2016

Adams is a Eastern Washington transfer who played his senior season at Oregon where he led the Ducks to a 7-3 record as a starter in 2015. An unconventional quarterback who lacks prototypical size, (Less than ideal hand size 9 1/8-inch as well) Adams will never be a exceptional pocket passer at the NFL level. But he does have the athleticism, competitive edge and playmaking instincts to give defenses fits, which he put on display at the East-West Shrine game earning MVP honors. Adams has a chance to stick around the NFL as a potential back-up, provided stays healthy. --April 8, 2016

Lomax started his career at CB before switching to DS where he brings a physical element to the position. However, is undersized, lacks speed/range and comes with some durability concerns including missing all of the 2012 season with a shoulder injury and battling a nagging hamstring injury in 2013. Lomax will need to be a heavy contributor on special teams to secure a roster spot at the next level. On the positive side, Lomax was voted a team captain and comes excellent football character and the mental toughness to battle through adversity. He projects as a late round pick. April 3, 2016

The grandson of former All-Pro running back Lawrence McCutcheon and nephew of former Browns' corner Daylon McCutcheon there's a lot to like about Madden's bloodlines. His size, vision and ability to help out on third down make him an intriguing potential Day 3 pick. However, there's a good chance he goes undrafted considering his extensive injury history and inability to stay healthy in college. Plus he has below average power despite his size, he's not a big-play threat and ball security is a concern. March 22, 2016

Newberry was mostly a reserve at FSU, spending a lot of time on special teams his first three seasons (2012-14) and even served as a blocking TE in 2013. He's an intriguing late-round prospect who never cracked the starting lineup but he flashes on tape and has measurables that teams look for in a project. He played in all 13 games as a senior in 2015 and finished with 19 tackles, 3 TFL, 2 sacks and 6 PBUs.Newberry has experience playing DE, DT and NT in multiple fronts, and he has the tools to play a similarly versatile role as a reserve in the NFL if developed properly. March 29, 2016

Bailey played in all 39 games during his final three seasons at UGA, combining for 127 total tackles but just 4 TFLs and 2.5 sacks. He has excellent size and length, but he's very limited athletically. Bailey was a team captain despite playing mostly as a rotational backup during his career and he has excellent football character. There's value here for a team in search of a big-body sub-package run defender at the DE position -- but that's all you're getting. Bailey grades out as a late-round/priority free agent prospect. -April 1, 2016

Signed with Cal but wound up at Southwest J.C. for two seasons. Then spent one year at El Camino College (to gain academic eligibility for Utah). In 2014, he played four games (2 INTs) before season-ending groin injury. Returned in 2015, started 12 games he played and finished with 56 tackles and two INTs. Carter is a SS that excels versus the run. He has coverage limitations and lacks game experience but the former high school sprint champion and WR has impressive straight-line speed and ball skills. Overcame a tough upbringing and best football could be ahead of him. Late-round grade.

Gilbert is a three year starter (46 total starts) who comes with strong football make-up. He was granted a fifth year of eligibility by the NCAA after suffering a season ending leg injury in 2011. He has adequate point of attack skills as a run defender but has a limited ceiling to develop into an impact pass rusher. Gilbert projects as a late round prospect who has the potential to add depth as an edge defender and has enough athleticism to be a solid special teams contributor. April 12, 2016

Jackson is a JUCO transfer who started for just one season at Alabama where he lined up at right tackle. His 33-inch arms and below average foot speed raise significant concerns about his ability to play tackle in the NFL and it's likely he'll have to kick inside to guard where he has the frame to develop into an effective backup for a team that features a power running game. March 17, 2016

Morgan was a four-year starter who played outside and inside at Michigan. With that said, he has marginal range for an outside linebacker prospect, and he's undersized to be an ILB at the next level. Plus, his frame raise concerns about his ability to stay healthy and he sustained a season-ending hand injury in the 2014 season opener. The bottom line is he projects as a reliable backup and special teams contributor, giving him a Day 3 grade. --April 10, 2016

A 2015 team captain Gionnni (gee-ah-nee) Paul is a better football player than athlete yet he still projects as a late round pick or rookie free agent. While he ran better at his Pro Day than he did at the Combine, he's an undersized linebacker with below average top-end speed. In addition, he has good football character but there are concerns about his off the field decision making after he started his career at Miami where he was suspended twice before transferring to Utah in 2013. March 27, 2016

Russell is a four year starter that saw his focus and production drop off in 2015 with his lowest catch and receiving yard total for his career. He has adequate athleticism to go along with excellent measureables to pose as a match-up problem. However, he needs to add polish with his routes, has limitations running the entire route tree and has to eliminate focus drops.Russell projects as a day 3 selection that has a chance to develop into a number four or five receiver who will need to excel in the red zone and be a contributor on special teams to survive on a roster. March 14, 2016

Dora is a fifth year senior who has four years of starting experience and comes with some minor durability. He is a hybrid edge defender whose best fit might be as a buck strong side OLB in a base 34 front. Dora projects as a late round or free agent prospect who has the potential to add depth to the back end of a roster as an edge setter against the run. Invited and participate at the NFLPA where he caught some eyes during practice. April 8, 2016

Holton is a junior college transfer (College of Dupage) who didn't start playing football until college. He dealt with a nagging hamstring injury this year and has just seven starts in his three seasons at Cincinnati. He needs experience and polish at the position but has a quality skill set of size, athleticism and speed to work with. He also comes with some minor character concerns. He projects as a fringe late round selection to undrafted free agent that may need a year or two on a practice squad to develop. March 15, 2016

Kirby appeared poised for a breakout senior season when he tore his ACL against Virginia Tech in October of last year. He has the work ethic and motor to contribute on special teams and potentially develop into a reliable backup. However, he's am undersized inside linebacker who doesn't show great athletic ability on tape and the knee injury has prevented him from working out for teams. He projects as a priority rookie free agent with all of that in mind. April 1, 2016

There's a lot to like about Matthews' pedigree considering he is the son of Hall of Fame offensive lineman Bruce Matthews and the younger brother of 2014 sixth overall pick Jake Matthews. He plays with the kind of smarts and toughness you'd expect based on his bloodlines too. Unfortunately, he wasn't blessed with size though and he'll have a much tougher time overcoming it at the NFL level. He's strictly a center who is a far better fit for zone heavy scheme than a power heavy scheme and he doesn't project as a starter. March 9, 2016

Monday has outstanding experience starting in all 52 games throughout his four year career. He comes with excellent make-up and work ethic and is constantly working on his craft. While he has room to improve his leg strength and touch, he has quality mechanics and did not have a punt blocked in 260 career attempts. Monday projects as a late round to free agent prospect. April 6, 2016

Oberkrom (Oh-berchrome) is the Big 12's all-time leader in field goals made with 79. There's a lot to like about his leg strength and he had his best season as a senior last year but he needs to continue to make strides in terms of his consistency and more importantly his accuracy. He projects as a late round pick or rookie free agent. April 11, 2016

Ojemudia has just 8 career starts all over the past two seasons. He was off to a strong start of his 2015 campaign (19 tackles, 6 TFLs and 2 sacks) before suffering a season ending torn Achilles in the fifth game of the season. He is a tweener with experience playing 34OLB and 43DE. He was unable to workout for scouts before the draft and will likely be a late round pick or free agent pick up. April 12, 2016

Montese Overton (moon-TEECE) is an undersized linebacker that is a better athlete than football player at this point. He has the speed and range to hold up in space but needs to play more under control and with better discipline. In addition, he comes with some character issues (Arrest in 2012 for animal cruelty and abandonment after leaving dog in apartment for 6 days without food or water) and must improve his preparation and approach to the game off the field. Overton projects as a late round developmental selection that could contribute early on ST's while he develops. March 25, 2016

Bercovici is behind the eight ball in terms of prototypical measureables and lacks ideal experience (3 career starts prior to earning fulltime starting job as a senior in 2015). On the positive side, he has a quick release and a strong arm, in addition to the excellent intangibles and work ethic teams look for in a developmental project. Case Keenum is a decent NFL comparison. -April 23, 2016

Garrett was a highly productive three-year player for the Aggies, piling up 48.5 TFL, 32.5 sacks and five forced fumbles in 36 starts. Durability was a bit of an issue, as he played six games in '15 with his left hand wrapped (wrist/thumb injury that required surgery; Jan., 2016) and he missed two games in '16 with a nagging high-ankle sprain. Garrett is a rare talent with an excellent pass rushing skill set and disruptive ability versus the run. He's scheme versatile, he has no off-the-field issues, and he should continue to improve with NFL coaching and more game experience. -March 25, 2017 The most naturally gifted player in the class, Garrett possesses a rare size, athleticism and explosiveness combination. He has the potential to turn into a premiere NFL pass-rusher thanks to his ability to win with both speed and power, along with exceptional flexibility bending the edge. -- Kevin Weidl  After ranking 30th in sacks last year (26 total), the Browns instantly upgrade their pass rush with the top talent in the class. Garrett is an ideal fit within first-year defensive coordinator Greg Williams' heavy 4-3 scheme and now gives Cleveland a pair of formidable ends, paired with Emmanuel Ogbah. -- Kevin Weidl

A redshirt junior, Trubisky (truh-BISS-kee) didn't crack the starting lineup until 2016 and enters the NFL with just 13 collegiate starts (three fewer than Mark Sanchez had leaving USC). That said, he's an accurate passer with the frame, mobility and arm strength to develop into an effective NFL starter. His 30:6 TD-to-INT ratio and 68.2 completion percentage are impressive, especially considering he threw two INTS and completed just 36-percent in the Hurricane Matthew game vs. Virginia Tech. Trubisky is likely to be the first quarterback off the board in April's NFL Draft. -January 21, 2017 Only was a one-year starter (13 career starts) and will need time to develop and hone his craft. He's an accurate passer with the frame and quality pocket awareness, mobility and arm strength to develop into an effective NFL starter. -- Kevin Weidl The Bears traded up one spot, and now hope that they have found their quarterback of the future. This ends up being a good landing spot for Trubisky, who was a one-year starter (13 total starts) at North Carolina and lacks ideal experience. He should have time to develop his game after Chicago signed QB Mike Glennon in free agency. -- Kevin Weidl

Played all 27 games during two seasons at Stanford (2015-16), amassing 102 tackles, 25.5 TFLs and 11.5 sacks. He led the team in tackles (62), TFLs (15) and sacks (8) as a redshirt sophomore in 2016. Thomas has a complete set of tools, including outstanding combination of size, quickness and power. He finished career with a dominating performance versus North Carolina in the Sun Bowl. Thomas projects as a top-15 pick in the 2017 draft. -March 18, 2017 A highly disruptive and versatile defensive lineman who can play in multiple roles along the front line. Thomas possesses explosive hands with an excellent combination of quickness, power and agility. -- Kevin Weidl New general manager John Lynch needed to address a defense that finished last in scoring defense in 2016 and gets an excellent value in Thomas after trading back one spot. Look for new defensive coordinator Robert Saleh to make the most of Thomas' versatility by moving him around the line and using him in a variety of ways. -- Steve Muench

After rushing for 2,206 yards and 23 TDs as sophomore in 2015, Fournette was unable to get on track as junior due to a lingering left ankle injury suffered in preseason camp (129-846-8TD). Missed 5 total games (Sat out Citrus Bowl). Durability is a slight concern due to wear and tear playing within LSUs physical run heavy offense (Career: 647 touches). Fournette is a punishing runner with rare size, speed (4.51) and power to be featured back ideally for a heavy power blocking scheme. Biggest areas he needs to improve are patience/tempo and in the passing game. Top 10 pick. -- March 19, 2017 A highly competitive and physical runner with a rare combination of size, speed and power. Fournette runs through a lot of contact and can be a nightmare to corral when reaching the open field. Needs to develop more patience as a runner at the NFL level. -- Kevin Weidl QB Blake Bortles struggled in his third season and the Jaguars hope to take some pressure off of him by handing the ball to Fournette, who is a workhorse with an elite physical skill set.
