The hope is Fournette's ability to force an extra defender near the box will open up some easier reads for Bortles off of play-action. -- Kevin Weidl

Davis was a three-year starter at WMU who finished with 332 career catches for 5,285 yards (15.9) and 52 TDs. His 5,285 receiving yards makes him the all-time leader in major college football history. Davis has not yet worked out during the pre-draft process due to an ankle injury. He has an excellent work ethic and was one of the most productive receivers in the country the past two years. Davis has a very good combination of size (6026, 209), speed, toughness and route running savvy. Davis projects as a difference-making NFL starter and grades out as a first rounder. -April 5, 2017. He has a very good combination of size, speed, toughness and route-running savvy. He does have some drops but makes up for it with his wide catch radius and ability to haul in the tough catches in contested situations. -- Kevin Weidl Some may consider this is a bit of a reach, but general manager Jon Robinson fills the Titans' most pressing need with Davis and gives quarterback Marcus Mariota a much-needed weapon on the outside. Davis is clearly one of the top three receivers in this class and projects as the Titans' No. 1 WR. -- Steve Muench

Adams, a team captain in 2016, left school early as a third-year junior who played in all 37 games with 26 starts. He racked up 189 total tackles, including 17.5 TFL. He also had 15 PBUs, 5 INTs, and 2 FFs. Adams is a versatile and physical safety. He has good (but not elite) cover skills and Ohio State's Malik Hooker is in another class in terms of ball skills. But Adams outclasses Hooker when it comes to game experience, leadership, run support and versatility (to play in the box, as the nickel in some situations, and in deep-half coverage). Adams is a top-10 prospect. -April 8, 2017 A naturally instinctive and versatile safety, Adams is physical in run support and has excellent athleticism in coverage. He plays fast and with infectious passion on the field while his maturity and leadership make him one of the more NFL-ready prospects in the class. -- Kevin Weidl In a similar situation to Leonard Williams (No. 6 overall pick in 2015), the Jets take advantage of another top talent falling to them at the same spot. Adams is one of the most NFL-ready prospects in this draft. He is an instinctive, versatile and physical safety who should thrive in Todd Bowles' aggressive defense. -- Kevin Weidl

Williams averaged 18 yards per catch and finished with 1,030 receiving yards as a sophomore in 2014 when he appeared to be the next big WR talent from Clemson (DeAndre Hopkins, Martavis Bryant, Sammy Watson). Unfortunately, Williams suffered a season-ending fractured neck in the 2015 opener. But he made a full recovery in 2016 (started all 15), hauling in 98 passes for 1,361 yards (13.9) with 11 TDs. Williams is a big, physical receiver with very good ball skills and adequate top-end speed for his size. He grades out as a mid-to-late 1st round pick. -April 14, 2017 A big and physical receiver, Williams needs polish with his routes but has the size and strength to create late separation when the ball is in the air. He's got the potential to develop into a one-on-one matchup problem outside the hashes and in the red zone due to his size, strength and ball skills. -- Kevin Weidl The Chargers provide Philip Rivers with another big-bodied receiver, similar to what Rivers had early in his career with Vincent Jackson and Malcom Floyd. Williams will add security for Keenan Allen and Stevie Johnson, who both suffered season-ending injuries last year. -- Kevin Weidl

McCaffrey has outstanding career production with 3,922 yards rushing (21 TDs) while adding 99 catches for 1,209 yards and 10 TDs in the passing game. (3,864 total yards in 2015 broke Barry Sanders NCAA single season record). Coaches and teammates rave about his work ethic and tireless motor. Lacks ideal size and power as inside runner and teams will need to have a plan on how to orchestrate his touches. That said, he is one of the most NFL ready players in this class and his versatility to contribute in all three phases make him worthy of a first round grade.  March 25, 2017 McCaffery is a three-way player who can contribute as a running back and returner on special teams and is one of the most polished receivers we've ever evaluated at the position. Outstanding intangibles and NFL-ready to contribute from day one. -- Kevin Weidl The Panthers needed to add speed and a dynamic playmaker on offense, and McCaffrey fits the bill. He is one of the most versatile players in the class who provides them a one-two punch in the backfield (Jonathan Stewart) with ability to flex out in the slot. He also fills the void left by Ted Ginn Jr. in the return game. -- Kevin Weidl

Ross had 33 catches his first two seasons (2013-14) -- and he was temporarily moved to starting CB for four games in 2014 because of injuries at that position. He then missed the entire 2015 season with a knee injury before returning in 2016, which was his breakout year (Rec: 81-1,150-14.2-17. KOR: averaged 24.1 yards with 4 career TDs). Ross has become well known for breaking Chris Johnson's Combine 40 record with his 4.22 time, but he's much more than a track speedster. Ross is a first-round talent at WR and brings additional value in the return game. -March 6, 2017 An explosive playmaker who can line up in the slot and outside the hashes. He possesses rare speed (4.22 40-yard dash at the combine) but also runs quality routes and is extremely dangerous with the ball in his hands both after the catch and as a returner on special teams. Lack of size and durability are concerns. -- Kevin Weidl After adding WR Tyler Boyd in the second round last year, the Bengals continue to make sure they surround QB Andy Dalton with weapons. Ross' ability to stretch the field vertically (4.22-second 40 at combine) also will go a long way in taking attention away from A.J. Green and provide him with more one-on-one situations. -- Kevin Weidl

Mahomes, whose father (Pat) played 12 seasons in MLB, finished his Texas Tech career with 29 starts (three seasons) and is only the 3rd FBS player with multiple seasons of 5,000 total yards of offense. He completed 64-percent of his throws while posting a 3.2:1 TD-to-INT ratio (93-29). He's a hard worker and has been durable (started final 29 games at TTU). There's no denying Mahome's outstandin skill set but he will only succeed in the NFL if given time and proper coaching to refine his poor footwork and to make a major transition from the "Air Raid" to a pro-style system. -April 7, 2017 Only the third FBS player with multiple seasons of 5,000 total yards of offense, Mahomes faces a steep learning curve transitioning to a pro-style offense and his mechanics are all over the place. However, he's a hard worker with an outstanding skill set, including a powerful arm and terrific arm talent. -- Steve Muench This is an ideal spot for Mahomes, who has arguably the best physical skill set of any quarterback in the class but needs a lot of refining mechanically. Mahomes should be given time to sit and develop behind Alex Smith while getting tutored by Andy Reid, who has a long track record of developing quarterbacks. -- Kevin Weidl

Lattimore only played two seasons at Ohio State and was a one-year starter as a redshirt sophomore in 2016. He has adequate size and limited game experience, but his cover skills are outstanding and he has the awareness and ball skills to generate takeaways. Lattimore is the top cornerback prospect in the 2017 class and there's a high probability he will be a top-10 pick (assuming he checks out medically after multiple hamstring injuries). -April 1, 2017 Lattimore is atop our list in a very deep cornerback class, with natural fluidity and the size and athleticism to play within a man or zone scheme. Displays outstanding speed with the closing burst to make up ground and the ball skills to finish when provided the opportunity. -- Kevin Weidl The Saints get strong value here with Lattimore, who needs some refining but is the top cornerback in the class. Lattimore has the talent to quickly develop into a starter and help improve the league's worst passing defense in 2016. -- Kevin Weidl

Watson finished his career with a 32-3 record as a three-year starter. He led Clemson to two ACC titles, two CFP Championship games (2015-16) and one CFP Championship title (2016). In consecutive CFP Championship appearances, Watson passed for 825 yards and led Clemson to 75 points versus Alabama's vaunted defense. Watson is a dynamic playmaker at the quarterback position. He needs to improve his deep accuracy and will need to adjust to a pro-style system, but he has the physical tools and rare intangibles to grow into a good NFL starter if developed and utilized properly. -April 1, 2017 Watson's ability to transition to a pro-style offense will ultimately dictate whether or not he succeeds in the NFL. A proven winner, there's no denying he has the physical tools and rare intangibles to develop into a franchise quarterback. -- Steve Muench After Cleveland took the Brock Osweiler contract off their hands, the Texans continue to get help from the Browns by trading up with them in hopes of finding their franchise quarterback. This is a good fit for Watson, who will get tutored by Bill O'Brien and will have a stingy defense to lean on if forced to play early. -- Kevin Weidl

Reddick is an explosive athlete who has the potential to develop into one of the most versatile three-down LBs in the class. The former 185 lbs. walk-on safety had a breakout season in 2016 where he was third in the FBS with 22  TFLs while adding 10  sacks. Mainly an edge defender at Temple, he showcased his ability to line up at off-line backer position with a strong showing at the Senior Bowl. Reddick's third down value and his ability to contribute on the core four special teams will likely put him in the first round consideration. April 6, 2017 A versatile linebacker who can line up all over the front seven. Reddick brings excellent value on third downs with his ability to hold up in coverage and rush the passer from various positions. He will also make an immediate impact in the special-teams phase. -- Kevin Weidl Adding Reddick next to Deone Bucannon gives the Cardinals a versatile player and two young, rangy inside linebackers to anchor their defense for years. Defensive coordinator James Bettcher will be able to move both these guys around on passing downs. While the Cardinals have more pressing needs, Reddick is an excellent value at 13. -- Steve Muench

Barnett was a three-year starter (39 games, 36 starts) with exceptional production (finished career with 52 TFL and 33 sacks -broke Reggie White's record of 32 sacks). Barnett is not the longest, twitchiest or fastest edge defender, but he has three elite traits: 1. Hand usage. 2. Closing burst to the QB. 3. Football instincts. He's also an impact player versus the run. We think he can stand up as an OLB in a base 3-4 scheme or he can stick his hand in the dirt as a DE in a 4-3 front. Barnett grades out as a late-first round prospect. -March 9, 2016 Tone-setter who is a better football player than athlete. He is one of the most natural edge rushers in the class, with outstanding snap anticipation, bend and closing burst. Barnett also brings quality instincts and point-of-attack skills setting the edge defending the run. -- Kevin Weidl Barnett is the most natural pass-rusher in the class, and combined with DE Brandon Graham, DT Fletcher Cox and DT Timmy Jernigan on the inside, the Eagles are looking to build a disruptive defensive line. Barnett also brings the toughness and leadership that Philadelphia needed to add to its roster. -- Kevin Weidl

Hooker was also recruited as a Division I basketball player out of high school. Redshirted in 2014 and played as a reserve in 2015 before starting all 13 games as a redshirt sophomore in 2016. He notched 74 tackles, including 5.5 TFLs. Hooker needs to add bulk/strength and improve his tackling skills in run support. His durability also needs monitoring after undergoing surgery in January on a torn labrum and sports hernia. But he's in an elite class when it comes to range in coverage and ball skills, which is why he grades out as a top-10 player in the 2017 Draft. -February 2, 2017 A ballhawking safety who possesses playmaking instincts and outstanding range as a center fielder, Hooker is in the Ed Reed mold with his ability to convert turnovers into points. Room to become more consistent in run support but is active and willing in this area. -- Kevin Weidl The Colts add the biggest ballhawking safety in the class to a defense that ranked 27th in the league against the pass in 2016. Hooker also fills a void left by Mike Adams, who departed for Carolina in free agency. -- Kevin Weidl

Humphrey is a redshirt sophomore who appeared and started in 29 of 30 games the past two seasons recording 13 PBUs and 5 INTs. Excellent bloodlines; Father Bobby played RB at Alabama and was a 1st round selection in 1998 NFL supplemental draft while Mother Barbara was a collegiate track star. Humphrey has arguably one of the highest ceilings in this years' CB class due to size and physical skill set but needs to show more consistency with instincts and ball skills. He projects as a potential top-40 selection whose best fit will be within a heavy press man or zone scheme.  April 5, 2017 While there's room for improvement when it comes to playing the ball and his eye discipline in zone coverage, Humphrey has the length, speed and fluidity to develop into a No. 1 corner. Plus, he's a reliable tackler and outstanding run defender. -- Steve Muench Humphrey is a perfect fit for Baltimore defensive coordinator Dean Pees' press man scheme. The Ravens have more pressing needs, but taking a corner makes sense considering Jimmy Smith has had problems staying heathy and Brandon Carr turns 31 this year. -- Steve Muench

Allen played in 58 games (38 starts) in four seasons. He turned down a 1st-round selection in last year's draft after notching 14 TFL and 12 sacks in Alabama's national title winning 2015 season. But he developed into an even more dominant player in '16 (69-16-10.5 with 2 of 3 fumble returns for TDs). He's a versatile DL who excels versus the run and is an impactful pass rusher. He's from a military family and has a great work ethic. Allen is a top-5 player in this class who would only slide out of the top-10 due to long-term shoulder concerns and below-average workout results. March 17, 2017 Allen is a versatile defensive lineman who plays with outstanding leverage and can line up in multiple spots along the front. Possesses the best sets of hands and is also one of the best interior pass-rushers in this defensive line class. -- Kevin Weidl Washington spent some money on its defensive line in free agency this offseason, but this is still an excellent pick based on value and fit. Allen's ability to set the edge should help bolster a run defense that finished 24th in the league. He's also a disruptive interior pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

Jackson is one of the most explosive and versatile players in this class due to his ability to contribute in all 3 phases of the game. In addition to his duties on defense (CB 34 starts - 28 PBUs - 6 INTs), he also recorded 38 career receptions for 628 yards and 6 TDs. A game changing returner on special teams (Career: PR - 12.6 - 4TD, KOR: 27.1 - 4 TD). Jackson is undersized and needs some technical work but he is an elite athlete that has a chance to develop into a versatile playmaker in the back end with the potential to quickly become a pro-bowl caliber returner on ST's.  March 26, 2017 One of the most explosive and versatile players in this draft, Jackson is an undersized corner with the potential to develop outstanding man-to-man cover skills with improved technique. He's expected to make an immediate impact in the return game. -- Steve Muench General manager Jon Robinson has filled the Titans' most pressing needs with his first two picks, as the Titans take a corner to push for a starting role opposite Logan Ryan. The Titans also finished tied for 18th in interceptions last year, so adding a playmaker like Jackson makes sense. He also can help in the return game. -- Steve Muench

Howard has appeared in 57 career games while starting in all 30 games the past two seasons while recording 45 receptions for 595 yards and 3 TDs in 2016. He has room to develop as a route runner but he is the most complete TE in the class with an outstanding combination of size, athleticism (see combine results) and soft hands. Improved as a run blocker late in his career. Took advantage of the post-season process with strong showings at the SR Bowl and combine. Projects as a first round pick who should quickly develop into a starter. -- March 12, 2017 The most complete tight end in the class. Howard is a big and athletic pass-catching tight end with the speed to stretch the vertical seams. In addition, he brings quality value as an inline blocker. He's got room to improve route awareness. -- Kevin Weidl After signing DeSean Jackson in free agency, the Bucs continue to help out quarterback Jameis Winston and surround him with offensive weapons. Howard adds a big-play element down the middle of the field when flanked by Jackson and Mike Evans on the outside. Howard's ability as an inline blocker also will help improve a rushing offense that ranked 24th last year. -- Kevin Weidl

Bolles is a juco transfer who made 12 starts at LT in his lone season at Utah. Character will be heavily investigated as he comes from a troubled upbringing that involved drugs and gangs. Eventually taken in by his former lacrosse coach where he has matured and taken steps to repair his life. As a prospect Bolles has room to add bulk and strength but has an excellent combination of length, flexibility and athleticism to develop into a starting LT. Turns 25 in May. Bolles has the potential to come off the board within the top 40 picks if teams are comfortable with character. -- April 6, 2017 Bolles is the most athletic offensive lineman in the class. He possesses quick feet and lateral agility with the length to develop into a starting left tackle. Needs to continue to get stronger in his lower half but has very good agility to cover up defenders as a run-blocker. -- Kevin Weidl A Denver offense that finished 31st in third-down efficiency (34.2 percent) and 26th in the red zone (46.8 TD percentage) last year needs a starting left tackle, and Bolles fills that need. Taking him also allows free-agent signing Menelik Watson and Donald Stephenson to compete for the right tackle spot. -- Steve Muench

Jarrad (pronounced: Jared) Davis was a 4th-year senior in 2016, starting 9 games (missed nearly 4 full games with leg injury) and finishing with 60 tackles, 9.5 TFL and 2.5 sacks. He had his best season as a first-time fulltime starter in 2015 (98-6.5-3.5). Durability is a minor concern (also missed final three games of 2014 with torn MCL). Davis' coverage instincts can improve but he's an explosive LB with good range, a relentless motor, elite intangibles and value on special teams. Grades out as a top-40 prospect if durability checks out. (NFL comp: OLB Kwon Alexander, Bucs). -April 8, 2017 An explosive run-and-hit linebacker who has quality instincts and covers sideline to sideline defending the run. Room to grow in coverage but improved throughout his career, and he is an underrated blitzer. Davis has elite football character and work ethic. -- Kevin Weidl The Lions fill the void left by DeAndre Levy, who is still a free agent. Davis adds a playmaker to the middle of the defense. He has the ability to contribute all three downs and should help immediately improve a run defense that ranked in the back half of the league last year. -- Kevin Weidl

Harris played all 38 games during his three seasons of eligibility and started all 24 games the past two years (2015-16), racking up a combined total of 117 tackles 30.5 TFL, 16 sacks, and 4 forced fumbles. He can continue to add bulk and improve his anchor strength versus the run. He also had both labrums surgically repaired while at Missouri. But Harris is a versatile, disruptive and relentless edge defender with upside (did not play football until junior year of high school). We have a fringe 1st-round grade on Harris but fully expect him to come off the board in the top-25. -April 8, 2017 An athletic and explosive athlete who was a former high school basketball standout, Harris is a speed rusher who has very good first step quickness and bend turning the corner. He's got a chance to become an impact edge defender if he can add bulk and improve his core strength. -- Kevin Weidl Miami needs to get younger at defensive end and Harris projects as a situational pass-rusher who can help improve a Dolphins pass rush that finished tied for 19th in sacks last year. Playing behind Cameron Wake and free-agent signee William Hayes early on will allow him to get stronger and improve his ability to defend the run. -- Steve Muench

Engram is a four year starter (43 career starts) and two-time captain that finished his career as the programs all-time leader in receptions (162), receiving yards (2,320) and touchdowns (15) for a tight end. In the mold of Washington Redskins TE Jordan Reed, he is an undersized move tight end who is a polished route runner with the speed and quickness (see combine results) to provide a mismatch in the passing game. Missed the final 5 games of the 2013 season with a high ankle sprain. Potential top-50 selection after a taking advantage of the pre-draft process. -- April 5, 2017 A four-year starter and two-time captain, Engram is an undersized move tight end who is never going to be a great blocker. However, he's a polished route runner whose combination of size, speed and athletic ability makes him a matchup nightmare. -- Steve Muench New York's tight ends averaged an NFL-low 7.7 yards per reception last season, and Engram gives the Giants a big-play threat at that position. He also gives head coach Ben McAdoo and quarterback Eli Manning a player who can move around the formation and create favorable matchups. -- Steve Muench

Conley is an underclassman entry but an experienced player with 41 games played (26 starts) during three seasons at Ohio State. He recorded 13 PBUs and six INTs as a starter the past two seasons. Conley has a little bit oftightness in his hips but he possesses the length and straight-line speed combination that most NFL teams desire. Conley also shows good overall awareness and ball skills, and he's tough in run support. And his Combine workout was outstanding (4.46 40-dash, 33-inch arms, 37" VJ, 6.68 short shuttle). Conley projects as a first round pick in the 2017 Draft. -April 12, 2017 He has a little bit of tightness in his hips, but he possesses the length-and-straight-line-speed combination that most NFL teams desire. He also shows good overall awareness and ball skills, and he's tough in run support. -- Kevin Weidl The Raiders continue to add talent in their back end and help solidify a porous pass defense that ranked 24th in the league. After re-signing cornerback Sean Smith to a four-year deal, Conley could line up in the slot as D.J. Hayden's replacement at nickelback. -- Kevin Weidl

Peppers's versatility, competitiveness and stamina are rare. Jim Harbaugh says he has the best football IQ of any player he's coached since Andrew Luck. He is a difference-making punt returner and can contribute situationally on offense. However, he's not Deone Bucannon (not nearly as strong or physical and lacks takeaway instincts), and he has limitations in coverage. If used properly, Peppers can be a difference maker on defense but there's risk due to his lack of positional development and reports of a diluted sample at the Combine (see: note above) only complicate matters - April 24, 2017 A relentless competitor, Peppers has an outstanding football IQ, tested well at the combine and is an excellent punt returner. However, he's not big enough to play linebacker, and limitations in coverage and questionable ball skills raise questions about his ability to become a difference-maker at safety. -- Steve Muench This is a reach, but Cleveland has a need at safety, and defensive coordinator Gregg Williams will make the most of Peppers' versatility. In addition, the Browns finished 26th in the league in yards per punt return last year and Peppers is a dangerous returner. -- Steve Muench

McKinley signed with Cal out of high school, failed to qualify, attended Contra Costa College in 2013, and then transferred to UCLA in 2014. He was a backup that before starting 23 of 24 games played (missed UNLV '16; groin) the last two seasons (2015-16) and racking up 96 tackles, 25.5 TFL, 14.5 sacks, 10 PBU and 5 FFs. McKinley has overcome a lot (rough neighborhood, dad never in picture, mom abandoned him at age 5) and he's a highly motivated player. He best suited to play RDE in an even front but could play 3-4 OLB in certain schemes. Grades out as a top-50 pick. -March 11, 2017 An explosive edge rusher, McKinley has excellent snap anticipation and first-step quickness to threaten the edge quickly as a pass-rusher. Also plays with the physical demeanor and relentless motor that teams look for in the front seven. -- Kevin Weidl The Falcons add another explosive edge rusher here opposite of Vic Beasley Jr., who led the league in sacks in 2016 (15.5). Atlanta continues to infuse speed into its defense and now has the potential to have a disruptive pair of book ends, which makes sense in a division in which they face Drew Brees, Jameis Winston and Cam Newton six times a year. -- Kevin Weidl

A fourth-year senior in 2016, "true-DAY-vee-us" White appeared in 49 career games (47 starts) tallying 167 tackles, 36 PBUs and 6 INTs. He's a very instinctive cover corner with average size, good speed, and quick feet but some tightness in his hips. He has adequate ball skills but is only decent in run support. White is the type of prospect that you pull for; he's a leader with an exceptional work ethic, and he has overcome a financially poor upbringing. He brings added value as a punt returner (career: 11.4 avg per PR, 2 TDs). White grades out as an early 2nd round prospect. April 7, 2017 A team captain with excellent intangibles and work ethic, White is an instinctive cover corner with average size, good speed and quick feet. He's got some tightness in his hips and he has average overall ball skills. -- Steve Muench The Bills help fill the void left by Stephon Gilmore and Nickell Robey-Coleman, who lined up at the nickelback spot. This is a good fit for Buffalo, as White is an instinctive player who has the versatility to play inside or outside and gives them added value as a potential returner on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

Charlton played sparingly in 10 games as a true freshman reserve in 2013. His playing time increased the next two seasons (2014-15), when he played in all 25 games (4 starts) and produced 49 tackles, 14 tackles for loss and nine sacks. He finally took over as a fulltime starter in 2016, when he racked up 48 tackles, 13 TFLs and a team-high 9.5 sacks despite missing two games (UCF and Colorado) with injury. Charlton fits best as a 4-3 DE. He may never be an elite player but Charlton has a well-rounded game as a pass rusher and run defender. Late-first round grade. -March 22, 2017 Charlton makes up for what he lacks in suddenness and top-end speed with his length, size and power. He's an effective edge setter against the run, plus he uses his length, hands and flexibility to beat offensive tackles rushing the passer. -- Steve Muench With Randy Gregory suspended for the 2017 season, Demarcus Lawrence coming off back surgery and 2016 fourth-round pick Charles Tapper missing his rookie season with a back injury, Dallas needed to add a defensive end. Charlton has the talent to make an immediate contribution, and look for defensive coordinator Rod Marinelli to get the most out of him. -- Steve Muench

Njoku "nJOW-koo" is a red hirt sophomore who has appeared in all 26 games the past 2 seasons (9 total starts). 2016: 43 catches for 698 yards (16.2) and 8 touchdowns. He also participated briefly as a high jumper on the Miami track team and recorded a jump of 7'1" in high school. Njoku lacks ideal experience and has room to become more consistent with his hands. However, he has a freakish skill set to quickly develop into a difference maker in the passing game. Parents are from Nigeria and has 8 siblings. Sports Hernia surgery in 2014. He projects as a first round pick. -- April 6, 2017 A move, or "F," tight end with freakish athleticism. He can become a more consistent inline blocker and add detail with his route running, but he has the chance to develop into a difference-maker in the pass game with rare run-after-catch ability for the position. -- Kevin Weidl Tight end Gary Barnidge wasn't nearly as productive last season as he was in 2015, and he turns 32 in September. Njoku gives an offense that finished 28th in passing yards per game a much-needed weapon. Look for coach Hue Jackson to move him around to create favorable matchups. -- Steve Muench

The younger brother of former Badger and current Texans defensive end J.J. Watt, T.J. Watt moved from tight end to outside linebacker as a redshirt sophomore in 2015 and missed the 2014 season with a knee surgery so there are concerns about experience at linebacker and medical. Yet he's an intriguing versatile LB who flashes strong point of attack skills and quality athleticism to line up in multiple spots along the front seven. Helped his stock with a strong showing at the combine. Watt projects as a second round pick. -- April 6, 2017 Watt is an above-average pass-rusher with the initial burst, balance and closing speed to threaten off the edge in the NFL. He also does a nice job of setting the edge against the run and has the range to make plays in pursuit. -- Steve Muench No Steeler recorded more than 5.0 sacks last season, James Harrison turns 39 in May and Jarvis Jones departed via free agency, making outside linebacker the Steelers' most pressing need. Watt is a perfect fit for their 3-4 scheme and projects as a starter early in his career. -- Steve Munch

Foster played 51 career games (all 23 starts in 2015, 2016) in four seasons. He dropped 15 pounds before his senior year in 2016 and showed much-improved quickness and range, finishing with a team-high 115 tackles (13 TFL - 5 sacks). Foster is an every-down linebacker with violent striking ability and an alpha-dog mentality. Excellent football character but some scouts have expressed concerns about decision making away from football and durability. Tested positive for a diluted sample at the Combine before being sent home early for an altercation with a medical staff member. -- April 25, 2017 Arguably the best pure football player in the class, Foster is an impact defender who owns the physicality and power to hold up in tight quarters and the range to cover sideline to sideline. An explosive hitter and underrated blitzer, he is a three-down player. -- Kevin Weidl Foster is an excellent pick from both a value and need standpoint. New general manager John Lynch needed to improve the league's worst run defense, as NaVorro Bowman has had problems staying healthy and free-agent signee Malcolm Smith is a better situational player than an every-down player. -- Steve Muench

Ramczyk (RAM-check) is a JUCO transfer who only has one year of starting experience at the FBS level and while it's not a glaring weakness on tape, his arm length (33 ') is a concern for a left tackle prospect. Of even greater concern, he's undergone hip surgery to repair a torn labrum and it's prevented him from working out for teams at the Combine and Wisconsin's pro day. That said he projects as a first-round pick with the skill set to start early on in his career based on the tape and he hasn't reached his potential yet as he can clean up his footwork and pad level. Ramczyk is coming off hip surgery, played only one year of FBS football and has shorter arms. Still, he projects as a first-round pick with the foot speed and size to develop into an effective left tackle based off his 2016 tape. -- Steve Muench Left tackle Terron Armstead has yet to play a full 16-game season, right tackle Zach Strief turns 34 this year and 2015 first-round pick Andrus Peat is a better fit on the inside. Ramczyk is arguably the best tackle prospect in this class. -- Steve Muench

King is a long, fast and versatile CB prospect who played the majority of his snaps on the perimeter during his four years at Washington, but also has experience at nickel and FS. He also has experience as a gunner and jammer on special teams. He's been mostly durable (missed three games combined in 2014 and 2015 but started all 14 games in 2016), and he's also a vocal leader who already handles his business like a pro. King grades out on tape as a second round prospect but his rare measurables and Combine workout could easily bump him into Round 1.1, 2017 He is a long, fast and rangy cornerback who also has experience lining up at safety. King has rare athleticism for his size with good ball awareness, and he is a physical tackler in run support. Brings quality value covering punts and kicks on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl The Packers fill one of their top needs with King, a cornerback who has the length and athleticism to fit within their heavy press-man scheme. King should be able to make an immediate contribution and help improve a pass defense that ranked 31st in the league in 2016. -- Kevin Weidl

A durable starter who appeared and started in all 43 career games during his three seasons at Alabama. Robinson has quality athleticism, excellent length and very good inline capabilities in the run game. Needs to become more consistent in pass protection particularly with his footwork and can more patience sitting back in sets. Arrested in May 2016 for illegal possession of a stolen firearm and possession of narcotics (eventually dropped). Robinson projects as a 2nd round pick that may need to start his career inside at guard to get acclimating to the speed of the NFL game. -- March 12, 2017 Robinson is a powerful run-blocker with the length and flexibility to develop into an above-average pass-blocker with improved footwork. He's expected to push for a starting role, though he might have to move to right tackle or guard early in his career. -- Steve Muench After taking Leonard Fournette at No. 4 overall, the Jaguars continue to bolster their ground game by adding the best run-blocking offensive linemen in this class. Robinson has a chance to step in at right tackle opposite of Branden Albert or line up at guard early on. Tom Coughlin has had a big influence early on, and clearly Jacksonville is looking to get more physical on offense. -- Kevin Weidl

McDowell played in 10 games as a backup in 2014 before emerging as a fulltime starter in 2015 (all 14 games), tallying 41 tackles, 13 TFLs and 4.5 sacks. His 2015 tape is more impressive than 2016 tape (34-9-1.5 in 9 games, missing final three due to nagging ankle injury), which shows a lot less consistent fight and effort (especially on back end of 7-game losing streak). McDowell is the most physically gifted interior pass rusher in the '17 draft but team's have to make a tough decision on his work ethic and ability to self motivate. McDowell grades out as a first-roundeer. -March 26, 2017 McDowell didn't always play like it last year, but he's one of the most talented defensive linemen in this draft -- when the effort is there. He's the most physically gifted interior pass-rusher and a disruptive run defender who can play defensive tackle or end. -- Steve Muench Seattle adds depth and improves its interior pass rush by adding McDowell, who is the most gifted interior pass-rusher in this class. It's a good landing spot for the inconsistent McDowell, as Seattle has the leaders to hold him accountable, and defensive coordinator Kris Richard will make the most of his versatility. -- Steve Muench

Baker is an early-entry prospect who played in 39 of 40 games during three seasons at Washington. He made 200 career tackles, including a team-high 71 in 2016. Baker lacks size but otherwise has very few weaknesses to his game. He also has been an outstanding special teams player throughout his career. He has a lot of Tyrann Mathieu-like qualities. Baker projects as a starting safety or nickel back in the NFL and should be a top-50 pick in the 2017 NFL Draft. -April 10, 2017 Baker is undersized with average ball skills, but he displays an above-average blend of burst, change-of-direction skills and instincts in coverage. Plus, he's an effective open-field tackler willing to step up in run support, and he's an outstanding special-teams player. -- Steve Muench With safeties Tony Jefferson and D.J. Swearinger gone in free agency and Antoine Bethea turning 33 in July, the Cardinals needed another young playmaker at the position. Arizona now has added two of the more versatile defenders in the class with its first two picks in Baker and Haason Reddick. -- Kevin Weidl

Jones played in all 50 games (41 starts) during four years at ECU, finishing with 399 catches for 4,279 yards (10.7) and 23 TDs. Had a record-setting senior year with 158 catches for 1,746 yards and eight TDs. Jones comes from a version of an "Air Raid" offense but proved capable of running a full route tree at the Senior Bowl, where he stood out as one of the top players all week. Jones' father (Robert) won three Super Bowls as a Cowboys LB in the 1990's and his uncle is former NFL QB Jeff Blake. Jones has very good personal and football character. He carries a Day 2 grade. -March 9, 2017 An ultra-productive and sure-handed college receiver, Jones needed to ease concerns about the competition he faced inflating his production and the scheme he played in. He did that by shining at the Senior Bowl and working out well at the combine. -- Steve Muench Buffalo fills its most pressing need and gets an excellent value here with Jones. He projects as the starter opposite Sammy Watkins and will help improve a passing attack that finished 30th in the league in 2016. -- Steve Muench

Lamp is a two-time captain and four-year starter who primarily lined up at left tackle in college. He did start three games at right guard during his redshirt freshman season and he's expected to move back inside where his short arms (32 ') won't be as much of a concern While his arms are more than an inch shorter than the five-year Combine average for guards he performed extremely well in the key tests for interior offensive linemen as his broad jump, short shuttle, 40-yard dash and bench press are all outstanding. He projects as a first round pick and Day 1 starter. A converted tackle who will likely move inside at the NFL level. He is a grinder who plays with great technique and balance, and also has the intelligence and versatility to line up at multiple spots along the offensive line. Plug-and-play starter from day one. -- Kevin Weidl The Chargers released D.J. Fluker this offseason, which created a vacancy at right guard. Lamp is our top-rated offensive lineman on the board and projects as a Day 1 starter at guard. He's got the toughness to help improve a run game that finished 26th in the league last year. -- Steve Muench

Maye is an interchangeable safety with good size and outstanding FBI's. 32 career starts but saw his 2016 campaign cut short after breaking his left forearm in the ninth game of the season. Had very good ball production for his career (17 PBU, 8 INT) but can improve playing the ball when caught in trail (See 2015 SEC Championship and LSU). While he is not as violent or physical against the run as former teammate Keanu Neal he is extremely reliable in run support. Maye projects as a potential top 50 pick who should quickly develop into a starter within a year or two. March 10, 2017 An instinctive and versatile safety, Maye is a reliable run defender with the range, length and athleticism to hold up in coverage. He's not as effective turning and running as he is facing the line of scrimmage. -- Steve Muench The Jets continue to shore up the middle of the back end of their defense by taking another safety in Maye. With a roster that lacked talent, New York adds a pair of young studs in the back who can grow together in Maye and Jamal Adams. -- Kevin Weidl

Played as a reserve in 27 of 28 games during his first two seasons (2014-15). Played all 13 in 2016 (12 starts), averaging 8 yards on 97 carries with 8 TDs and 11.7 yards on 74 catches with 7 scores. Durability concerns exist due to lack of size. Also had foot surgery in Jan., 2016. Samuel is an explosive versatile weapon without a true "position fit" but he's capable of developing into a dangerous slot-WR that gets a handful of carries per game. He also could have some value as a kick return specialist. For a creative offensive team with a plan, Samuel has second-round value. -April 3, 2017 An undersized and versatile weapon, Samuel is a big-play threat. He's got the burst and elite top-end speed to develop into a dangerous slot receiver who gets a handful of carries per game and possibly contributes in the return game. -- Steve Muench Carolina has used its first two picks to get two of the most versatile offensive weapons in this class, landing Christian McCaffrey in Round 1 and now Samuel. Samuel projects as more of a slot receiver than a running back, but the Panthers will move him around and mix him into the run game. -- Steve Muench

Cook rushed for 1,000 yards in all three season including a career high 1,765 yards and 19 touchdowns in 2016. He has excellent vision, speed, the ability to create yards on his own -- 749 rushing yards after contact led all Power-5 RBs in 2016  and quality versatility in the passing game. On tape alone, Cook grades out as a first round pick but he does come with some risk that includes durability concerns (3 prior shoulder surgeries dating back to HS and hamstring issues in 2015), character red flags and ball security issues that will need to be weighed into his evaluation.  March 11, 2017 Cook is the most natural runner of running back class. He is elusive, has outstanding vision and patience and acceleration out of cuts, as well as bringing quality versatility in the passing game. Durability and ball security are slight concerns. -- Kevin Weidl With the addition of Cook, the Vikings continue to look to fill the void left by Adrian Peterson. Cook is the most natural runner in the class and adds a big-play element to the backfield. In addition, they signed RB Latavius Murray in free agency, which provides a safety net for Cook's durability and ball security concerns. -- Kevin Weidl

Williams is a 3 year starter who appeared in 39 career game with 37 starts (missed Oregon St. and UCLA with an undisclosed injury in 2016). He is an instinctive free safety prospect that has very good range and quality ball skills recording 10 INTs in the past two seasons (2015-'16). Williams has room to get stronger and can be more aggressive in run support. He projects as a third round pick.  March 14, 2017 Williams is a true free safety who has above-average instincts and recognition skills along with a very good range. He also shows quality ball skills to finish when provided the opportunity. He needs to get strong and more physical in run support. -- Kevin Weidl After taking the top corner in the class in the first round (Marshon Lattimore), the Saints continue to infuse playmakers in the back end. Williams is a free safety who will provide more flexibility for last year's pick Von Bell to utilize his versatility in coverage and help improve a pass defense that ranked dead last in 2016. -- Kevin Weidl

Jones played in all 41 games (40 starts) during his three seasons at Washington (2014-16). Jones is a silky smooth cover corner with good height, length and speed. He can play press and off coverage --and while he's slightly better in man-to-man coverage, he's very effective playing zone. Jones can improve by adding bulk and getting stronger. But otherwise, he's a complete CB with the tools to quickly develop into a good NFL starter. Jones grades out as a first round prospect on tape but will likely fall to Day 2 due to Pro Day Achilles tendon tear. -March 25, 2017 Jones is one of the most talented cornerbacks in the 2017 class, but he will likely need to "redshirt" his rookie season after an Achilles injury at his pro day. He is a fluid athlete with quality mirror skills in man coverage and shows above-average awareness locating and playing the ball. -- Kevin Weidl Philadelphia fills its most pressing need at cornerback and gets a player who could turn into an absolute steal in Jones. He's a scheme-versatile player with the football I.Q. and natural ability to step into a starting role for the Eagles if, as expected, he makes a full recovery. He also gives Philadelphia a playmaker. -- Steve Muench

Everett is a fourth year who started career at Bethune Cookman before hitting the JUCO ranks, UAB and then South Alabama for the past two seasons (90 - 1,292 - 12TD). A former high school basketball standout who only started playing football his senior year of high school, Everett has room to develop in terms of his football IQ. That said, he has a strong combination of speed, athleticism and ball skills to become a pass catching mismatch at the next level as an undersized F-tight end. Everett has the potential to be off the board within the top-75 selections.  April 5, 2017 Everett is an undersized tight end who can move around the offense. He has above-average athleticism, reliable hands and the speed to stretch the vertical seams. He is a UAB transfer who didn't start playing football until his senior year of high school and still needs some developing as a route runner. Everett's best football could still be ahead of him. -- Kevin Weidl Everett is a reach at this point, but it comes as no surprise that the Rams targeted a receiving tight end with a high ceiling, even after taking Tyler Higbee in the fourth round last year. As the offensive coordinator in Washington, Sean McVay valued smaller tight ends who were better receivers than blockers, and they ran more three-tight end sets than most teams. It seems he's using the same approach as Los Angeles' new head coach. -- Steve Muench

Wilson is a third year junior who was a two year starter (39/24) for the Gators including all 13 games in 2016 while recording 6 PBUs and 3 INTs. He is a big and physical cornerback who displays strong instincts and outstanding ball skills. Wilson does have a little bit of tightness in off man coverage and is at his best in press-technique or zone coverage. He has the chance to develop into a quality number two CB with the size and physicality to potentially move to safety later in his career. Wilson should be off the board within the top-40 picks.  April 5, 2017 Wilson is a big and physical corner who masks the tightness in his hips with his instincts and ability to disrupt receivers in press coverage. He's also a playmaker who plays faster than his timed top-end speed and has outstanding ball skills. -- Steve Muench The Colts fill a need with Wilson, who has the size and physicality to thrive within defensive coordinator Ted Monachino's heavy press-man scheme. With the addition of Wilson and Malik Hooker, first-year general manager Chris Ballard is clearly looking to provide Andrew Luck with some help on defense. -- Kevin Weidl

Bowser played in a rotation in 26 games his first two seasons (2013-14) before emerging as a fulltime starter the past two years (2015-16), starting all 22 games he played and racking up 97 tackles, 18.5 TFL, 14 sacks, 6 PBUs and 2 FFs. He missed 5 games in 2016 with an orbital fracture suffered in a scuffle with teammate Matthew Adams prior to UConn game. But by all accounts Bowser has good football character, he takes to hard coaching and the game is important to him. Bowser is a work-in-progress edge defender with explosive traits. He's an underrated prospect. Round 2 grade. -March 31, 2017 A former star high school basketball player who also played hoops for the Cougars early in his career, Bowser is a work in progress as a football player. However, he's already made great strides, plus he has explosive traits and above-average upside for an edge defender. -- Steve Muench The Ravens cut Elvis Dumervil this offseason, and though Terrell Suggs is still productive, he is 34 years old. Bowser is an excellent fit for Baltimore's 3-4 defense, as he should make an immediate impact rushing the passer and has the tools to quickly develop into a starter. -- Steve Muench

A redshirt sophomore, Mixon ranked second in the FBS in all-purpose yards per game (195.6) last year and he has the skill set of a franchise every-down back. However, organizations are going to have a difficult time deciding whether or not to take him off the board following the release of a video of him punching a woman in the face breaking her jaw, eye socket and cheekbone in 2014. He was suspended for the 2014 season. Also suspended for 2016 Iowa State game after reportedly tearing up a ticket and throwing it at a parking officer. Worked out well at Pro Day. Not invited to Combine. Mixon has quick feet and good top-end speed for his size, plus he's an outstanding receiver with experience working out of the slot. He comes with substantial off-the-field baggage, though, and many organizations might not want to deal with the fallout of drafting him. -- Steve Muench The Bengals needed to shore up the RB position, as Jeremy Hill is entering a contract year after suffering a season-ending ACL injury in Week 11. Mixon is one of the most talented runners in the class and a dynamic playmaker. -- Kevin Weidl

Anderson played in 42 games as a backup his first three seasons (2013-'15) before finally taking over as a starter in 2016, when he finished with 61 tackles, a team-high 19.5 TFL and 9 sacks. That gave him a combined 31 TFL and 15 sacks his last two years. Anderson lacks athleticism and length (30 7/8' arms), making him a bit of a 'tweener at the next level (fits Ravens/Steelers). But he has good FBI's, efficient hands and plays with an edge. He brings outstanding intangibles and is a well-respected leader by teammates and coaches. Anderson grades out as a late-Day 2 prospect. -March 17, 2016 Anderson, who is a better football player than athlete, is one of the more underrated prospects in this 2017 class. He possesses heavy and active hands, natural leverage and plays with a tone-setting mentality. He has a knack for making big plays. -- Kevin Weidl The Redskins continue to add versatility, toughness and pass-rushing help to their front with the additions of Anderson and Jonathan Allen with their first two picks. Anderson will provide another edge rusher opposite of Ryan Kerrigan and also could see some time at inside linebacker, where Washington needs need help. -- Kevin Weidl

A juco transfer, Evans has appeared and started in 24 of 26 games at A&M the past 2 seasons while recording 11 PBUs and 5 INTs. Tightly packed and explosive athlete that has enough size and physicality to play near the box along with the athleticism to handle middle of the field responsibilities. Aggressive feast or famine safety that can manufacture big plays but will need to learn to play with more discipline at the next level. Evans projects as a top 100 pick who has chance to develop into a quality starter within a year or two. NFL Comparison: Denver Broncos DS TJ Ward. -- March 11, 2017 Evans gambles and gets caught out of position, but his aggressiveness and above-average ball skills also lead to big plays. Plus, he plays faster than his timed top-end speed, he has above-average short area cover skills, and he's tough against the run. -- Steve Muench Tampa Bay has some depth at safety and it signed J.J. Wilcox, but Bradley McDougald signed with Seattle and the Bucs need a safety capable of pushing for a starting job. Evans is an instinctive safety who fits the bill. He is a bit of a reach here, though, especially with Connecticut's Obi Melifonwu still on the board. -- Steve Muench

The 2016 ACC defensive player of the year, Walker was 2nd in the nation for sacks (16) and tied for 6th in TFLs (21  ). He is a better football player than athlete who has bought into the process and plays with a tone setting mentality coveted along the front 7. Two-time team captain, film junky and one of the more technically advanced DL in the class in terms of hand usage and understanding how to create leverage as a pass rusher. Walker projects as a top-100 pick.  March 15, 2017 Walker has some athletic limitations, but he makes up for it with outstanding instincts, technique and hand usage. He has a strong point of attack against the run and shows the ability to reduce inside as pass-rusher where he is most effective with his initial quickness and great understanding for leverage. -- Kevin Weidl After losing Malik Jackson and Sylvester Williams in free agency the past couple of offseasons, the Broncos needed to infuse some interior pass-rushing help. Walker also should help improve a rushing defense that ranked 28th in 2016. -- Kevin Weidl

Kizer is redshirt sophomore and two year starter (12-11 career record) who is coming off an up and down 4-8 season in 2016 (59% - 2,925 yards  26 TDs  9 INTs). He possesses similar size, arm strength and deceptive mobility to that of Ben Roethlisberger or Joe Flacco. However, he would have benefitted from another year to hone his mechanics, develop mentally and continue to mature as a leader. Kizer holds an early second round grade but could be selected higher due to enticing physical skill set and enormous ceiling. -- April 5, 2017 Kizer is a redshirt sophomore who would have benefitted from another year to work on his mechanics, develop the mental aspect of his game and continue to mature as a leader, but he has prototypical size and arm strength to go along with deceptive mobility. -- Steve Muench Drafting a quarterback in the first round hasn't exactly worked out for the Browns. The four they selected in the first round since 1999 -- Tim Couch, Brady Quinn, Brandon Weeden and Johnny Manziel -- were a combined 32-67 with Cleveland. Taking one in the second round reduces the risk to some degree, and if head coach Hue Jackson and quarterbacks coach David Lee can unlock his potential, Kizer is a steal here. Of course, that's if they get him to realize his considerable upside. -- Steve Muench

Tabor is a fluid athlete with good size and length for the position. Also flashes quality playmaking instincts with excellent production with 28 PBUs and 9 INTs (3 returned for TDs) over 26 career starts in the past 3 seasons. While Tabor has quality mirror skills there are questions about his explosiveness (VJ: 32" at pro day) and long speed (4.62 forty at combine). Will likely need to play in a heavy zone or press scheme to maximize his skill set. Better football player on tape than test scores indicates. Projects as a day two pick in deep CB class.-- March 29, 2017 Tabor is a long and fluid athlete who has good short-area quickness and flashes playmaking instincts with quality ball skills. He also shows the willingness to step up in run support. Tabor's best team fit will be within a heavy zone coverage scheme because of his lack of ideal long speed. -- Kevin Weidl Tabor lands in an ideal spot under defensive coordinator Teryl Austin's zone-heavy scheme. This will allow him to maximize his skill set and protect him vertically, as he lacks ideal speed and range. -- Kevin Weidl

A team captain as junior, McMillian has appeared in all 41 career games while starting all 26 games the past two seasons (2015-'16). Team leading 102 tackles in 2016. McMillan is an instinctive and physical inside linebacker with quality range as a run defender. Improved every year in coverage and tested well at combine. However, there are still questions whether he can be a three-down linebacker at the NFL level. McMillan hasthe potential to be off the board within the top 75 selections of the 2017 NFL Draft. -- March 15, 2017 A team captain as a junior, McMillan is an instinctive and hard-nosed run-stopper who gets off blocks, closes well in pursuit and tackles well. He also made strides in coverage at Ohio State and has enough range to develop into a three-down linebacker. -- Steve Muench Miami fills its most pressing need with McMillan, who is an excellent addition to a linebacking corps that includes Kiko Alonso and free-agent signing Lawrence Timmons. Miami may protect him on obvious passing downs early in his career, but I believe that he has the tools to develop into an every-down player for the Dolphins. -- Steve Muench

Tomlinson spent his first three seasons contributing as a reserve (30 appearances, 0 starts 2013-15) before starting all 15 games at DT in 2016, when he notched 62 tackles, 5.5 TFL and 3 sacks. He doesn't offer much upside as a pass rusher but Tomlinson is a stout run defender with the size, strength and instincts to contribute as a rotating DT/NT within a one and/or two-gap scheme. He also has great character. Durability could be a concern for some teams (torn ACL in both knees early in his career) but played all 49 games his last 3 years. Tomlinson carries a late-Day 2 grade. -March 9, 2017 Tomlinson has the size, strength and instincts to develop into an effective nose tackle or 3-4 defensive end who can help bolster a run defense. He's not much of a pass-rusher though. Also, there are medical concerns stemming from knee injuries earlier in his career. -- Steve Muench Tomlinson helps New York fill the void left by the departure of Johnathan Hankins in free agency. Tomlinson will add immediate depth on the interior and help make sure the Giants continue to be stout defending the run. They were tied for third in rush defense in 2016. -- Kevin Weidl

Melifonwu (mel-un-FON-woo) was born in London before moving to Massachusetts. A durable four-year starter at UConn, he missed just one of 49 games (shoulder injury vs. SMU 2015. He finished his career with 361 total tackles, including a team-high 128 in '16. He's a hard worker and well respected but not much of a vocal leader. Melifonwu improved throughout his career and became more consistent playing the ball in the air and with his aggressiveness in run support as a senior. Physically, he's freakishly gifted (see: Combine). Melifonwu grades out as a second-round prospect. -April 10, 2017 Melifonwu is a freakishly gifted athlete who turned heads with an outstanding combine workout. The four-year starter and hard worker also made steady improvements at Connecticut, most notably with his consistency playing the ball and his aggressiveness in run support. -- Steve Muench The Raiders have two effective starters at safety in Karl Joseph and Reggie Nelson, but Nelson turns 34 this year so Melifonwu projects as the No. 3 who could replace Nelson and team up with Joseph to give the Raiders one of the most talented safety tandems in the league. Oakland also values size at corner, and the versatile Melifonwu could line up on the outside at times as well. -- Steve Muench

Cunningham appeared in 36 games during three seasons at Vandy. All 22 career starts came in his last two years (2015-16), when he racked up 228 total tackles, 33 TFLs, 4.5 sacks and 6 forced fumbles. In 2016, he became the first player in school history to earn unanimous First Team All-America recognition. Cunningham should continue to improve his take-on skills and tackling as he gains more experience and strength. But you can't coach his length, athleticism and range (vs. run and in coverage). He projects as an every-down LB in the NFL and carries a Day-2 grade. -March 21, 2017 Cunningham is a long, athletic and versatile linebacker who fits in today's NFL game. He is still developing his instincts and must continue to improve his point of attack skills. He should be a contributor early in his career thanks to his range and value on third downs. -- Kevin Weidl This a great landing spot for Cunningham, a player who has big upside but needs some time to develop. The Texans will groom him to be Brian Cushing's eventual replacement and provide the Texans with a pair of playmakers on the inside, teamed up with Bernardrick McKinney (seventh in total tackles last year). -- Kevin Weidl

Pocic (Poe-sick) was a three-year starter with 37 career starts (27 at OC, nine at ROG, one at ROT). LSU was 25-12 with Pocic as a starter, including 20-7 with him at center. He's a bigger center prospect with quality agility, flexibility and leverage despite his taller frame. He also shows very good awareness and has the experience and size to potentially line up at guard. Pocic has excellent football character and has been durable throughout his career. His 2016 tape was not as strong as 2015, which made him a difficult evaluation. We grade him out as a mid-round prospect. March 13, 2017 Pocic dealt with some injuries and did not play as well as he did as a junior in 2015. But he has quick feet, good hands and is one of the most versatile offensive linemen in the class. He has the ability to line up at all five positions if need be. -- Kevin Weidl This is early to take Pocic, especially with Ohio State's Pat Elflein still on the board, but the pick makes sense considering Seattle gave up 42 sacks (27th in NFL) and averaged only 3.4 yards per rush (29th) last year. Look for Pocic to compete for one of the three interior offensive line spots. -- Steve Muench

'tawn-o pass-N-yo' is a 3 year starter that appeared in started in all 24 games the past two seasons (missed 8 games in 2014 with a knee injury). Team captain in 2016 with 21  TFLs and 11 sacks while earning CAA defensive player of the year honors. Started playing football as a junior in high school and still relatively raw instincts wise. However, has one of the higher ceilings of any prospects in this class due to a rare physical tools box. Projects as a day two pick who has the potential impact starter with proper coaching and development.  March 18, 2017 Kpassagnon is an FCS prospect who didn't start playing football until his junior year of high school, and his lack of ideal playing experience shows up at times. The flipside is that he has rare physical tools and one of the higher ceilings in this 2017 class. -- Steve Muench The Chiefs signed Bennie Logan to a one-year deal to replace Dontari Poe at NT but need to continue to infuse size and strength up front, as they ranked 26th against the run in 2016. Kpassagnon has a chance to develop and provide them with another big body at the 5-technique opposite of Chris Jones. -- Kevin Weidl

"chih-doe-bey ah-wooz-yeh" is a three year starter whose career production is impressive (226 tackles, 17 TFL, 9 sacks, 28 PBUs, 5 FFs, and 3 INTs). Awuzie has outstanding personal and football character, and he is one of the hardest working players in the Colorado program. An explosive athlete (see combine results) with good size. Awuzie has man-to-man limitations (See Bowl Game vs Oklahoma State) but he is very good in run support, he's instinctive in zone coverage and projects as a nickel-slot cornerback that will also cover kicks in the NFL. - April 4, 2017 A three-year starter with outstanding football character, Awuzie shows man-to-man limitations on tape, but he's an explosive athlete who tested well at the combine and shows above-average instincts in zone. He's also outstanding in run support and should cover kicks in the NFL. -- Steve Muench Awuzie is an excellent fit for Rod Marinelli's Cover 2-heavy scheme. He'll likely compete for a starting job at corner, but he's versatile enough to play safety where Dallas also has a need, and he has the potential to develop into a special-teams player as well. -- Steve Muench

Jones is a fourth year junior who was moved from the field to boundary safety in 2016 where he led the team with 109 tackles with 8 PBUs and 3 INTs. Jones lacks ideal experience  one full year as a starter (2016) -- and has room to develop in terms of instincts. However, he is an interchangeable and physical safety with excellent combination of size, athleticism and versatility. Jones should add immediate depth to a secondary and with the potential to quickly develop into a starter as he gains experience. He projects as an earlier day two selection.  April 50, 2017 Jones lacks ideal experience -- one full year as a starter (2016) -- and he has room to develop in terms of his instincts, but he's an interchangeable and physical safety with an above-average combination of size, speed and ball skills. -- Steve Muench This isn't a glaring need, but a great value for the Packers who add an athletic and interchangeable safety to a secondary that ranked 31st against the pass in 2016. Jones adds insurance for Morgan Burnett who enters a contract year.

Smith-Schuster was a three-year starter (40 games, 39 starts) who finished with 2013 catches for 3092 yards (14.5) and 25 TDs. His 213 career catches is fourth all-time at USC. Smith-Schuster will never take the top off of NFL defenses but he's a gifted wide receiver with solid size, good ball skills and a competitive fire. Smith-Schuster should emerge as a good No. 2 or No. 3 starter in the NFL. He grades out as a Day 2 prospect. -March 28, 2017 Smith-Schuster is a possession receiver who lacks elite top-end speed to stretch the field vertically. However, he has good size, runs quality routes and has very good hands and body control when adjusting to throws outside of his frame. -- Kevin Weidl Martavis Bryant has been conditionally reinstated, but Markus Wheaton signed with Chicago and Sammie Coates is coming off offseason groin surgery. Smith-Schuster is a savvy and physical route runner who is ready to contribute and push for a starting WR role for the Steelers early on. -- Steve Muench

Dawkins is a three year starter that has appeared in 45 games with 43 total starts at LOT. Dawkins doesn't have exceptional flexibility or athleticism but he's a powerful run blocker and plays within himself in pass pro. Lined up at OG at the Senior Bowl where he likely could find a home at the next level. Has the necessary length (35' arms) to line up at ROT. Suffered a season ending for injury in fifth game of freshman year (2013). Weight and diet may need to be monitored. Projects a day two pick who could quickly turn into a versatile starter.  March 22, 2017 Dawkins is expected to move inside to guard where he lined up at the Senior Bowl and he has the tools to quickly develop into a starter. He also has the long arms and enough athletic ability to provide some depth at right tackle. -- Steve Muench Dawkins is versatile player with the ability to line up at both guard and tackle, which helps shore up the Bills along the offensive line. He should eventually be groomed as Jordan Mills' replacement at right tackle. -- Kevin Weidl

A redshirt senior and four-year starter Moton (MOAT-ton) lined up at right tackle for three seasons and he could play right tackle most likely for teams that feature the power run game like Carolina. However, he fits best at guard where he lined up as a redshirt junior in 2015 and has the potential to quickly develop into a starter. In addition, there's a lot to like about his ability to provide depth at both positon early in his career, his durability (started 52 games in college) and his work ethic. Moton played right tackle in college, but he is a bit heavy legged in pass protection. He may be forced to bump inside to guard at the NFL level. That said, he has a thick and massive frame with natural inline power and plays with the physical disposition teams covet along the offensive line. -- Kevin Weidl Michael Oher (missed final 13 games of 2016) and Daryl Williams (started 10 games) are expected to compete for the right tackle spot, but Oher missed the final 13 games of the season because of a concussion, and Williams might be a better backup than a starter. Moton is capable of coming in and wining that right tackle spot. -- Steve Muench

A redshirt senior Ogunjobi (Oh-ghun-JOE-bee) is a four-year starter who recorded 28 tackles-for-loss over the past two seasons. He didn't start playing football until his sophomore season of high school and Charlotte didn't make the jump to the FBS until the 2015 season but he's quickly developed into a disruptive run stopper, he flashed the week of the Senior Bowl and he has the work ethic to realize his potential. He primarily lined up at nose tackle on tape and could play there in a one-gap scheme but he projects best at DT. Ogunjobi is a disruptive interior defensive tackle who has a good combination of quickness and power. He plays with quality leverage and flashes quick and heavy hands in combat to disengage from blocks. He has the versatility to fit within a one- or two-gap scheme. -- Kevin Weidl The Browns continue to address their defensive front line to help a defense that ranked 30th against the rush in 2016. Ogunjobi will have a chance to quickly develop into a strong contributor and eventually start. -- Kevin Weidl

(Ah-kellow) Witherspoon started 21 of 35 games played during three years at CU (senior year in high school was his first season of football, so he began at Sacramento City College in 2013). In 2015-16 combined, he had a modest three interceptions but racked up 26 PBUs. Witherspoon's height-weight-speed combination is outstanding and his Combine workout exceeded expectations (at 6026 and 188 pounds he ran a 4.45 40-yard dash, a 4.12 short shuttle, and a ... 3-cone, while also posting a vertical jump of 40.5" and a broad jump of 11'4"). Witherspoon grades out as a mid-round pick. -April 11, 2017 Witherspoon possesses a rare blend of height, length and top-end speed. He tested well, especially for a taller corner, in the agility drills. While he only intercepted three passes in three seasons at Colorado, he broke up 22 passes during the 2016 season. -- Steve Muench New general manager John Lynch continues to address a defense that allowed 480 points (tied for ninth most in NFL history) and 6,502 total yards (eighth most) last season. He also fills the 49ers' most pressing need outside of quarterback by taking Witherspoon, who projects as a Day 1 starter in new defensive coordinator Robert Saleh's scheme. -- Steve Muench

Kamara started at Alabama before transferring to a junior college and then Tennessee. He has the potential to develop into a three-down back. He was was named a 2016 team captain as the only redshirt junior but Alabama suspensions and 2014 arrest for driving without a learner's permit raise character concerns. Other red flags: has a history of knee injuries, didn't start until last year and has to improve consistency fielding punts to return punts in the NFL. While he didn't run quite as well as expected at the Combine, he led all running backs with a 39 1/2" vertical and 10'11" long jump. Kamara is a quick and sudden runner who runs behind his pads and with better power than his size indicates. He is also a polished route runner who adds quality versatility to the passing game. Off-the-field concerns include Kamara being twice suspended in his time at Alabama and a 2014 arrest for driving without a license. -- Kevin Weidl Kamara gives the Saints a dynamic runner and a versatile reserve behind Mark Ingram and Adrian Peterson. He should be a strong contributor on third downs as an outlet for Drew Brees in the passing game. -- Kevin Weidl

A two-year starter and 2016 team captain Dawuane (duh-WON) Smoot recorded 30 tackles-for-loss and 13 sacks in addition to forcing five fumbles over the past two seasons. He's not as consistently disruptive on his 2016 tape as he is on his 2015 tape and he did not make much of an impression the week of the Senior Bowl. That said he projects as a situational pass rusher with the work ethic and enough natural ability to develop into an every-down LDE or possibly 34OLB if he regains his form and plays like he did in 2015. He projects as a fringe Day 2 pick with that in mind. Smoot flashes the quickness and bend to develop into an effective pass-rusher. He needs to continue to add bulk and improve strength to become every down player. Projects as a situational pass-rusher early in his career. -- Kevin Weidl You can never have enough edge rushers, and Smoot flashes some upside getting after the quarterback. However, the Jaguars need Smoot to play like he did in 2015 and make an impact as a situational pass-rusher. Considering their depth at defensive end, they could have filled more pressing needs here. -- Steve Muench

A two-time team captain and four-time consensus FCS All-American, Kupp broke 15 FCS records at Eastern Washington finishing his illustrious career with 428 catches for 6,464 yard and 73 touchdowns. He caught 40 passes for 716 yards and 11 touchdowns in four games against Pac-12 teams. He didn't test as well as expected 4.62 40-dash and 31' VJ are both red flags -but he's a better football player than athlete and he plays slightly faster than his timed speed. Kupp projects as a productive No. 2 or No. 3 possession receiver who should push for early playing time. Day 2 grade. April 14, 2017 Kupp is not the biggest or the fastest receiver, but he is a tough player who possesses reliable hands and has a natural feel as a route runner. He is at his best working against zone coverage where he flashes excellent spatial awareness getting into open windows. -- Kevin Weidl The Rams continue to provide help for Jared Goff with Kupp, who is a reliable target with a great feel for the position. With the addition of Kupp, TE Gerald Everett and Robert Woods in free agency, St. Louis has started to revamp its pass-catching corps. -- Kevin Weidl

Elflein (ELF-line) played 54 career games with 42 starts (both guard positions before making a seamless move to center in 2016). He has adequate size and athletic limitations (as seen in poor Combine showing) but he's stronger than his frame indicates and highly efficient thanks to great angles, technique and toughness. Coaches rave about his work ethic, football IQ and leadership. Elflein should be a plug-and-play starter as a rookie. He grades out as one of the top interior offensive linemen in the class and should come off the board on Day 2 pick of the 2017 NFL Draft. -April 3, 2017 Elflein, who is the top-ranked center on our board, is on the smaller side. He doesn't have great athletic ability, but he has the length, toughness and smarts to be a Day 1 starter at center. He's also versatile enough to line up at guard. -- Steve Muench Minnesota needed to address its interior offensive line, and Elflein is an excellent value at this point in the draft, as he's the best center on our board. Look for him to compete for and win a starting spot at one of the interior offensive line positions for the Vikings. -- Steve Muench

Feeney is four year starter and team captain. Bumped out to ROT in 2016 but projects as a guard at the next level where he allowed just one sack (2,719 snaps) in 37 career games at ROG prior to his senior season. Missed four games in 2016 with a concussion and received a medical redshirt in 2013 after suffering a foot injury in preseason camp. Feeney doesn't have an elite physical tool box but he is a highly intelligent technician and a grinder that has a chance to develop into a quality starter sooner than later. Projects as a day two pick.  March 13, 2017 Feeney is a technician who plays on his feet, has good balance and a strong feel for angles. He doesn't have elite inline power, but he does a nice job of moving his feet upon contact and shows good patience in his pass sets. -- Kevin Weidl The Chargers take their second guard of the night and clearly aren't messing around when it comes to addressing the interior of the offensive line. Western Kentucky's Forrest Lamp projects as one starter and Feeney is more than capable of pushing Orlando Franklin, who has underperformed, for the other starting spot. -- Steve Muench

The past two seasons Taywan (TAY-waan) Taylor led all FBS players with 3,197 receiving yards and 34 touchdown catches. His 184 receptions over that span ranked sixth in FBS. He set single season school records for receiving yards and receptions in 2015 then broke both records again in 2016. He hasn't just victimized Conference USA competition either as he put up big numbers against Vanderbilt and Alabama in 2016 in addition to LSU in 2015. He's an explosive playmaker with the ability to make an immediate impact on offense and potentially contribute to the return game. Taylor is an explosive playmaker with the burst, open-field instincts and elusiveness to threaten after the catch and potentially contribute in the return game. He put up big numbers against Vanderbilt and Alabama in 2016 and against LSU in 2015. -- Steve Muench After taking Western Michigan's Corey Davis in Round 1, general manager Jon Robinson continues to surround quarterback Marcus Mariota with weapons. Taylor has the tools to make an immediate impact working out of the slot for the Titans. -- Steve Muench

Willis is a durable 3 year starter -- 39 consecutive starts to end his career -- who has been productive with 40  TFLs and 26  sacks including career highs in TFLs (17 1/2) and sacks (11 1/2) as a senior. Put up rare combine testing numbers for his size. On tape, there are flashes that correlate with his test numbers but doesn't show it with consistency and he can develop more of a physical edge to his game. Willis has the potential and tools to develop into an above-average starter down the road as versatile edge defender within a base 43 or 34 scheme.  April 5, 2017 Willis has athleticism for his size and brings excellent production over the past two seasons (33 TFLs, 21 sacks). While his snap anticipation is a bit inconsistent, he has very good first-step quickness with quality flexibility and speed-to-power capabilities to develop into an effective edge rusher. -- Kevin Weidl The Bengals needed to add another young pass-rusher opposite of Carlos Dunlap, and Willis is just that. He has a chance to eventually replace -- and be an upgrade on -- Michael Johnson. -- Kevin Weidl

Wormley redshirted in 2012 before playing in all 51 games (30 starts) during his four seasons of eligibility. He started 23 of 26 games played his final two years (2015-16), racking up 83 tackles, 23.5 TFL and 12.5 sacks. Wormley has some versatility as an interior defender capable of playing DT in a base 4-3 and DE (five technique) in a 3-4 front. He is a long, well-proportioned defender who does his best work versus the run. He will never be a good pass rusher but at least he's capable of getting some push and occasionally moving the QB off his spot. He carries a Day 2 grade. March 22, 2017 Wormley is a long, well-proportioned defender who does his best work against the run. He will struggle to be a good pass-rusher, but at least he's capable of getting some push and occasionally moving the QB off his spot. -- Kevin Weidl The Ravens add another big and powerful body to their front line in an effort to replace Lawrence Guy and Timmy Jernigan, who departed this offseason.
