Wormley should help the Ravens continue to maintain a rushing defense that ranked fifth in the league last season. -- Kevin Weidl

Riley was a team captain who led the team with 93 tackles in his first year as a full-time starter in 2016. He is an undersized three-down linebacker with solid FBIs and flashed impressive savvy on tape despite his lack of experience. Riley also brings value as an experienced special teams stand-out for the Tigers. While he's not quite as explosive, Riley's rise as a senior is similar to former teammate Deion Jones (ATL 2nd round pick 2016) with both taking advantage of their lone year as a starter and strong Senior Bowl performances. Riley grades out as a Day 2 prospect.  April 6, 2017 Riley is an instinctive and rangy three-down linebacker. He doesn't have elite power at the point of the attack, but he shows savvy negotiating traffic inside the tackle box and finding the football. He's an extremely reliable tackler who holds up well in space. -- Kevin Weidl Coach Dan Quinn continues to infuse speed on the defensive side of the ball. Similar to Deion Jones (2016, second round), Riley is another space linebacker who should help provide the Falcons with more range and versatility at the second level of their defense. -- Kevin Weidl

Alex 'anne-zuh-LOAN-ee' is a redshirt junior that comes with big durability concerns with three separate shoulder and arm injuries while piecing together just one full season in his four years at Florida. He shows fast eyes, good range and is reliable as tackler. Anzalone was off to a fast start in 2016 with 53 tackles, 4 TFLs and 3 sacks before suffering a season ending broken left forearm against Arkansas. Anzalone's draft status will vary due to individual medical checks but he has a chance to be a steal in the mid-rounds if he can remain healthy.  March 10, 2016 The medical concerns are significant for Anzalone, who has sustained multiple shoulder injuries and a broken forearm. He could prove to be a steal if he stays healthy because he's a fundamentally sound tackler with above-average instincts and range. -- Steve Muench The Saints continue to target defense with Anzalone, who will provide immediate depth. After signing A.J. Klein, the Saints now have quality depth at the second level. -- Kevin Weidl

In his final two seasons (2015-16), Williams racked up 28.5 TFL and 19.5 sacks. In 2016, 52-percent of his tackles came behind the line of scrimmage. But his sack production dipped in 2016, including zero solo sacks in final five games. Williams is a pass-rush specialist who excels when his lone job is to attack the QB off the edge. Based purely off tape, he grades out as a Day 2 prospect. However, character baggage (report he failed multiple drug tests at Alabama and was suspended for first half vs. Kentucky 2016 after arrest on misdemeanor gun charge) could cause him to slide. -March 9, 2017 Williams is an explosive speed rusher who has exceptional first-step quickness and excellent flexibility bending the edge. He is still developing in terms of instincts and can continue to get stronger to become more consistent versus the run. -- Kevin Weidl General manager Ozzie Newsome continues to address the pass rush. Williams doesn't project as an every-down player as a rookie, but he should make immediate contributions as a situational pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

A two-year starter and redshirt junior ArDarius (R-Darius) Stewart led the Tide in receiving yards (864), yards per reception (16.0) and receiving touchdowns (8) despite missing three games last year. He has the ability plus the work ethic to develop into an effective No.2 and should make early contributions as a sub-package receiver thanks to his ability to move around the formation and produce after the catch. He also has experience returning and covering kicks. There are minor red flags as he served a one-game suspension and missed two games with a leg injury in 2016. Stewart is a tough competitor with the burst, determination and top-end speed to produce after the catch and potentially return kickoffs in the NFL. He's a natural pass-catcher who has above-average body control and good length for his frame. -- Steve Muench Stewart helps ease the loss of Brandon Marshall, who is now with the New York Giants. Stewart adds another young target next to Robby Anderson, who flashed as a rookie. Stewart has the ability to line up inside and outside the hashes. -- Kevin Weidl

Bashum has 37 career starts with 42  TFLs and 29  sacks over the past four seasons. Career highs in TFLs (16) and sacks (11  ) in 2016. He is a hybrid edge defender that needs development with his technique but possesses the size, athleticism and explosive traits that translate well to the NFL game. Also brings added value as a core special teams player. Tough upbringing and dealt with some immaturity early in career, but overall football character is good. Projects as a fringe day two pick with the potential to develop into a starter within a year or two.  April 5, 2017 Basham is a hybrid edge defender who needs to develop his technique, but he possesses the size, athleticism and explosive traits that translate well to the NFL. Also brings added value as a core special-teams player. -- Kevin Weidl New general manager Chris Ballard continues to address a defense that finished 30th in the league in yards allowed per game, filling one of the Colts' most pressing needs by taking Basham here. Basham is a good fit at 3-4 OLB in the Colts' 3-4 scheme, and he should push for a starting role early on. -- Steve Muench.

Moreau finished his career with 51 games played (40 starts). He suffered a season-ending Lisfranc injury in the third game of 2015 but he returned healthy in 2016, starting all 12 games and finishing with 37 tackles, 9 PBUs and 2 INTs. Moreau must improve at tracking the ball in the air but he is an experienced cover corner with good size and excellent measurables (Combine: 4.35 40-dash, 4.21 20-shuttle, 38" VJ, 11-4 BJ). Moreau grades out as a second round prospect. -March 25, 2017 Moreau is a long, athletic and rangy press cornerback. He uses his size and strength to his advantage to disrupt receivers at the line of scrimmage and is a willing tackler in run support. He can become more consistent locating and playing the ball. -- Kevin Weidl The Redskins return both cornerback starters in Josh Norman and Bashaud Breeland. However, Breeland is entering a contract year and Moreau is a solid fit to be an eventual replacement and help a pass defense that ranked 25th in the league. -- Kevin Weidl

A redshirt junior, Henderson finished 2016 with 1,535 receiving yards on 82 catches. He tied Western Michigan's Corey Davis for the FBS lead in touchdown receptions with 19 despite playing in one less game. He set the NCAA Division I record for consecutive games scoring at least one touchdown with 35. He is a fierce competitor who has above average speed and tested well in terms of lower body explosiveness -10'11" broad and 36" vertical - but he's undersized, he's had some problems staying healthy and his average 10-yard split doesn't match up with the burst he shows on tape. Henderson is on the smaller side, and he's had some problems staying healthy, but he's a tenacious competitor who separates, catches the ball well and is a threat to turn a catch underneath into a big play. He's also fast enough to stretch the field. -- Steve Muench Demaryius Thomas and Emmanuel Sanders both eclipsed the 1,000-yard mark in receiving last season, but no other receiver or tight end had over 23 catches. Henderson should step into that No. 3 role. -- Steve Muench

Rivers did a prep school year at Fork Union (2012) and played as a reserve freshman at Youngstown in 2013 before taking over as a fulltime starter in 2014. He dominated the small school level of competition the past three seasons with 160 total tackles, 52 TFL and 38 sacks. Rivers, who had top-five DL results at the Combine in the 40 (4.61), bench press (30), VJ (35") and 3-cone (6.94), played LDE in a base 4-3 and is a 3-4 OLB conversion candidate in the NFL. He's been durable, has no off-the-field baggage, loves the game, and is a vocal leader. Rivers carries a Day 2 grade. -April 3, 2017 Rivers dominated the level of competition he faced at Youngstown. He also eased concerns about that competition and his ability to move to a 3-4 scheme by finishing in the top five for defensive linemen in the 40-yard dash, three-cone drill, vertical jump and bench press at the combine. -- Steve Muench This is a pure value pick for the Patriots, who continue to infuse a strong defense with another versatile edge defender in the front seven. -- Kevin Weidl

Godwin is third year junior who has proven durable appearing in all 40 career games. He finished his career starting in 25 of 27 contests the past two seasons while recording 128 catches for 2,083 yards (16.3 YPC) and 16 touchdowns in that span. Displays some tightness with underneath routes but Godwin is a tough and physical receiver with above-average size and excellent ball skills. Coaches speak highly of his humbleness, work ethic and overall football character. Helped stock by testing much better than anticipated at the combine. Projects as a top 100 pick. -- April 5, 2017 Godwin is a physical route runner with an above-average blend of height, weight and top-end speed, and he helped himself with a strong showing at the combine. He's also sure-handed with the body control, leaping ability and focus to make tough catches. -- Steve Muench The Buccaneers continue to build an arsenal for quarterback Jameis Winston. Godwin has a chance to do some damage in one-on-one matchups with the attention DeSean Jackson and Mike Evans will command. -- Kevin Weidl

Garcia was a redshirt senior and four-year starter who lined up at left tackle at Troy. His arm length (33 3/8') is a red flag for offensive tackles and he's struggled to keep weight on 293 pounds at Senior Bowl raising concerns about his ability to transition inside. While he's not been a problem off the field, there are concerns about maturity and work ethic. He sustained a season-ending knee injury in 2013. His tape is erratic and he's a bit of a project but if developed properly he has the tools to emerge as a LOT starter in the NFL. Best tape of 2016 was versus Clemson. -April 5, 2017 Garcia has less than ideal arm length for an offensive tackle, but he makes up for it with quick feet, good balance and shows a compact and powerful punch in pass protection. He has adequate inline power as a run-blocker and flashes an edge to his game. While he hasn't had problems off the field, there are concerns about Garcia's maturity and work ethic. -- Kevin Weidl Garcia is a versatile lineman and could be groomed to take over at left tackle for Nate Solder, who is entering a contract year. -- Kevin Weidl

Hunt finished his four-year career with outstanding production (Rushing: 782-4,945-6.3-44. Receiving: 73-555-7.6-1). He was mostly durable and has exceptional ball security, but he enters the NFL with 855 career touches. His role as a pass catcher increased in 2016 (career-high 41 catches) and his elusiveness in space should make him a receiving weapon in the NFL. While he lacks top-end speed, Hunt creates his own yards thanks to a high-level combination of balance, vision and lower-body strength. Hunt projects as a versatile rotation back and carries a mid-round grade. April 10, 2017 Hunt runs with a good combination of balance, vision and lower-body strength. He doesn't have to come off the field on third down, either. He's a reliable receiver who makes defenders miss and he flashes the potential to develop into an effective pass-blocker. -- Steve Muench Kansas City had a need at running back after cutting Jamaal Charles, and Hunt's ability to contribute on all downs makes him a good fit for the Chiefs' scheme. -- Steve Muench

Webb passed for 5,557 yards and 46 TDs in 23 games at Texas Tech but lost his starting job and transferred to Cal, where he was a one-year starter (all 12 games) in 2016. He completed 61.6-percent of his throws at Cal with a 3-to-1 TD-to-INT ratio. Webb has had some durability issues, he needs to transition from the Air Raid offense to a pro system, and his accuracy is inconsistent. On the positive side, he has prototypical size, very good arm strength, and the football intelligence to absorb. Webb grades out as a late-Day 2 prospect. -April 9, 2017 A Texas Tech transfer who has had some durability issues, Webb will face a steep learning curve in his transition from the Air Raid offense, and his accuracy is inconsistent. On the positive side, he has prototypical size, very good arm strength and the football intelligence to absorb. -- Kevin Weidl Eli Manning is 36 years old, and while the Giants signed Geno Smith to a one-year deal, they don't seem to be the heir apparent. Taking Webb now allows head coach Ben McAdoo and his staff time to help the quarterback transition from the Air Raid offense he played in to a pro-style offense. -- Steve Muench

Vanderdoes played in 39 game (32 starts) and finished with 122 tackles, 13.5 TFL, and 4.5 sacks. Unfortunately, he tore his ACL in UCLA's 2015 season-opener vs. Virginia and sat out the remainder of the year. He returned to start all 12 games '16 but was overweight and lacked the same explosiveness from earlier in his career. The results were reflected in his modest production (27-1.5-1.5). He's a powerful DT with the versatility to fit in a base 43 or 34 front. Vanderdoes' medical reports and football character will play big factors in what portion of Day 3 he's drafted. -March 1, 2017 Vanderdoes projects as a powerful run stopper who won't make much of an impact rushing the passer. He missed most of the 2015 season after tearing an ACL, and last year, he was overweight and didn't show the same explosiveness as earlier in his career. -- Steve Muench The Raiders ranked 23rd in rushing defense last season, and Vanderdoes adds size and power on the interior, especially if he is able to return to the 2014 form he showed on tape. -- Kevin Weidl

A one-year starter and true junior D'Onta (dee-ON-tay) Foreman rushed for more yards per game (184.4) than any other back in the FBS last year and his 2,028 rushing yards were second-most in school history. He's a powerful runner with above average upside but he missed at least one game with an injury in each of his three seasons at Texas and he was held out of the Combine after doctors found stress fracture in foot. There are two other concerns - ball security and he'll have to make substantial strides as a receiver and pass blocker to develop into an every-down back. Foreman's injury history and ball security issues are reason for concern. Plus, he's faster than he is quick. However, he possesses a rare blend of size and top-end speed, and he averaged more rushing yards per game (184.4) than any other FBS back last season. -- Steve Muench Houston is looking to ease Lamar Miller's workload, as he was effective but dealt with ankle, shoulder and rib injuries last season. Forman has the talent to step into the No. 2 role and help keep Miller fresh and healthy. -- Steve Muench

Griffin is a 2 year starter who is coming off his most production season in 2016 recording 15 PBUs and 4 INTs. Griffin is a bigger CB with long arms (32 3/8') and has intriguing athleticism on tape which was confirmed by outstanding test results at the NFL Combine (40-4.37; VJ-38 1/2"; BJ-11'0") . However, he lacks ideal instincts at this point and needs a lot of coaching with technique. Projects as a day three developmental prospect that has the traits to develop into a quality starter if he can learn to play with better eye discipline and continue to mature off the field. -- March 11, 2016 Griffin lacks ideal instincts at this point and needs some polish with his technique. However, Griffin is a bigger cornerback with long arms (32 3/8-inch arms) and has intriguing athleticism on tape to become an adequate reserve with the potential to develop into a starter down the road. -- Kevin Weidl Seattle looks to groom Richard Sherman's potential eventual replacement here. Griffin is raw, but he has big-time upside and the quality size the Seahawks covet at the position. -- Kevin Weidl

An arm injury cost Johnson five games of his sophomore year (2014), but he played in 20 games (two starts) at CB and on special teams his first two seasons (2013-14). Johnson moved to FS in 2015 and started all 25 games his final two seasons, combining for 140 tackles, 12 PBUs, 6 INTs and 3 FFs. He's a high energy, positive individual who is well respected by teammates. Also a hard worker with no baggage. He's been productive on cover teams and also blocked a kick in '15, so he's likely to be a core special teamer in the NFL. Johnson grades out as a mid-round prospect. -March 19, 2017 Johnson needs to continue to get stronger and become more consistent in run support. He is an instinctive and fluid athlete who shows quality range. Johnson also has the ball skills to finish when in position. Comes with some minor durability concerns from early in his career. -- Kevin Weidl General manager Les Snead fills a need and gets a good value at this point in the draft with Johnson. The Rams tied for 23rd in takeaways last season (18), and Johnson has the ball skills and instincts to give them a playmaker on the back end. -- Steve Muench

Lewis finished his four-year career with 48 games played (30 starts) and emerged as one of college football's premier cover corners the past two seasons (2015-16). Similar to Jason Verrett (Charge) -- minus the 4.39 speed -- Lewis is undersized but physical, and possesses elite coverage instincts and body control. Lewis projects as a nickel starter early in his career and should develop into a good fulltime starter down the line. It's impossible to predict the outcome of his recent off-the-field issue, but purely from a football perspective Lewis carries an early Day-2 grade. April 14, 2017 Lewis is one of the most naturally instinctive corners we've studied in years and he's tough for his size both in coverage and stepping up in run support. He's also got the closing burst and ball skills to develop into a playmaker. -- Steve Muench It's not surprising that the Cowboys have taken two corners, considering they parted ways with starters Brandon Carr and Morris Claiborne. Lewis has the toughness and instincts to make early contributions in Dallas' scheme, plus he has the ball skills to help a defense that had only 20 takeaways (tied for 19th) last season. -- Steve Muench

Adams was a fourth-year senior in 2016 who appeared in 52 career games (36 starts) tallying 151 tackles, 21 TFLs, and 11 sacks. He is a one-gap penetrator that has ideal size and quickness as a three technique within a base 43 scheme. However, Adams is a bit of an underachiever to this point whose production and tape don't always match his physical ability. The 2016 season was a "contract year", so Adams' effort was much more consistent than in 2015. While he's gifted enough to warrant second-round consideration, we think there's enough risk here to hold off until Round 3. April 8, 2017 Adams is a disruptive one-gap penetrator who has ideal size and quickness for a three-technique prospect. He underachieved for much of his time at Auburn though, and his effort in 2016 was far more consistent than it was during the 2015 season. -- Steve Muench This isn't necessarily a big need, but it's a strong value. Adams has the versatility to line up in multiple spots and provide disruption, if Green Bay can get him to play with consistency. -- Kevin Weidl

Sutton is a four year starter that made 40 consecutive starts to begin his career before suffering a fractured right ankle in the 2nd game of the season in 2016 (missed 5 games). He is a fluid athlete with quality mirror skills and average size. Quality career ball production: 28 PBUs  6 INTs. Recorded 4 PBUs and 1 INT in seven games in 2016. Brings added value on special teams as returner (3 career PR for TDs). Needs to become more consistent in run support. Sutton projects a fringe day two pick who could end up finding a home as starting NB in the NFL. -- March 26, 2017 Sutton dealt with a lower leg injury and failed to get on track as a senior in 2016. He has average size but shows quality awareness, along with the quickness and mirror skills to potentially develop into a starter as a slot corner. -- Kevin Weidl The Steelers hit on CB Artie Burns (first round, 2016) and safety Sean Davis (second, 2016) but need to continue to get more talent in the secondary. Sutton could be an upgrade for CB Ross Cockrell, who is more suited as a reserve than a starter. -- Kevin Weidl

Hill appeared in 46 career games making 26 starts including all 13 at strong safety in 2016 where he recorded 51 tackles, 3 PBUs and 3 INTs. Bigger safety with good athleticism  tested well at the combine  enough range to hold up in the back and can matchup with tight ends in man coverage. Not much of a playmaker at this point but he has the ability to depth to a secondary while also contribute on special teams early in his career. Suspended for the Maryland game for violating team rules in 2014. Projects as a mid-day three pick.  March 9, 2016 A bigger safety with enough range to hold up in the back end, Hill can also matchup with tight ends in man coverage. He's not much of a playmaker at this point, but he has the ability to add depth to a secondary while also contributing on special teams early in his career. -- Kevin Weidl Seattle needed to add depth, considering strong safety Kam Chancellor had offseason surgery to remove bone spurs from both ankles and missed four games with a groin injury in 2016, plus he's going into a contract year. Hill is a good fit at strong safety in the Seahawks' scheme. -- Steve Muench

Golladay began his career at North Dakota (FCS) before transferring to Northern Illinois in 2014 (sat out that season per NCAA transfer rules). Racked up 160 catches (averaged 14.3 ypc) and 18 receiving touchdowns durin two season as a starter at NIU (2015-16). In 2016, he also rushed for 9.6 yards on 20 carries with two more scores. Golladay is a huge target with a somewhat linear frame and above average speed for his size. He has a chance to develop into a No. 4 WR in the NFL and can help on the perimeter, especially in the red zone. Golladay is a big target with good hands and above-average speed for his size. He struggles to separate transitioning out of breaks, though. He has a chance to develop into a No. 4 receiver who potentially makes his biggest impact in the red zone. -- Steve Muench Golden Tate had a strong year and Marvin Jones returns, but 36-year-old Anquan Boldin is a free agent and may not return. Taking Golladay this early is a reach, but he has a high ceiling and the Lions shouldn't need him to play too significant a role as a rookie. -- Steve Muench

Cordrea (cohr-DRAY) Tankersley played mostly on special teams his first two seasons (2013-14) before taking over as fulltime starter in 30 games the past two years (2015-16). He has good height-weight-speed combination. He's at his best playing on the line and he had great ball production during his two seasons as a starter. However, Tankersley has some tightness, he's not nearly as effective in off-man coverage, and he's had pass interference problems as a result of ball tracking inconsistency. For teams with heavier press-man/zone schemes, Tankersley could be a mid-round fit. April 1, 2017 Tankersley is a playmaker with an impressive blend of size, length and top-end speed, but he's not as effective in off coverage as he is in press. He has also been flagged for pass interference eight times over the past two seasons. -- Steve Muench The Dolphins needed to add depth behind Byron Maxwell and 2016 second-round pick Xavien Howard, who both missed time last year with injuries. Tankersly may see time in the slot early on. -- Kevin Weidl

Averaged over 15 yards on 154 catches with 23 TDs his final two seasons at Grambling. Limited experience as a punt returner. Had a solid Senior Bowl week. Ran a 4.40 40-yard dash at pro day. Day 3 grade. Has potential to contribute on offense and special teams in the NFL. -April 17, 2017 Williams is average sized with above average top-end speed and ball skills. He also eased concerns about the level of competition he faced at Grambling with a sold week at the Senior Bowl and a big game at Arizona in 2016. -- Steve Muench Larry Fitzgerald is still productive but turns 34 this year, the effects of the sickle-cell trait slowed John Brown last season and Arizona released Michael Floyd, so adding a young receiver here makes sense. There's a lot to like about Williams' top-end speed, making him a good fit for the Cardinals. -- Steve Muench

'ra-SOO-ell' Douglas started his career at Nassau CC before transferring to West Virginia the past two seasons. He is a high-cut, long and rangy cornerback with exceptional ball skills. Finished the 2016 season tied for the FBS lead with 8 INTs while adding 8 PBUs in his first year as a starter. Douglas' best fit will be within a heavy press man or zone scheme (Seattle) where he can maximize his size and physicality while minimizing some of the tightness he shows in off coverage. Projects as a third round pick with the potential to turn into starter within a year or two. -- April 6, 2017 Douglas is a longer press cornerback who shows excellent range and the physicality to defend the run. He also possesses strong ball awareness (tied for the FBS lead with eight interceptions in his first year as a starter in 2016). -- Kevin Weidl Philadelphia continues to attack its most pressing need and takes its second corner of the night. Douglas is a good fit for defensive coordinator Jim Schwartz's scheme, and the Eagles could very well have landed a starter here. -- Steve Muench

A four-year starter "JOHN-new" Smith hasn't been as productive the past two seasons as he was in 2014 when he caught 61 passes for 710 yards and eight touchdowns. A knee injury that forced him to miss the final four games of the 2015 season raises concerns about his durability and teams will have questions regarding an incident where his girlfriend pouring boiling water on him in the fall of 2016. That said his work ethic, ability to separate and ability to produce after the catch could lead a team to draft this F prospect on Day 3 despite his below average hands and small frame. April 5, 2017 Smith lacks ideal length and needs to get more consistent as an inline blocker. However, he is an explosive athlete with the speed and reliable hands to develop into an adequate target in the passing game as a move or "F" tight end. -- Kevin Weidl Tennessee adds yet another weapon in Smith, who has the talent to make an immediate impact in the passing game and improve the tight end depth behind Delanie Walker. -- Steve Muench

Langley is a Georgia transfer who started 17 games over the past two seasons at Lamar and finished the 2016 season with 43 tackles, seven passes broken up and six interceptions. His senior season was by far his most productive and it came against FCS competition. While he doesn't have great change of directions skills he's a playmaker with the natural ability to develop into an effective starter in press and press zone schemes. He's also a dangerous punt returner who returned 21 punts for 245 yards and two touchdowns. Langley has the length, strength and ball skills to develop into an effective press corner. While we like his ability as a returner (two TDs last season), he shows tightness in coverage and he needs to improve his recognition. -- Steve Muench Aqib Talib and Chris Harris Jr. are signed through 2019 and Denver is expected to pick up the fifth-year option for nickelback Bradley Roby. This is a little early to target Langley, but he's got a high ceiling and is a good fit for defensive coordinator Joe Woods' scheme. -- Steve Muench

"nah-ZAYR" Jones is a redshirt junior who has 3 years of starting experience (34 games). Finished the 2016 season with 70 tackles, 9.5 TFLs and 2.5 sacks. Jones can develop as a pass rusher and play with more consistency as he will disappear on tape at times. However, he has an intriguing physical skill set with a combination of size, athleticism and power. Has a rare chronic disease (Complex Regional Pain Syndrome) and teams have expressed some concerns about football character which may weigh into his final grade. Jones projects as a mid-round pick. -- April 5, 2017 Jones needs some development as a pass-rusher and can play with more consistency at times. However, he has an intriguing physical skill set with a combination of size, athleticism and power to develop with the potential to add depth on the interior of a front line. -- Kevin Weidl Seattle doesn't have great depth behind 2016 second-round pick Jarran Reed and Ahtyba Rubin, who turns 31 this year. They have addressed that by adding Malik McDowell in the second and now Jones. -- Steve Muench

Hendrickson was a three-year starter who played in all 48 games during four seasons at FAU (2013-16). He tallied 41 career TFL, 29 sacks and 7 forced fumbles (29.5 TFL, 22.5 sacks, 6 FFs his last two years). He's an effort-based edge rusher who dominated "Group of Five" competition. He has an excellent size-speed combo and he's a relentless pass rusher. However, Hendrickson has short arms (which NFL OTs will exploit) and lacks flexibility bending the edge. He also needs to get stronger versus the run to see the field more (pass rush specialist right now). Early-Day 3 grade. -April 9, 2017 Hendrickson dominated "Group of Five" competition, thanks to his rentlessness as a pass-rusher. He has an excellent size-speed combination, but his shorter arms and lack of flexibility bending the edge are concerns. -- Kevin Weidl New Orleans ranked 27th in the NFL with 30 sacks last season and needs an edge rusher to complement Cameron Jordan (7.5 sacks). Hendrickson has the potential to become that player. -- Steve Muench

It will be hard to find a QB in this class with a better combination of competitiveness, toughness and football IQ than Beathard. He's an unselfish natural leader, and he's a tireless worker. As a passer, Beathard is fearless in the pocket and he has a high efficiency grade on pressure drops. However, Beathard simply has physical limitations that are tough to overcome in the NFL. He lacks ideal size, many of his outside-the-numbers throws lose energy, he's not very mobile and he holds onto the ball too long. Projects as a good NFL backup and carries an early-Day 3 grade. -April 9, 2017 Beathard lacks an elite physical skill, but he is an unselfish leader and tireless worker -- all of which may allow him to overcome his physical deficiencies. He possesses a strong combination of competitiveness, toughness and football IQ to potentially develop into a serviceable backup. --- Kevin Weidl New general manager John Lynch and head coach Kyle Shanahan didn't target a quarterback ready to make an early contribution in the first two rounds, but they get a developmental prospect in Beathard here. -- Steve Muench

Conner rushed for 1,765 yards and 26 TDs as a sophomore in 2014 but sustained a season-ending right knee injury (MCL) in the 2015 opener, and then doctors discovered he had Hodgkin lymphoma while in rehab three months later. After 12 rounds of chemotherapy, Conner has been cancer free since May, 2016. He returned to rush for 1,092 yards on 216 carries and 16 TDs in 2016. Conner projects as a rotational power back who may never be a major weapon in the pass game but has soft hands as an outlet receiver and the size/toughness to protect. Conner grades out as a mid-round prospect. April 9, 2017 Conner is a highly competitive power back who runs with outstanding balance to grind out tough yards after contact. He may never be a major weapon in the pass game, but he shows soft hands as an outlet receiver, along with the size/toughness to protect. He'll contribute on special teams, too. -- Kevin Weidl Knile Davis signed a one-year deal and former backup DeAngelo Williams is a free agent (and 34), so Conner is expected to provide some much-needed depth behind Le'Veon Bell. -- Steve Muench

A three-year starter and 2016 captain Biegel's (BEE-gull) production dipped last year due in large part to a right foot injury that forced him to miss two games - Michigan and Ohio State. Adding to the medical concerns he missed the 2012 season with a foot injury. That said he made more of an impact on the 2016 tape than the stats suggest and he tested well at the Combine. He may be a better fit at SLB than he is at 34OLB where he lined up at Wisconsin but he projects as a backup who contributes on special teams and has the potential to develop into a starter if he checks out medically. Biegel is an instinctive and rangy run defender. He's also an relentless pass-rusher with the size and speed to compete with tight ends in coverage. He has a history of foot injuries, though, and his arms are on the shorter side for a 3-4 outside linebacker. -- Steve Muench

Johnson appeared in 47 games while making all of 27 career starts over the past two seasons. Nearly doubled his production for sacks (7 1/2) and TFLs (10) in his 2nd year as a starter. Also displayed improved strength, particularly in his lower half (showed more of power element as a rusher and improved anchor vs the run). His combine test results were not reflective of explosiveness seen on tape: 5.38 40-dash, 1.91 10-spli, 28" VJ and 8'4" BJ were all below average. Johnson is best suited for a one-gap heavy scheme and he has a chance to develop into a starter down the line. -March 22, 2017 Johnson didn't test as well as expected at the combine, but what shows on tape is that he's an effective run-stopper with above-average initial quickness. He is one of the most explosive interior pass-rushers in this 2017 class. -- Steve Muench

A redshirt senior Dede (DEE-dee) Westbrook is a JUCO transfer who broke Oklahoma's single-season receiving touchdown record (17) and he's the school's first Fred Biletnikoff Award winner. He projects as an explosive slot receiver and return man but he's an undersized prospect who has had problem staying healthy  ruptured intestines in high school, season-ending leg injury first year of community college and slowed by a hamstring injury last year. Some teams may take him off their boards considering he was arrested following domestic violence incidents twice before he got to Oklahoma. Westbrook is an explosive slot receiver and return man with excellent top-end speed, but he's undersized and there are concerns about his durability. Though he wasn't convicted in either case, he was also twice arrested on complaints of domestic violence before he got to Oklahoma. -- Steve Muench

Brother, Cedrick, plays safety for the Vikings. Tedric suffered a concussion vs. UCLA in 2014 but has otherswise been a durable player. Lacks initial burst, as seen in his poor 10-yard split (1.63) for a DS. But has good overall range and is athletic enough to matchup one-on-one versus many bigger WRs. Better deep than in the box. Great experience and instincts. Very good ball skills. Underrated player. Good value pick if on the board on Day 3. -April 15, 2017 Thompson has good range and is athletic enough to match up one-on-one vs. many bigger wide receivers. He is an experienced and instinctive player who has a chance to develop into a quality reserve. -- Kevin Weidl

Jackson was a fourth-year contributor who appeared in 18 games (15 starts) at CB his first two seasons (2013-14) before switching to free safety in 2015. He appears more comfortable at safety, where in 23 starts the last two years (2015-16) he racked up 12 PBUs and 7 INTs. Jackson is versatile and has ball-hawking skills but he needs to get stronger and become more consistent against the run. He grades out as a fringe Day-2 prospect coming into the 2016 season but durability (torn ACL in spring of 2014 and broken leg in Game 8 of 2016) could negatively affect his draft slot. -March 17, 2017 Jackson isn't a physical run stopper and he has durability questions, but the former corner is a ball hawk with above-average cover skills. He's also dangerous with the ball in his hands, returning two punts for touchdowns last year. -- Steve Muench

A redshirt senior Jenkins is a three-year starter who led Maim with 56 unassisted tackles last year and he finished his college career with nine interceptions. He ran well at the Combine (4.51) but he's more of a straight-line player with limitations in coverage. He has the frame, toughness and enough range to contribute as a reserve who also contributes on special teams early in his career and he has the potential to develop into a starter in time. Jenkins is a strong safety prospect who is a straight-line player with limitations in coverage. He has the frame, toughness and is a reliable tackler to add depth in the secondary while also contributing on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

Samaje (sah-MAH-jay) Perine (PEE-rine) punishing runner who rushed for 4,122 yards and 49 TDs on 685 carries (6.0 ypc) during three seasons at OU (2014-16). He is best suited for an offense that features the power-run game like Seattle and Carolina. He will never be a big-play weapon in the pass game but he can be an every-down back in the NFL because he's a reliable underneath outlet and he can pass protect. Durability could knock him down a bit but he has strong football character. Perine grades out as a Day 2 prospect. April 9, 2017 Perine isn't much of a big-play threat, but he is a powerful runner who makes the most of his blocking. He put up big numbers in three seasons at Oklahoma. He's also a reliable checkdown target and a willing blocker in pass protection. -- Steve Muench Washington fills one of its most pressing needs and gets an excellent value in Perine early on Day 3. He has the potential to emerge as the starter in the Redskins' backfield and help improve a ground game that ranked 21st in yards per game last year. -- Steve Muench

Johnson ended his Pitt career with 40 consecutive starts and took his game to another level as a senior in 2016, becoming the first Pitt offensive lineman to earn first-team All-America honors in 22 years (Ruben Brown, 1994). Johnson is durable, leads by example and was one of the hardest working players in the Pitt program. He was invited to the Senior Bowl but a minor injury prevented him from participating. Johnson should be a plug-and-play starter at guard in the NFL. He's one of the top interior offensive linemen in the 2017 class and grades out as a Day 2 prospect. -March21, 2017 Johnson is a tough and reliable guard who plays on his feet with quality balance. He has adequate inline power as a run-blocker who moves his feet well to sustain blocks. He also shows good flexibility and quick feet in pass protection. Johnson has a chance to add immediate depth to an NFL team and could quickly develop into a starter. -- Kevin Weidl

Lawson had his healthiest and most productive season in 2016, when he racked up 13.5 TFL and nine sacks. He's a sawed-off Tasmanian devil of an edge defender with a great passion for the game. He is stout against the run and brings a strong combination of quickness and power as a pass rusher. However, Lawson is shorter than ideal and comes with a history of durability problems (Missed entire 2014 season with a torn ACL; Missed six games in 2015 with a hip injury). Lawson grades out as a later Day 2 pick for teams that are comfortable with him medically. -March 13, 2017 Lawson's injury history -- torn ACL in 2014 and hip injury in 2015 -- is a concern. Plus, he's got short arms. On the other hand, he's a tone-setter against the run and a relentless pass-rusher who has violent hands and above-average closing speed. -- Steve Muench

Reynolds transferred from Tyler Junior College in 2014 and started all 38 games during his three seasons at Texas A&M (2014-16). He was the team's leading receiver in 2016 (61-1,039-12) and finished his three-year career with 153 catches for 2,611 yards and 30 TDs. Reynolds needs to get stronger and become more consistent with his ball skills (makes a lot of tough catches but drops too many easy ones), but he's a longer receiver with big play ability (career 17.1 YPC). Reynolds grades out as a mid-round prospect. -February 10, 2017 Reynolds is quick enough to separate underneath and fast enough to stretch the field, but he's lean and needs to get stronger. He also needs to improve his consistency fielding the ball. He makes a lot of tough catches and drops too many easy ones. -- Steve Muench The Rams hired a young, offensive-minded head coach in Sean McVay and needed to help second-year quarterback Jared Goff, so using three of their first four picks on pass-catchers makes sense. Reynolds projects as a sub-package receiver who can help the Rams stretch the field early in his career. -- Steve Muench

Hollins is a big and physical WR with the speed to stretch the field vertically (20.6 YPC for career). While he only recorded 81 career catches nearly a  of them went for a touchdown (20). A former walk-on who plays with a chip on his shoulder and was a special teams captain throughout his career (see competitiveness).Had his 2016 season cut short after suffering a broken collarbone in the seventh game of the season. Hollins is one of the more underrated WRs and could end up being a steal for a vertical passing offense in the third or fourth round.  March 8, 2017 Hollins, who is coming off a season-ending broken collarbone injury, is a former walk-on with the frame, length and top-end speed to stretch the field. A special teams captain throughout his college career, he projects as a core special teams' player at the next level. -- Steve Muench This is an excellent pick for the Eagles, who get a receiver with size-speed combination to stretch the field and is outstanding on special teams. -- Steve Muench

Cohen is the inaugural recipient of the Black College Football Player of the Year Award. He started 40 games at FCS North Carolina A&T finishing with 5,619 yards and 56 touchdowns on 868 carries in addition to 98 catches for 945 yards and three touchdowns. His size will likely prevent him from developing into a starter plus his frame and heavy workload raise durability concerns even though he only missed one game with an injury. That said he's a playmaker with the skill set to develop into an effective complementary back that contributes on third down and makes the most of the touches he gets. Cohen's size will probably prevent him from developing into an NFL starter, but he's a playmaker with the skill set to develop into an effective complementary back. He could contribute on third down and make the most of the touches he gets. -- Kevin Weidl

Gedeon spent his first three seasons as a reserve LB and core special teamer. In his only season as a starting ILB in 2016, Gedeon led the team with 106 total tackles, including 15.5 TFL and 4.5 sacks. Both of Gedeon's brothers also played college football - Alex at Harvard and Sam at the Naval Academy. The more tape we studied of Ben the more we appreciated his game. He may never develop into a starter in the NFL but he's capable of contributing as a backup linebacker and core special teams player. Gedeon grades out as a Day 3 prospect. -March 22, 2017 Gedeon possesses fast eyes and quick recognition skills as a run-defender to go along with quality awareness in coverage. He has some physical limitations that may prevent him from becoming a full-time starter, but he's capable of contributing as a backup linebacker and core special teams player. -- Kevin Weidl

Williams is an undersized, quick and speedy back that comes with some off-the-field baggage and ball security concerns. Started his career at Uconn before transferring after being arrested on larceny charges in August of 2013. Hit the JUCO ranks before spending his final 2 seasons at Utah. Quit the team briefly in 2016 before returning and going on a tear down the stretch. (Final 7 games: 1,332 rushing yards and 10 TDs). Projects as a day three prospect that has the potential to add depth as a change of pace runner. -- April 6, 2017 An average-sized back who has below-average power, Williams put the ball on the ground too much last season. He also comes with some off-the-field baggage, including stops at different colleges, an arrest and a brief absence from the game. On the flip side, he's an explosive runner who has good top-end speed and vision and he flashes as a receiver. -- Steve Muench Carlos Hyde has yet to play a full 16-game season, so the 49ers needed to improve their depth behind him. In addition, new head coach Kyle Shanahan has a potent one-two punch like he did with RBs Devonta Freeman and Tevin Coleman in Atlanta. -- Steve Muench

A redshirt senior and 2016 team captain Siragusa started 42 games at San Diego State and played well enough to earn an invite to the Senior Bowl where he injured his thumb during the first practice. He played just two years of high school football, he needs to clean up his technique and his tape is a little erratic. Plus he'll need to keep his weight down if he's to realize his potential. However, he tested well at 319 pounds at the Combine and he has the power, feet and length to quickly develop into a quality starter in the NFL. Siragusa needs to clean up his technique and become more consistent. But he has quick feet, adequate length and flashes quality power to become a serviceable backup and potential starter down the road with proper development. -- Kevin Weidl

Nicholson is a third year junior who has appeared 38 career games with 23 starts while recording 169 tackles 4 PBUs and 4 INTs over the past two seasons (2015-'16). He is a big and physical strong safety prospect who is most comfortable near the box. Nicholson is an explosive athlete (See combine numbers) who possesses some tightness transitioning out of breaks that gives him some limitations as the last line of defense. Lacked focus with preparation early on but matured in this area as his career progressed. He projects as a mid-round prospect at this point.  April 5, 2017 Nicholson has the frame and length to hold up as a run-stopper in the box. While he ran an excellent 40 (4.42) and shows good range in coverage, he has some tightness in hips and is not a ball hawk. -- Steve Muench

Reeves-Maybin is a classic Tampa- WILL (or possibly even MIKE) linebacker who started in all 26 games during the 2014 and 2015 seasons --and lead the Vols in tackles both years (206 total)-- but his 2016 season was cut short due to a shoulder injury suffered in Game 4 (Florida). Reeves-Maybin comes with strong make-up; team captain and earned his degree in just three years. He's undersized and durability is a significant concern (also missed 2016 spring with a shoulder injury). But Reeves-Maybin shares similar traits to a Lavonte David or Darren Lee, and could be a Day 3 steal. -March 25, 2017 Reeves-Maybin is an instinctive and rangy run-defender with above-average cover skills on tape, but he didn't test as well as expected in agility drills at his pro day. He's also undersized, and he missed most of the 2016 season with a shoulder injury. -- Steve Muench
A team captain and highly productive FCS linebacker, Ebukam is an average-sized outside linebacker with good length, good athletic ability and excellent top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

Wilson played 29 career games (19 starts) and finished with 107 tackles, 15 PBUs and 9 INTs. Wilson is a talented underclassman entry (third-year sophomore) who lacks ideal game experience and comes with some durability baggage (missed most of 2015 with ACL tear). Had he returned for another healthy season in 2016, Wilson could have worked his way into the first couple rounds. But considering his inexperience, injury history, jump in talent level, and concerns about his information processing in a more complex NFL passing game; Wilson's current value is in the middle rounds. -March 31, 2017 There's a lot to like about Wilson's frame, short-area cover skills, ability to play the ball and willingness to step up in run support. He needs to get stronger and improve his recognition in coverage, though, and he doesn't have great top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

A one-year starter Roberts is a Y prospect coming off a breakout year catching 16 touchdowns with 10 of those coming in the red zone. He also flashed at the East-West Shrine game and at the Senior Bowl. He doesn't have great top-end speed and he's still developing as a blocker but he has the tools to make an immediate impact in the red zone and become an effective No. 2 tight end if he keeps his weight down and puts in the work. Roberts lack ideal top-end speed and he's still developing as a blocker. He has the tools to make an immediate impact in the red zone and become an effective No. 2 tight end if he keeps his weight down and puts in the work. -- Kevin Weidl

Malone started 31 games in his three years at Tennessee and he's coming off his most productive season by far. His size-speed combination is intriguing - he ran the third fastest 40 out of all the receivers at the Combine - and he should draw the interest of teams looking for a receiver to stretch the field. He needs to make strides as a route runner and continue to get stronger on contested throws but there's a lot to like about his big-play potential and upside as a fringe Day 2 pick. A bigger receiver with exceptional speed to stretch he field vertically, Malone needs to improve as a route runner and continue to get stronger on contested throws. But there's a lot to like about his big-play potential and upside. -- Kevin Weidl We didn't identify receiver as a pressing need coming into the draft and the Bengals already added Washington's John Ross in the first round, but A.J. Green is coming off hamstring injury. Malone is an excellent value here and he gives Cincinnati another player that can take the top off the coverage. -- Steve Muench

A true junior and two-year starter Sharpe started 26 games at left tackle for the Gators over the past two seasons and his size is intriguing. However, he's a developmental prospect with concerns about his ability to protect the edge in the NFL and he will likely have to move inside to guard to succeed in the NFL. Sharpe has the massive frame to overwhelm defenders in the run game and the length to push speed rushers past the pocket. He's a below-average athlete who struggles to bend and needs to make strides as a hand fighter, and as a result, he projects better at guard. --Steve Muench

Cousin of Michael Kidd-Gilchrist (Hornets), Davenport started all 44 games at left tackle during his four seasons at Bucknell. The two-time team captain has good football character and excellent game experience, albeit at the small-school level. Davenport is a developmental project who needs to improve his technique (footwork and base). But he has the length and enough movement skills to be molded into a starting tackle or guard in the NFL. Davenport could become the eighth non-FBS offensive lineman selected in the top 100 picks in the last 10 drafts. Early Day-3 grade. April 7, 2017 Davenport is a developmental prospect who needs to improve his core strength and refine his technique, but he has the frame, long arms, quick feet and work ethic to develop into a starter. -- Steve Muench

A 2016 team captain, Wise started ten of the 50 games he appeared in and there are concerns regarding his medical as he broke a hand and separated a shoulder in 2016. Plus he sustained a season-ending injury in 2012. His 40-time (4.92) is a red flag for a defensive end that weighs more than 265 pounds. However, he's long levered (35 5/8' arms) with the power to develop into an effective LDE or 34DE who also rushes from the inside if he can stay healthy. He also played well at the East West Shrine game and his father was a defensive tackle taken by Seattle in the ninth round of the 1988 draft. Wise only started 10 games at Arkansas and his injury history is concerning. He didn't run well at the combine either. However, the 2016 team captain is an above-average hand fighter who has excellent length and the potential to develop into an effective rotational player. -- Steve Muench

Though Ron Dayne would hold the record if the NCAA counted his bowl game numbers, Pumphrey is an ultra productive back who technically broke the FBS career rushing record finishing with 6,405 rushing yards in addition to rushing for 62 touchdowns. He's a versatile weapon with the talent to develop into an effective complementary back who potentially helps out in the return game. On the downside, he doesn't have the size to develop into an every-down back. Though injuries have not been an issue, his frame and heavy workload (1,159 career touches) raise concerns about his long-term durability. Pumphrey is a pint-sized running back who owns the NCAA career-rushing record. He's a versatile weapon with the talent to potentially develop into an effective complementary back who also has the capabilities to help out in the return game. -- Kevin Weidl The Eagles were in the market to add depth to the position. Pumphrey is an undersized but versatile playmaker who likely will be groomed as Darren Sproles' replacement, since Sproles turns 34 in June. -- Kevin Weidl

Switzer was a three-year starter who set school records for career catches (244), catches in a season (96 in 2016) and career receiving yards (2,907). He owns the ACC career mark for punt returns for TDs with seven and tied the NCAA standard for punt return scores in a season (5 in 2013). He performed well the week of the Senior Bowl and ran well at the Combine. Multiple scouts have reported that he can by a "diva" and "difficult to put up with". Switzer projects as a reliable slot receiver who can help out on punt returns if his fielding percentage improves. Early-Day 3 grade. -April 7, 20 While Switzer is undersized, he's the best route runner in this draft class. He has the burst and open-field instincts to develop into a productive slot WR and punt returner. Scouts have reported that he can be difficult, though. -- Steve Muench Switzer has the potential to develop into a productive slot receiver for the Cowboys and should make an immediate impact returning punts. -- Steve Muench

Williams is BYU's all-time career rushing leader finishing with 3,901 yards plus 35 touchdowns. He also had 60 career catches for 567 yards and one touchdown. He missed three games with a high ankle sprain in 2016 and sustained a serious knee injury in 2014. BYU suspended him for a game after he was arrested on suspicion of underage drinking in March of 2014 and he sat out the 2015 season to deal with personal issues. However, he is a 2016 team captain with a strong work ethic and he projects as a valuable backup if he stays healthy and keeps his off-the-field issues in his rearview mirror. Williams' injury history is a concern and he's not a big-play threat. But the downhill runner has the potential to develop into an effective complementary back. While he struggled with BYU's strict rules at times, the 2016 team captain is considered a hard worker. -- Steve Muench The Packers needed to add depth and competition for converted receiver Ty Montgomery and Christine Michael in the backfield. Williams has the potential to win the No. 2 role and make a strong contribution as a rookie. -- Steve Muench

Dobbs was a four-year player and three-year starter who finished with a 23-12 career record. He completed 61.3-percent of his career passes and finished with a 1.8-1 TD-INT ratio (2.2-1 ratio his final three years). In addition, he rushed for 2,106 yards and 32 scores. An Aerospace Engineering Major, Dobbs has excellent intangibles and intriguing physical tools as a dual-threat QB. His Senior Bowl performance (under Browns HC Hugh Jackson) was promising but Dobbs is still very much a project as a passer and needs the right coaching/scheme to last in the NFL. Day 3 grade. -February 22, 2017 Dobbs took advantage of the postseason process to improve his draft stock, including a strong showing at the Senior Bowl. He has a very good physical skill set with size, arm strength and mobility. He also has the mental capacity and competitive temperament to develop into a quality backup and potential starter down the road. -- Kevin Weidl Ben Roethlisberger (35 years old) considered retiring for several months, and while backup Landry Jones re-signed for two years, he hasn't shown enough to be considered the heir apparent. Dobbs has the tools and intangibles to develop into an effective starter in time. With Roethlisberger and Jones ahead of him, he has time to learn the offense and improve his lower-body mechanics. -- Steve Muench

A team captain as a senior, Harlow has 4 years of starting experience at both ROT and LOT. However, lack of length (32' arms) will likely force him to move inside at the NFL level. Harlow plays with quality balance and technique to go along with good quickness. However, has just average size and can struggle with power due to lack of a prototypical anchor/powerbase. Missed the final five games of 2015 with a broken ankle suffered against Colorado. Projects as a day 3 develop prospect who could end up finding a home at center for heavy zone blocking scheme.  March 31, 2016 A team captain, Harlow started 23 games at left tackle and 14 at right tackle. He also took snaps at all five offensive line positions in practice, and he projects best on the inside. While he lacks ideal power, he's a technician with good balance. -- Steve Muench

Banner redshirted in 2012 and he joined the 2013 USC men's basketball team but did not see any action. He missed most of the 2013 football season after having surgery on both hips. Banner went on to start 38 games (36 ROT, 2 LOT) the next three seasons (2014-16). Keeping his weight in check will be critical to his NFL success (he's been as big as 385 pounds while at USC). Banner is an excellent-sized right tackle (or guard) prospect (6083, 353 pounds with 34 7/8-inch arms) with marginal speed (5.58 40-dash) and agility (5.21 short shuttle). Grades out as a mid-round prospect. April 1, 2017 Banner, a massive right tackle or guard prospect, has the power and size to overwhelm defenders as a run-blocker. He possesses excellent length but needs to show more patience and balance in pass protection. His weight will need to be monitored. -- Kevin Weidl

Glasgow's (GLASS-go) brother, Graham, is a starting guard for the Lions. Ryan, a former walk-on, played 11 games as a reserve his redshirt freshman season (2013). The next three seasons he started 33 of 34 games played (missing final four of 2015 with a torn pectoral muscle) and combined for 86 total tackles, 18.5 TFRL and just four sacks (all in 2016). Glasgow had his best season as a senior. He's a powerful grinder versus the run and while he'll never be an elite pass rusher, he is strong, crafty and relentless enough to contribute. Glasgow grades out as a mid-round prospect. -March 21, 2017 A powerful grinder versus the run, Glasgow will never be an elite pass-rusher, but he's strong, crafty and relentless enough to contribute. -- Kevin Weidl

Chesson has appeared in 37 games (18 starts) during his first three years (2013-15) after redshirting in 2012. After catching just 29 passes in his first two seasons of eligibility, Chesson had a breakout year in 2015 with 50 receptions for a team-high 764 yards (15.3 ypc) and nine touchdowns. In addition to having a very good combination of size, speed and ball skills, Chesson has elite intangibles and football character.He projects as a Day 2 pick in 2017.  June 10, 2016 Chesson has a very good combination of size, speed and ball skills to potentially develop into a No. 3 or No. 4 receiver. He also has elite intangibles and football character. -- Kevin Weidl

Gallman was a three-year starter who had his best season in 2015 (rushing:283-1,527-5.4-13. Rec: 21-213-10.1-1). He wasn't featured as much in 2016 but still rushed for 1,133 yards on 232 carries (4.9) and 17 TDs, while also catching 20 passes for 152 yards (7.6). Son of a Marine (Wayne Sr.), Gallman is a versatile back with good agility and pass-catching ability. The biggest knock on his game is he lacks power, but he's a hardnosed banger of a runner. For a team in the market for a versatile load-sharer, Gallman should turn out to be a Day-3 value pick. -February 24, 2017 Gallman is a versatile back who has good agility and pass-catching ability. The biggest knock on his game is that he lacks power, but he's a hard-nosed banger of a runner and could add good value for a team in need of a versatile athlete to share the workload. -- Kevin Weidl

Hansen is an Idaho State transfer who has appeared in 20 games the past two seasons at Cal with nine starts all coming in 2016. Despite missing two games with an ankle in injury he finished the 2016 season with 92 catches for 1,249 yards, 11 TDs and was fourth in the FBS averaging 125 receiving yards per game. Hansen is a polished route runner with quality hands and the toughness to potentially develop into an adequate third receiver on the roster. He currently projects as early day three selection.  April 5, 2017 Hansen, an Idaho transfer, is a polished route runner with quality hands and the toughness to potentially develop into an adequate third or fourth receiver on a NFL roster. -- Kevin Weidl

Watkins played sparingly as a freshman (2012). He was emerging as a starter three games into 2013 but suffered season-ending injuries from a car accident that killed the driver (high school fried). He played 11 games in '14 before starting all 15 in '15. His decision to return as a senior paid off (Won national title and career-best production: 50-13.5-10.5). He's not an explosive player but he's big, long, strong and mobile. He can play DT or NT in a 4-3 front and also some 3-4 DE. We think he's capable of developing into an effective three-down starter in the NFL. Day 2 grade. -April 1, 2017 Watkins doesn't have an elite physical skill set, but he is quick, shows quality hands and has had good production throughout his career. He makes up for some deficiencies with a relentless motor and plays with the toughness and physical demeanor you look for in an interior defensive lineman. -- Kevin Weidl

Mack rushed for over 1,000 yards in all three seasons as a starter while setting the school record for rushing yards (3,609) and career touchdowns (33). He is an explosive runner with adequate size and brings quality versatility in the passing game. More of a finesse than physical runner who is at his best as a perimeter runner. Needs to be more assertive as an inside runner and ball security is a concern. Mack projects as a mid-round pick who has a chance to add quality depth and become a potential starter ideally for a heavy zone blocking scheme.  March 21, 2017 Mack put the ball on the ground too much last year and he's too quick to bounce runs outside. With that said, he has quick feet and accelerates well for a 213-pound back. He's also an above-average receiver who is a threat after the catch. -- Steve Muench

Wide-bodied DT with the ability to eat space. Light came on late in his career. Did a lot of maturing. He's raw and needs technique work, but has moldable tools. Ran a 5.12 40-yard dash at 6043 and 334 pounds. Will never be an overly effective pass rusher but he has the size and strength to contribute as a situational run plugger. Grades out as a late-rounder or priority free agent. -April 11, 2017 Stewart is a wide-bodied space eater who is raw but he had a strong pro day workout and has moldable tools. While he'll never be an overly effective pass-rusher, he has the size and strength to contribute as a situational run stopper. -- Steve Muench

Butt played in 49 of 51 games (37 starts) during four seasons at UM. He notched 138 catches, including 97 for 1,200 yards (12.4) and 7 TDs during his final two seasons. Unfortunately, a torn right ACL in his final game (Orange Bowl vs. FSU) required surgery in early January and will prevent him from working out prior to the draft. Butt is a "Y" TE prospect but has size-potential to increase his role "in-line" if he continues to improve his strength. Route running savvy, ball skills and football character are his top qualities. We still expect Butt to come off the board on Day 2. -April 1, 2017 Butt tore an ACL against Florida State in the Orange Bowl and consequently hasn't worked out for NFL teams. Beyond the medical concern, he needs to get stronger, but he has good size potential and is a dependable receiver who knows how to get open. -- Steve Muench The Broncos severely need an upgrade at tight end, as their 53 total receptions from the position ranked 31st in the league and 591 total receiving yards ranked 28th. Denver gets great value and a potential steal here with Butt, who could be back as early as August. -- Kevin Weidl

Kittle is a fifth year senior who had 22 catches for 314 yards (14.3) and 4 TDs in his first year as a full time starter. Kittle needs some polish but he has exceptional raw athleticism (See Combine results) and the competitiveness to turn into a quality move-TE (F) while also contributing on special teams. Missed the Michigan and Illinois games late in the season after suffering a right foot sprain vs Wisconsin. He projects as a mid-round pick. -- (April 15, 2017) Kittle needs refine his skill set, but he has the raw athleticism (tested extremely well at the combine) and competitiveness to turn into a quality move-TE (F) while also contributing on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

Brown is a three year starter that finished 2016 leading the MAC conference with 128 tackles while adding 15 TFLs and 4  sacks. Twitchy run and hit linebacker that has strong playmaking instincts defending the run. Shorter and lacks ideal length (31  ') but makes up for it with his athleticism (tested extremely well across the board at combine). Comes with strong makeup. Experienced core special teams player that should make an immediate in that area. Brown could end up bring strong return in the mid-rounds with a chance to develop quickly into a starter.  April 3, 2017 Brown, a twitchy run-and-hit linebacker, displays strong playmaking instincts defending the run. He lacks ideal length (31 1/4 inches) but makes up for it with his athleticism and tackling ability. He is also an experienced special teams player who should make an immediate impact in that area. -- Kevin Weidl

A three-year starter, Kazee (KAY-zee) is a 2016 team captain who was named the Mountain West Defensive Player of the Year each of the past two seasons and intercepted at total of 15 passes during that run. He's undersized with average top-end speed and athletic ability but he's a better football player than athlete on tape and he shined the week of the Senior Bowl. He's smart, he plays the ball well, he's got the toughness to compete with bigger receivers and he tackles well for his size and the position. Plus he could compete for the punt returner role. Undersized with short arms and average top-end speed, Kazee is a better football player than athlete, and he stood out the week of the Senior Bowl. He's instinctive in coverage, he plays the ball well, and he's a tough run-stopper. -- Steve Muench

Leggett missed five games due to minor injuries his first two seasons (2013-14) but started all 30 games in 2015-2016. His production improved each year and he finished with 112 career receptions for 1,598 yards (14.3) and 18 TDs. Leggett has a great frame, carries his weight well and is a smooth-moving pass catcher with speed to stretch the field vertically as an "F" TE. However, he's not as sudden as he is fast (so he has limitations as a route runner and after catch) and he's not a strong enough blocker to rely upon in-line very often. Leggett grades out as a Day-2 pick. -March 1, 2017 Leggett is an underrated receiver with enough speed to produce after the catch and make plays down the seam. He needs to get stronger and play with better technique, but he has the frame and length to develop into an effective inline blocker. -- Steve Muench Jets tight ends had a combined NFL-low 18 catches for 173 yards and no touchdowns last year. Leggett is an excellent value pick at this point in the draft. -- Steve Muench

King has been a durable four year starter that has appeared in all 53 career games with 51 starts while recording 33 PBUs and 13 INTs. Production dipped in 2016 where he had 7 PBUs and 3 INTs after leading the nation with 8 INTs as a junior. King lacks elite speed and he displays some tightness on tape. However, he has excellent recognition, playmaking instincts and ball skills to develop into a quality starter ideally in a heavy zone coverage scheme. Also brings added value as a returner on special teams. Projects as a day two pick. -- March 22, 2017 On the shorter side with average top-end speed, King isn't as fluid on tape as his combine results would suggest. He is, however, a playmaker with better quickness than speed and good instincts. He's also a tough player who is willing to step up in run support. -- Steve Muench

A true senior and 2016 team captain Elder led Miami in PBU's each of the past two seasons and finished tied for third on the team with 76 tackles last year. He's an undersized prospect with below average ball skills but he's a tough competitor who plays bigger than his size would suggest and rarely makes mistakes. In addition, he has experience returning and covering kicks. He projects as a sub-package defensive back that primarily lines up over the slot and also contributes on special teams. An undersized corner with below average ball skills, Elder shows quality instincts and discipline in coverage. He's also an outstanding run defender for a corner and limits production after the catch despite his smaller frame. -- Steve Muench

Elliott finished his career as Memphis' career leader in scoring (445 points) and field goals (81). He has trained with former Tiger Stephen Gostkwoski during summers and he has a powerful leg despite his diminutive frame. However, he'll need to be more consistent with his accuracy if he's to make it in the NFL. Elliott finished his career as Memphis' career leader in scoring (445 points) and field goals (81). He has a powerful leg despite his small frame, but he needs to be a little more consistent. -- Steve Muench

A two-year starter Sprinkle is the Arkansas' all-time leader for receiving touchdowns by a tight end (11) and there's no denying he has the size, speed and length to develop into a productive F tight end at the NFL level. However, his production doesn't match up with his talent and he didn't stand out at the Senior Bowl where the talent tight end was excellent this year. In addition, Arkansas suspended him from the Belk Bowl after the got caught shoplifting from a Belk department store raising concerns about his maturity and decision making. Sprinkle possesses the size, speed and length to develop into a productive "F" tight end at the NFL level. He needs development as a route runner and continues to improve his strength to become more consistent as a blocker. Also of note, Sprinkle has minor character concerns as he was suspended for the 2016 Belk Bowl after being cited for shoplifting at a Charlotte, North Carolina, department store. -- Kevin Weidl

Brown played special teams and sparingly as a reserve on defense during his first two season at UCLA (2013-14). In 2015, he took over for the injured Myles Jack and started the final nine games that season and all 12 games in 2016. He racked up 213 tackles, 9 TFL and 3 sacks the past two years. He's an undersized but fast WLB prospect. He gives good effort and he strong football character. Big his lack of bulk, strength and recognition skills are why he projects as a late-round pick or undrafted free agent. Brown will need to excel on special teams to stick on a NFL roster. -March 11, 2017 Brown is an undersized linebacker that needs to get stronger at the point of attack and improve his recognition skills. He's rangy, has a good motor and has good overall football character. -- Steve Muench

Hill is a true junior who rushed for 3,491 yards over the past two seasons finishing the 2016 season seventh in the FBS in rushing yards per game (132.8) and fourth in rushing touchdowns (22). He's a tough downhill runner with good finishing power and he's an above average pass blocker. However, he's not a big-play threat, he caught just eight passes last year and - though he's been durable - he's carried a heavy workload touching the ball 658 times over the past two seasons. Plus, Wyoming reportedly suspended him for the first quarter of the Poinsettia Bowl for missing curfew. The 219-pound Hill is a tough downhill runner with good finishing power, but he's not much of a big-play threat as he caught just eight passes in 2016. He has carried a heavy workload, getting 610 carries over the past two seasons. -- Steve Muench

Holden is a 3 year starter appearing in 48 career games with 32 starts. He is a taller OT prospect with shorter arms (33 ') but has quick feet and good hands that allow him to overcome his lack of ideal length. Quality positional blocker in the run game. Will constantly battle pad level due to height and can continue to improve strength in his core and lower body. Late add on at the Senior Bowl and played well. Holden projects as an early day 3 pick that has a chance to add depth and potentially develop into a starter ideally for a heavy zone blocking scheme.  March 24, 2017 A taller OT prospect with shorter arms (33 1/4 inches), Holden has quick feet and good hands, which allow him to overcome his lack of ideal length. He's a quality positional blocker in the run game, but he can continue to improve strength in his core and lower body. -- Kevin Weidl

Hairston is a redshirt senior that started his career at WR before switching to CB in his final two seasons. Recorded 3 PBUs and 2 INTs in his first season as a starter in 2016. He is a fluid and balance mover who has solid instincts despite lack of experience and will set the edge in run support. Brings added value on special as non-returner. Missed 4 games in 2013 with ankle injury. Hairston projects a mid-round pick whose best football could be ahead of him as he continues to gain experience at the position.  March 20, 2017 Hairston, a former receiver who didn't move to corner until 2015, should get better with experience. He has an above average combination of balance, fluidity and short-area quickness. He's also outstanding in run support and expected to cover kicks. -- Steve Muench

Jermaine "eh-LOO--muh-nor" was born in London and moved the states before his junior year of high school when he first started playing football. The transfer from Lackawanna College (PA) is in his first year as a starter and was moved from OG to ROT two weeks before the start of the 2016 season. Despite testing well at the combine for his size, Eluemunor maybe best suited as a guard at the next level where he can maximize his size and natural power. He projects as a day two pick that should add immediate depth with the potential to quickly develop into a starter. -- April 6, 2017 Eluemunor is a massive and naturally powerful individual who plays with quality balance. Has experience lining up at right tackle and guard, where he will likely end up finding a home in the NFL. He only started playing football as a junior in high school and his best football appears to be ahead of him. -- Kevin Weidl

Johnson has a been a durable starter at LOT who entered the starting line up late in the season in 2014 and has started in all 31 consecutive games to end his career.He quick feet, exceptional length (36") and better functional strength than expected on tape. However, he is a waist bender whose lack of flexibility in his lower half is concerning protecting the edges at the NFL level. Johnson will need to rely on great technique to become a consistent starter. Best suited for a heavy zone blocking scheme. Projects a mid-round pick. -- March 12, 2017 With 36-inch inch arms and good initial quickness, Johnson pushes speed rushers past the pocket and gets good initial surge in the run game when his technique is sound. But he's a waist bender with below-average lower-body flexibility. -- Steve Muench

A redshirt junior and 2016 team captain Walker is a three-year starter who finished his college career with 278 tackles, 39.5 tackles-for-loss and six forced fumbles. While his production dipped last year, he missed two weeks of training camp with a knee injury that prevented him from entering the season in ideal playing shape and slowed him early on. His limitations in space are a concern but he has the work ethic and instincts to overcome his physical deficiencies and develop into an effective starter. He projects as a valuable reserve and special teams' contributor at the least. A big and physical linebacker, Walker has adequate range for his size. He does have some limitations in space, but he has the work ethic and instincts to overcome his physical deficiencies. -- Kevin Weidl

A true junior, McNichols' production - 3,205 rushing yards, 1,089 receiving yards and 554 kickoff return yards in addition to 55 total touchdowns  is impressive. There are two red flags and the first is his medical as he underwent shoulder surgery after the Combine, sustained a concussion in 2015 and underwent hernia surgery in the spring of 2015. The second is he puts the ball on the ground too much. If he stays healthy and improves his ball security he projects as a productive No.2 back with the skill set to contribute on third down and potentially in the return game. There are concerns about McNichols' injury history and ball security, but he's a versatile weapon with the burst and versatility to develop into an effective complementary back. He figures to make substantial contributions on third down. -- Steve Muench

Milano played as a reserve LB and on special teams in 25 games his first two seasons. He played all 25 games (24 starts) at SAM linebacker his last two years (2015-16), combining for 118 tackles, 28.5 TFLs, and 13 sacks. Milano is a high-intensity OLB who leaves it all on the field. He's undersized and has some tightness but he's more powerful than frame indicates and above average quickness/speed. Milano has the perfect temperament to bring value on special teams and while he fights for a versatile role at linebacker in the NFL Milano carries a mid-Day 3 grade. -March 19, 2017 Milano leaves it all on the field and has the perfect temperament to contribute on special teams while he fights for a backup role on defense. He's undersized, but he's more powerful than his frame would suggest, and he has good quickness/speed. -- Steve Muench

Asiata is a 3 year starter (42 total starts) who will turn 25 in December of this year and is the younger brother of Minnesota RB Matt Asiata. He has experience at both guard spots and ROT but projects inside. Asiata needs to play more within himself but possesses a massive, thick and powerful frame to fit ideally within a heavy power blocking scheme. Nutrition and diet will need to be heavily monitored due to past weight issues.
