Asiata projects as a mid-round prospect who has the ability to add depth on the interior and potentially develop into a starter down the road. April 6, 2017 Asiata has experience at both guard spots and right tackle, but he projects inside at the NFL level. He needs to play more within himself but possesses a massive, thick and powerful frame to fit ideally within a heavy power blocking scheme. Asiata's nutrition and diet will need to be monitored because of past weight issues. -- Kevin Weidl
He has quality size with an excellent combination of speed and ball awareness. He shows the potential to play in the slot at nickelback as well as outside the hashes. -- Kevin Weidl

Gibson is a fourth year junior who has started in all 26 games the past two seasons while recording 80 catches for 1,838 yards, 17 touchdowns and averaged nearly 23 yards per catch in that span. He has average size and needs development as a route runner. However, Gibson is a big play vertical threat who has excellent speed and tracks the ball extremely well down the field. Also brings experience as a returner on special teams. Gibson projects as a mid-round pick whose best fit will be within a heavy vertical passing game.  April 6, 2017 A developing route-runner with below-average size, Gibson is a big-play threat who plays faster than his timed top-end speed. He tracks the ball well and flashes a second gear stretching the field. -- Steve Muench

Moss began at Nebraska, where he just three games as a freshman because of a shoulder injury. He played in a rotation in 12 games (3 starts) in 2013 but was dismissed from campus due to an off-field incident (reportedly exposed himself to a fell student) and missed the entire 2014 season. Bo Pelini, his former coach at Nebraska, gave Moss a second chance at YSU, where Moss played 25 games (17 starts) the past two seasons and racked up 84 tackles, 22 TFL and 14 sacks. Moss has enough talent as an edge defender to contribute as a NFL backup. He grades out as a Day 3 prospect. -April 3, 2017 An above-average run defender, Moss has the frame, length and initial burst to provide depth and potentially start at defensive end in a base four-man front. His character is a concern, though; he was dismissed from Nebraska following a public indecency charge. -- Steve Muench

A team captain, Marquel (mar-KELL) Lee is a three-year starter and true senior who finished his career with 291 tackles, 42 tackles-for-loss, 14.5 sacks and four forced fumbles. He may be a better fit on the inside where his athletic limitations won't be as much of a concern but he doesn't project as a starter regardless of where he lines up. He's a hard worker who led Wake Forest in special teams' tackles as a freshman and has enough tools to develop into an effective special teams' player who provides some depth at linebacker if he improves his consistency as a tackler. Lee has enough tools to develop into an effective special-teams player who provides some depth at linebacker if he becomes a more consistent tackler. -- Kevin Weidl

Decoud (deh-kood) is the cousin of former Cal and NFL safety Thomas Decoud. He didn't qualify academically coming out of high school and attended three different schools before transferring to Oregon State where he started for two years. He's a hard worker and confident player with the frame and length to provide depth in zone and press heavy schemes. He doesn't have great scheme versatility though and athletic limitations could prevent him from developing into a starter though. His medical is also a concern as he sustained a concussion in 2015. Decoud is a hard worker and confident player with the frame and length to provide depth in zone- and press-heavy schemes. He doesn't have great scheme versatility, though, and his athletic limitations could prevent him from developing into a starter. -- Steve Muench

Adams is a transfer from Toledo who was a two year starter who appeared in 49 games with 29 career starts. Led the team in receiving in 2016 with 67 catches for 822 yards (12.3) and 5 TDs (Rushing: 231 yards and 5 TDs). Adams is a leaner WR that needs to get stronger and become more consistent both with his routes and hands. However, he has speed that can't be coached and big play ability particularly after the catch and as a returner on special teams that may warrant a team taking a late round flyer on him.  April 6, 2017 Adams needs to add strength and more polish as a route runner but he has explosive speed and brings big-play upside. He provides added help as a returner where he could replace Cordarrelle Patterson who departed in free agency for Oakland. -- Steve Muench

Peterman began his career at Tennessee, where he played sparingly in 10 games (one start) during his first two seasons (2013-14). He transferred to Pitt in 2015 and took over as the starter that season. He went on to play all 26 games (24 starts) during his two seasons as a Panther, completing 61-percent of his throws and posting a 3.1-1 TD-to-INT ratio (47-15). He has a very strong work ethic, leadership skills and intangibles. Peterman grades out as a mid-round pick. He projects as a good backup in the NFL who could possibly develop into a solid starter down the line. -April 14, 2017 Peterman is a cerebral quarterback who has two years of starting experience within a multiple pro-style system at Pitt. He is a quick decision-maker who lacks elite arm strength but makes up for it with above-average timing and anticipation as a starter. Peterman's overall mobility is underrated. -- Kevin Weidl Tyrod Taylor took a pay cut and restructured his contract, plus he's coming off offseason groin surgery. Peterman has the tools and intangibles to compete for the backup job and potentially become the Bills' starter later in his career. -- Steve Muench

McKenzie is a third year junior that led the Bulldogs in receiving with 44 catches for 633 yard and seven TDs. He is a pint-sized slot-WR who has an outstanding combination of speed and quickness. Shares some similarities to Rams WR Tavon Austin with his ability to create with the ball in his hand. Battled a hamstring injury in 2015 and missed 3 games. Suspended for the Belk Bowl as freshman (2014) for violation of team rules. McKenzie projects as a mid-round who brings added value as returner on special teams as a returner (6 career returns for a TD).  March 19, 2017 A true junior, McKenzie is a vastly undersized, showing raw route-running ability and average ball skills. But he has the burst to quickly separate and he's a threat to go the distance whenever he touches the ball as a receiver/return man. -- Steve Muench

Allen was recruited as a WR before making the switch in redshirt sophomore season (2014). Most productive season in 2016 where he recorded 6 PBUs and 4 INTs. Also tested extremely well across the board at the Combine. With only three seasons (12 total starts) at the position, Allen is raw but has rare measureables and a favorable tool box  tested extremely well at the combine across the board -- to mold and potentially develop into a quality starter down the road in a heavy press or cover-two scheme. Projects as a mid-round pick. March 14, 2017 A former receiver, Allen is a developmental prospect with just 12 total starts at corner. He has rare measurables and he tested very well at the combine. He has the potential to develop into a quality starter in a heavy press or Cover 2 scheme. -- Steve Muench

Saubert had surgery on his right labrum after his high school senior year and redshirtedg at Drake (non-scholarship FCS) in 2012. He went on to start 37 of 41 games (missed three in '14 with right PCL sprain) and tallied 183 catches for 2,179 yards (11.9) and 20 TDs. Saubert showed well at the East-West Shrine game versus a higher level of competition, he has football smarts and picks up concepts quickly, and he has good special teams experience. However, his lean frame appears maxed-out and he's a liability as a blocker. Saubert grades out as a Day 3 developmental project. -April 7, 2017 Saubert showed well versus a higher level of competition at the East-West Shrine game. He's a big-play threat who has good size-speed combination and good special teams experience. However, his lean frame appears maxed out, and he's a liability as a blocker. -- Steve Muench

Very good size-speed combo. Solid vertical route runner but limited. Struggles to uncover short-to-intermediate. Good production last two seasons with 97-1,651-10. -April 15, 2017 Yancey is a limited route runner who is going to have some problems separating from underneath coverage. He's got the speed to stretch the field in addition to the frame and leaping ability to win 50-50 balls downfield. -- Steve Muench

JJ 'deal-min' is a three year starter who lined up at ROT in 2014-'15 seasons before moving into OC as a senior. Started in the first five games of the 2016 season before suffering a season ending lower leg injury (did not workout at the combine).He has good size and adequate inline power for the position. Needs to learn to play with more patience and balance particularly in pass pro. Cousin of former San Diego Charger OL Kris Dielman. A day three developmental prospect who has the potential to become a versatile reserve on the interior.  March 25, 2017 Dielman has good size and adequate inline power, but he needs to learn to play with more patience and balance, particularly in pass protection. He has some durability issues and played in only five games last season. Dielman has the potential to become a versatile reserve. -- Kevin Weidl

A three-year starter and 2016 team captain Taylor finished second in the FBS in receiving yards per game (128.8) and receptions (126) last year in addition to leading Louisiana Tech in receiving each of the past three seasons. He's a hard worker with an outside chance of developing into a sub-package slot receiver and possibly punt returner but his diminutive frame, small hands (8 5/8') and marginal top-end speed will likely prevent him from succeeding in the NFL. In addition, the scheme he played in and the competition he faced inflated that production Taylor is a hard worker with an outside chance of developing into a sub-package slot receiver. He also has some punt-return skills. But he has a diminutive frame, small hands and marginal top-end speed. -- Kevin Weidl

An average-sized defensive tackle with good length, Godchaux was a three-year starter in the SEC. However, he has athletic limitations and needs to get stronger at the point of attack. -- Steve Muench

Logan is a fourth year junior who has started in 20 career games while spitting carries with Elijah Hood over the past three seasons. Coming off a career year in 2016 rushing for 650 yards (5.4 YPC) and 7 TDs. He is an undersized change of pace runner that has excellent top-end speed (4.37 fastest of all RBs at combine) and brings excellent versatility in the passing game (Career: 76-663-4TDs) and as a returner on special teams (2 KOR TDS in 2016). Took advantage of post-season process with strong showings at the NFLPA game and combine Projects as an early day three pick. March 7, 2016 Logan is an undersized change-of-pace runner who has quality vision, excellent top-end speed and flashes the quickness to create yards on his own. He also brings strong versatility in the passing game and as a returner on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

A redshirt senior Isidora (Is-A-Door-a) started the final 39 games of his career at right guard. He has the size, tenacity and enough power to develop into an adequate reserve but he needs to play with better pad level and he's a liability in pass protection. It's also worth noting that he struggled the week of the Senior Bowl. While a team could take a chance on his experience and frame, he projects as a late round pick or rookie free agent. Isadora has the size, tenacity and enough power to develop into an adequate reserve, but he needs to play with better pad level and is a liability in pass protection. -- Kevin Weidl

Donahue recorded 119 tackles, 36.5 tackles for loss and 25.5 sacks in his two seasons at West Georgia. The 49ers drafted his father Mitch in the fourth round of the 1991 draft and he played in the NFL for four seasons. Dylan attended four different schools after high school and he'll turn 25 in August. He's a relentless pass rusher with good top-end speed and he dominated Division II competition on tape but his frame, the level of competition he faced and questions concerning his positon fit make him a late-round or rookie free agent prospect. Donahue is a relentless pass-rusher with good top-end speed. He dominated Division II competition on tape but his frame, the level of competition he faced and questions concerning his position fit are all concerns. -- Steve Muench

A redshirt junior, Jones is UTEP's all-time leading rusher with 4,114 rushing yards and he rushed for 33 touchdowns. He helped himself with a strong Combine recording the second highest vertical (37 ') and third highest broad jump (10'7') for the backs. However, he doesn't play as fast as his Combine 40, he's had problems holding onto the ball and he's had problems staying healthy missing most of 2015 with an ankle injury. While he was a 2015 team captain he was arrested ion suspicion of DUI in 2016. He projects as a complementary back if he checks out medically and improves his ball security Jones had a strong combine, recording the second-highest vertical jump and third-highest broad jump for the running backs. However, he doesn't play as fast as his combine 40-yard dash, and he ran slower at his pro day. His injury history is also reason for concern. -- Steve Muench

Ukeme (ew-KIM-ay) Eligwe (ee-LEEG-way) recorded 104 tackles in his only season as a starter last year. He played a reserve role on Florida State's national championship team in 2013, missed most of 2014 with a foot injury and had to sit out the 2015 season after transferring to Georgia Southern. He opted not to take advantage of a medical redshirt and return to school for another season. He's a hard worker who has matured but Florida State dismissed him for a violation of team rules in 2014. He projects as a reserve middle linebacker who contributes on special teams early in his career. A Florida State transfer, Eligwe dealt with some durability and off-the-field issues before transferring to Georgia Southern. If he can remain healthy and stay focused, he has the tools to add depth at inside linebacker while contributing on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

Brantley was a three year contributor (38 games played, 21 starts) who amassed 20 TFLs and 5.5 sacks as a starter the past two seasons (2015-16). He has the combination of quickness and power to emerge as a difference-making starter at three-technique or nose tackle in a base 4-3 scheme. While he's explosive on a straight-line, Brantley has some stiffness in movement, which plays a part in his lack of sack production (but he has upside and is disruptive in this area). Grades out as Day 2 talent on tape but his personal/football character are major turnoffs (see: note above). -April 24, 2017 When his motor is on, Brantley is one of the quickest and most disruptive three-techniques in the class. He has excellent first-step quickness, is a polished hand fighter and more disruptive as a pass-rusher than his stats indicate. Lack of effort is a concern, and he doesn't always maximize his talent. On April 24, Brantley was charged Friday with misdemeanor simple battery. -- Kevin Weidl

Clarke is a three year starter who appeared in 50 career games with 38 starts. Stared in all 13 games in 2016 finishing with 94 tackles, 2 PBUs and 2  TFLs. Clarke is an interchangeable safety with average size, quality athleticism and reliable against the run. Lacks ideal playmaking ability for the position (Career: 21 PBUs and just 2 INTs). Solid makeup. Team captain with good work and practice habits. Projects as a day 3 developmental pick that will need to be a heavy contributor on special teams early in his career.  April 4, 2017 A team captain and three-year starter at Virginia Tech, Clarke is an interchangeable safety and reliable run-defender with average size and above-average length. He also has the athletic ability and range to hold up in coverage, but he's not a playmaker yet. -- Steve Muench

Tyson started 16 of the 43 games he played in at Cincinnati finishing with 137 tackles, 11 PBUs and seven interceptions including five last year. He has the height-weight-speed to develop into a starting safety in time but he projects as a sub-package defensive back who lines up over the slot and contributes on special team early in his career. He missed two games with an ankle injury in 2016 and he missed two games in 2015 so the medical is a minor concern. Tyson had five interceptions last year, and he has the height-weight-speed combination to develop into a starting safety in time. Early in his career, he projects as a sub-package defensive back who lines up over the slot and contributes on special team. -- Steve Muench

McGuire lost his father when he was 12. He had multiple injuries (two broken foot bones and thumb) in high school, and had labrum surgery 2015 offseason and a lingering foot injury in 2016. McGuire played in all 51 games during his four seasons at ULL and was a highly productive back with 711 career carries for 4,353 yards (6.1) and 42 TDs. He also caught 129 passes for 1.383 yards (10.7) and 10 TDs. His "measurables that correlate" from the Combine were all above average -- 4.51 40-dash, 36-inch vertical jump, and 10-foot broad jump. McGuire grades out as a Day 3 prospect. -April 15, 2017 McGuire's quickness and balance give him the upside to develop into a versatile complementary back. But he comes with some durability concerns. His ability to stay healthy will play a big part in determining whether succeeds in the NFL. -- Kevin Weidl

Smart made 36 consecutive starts to end his career and recorded 33.5 tackles-for-loss over the past two seasons. He's an undersized 43NT prospect with shorter arms (32 3/8') and he didn't stand out the week of the Senior Bowl amplifying concerns about the level of competition he faced in the American Athletic Conference. However, he's a hard worker with the hands, quickness and enough size to develop into an effective reserve 43NT or DT. An undersized DT with shorter arms, Smart didn't run as well as expected at the combine. But he's a hard worker who shows the active hands and quickness to develop into an effective reserve in an aggressive one-gap scheme. -- Steve Muench

Sam 'tevv-ee' who started his career at defensive tackle before switching to the offensive line in his second season. Two year starter who started all 13 games at LOT before switching to right tackle in 2016 with the arrival of Garrett Bolles (missed 2 games due to an injury). Tevi has good feet and length (34') for the position but needs to get stronger (Bench: 15 reps) and is still developing awareness wise. Projects as a mid-to-late round developmental prospect who could develop into a serviceable back up ideally for a heavy zone blocking scheme. -- March 25, 2017 A converted defensive lineman, Tevi has good feet and length for the position, including 34-inch arms, but he needs to get stronger and is still developing his awareness. He's a developmental prospect with the potential to become a serviceable backup, ideally for a zone-heavy blocking scheme. -- Kevin Weidl

Woods is a versatile safety with above-average top-end speed. He misses some tackles, but he was Louisiana Tech's second-leading tackler last year. He flashes the ability to get to the quarterback and has the potential to develop into a playmaker. -- Steve Muench

Evans is an athletic space linebacker who shows quality range and has very good awareness and ball production in coverage for the position. He has a chance to contribute as a sub-package nickel linebacker and on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

Taylor is a two-year starter whose 51 tackles and 7 sacks in 2016 where the highest totals for an interior defensive linemen in the Mike Gundy era (2005-present). Registered 21  TFLs, 12 sacks and 5 blocked kicks in 26 starts the past two seasons. Taylor is a bit top-heavy and plays high but has a nice combination of length (34 3/8" arms) quickness and natural power to work with develop as a one-gap interior defender. Tested well at the combine. Projects as a day three developmental prospect that has a chance to add depth ideally for a base 43 interior front line.  April 6, 2017 While Taylor tends to get moved off the spot and needs to improve his hand fighting as a pass-rusher, he possesses a good blend of quickness, length and power. He also blocked five kicks at Oklahoma State. -- Steve Muench

Vallejo (vuh-LAY-ho) is a true senior who started 39 games at Boise State finishing with 277 tackles, 36 tackles-for-loss and 5.5 sacks. 2014 was by far his best season. Boise State suspended him for the 2015 Poinsettia Bowl following the 2015 season. He's a hard worker and team first player who played through a serious wrist injury before undergoing season-ending surgery last year. He's an undersized linebacker who isn't quite athletic or fast to move to safety. He projects best as a Nickel linebacker that makes his biggest contributions on special teams with that in mind. Vallejo is an undersized tweener who isn't quite athletic or fast enough to make the move to safety. He projects best as a nickel linebacker who makes his biggest contribution on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

Al-Qudain (al-KWUH-deen) Muhammad is a LDE/34OLB prospect who led the Hurricanes in tackles for loss (8.5) and sacks (5) in 2015. His frame and versatility are intriguing. However, maturity and availability are substantial concerns considering he missed two seasons because of off-the field issues  Miami suspended him for the 2014 season after he punched a student in the face and dismissed him for violating NCAA rules in the summer of 2016. A boom-or-bust prospect, Muhammad is an intriguing DE/3-4 OLB prospect with long arms and a quick first step. He has missed two seasons, including last year because of off-the-field issues, and he didn't test as well as expected at the combine. -- Steve Muench

Clark appeared in 36 games (15) as a defensive back during his four seasons at UM. A torn ACL in Game 4 (Penn State) cut his redshirt senior season short in 2016. Clark was off to a promising start, posting 10 tackles and two PBUs prior to injury. He's a long DB with good straight-line speed and he has experience at CB, FS and at the nickel. Durability is an issue, he needs to be in the right role within the right system, and he needs to be more aggressive in support. Clark is unlikely to workout prior to the NFL draft and he projects as a late-round pick or priority free agent. -March 9, 2017 Clark is coming off a torn ACL and needs to be more aggressive in run support, but he has good length and straight-line speed. He also has experience at corner, free safety and nickelback. -- Steve Muench

Jones is a JUCO transfer (East Mississippi CC) who has appeared in all 25 career games (15 starts) in two seasons at Ole Miss including starting all 12 contests in 2016 heading into their bowl game. He lacks ideal height and has shorter-arms (31 ') but plays with natural leverage and is a stout run defender. Jones has a chance to develop into a rotational interior defender and potential starter down the road ideally as a 43 NT.  December 1, 2016 Jones lacks ideal height and has shorter arms (31 1/2-inch arms) but plays with natural leverage and is a stout run-defender. Jones has a chance to develop into a rotational interior defender and potential starter down the road -- ideally as a 4-3 nose tackle. -- Kevin Weidl

A redshirt senior and two-time team captain Roullier (ROO-lee-ay) started 43 games at Wyoming lining up at guard for two seasons before moving to center last year. His versatility, intelligence and character make him a Day 3 option for teams looking to add depth along the interior offensive line. He doesn't project as a starter though. He struggles to sustain due in large part to his shorter arms (32 ') and while he posted an outstanding short shuttle time (4.47) at the Combine, his 5.54 40-tme and performance on the bench press (19 reps of 225 pounds) raise red flags. A two-time team captain, Roullier lined up at guard for two seasons before moving to center in 2016, and he has the potential to develop into an effective reserve. His shorter arms and below-average upper body strength could prevent him from developing into a NFL starter. -- Steve Muench

Bisnowatay (biz-NO-vah-tee) missed four games as a redshirt freshman in 2013 and one game in both 2014 and 2015 with ankle injuries, but he started all 13 at left tackle in 2016 and finished his career with 43 starts. He is a tough and smart football player who could overcome his physical deficiencies in the NFL but likely will need to move inside to guard. Bisnowatay grades out as an early-Day 3 prospect. -March 21, 2017 Bisnowaty is a tough and smart player who could overcome some physical deficiencies in the NFL but likely will need to move inside to guard from left tackle where he lined up at Pitt. -- Kevin Weidl

Hodges is 3 year starter who moved from TE to WR in 2016 (48 catches  691 yards  7 TDs). Projects as move TE at the NFL level. Rare size and athleticism which was showcased at the combine clocking in with a 4.57 (5th for TEs) while setting the bar in the VJ: 39' and BJ: 11'2'. Hodges has an extremely high ceiling and flashes the potential to develop into a difference maker in the passing game. However, the lack of consistency in his overall game (most glaring drops) make him one the bigger boom/bust prospects in the class.  March 31, 2017 Hodges showcased his rare natural ability at the combine and flashes the potential to develop into a difference-maker in the passing game. However, his tape doesn't always match up with his talent, and he's one of the bigger boom-or-bust prospects in the 2017 class. -- Steve Muench

'peet-tuh tao-mo-eh-pen-new' appeared in 46 career games that has never been a full time starter (7 career starts) in his four seasons at Utah. Born in Texas before moving to Tonga at 3-months old. Returned to the states at age 17 and played just one year of HS football. Extremely raw at this point. English is his second language which makes his learning curve steeper than normal. Projects as a late round developmental prospect where he has potential to contribute as a designated pass rusher (21  career sacks including career high nine in 2016). -- March 14, 2017 Taumoepenu is a developmental prospect who only played one year of high school football and started just seven games in four seasons at Utah. He is extremely raw but he flashes the potential to develop into a disruptive pass-rusher and he fits best at 3-4 OLB. -- Steve Muench

Henderson is a 3 year starter that broke the school record for career rushing yards (4,635) and rushing TDs (35). He lacks prototypical size but is built low to the ground and has above-average balance, lateral agility to go with very good top end speed. Also brings quality versatility in the passing game (Career: 97-921-6 TDs). Missed 3 games with a shoulder injury in 2016. Needs to become more decisive as an inside runner. Projects as a day 3 pick who could add depth in a backfield as change of pace runner.  March 30, 2017 Henderson lacks prototypical size and needs to be more decisive between the tackles, but he's built low to the ground and is an above-average receiver. He also shows good balance and lateral agility to go along with ideal top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

Jones is a converted wide receiver who switched over to cornerback this past season. He is still learning the nuances of the position but has developmental upside due to his length, athleticism and ball skills. -- Kevin Weidl

The son of former Oklahoma running back Weldon Ledbetter and cousin of former Titans receiver Isaac Byrd, Jeremiah Ledbetter is a redshirt senior and JUCO transfer who started 25 of the 26 games he played in at Arkansas. While he lined up all over the defensive front for the Razorback and he projects best as a LDE or 34DE with the ability to contribute as an interior pass rusher. Ledbetter is a versatile defensive end who can fit within a base 3-4 or 4-3 front. He brings added value with his ability to reduce inside as an interior rusher in passing situations. -- Kevin Weidl

Rodgers is a tough and durable throwback who appeared in all 53 career games (25 starts) over 4 seasons at Virginia Tech. Lined up in multiple spots for the Hokies including at tailback. Rushed for 283 yards on 67 carries while adding 2 TDs in 2016. Brings strong versatility in the passing game (Career: 60  724  7 TDs). A team captain with outstanding intangibles. Rodgers is a late round pick who won't surprise if making a 53-man roster as a rookie due to his ability to contribute on special teams and approach to the game.  March 31, 2017 Rogers, a team captain at Virginia Tech, has outstanding intangibles. He is versatile fullback who lined up at multiple spots, including tailback. He moved around the formation as a receiver and has the potential to be a core special-teams player. He's undersized with average top-end speed, though. -- Steve Muench

Wilson is a developmental prospect who lined up at corner in addition to playing some running back and contributing on special teams. He scored in six different ways when he was at Houston. He has average size and his pro day short shuttle (4.42) is a red flag for a corner, but he has excellent top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

Ford was a fourth-year senior in 2016 who appeared in 52 career games (24 starts) and finished with 275 tackles, 11.5 TFLs, 11 PBUs and 5 INTs. He is a versatile safety who has experience playing at the nickel-back position and was the teams' leading tackler in 2014 and 2015 (combined for 211 total tackles). Ford is a better run defender than coverage safety. He has elite speed but some hip tightness, so he's more effective when lined up closer to the line of scrimmage and when playing the ball in front of him. He grades out as a mid-Day 3 prospect. -April 8, 2017 Ford is better against the run than he is in coverage, even though he has outstanding speed and he's on the smaller side for a box safety. He's a straight-line player who closes well, but he looks tight in space and has average ball skills. -- Steve Muench

Davis started in all 48 career games and finished as Georgia State's career leader in receptions (222) and receiving yards (3,391). Killed the Combine. Ran a 4.44 and was first in the BJ (11'4') and second in both the VJ (41') and BP (19) for the WR group. Played well in a close lost at Wisconsin (6-93-1TD). He is a little straight line and has room to add polish as a route runner. However, he is a big, strong and explosive WR with outstanding makeup (1's across the board for top boxes) . Potential to be a day 3 steal due to upside.  March 24, 2017 While he lacks polish as a route runner and there are concerns about the level of competition he faced, Davis is a big, strong and explosive receiver who tested extremely well at the combine and has the work ethic to realize his considerable upside. -- Steve Muench

Senior, who is from Montreal, is a redshirt senior and three-year starter with the potential to develop into an effective No. 3 swing tackle. However, he doesn't project as a starter at the NFL level as he doesn't have ideal length (34' arms) for a left tackle or ideal strength for a right tackle. There are concerns about his work ethic and inconsistent play both on tape and at the Senior Bowl. There are questions concerning his playing weight as he gained 40 pounds between the spring of 2016 and the Combine where he did not test as well as expected. A three-year starter, Senior has the frame, smarts and enough length to provide depth as a No. 3 swing tackle. He'll have to improve his power base and make strides as a hand fighter if he's going to develop into a starter at right tackle. -- Steve Muench

McDermott is a redshirt senior and three-year starter who lined up at left tackle at UCLA but played some right tackle during one practice at the Senior Bowl and believes that he can play on the right side with more work. He's not as athletic on tape as his basketball background and Combine numbers would suggest. There are also medical concerns as he underwent shoulder surgery in high school and sprained a knee in 2015. If he stays healthy and proves he can play on both sides, he has the potential to develop into a valuable No. 3 swing tackle. McDermott isn't as athletic on tape as his combine numbers would suggest. He's not an overpowering run-blocker either. He has the length to develop into a No. 3 swing tackle if the collegiate left tackle proves he can provide depth at right tackle, too. -- Steve Muench

A two-year starter, Amichia primarily lined up at left tackle in college but also started two games at right tackle in 2014 and could develop into an adequate No. 3 swing tackle. His arms are on the shorter side, and it's more likely he'll have to move inside to make it in the NFL. -- Steve Muench
The Steelers are looking to groom the eventual replacement for long snapper Greg Warren, who is 35 years old and entering his 13th season. -- Kevin Weidl

Qualls is a redshirt junior and two year starter that has appeared in 38 career games with 19 starts while finishing 2016 with 38 tackles, 5 TFLs and 3 sacks. A short, squatty and powerful interior defender that plays with quality leverage (HS wrestling background) to go along with adequate initial quickness. Qualls has the chance to add immediate depth and help bolster a run defense within a one or two gap scheme. Needs development as a pass rusher to prove he can be a three down player. Projects as a day three pick.  April 3, 2017 A high school wrestler, Qualls is a powerful run defender with the bulk and upper-body strength to stack up blockers. He's quick enough to disrupt some plays in the backfield, but doesn't offer much as a pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

Kaaya's smaller frame took a beating as a three-year starter at Miami. He suffered a concussion in 2015 and missed the following week, but to his credit he started all 38 other games. He completed 61-percent of his career passes and finished with a 2.9-1 TD-INT ratio (69-24). Kaaya needs to add bulk/strength to his frame and his below average arm strength is limiting. But in a precision/timing based offense, Kaaya has the fast eyes, release quickness and anticipation to develop into a really good backup or possibly a solid starter. Kaaya grades out as a mid-round prospect. -April 8, 2017 A three year starter within a pro-style system, Kaaya shows fast eyes working through progressions and is extremely accurate when throwing from a clean pocket. His lack of ideal mobility is a concern, and he needs to show he can be more consistent under pressure. -- Kevin Weidl

"Mahr-quez" White is a two-year starter (24 starts past two years) who made his biggest contributions on special teams his first two seasons while he played in the shadow of the Seminoles' other talented DBs. He has average size with good fluidity and quality mirror skills to line up in press or off coverage. However, he has room to get stronger and become more consistent both playing the ball and in run support. Marginal career ball production (6 PBU-3 INTs). White projects as a mid-round pick.. -- March 15, 2017 White has average size with good fluidity and quality mirror skills to line up in press or off coverage. However, he has room to get stronger and become more consistent both playing the ball and in run support. -- Kevin Weidl

Levin is a four-year starter and redshirt senior who lined up at guard and tackle at Tennessee-Chattanooga. He's on the lighter side for an offensive guard and while he played some tackle in college he's a much better fit on the inside where he's got the frame, length smarts to develop into a starter if a team is willing to develop him. His tenacity on tape and work ethic should also help his cause. A four-year starter, Levin lined up at guard and tackle at Tennessee-Chattanooga. While he's on the smaller side for a guard prospect, he's a better fit on the inside, where he has the frame, length and smarts to develop into a starter in time. -- Steve Muench

McQuay III is a leaner safety with shorter arms for his frame and average playing speed, but he flashes above-average ball skills. He has the potential to develop into an adequate reserve who will make his biggest impact on special teams. -- Steve Muench

Coley played 46 of 52 games (missed 3 in '15 with hamstring) and finished four-year career with 166 catches (13.4 ypc). He started all 13 in 2016 and led the team with 63 catches for 754 yards (12.0) and nine TDs. There's no question Coley has the speed, athleticism and enough ball skills to make an impact in the league. He's best suited to serve as a slot receiver that can stretch the field vertically. Coley needs to get stronger and improve his route running skills (especially vs. press) but his work ethic and football character are very much in question. Early Day 3 grade. -February 9, 2017 Coley has the speed, athleticism and ball skills to develop into a dangerous slot receiver and return man if he gets stronger and improves his route-running skills. His work ethic and football character have been questioned though, so he may never realize his upside. -- Steve Muench

Ifeadi (if-AH-dee) Odenigbo (o-DEN-uh-bo) is redshirt senior who started just five of the 50 games he played at Northwestern finishing with 26.5 tackles-for-loss, 23.5 sacks and five forced fumbles. His arm length (32 5/8') and strength at the point raise concerns about his ability to develop into an every-down defensive end while his fluidity and instinct raise concerns about his ability to transition to 34OLB. He's an intriguing Day 3 prospect because he's flashed the ability to get after the quarterback and he hasn't reached his upside as a pass rusher yet. Odenigbo lacks ideal length and needs to get stronger at the point of attack to become an every-down player. He can be a help in pass-rushing situations; he flashes good quickness off the edge. -- Kevin Weidl

A JUCO transfer Shalom (Sha-lome) Luani (Loo-ah-knee) started 25 games at Washington State finishing with 148 tackles, eight interceptions and three forced fumbles. He grew up in America Samoa where he was a soccer star and stayed in America after a tournament to chase his dream of playing football. English is his second language so there may be communication issues and while assault charges were dropped, he got into an off-campus fight in 2016. His tackling is also a substantial concern but his toughness, athletic ability and desire to succeed could cause a team to take him late. While Luani needs to improve his recognition in coverage, he has the toughness, length, speed and athletic ability to develop into a backup safety and special-teams contributor if he becomes a more consistent tackler. -- Steve Muench

Average size, elite speed. Has some upside. Myrick is an average-sized corner with below-average ball skills and average instincts, but he has some upside thanks to his elite top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

Steven 'tooey-kolo-va-too' is a graduate transfer from Utah who recorded 53 tackles, 2 TFLs and  sack in his first season as full-time starter at USC. He is a massive and powerful two-down space eater that will instantly upgrade the interior run defense. Weight and diet will need to be monitored. Missed the 2013 season with a foot injury. Mature individual who is married and will be 26 years old this upcoming June. Fringe day two pick.  March 25, 2017 Tu'ikolovatu is a massive and powerful two-down space-eater who will instantly upgrade a team's interior run defense. His weight and diet will need to be monitored. -- Kevin Weidl

Gonzalez is the all-time FBS career record holder for most field goals with 96 and he holds the FBS record for points by a kicker with 494. He is coming off a stellar senior season and he's versatile enough to handle the kickoff duties in addition to place kicking duties. He projects as a late round pick and has an excellent shot to win a starting job in the fall. Gonzalez is the all-time FBS career record-holder for most field goals with 96 and holds the FBS record for points by a kicker with 494. He is coming off a stellar senior season, and he's versatile enough to handle the kickoff duties in addition to place-kicking duties. -- Steve Muench

Rochell was a four-year contributor at Notre Dame, playing in 49 career games (38 starts). He had some back issues early in his career that limited his weightlifting but was finally fully healthy as a senior in 2016, when he totaled 55 tackles, 7 TFL and one sack (finished career with 167-22-4.5). Rochell projects as a backup five-technique DE in a 3-4 scheme. He is a tough competitor, and he has length, size and strength to serve as a space eater versus the run but he's slow getting off blocks offers very little as a pass rusher. He grades out as an early-Day 3 prospect. April 6, 2017 A 2016 team captain, Rochell is a tough competitor with the size and strength to set the edge and develop into an effective rotational player in a base three-man front. He's slow to get off blocks and he's not an explosive edge rusher. -- Steve Muench

There are obvious concerns about the level of competition Moore faced in college, and he has shorter arms, but Moore has an above-average blend of size and speed. He's an intriguing developmental prospect. -- Steve Muench

Carraway has started in 33 career games including all 26 in the past seasons while recording 22 1/2 TFLs and 17 sacks within that span (2015-'16). A 34 OLB prospect that has excellent length (34 1/2" arms) and quality athleticism. Needs to get stronger particularly in his lower half to improve point of attack skills and adding more of power element to his game. High character individual who has a quality work ethic. Projects as a mid-round pick that can add depth and has the athleticism to contribute on special teams while he develops early in his career. -- March 19, 2017 Carraway is a 3-4 outside linebacker prospect who has excellent length (34 1/2-inch arms) and quality athleticism. He needs to get stronger, particularly in his lower half, to improve his point of attack skills and add more of a power element to his game. -- Kevin Weidl
Ivie is a grinder who lacks an elite physical skill set but has quality power. He plays with the toughness and motor that could allow him to overcome his deficiencies. -- Kevin Weidl

A graduate transfer from Texas, Colbert moved from safety to corner at Miami. He flashed signs of developing into an effective press corner, and there's a lot to like about his upside -- he ran a 4.38 at his pro day -- but he missed five games with injuries last year and needs more time to develop. -- Steve Muench

Suspended 3 times at Georgia before being dismissed in 2014. After piecing together a full season in 2015 at UL, he battled a nagging hamstring injury that limited him late in season in 2016 causing his production to dip. A bigger high cut DS who could ultimately find a home as a Nickel-LB. Reportedly has taken advantage of second chance and has matured since arriving at Louisville. Commitment to eliminating distractions outside of football (history of marijuana issues) may ultimately determine his success or failure at the NFL level. Projects as a mid-round pick. -- March 29, 2017 Harvey-Clemons is a big safety who has marginal top-end speed and below-average fluidity. He's a physical run-stopper who could turn into an effective nickel linebacker who also covers kicks. Eliminating distractions outside of football may ultimately determine his success or failure in the NFL. -- Steve Muench

A three-year starter, Ware has shorter arms for an offensive tackle, and there are concerns about the level of competition he faced in college. But he has the athletic ability and size to transition inside and provide depth at guard. -- Steve Muench

Butker finished his career as Georgia Tech's all-time leading scorer with 337 career points and 208 career PATs. He's got good leg strength and showed much improved accuracy last year, but he wasn't nearly as accurate his first three seasons at Georgia Tech. -- Steve Muench

Ejuan (prefers to be called 'Juan') Price is a disruptive edge rusher who could develop into a productive sub-package player at the NFL level but he'll have to show that he can make the transition from 43DE to 34OLB. It's critical that he perform well during linebacker drills during the pre-draft process as a result. There are also substantial medical concerns - he's missed two seasons and the bulk of another with injuries  and he turns 24 in January so he's on the older side. Improved test results at Pro Day from combine. At this point he projects as a Day 3 pick. -- April 15, 2017 Price is a dynamic pass-rusher with active hands and good first-step quickness, but he's an undersized 3-4 outside linebacker prospect who isn't as effective in space as he is attacking upfield. Also, Price missed two seasons and the bulk of another with injuries. -- Steve Muench
He is a twitchy and athletic cornerback with adequate size and quality mirror skills in man coverage. -- Kevin Weidl

Seaton is an interesting small-school prospect who has athletic limitations and might need to kick inside to guard despite having very good length. He's big and strong enough to make the transition to guard. -- Steve Muench

A three-year starter, Ford became the first Virginia Tech player to finish a single season with more than 1,000 receiving yards in 2015 and he eclipsed the 1,000 yard mark again in 2016. He also set the single-season school records for catches (75) and touchdown catches (11) in 2015. He's an above average route runner with the savvy to get open but his mediocre Combine performance is an accurate reflection of the explosiveness he shows on tape. He also needs to fill out his frame and get stronger to develop into an effective outside receiver in the NFL. He projects as a Day 3 prospect. A three-year starter, Ford is an above-average route runner, but his mediocre combine performance is an accurate reflection of the explosiveness he shows on tape. He also needs to get stronger and bulk up if he's to develop into an effective outside receiver. -- Steve Muench
He is a bigger back with quick feet and lateral agility for his size. He also brings quality power to grind out yards after contact. -- Kevin Weidl

Brown played sparingly as a true freshman in 2014 (one catch) before missing all of 2015 with a broken leg suffered in August camp. As a third-year sophomore in 2016, he finished 2nd on the team with 32 catches (12.6ypc with 7 TDs). Oklahoma '16 was his best tape (4 TD catches) but his overall production is lacking. Brown has size, ball skills and athleticism to develop into a solid No. 3 or No. 4 who excels in the redzone. He's capable of becoming a better pro than college player but is he self motivated enough to keep his weight in check and maximize his raw tools/ Day 3 grade -April 4, 2017 Brown's size, ball skills and athleticism give him a chance to develop into a solid No. 3 or No. 4 wide receiver who excels in the red zone. He's capable of becoming a better pro than college player, but he needs to be motivated enough to keep his weight in check and maximize his raw tools. -- Kevin Weidl

Williams has only one year of experience at the FBS level, and he's a limited athlete who didn't play a big role as a ball carrier or receiver in Miami's offense, but he has an intriguing blend of size and speed. -- Steve Muench
Muhammad is an undersized back with excellent top-end speed and has the potential to develop into an effective complementary back who contributes on third down. -- Steve Muench

Hood had a break out year in 2015 (1,463 rushing yards, 17 TDs) but was unable to get back on track in 2016 (858 yards and 8 TDs) as he missed time battling an undisclosed illness while also suffering a concussion in which he missed two games including the Sun Bowl. Hood lacks ideal quickness and may struggle to create yards on his own at the next level. However, he is a big, physical and powerful back that can churn out in between the tackle and add depth to a backfield as a short-yardage runner. Projects as a day three pick. March 8, 2016 Hood is a physical and powerful runner who churns out yards between the tackles and can add depth as a short-yardage back. He's not as quick on tape as his testing would suggest, and he put the ball on the ground too much at North Carolina. -- Steve Muench

Fuller is a fifth-year senior and three-year starter with the intelligence, work ethic, frame and length to develop into a starting center in time and provide depth along the interior offensive line early his career but the tape doesn't match the talent. He'll need to play with greater intensity and clean up his technique to play a substantial role in the NFL. In addition, he's not a great athlete on tape and his short shuttle time (4.84) is a red flag for an interior offensive lineman. A three-year starter, Fuller has the football IQ, frame and length to provide depth along the interior offensive line and develop into a starting center in time. But, Fuller is not a great athlete and he'll need to clean up his technique to play a substantial role. -- Steve Muench

A 2016 team captain, Hester is a redshirt senior and four-year starter who finished his career with 161 tackles, 31  tackles-for-loss and 13 sacks. He tore the labrum in his right shoulder against Ohio last year and underwent surgery in December. In addition to raising medical concerns, the injury prevented him from participating in the East West Shrine game and working out at the Combine. He's a disruptive three-technique with the potential to develop into an effective backup in an aggressive base four-man front and he could turn into a good Day 3 value pick if he checks out medically. Hester is a disruptive 3-technique with the potential to develop into an effective backup in an aggressive base four-man front. He could turn into a good value pick if he can overcome some durability concerns. -- Kevin Weidl
A team captain who graduated in three years, Tocho has enough length and top-end speed to provide depth in a press-heavy scheme. -- Steve Muench

A JUCO transfer, Carrell is on the lighter side with shorter arms. He needs to improve his upper-body strength but he has the quickness to develop into a disruptive backup 3-technique. -- Steve Muench

Dupre was a third-year junior in 2016, when he led the team with 46 catches for 593 yards (14.5) and 3 TDs. He started all 25 games his final two seasons and played in all but one game during his three-year LSU career (missed season-opener vs. Wisconsin as a freshman in 2014 with an ankle injury). Dupre finished with 98 career catches for 1,609 yards (16.4) and 14 TDs. He's a smooth, sure-handed WR that was hamstrung by a brutal QB situation. He lacks speed and polish. Dupre grades out as a mid-round prospect and could emerge as a solid No. 3 WR in the NFL if developed properly. March 5, 2017 While Dupre has just average speed and quickness, he is a smooth athlete for his size with reliable hands and the strength/toughness to win in contested situations. Has a chance to develop into a quality No. 3 receiver. -- Kevin Weidl
Adams is a disruptive edge defender who fits best at 3-4OLB where he has the length, initial quickness and closing speed to develop into an effective pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench
A JUCO transfer, there are concerns about Carson's pedestrian production at Oklahoma State and durability, plus he has average size and top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

Physical run stuffer. Fits as 5-technique or LDE. Grinder. 7th round or priority free agent. -April 19, 2017 O'Connor is a grinder who is tough against the run and rushes the passer with good effort but he has shorter arms and below-average upper-body strength. -- Steve Muench

Jerome is a 4 year starter who finished the 2016 season with 59 tackles, 5 PBUs and 6 INTs. Better football player than measureables and test times indicate. Possesses natural FBIs and playmaking instincts where he recorded 28 PBUs and 18 INTs for his career. Brings added value on special teams as returner (4 career returns for TDs). Checks all the boxes off the field (Captain/Work Ethic/Film Rat). Helped his stock immensely in the pre-draft process (see above). A mid-round pick that could end up developing into a starting sub-package NB.  April 4, 2017 A smaller safety who didn't test well at the combine, Jerome is a better football player than athlete, and he eased concerns about the level of competition he faced in college with a strong showing at the Senior Bowl. Jerome's experience returning kicks will help his stock. -- Steve Muench

Hikutini is a double transfer (2012-'13: Sacramento St. 2014: City College of SF) before landing at Louisville prior to the 2015 season. In two seasons, he has appeared in 23 games with 12 starts (2015: missed 3 games with a shoulder injury) and had a breakout 2016 season with 49 catches for 656 yards (13.4) and 8 TDs heading into the Citrus Bowl. Hikutini still has room to polish as a route runner and can improve his blocking. However, he has the size, athleticism and ball skills to potentially develop into a starter. He projects as a fringe day two pick.  April 15, 2017 Hikutini can still add polish as a route runner and improve his blocking. But his quality size and the athleticism he shows getting out of his stem gives him the potential to develop into a starter down the road. -- Kevin Weidl

"kee-OHN-tay" Davis is a two year starter who has started in all 24 games that past two years while recording 24 sacks and 28 1/2 TFLs in the span (2015-'16). He has some stiffness and limitations athletically. However, he is a physical edge defender who has good initial quickness and brings strong speed-to-power capabilities to develop as a pass rusher. Team captain as a senior and good overall makeup. Davis projects as a fringe day two pick that will add quality depth on the edge with the potential to develop into a starter down the road. -- March 22, 2017 Davis has some stiffness and limitations athletically, but we love his physicality as an edge defender. He shows good initial quickness and brings strong speed-to-power capabilities to develop as a pass-rusher. Davis also has good overall makeup and was a team captain. -- Kevin Weidl

Cannon started 32 games and put up big numbers in his three seasons at Baylor finishing his career with 195 catches for 3,113 yards and 27 touchdowns. He's an undersized receiver who missed the 2016 Iowa State game with a groin injury and underwent arthroscopic knee surgery in the 2016 off-season. He's also an underdeveloped route runner who faces a steep learning curve transitioning to the NFL. He still projects as a mid-round pick because he has the toughness, quickness and top-end speed to develop into a productive slot receiver who potentially also returns kickoffs. Cannon, an underdeveloped route runner, faces a steep learning curve transitioning to the NFL. We like his toughness, quickness and top-end speed, though. He has the potential to develop into a productive slot receiver and contribute on special teams as a returner. -- Kevin Weidl

Aviante (AWvee-on) Collins started 29 games at right tackle including all 13 last year and another seven at left tackle while he was at TCU plus he helped himself with a strong Combine performance. He projects as a Day 3 pick because he started just 14 games over the past three seasons as he lost his starting job in 2014 and sustained a season-ending injury in 2015. Plus there are fit concerns. His length raise concerns about his ability to play on the outside and there's no guarantee he's capable of transitioning inside. Collins is a left tackle prospect who lacks ideal bulk and inline power and is best fit for a zone blocking scheme. He needs to show more consistency with his play, but he has an athletic skill set to work with and could develop into a potential serviceable reserve who can add depth to an offensive line. -- Kevin Weidl

"or-Loss-kee" is a two time team captain that started in all 39 games the past three years to end his career. He has average size and athleticism but has really developed into a technician to go along with a quality feel for angles. He is also a film junky that has the intelligence and work ethic that is coveted at the position. Orlosky projects as a mid-round pick that has a chance to develop into a serviceable back-up and potential starter down the road within a heavy zone-blocking scheme. -- March 17, 2017 Orlosky is a film junkie who has the intelligence and work ethic that is coveted at the position. He has average size and athleticism but makes up for it with excellent technique to go along with a quality feel for angles. Orlosky, who is a two-time captain, has the potential to develop into a serviceable starter for a heavy zone-blocking scheme. -- Kevin Weidl

"JESS-a-men" Dunker started his career at Florida but transferred after 1 year largely stemming from an arrest for 3rd degree grand theft of a scooter and driving with suspended license in January of 2013. A 4 year starter at TSU who moved from LG to LOT in 2016. Dunker lacks an elite anchor but he is one more 'twitchy' and athletic OL in this class with the potential to develop into a starting LOT within a heavy zone scheme. However, with his high ceiling comes high risk due to character and accountability concerns that teams will weigh heavily with his evaluation.  April 1, 2017 Dunker lacks an elite anchor, but he is one more "twitchy" and athletic offensive lineman in this class with the potential to develop into a starting left tackle within a heavy zone scheme. However, he is comes with some risk because of character concerns (two arrests while at the University of Florida) and accountability concerns. -- Kevin Weidl

John "Toeth" is a durable four year starter OC (47/46) with good size for the position. Excellent hand fighter and has quality inline power. However, he has some stiffness and lacks ideal athleticism. Will need to rely on proper technique to mask these flaws both in space and working against quicker interior rushers. Team captain who has the intelligence (Mechanical Engineer Degree), toughness and leadership qualities that are coveted at the position. Projects as a mid-round pick who should add depth on the interior with the potential to develop into a serviceable starter.  March 23, 2017 A team captain and four-year starter, Toth is an excellent hand fighter with good inline power. He also has the toughness and football IQ teams covet at center. He'll need to play with sound technique to mask his lack of ideal athleticism in pass protection. -- Steve Muench

Johnson was a four-year player and one-year starter. He sat behind 2017 NFL draft picks T.J. Green and Jayron Kearse but got his shot to start in '16 and made the most of it (63 tackles, 7 PBUs and 5 INTs). He's a well-respected person and player. Comes from a supportive family, the game is important to him, and he takes to hard coaching. His combine measurables across the board (size, speed, shuttles, jumps) were nearly identical to or slightly better than the 5-year average for DS's. Johnson's best football appears to be in front of him. He could be an early Day 3 value pick. -April 1, 2017 Johnson is a free safety prospect who possesses quality instincts and overall range as a center fielder. He also displays quality ball skills and the ability to finish when provided the opportunity. He comes with strong intangibles. -- Kevin Weidl

A former JUCO transfer Phillips is coming off a breakout senior season finishing with 20 tackles-for-loss and nine sacks. He's an older prospect  turns 25 in September  who will have to move from defensive end to outside linebacker as he is on the lighter side even for a 34OLB and he has just one notable year of production under his belt. That said his potential as a pass rusher, notable production last year and strong performance the week of the Senior Bowl make him an interesting Day 3 prospect. Phillips is a versatile edge defender whose best fit will be as a 3-4 outside linebacker, where he brings upside as a pass-rusher because of his first step quickness and ability to bend the edge. He needs to continue to improve his instincts and develop stronger point of attack skills to become an every-down player. -- Kevin Weidl

"juh-RON" Jones redshirted in 2012 before playing 36 games (18 starts) the next four seasons (2013-16), totaling 105 tackles, 19.5 TFL and 4.5 sacks. He missed two games in 2014 with a Lisfranc fracture and missed the 2015 season with a torn right MCL suffered during fall camp. Jones is an underachiever with an inconsistent motor. He has great length and his flashes are bright, but they're too few and far between. He he wasn't productive in college and he has not shown self-discipline to stay in shape. Jones has upside but too much risk to draft before Day 3 grade. -April 6, 2017 Jones has great length and shows flashes of quickness and athleticism to develop into a disruptive interior defender. However, he needs to become more consistent both on and off the field to ever reach his potential. He also has some minor durability concerns. -- Kevin Weidl

Mama started four games at guard as a true freshman before starting 25 of 27 games played at left guard in 2015-'16. He's a talented player but comes with major red flags. He is constantly fighting to keep his weight down (shed 70-plus pounds at USC). He is still out of shape, he had ridiculously poor workout numbers at the Combine and USC's Pro Day, and multiple scouts voice concerns about his poor work ethic and lack of accountability. While he's gifted enough to start at guard in the NFL, the risk-level is too great to gamble on before Day 3. April 1, 2017 Mama has the length, power and smarts to become an effective starter. There are major red flags, though. He struggles to keep his weight down, he didn't test well at the combine or his pro day and scouts have voiced concerns about his lack of accountability. -- Steve Muench

A 2016 team captain, Amba (AUM-buh) Etta-Tawo (ET-ta-TAH-wo) is a redshirt senior and Maryland graduate transfer coming off a breakout season setting 10 school receiving records in his only season with Syracuse. He finished with 94 catches for 1,482 yards and 14 touchdowns. He's a developing route runner with inconsistent hands and just one-year of quality production. His frame, production last year and height-weight-speed make him an intriguing early Day 3 prospect though. A 2016 team captain and Maryland graduate transfer, Etta-Tawo is a developing route runner who has inconsistent hands, and his senior season was by far his most productive. That said, Etta-Tawo's frame, production last season and height-weight-speed combination make him an intriguing developmental prospect. -- Steve Muench

Howard had his best season in 2016 finishing with 53 receptions for 827 yards and a team-high eight touchdown catches. He's a high cut receiver who is going to have problems separating from underneath coverage but has the size and strength to make contested catches. There's also a lot to like about his length (33 1/8' arms), massive hands (10 3/8') and size-speed combination. He's a developmental prospect that needs to make strides as a route runner but has a high ceiling. Howard is a big receiver who is going to have problems separating, but he has the strength, big hands and long arms to make contested catches underneath. While he doesn't have great top-end speed, he's fast enough to make the occasional play downfield. -- Steve Muench

Fields struggled to stay out of trouble at TCU where he was suspended in 2013 and dismissed in 2014 after being charged with misdemeanor assault as a result of allegations he threatened and hit his ex-girlfriend (eventually dropped). Missed nearly 2 full games while dealing with an undisclosed injury in 2016 and production dipped significantly (2015: 22 1/2 TFL, 11 sacks -- 2016: 9 TFL, 6 sacks). Fields is a disruptive edge defender (Career: 52 TFLs and 27 sacks) but can play with more consistency and comes with some risk/baggage which will likely affect his draft slot. -- March 29, 2017 Fields is a disruptive edge defender who has above-average initial quickness and active hands, but he's undersized with short arms for a defensive end/3-4 outside linebacker prospect. In addition, his erratic motor raises concerns about his football character, plus there are durability and off-the-field issues (an arrest and a dismissal from TCU). -- Steve Muench

Ross broke four career school records - catches (195), consecutive games with a catch (34), 100-yard receiving games (10) and receiving yards (2,484)  at Mississippi State. He's a grinder with a professional work ethic and he could develop into a top three receiver for a team in time but his tape is a little inconsistent and he projects as a sub-package receiver who potentially helps out on special teams at this point. A productive SEC receiver, Ross has the professional work ethic and tools to develop into a top-three receiver, but he's a little too straight line and he doesn't play as fast as he tested at the combine. He also has experience returning punts. -- Steve Muench

Braden was a three-year starter at Michigan (2014-16) after redshirting in 2012 and playing sparingly in 2013. He projects best as at OG in the NFL but he does have experience at both OT positions. He's a hard worker with a pack-a-lunch mentality. His measurables at the combine (6-4 1/2, 329 pounds with 34-inch arms and a 5.03 40-yard dash) were better than estimated last spring. Braden has some athletic limitations and needs to continue working on his base/balance, but he's a smart player with an intriguing height-weight-speed combination. He grades out as a Day 3 prospect. -March 26, 2017 Braden has experience at both offensive tackle spots and enough arm length to provide depth at right tackle, yet he projects best at guard, where he started 17 games over the past two seasons. He has the potential to develop into an effective NFL starter. -- Steve Muench

Ordorf, whose father (Scott) played college football (Cal University of PA) and in the USFL, played the first nine games (five starts) as a true freshman in 2013 before suffering a season-ending knee injury. He returned to play 10 games as a backup in 2014 before regaining the starting job his final two years, when he played all 26 games (20 starts) and hauled in 48 passes for 813 yards (16.9) and 10 TDs. Scott has an impressive combination of size, strength and straight-line speed. He's unpolished but has tools to improve in the NFL. He grades out as a Day 3 prospect. -February 20, 2017 Orndoff has an impressive combination of size, strength and straight-line speed. He's unpolished but has tools to improve and develop into an adequate No. 2 or No. 3 tight end in the NFL. -- Kevin Weidl

A redshirt junior, Walker has the size and quickness to play DT in addition to the length to play 34DE. He appeared poised for a breakout junior season and he flashes Day 2 talent on tape  see the first half of the 2016 Ohio State game  but there are a number of red flags starting with the medical as he sustained his third concussion early on in 2016. He also left Oklahoma in November to focus on the draft  a decision his defensive coordinator described as quitting on teammates  and there were already concerns about his work ethic. Finally he started just four games at Oklahoma. Walker comes with some red flags, including durability and character concerns. If he can stay healthy and focused, he has the size, quickness and length to develop into a rotational defender along the front line. -- Kevin Weidl

"TRAY-vin" Dural is a 3 year starter (29 total starts). Production dropped in yards (280), YPC (10.00) and TD receptions (1) as a senior. A lot had to do with QB play which admittedly has not been great throughout his career at LSU. Dural has good ball skills and size but he will struggle to get vertical like he did in college and he needs to improve his strength against more physical CBs (release). He also comes with some durability concerns (2015: Missed final 4 games with hamstring; 2016: Missed 2 games with a shoulder injury). Projects a Day-3 pick. -March 17, 2017 Dural -- who has above-average size, good speed and reliable hands -- needs to add polish and become stronger as a route runner. He has the chance to add depth in the back end of a roster early on and eventually develop into a No. 3 receiver. -- Kevin Weidl

Clement (CLEM-ent) had his best season a senior finishing with 1,375 yards and 15 touchdowns on 314 carries. He has the instincts, size and enough foot speed to develop into an effective complementary back but there are a number of red flags. He didn't run well at the Combine. He put the ball on the ground too much last year. He missed most of the 2015 season with a hernia injury that required surgery. Finally, there are concerns about his maturity due in part to a 2015 altercation at an off-campus apartment and how he misled his coaches and authorities about his role in that altercation. Clement doesn't have elite speed, needs to improve his ball security and comes with some durability concerns. With that said, he has the instincts, size and enough foot speed to potentially develop into an effective complementary back. -- Kevin Weidl

Lampkin is a two-year starter that recorded 8 PBUs and 2 INTs within that span (2015-'16). He comes with durability concerns and his lack of ideal size is also a concern when it comes to matching up with the bigger receivers. On the other hand, he has enough instincts and cover skills to potentially stick as a potential sub-package DB ideally in a heavy zone scheme. He was Oklahoma State's special teams MVP in 2013 and will need to be a heavy contributor in this area early in his career while he develops. Lampkin projects as a late round developmental prospect. -- February 27, 2017 Lampkin comes with durability concerns, and his lack of ideal size is also a concern when it comes to matching up with bigger receivers. But he has enough instincts and cover skills to potentially stick as a sub-package DB, ideally in a heavy-zone scheme. -- Kevin Weidl

Praise Martin - "OH-gwee-kay" has appeared in 47 career games with 28 starts including 11 in 2016 where he recorded 7 1/2 sacks and 10 TFLs. He is a sawed-off 34 OLB candidate that lacks ideal athleticism but plays with a physical demeanor and has a quality combination of leverage, power and finishing strength to develop as a pass rusher. Started career in 2011 but was not with the team in 2012-'13 due to rape allegations that were eventually dropped. Projects as a late round developmental pick that can contribute on special teams early on (5 career BK's) while he develops. -- March 20, 2017 A sawed-off 3-4 OLB candidate, Martin-Oguike lacks ideal athleticism but plays with a physical demeanor. He has a quality combination of leverage, power and finishing strength to develop as a pass-rusher. -- Kevin Weidl

Wheeler redshirted in 2012 before emerging as a fulltime starter at left tackle the next four seasons (2013-16). He finished his USC career with 45 starts (missed five games in '14 with knee injury, two games in '15 with a concussion, and missed two starts in '16 with ankle injury). Wheeler is a tall college OT that might need to convert inside to guard or center in the NFL. He has good height with a somewhat narriw build and shorter than ideal arm length (33 7/8'). He moves better than his workout times but lacks core strength. Wheeler grades out as a Day 3 prospect. -March 28, 2017 Wheeler is a bit of a tweener, and he lacks the ideal athleticism and quickness to protect the edge. Because of his taller, leaner build, he'll need to get stronger in his core to bump inside at guard. His best fit might ultimately be as a center in the NFL. -- Kevin Weidl

Noil had trouble staying on the field at Texas A&M, missing eight games in three seasons (due to injuries and off-the-field issues that led to multiple suspensions). He wound up playing 31 games and finished with 88 catches for 1,134 yards (12.9) and 9 TDs, while also averaging 23 yards per KOR and 11.6 yards per PR. Noil is one of the "twitchiest" players in this draft and he's capable of contributing in the NFL as a slot receiver and return specialist but concerns about his size, durability and character will negatively effect his grade. We think he's worth a Day-3 pick. -April 5, 2017 Noil is one of the twitchiest players in this draft, and he's capable of contributing in the NFL as a slot receiver and return specialist. The biggest concerns are his lack of size, durability and character; he had multiple suspensions at Texas A&M. -- Kevin Weidl

A 2016 team captain, Damarius (duh-MARE-ee-iss) Travis started 23 games at Minnesota and he had his best season as a redshirt senior finishing the 2016 season with a team-leading 83 tackles in addition to five tackles-for-loss and two interceptions. He has outstanding football character and he was an excellent special teams' player early in his career at Minnesota. He missed most of the 2015 season with a hamstring injury. He has the potential to develop into an effective reserve defensive back but doesn't project as a starter because of limitations in coverage. Travis has the potential to develop into an effective reserve defensive back. His experience on special teams will also be an asset wherever he ends up. -- Kevin Weidl

Pascal is a redshirt senior and three-year starter who finished his career with 233 catches for 3,184 yards and 30 touchdowns. He has an intriguing height-weight-speed combination, he catches the ball well and he has experience lining up in the slot and on the outside. He's not the most explosive route runner or big-play threat but he has the potential to develop into an effective sub-package receiver plus he has experience covering kicks and he should contribute on special teams early in his career. Pascal's height-weight-speed combination is intriguing, and he catches the ball well. While he's not the most explosive route runner or a big-play threat, he has the potential to develop into an effective sub-package receiver. -- Kevin Weidl

Tashawn (tuh-Shawn) Bower started seven of the 40 games he appeared in at LSU lining up at defensive end his first three seasons and moving to a defensive end/outside linebacker role in LSU's 3-4 scheme last year. He also kicks inside to rush the passer. His sub-par production is a concern but he makes more of an impact on tape than the numbers would suggest and he benefited from the move last year. While he may never develop into a starter, he's a hard worker who will get the most out of his natural ability and has enough tools to play 34OLB in the NFL. Bower is a versatile edge defender who made more of an impact than his production indicated. He might never develop into a starter, but he's a hard worker who will get the most out of his natural ability and has enough tools to potentially develop into an adequate backup, ideally as a 3-4 OLB. -- Kevin Weidl

The son of Bryan Cox Sr. (former NFL LB and current Falcons DL coach), Cox Jr. was a four year contributor at Florida (44 games, 28 starts). He had his best season in 2015, recording 10.5 TFL and 3.5 sacks. His tape was not nearly as impressive during an injury-riddled 2016 season (11 games, 5 starts: 19 tackles, 2.5 TFL and a half sack). He also missed the 2014 bowl game with a hip injury that required surgery. Cox is powerful versus the run but lacks athleticism in the pass game. He's best suited to play over the TE as a standup 3-4 OLB. Grades out as a Day 3 prospect. March 7, 2017 Powerful versus the run, Cox is best suited to play over the tight end as a stand-up 3-4 OLB. He lacks athleticism in the pass game but is a physical player who plays hard on tape. Durability is a concern. -- Kevin Weidl

A three-year starter, Ekanem (ee-CAN-um) recorded a total of 24 tackles-for-loss and 14 sacks in the two seasons leading up to his senior year. He's an effective hand fighter who has enough tools to develop into and reliable reserve in addition to the temperament and experience to contribute on special teams. However, his upside at LDE is limited by his frame and he doesn't appear to have the burst or agility to develop into an every-down 34OLB. He projects as a Day 3 pick. -- April 6, 2017 Ekanem is an effective hand fighter who has enough tools to develop into and a reliable reserve on defense. Not to be overlooked: He also has the temperament and experience to contribute on special teams. -- Kevin Weidl

Rector is a 3 year starter who finished 2016 with 32 catches for 367 yards (11.5) and 3 touchdowns. He is a smooth and sudden athlete that tested extremely well at the combine. Needs to get stronger and continue to hone his craft as a route runner. Has traits that translates the NFL level including speed to stretch the field and generate a big play with the ball in his hand. Success or failure will depend heavily on his focus away from the field. Suspended for the 2015 season opener vs Northwestern for 'disciplinary reasons'. Projects as a late round developmental pick.  March 25, 2017 A smooth and sudden athlete, Rector tested extremely well at the combine. He needs to get stronger and continue to hone his craft as a route runner. His speed to stretch the field and ability to generate a big play with the ball in his hand will translate to the NFL. -- Kevin Weidl

A 2016 team captain, Dare (DAR-ay) Ogunbowale (oh-goon-bo-WALL-ay) is a former walk-who didn't play high school football until his junior year and moved from defensive back to running back in 2014. He led the Badgers in rushing with 819 yards and seven touchdowns in 2015 but played a reduced role due in part to the return of Corey Clement in 2016. He's an average sized back with below average top-end speed but he's a hard worker with the potential to develop into a core special teams' player and serviceable No. 3 back. Ogunbowale has below-average top-end speed, but he's a hard worker and has the potential to develop into a core special-teams player and serviceable No. 3 back. -- Kevin Weidl

Sickels is a redshirt junior and two year starter who finished the year with a team leading 12  TFLs and was tied for a team high 6 sacks. The second half of the Ohio State game (suspended for the first half for off the field conduct) will be his calling card tape as he finished the game with 3  TFLs and 2  sacks in PSU's upset win over the Buckeyes. Sickels is a hybrid edge defender who is quick, tough and plays with a high motor. Improved sub par test numbers from the combine at his pro day. Projects as a day three developmental prospect. -- April 5, 2017 A hybrid edge defender with good quickness, Sickels shows toughness and plays with a high motor. He's an average athlete, though, and will need to improve his technique to develop into an every-down starter at the next level. -- Kevin Weidl
