Oliver is a two-time team captain and redshirt junior who started 25 of the 39 games he played in at Indiana and he finished his career with 255 tackles, 24.5 tackles-for-loss, five sacks, 12 forced fumbles and two interceptions. There are medical concerns as he tore an ACL in 2014 and missed Indiana's bowl game with a nagging injury. He projects as a reserve inside linebacker that helps bolster the run defense and has the mentality as well as the tools to make an immediate impact on special teams. Oliver projects as a reserve inside linebacker who will make the most impact as a run defender and on special teamsw. He comes with some durability concerns. -- Kevin Weidl

Smith racked up 495 carries for 2,235 yards (4.5) and 22 TDs during his four seasons at Michigan. He led the team in rushing each of his final three seasons. However, it should be noted he averaged just 2.9 yards per carry versus the better defenses faced in 2016 (Wisconsin, MSU, Iowa, Ohio State and FSU), compared to 5.9 yards per carry versus all other opponents. Smith is a punishing runner with limited speed and elusiveness. He will fit best as a change-of-pace runner in the NFL, likely for a team featuring a power-based run game. He grades out as a late-round prospect. -April 6, 2017 Smith is a punishing runner with the lower-body strength to develop into an effective change-of-pace back for a team that features a power running game. But his marginal top-end speed, limited elusiveness and lack of upside as a receiver is concerning. -- Steve Muench

Brown lined up at WR for the Rams where he dominated the D2 level of competition due to his size and physicality. (2nd in the nation with 1,580 receiving yards on 99 catches while adding 22 TDs as senior in 2016). However, at 255 lbs along with a lack of ideal speed (4.70) and quickness for an NFL WR, Brown will likely be forced to transition as a F-TE in the NFL. Good showing at EW Shrine game. Missed the 2013 season with a torn ACL. Day 3 pick who has the chance to develop into a versatile receiving TE.  April 1, 2017 Brown lined up at receiver at Shepherd, where he dominated Division II competition because of his size and physicality. At 255 pounds with marginal top-end speed for a receiver, he'll probably have to transition to a move-TE (or "F") in the NFL. -- Steve Muench

Kelsey is a durable 3 year starter who finished his career with 39 consecutive starts while leading the team in tackles the past two seasons (93 in 2016). A team captain as a senior, he has the intelligence, work ethic, motor and toughness give him a chance to overcome his physical deficiencies (See combine results) and develop into a serviceable backup and special teams' contributor. However, his shorter arms and lack of top-end speed (4.92) will more than likely prevent him from becoming an every-down player in the NFL. Projects as a late round pick. -- March 29, 2017 Kelsey's intelligence, work ethic and motor give him a chance to overcome his physical deficiencies and develop into a serviceable backup LB and special teams' contributor. His shorter arms and marginal top-end speed will probably prevent him from becoming an every-down player. -- Steve Muench

The son of 1988 NBA first round pick Jerome Lane, Lane is a redshirt junior who moved from linebacker/safety to receiver in August of 2015 and caught 101 passes for 1,800 yards and 14 touchdowns over the past two seasons. He's raw with marginal timed top-end speed and there are concerns about the level of competition he faced at Akron. However, he's just 21 years old, he's got good size and he's quicker than fast both on tape and in his testing making him an interesting Day 3 developmental prospect. A redshirt junior, Lane moved from linebacker/safety to receiver in 2015. He's raw and his timed top-end speed is below-average, but he's just 21 and he has good size. He also looks quicker on tape than his 4.6 40 would indicate. -- Steve Muench

Jefferson is a redshirt senior and two-year starter who finished his career with 35 tackles-for-loss, 13  sacks and six forced fumbles. He's a 2016 team captain who has outstanding football character and projects best as a reserve LDE that kicks inside to rush the passer. He could also provide depth for a base three-man front but he's on the smaller side for a 34DE prospect. He wasn't invited to the Combine and he didn't run at his Pro Day. He's a below average athlete with marginal burst on tape. There's also a medical concern as he underwent shoulder surgery in December. Jefferson is a below-average athlete with marginal burst on tape, and he's coming off shoulder surgery. But the 2016 team captain has the frame, length and work ethic to develop into an effective rotational defensive end in a base four-man or three-man front. -- Steve Muench

Quick is a three year starter (45/31) who has 117 career receptions for 1,878 yards (16.0) and 14 TDs heading into the Citrus Bowl. Quick projects as a slot-WR due to lack ideal measureables and elite speed. However, he polished route runner who shows quality ball skills. Quick comes with minor durability and off the field questions. He projects as a day three prospect who has a chance to add depth on a roster but will need to prove he can contribute on special teams. -- April 6, 2017 An undersized receiver with below-average top-end speed, Quick will probably need to prove he can contribute on special teams to make a roster. His polished route-running ability and quality ball skills give him a chance to develop into an effective slot receiver. -- Steve Muench

Brown is a two year starter that is coming off career highs for TFLs (14) and sacks (3) in 2016. He is a shorter (6003) and squatty two-down interior run defender with adequate arm length (33 1/8) and a powerful upper body. Needs to develop as pass rusher (Career: 6 1/2 sacks). Team captain in 2016 with outstanding make-up and work ethic. Close bond with former teammate Sheldon Rankins (Saints 1st Rd pick 2016). Missed the entire 2013 season with Achilles' Tendon injury. Projects a mid-to-late day three pick ideally as a NT for a heavy base 43 front. -- March 29, 2017 A team captain with outstanding makeup and work ethic, Brown is on the lighter side, but he's a short and stout two-down interior run defender with adequate arm length and a powerful upper body. He doesn't have much upside as a pass-rusher, though. -- Steve Muench

Buchanan started 32 games at right tackle at Miami of Ohio but his arm length (32 3/8') is a substantial red flag for offensive tackles and he projects better at guard with that in mind. While he has the size, intelligence and foot speed to make the transition and potentially develop into a starter, his Pro Day 40 time (5.51) is a red flag for offensive guard prospects and he doesn't always play with the nasty disposition teams covet in their interior offensive linemen. Buchanan started 32 games at right tackle, but his arm length is a red flag for an offensive tackle prospect. He projects better at guard, where he has the size, intelligence and foot speed to develop into an effective backup and potentially start in time. -- Steve Muench

'duh-MORE-ee-ay' Stringfellow began his career at Washington before transferring to Ole Miss where he appeared in 24 games the past 2 seasons while starting in all 12 games in 2016 (46 catches, 716 yards, 6 TDs). He is big WR with an intriguing skill set who shows flashes but needs to show more consistency both on and off the field. Left off the combine invite list due to off-the-field incidents at both Washington and Ole Miss. Stringfellow is a risk-reward prospect that has potential to bring solid value on day 3 if he can get his priorities in check. April 5, 2017 Stringfellow has an intriguing skill set and flashes on tape, but he's a boom-or-bust prospect who needs to be more consistent on and off the field. He was left off the combine invite list because of off-the-field incidents at Washington and Ole Miss. -- Steve Muench

Gennesy "JIN-is-see" is a JUCO transfer (E. Mississippi CC) who has now started in 20 consecutive games since the start of the 2015 season before redshirting in 2014. He has an intriguing tool box to work with due to adequate size along with above-average athleticism and feet for a left tackle prospect. Gennesy he has a chance to develop into an adequate back-up and possible starter down the road -- ideally for a zone blocking scheme -- if he learns to play with better balance and continues to develop his strength particularly in his lower body. -- April 6, 2017 Gennesy has an intriguing tool box, including above-average athleticism and feet for a left tackle prospect. He has a chance to develop into an effective backup and possibly grow into a starter if he learns to play with better balance and continues to develop his strength. -- Steve Muench

A four-year starter and redshirt senior Nickerson finished his career with 353 total tackles. He was also named a 2015 team captain at Cal where he played for three seasons and a 2016 team captain at Illinois where he transferred to play for his father Illinois defensive coordinator Hardy Nickerson Sr. as a graduate. He's an overachiever that may not have the natural tools to develop into an every-down player in the NFL but he has the potential to provide quality depth as a reserve linebacker and special teams' contributor. Nickerson was a 2015 team captain at Cal and a 2016 team captain at Illinois, where he transferred to play for his father. An overachiever who doesn't project as a starter, Nickerson has the potential to develop into a serviceable backup and special-teams contributor. -- Steve Muench

Staples is a UAB transfer who appeared in 22 games with 18 starts the past 2 seasons for Louisville while recording 36 catches for 615 yards (17.1) and 2 TDs in 2016. He is a bit straight line but has excellent length (33 ' arms) to go along with quality speed and range as vertical receiver outside the hashes. Missed the first four games in 2015 due to a knee injury suffered in preseason. Chance to add depth as a fourth or fifth receiver on roster.  April 2, 2017 Staples might struggle to separate on underneath routes, and he's not as much of a threat after the catch, but he has the wide catch radius and top-end speed to develop into a dangerous vertical receiver outside the hashes. -- Steve Muench

Rudolph played 13 games (six starts) as a true freshman in 2014, finishing with 38 catches for 555 yards and four TDs. He went on to lead the Seminoles in receiving each of the next two years (2015-16), combining for 115- 1,756-15.3-14. Rudolph is a smooth glider with good ball skills. He has a solid work ethic and he brings strong intangibles to the NFL (Bo Paske middle school lunch visit is well documented).However, Rudolph 's lack of suddenness, lower-body explosiveness and top-end speed put a lower ceiling on his NFL potential. He grades out as a mid-Day 3 prospect. March 21, 2017 Rudolph is a smooth glider with good ball skills. He has a solid work ethic and strong intangibles. Rudolph's lack of suddenness, lower-body explosiveness and top-end speed, however, put a ceiling on his pro potential. -- Kevin Weidl

Adeboyejo (add-ah-BOY-joe) is a true senior who caught 106 passes for 1,454 yards and 11 touchdowns in his four seasons at Ole Miss. His hands are inconsistent, his production doesn't match his talent and it doesn't help his cause that he didn't return kicks at Ole Miss. He could still get drafted late as a developmental prospect with above average upside and he helped himself at the Combine. His 40 (4.42), 10-yard split (1.54), three-cone time (6.73) and broad jump (10'3') are all excellent results for a receiver. Adeboyejo needs to show more consistency, particularly with his hands. He projects as a developmental prospect with quality upside, which he reinforced with a good showing at the combine. -- Kevin Weidl

Cethan (SEETH-un) Carter is a true senior who started 35 games finishing with 59 catches for 744 yards and four touchdowns. Erratic quarterback play impacted on his production but so did injuries and a suspension. He missed three games with an elbow injury in 2016 and he missed four games with a foot injury in 2014. He's a developmental prospect who may have to spend time on a practice squad early on but he has the skill set to develop into an effective F tight and the work ethic to make the most of his natural ability if he stays healthy and takes care of his business off the field. Carter is a developmental prospect who might have to spend time on a practice squad. He has the skill set to develop into an effective "F" tight end. -- Kevin Weidl

Noble 'wah-CHEW-koo' has started in all 38 games he's appeared in over the past 3 seasons. Recorded 40 tackles, 7  TFLs and 4 sacks in 2016 after registering 8  sacks his junior year. A hard edge setter vs the run that plays with a physical demeanor and high motor. Lack of ideal quickness and bend puts a cap on his ceiling in this department. Nwachu projects as a late round pick who has the potential to add depth and help bolster the run defense ideally for a base 43 scheme.  April 3, 2017 Nwachukwu is a hard edge setter vs. the run who plays with a physical demeanor and high motor. Lack of ideal quickness and bend put a cap on his ceiling. -- Kevin Weidl

Lee is a two-year starter and former walk-on with the frame, smarts and toughness to develop into a starting guard or versatile reserve that provides depth at guard and right tackle. However, he's a developmental prospect who needs to make strides in terms of his technique- most notably his hands and pad level - to play a significant role in the NFL. He projects as a late round pick that could spend some time on the practice squad as a result. Lee has the smarts and toughness to develop into a versatile reserve who provides depth at guard and right tackle. He's a developmental prospect, however, who needs to make strides in terms of his technique, most notably in his hands and pad level. -- Kevin Weidl

Likely is a four-year starter and 2016 team captain whose numbers dipped the past two seasons with injuries playing a role. He missed most of 2016 with a torn ACL. Shoulder and ankle injuries hindered him in 2015. His diminutive frame amplifies durability concerns and will prohibit him from developing into a starter on the outside. His struggles fielding punts are also a concern. However, he is an excellent athlete with the potential to develop into an effective slot corner and dangerous return man  returned two kickoffs and four punts for touchdowns at Maryland  if he can stay healthy. Likely is an undersized cornerback who has durability concerns; he tore an ACL in October. He is an excellent athlete, however, who has the potential to develop into an effective slot corner and dangerous return man -- if he can stay healthy. -- Kevin Weidl

Scott was productive each of his three seasons at Clemson, finishing with 245 receptions for 2,480 yards (10.1) and 19 TDs. He struggled as a punt returner but he did average 24 yards per KOR the past two years (2015-16). There's a lot to like about Scott's competitiveness and toughness. He has solid hands, he's a willing blocker and he runs hard with the ball in his hands. But Scott's like of size, speed and explosiveness put a low ceiling on his NFL potential. Scott will likely need to make a team on his ability to contribute on special teams. He's a late round prospect. -March 10, 2017 Scott has solid hands and is a willing blocker. He also runs hard with the ball in his hands. He lacks the size, speed and explosiveness, however, to be a big-time NFL receiver. -- Kevin Weidl

Grace did not play in 2016 after he was dismissed from the team for NCAA violations for ties to local luxury rental car agency. Started in 10 games in 2015 and led the Hurricanes with 79 tackles while adding six TFLs and five PBUs. Grace is an undersized space linebacker who has the range and athleticism to be contributor as a sub-package linebacker and special teams contributor. Did not workout for teams prior to the draft to our knowledge. Late round developmental or PFA grade.  April 5, 2017 Grace is an undersized space defender who has the range and athleticism to contribute as a sub-package linebacker and special-teams contributor. He did not play in 2016 after being dismissed from the team in August for committing NCAA violations. -- Kevin Weidl

Scott was productive each of his three seasons at Clemson, finishing with 245 receptions for 2,480 yards (10.1) and 19 TDs. He struggled as a punt returner but he did average 24 yards per KOR the past two years (2015-16). There's a lot to like about Scott's competitiveness and toughness. He has solid hands, he's a willing blocker and he runs hard with the ball in his hands. But Scott's like of size, speed and explosiveness put a low ceiling on his NFL potential. Scott will likely need to make a team on his ability to contribute on special teams. He's a late round prospect. -March 10, 2017

Thomas is a 2 year starter who led the Owls with 953 yards rushing while adding 13 TDs in 2016 despite missing the first 2 games with a hand injury. He is undersized change of pace back that brings quality versatility in the passing game (2016: 33 catches  418 yards - 6TDs) and as a returner on special teams (KOR TD in 2015). He projects as a late round pick.  March 22, 2017 An undersized back with below-average power, Thomas has marginal top-end speed, but he runs hard, he's quicker than fast, he's a polished receiver and he has experience returning kickoffs and punts. -- Steve Muench

Greg 'Pike' is a three year starter (36 career starts) that has experience at both guard positions and at ROT where he started in all 13 games in 2016. Projects as a guard at the NFL due to less than ideal arm length (33 1/4") and lack of ideal athleticism to protect the edge. While he has ideal size and strength for the position he needs to play with more consistent leverage and showing better balance playing on his feet. Did not receive an Combine Invite. Projects as a mid-to-late day three prospect that has the potential to develop into a serviceable reserve. -- March 19, 2017 Pyke projects as a guard because of his less-than-ideal length and lack of athleticism. He does have the size and strength to potentially develop into a versatile reserve. -- Kevin Weidl

A two-year starter and 2016 team captain Langi (long-ee) started at Utah where he played running back in 2011 before going on a two-year mission. He transferred to BYU and moved to linebacker in 2014. He's also saw time at defensive end and got 25 carries at BYU. Fit is a concern. He projects best at inside linebacker but he doesn't have ideal instincts for an inside linebacker and he doesn't have ideal size or length for an edge defender. There are also concerns about off-the field behavior stemming in part from a high school incident and missing 2015 spring practice for undisclosed reasons. Langi is a tweener without ideal size or length for an edge defender. He projects best at inside linebacker, where he could add depth as a reserve if he can improve his instincts. -- Kevin Weidl

Seals-Jones was a fourth-year junior who appeared in 38 career games with 120 catches for 1,424 yards (11.9 average) and nine TDs. He received a medical redshirt (knee) after appearing in just two games his freshman year (2013). Seals-Jones needs to refine his route running but he is a big, physical and athletic WR/TE hybrid who can create mismatch problems, particularly in the red zone. His work habits will be investigated heavily. Cousin of Eric Dickerson, Seals-Jones has the physical tools to outplay his draft grade but at this point we think he's only worth a Day 3 pick. -April 4, 2017 Seals-Jones needs to refine his route-running, but he is a big, physical and athletic receiver-tight end hybrid who can create matchup problems, particularly in the red zone. -- Kevin Weidl

WR moved to TE. Had early career injuries. Ran well at Pro Day and tested out well. Developmental matchup piece in 7th round or as priority free agent. -April 19, 2017 Croom, a former receiver, has the length, top-end speed and enough quickness to develop into a receiving tight end who causes matchup problems for defenses. But he's never caught more than 21 passes in a season and his injury history is reason for concern. -- Steve Muench

Harris is a four-time team captain and the NCAA All-Division record holder for career tackles with 633. He also recorded 34 tackles-for loss and six interceptions in addition to punting 35 times and connected on 12 point after attempts. He stands out on tape but the level of competition he played against at Division II Lindenwood is a concern and his performance the week of the Senior Bowl failed to ease that concern. A team could take a chance on him because of his production and intangibles. He's going to have a tough time making a roster unless he becomes a core special teams' player though Harris stands out on tape and dominated Division II-level competition, but he lacks ideal size and athleticism and will need to be a special-teams contributor to survive on a 53-man roster. -- Kevin Weidl

Johnston handled the punting duties for the Buckeyes in all four seasons in the program. Australian punter who grew up in Geelong Australia. Johnstone has quality leg strength and excellent touch placing over 50% of his career punts inside the opponents' 20 yard line. Also shows the ability to alter his approach using a traditional approach or rugby style pending on field positon or situation. Projects as a late day three pick.  April 5, 2017 Johnston has quality leg strength and excellent touch, placing more than 50 percent of his career punts inside the opponents' 20-yard line. He also shows the ability to alter his approach using a traditional approach or rugby style depending on field positon and situation. -- Kevin Weidl

After redshirting in 2012, Kalis played in 50 games (43 starts) as a four-year starter at right guard for the Wolverines. He is an overachiever with great toughness and effort. Kalis has athletic limitations and lacks versatility. He was not invited to the Combine but participated in Michigan's Pro Day. Kalis grades out as a fringe late-round or priority free agent prospect. -March 27, 2017 Kalis has athletic limitations and lacks versatility, but he plays with great toughness and effort. He also has the intelligence to potentially stick on a roster and add depth on the interior. -- Kevin Weidl

Redding is a junior who declared early after eclipsing the 1,000 yard rushing mark the past two season (2015-'16). He is an undersized back that runs hard, has quality vision and brings adequate versatility in the passing game. However, he lacks ideal speed and explosiveness on tape and his test results at the combine were concerning. Redding projects as a potential late round pick that could add depth to a backfield. Will likely need to be a heavy special teams contributor to ensure a roster spot.  March 13, 2017 Redding is an undersized back who runs hard, has quality vision and brings some versatility in the passing game. He lacks ideal speed, however, and doesn't show NFL-level explosiveness on tape. -- Kevin Weidl

A four-year starter and East West Shrine game participant Tom is an overachiever who loves football and has above average football smarts. That said, he doesn't project as a starting center based off his tape and he doesn't appear versatile enough to provide depth at multiple positions. His frame and powerbase raise concerns about his ability to provide depth at guard. While his arm length (33 5/8') is good for a center it's a red flag for a tackle and he hasn't played on the outside since his freshman year. Tom lacks ideal athleticism and needs to get stronger. He does have quality footwork and technique, good football smarts and enough toughness to potentially provide depth. -- Kevin Weidl

Stribling played mostly as a reserve DB and on special teams in 17 games during his first two seasons (2013-14). He went on to play 24 games (17 starts) his final two years (2015-16) and racked up 45 tackles, 16 PBU, and 6 INTs. Stribling improved throughout his college career, he has solid length and quick feet. But his instincts are concerning, he lacks strength, and his workout numbers raise a serious red flag (ran 4.60 40-yard dash, 31.5" VJ, 4.56 short shuttle, and had just 5 bench press reps). Stribling grades out as a late-round prospect or priority free agent. -March 22, 2017

'Russell' Shell started his career at Pitt but ended up transferring after one season for undisclosed reasons. Lowest production of his career in 2016 season (514 yards and 5 TDs) due to a hand injury that limited him in the second half of the season and forced him to miss a total of 3 games. Shell lacks ideal speed and suddenness as a runner but he is a physical runner with a strong combination of balance and power to grind out tough yards. Projects a mid-day three pick that has the potential to add depth in the backfield.  March 17, 2017

A special teams' standout his first two seasons at Clemson, Boulware emerged as a highly productive starting MLB his final two seasons (2015-16), combining for 209 tackles, 19.5 TFL, 6 sacks, 6 forced fumbles and three INTs. Boulware has good short-area quickness, excellent instincts and plays with a high motor. He loves the game and leaves it all on the field. Unfortunately, he's undersized with below average speed, redirect skills and lower-body explosion. Special teams will need to be his NFL ticket. Boulware grades out as a late-round or priority free agent prospect. -March 30, 2017 Boulware has good short-area quickness, excellent instincts and a non-stop motor, but he's undersized with below-average speed and redirect skills. A special-teams' standout his first two seasons at Clemson, he'll probably need to make an impact on special teams to make an NFL roster. -- Steve Muench

Peterson started in 30 consecutive games before having season ending surgery on his back after the 5th game of the 2016 season. A guard prospect who fits best in zone-heavy scheme until or unless he fills out his frame and improves his powerbase but he's a grinder who plays with an edge and consistently finds a way to get the job done thanks in large part to effort. He projects as a late round pick who has the potential to develop into a serviceable back-up if able recover and get back to full health from his surgery. -- March 8, 2017 Peterson is light for a guard and is coming off season-ending back surgery. He does have the potential to develop into a serviceable backup. He's a grinder who plays with an edge and finds a way to get the job done, thanks in large part to effort. -- Steve Muench

Sojourn (SO-jurn) Shelton started a school-record 51 games at Wisconsin where he broke up 41 passes and intercepted nine passes over the course of his career. He's got the instincts, cover skills and enough playmaking ability to develop into an effective Nickel or Dime corner. However, he doesn't have the size to develop into a fulltime starter on the outside and his poor tackling is a concern both in regards to his ability to play a substantial role on defense and contribute on special teams. Shelton has the instincts, cover skills and playmaking ability to develop into an effective nickel or dime corner. He doesn't have the size to develop into a starter, and his poor tackling is a concern, especially because he'll need to make an impact on special teams. -- Steve Muench

A three-year starter and 2016 team captain, Thomas finished his career with 223 tackles including 149 unassisted and lined up high, in the box and over the slot at Oklahoma. He is a hard worker with great football character but his production dipped last year and his 2015 tape is better than his 2016 tape. A Combine snub, he didn't work out well at his Pro Day either as he reportedly ran a pedestrian 4.66 40 and posted a slower three-cone time (7.07) for a safety. He could get drafted late because of experience and intangibles but he projects as a career backup and special teams' player. A three-year starter and 2016 team captain at Oklahoma, Thomas is a hard worker with great football character and good instincts. However, he's an inconsistent tackler, and he posted a below-average 40 time at his pro day. His 2015 tape is better than his 2016 tape. -- Steve Muench

Jarwin finished his career with just 41 catches for 616 yards and five touchdowns plus he's a sub-par blocker with a lean lower body. He still has a chance to get drafted late though as he flashes the potential to develop into a productive F tight end and his Pro Day workout backs up the upside he shows on tape. In addition, he's a former walk-on with outstanding football character and the mentality to develop onto a core special teams' player. Jarwin is a sub-par blocker with a lean lower body. He has a chance to develop into a productive receiving tight end, and his pro-day workout reflects the upside he flashes on tape. He also has the mentality to develop into a core special-teams player. -- Steve Muench

Lucas is a competitive undersized WR that plays bigger than his measureables indicate. A three year starter that finished 2016 with 81 catches for 1,180 yards and 15 TD. Possesses good play speed and quickness and quality ball skills. Missed the final games of 2015 from a torn patella tendon in his knee. Lucas projects as late round developmental pick who could add depth as 4th or 5th WR working from the slot.  March 31, 2017 A three-year starter, Lucas is a competitive, undersized receiver who plays bigger than his measurables and faster than his timed top-end speed would suggest. He's also tough enough to do the dirty work over the middle, and he catches the ball well. -- Steve Muench

A redshirt senior, Ugokwe (u-go-kway) is a four-year starter and former walk-on who started seven games at left tackle as a redshirt freshman and then moved to right tackle. He only played two years of high school football and he's raw from a technique standpoint - most notably the way he uses his hands. His high center of gravity is also a concern as he struggles to sink both in the run game and on pass pro. However, his size and length (35 3/8') make him an intriguing developmental swing tackle that could get drafted late or sign with a team as a rookie free agent. Ugokwe is a former walk-on who started seven games at left tackle and then moved to the right side. He's raw, and his high center of gravity is a concern, but his size and length make him an intriguing developmental swing tackle prospect. -- Steve Muench

Stevenson was originally recruited as a linebacker before switching over to fullback. He has appeared in 48 total games making 20 starts (2016: 9 carries - 90 yards - 6.9 - 4 TDs). Stevenson is an undersized and versatile fullback who is an above-average runner for the positon (See long runs vs Clemson and Florida in 2016). He has battled through some minor leg injuries throughout his career. Stevenson projects as a late round pick who has the potential to add versatility and depth in a backfield while also become a solid contributor on special teams.  March 18, 2017 A versatile fullback, Stevenson is an effective inside runner who has good vision and flashes the ability to produce after the catch. However, he's undersized and isn't an overpowering blocker, and he has battled minor leg injuries throughout his career. -- Steve Muench

Marks is a redshirt senior who set the Pac-12 career receptions with 312 for 3,426 yards and 37 touchdowns. He's an undersized receiver with shorter arms (30 3/8') and he weighed seven pounds less at his Pro Day than he did at his Combine. He sustained a concussion in the fall of 2014 and his slight frame raises concerns about his durability. He's a hard worker but teams will have questions regarding his off-the-field decision making that stem in part from an arrest for his involvement in a bar fight in 2014. He was redshirted in 2014. He projects as a sub-package slot receiver. Marks catches the ball well and is tough over the middle, but he's undersized with shorter arms and average top-end speed. NFL teams will also have questions regarding his off-the-field decision-making because of an arrest for his involvement in a bar fight in 2014. -- Steve Muench

Bullough was a fifth year senior in 2016 and second-year starter. He led the team with 106 tackles in 2015 but missed three games early in 2016 () and finished with just 76 tackles. Bullough loves the game and takes great pride in his preparation. He's a team captain and intelligent player with average athleticism and tackling skills. He is undersized and might be maxed out. He needs to get stronger and improve take-on skills. Bullough grades out as a late-round prospect who will need to excel in multiple areas of special teams in order to make a roster early in his career. March 17, 2017 A team captain at Michigan State, Bullough loves the game and takes great pride in his preparation. He needs to get stronger and improve his take-on skills, but his frame might be maxed out. He'll need to excel in multiple areas of special teams to make an NFL roster. -- Steve Muench

"Duh-RELL" Daniles was converted from high school WR to college TE by former head coach Steve Sarkisian. He had just 47 career catches but averaged 15.5 yards per catch with five TDs. Stood out atteh NFLPA al-star game. Has good experience on special teams -- gunner on punt team. Grades out as a late-round prospect. -April 15, 2017 A former high school receiver, Daniels moved to tight end under former coach Steve Sarkisian, and he has the length, top-end speed and frame to develop into an effective receiving tight end. He also has experience covering punts and should contribute on special teams. -- Steve Muench

Robinson transferred from Michigan State following his redshirt freshman season. He started five games in his first two seasons at Tennessee State before starting all 11 last year. He finished 2016 with 42 tackles, five interceptions and eight PBUs. He weighed 182 pounds at his Pro Day raising concerns about his ability to play on the outside and his short shuttle time (4.44) is a red flag that raises concerns about his ability to line up over the slot. There are also concerns about his off the field behavior that stem in part from a 2013 arrest for underage drinking and driving. A Michigan State transfer, Robinson has above-average speed, good instincts and he intercepted five passes last season. However, he's undersized and he weighed seven pounds less at his pro day than he did at the combine. He's also a below-average run-stopper. --Steve Muench

Taylor was a highly productive four-year starter (51 games, 45 starts) who racked up 331 tackles, 50 TFL, 25.5 sacks (18.5 last two seasons), 6 FFs and 4 INTs. He has playmaking instincts but a poor size-speed combo makes him a bit of a tweener, and he'll likely need to make it in the NFL on special teams. Coaches need keep him focussed and scouts voice some concern about the people he surrounds himself with. He was suspended one game in 2016 for violating team rules. But teammates and coaches love/respect his outgoing personality and his tough-guy approach. Late-round grade. -April 1, 2017 A highly productive four-year starter at Houston, Taylor has above-average instincts and a great motor. Taylor's subpar size-speed combination raises legitimate questions about his ability to make the jump to the NFL, and he'll probably need to develop into a core special-teams player. -- Steve Muench

Vereen played in 48 career games during four seasons at Tennessee. He played in all 26 games (18 starts) his last two seasons (2015-16) and racked up a combined 21 TFL and 10.5 sacks. Vereen has some shock in his hands and he gives excellent effort. He also has very good intangibles and has been durable throughout his career. But Vereen lacks twitch and explosiveness as a pass rusher and has some athletic limitations in space. Vereen, who was not invited to the NFL Combine, will need produce on special teams in order to make the back-half of a NFL roster. Late-round grade. -April 8, 2017 Vereen has some shock in his hands, and his effort is excellent. He also has good intangibles, but he lacks explosiveness as a pass-rusher and has athletic limitations. He'll need to produce on special teams to make the back half of an NFL roster. -- Steve Muench

Carter had a team leading 85 tackles in his only season as full-time starter in 2016. He is big and physical strong safety prospect who is at his best when utilized near the box. Adequate career ball production (10 PBUs and 3 INTs) although did not record an INT in 2016. Overcame a rough upbringing. Strong work ethic. Carter has a chance to develop into an adequate reserve and has the toughness, measureables and enough athleticism to be a strong contributor on the core four special teams. Projects as a day three pick.  March 29, 2017 Carter is a big and physical strong safety prospect who is at his best playing neat in the box. He has the work ethic and enough talent to develop into an adequate reserve and a strong contributor on the core four special-teams' units. -- Steve Muench

Clements started 20 of the 46 games he played in finishing with 25.5 tackles-for-loss, four sacks and four forced fumbles. Medical and whether or not his testing results match up with his tape are concerns. He didn't participate in East West Shrine game and didn't run at Combine or Illinois' Pro Day after sustaining an injury in the regular season finale. He was charged with misdemeanor battery and signed a second chance agreement to erase charges in 2016. He projects as a reserve three-technique Day 3 pick if the medical checks out and teams feel that off-the-field behavior won't be an issue Clements is a disruptive run-defender who has the potential to develop into a reserve 3-technique in a one-gap scheme. He's not as effective rushing the passer as he is defending the run. An injury prevented Clements from working out at the combine and Illinois' pro day. -- Steve Muench

A three-year starter and two-time team captain, Ellis led Arkansas in tackles each of the past two seasons and he's the first two-time Academic All-American in program history. He's an instinctive inside linebacker with enough size, speed and athletic ability to develop into a starting inside linebacker or weak inside linebacker but he projects as a depth linebacker who makes his biggest contributions on special teams unless he gets stronger at the point. A three-year starter and two-time team captain, Ellis needs to get stronger at the point of attack. He's an instinctive inside linebacker with enough size, speed and athletic ability to develop into a valuable backup who makes his biggest contributions on special teams. -- Steve Muench

A fifth-year senior that started 28 games at Arkansas Hatcher averaged 16.8 yards per catch and caught a career-high eight touchdowns last year. He doesn't project as a big-play threat at the NFL level though and he doesn't have the burst to regularly separate from man coverage. His 40 (4.64) is a red flag and his 10-yard spit (1.64) is a borderline red flag. A team could take chance on his ball skills and frame late but he projects as a late round pick or rookie free agent who will need an impressive training camp to make a roster. Hatcher has marginal top-end speed and doesn't project as a big-play receiver, even though he averaged 16.9 yards per catch last season. He doesn't have the burst to regularly separate from man coverage either, but he has a good frame and above-average ball skills. -- Steve Muench

Neal was a fourth-year senior in 2016 who appeared in 47 career games (all 24 career starts were in final two seasons, when he combined for 108 tackles, 15 TFL, and 11.5 sacks). While that's strong production from a defensive end, its more of a testament to his motor and effort than physical skill set. Neal is on the shorter-side and lacks explosiveness as an athlete, but he does have longer arms (33 1/8') and shows quality power. Neal grades out as a late-round pick or priority free agent. He would fit best in a Ravens type of 3-4 scheme. -April 7, 2017

A 2016 team captain and four-year starter Skipper started at right tackle, left tackle and left guard plus he blocked seven kicks at Arkansas. Yet the versatility he showed in college doesn't translate well to the NFL. In fact, there are concerns about fit as his arm length (33 3/8') is a red flag for an offensive tackle and his high center of gravity, short shuttle (5.01) and 40 time (5.42) all raise concerns about his ability to play on the inside. It wouldn't be a surprise to see a team draft him late because of his work ethic and resume.

Brown started his career at Florida International before transferring to Ole Miss where he appeared in 32 career games (24 starts) over his three seasons in Oxford. Dealt with a broken foot late in the 2015 season that required surgery and caused him to seven games over the past two seasons. Brown has a favorable frame but needs a lot of work in terms of technique and his instincts aren't up to par at this point either. Projects as a fringe late round pick or priority free agent.  April 6, 2017

Cox played in 51 games as a four-year contributor, including 25 starts (16 at DS, 9 at CB). Finished his career with 166 tackles, 14 PBUs, 5.5 TFL, four INTs. Cox struck a plea deal in January, 2017 to resolve a criminal case stemming from an alleged assault on a taxi driver in November, 2016. He was suspended for his final career game (Penn State) following the arrest for misdemeanor assault. Cox has no other issues off the field and by all reports he has very good football character (team captain 2016). Cox grades out on tape as a Day 3 FS prospect with some versatility. March 25, 2017

Leamon started 29 games including every game of the past two seasons. He signed with Clemson coming out of high school but he didn't qualify academically so he enrolled at South Carolina State. He's a developmental prospect who isn't ready to play a significant role early on in his career. That's said, he has the length (35 ' arms), size and enough athletic ability to develop into a starting right tackle or a reliable No. 3 swing tackle.

A two-year starter and the nephew of former Cowboys safety Darren Woodson, Luke has good experience with 38 career starts (51 games played). He has good fluidity and change-of-direction skills. He also has above average ball skills (8 career INTs and 24 PBUs). But Luke, who has below average length and marginal top-end speed, will need to overcome odds in order to make a 53-man roster in the NFL. Luke grades out as a late-round or priority free agent prospect in the 2017 NFL Draft. -April 4, 2017

Torgensen started all 29 games played (missed one in 2015 with concussion) during his final three seasons (2014-'16) and led Penn to 16-4 record and shares of the Ivy League title his final two seasons (2015-16). Finished as Penn's all-time leader in completion percentage (65.1), total offense (7,937) and passing TDs (52). He was the best QB at the NFLPA game. He's an athletic rhythm passer with just average size and arm strength, and he's a much more accurate short-to-intermediate than he is vertically. Torgensen grades out as a late-round prospect or priority free agent. -April 4, 2017

Thomas has appeared in 41 career games with 21 starts including starting all 13 games in 2016 while recording 10 PBUs, 1 INT and 68 tackles. Thomas is a competitive and tough player and comes with outstanding character and work ethic. He flashes quality instincts and took steps a run defender as a senior but his lack of ideal fluidity and range may put a cap on his ceiling at the next level. He projects as a late round pick that will need to be a heavy special teams contributor early in his career as he continues to develop as a player.  March 9, 2016

Davis is a two-year starter and 2016 team captain who eclipsed the 100-tackle mark each of the past two seasons. He's an instinctive middle linebacker with excellent work ethic plus his Pro Day 40 (4.81) is a better reflection of his playing speed than his Combine 40 time. He projects as a reserve linebacker who makes his biggest contributions on special teams' player as he's undersized for an inside linebacker and he's not athletic or rangy enough to transition outside.

A team captain and former walk-on Austell is a redshirt senior and four year starter at FCS Charleston Southern who lined up at left tackle after moving from the defensive line to the offensive line in 2013. He doesn't have the length (32') arms to play on the outside and his frame raises concerns about his ability to transition to offensive guard in the NL. However, he has the smarts, work ethic and enough size to develop into an effective center in time. He projects as a late round pick or rookie free agent who could make a practice squad with that in mind.

A three-year starter and redshirt senior, Stewart put up good new numbers at Baylor finishing his career with 261 tackles, 12 interceptions and 15 pass deflections yet he projects as a fringe draft pick who is going to have a tough time making an active roster. He's an undersized safety with average speed and his tackling is a concern both in terms of run support and special teams. There are also a couple of red flags. He underwent shoulder surgery in 2015 and he missed two games with a hamstring injury that year plus Baylor suspended him for the 2015 season opener.

Conrad 'you-crow-pee-nuh' is a former walk-on who was awarded a scholarship in the 2015 season. He has a soccer background in high school and comes with above-average leg strength (Career long 52 yards) and accuracy (82% career FG conversion rate). Worked hard on his craft to overcome early struggles in his career. Projects as late round pick that has a chance to develop into a serviceable NFL place kicker.  April 5, 2017

Thomas started 30 games at Connecticut and had his best season as a senior finishing with 100 catches for 1,179 yards and three touchdowns. The son of his high school coach, he's got the smarts and enough natural ability to develop into a sub-package receiver plus he has experience covering kicks. However, he doesn't project as a top 3 receiver in the NFL, he didn't return kicks at Connecticut and he'll need to make a substantial impact covering kicks to make an NFL roster.

Vogel transferred from Florida to Miami in 2014, when he averaged 42.8 yards on 52 punts with 21 landing inside the opponents' 20-yard line. In 2015 he averaged 42.5 yards on 67 punts with 210 landing inside the opponents' 20. And in 2016 he averaged 43.8 yards on 64 punts with 25 landing inside the opponents' 20. Vogel grades out as a late-round prospect. -April 15, 2017

Williams is an instinctive change of pace back who is one of the elusive runners in this class. Made big strides with discipline in between the tackles (See vision/patience) his final 2 seasons under new OC/RB Coach Eddie Gran. Needs to become more consistent in the passing game and comes with some ball security issues. Dealt with a right elbow injury late in the 2015 season and had offseason surgery. Maturity issues early in career but grew up late in career. Projects as a mid-to-late day three pick that has a chance to outperform his draft slot.  March 23, 2017

Whitfield is a small but quick and fast slot receiver with some upside as a return specialist. While undersized, he's been durable (played all 53 games during four seasons at FSU, including 11 starts the last two years). However, his production dipped as a receiver in 2016 (34-395-11.6-1) compared to 2015 (57-798-14.0-16), and he averaged nearly four fewer yards per KOR last season compared to his first three seasons. Whitfield grades out as a late-round prospect and will likely have to prove capable of handling return duties in order to make a team's 53-man roster. March 21, 2017

Sterns has started in all 38 games he appeared in over the past three seasons while leading the team in tackles in each of those seasons (325 career tackles). Finished 2016 with 101 tackles while adding 5 PBUs and 3 INTs. Sterns is an undersized but aggressive safety who has some limitations and can play with better eye discipline in coverage. Also brings added value as a non-returner on special teams. Outstanding work ethic and football character. Projects as a late round developmental prospect. -- April 3, 2017

Good sized punter with average leg strength and very good accuracy. Two-year starter at Arkansas, averaging 43.4 yards per punt. Quarterback in high school and also played basketball and soccer. Earned a scholarship after the 2015 regular season, his first as the team's starting punter. Baker could be a late-round pick or a priority free agent. -April 14, 2017

A true senior and two-year starter, Morgan led Arkansas in receptions each of the past two seasons and 88 of his 138 career receptions resulted in first downs. He's a tough slot receiver with experience returning kicks and his work ethic won't be the reason if he doesn't make in the NFL but his frame, marginal burst and prohibitive top-end speed will be tough to overcome.

Pankey is a three year starter (36 total starts) who has lined up at LOG and LOT throughout his career. Lined up at LOT but projects as an OG in the NFL due to lack of lateral quickness and flexibility in his lower half. Missed four games as redshirt freshman in 2013 after having off-season knee surgery. Needs to develop more of sense of urgency with his game and develop better preparation habits. Projects as a late round developmental prospect who has a chance to add depth on the interior of front line.  March 17, 2017

Robinette led Air Force in receiving yards each of the past four seasons and averaged 22.5 yards per catch over the course of his career. He's a big-bodied receiver with good length (32 3/8' arms) and the potential to develop into an effective sub-package receiver that lines up in the slot and out wide. However, there are concerns about the run-heavy attack he played in at Air Force as he benefitted from teams loading up against the run and doesn't run a complete route tree. In addition, his 40 time is a red flag for receivers and he doesn't project as the big-play threat he was in college. Robinette is a big target, but he faces a steep learning curve transitioning to a pro-style offense. While he averaged 22.5 yards per catch at Air Force, he has marginal top-end speed and isn't expected to stretch the field in the NFL like he did in college. -- Steve Muench

Jones missed part of his senior season with a broken arm. He can become more consistent as a tackler and has some tightness that will limit him in certain man-to-man coverage situations, but he has adequate size and excellent straight-line speed. He also has playmaking instincts and very good ball skills. Jones has good football character and the right mindset to make a roster on his special teams contributions. Grades out as a late-round prospect. -April 10, 2017

Brown has the frame and tenacity to develop into an effective reserve. There are two red flags though. Either could cause teams to take him off their boards. The first is his medical. Doctors performed multiple surgeries and almost had to amputate after he injured his leg against Utah in 2014. He wasn't as explosive and missed three games with injuries when he returned in 2016. The second involves his character. He has a history of getting into fights with teammates and while authorities reportedly determined the woman was the aggressor he was involved in a domestic violence incident in 2015.

A redshirt senior and former walk-on, Brunskill started 34 games at San Diego State where he moved from the offensive line to tight end as a redshirt freshman and back to the offensive line where he lined up at right tackle as a senior. He also played center in high school and that's where he projects best in the NFL as he doesn't have the size or length to stay at tackle and he's not athletic enough to play tight end. He's got better length than undersized 2011 sixth round pick Eagles' center Jason Kelce but he weighs even less coming out of college and he's not as athletic.
Has a chance to surprise. Smart, powerful player with instincts as a pass rusher. Could be late-round/priority free agent diamond in the rough. -April 15, 2017

A three-time team captain Leidner (LIDE-ner) checks five of Bill Parcells' boxes for drafting a quarterback. He's a senior, he's a three-year starter who started 41 games, he won 24 games as a starter and he's graduated. The two boxes he failed to check are significant though. He finished with a 9:8 touchdown-to-interception ratio and threw eight touchdowns compared to 12 interceptions as a senior plus his 56.4 career completion percentage is a red flag. Add in pedestrian arm strength and a disappointing season in which he missed a game with a concussion and he is a fringe Day 3 pick.

Russell Wilson is the closest NFL comparison for Mayfield in our opinion, but there are still some obvious flaws in that comp. Mayfield is one of the most polarizing players in this class, in large part due to his outstanding football character and leadership but debatable maturity. In our opinion, Mayfield grades out as a good NFL starter but he clearly comes with some red flags (measureables, footwork, played in spread offense). When all said and done; Mayfield is a likely top-10 pick in the 2018 NFL draft. Russell Wilson is the closest NFL comparison for Mayfield, but there are still some obvious flaws in that comp. Mayfield is one of the most polarizing players in this class, in large part due to his outstanding football character and leadership but debatable maturity. Mayfield comes with some red flags (measurables, footwork, played in spread offense). The four first-round quarterbacks the Browns have drafted since 1999 had a combined 32-67 record in Cleveland. Sam Darnold would have been the safer pick to break that trend. However, Mayfield is our fourth-ranked QB, and there's not much that separates him from the two ranked ahead of him. Ultimately, general manager John Dorsey had to ignore the noise and take the QB who he feels fits his organization best. Mayfield faces a steep learning curve adjusting to a pro-style offense, but should benefit from playing behind Tyrod Taylor until he's ready to start. -- Steve Muench

Barkley is an explosive runner with a rare combination of size, speed, body control and competitiveness. He displays burst to turn the corner and run away from pursuit when he catches daylight. He has the lateral quickness to make defenders miss in the hole and on the second level. Barkley shows good vision and patience running between the tackles in addition to a good feel for cutback lanes and open field instincts. He takes care of the football. His career fumble percentage (0.5 percent) on offensive touches is excellent and he didn't fumble once despite 271 offensive touches in 2017.

He's not a bulldozer who pushes the pile in short yardage situations but he's a tough runner with the size, balance and strength to regularly pick up yards after contact. Barkley has above-average overall ball skills, and is a developing route runner with the burst to separate and big-play threat after the catch. He also has the size and toughness to quickly develop into an effective pass-blocker in the NFL.

The top prospect on our board, Barkley projects as a Day 1 every-down back with the elite talent and elite intangibles to become a franchise-changing player. He's gifted enough to earn emerge as an All-Pro caliber player early in his career. Barkley carries the highest running back grade we've given since former Sooners great Adrian Peterson. As far as NFL comparisons go, Todd Gurley (Rams), Ezekiel Elliott (Cowboys) and Barry Sanders (former Lion) are all fair in their own right.

The top prospect on our board, Barkley projects as an every-down back with the elite talent and intangibles to become a franchise-changing player. He's gifted enough to emerge as an All-Pro caliber player early in his career. Barkley is our top-ranked prospect and fills a pressing need for the Giants, who ranked 26th in rushing yards per game and 22nd in rushing yards per carry in 2017. Look for Pat Shurmur and Mike Shula to maximize Barkley's rare natural ability. He should take some pressure off Eli Manning and free up their talented pass-catchers by forcing defenses to respect the run. He'll make an immediate impact as a receiver and blocker, too. -- Steve Muench

Darnold couldn't have possibly lived up to the hype entering the 2017 season, especially when losing three offensive linemen to the NFL and both starting wideouts (including JuJu Smith-Schuster). There's no question that he developed some bad habits with his footwork (lazy/sloppy with lower-body at times) and ball security (dangling ball with one hand when moving in the pocket), but both are correctable.

The bottom line is that Darnold is the most complete quarterback in the 2018 class and he has the type of makeup that most good NFL starters possess. Darnold grades out as a high-level NFL starting quarterback and he projects to be a top-five pick.

There's no question Darnold developed some bad habits with his footwork (lazy/sloppy with his lower body at times) and ball security (dangling ball with one hand when moving in the pocket), but those issues are correctable. The bottom line is, Darnold is the most complete quarterback in this class, and he has the type of makeup that most good NFL starters possess. The Jets have a lot of quarterbacks, but a franchise that's ranked 31st in passer rating (74.9), completion percentage (57.2) and interceptions (162) traded up and ended up with the best QB in this class. Darnold needs to cut down on the turnovers -- he turned the ball over 36 times (22 INTs and 14 lost fumbles) in 24 games at USC -- but new offensive coordinator Jeremy Bates is a former quarterback coach, and playing behind Josh McCown will help. -- Steve Muench

Ward was a three-year player and one-year starter at Ohio State. He is on the smaller side but is physical with an elite combination of quickness, hip-fluidity and closing burst. He is instinctive and aggressive in man-to-man coverage and has the ball skills to take it away. He should emerge as a top-level man-to-man cover corner in the NFL and could be a top-10 pick. Ward is on the smaller side but is physical with an elite combination of quickness, hip fluidity and closing burst. He is instinctive and aggressive in man-to-man coverage and has the ball skills to take it away. It's tough to justify passing on Bradley Chubb from a value standpoint, but the Browns allowed a league-worst 68.6 completion percentage in 2017, and they've addressed their top two needs with their first two picks. Ward is the best corner in this class, projects as a Day 1 starter and is a good fit for defensive coordinator Gregg Williams' scheme. -- Steve Muench

Chubb has a prototypical build, plays a lot of snaps, has some experience in coverage and compares to Terrell Suggs (Ravens).He grades out as a high-impact NFL edge defender and projects as a top-10 pick. He plays a premium position and is one of the best all-around football players in the 2018class. Chubb has a prototypical build, plays a lot of snaps, has some experience in coverage and compares favorably to Ravens pass-rusher Terrell Suggs. He grades out as a high-impact NFL edge defender and is one of the best all-around players in this class. We didn't identify edge defender as one of the Broncos' top three needs, but Denver finished 22nd in sacks in 2017 and Shane Ray is coming off a disappointing season. Chubb will be an excellent complement to Von Miller, and improving the pass rush should help a secondary that made Aqib Talib a cap casualty. -- Steve Muench

Nelson became the third offensive lineman in 97 seasons of Notre Dame postseason awards to take home the team's MVP following the 2017 season. He is a road grader who excels at getting into defenders and moving them off the ball. He anchors well and his wide frame and strong hands tend to mask his athletic limitations when he's forced to mirror. Nelson is one of the best guard prospects in recent history and he grades out as a Day 1 starter. He projects as a top-10 pick. Nelson is a road grader who excels at getting into defenders and moving them off the ball. He anchors well, and his wide frame and strong hands tend to mask his athletic limitations when he's forced to mirror. Nelson is one of the best guard prospects in recent history. The Colts allowed the most sacks in the NFL (56) in 2017, and quarterback Andrew Luck missed the entire season with a shoulder injury. They also averaged 3.7 yards per rush (28th in the league), so adding the top offensive lineman in the draft makes complete sense. Nelson is a day one starter with the potential to develop into a perennial All-Pro. -- Steve Muench

Coming out of high school, Allen did not have a single Division 1 scholarship offer. He was a 6-4, 185-pound high school senior. In 2014, Allen started for Reedley College as a freshman until later transferring to play for Wyoming. As a two-year starter at Wyoming (25 starts), Allen completed just 56.1 percent of his throws with a 2.1-1 TD-to-INT ratio. He also rushed for 728 yards on 234 carries with 12 TDs.

Allen has elite arm strength and his accuracy is good when his feet are set properly. Also has better-than-average accuracy when on the move. Allen is one of the most physically gifted quarterbacks to come out of college in the last five years. His ceiling is incredible but so too is his bust potential. The team/situation he's drafted into will be far more important to his success than his draft slot.

Allen has elite arm strength, and his accuracy is good when his feet are set properly. He also has better-than-average accuracy when on the move. Allen is one of the most physically gifted quarterbacks to come out of college in the last five years. His ceiling is incredible, but so is his bust potential. The Bills signed former Bengals backup AJ McCarron to a two-year deal, which will buy them time to work on Allen's accuracy and ability to process coverages quickly. Allen's rare arm strength makes him a good fit for the Bills, who have hit a home run if they're able to help Allen reach his considerable potential. -- Steve Muench

Smith is an undersized (6-1, 236) linebacker with excellent instincts, athleticism and tackling skills. He takes good angles and shows outstanding closing burst to the ball carrier. In addition to getting a plug-and-play starting weakside linebacker, the team that drafts Smith in Round 1 gets a player with excellent work habits, football character and leadership. Smith is an undersized linebacker with excellent instincts, athleticism and tackling skills. He takes good angles and shows outstanding closing burst to the ball carrier. Smith has excellent work habits, football character and leadership. The versatile Smith will likely line up at inside linebacker in coordinator Vic Fangio's 3-4 defense. Danny Trevathan has a high cap number, and while Nick Kwiatkoski could start next to him following the release of Jerrell Freeman, the Bears were looking to add speed and athleticism. Smith provides both and is an excellent value. -- Steve Muench

McGlinchey, who started 24 games at left tackle over the past two seasons, is an alpha leader and there's a lot to like about his blend of smarts and effort. He has a quick set, above-average length and enough athletic ability and balance to mirror. However, he gives too much ground to speed-to-power rushers at times. McGlinchey grades out as a starting right tackle who can fill in at left tackle in a pinch. He projects as a top three tackle in this class and a first-round pick. McGlinchey is an alpha leader, and there's a lot to like about his blend of smarts and effort. He has a quick set, above-average length and enough athletic ability and balance to mirror. However, he gives too much ground to speed-to-power rushers at times. McGlinchey grades out as a starting right tackle who can fill in at left tackle in a pinch. McGlinchey is our top tackle, but ninth overall was a little early to draft him, especially considering that the 49ers have more pressing needs. Left tackle Joe Staley turns 34 in August and right tackle Trent Brown is coming off season-ending shoulder surgery, so making sure they give quarterback Jimmy Garoppolo sound protection is critical. -- Steve Muench

Rosen was a top recruit coming out of St. John Bosco High School, enrolled early at UCLA and became the first true freshman quarterback to start a season-opener in school history. When Jedd Fisch was hired as offensive coordinator prior to the 2017 season he became Rosen's third different offensive coordinator in three years.

For his career, Rosen started 30 games with a 17-13 record, he completed 61 percent of his attempts and finished with a TD-to-INT ration of 2.3-1. He suffered two season ending injuries - one to his throwing shoulder in Week 6 of 2016, which required surgery, and he also suffered two concussions in 2017 (keeping him out of one regular season game and the bowl game).

Rosen is the best pocket passer in the 2018 draft and is NFL ready. Accuracy, touch and timing are his best traits. Throws from a balanced base. Gets the ball out on time. He lacks ideal mobility and turnovers have been an issue (26 INTs and seven fumbles lost in 30 starts), but the reality is that Rosen carries an elite grade based solely on his tape. If a quarterback-needy team at the top of the draft passes on Rosen it will have everything to do with concerns regarding his durability and "football character."

Rosen is the best pocket passer in the draft and is NFL-ready. Accuracy, touch and timing are his best traits. He lacks ideal mobility, and turnovers have been an issue, but the reality is that Rosen carries an elite grade based solely on his tape. Arizona needs a young quarterback considering Sam Bradford's injury history and Mike Glennon's inability to hold on to a starting job. Rosen was the top quarterback on the board, and he's a good fit for offensive coordinator Mike McCoy, who will adjust his scheme to maximize Rosen's strengths when the time comes for Rosen to take over. -- Steve Muench

Fitzpatrick is an active run stopper who has an NFL build, closes well and plays with an edge. He's at his best lining up over the slot and playing close to the line of scrimmage. While he intercepted just one pass in 2017, he's a difference maker who picked off eight passes and returned four of them for touchdowns in his first two seasons at Alabama. He also finished third on the team with 60 tackles in 2017, including 8.0 TFLs and eight passes broken up.

He grades out as a high-level starter in the NFL and should win a starting job as a rookie. Expect Fitzpatrick to be a top-10 pick in the 2018 NFL draft.

Fitzpatrick is an active run-stopper who has an NFL build, closes well and plays with an edge. He's at his best lining up over the slot and playing close to the line of scrimmage. Fitzpatrick grades out as a high-level starter in the NFL. Defensive coordinator Matt Burke gets a versatile playmaker in Fitzpatrick. Taking a safety at No. 11 is an indication that the Dolphins could be moving on from T.J. McDonald, and pairing Fitzpatrick with Reshad Jones should give them an excellent safety tandem. Our only knock here is that Derwin James would have been a slightly better pick. -- Steve Muench

Vea totaled 12 TFL and 8.5 sacks the past two seasons. A wide bodied DT with tree trunks for legs and country strong, he can hold his ground against double teams. He runs extremely well for his size and compares to Haloti Ngata (Eagles). There's no denying Vea's uniquely impressive skills. He's a dominant run defender and can be a disruptive pass-rusher because of his quickness, power and awareness. If you feel good about his weight, self-discipline and conditioning he's worth a first-round pick. A wide-bodied tackle with tree trunks for legs, Vea can hold his ground against double-teams. He runs extremely well for his size and compares to new Eagles DT Haloti Ngata. There's no denying Vea's uniquely impressive skills. He's a dominant run defender and can be a disruptive pass-rusher because of his quickness, power and awareness. Vea is the perfect complement to disruptive three-technique Gerald McCoy. Vea has the ability to dominate when teams don't double him, which will make it tougher for offensive linemen to reach rangy inside linebacker Kwon Alexander. All of this should help improve a run defense that ranked 23rd in the league last season. He can also push the pocket as a pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

Payne started all 14 games in 2017 and finished with one TFL on his only sack of the season. He is an excellent run-stuffer who is tough to move off the ball and has the upper body strength to control blockers. However, he's a relatively one-dimensional defender who doesn't regularly generate pressure as a pass-rusher. Payne is an excellent run-stuffer who is tough to move off the ball. He has the upper body strength to control blockers. Payne, however, is a relatively one-dimensional defender who doesn't regularly generate pressure as a pass-rusher. No team gave up more rushing yards per game last season than Washington. With 2017 first-round pick and former Alabama teammate Jonathan Allen coming off a foot injury that forced him to miss most of his rookie campaign and Payne now in the fold, the Redskins should be stouter up front. Payne is also a better pass-rusher than his sack numbers would suggest. -- Steve Muench

Davenport has outstanding size and ran an elite 4.58-second 40-yard dash at the combine. He excels at working through contact, plays a ton of snaps and showed a strong motor late in games. He was in a two-point stance in UTSA's scheme, but should develop into a better player with his hand in the dirt in the NFL. He struggles in space and is definitely best suited to play 4-3 DE in the NFL. Multiple scouts have mentioned that Davenport suffers from anxiety issues and that he surprisingly lacks confidence for such a talented and accomplished player. He has enough initial power, shock in hands and explosive short-area burst to become an impact pass-rusher in NFL, but needs to improve his pad level. It might take some time to develop into an impact every-down player, but he has the raw ability and is likely a top-20 pick. Davenport has outstanding size and ran an elite 4.58-second 40-yard dash at the combine. He excels at working through contact, plays a ton of snaps and showed a strong motor late in games. He was in a two-point stance in UTSA's scheme but should develop into a better player with his hand in the dirt in the NFL. He struggles in space and is best suited to play 4-3 end. Cameron Jordan was a first-team All-Pro after posting 13 sacks last season, but Alex Okafor is coming off a season-ending Achilles injury, and the Saints could use another top-flight edge rusher. The Saints' defense made strides after drafting three defensive players with their first four picks in 2017, and adding Davenport puts them in position to continue to progress in the right direction. -- Steve Muench

Miller moved from right tackle in 2016 to the left side in 2017. He has excellent size -- long with adequate bulk and room to add. Occasionally he will be stressed by good speed off the edge and will give up ground initially against powerful rushers, but he almost always does a good job of resetting. He needs to improve lower-body strength and doesn't get much movement in the run game, but has good range as a second-level blocker. Miller has very good football character, takes to hard coaching and loves the game. He's a tall tackle with the potential to develop into an adequate, but not great, NFL starter who will likely come off the board in Round 2. Miller has excellent size; long with adequate bulk and room to add. He needs to improve lower-body strength and doesn't get much movement in the run game, but has good range as a second-level blocker. He also has very good football character, takes to hard coaching and loves the game. He's a tall tackle with the potential to develop into an adequate, but not great, NFL starter. This was a little early to draft Miller, but he has a great deal of upside and fills a need. Free-agent signing Breno Giacomini is an adequate stopgap at right tackle, but he's not the long-term answer. Plus, left tackle Donald Penn turns 35 in April and underwent foot surgery in December. Miller has experience playing on the right and left sides. -- Steve Muench

Edmunds started all 27 games over the past two seasons, recording 215 tackles, 32.5 tackles for loss and 10 sacks. He possesses a unique blend of length (34 ), height, weight and top-end speed. He's a powerful downhill striker with the instincts and burst to shoot gaps and blow up plays in the backfield. He has the potential to develop into a productive pass-rusher at the NFL level. He's 19 years old with one of if not the best toolbox in this class. He has excellent overall football character and a professional work ethic. Edmunds grades out a Day 1 starting linebacker and perennial pro bowl player. He projects as a top 10 pick. Edmunds possesses a unique blend of length, height, weight and top-end speed. He's a powerful downhill striker with the instincts and burst to shoot gaps and blow up plays in the backfield. He has the potential to develop into a productive pass-rusher at the NFL level. Edmunds is 19 years old with perhaps the best toolbox in this class. Linebacker is one of Buffalo's most pressing needs after Preston Brown, who led the league in tackles last year, left for Cincinnati. Edmunds is a rangy day one starter with rare upside, and coach Sean McDermott values speed at linebacker. No Bills player had more than four sacks in 2017, and the versatile Edmunds has the tools to develop into a productive pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

James missed the 2016 season because of a fractured foot and FSU suffered through a disappointing 2017 season, but he is an elite talent who is highly likely to have a better pro career than college one. His versatility makes him a perfect fit in today's matchup-centric NFL. James has great range versus the run, closes in a flash and explodes through ball carriers. He misses the occasional tackle but he has the athletic ability and length to make one-on-one plays in space.

In addition to his outstanding skill set, James is an alpha dog who will quickly become the defensive leader of the team that drafts him. James is a top-10 value in the 2018 class.

James has great range versus the run, closes in a flash and explodes through ball carriers. He misses the occasional tackle but has the athletic ability and length to make one-on-one plays in space. James is an elite talent who is highly likely to have a better pro career than college one. Tre Boston remains unsigned, creating a need at safety opposite Jahleel Addae who led the team with 96 tackles in 2017. Derwin James projects as a day one starter, and defensive coordinator Gus Bradley should be ecstatic the Charges landed a safety with this kind of talent and versatility. James is the eighth-ranked prospect on our board and the best overall player available. -- Steve Muench

Alexander's technique can be a little erratic -- gets caught lunging and off balance at times -- but he's smooth and fast enough to stay on receiver's hip in press-man when his footwork is sound. He projects as a starting cornerback in the NFL, and he can play on the perimeter and in the slot. Alexander is fluid with good speed, and he's instinctive and highly competitive. The downside is that durability is a legitimate concern for him, as he missed eight games in three seasons due to injury. He is an undersized (5-10, 196), physical cornerback. Alexander's technique can be a little erratic -- he gets caught lunging at times -- but he's smooth and fast enough to stay on receivers' hips in press-man when his footwork is sound. He projects as a starting cornerback in the NFL, and he can play on the perimeter and in the slot. Alexander is fluid with good speed, and he's instinctive and highly competitive. Durability is a legitimate concern, however. The Packers brought back Tramon Williams, but he's 35 years old, and they traded Damarious Randall to the Browns. Alexander is a playmaker whose ability to match up in man and make sound reads in zone will give new defensive coordinator Mike Pettine the freedom to mix up coverages and keep quarterbacks off balance. -- Steve Muench

Vander Esch, a former walk-on and one-year starter, is a sideline-to-sideline run defender with a rare combo of size, length (33 7/8' arms) and athletic ability. He needs to improve at getting off blocks but he has the instincts and initial quickness to beat blockers to the point of attack. He grades out as a starting inside linebacker who could develop into a Pro Bowler in time. Vander Esch, a former walk-on and one-year starter, is a sideline-to-sideline run defender with a rare combo of size, length (33 7/8-inch arms) and athletic ability. He needs to improve at getting off blocks, but he has the instincts and initial quickness to beat blockers to the point of attack and could develop into a Pro Bowler in time. Jaylon Smith made a remarkable return from a knee injury/nerve damage last season, but Sean Lee will be 32 in July and has missed at least five games in four of the past six years. Vander Esch is a reach at No. 19, especially with Alabama's Rashaan Evans still on the board. However, Vander Esch's range as a run defender and in coverage makes him a good fit for defensive coordinator Rod Marinelli's scheme. -- Steve Muench

Ragnow is a three-year starter with 19 starts at center and 14 at right guard. He's an alpha leader and captain with the work ethic and football I.Q. to quickly take control of an NFL huddle. He suffered a season-ending ankle injury during the 2017 Auburn game. Ragnow is an effective positional blocker who plays with an edge and grades out as a starter early in his career. His floor is a versatile interior backup. He's a top-five center in this class and projects as a Day 2 pick. Ragnow is an alpha leader and captain with the work ethic and football IQ to quickly take control of an NFL huddle. He is an effective positional blocker who plays with an edge and grades out as a starter early in his career. The Lions had the NFL's worst run game and tied for 24th with 47 sacks allowed. Plus, center Travis Swanson signed with Jets. There was some speculation that Graham Glasgow would move from guard to center this year, and Ragnow could play guard, though it's likely he takes over as the starting center. Either way the Lions have done a good job of addressing the interior offensive line. -- Steve Muench

Price is a two-time All-American, won the Rimington Trophy in 2017 and set school records for starts and consecutive starts (55). He moved from guard to center in 2017 and has experience at all three interior spots. There is much to like, but scouts have expressed concerns about his personality and ability to handle hard coaching. Price gets good initial push and flashes the ability to move defenders off the ball.
