The biggest area of concern is his length. His short arms (32 inches) hinder his ability to get his hands on defenders and he gets caught off balance lunging at times. Price grades out as a starting center with the feet, strength, toughness and intelligence to overcome his lack of ideal length. He projects as a top-40 pick.

Price has experience at all three interior spots. He gets good initial push and flashes the ability to move defenders off the ball. He grades out as a starting center with the feet, strength, toughness and intelligence to overcome his lack of ideal length (32-inch arms). Cincinnati needed to replace free-agent departure Russell Bodine and stabilize its offensive line. Iowa's James Daniels would have been the better pick, but the Bengals could have been concerned about his history of knee injuries. Price does project as an effective starting center early in his career. -- Steve Muench

Evans has made great strides since moving into a starting role late last year and he was a standout in both CFP games (versus Clemson and Georgia). He emerged as the leader of Alabama's defensive front seven in 2017 and it's obvious on tape that he loves the game. Light on his feet in coverage, he's versatile and strong against the run.

Evans grades out as a good NFL starter and is likely to be a top-40 pick in 2018.

Light on his feet in coverage, Evans is versatile and strong against the run. It's obvious on tape that he loves the game. Evans grades out as a good NFL starter. Tennessee had a vacancy at the inside linebacker spot next to Wesley Woodyard after Avery Williamson signed with Jets. The 14th-ranked player on our board, Evans is an excellent value at No. 22 and should make a smooth transition to defensive coordinator Dean Pees' 3-4 scheme. -- Steve Muench

Wynn, a durable three-year starter at left guard and tackle, stood out at this year's Senior Bowl despite dealing with a torn labrum. He had surgery in late-January and is expected to be ready for training camp. He was a shorter college left tackle who will likely move inside to guard in the NFL. As a guard, he's only slightly undersized and has average arm length. More importantly, he is a complete player with a high-level blend of agility, balance, power and technique. Wynn projects as a plug-and-play starter and should develop into a top-tier NFL guard. He is likely to be a top-50 pick if his medical reports check out. Wynn was a shorter college left tackle who will likely move inside to guard in the NFL. As a guard, he's only slightly undersized and has average arm length. More importantly, he is a complete player with a high-level blend of agility, balance, power and technique. Wynn projects as a plug-and-play starter and should develop into a top-tier NFL guard. The Patriots don't have a pressing need at guard, where Wynn has experience. But they do have a pressing need at tackle after losing Nate Solder to the Giants, and Wynn has experience lining up at left tackle. He doesn't have ideal length for a tackle, so it will be interesting to see where they play him. He projects as a starting guard if he doesn't pan out on the outside. -- Steve Muench

Moore was a three-year player at Maryland, where he racked up 146 catches for 2,027 yards and 17 TDs. Thickly built and strong, he is more fluid than twitchy. A savvy route-runner, he knows how to set up DBs in man-coverage and has a good feel for finding soft spots in zones. Moore is instinctive with good ball skills, body control and soft hands, and very competitive on contested catches. He excels at tracking the ball vertically, and though he lacks great top-end speed he accelerates quickly, frequently makes the first defender miss and is a strong runner. A humble, hard worker, Moore lacks great height but is tightly packed and is a tough competitor with very good football IQ and character. He grades out as a starting wideout in the NFL and is likely to be a second-round pick.

Moore is thickly built and strong and is more fluid than twitchy. A savvy route runner, he knows how to set up defensive backs in man-coverage and has a good feel for finding soft spots in zones. Moore excels at tracking the ball vertically, and though he lacks great top-end speed, he accelerates quickly. Moore lacks great height but is a tough competitor. Devin Funchess made strides last season, but no other returning receiver had more than 17 catches in 2017, and trade acquisition Torrey Smith is now on his third team in three seasons. Moore gives Cam Newton a much-needed weapon on the outside, and he has the ability to quickly develop into the Panthers' top receiver. -- Steve Muench

Hurst is a true junior who set South Carolina's single-season records for catches (48) and receiving yards (616) by a tight end in 2016. He caught 44 passes for 559 yards in 2017. He played baseball in the Pirates' organization before walking on at South Carolina in 2015 and will be a 25-year-old rookie.

South Carolina moved him all around the formation and he could develop into a matchup problem because of that versatility. He is fast enough to get down the seam and his deficiencies as a blocker have nothing to do with effort.

Hurst' is an F tight end with the skills to make an immediate impact as a receiver and develop into an adequate enough blocker to become an every-down player.

South Carolina moved Hurst around formations, and he could develop into a matchup problem because of that versatility. He is fast enough to get down the seam, and his deficiencies as a blocker have nothing to do with effort. Hurst has the skills to make an immediate impact as a receiver and develop into an adequate enough blocker to become an every-down player. The Ravens' top returning tight end, Nick Boyle, is a better blocker than receiver, and 33-year-old quarterback Joe Flacco ranked 32nd in the NFL in yards per pass attempt (5.7). Hurst has the top-end speed to stretch the middle of the field and does an above-average job of picking up yards after the catch. -- Steve Muench

Ridley played all 44 games (40 starts) in three seasons at Alabama, finishing with 224 catches for 2,781 yards and 19 TDs. He has average size but outstanding foot quickness and speed, and is a uniquely refined route-runner for a college wide receiver.

He drops his weight in a flash and is savvy with his stems and set-up moves. Ridley has good awareness in 'scramble drill' but needs to get stronger and is slow getting off press at times (choppy, wasted movement). He needs to involve his hands more and be more aggressive with DBs. Ridley plucks with his hands, is quick to transition upfield and frequently makes the first defender miss.

He has good acceleration, open-field vision and run skills and is a willing blocker. Ridley plays with an edge, grades out as the top wide receiver in the 2018 class and projects as a first-round pick.

Ridley has average size but outstanding foot quickness and speed, and he is a uniquely refined route-runner for a college receiver. He drops his weight in a flash and is savvy with his stems and setup moves. Ridley plucks with his hands, is quick to transition upfield and frequently makes the first defender miss. Atlanta had more pressing needs, but adding a receiver after Taylor Gabriel signed with Chicago made sense. Ridley is a good value at 26. He should make an immediate impact in the Falcons' three-receiver sets and make a passing attack that ranked eighth in the league last season that much tougher to defend. -- Steve Muench

Penny is a big back with deceptive burst and top-end speed who broke out in 2017 with 2,248 rushing yards and 23 TDs on 289 carries. He explodes to and through the hole, is quick to turn the corner and can pull away when he gets a seam (he clocked a 4.46-second 40 at the combine).

Penny tries to make too much happen at times, but shows above average vision and instincts. He runs with a narrow base, but has the balance, size and stiff-arm to pick up yards after contact.

A hard worker, he has above average hands and the potential to develop into a three-down back if he improves in pass protection. His 13 reps on the bench at the combine are concerns, but Penny has the tools to be a No. 1 back. He'll likely need time to develop as a route-runner and blocker, but should make an immediate impact on special teams.

Penny is a big back with deceptive burst and top-end speed who broke out in 2017 with 2,248 rushing yards and 23 TDs on 289 carries. He tries to make too much happen at times, but shows above average vision and instincts and has the tools to be a No. 1 back. Penny is the fifth-ranked running back on our board, so this is a reach. But he fills a pressing need for the Seahawks. No Seattle back rushed for more than 240 yards last season. His deficiencies as a pass-blocker are concerning considering the issues along the offensive line, but he's an above-average receiver who gives Russell Wilson another weapon. -- Steve Muench

Son of former Pro Bowl TE Ferrell Edmunds and brother of first-round LB prospect Trumaine Edmunds. He has an elite size-speed combination with long arms and big hands. He needs to improve his recognition skills, angles and ball location in order to push for a starting job at the next level, but should provide value on special teams. He's likely a pick early on Day 3. Edmunds has an elite size-speed combination with long arms and big hands. He needs to improve his recognition skills, angles and ball location in order to push for a starting job at the next level but should provide value on special teams. We had a Day 2 grade on Edmunds, as there are better safety options on the board. The decision to pass on Mike Hughes is also surprising, with Sean Davis returning at one safety spot and free-agent signing Morgan Burnett at the other. However, Davis underwent off-season shoulder surgery. They could play Davis in the slot, and we expected them to take a safety at some point. -- Steve Muench

Bryan broke out in 2017 with 6 TFL and 4 sacks in 11 starts. He has elite first-step quickness, outstanding short-area explosiveness and compares to Fletcher Cox (Eagles). He is scheme versatile, but we think he fits best as a three-technique in a 4-3 front. He's still developing his instincts and technique, so he might endure some early struggles, but if developed properly he can become a high-impact player and projects as a top-40 pick. Bryan has elite first-step quickness, outstanding short-area explosiveness and compares to Eagles tackle Fletcher Cox. He is scheme versatile, but he fits best as a three-technique in a 4-3 front. He's still developing his instincts and technique, so he might endure some early struggles. If developed properly, Bryan can become a high-impact player. Jacksonville already has the most expensive and arguably the best defensive line in the league, and the Jaguars finished second in scoring defense last season. If it's not broken, then don't fix it. Bryan is a good value at 29th overall, and his explosive get-off makes him a good fit for defensive coordinator Todd Walsh's scheme. -- Steve Muench

Hughes transferred to UCF prior to the 2017 season and started all 13 games. He's shorter than ideal but has very good top-end speed. He gets physical in coverage and can hold up versus bigger, taller WRs. He also could be a big-time difference-maker as a return specialist. Hughes grades out as a good starting NFL cornerback and projects as a first-round pick. Hughes is shorter than is ideal, but he has very good top-end speed. He gets physical in coverage and can hold up versus bigger wide receivers. He also could be a big-time difference-maker as a return specialist. Hughes grades out as a good starting NFL cornerback. The strength of this organization is a defense that finished first in scoring and total defense last year. Pro Bowler Xavier Rhodes is the only sure thing at corner, where Minnesota hasn't exercised the fifth-year option for Trae Waynes, and Terence Newman remains unsigned. Hughes is an excellent fit for defensive coordinator George Edwards' scheme and should push for the starting role opposite Rhodes. -- Steve Muench

An average-sized back, Michel was never a full-time starter in four years at Georgia, but grades out higher than teammate Nick Chubb. Michel reaches top-gear in a flash, hits the hole hard and can make sharp cuts without throttling down. He's not overpowering, but runs behind his pads and can be tough to bring down.

He makes a lot of defenders miss in the hole and his top-end speed (4.54 at combine) is good enough to pull away if he has an angle (he racked up 279 rushing yards and three TDs on just 25 carries in two postseason games this year). He has the potential to be a dangerous receiver, is a willing blocker and has improved his ball security.

The question is if he will be able to carry the load as a No. 1 back, because he's shown fatigue late in games when getting starter-like touches. He grades out as an impact starter and likely top-50 pick who probably will need to play in a regular rotation.

Michel reaches top-gear in a flash, hits the hole hard and can make sharp cuts without throttling down. He's not overpowering, but he runs behind his pads and can be tough to bring down. He has the potential to be a dangerous receiver, is a willing blocker and has improved his ball security. This is a surprise considering that the Patriots haven't taken a running back in the first round since Laurence Maroney in 2006 and they have good depth at the position. It makes sense from the standpoint that Dion Lewis signed with Tennessee and Michel has the kind of versatility that offensive coordinator Josh McDaniels values. -- Steve Muench

Jackson is a very difficult evaluation, as no player in college football the last two years has been more explosive with the ball in his hands. But he needs a lot of refinement as a passer -- specifically when it comes to his inconsistencies with progression reads, anticipation and ball placement. There's also legitimate concern about his potential durability given his slight frame (6-2, 216) and inevitable high volume of carries in the NFL. Jackson's willingness to accept a versatile role early in his NFL career could be an important factor in his early-career production.

Jackson's patience in the pocket improved, but there's still room for growth. He's slow through progressions at times and played in a "check with me" offense; only 8.4 percent of snaps in 2017 were from under center. Also worth noting that Louisville had a lot of pre-snap penalties on tapes we viewed.

Simply put; he's too dynamic not to find ways to get the ball in his hands, but he might not be refined enough as a passer right now to hand him the keys to an NFL offense as a rookie.

Jackson is too dynamic not to find ways to get the ball in his hands, but he might not be refined enough as a passer to hand him the keys to an NFL offense as a rookie. Joe Flacco has averaged 6.5 yards per attempt and has an 82.1 passer rating since winning Super Bowl XLVII. That ranks 40th and 36th, respectively, among 46 passers with at least 500 attempts. General manager Ozzie Newsome taking the Ravens' quarterback of the future in his last draft at the helm makes sense. -- Steve Muench

Corbett is a four-year starter and two time captain who played left tackle at Nevada but lined up at right tackle, guard and center the week of the Senior Bowl. He also worked on snapping after practice throughout the 2017 season. He flashes a powerful punch, but his length (33 3/8') is a red flag for offensive tackles and he occasionally gets beat to the inside on tape but he's tough to shake once he's locked on. He shows good awareness on tape and has the football smarts to play multiple positions in the NFL.Corbett projects as versatile reserve interior lineman with the skills and frame to develop into an effective starting guard or center. He could also provide depth at right tackle in a pinch and projects as a mid-round pick. Corbett flashes a powerful punch, but his length (33 3/8 inches) is a red flag for offensive tackles, and he occasionally gets beat to the inside on tape, but he's tough to shake once he's locked in. He shows good awareness and has the football smarts to play multiple positions in the NFL. The departure of longtime tackle Joe Thomas creates a depth issue on the offensive line in Cleveland, and Austin Corbett provides immediate depth and potential starting reps at multiple positions -- he started at both tackle and guard in college. He could play either, but is a better fit inside. -- Chris Sprow

Hernandez started 49 games at left guard and has a professional work ethic. He's a powerful drive blocker who seals off linebackers at the second level and is athletic enough to develop into an effective zone blocker. He gets set quickly, anchors well in pass pro and grades out as a Day 1 starting guard with the potential to develop into a pro bowler despite his shorter arms. He projects as a first-round pick. Hernandez is a powerful drive blocker who seals off linebackers at the second level and is athletic enough to develop into an effective zone blocker. He gets set quickly and anchors well in pass pro. He has the potential to develop into a Pro Bowler despite his shorter arms. Fixing the offensive line is one of new general manager Dave Gettleman's top priorities, and he lands the second-best guard in the draft at the top of Round 2. Hernandez is a day one starter who will create seams for running back Saquon Barkley and help keep Eli Manning upright. -- Steve Muench

Chubb started 40 of 47 games played during four seasons at Georgia. He carried the ball 758 times for 4,769 yards (6.3) and 44 TDs. Chubb sustained a season-ending left knee injury (tore three ligaments including PCL but did not tear ACL) against Tennessee in 2015. He was named a team captain in 2016 and worked hard to return from the injury.

Chubb projects as a two-down type of back who can wear down a defense if given enough carries. He has a very good blend of size, balance, strength and vision as a runner. He will never be a threat as a receiver but he has reliable hands underneath and he should develop into a good pass protector in the NFL. Chubb will likely hear his name called on Day 2 of the 2018 NFL draft.

Chubb projects as a two-down type of back who can wear down a defense if given enough carries. He has a very good blend of size, balance, strength and vision as a runner. Nick Chubb was a productive force at Georgia; he and first-round pick Sony Michel both played there from 2014 to 2017, yet the newly-minted Browns running back outpaced Michel 4,769 to 3,613 in rushing yards. The 227-pounder ran 4.52 seconds at the combine and creates an impressive trio alongside Carlos Hyde and Duke Johnson. -- Chris Sprow

Leonard is a sideline-to-sideline run defender who plays fast, tends to take sound pursuit angles and chases with excellent effort. He misses the occasional open-field tackle but he's an above-average overall tackler who plays with good body control in space and he flashes good stopping power when he's able to build up a head of steam. He's athletic enough to compete with backs and long enough to compete with tight ends in man coverage.

Leonard grades out as a weak- or strongside linebacker in a base four-man front who makes an immediate impact on special teams and earns a starting job early on in his career.

Leonard is a sideline-to-sideline run defender who plays fast, tends to take sound pursuit angles and chases with excellent effort. He's an above-average overall tackler who plays with good body control in space and grades out as a weak- or strongside linebacker in a base four-man front who makes an immediate impact on special teams and earns a starting job early on in his career. The Colts are going from a base 3-4 defense to a base 4-3 defense under new coordinator Matt Eberflus. They need outside linebackers who can hold up in space like Leonard to make a smooth transition. -- Steve Muench

Smith is a three-year starter at right guard with an elite combination of size, speed and strength. He's durable with an explosive first step and flashes initial power at the point of attack. An inconsistent finisher, he has some tightness, which leads to balance issues.In pass protection, he has good length, a powerful punch and is quick in his pass pro set. He's not much of a vocal leader, but has an excellent work ethic lives in the weight room and loves the game.Smith will be at his best in a zone-heavy scheme. He grades out as a backup early in his career, but has the tools to develop into a solid starter and projects as a third-round pick. Smith is a three-year starter at right guard with an elite combination of size, speed and strength. He's not much of a vocal leader, but has an excellent work ethic, lives in the weight room and loves the game. The Colts are making it clear that they believe the shortest path to Andrew Luck's sustained health is to let him turn around and hand off more often. They now possess two of the draft's most effective human bulldozers in Quenton Nelson (No. 6 overall) and Braden Smith. Smith is an experienced lineman likely to stick at guard. -- Chris Sprow

Jones, an explosive back with a leaner-than-ideal frame, finished with 591 carries for 3,619 yards and 39 TDs. He has outstanding initial burst and top-end speed that is a notch below elite (a slightly slower Jamaal Charles). He's not overpowering, but breaks a lot of arm tackles because of his burst and good contact balance. More physical in 2017, he hits the hole hard but has inconsistent vision and patience and a tendency to bounce wide too often.

He flashes the ability to pluck on the run, but was mostly used as an outlet in the passing game. There are no off-field incidents, but multiple scouts voiced concern about his 'diva' qualities. He's durable and leaves USC with plenty of tread on his tires (623 offensive touches in three years).

Jones might not hold up with as many touches as some elite NFL backs, but has some serious juice and grades out as an eventual starter. He projects as a top-50 pick.

Jones is an explosive back with a leaner-than-ideal frame. He has outstanding initial burst and top-end speed that is a notch below elite (a slightly slower Jamaal Charles). He breaks a lot of arm tackles because of his burst and good contact balance. He might not hold up with as many touches as some elite NFL backs, but has some serious juice and grades out as an eventual starter. The Buccaneers fill a pressing need. They released Doug Martin and were one of two teams that didn't have a player rush for 500-plus yards last season. Jones is raw when it comes to his ability to help out on third down, but he should give the ground game a much-needed boost. -- Steve Muench

Daniels is a true junior and two-year starter who doesn't turn 21 until September. He has a history of knee injuries and a somewhat leaner frame -- although he bulked up to 306 pounds at the combine and ran a ridiculous 4.40 short shuttle, which has been a drill that strongly correlates to NFL success. Daniels makes the line calls and is a smooth mover and technician whose initial quickness and athletic ability make him a good fit for zone-heavy schemes. He also has enough core strength to be an effective drive-blocker and flashes a nasty disposition. Daniels projects as a starting center early in his career and should at least provide interior depth as a rookie. If his medical checks out, he could be the first center drafted and is talented enough to develop into a player similar to Jason Kelce (Eagles). Daniels is talented enough to develop into a player similar to the Eagles' Jason Kelce. Daniels made the line calls at Iowa and is a smooth mover and technician whose initial quickness and athletic ability make him a good fit for zone-heavy schemes. Todd McShay calls him the best center in the draft. And after a season in which Mitchell Trubisky was sacked on 8.1 percent of his dropbacks and the Bears ran between the tackles at the third-lowest rate in the NFL, the interior of the O-line needed a talent injection. Will Daniels stay at center, or move to guard? In either case, Chicago could benefit. -- Chris Sprow

Sutton racked up 193 catches for 3,193 yards and 31 TDs over the past three seasons. He has excellent size, with a body type comparing to Tampa Bay's Mike Evans. Despite average speed, he has good body control for such a big target. Sutton has long arms and big, strong hands with a huge catching radius and the ability to box out cornerbacks and make contested catches.

However, he's an elementary route-runner who does a lot of dancing and has too many wasted steps when attempting to get off the line, and his production dipped significantly against good competition.

Sutton looks the part and has some highly intriguing traits, but if he is going to produce at the expected level of a late-first or second-round pick, he needs to improve his foot quickness and route-running skills.

Sutton has long arms and big, strong hands with a huge catching radius and the ability to box out cornerbacks and make contested catches. He looks the part and has some highly intriguing traits, but if he is going to produce at the expected level, he needs to improve his foot quickness and route-running skills. John Elway took the best available player in the first round with Bradley Chubb, and he fills one of the Broncos' top three needs with his first pick on Day 2. Demaryius Thomas and Emmanuel Sanders both failed to reach 1,000 yards in 2017, while Cody Latimer is now a Giant. -- Steve Muench

Landry was a four-year player and three-year starter who played in 45 games (29 starts) during his career at Boston College. Landry's best season was in 2016, when he led the nation with 16.5 sacks and seven forced fumbles.

Like Falcons DE/OLB Vic Beasley (No. 8 overall, 2015), Landry might need time to get stronger and expand his pass-rushing arsenal, but he's capable of making some impact as a sub-package pass rusher as a rookie. For the right 3-4 schemes or certain 4-3 schemes, Landry is capable of developing into a good three-down starter at OLB in the NFL in a couple years. His value is in the late-first to mid-second round range.

Landry might need time to get stronger and expand his pass-rushing arsenal, but he's capable of making an impact as a sub-package pass-rusher as a rookie. For the right 3-4 schemes or certain 4-3 schemes, Landry is capable of developing into a good three-down starter at OLB in the NFL in a couple years. The Titans were in desperate need of edge-rushing help, and with Landry, they get a player who piled up a whopping 16.5 sacks and 22.0 tackles for loss in 2016. Why was he available at No. 41? Because the 2017 version was a player who battled injuries and fell to 5.0 sacks. Mike Vrabel gets upside at a position he knows well. -- Chris Sprow

Gesicki holds the Penn State tight end career records for catches (129), receiving yards (1,481) and receiving TDs (15). He's not an alpha leader, but is a hard worker. A big target with long arms and big hands, he has outstanding ball skills and excels at high-pointing in jump-ball situations. Gesicki has enough speed to make plays down the seam and runs hard after the catch, but is not an elite big-play threat. He's a below average positional blocker who lacks the strength to be an effective in-line blocker at this point.

Gesicki projects as an F tight end with the tools to quickly develop into red zone weapon and matchup problem for defenses. He projects as a Day 2 pick.

Gesicki is a big target with long arms and big hands who excels at high-pointing in jump-ball situations. But he's a below average positional blocker who lacks the strength to be an effective in-line blocker at this point. Gesicki is an outstanding athlete, and he fills a pressing need. However, he's a marginal blocker. South Dakota State's Dallas Goedert is a more complete player and still on the board at 42. -- Steve Muench

Johnson missed the first three games in 2017 but still rushed for 1,391 yards and 18 TDs on 285 carries. He is an aggressive runner with very good acceleration who flashes the ability to lower his shoulder, but he's not overly powerful. He goes down too easily at times and his lack of contact balance is concerning.

Johnson has very good play speed and shows good patience, but his open-field elusiveness is underwhelming and he misses too many creases and cutback lanes.

His production was aided a bit by Auburn's scheme, but he grades out as a good change-of-pace backup who appears capable of returning kickoffs. He's likely to be drafted in the middle rounds.

Johnson is an aggressive runner with very good acceleration. Though his production was aided a bit by Auburn's scheme, he grades out as a good change-of-pace backup in the NFL who appears capable of returning kickoffs. Watch Kerryon Johnson and you'll see a bit of Le'Veon Bell, another former second-round pick. No, he is not Bell, but Johnson combines patience, lateral quickness and power when he picks his lane. Detroit is desperate for more consistency from its rushing attack, and Johnson will get his shot. -- Chris Sprow

Pettis is fast enough to stretch the field and he's got deceptive burst after the catch. There's room for improvement in terms of attention to detail and consistency but he's a smooth route runner with the quickness to separate. He attacks the ball with his hands and he flashes the ability to make some tough catches. Pettis grades out as a sub-package slot receiver who contributes as a punt returner early on and potentially develops into an effective No. 2 WR if he's able to fill out his frame and get stronger. Pettis is fast enough to stretch the field and grades out as a sub-package slot receiver who contributes early as a punt returner and potentially develops into an effective No. 2 if he can fill out his frame and get stronger. Marquise Goodwin and Trent Taylor flashed last year, but Pierre Garcon will be 32 and he missed the final eight games of the 2017 season with a neck injury. Pettis gives Jimmy Garoppolo a vertical threat with the speed to take the top off the coverage. At 6 feet, he also gives the 49ers some needed height at receiver. -- Steve Muench

Jackson is a playmaker with above-average ball skills and instincts. He has the strong work ethic to realize his potential. Jackson projects as a top-five corner in this class and good starter in the NFL. However, as a one-year starter he's still a work in progress and will need to make strides with his technique in order to pay dividends as a first-round pick. Jackson is a playmaker with above-average ball skills and instincts. He has the strong work ethic to realize his potential. As a one-year starter, however, Jackson is still a work in progress and will need to make strides with his technique in order to pay dividends. Double down at cornerback? Why not? The Packers allowed an NFL-high 21 passing touchdowns and an NFL-high 88 Total QBR on passes to wide receivers last season. After drafting Jaire Alexander in Round 1, the Packers land a corner most thought would also go on Day 1 with Jackson, who brings length and tremendous ball-hawking skills to the Green Bay secondary. -- Chris Sprow

Speaks moves well for his size and has the first-step quickness to develop into a disruptive interior pass-rusher. On the downside, he takes too long to get off some blocks as a run defender and he doesn't counter well enough rushing the passer. He grades out as a reserve end with the potential to develop into a starter. Speaks has the first-step quickness to become a disruptive interior player, but takes too long to get off some blocks and doesn't counter well enough as a pass-rusher. He grades out as a reserve end with the potential to develop into a starter. Speaks fits best at defensive end in the Chiefs' scheme based on our evaluation, and it will be interesting to see if they play him at outside linebacker where they have a bigger need. That said, the Chiefs need to improve a pass rush that has just 59 sacks over the past two seasons, and Speaks flashes upside as a pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

Over the past three seasons, Kirk caught 234 passes for 2,856 yards and 26 TDs, returned 48 kickoffs (for 1,048 yards and one TD) and 37 punts (for 814 yards and six TDs). He's a relentless worker and natural leader who by all accounts has elite intangibles. A tough slot receiver, he makes contested catches and isn't afraid to do the dirty work over the middle. He also has good open-field instincts and the speed to break away. However he's not an ankle-breaker in space and posted disappointing three-cone (7.09) and short shuttle (4.46) times at the combine. Kirk grades out as a good NFL slot receiver who has value in the return game. We think his value is on Day 2. Kirk is relentless worker and natural leader who, by all accounts, has elite intangibles. He's a tough slot receiver who makes contested catches and isn't afraid to do the dirty work over the middle. He also has good open-field instincts and the speed to break away. He grades out as a good NFL slot receiver who has value in the return game. The sands in the Larry Fitzgerald hourglass are falling slower than most thought. Fitz caught a ho-hum 109 (!) passes in 2017, but he also turns 35 before Week 1, and the depth behind him is light on upside. Kirk is an experienced, productive and smooth route runner with 4.47-second speed and should see the field quickly. So ... are those passes coming from Sam Bradford, or fellow rookie Josh Rosen? -- Chris Sprow

Nwosu has adequate-to-good initial burst, but great closing burst as a pass-rusher. He's a sudden player, with just average height. He'll likely be a sub-package contributor early in his career and it's possible he could develop into an every-down starter in the right situation. His best fit will be at SOLB in a base 3-4 scheme or SLB in a base 4-3 scheme. Nwosu has adequate-to-good initial burst, but great closing burst as a pass-rusher. He'll likely be a sub-package contributor early in his career, and it's possible he could develop into an every-down starter in the right situation. No Charger linebacker started more than 11 games in 2016, and Nwosu is an excellent fit for defensive coordinator Gus Bradley's scheme. Nwosu has the tools to develop into a starter and should make an immediate impact as a situational pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

Goedert was a four-year player and two-year starter at South Dakota State. He finished with 198 receptions, averaging 15.1 yards per catch with 21 TDs. He has an outstanding combination of size and speed with big, soft hands. A natural hands snatcher, he has a quick and savvy release off the line as an in-line tight end, and is a willing blocker.

An underrated prospect from a small school, he's a rare two-way tight end who should be an immediate contributor and an every-down player by Year 2. Goedert projects as a long-time starter who can play as a 'Y' (inline) or 'F' (detached). He's worth a late first-round pick in our opinion.

Goedert has an outstanding combination of size and speed, with big, soft hands. A natural hands snatcher, he has a quick and savvy release off the line as an in-line tight end and is a willing blocker. The Dakota Eagles! Philly landed a franchise-altering talent from North Dakota State 24 months ago (Carson Wentz). Now the Eagles go for a Zach Ertz clone out of South Dakota State. The Eagles led the NFL with 110 receptions by tight ends last season, but Brent Celek and Trey Burton are gone, and the 6-5, 256-pound Goedert could see targets early. -- Chris Sprow

Williams was a college left tackle who could possibly remain at tackle in the NFL, but short arms could force a move inside to guard or center. He shows good pre-snap awareness in pass pro where he recognizes and picks up stunts and blitzes. Williams grades out as a solid starter and he has the maturity and technique to challenge for a starting job immediately. He is likely to be a top-40 overall pick. Williams shows good pre-snap awareness in pass protection, during which he recognizes and picks up stunts and blitzes. He grades out as a solid starter and has the maturity and technique to challenge for a starting job immediately. The Cowboys might have taken a tight end had the Eagles not traded up to get Dallas Goedert, but it's no secret how much Dallas values talented offensive linemen, and Williams is an excellent value at 50. He could compete for the right tackle or left guard spot. -- Steve Muench

Miller broke Memphis' career receptions mark (238) and his own school single-season record for receiving yards (1,462) in 2017. Over the past two seasons he's caught 191 passes for 2.896 yards and 32 touchdowns. In 2017 he led the FBS in TD catches (18) and ranked second in yards after the catch. There's some tightness in his hips, but he's savvy with the quickness to get open and produce after the catch. He's also got enough speed to make the occasional play downfield.

Though he flashes the ability to make difficult catches, he bobbles and drops passes he should field clean. Ball security is a concern and he is on the smaller side, but he has the skills and toughness to develop into a productive sub-package receiver who primarily works out of the slot and potentially contributes on special teams.

Though Miller flashes the ability to make difficult catches, he bobbles and drops passes he should field cleanly. Ball security is a concern and he is on the smaller side, but he has the skills and toughness to develop into a productive sub-package receiver who primarily works out of the slot and potentially contributes on special teams. The Bears added wide receivers Allen Robinson and Taylor Gabriel in free agency, but Miller gives them some fresh, healthy legs at a position where they've been remarkably thin over the last two seasons. Miller put up huge totals at Memphis, with 191 catches over the past two seasons, and Mel Kiper had him ranked as the No. 3 wideout in this class. Mitchell Trubisky gets more help. -- Chris Sprow

Turay has the burst/bend to win with speed off the edge and is at his best rushing the passer, but is capable when dropping into coverage.He projects as a situational pass-rusher early in his career and has the potential to be more productive as a pro than he was in college, which is why he projects as an early Day 3 pick. He has a better chance of developing into an every-down 3-4 OLB (his college position) than an every-down RDE. Turay can win with speed off the edge and is at his best rushing the passer but is capable when dropping into coverage. He projects as a situational rusher early in his career with a better chance to become a starter at 3-4 OLB than RDE. A Colts defense that finished 31st in sacks with 25 and allowed a league-worst 8 yards per pass last season needs edge-rushers with the burst, athletic ability and closing speed to get after the quarterback. Taking Turay fills an important need with that in mind. -- Steve Muench

Stewart, a three-year starter at UNC, grades out highly in two very underrated traits at the cornerback position toughness and football intelligence. He is a scheme-versatile corner who is capable of pushing for playing time right away, likely in a nickelback role. He's an experienced and versatile football player but he might be better suited inside because he lacks ideal perimeter length and top-end speed. Stewart, a three-year starter at UNC, grades out highly in two very underrated traits at the cornerback position -- toughness and football intelligence. He is a scheme-versatile corner who is capable of pushing for playing time right away, likely in a nickelback role. The Bucs needed help in the secondary even before you consider that veteran Brent Grimes is almost 35 and could be in his last season. They broke up a league-low 38 passes and allowed 66.9 percent of passes to be completed, also a league-worst rate. Stewart offers versatility, experience and plenty of strength for the position, if not elite speed. He'll see the field early. -- Chris Sprow

Bates started all 24 games that he played during his two seasons at Wake Forest. He lacks size and will fail to finish occasionally as a tackler, but he's an instinctive and aggressive defender with very good cover skills. He can hold up in deep-zone coverage and is capable of matching up with most slot receivers. He is one of the top-five safeties and should be a top-50 pick. Bates is an instinctive and aggressive defender with very good cover skills, though he lacks size and will fail to finish occasionally as a tackler. He can hold up in deep-zone coverage and is capable of matching up with most slot receivers. He is one of the top five safeties in this class. The Bengals had just 14 takeaways, tied for second-fewest in the NFL in 2017, and their starting safeties combined for two interceptions. Plus Shawn Williams and George Iloka are physical, big-bodied safeties. Bates gives the Bengals a free safety with the instincts, cover skills and ball skills to develop into a playmaker. -- Steve Muench

Jackson spent the majority of snaps at nickel slot position, which is where he best projects in the NFL. His football character has been questioned by multiple NFL scouts and will likely affect his draft stock, but he has the athleticism and speed (4.32 was fastest 40 time of 2018 combine) to develop into a good starting NFL cornerback. Jackson spent the majority of snaps at nickel slot position, which is where he best projects. He has the athleticism and speed -- his 4.32 was fastest 40 time of 2018 combine -- to develop into a good starting NFL cornerback. The Panthers allowed 11 touchdowns to slot receivers last season, the second-worst in the NFL. Jackson figures to start his career in the slot, where elite twitchiness is useful and a slight frame could be less of an issue. Jackson is 5-11 and played at under 180 pounds at LSU, but the 4.32-second speed can be an eraser. -- Chris Sprow

Dawson is at his best when he can play press-man in the slot and when he can work in short areas. The more grass he's asked to cover, the less effective he becomes. Top-end speed is average on tape but he ran well at the combine (4.46). His below-average fluidity and measurables (height, arm length and top-end speed) put a limit on his NFL potential but he does grade out as a potential sub-package contributor. Dawson is at his best when he can play press-man in the slot and when he can work in short areas. His below-average fluidity and measurables (height, arm length and top-end speed) put a limit on his NFL potential, but he does grade out as a potential sub-package contributor. The Patriots signed Jason McCourty to compete for the starting spot vacated by Malcolm Butler opposite Stephon Gilmore. However, 2016 second-round pick Cyrus Jones has been a disappointment, and Dawson is at his best playing over the slot, so look for him to compete for the No. 3 role. -- Steve Muench

Hall arrived at Sam Houston State at 235 pounds in 2013 and has bulked up to 290-plus pounds. Put up a 38-inch vertical at pro day and was timed by some scouts in the 4.8-second range on his fastest 40-yard dash. Finished career with 86.5 TFL and 42 sacks to go along with 14 career blocked kicks, which is three shy of the FCS all-time record. Hall put up a 38-inch vertical at pro day and was timed by some scouts in the 4.8-second range on his fastest 40-yard dash. Finished his career with 86.5 TFL and 42 sacks to go along with 14 career blocked kicks, which is three shy of the FCS all-time record. The Raiders need to add depth on the interior of their defensive line, and Hall gives them a versatile defender who can be a disruptor against the run. Khalil Mack and Bruce Irvin get more chances for game-changing plays on third-and-8 if the run defense holds up. Hall can help. -- Chris Sprow

Oliver was a three-year player and one-year starter at Colorado. He possesses excellent arm length and above-average speed for his size, but he's still developing his instincts, technique and strength at cornerback. If developed properly, he should contribute as a sub-package corner early in his career before emerging as a solid perimeter starter. He's a likely Day 2 pick. Oliver has excellent arm length and above-average speed for his size, but he's still developing his instincts, technique and strength at cornerback. If developed properly, he should contribute as a sub-package corner early in his career before emerging as a solid perimeter starter. Corner isn't a pressing need, but this pick makes sense from a value and fit standpoint. Oliver's length, frame and ball skills make him an excellent fit for defensive coordinator Marquand Manuel's press-zone scheme. Oliver has the potential to develop into a starter early in his career. -- Steve Muench

Over the past two seasons Guice rushed 420 times for 2,638 yards and 26 TDs and caught 27 passes for 230 yards and three TDs. He was slowed by injuries in 2017 and needs to be pushed according to some scouts. Guice hasn't put up big numbers as a receiver and there's room for improvement in pass pro, but there's reason to be optimistic he'll develop into a three-down NFL back. His running style compares to Arian Foster's and he grades out as a No. 1 with the potential to develop into a pro-bowl caliber player if he progresses as expected in the passing game. Guice hasn't put up big numbers as a receiver and there's room for improvement in pass protection, but there's reason to be optimistic he'll develop into a three-down NFL back. His running style compares to Arian Foster. Guice needs to be pushed, according to some scouts. A 224-pound sledgehammer who takes some joy in running through contact, Guice can also run past you with his sub-4.5-second speed. He enters a Washington backfield that has volume but no clear No. 1 option. From a talent profile perspective, Guice has a chance to push his way to the top of the depth chart in 2018. -- Chris Sprow

Washington doesn't have a prototypical frame, he doesn't run a complete route tree and he drops some passes that he should catch. However, his long arms (33 1/2") ease concerns about his height and he flashes the ability to make some tough catches. He's built like a running back and turns into one after the catch. While he doesn't show an elite second gear, he's fast and athletic enough to threaten vertically and he's rarely caught from behind after the catch.

Washington may never develop into a starter on the outside but his potential to develop into an effective slot receiver makes him a Day 2 value.

Washington doesn't have a prototypical frame, doesn't run a complete route tree and drops some passes that he should catch, but his long arms (33 1/2 inches) ease concerns about his height. While he may never develop into a starter on the outside, he has potential to develop into an effective slot receiver. Pittsburgh traded Martavis Bryant to Oakland on Day 1 of the draft, plus Eli Rogers tore an ACL in the playoffs and remains unsigned. General manager Kevin Colbert hit a home run when he took JuJu Smith-Schuster with the 62nd pick last year, and adding Washington here should give the Steelers a formidable three-receiver set. -- Steve Muench

Chark caught 66 passes for 1,351 yards (20.5 per catch) and six TDs over the past two seasons and returned 18 punts for 190 yards and two TDs in 2017. LSU's run-heavy offense limited his opportunities, but he crushed the pre-draft process at the Senior Bowl and combine. His test results, including the 40-yard dash (4.34), were all outstanding, and it shows up on tape. He grades out as a big-play No. 2 receiver capable of immediate contributions as a sub-package WR and return man while he develops as a route-runner. We think Chark is worth a second-round pick. Chark crushed the pre-draft process at the Senior Bowl and combine. His test results, including the 40-yard dash (4.34), were all outstanding -- and it shows up on tape. He grades out as a big-play No. 2 receiver capable of immediate contributions as a sub-package WR and return man while he develops as a route-runner. The Jags lost a downfield threat in Allen Robinson in free agency, and while Chark doesn't offer Robinson's physicality and ability to win at the catch point, he has 4.34 speed and can take the top off the defense and keep safeties off the line. The Jags want to run the ball, and guys like Chark make defenders back up. -- Chris Sprow

O'Neill moved from tight end to right tackle in 2015, then played left tackle in 2017. He has the length (34 1/8' arms) to push speed rushers past the pocket and tends to recover well thanks to his balance. O'Neill is an athletic positon blocker who fits best in a zone-heavy scheme and doesn't generate much push in the run game. His frame, smarts and athletic ability make him an intriguing Day 2 prospect. He projects as a quality swing tackle early in his career, but must get stronger and upgrade his hand usage to become a reliable starter. O'Neill is a former tight end who has the length (34 1/8-inch arms) to push speed rushers past the pocket and tends to recover well thanks to his balance. He's an athletic position blocker who doesn't generate much push in the run game. He projects as a quality swing tackle early in his career, but must get stronger and upgrade his hand usage to become a reliable starter. Mike Remmers moved from right tackle to left guard in the playoffs, where he's a better fit. He can stay there with the addition of O'Neill, who has experience lining up at right tackle and left tackle. O'Neill is an excellent athlete, making him a good fit for new offensive coordinator John DeFilippo's zone-run concepts. -- Steve Muench

Davis played in 38 of 40 possible games during his three seasons at Auburn and finished with 25 starts at cornerback. A willing defender in run support, Davis has the size, length, speed and toughness to eventually develop into a starting NFL corner in a press-man heavy scheme. He projects as a Day 2 draft pick. Davis played in 38 of 40 possible games during his three seasons at Auburn and finished with 25 starts at cornerback. A willing defender in run support, Davis has the size, length, speed and toughness to eventually develop into a starting NFL corner in a press-man-heavy scheme. The Bucs are doubling down in the secondary on Day 2, and when you allowed an NFL-worst 4,169 passing yards last season and are aging in spots, that's not the worst idea. Davis has a long frame and arms and could become an effective man-to-man corner. The Bucs could use one. -- Chris Sprow

Lewis recorded 34 tackles-for-loss and 23 sacks over the past three seasons. He's a better run defender than pass-rusher, but makes an impact getting after the QB despite his athletic limitations. He wins with power and might start as a run specialist, but has the tools and toughness to develop into a starting LDE in a 4-3 scheme. He doesn't project as a double-digit sack guy, but helped his stock with a strong Senior Bowl and projects as a mid-round pick. Lewis is a better run defender than pass-rusher but makes an impact getting after the QB despite his athletic limitations. He wins with power and might start as a run specialist but has the tools and toughness to develop into a starting LDE in a 4-3 scheme. The Colts take their second 4-3 defensive end in 13 picks. Lewis isn't the same kind of explosive edge rusher as Rutgers DE Kemoko Turay, but he's stronger against the run, and the Colts' run defense finished 26th in the league last year. Plus, Lewis is an effective interior pass-rusher who the Colts can kick inside on passing downs. -- Steve Muench

Parker, a four-year starter at left tackle, blocks to the echo of the whistle and has shown the ability to bury defenders. But his inconsistency and technique are concerns. He grades out as a developmental prospect with a high ceiling and he could turn into an excellent value pick if he's able to reach his considerable potential. Parker, a four-year starter at left tackle, has the ability to bury defenders, but his inconsistency and technique are concerns. He's a developmental prospect with a high ceiling who could be an excellent value pick if he reaches his potential. The Raiders have a young QB to protect. Donald Penn is 35, and fellow rookie Kolton Miller could be asked to start at right tackle right away, so the addition of Parker is useful depth. Parker has the frame of a future left tackle but faces a huge leap in competition and will have to be more consistent. Tom Cable gets a raw talent to coach up. -- Chris Sprow

Carter is a long, lean and fast 3-4 OLB prospect who needs to bulk up and get stronger before he's capable of competing for a three-down starting job in the NFL. But early in his career he's capable of contributing as a sub-package pass-rusher and he can cover kicks on special teams. He has a terrific motor and excellent range versus the run. Carter could hear his name called on Day 2 of the draft. Carter has a terrific motor and excellent range versus the run. He's a long, lean and fast 3-4 OLB prospect who needs to bulk up and get stronger before he's capable of competing for a three-down starting job in the NFL, but is capable of contributing as a sub-package pass-rusher and can cover kicks on special teams early in his career. New coordinator James Bettcher is installing the 3-4 defense he ran in Arizona, and Olivier Vernon is the only proven edge rusher. Carter's frame, length and versatility make him a perfect fit for the scheme, plus he has the top-end speed to develop into a productive edge rusher. -- Steve Muench

Thomas is a three-year starter and 2017 captain who had 23.5 tackles for loss and 10 sacks over the past two seasons. He flashes some upside as an interior pass-rusher, but doesn't have the burst or lower-body flexibility to regularly win with speed. He's at is best playing end on run-heavy downs and kicking inside on pass-heavy downs. Thomas projects as a starting defensive end early in his career, but his deficiencies as a pass-rusher could drop him to late Day 2 or early Day 3. Thomas flashes some upside as an interior pass-rusher, but doesn't have the burst or lower-body flexibility to regularly win with speed. He projects as a starting defensive end early in his career, but has deficiencies as a pass-rusher. The Browns surprised a lot of people when they passed on the opportunity to draft Bradley Chubb at No. 4 overall, but Thomas gives them a rotational pass-rusher to mix in with Myles Garrett, Emmanuel Ogbah and Carl Nassib. Thomas piled up 26.0 tackles for loss in his final two seasons at The U. -- Chris Sprow

Reid grades out as a plug-and-play starter at free safety in the NFL. He's a ballhawk with excellent speed and athleticism, who has experience playing safety, nickel and cornerback. While he certainly can handle a versatile role in the NFL, we think he's at his best working as a centerfielder in a single-high safety look. Reid is one of the top five safeties in the 2018 class and should be a top-40 overall pick. Reid grades out as a plug-and-play starter at free safety. He's a ballhawk with excellent speed and athleticism, who has experience playing safety, nickel and cornerback. While he certainly can handle a versatile role in the NFL, we think he's at his best working as a center fielder in a single-high safety look. The Texans signed Tyrann Mathieu in free agency, and Andre Hal was their most productive defensive back last year, but Mathieu is in Houston on a one-year deal. Reid is the 39th-ranked player on our board and an excellent value pick at 68. -- Steve Muench

Stout, powerful and active one-gap defensive tackle or 4-3 nose tackle who excelsagainst the run and can occasionally force the QB off his spot as a straight-line power rusher. He grades out as a potential two-down NFL starter and likely will be drafted on Day 2. Stout, powerful and active one-gap defensive tackle or 4-3 nose tackle who excels against the run and can occasionally force the QB off his spot as a straight-line power rusher. Hill grades out as a potential two-down NFL starter. The Giants already have one double-team eater in Snacks Harrison, and Hill can provide some immediate insurance on the interior of the defensive line. Don't bother to run inside if you see those two on the field at the same time. -- Chris Sprow

Warner is a versatile player with above-average closing speed when he chases with effort and he covers a lot of ground in coverage. He is athletic enough to develop above-average man cover skills and has the active hands and change-of-direction skills to threaten off the edge as a pass-rusher. The greatest concern with him is he's a subpar tackler who frequently fails to wrap up. He grades out as nickel linebacker or safety who contributes on special teams. Warner has above-average closing speed, is athletic enough to develop above-average man cover skills and can threaten off the edge as a rusher. However, he's a subpar tackler who grades out as nickel LB or safety who contributes on special teams. Warner is a versatile linebacker who will likely compete for a starting spot on the outside, where Eli Harold is expected to become a designated pass-rusher, and Malcolm Smith missed the 2017 season with a pectoral muscle. Warner has the skill set to help a defense that ranked 30th in opponents' third-down percentage last season. -- Steve Muench

Freeman, the career rushing leader in the FBS, is a well-built and highly efficient back with very good vision and run instincts. He isn't overpowering but he has good contact balance and generates a comparatively high percentage of yards after contact. On the flipside, he has just decent agility/acceleration and he's very average in the passing game. Also a sizeable concern is the unusually high workload that he carried while at Oregon. Freeman grades out as a rotational backup tailback in the NFL and will likely be selected later on Day 2. Freeman, the career rushing leader in the FBS, is a well-built and highly efficient back with very good vision and run instincts. He isn't overpowering, but he has good contact balance and generates a comparatively high percentage of yards after contact. Don't be surprised to see the wildly productive Freeman find his share of carries early on. His 230-pound frame gives the Broncos a heftier downhill dimension to pair with Devontae Booker. Freeman has a Pac-12 record 60 touchdown carries -- not to mention a whopping 5,621 yards -- and his 4.54-second speed in that frame is nothing fun to tackle on the second level. -- Chris Sprow

Shepherd is a hard-charger who flashes the ability to get off blocks quickly and is an above-average tackler with a good motor. But the level of competition he faced in Division II is a concern. He grades out as a reserve nose tackle with the potential to develop into an above-average starter which is why he projects as a Day 2 pick. Shepherd is a hard-charger who flashes the ability to get off blocks quickly and is an above-average tackler with a good motor. But the level of competition he faced in Division II is a concern. The Jets have a need along the defensive line following the departures of Muhammad Wilkerson and Kony Ealy. Plus, they could upgrade over 32-year old Steve McLendon. Shepherd is an outstanding run defender with the strength and size to help improve a run defense that finished 24th last season. -- Steve Muench

Baker is an undersized weakside LB prospect with very good athleticism and speed (ran 4.53 at combine). He's able to locate the ball quickly, closes in a flash and is a solid wrap-up tackler. A rangy run defender, he excels in man-to-man coverage. Baker projects as a three-down linebacker and could be a second-round pick. Baker is an undersized weakside LB prospect with very good athleticism and speed (ran 4.53 seconds at combine). He's able to locate the ball quickly, closes in a flash and is a solid wrap-up tackler. Baker, a rangy run defender who excels in man-to-man coverage, projects as a three-down linebacker. No team allowed more receptions by tight ends than the Dolphins did last season, and they allowed those catches at a clip above 70 percent. Baker can certainly run with tight ends given his 4.53-second speed in a lean frame for a linebacker, and he played with current Miami middle linebacker Raekwon McMillan in Columbus. Baker is also an immediate shoo-in on special teams. -- Chris Sprow

Christian started all 39 games at tackle during his three seasons and has experience lining up on both sides. He has the quick set and long arms to push speed rushers upfield. He's an easy mover who mirrors well and an athletic run-blocker who flashes the ability to move defenders off the ball. Christian grades out as an above average No. 3 swing tackle early in his career with the length, frame and feet to develop into an effective starting left tackle in a year or two. He fits best in a zone-heavy scheme. Christian has the quick set and long arms to push speed rushers upfield. He's an easy mover who mirrors well and an athletic run-blocker who flashes the ability to move defenders off the ball. He grades out as an above average No. 3 swing tackle early in his career with the length, frame and feet to develop into an effective starting left tackle in a year or two. The Redskins need depth at tackle, with left tackle Trent Williams hampered all last season by a knee injury before finally landing on injured reserve. Christian projects as an above-average swing tackle with the versatility to provide depth on both sides and has the potential to develop into a starter in time. -- Steve Muench

Nnadi, a three-year starter at FSU, is an outstanding run defender who is a much better football player than he is tester, but his poor combine workout hurt his stock.A one-dimensional run-stopper with limited upside, he is ready for the NFL but is never going to be more than a one-or-two down player.He compares to Brandon Mebane (Chargers) and projects as a mid-round pick. Nnadi, a three-year starter at FSU, is an outstanding run defender who is a much better football player than he is tester. A one-dimensional run-stopper with limited upside, he is ready for the NFL but is never going to be more than a one- or two-down player. The Chiefs have allowed 4.48 yards per rush between the tackles over the last two seasons, the third-worst rate in the NFL. Nnadi is a lot better in pads than he is in spandex and has the potential to work his way into the defensive interior rotation right away. His motor doesn't quit. -- Chris Sprow

Rudolph was a team captain, four-year player and three-year starter who led the FBS in passing yards (4,904 yards) in 2017. He works hard in the film and weight rooms but he's not an alpha and scouts have some concerns about his ability to take control of an NFL huddle/locker room.

Rudolph is an accurate short-to-intermediate passer with an NFL build and he's mastered Oklahoma State's offense. While he flashes above-average downfield touch, there are concerns about his ability to drive the ball downfield/into tight pockets and he appears to lack confidence in his arm strength at times. He holds onto the ball too long at times and he fumbled eight times over the past two seasons (26 games) losing six of those fumbles. Finally, he shows the ability to get through his progressions and flashes above-average anticipation but Oklahoma State's spread offense and play-action package creates big windows. He also had very good weapons at WR throughout his college career.

Rudolph grades out as a backup/fringe starter and is a likely Day 2 pick.

Rudolph was a team captain, four-year player and three-year starter who led the FBS in passing yards (4,904 yards) in 2017. He works hard in the film and weight rooms, but he's not an alpha, and scouts have some concerns about his ability to take control of an NFL huddle/locker room. The Steelers get the potential heir to 36-year-old Ben Roethlisberger. Rudolph is a good value at 76, and landing with the organization that drafted his college teammate, receiver James Washington, should help Rudolph make the transition to the NFL. -- Steve Muench

Jefferson has always been a better athlete and 'tester' than he is football player. He clearly has the physical tools to play linebacker in the NFL but he's never going to be an alpha dog and his key-and-diagnose skills need to improve. An above-average tackler, Jefferson needs to be used properly in a system that emphasizes aggressiveness over reading-and-reacting in order to emerge as a solid NFL starter. Jefferson clearly has the physical tools to play linebacker in the NFL, but he's never going to be an alpha dog, and his key-and-diagnose skills need to improve. An above-average tackler, Jefferson needs to be used properly in a system that emphasizes aggressiveness over reading-and-reacting in order to emerge as a solid NFL starter. Vontaze Burfict is still a force, but he's prone to injuries and suspension. Nick Vigil and Jordan Evans battled injuries and inconsistency last year. Jefferson has the talent to step in for Burfict while he's serving a four-game suspension to start the season, and then push for the starting job opposite Burfict when the suspension ends. -- Steve Muench

Green, who had 19 tackles for loss and 16 sacks over the past two seasons is long, athletic and naturally powerful in his upper body. His tape is inconsistent, but he has the potential to develop into an impact player similar to Cameron Jordan (Saints). Greene is still developing as a player, but there's no denying his raw talent potential. He might only contribute in sub packages as a rookie, but he has the length, natural power and athleticism to develop into a highly productive starter in the NFL. He is also scheme versatile and projects as a Day 2 pick. Green is still developing as a player, but there's no denying his raw talent potential. He might only contribute in sub packages as a rookie, but he has the length, natural power and athleticism to develop into a highly productive starter in the NFL. Cliff Avril turned 32 earlier this month and played only four games in 2017. Pete Carroll gets a needed pass-rushing specialist (10.0 sacks last season) who could fit on the edge in Green, and from his old stomping grounds at USC. Green could play early in a rotation that includes a hopefully healthy Avril, Frank Clark and Dion Jordan. -- Chris Sprow

Rankin, who made 19 starts at left tackle the past two seasons, has good initial quickness and enough short-area agility to mirror-and-slide as an interior lineman in the NFL. The more space he's in the less effective he becomes, and he his arms (33 3/4 inches is a red flag at tackle) mean Rankin could be facing a position change.We've said since last summer that his best NFL position might be at center. He practiced there in 2017 spring ball and also has practice experience at both tackle spots. Rankin was a college left tackle that might need to convert inside to guard or center in the NFL. He grades out as an early-career backup who is capable of developing into a solid NFL starter and projects as a Day 2 pick. Rankin, who made 19 starts at left tackle the past two seasons, has good initial quickness and enough short-area agility to mirror-and-slide as an interior lineman in the NFL. The more space he is in, the less effective he becomes, and his arms (33 3/4 inches is a red flag at tackle) mean Rankin might have to move inside to guard or center in the NFL. The Texans have a pressing need at tackle, where they could play Rankin, as he started 19 games at left tackle over the past two seasons. However, he doesn't have ideal length for a tackle and projects better on the inside. -- Steve Muench

Gallup caught 176 passes for 2,685 yards and 21 TDs in two seasons with the Rams after transferring from a Kansas community college. He set Colorado State's single-season record for receptions (100) in 2017 and is the only Ram to catch three or more TD passes three times.

He's a zone-buster who lacks the second gear to run past cornerbacks and pull away from pursuit, but his above average playing speed makes him a vertical threat and dangerous when he gets a seam. His hands are a touch inconsistent, but he flashes the ability to pluck and make contested catches.

Gallup projects as a sub-package receiver with the potential to develop into an effective No. 2 if the testing matches the tape.

Gallup caught 176 passes for 2,685 yards and 21 TDs in two seasons with the Rams after transferring from a Kansas community college. He's a zone-buster who lacks the second gear to run past cornerbacks and pull away from pursuit, but his above-average playing speed makes him a vertical threat and dangerous when he gets a seam. "Big D" stands for "Dicey" as it pertains to pass-catching options for the Cowboys. Not only is Dez Bryant gone, but Jason Witten was headed to the broadcasting booth as of Friday. Gallup could see immediate action as a target for Dak Prescott after a wildly productive, 100-catch season in 2017. This guy can destroy press coverage and get open and has decent wiggle after the catch. A possible Round 3 steal. -- Chris Sprow

Walker has an above-average blend of size, length (33.5-inch arms) and top-end speed for a safety. He has the range to cover a deep half and he's at is best in underneath zone. Walker grades out as reserve safety with some upside and the tools to develop into a core special teams' player but will need to show better discipline and awareness in coverage to play a substantial role on defense. He projects a Day 3 pick. Walker has an above-average blend of size, length and top-end speed for a safety with the range to cover a deep half. He is at is best in underneath zone and grades out as reserve with some upside and the tools to become a core player on special teams. Walker doesn't fill a pressing need as Glover Quin is entrenched at strong safety, and free safety Tavon Wilson re-signed for two years. It's also a little early to take Walker, who we have a fourth-round grade on, but there's a lot to like about his upside, and adding him improves the Lions' depth at safety. -- Steve Muench

Brown, a captain, is one of just three players to be named Big 12 Offensive Lineman of the Year multiple times (2016 and 2017). Heis a powerful run-blocker who engulfs defenders and moves them off the ball when his technique is sound, and his width and length make it tough for speed rushers to turn the corner. However, he had a historically bad combine, raising concerns about his ability to succeed in the NFL. He did perform better at his pro day, and the tape shows a potential starting right tackle in a power-based scheme, but some teams will take him off their draft board because there's never been a starting NFL tackle with such marginal testing results. He projects as a fringe Day 2 pick as a result. Brown is a powerful run-blocker who engulfs defenders and moves them off the ball when his technique is sound, and his width and length make it tough for speed rushers to turn the corner. However, he had a historically bad combine, raising concerns about his ability to succeed in the NFL. It's possible Brown goes a full round earlier if he simply managed to miss his flight to the NFL combine. No joke. His disastrous workout performance in Indy doesn't match up with tape that makes him look like a potential starting NFL right tackle ... and possibly soon. Brown's late father, Orlando, was a starting tackle for the Ravens, and his son has that potential. -- Chris Sprow

Jones shows the ability to walk interior offensive linemen back, but he's not an effective finisher as a pass-rusher. He grades out as a possible future NFL starter (at least a two-down player) and will fit best in a one-gap heavy scheme as a DT or 4-3 NT. He should come off the board on Day 2. Jones shows the ability to walk interior offensive linemen back, but he's not an effective finisher as a pass-rusher. He grades out as a possible future starter (at least a two-down player) and fits best in a one-gap-heavy scheme as a DT or 4-3 NT. The Chargers continue to address a defense that finished 31st in rushing yards allowed per game and surrendered a league-worst 4.9 yards per carry in 2017. Jones is an above-average run-defender with the talent to fill in for Corey Liuget while he serves a four-game suspension, then push 33-year-old Brandon Mebane for the starting nose tackle job. -- Steve Muench

Gaulden is a tweener corner/safety who primarily lined up over the slot in Tennessee's scheme. He's at his best in off and zone coverage as he has above-average route recognition and he limits production after the catch. A better football player than athlete, he grades out as a reserve defensive back. Gaulden is a corner/safety tweener who primarily lined up over the slot in college. He's at his best in off and zone coverage as he has above-average route recognition and limits production after the catch. A better player than athlete, he grades out as a reserve. Cornerback Daryl Worley and safety Kurt Coleman have departed from the Carolina secondary, and the Panthers added cornerback Donte Jackson and now a safety in Gaulden on Day 2. The performance on the field looks better than the 40 time (4.61 seconds) for Gaulden, which gives him some steal potential in this range. He'll compete to play early. -- Chris Sprow

Diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes at age 9, Andrews (112 catches for 1,765 yards) is Oklahoma's all-time leader in receiving yards by a tight end and he caught a least seven touchdowns (22 total) in each of his three seasons. He does a good job of locating soft spots in zones and his size makes him a mismatch for defensive backs when he flexes out.

Andrews is an F prospect who has the potential to develop into an effective No. 2 but needs to get stronger and improve his consistency, which is why he projects as an early Day 3 pick at this point.

Andrews does a good job of locating soft spots in zones, and his size makes him a mismatch for defensive backs when he flexes out. He has the potential to develop into an effective No. 2, but needs to get stronger and more consistent. It's not a surprise that the Ravens have drafted two tight ends with the tools to make plays in the passing game after Ben Watson signed with the Saints. Top returning tight end Nick Boyle is a better blocker than receiver, and they finished last season with the 29th-ranked passing attack. -- Steve Muench

There's no denying Key's natural talent. He broke LSU's single-season sack record with 12 in 2016 and has a similar build and athleticism to a young Jason Taylor. Though he has an exceptionally high ceiling,he is still very much a risk-reward prospect. He needs to add bulk and more power to his game, and he needs to go to a team that can provide him good structure. Though Key has an exceptionally high ceiling, he is still very much a risk-reward prospect. He needs to add bulk and more power to his game, and he needs to go to a team that can provide him good structure. If it was only about natural talent, Key could be in the Round 1 tier of former No. 5 overall pick and now Raiders superstar teammate Khalil Mack. It's no exaggeration. Key has top-10 talent, but significant off-field concerns. If he prepares like Mack, Key could be an immediate rotational pass-rusher for the Raiders with double-digit sack potential. This is a developmental story that could partly define Jon Gruden's early days in Oakland. -- Chris Sprow

Burks tested well in the combine testing that best correlates with outside linebackers having success in the NFL, as his top-end speed, broad jump (10-foot, 11 inches) and three-cone time (6.82 second) are all outstanding; his short shuttle (4.15 seconds) is borderline outstanding. He has the potential to develop above-average cover skills and he has above-average ball skills for a linebacker.

Burks grades out as a backup outside linebacker with excellent upside but he will likely make his biggest contributions on special as he tries to carve out a role on special teams. He projects as an early Day 3 pick.

Burks tested very well at the combine; his top-end speed, broad jump (10 feet, 11 inches) and three-cone time (6.82 second) are all outstanding. He grades out as a backup outside linebacker with excellent upside, but he will likely make his biggest contributions on special teams. New general manager Brian Gutekunst is using his first draft to address a defense that finished 26th in points allowed per game last season. Burks is a good value pick at 88th overall, and he improves depth at inside linebacker where he fits best in the Packers' scheme. -- Steve Muench

Noteboom started 11 games at right tackle and 29 on the leftover his final three seasons. He's a finesse blocker with excellent length who shows good awareness, but occasionally will give up too much ground against powerful rushers. He plays too high, lacks strength and does not get consistent movement as run blocker. Noteboom has the size, length and enough mobility to compete for a starting job at tackle (or possibly guard) in the NFL, but it will likely need to be for a zone-heavy team. His lack of strength and nastiness will turn some teams off, and he projects as a Day 3 pick. Noteboom is a finesse blocker with excellent length and good awareness. He has the size and enough mobility to compete for a starting job at tackle or guard, but it will likely need to be for a zone-heavy team. His lack of strength and nastiness will turn some teams off. The Rams are a popular pick in the NFC West, but offensive line age (and health) will be worth watching. Andrew Whitworth is 36, Rodger Saffold will be 30 in Week 1, John Sullivan is 32 ... you get the idea. Noteboom offers immediate depth, but whether he ends up at tackle or guard is a question. -- Chris Sprow

Senat had his best season in 2017 with 10.5 TFL and six sacks. He's an active interior lineman who is a much better football player than tester and compares to Jovan Hargrave (Steelers). Senat grades out as a backup who should be able to contribute in a rotation. His best NFL fit is as a 4-3 nose tackle and he is a likely mid-round pick. Senat is an active interior lineman who is a much better football player than tester and compares to Javon Hargrave (Steelers). Senat's best fit is as a 4-3 nose tackle, and he grades out as a backup who should contribute in a rotation. Dontari Poe signed with division rival Carolina, and Ahtyba Rubin is an unsigned free agent, which creates a need at defensive tackle. Senat is a squat run defender with the potential to develop into an excellent complement to the explosive Grady Jarrett on the inside. -- Steve Muench

Smith is a three-year starter who caught 168 passes for 2,748 yards and 22 TDs at UCF. He uses his hands well to get off the line, uses his speed to drive defenders back creating space underneath, and appears to have a good feel for zone looks. He doesn't have an elite second gear and he's not an ankle-breaker in space, but he's fast enough to stretch the field and is a competitive runner.

There's a lot to like about his length and he flashes the ability to make tough catches. However, he drops the occasional pass. Smith projects as a sub-package slot receiver who needs to make strides as a route-runner to push for a top-3 role, but his frame, length and playing speed make him an intriguing developmental prospect.
