Smith doesn't have an elite second gear, but he's fast enough to stretch the field. He projects as a sub-package slot receiver who needs to make strides as a route runner. His frame, length and playing speed make him an intriguing developmental prospect. The Saints have a clear No. 1 wide receiver in Michael Thomas but could use some added help in the WR corps given how much they relied on the ageless burners of Ted Ginn in 2017. Cameron Meredith arrives, but so too does some young speed and length, as Smith offers sub-4.5-second speed and a 6-2 frame. He was productive from day one at Central Florida, and Drew Brees offers the opportunity for more. -- Chris Sprow

Okorafor grades out as a developmental project with starter traits. He has outstanding size, above-average strength and enough agility to develop into an NFL starter -- likely at RT -- but inconsistencies in his leverage/balance and hand use need to be cleaned up. It will be important for Okorafor's career that he lands on a team with a good technique teacher at the offensive line coach position. Okorafor is a likely Day 2 pick. Okorafor grades out as a developmental project with outstanding size, above-average strength and enough agility to become an NFL starter -- likely at RT. It's important that he lands with a good offensive line coach. Right tackle Marcus Gilbert missed 10 games due to injuries and a PED suspension in 2017, and swing tackle Chris Hubbard signed with the Browns. Okorafor steps into that No. 3 swing tackle role with the ability to provide depth at both tackle spots. He has the potential to develop into an effective starter at right tackle. -- Steve Muench

Harrison isn't much of a leader and will be best suited in an environment with strong veteran presences. He's a talented free safety with excellent size, good speed and above-average recognition skills. Harrison projects as a future NFL starter but he needs the right environment to succeed. It's likely that he is drafted at some point on Day 2. Harrison is a talented free safety with excellent size, good speed and above-average recognition skills. He projects as a future NFL starter with the right environment. Harrison comes from a defense defined by aggressiveness and swarming speed to the ball. Jacksonville will offer a lot of the comforts of Tuscaloosa in that regard, and Harrison's versatility (namely at either safety position) could get him on the field relatively early, even on an outstanding NFL defense. -- Chris Sprow

Cappa, a team leader and tone-setter with a professional work ethic, flashed enough to ease concerns about the level of competition he faced, but he had an up and down week at the Senior Bowl. He is a tenacious finisher who works hard in the film room and has above-average football intelligence. His arm length (33 1/8 inches) is a red flag when it comes to him playing on the outside in the NFL. He plays too high and leans at times as a run-blocker, and his initial hand placement is inconsistent in pass pro.

Cappa is a developmental interior prospect who ideally shows the ability to fill in at center and guard. He might never develop into a starter, but has the mental and physical toughness to become an above average backup.

Cappa is a developmental interior prospect who ideally shows the ability to fill in at center and guard. He might never develop into a starter but has the mental and physical toughness to become an above average backup. J.R. Sweezy and Ali Marpet are both coming off season-ending injuries, and Marpet is in a contract year. Tampa Bay is looking to improve a run game that finished 23rd in rushing last year. Cappa is a tenacious run-blocker with a nasty disposition. -- Steve Muench

Moore is a free safety with outstanding length (33 1/8-inch arms) and top-end speed. A one-year wonder with room to grow when it comes to his technique and reads, he's coming off a breakout senior season and has promise. Moore is a free safety with outstanding length (33 1/8-inch arms) and top-end speed. A one-year wonder with room to grow when it comes to his technique and reads, he's coming off a breakout senior season and has promise. If you can run 4.32 seconds at over 6 feet tall, the NFL will find you in Greenland ... the northern portion. Early on, Moore projects as depth at safety and regular special-teams duty, but if he shows in camp what he did in his final year in college, look out. NFL teams see third-rounders as reasonable bets to start, and Moore got that nod. -- Chris Sprow

Phillips racked up 26.5 TFL and 14 sacks the past two seasons. He's a highly disruptive run defender with elite intangibles who led the nation in tackles for a defensive lineman with 102. His position fit will be a concern for some teams and he grades out as a starting defensive lineman for teams that have a specific plan for him as a three-technique, 4-3 nose tackle or 3-4 defensive end -- or some combination of those. Phillips projects as a Day 2 pick. Phillips is a highly disruptive run defender with elite intangibles who led the nation in tackles for a defensive lineman with 102. He grades out as a starting defensive lineman if he's used as a three-technique, 4-3 nose tackle or 3-4 defensive end (or some combination). The Bills signed Star Lotulelei to start inside next to Adolphus Washington, and Kyle Williams signed a one-year deal. That said, Harrison is the 43rd-ranked player on our board, making him an outstanding value pick. -- Steve Muench

Cole's 51 consecutive starts broke Jon Jansen's record for a Michigan offensive lineman. A captain and leader, he has bounced between center and left tackle. He has good range, but has short arms (32 ') even for a center. He's clearly a better fit at center as he has some problems handling speed off the edge, but he doesn't have the strength to regularly move defensive tackles off the ball. Cole is smart, quick and big enough to develop into serviceable starting center with added strength. He projects as a versatile backup interior offensive lineman early in his career. A captain and leader, Cole has bounced between center and left tackle. He's clearly a better fit at center, as he has some problems handling speed off the edge, but he doesn't have the strength to regularly move defensive tackles off the ball. The Cardinals averaged 3.4 yards per rush between the tackles last season, 30th in the NFL, and only slightly down from 2016 (with a healthy David Johnson) when they averaged a meager 3.5 yards on such runs (29th). Enter Cole, a remarkably rare freshman starter at Michigan who helped anchor an effective run game there. Don't bet against Cole starting at some point as a rookie. -- Chris Sprow

Akins, 25, is a former outfielder who pursued a professional baseball career after high school. He was a receiver who returned kicks his first two seasons at UCF before switching positions in 2016.

Akins is an above average route-runner whose size, athletic ability and ability to move around the formation make him a tough matchup. He projects as an F tight end with the skills to make an immediate impact as a situational receiver, but he'll need to make strides as a blocker to play a bigger role.

Akins, 25, pursued a professional baseball career after high school. He projects as a flex tight end with the skills to make an immediate impact as a situational receiver but needs to make strides as a blocker to play a bigger role. This is a little early to take Akins, especially with Miami's Chris Herndon still on the board. But there's no question that the Texans need help at tight end. C.J. Fiedorowicz suffered three concussions last year and retired. Stephen Anderson caught 25 passes, while Ryan Griffin caught 13. -- Steve Muench

Yiadom was a three-year starter at Boston College. Long cornerback with above-average height and very good arm length but gets too grabby at times and will need to adjust to NFL rules.. He grades out as a No. 3 or No. 4 corner in the NFL. Yiadom also is an effective jammer on punt return units, which increases his value. He projects as a mid-round pick. Yiadom, a three-year starter at Boston College, is a long cornerback with above-average height and very good arm length but gets too grabby at times and will need to adjust to NFL rules. He also is an effective jammer on punt return units, which increases his value. After years of excellence, the Denver pass defense became a middle-of-the-pack unit in 2017 and ended up allowing the fifth-most touchdown passes in the NFL (29). Yiadom offers above-average length and plenty of experience, which could be useful early in a division where passing offenses in Kansas City, Oakland and Los Angeles will put Denver to the test. -- Chris Sprow

O'Daniel is a tweener outside linebacker/safety. While position fit is a concern, there's a lot to like about what he can do. He's an above-average tackler with good range. He was a team captain who is tied for first in Clemson history in special teams tackles. He may never be an every-down player but he grades out as a core special teams contributor who could carve out a role on defense. O'Daniel is an OLB/safety tweener, but there's a lot to like. He's an above-average tackler with good range who might never be an every-down player, but grades out as a core special-teamer who could carve out a role on defense. It will be interesting to see where the Chiefs play O'Daniel. He's undersized for a linebacker, but he tested like a safety, where the Chiefs have a need, and they could move him there. Look for him to make an impact on special teams while he carves out a role for himself on defense. -- Steve Muench

Thomas went to Nassau Junior College for two years, then transferred to Indiana for two seasons. He had 25 catches for 376 yards (15.0 yards per catch) and five TDs in 2017.

He has slightly below-average height, but is tightly packed with a thick, muscular build. He's a natural hands catcherand reliable target withimpressive body control, but needs to learn an NFL route tree and show the ability to separate more frequently on his own. He's not elusive after the catch and needs to do a better job with ball security, but does show adequate acceleration. He's not dominant at the point of attack, but has adequate size and the strength to sustain blocks.

Thomas grades out as a contributing backup TE with some versatility to play either in-line or detached.He's a mostly reliable target with a slightly above average overall skills. A likely mid-round pick in 2018.

Thomas is a natural catcher and reliable target with impressive body control, but he needs to learn an NFL route tree and show the ability to separate more frequently on his own. He grades out as a contributing backup TE with some versatility to play either in-line or detached.

Holmes has the size, length and strength to set a hard edge and is versatile enough to reduce inside to rush the passer. He doesn't show great burst or bend when he rushes off the edge, and though he does an adequate job of getting to depth, he's not an ideal 3-4 OLB candidate. Holmes has the tools to develop into a starting LDE or 3-4 DE who kicks inside to rush the passer, but early in his career he might need to be more of a rotational end as he continues to develop. He projects as a Day 2 pick. Holmes has the size, length and strength to set a hard edge. He has the tools to develop into a starting LDE or 3-4 DE who kicks inside to rush the passer, but early in his career he might need to be more of a rotational end as he continues to develop.

Coutee played sparingly as a freshman, but racked up 148 catches for 2,319 yards with 17 TDs over the past two seasons. In 2017 he averaged 31.5 yards on 10 kickoff returns, taking one back for a TD. He is undersized with a lean frame, but was durable in college. A smooth athlete with explosive speed, he can take the top off the defense.

Coutee gets easily out-muscled, but his ball skills are above average and he shows good focus in traffic. He needs to take more pride in his blocking and will need time to adjust to an NFL passing game and verbiage. Coutee compares to Atlanta's Andre Roberts and grades out as an immediate starting kick returner who could develop into a sub-package slot receiver. He projects as a mid-round pick.

Coutee is a smooth athlete with explosive speed who can take the top off the defense. His ball skills are above average, he shows good focus in traffic and grades out as a starting kick returner who could develop into a sub-package slot receiver.

Hines was the only running back to run a sub 4.4 40 at the combine and his top-end speed makes him a threat to pull away any time he gets a seam. He's explosive turning the corner and he has the lateral quickness to make defenders miss. He grades out as a change-of-pace back with the ability to turn limited touches into substantial production and bring added value as a potential return man. Hines, with elite top-end speed, was the only running back to run a sub-4.4 40 at the combine. He grades out as a change-of-pace back with the ability to turn limited touches into substantial production. He could bring added value as a return man.

Callaway is a dangerous slot receiver who makes the first defender miss and has the explosive acceleration to threaten after the catch. His arms (31.5 inches) are almost a half-inch shorter than the five-year combine average for receivers and he's not going to regularly win 50-50 balls downfield, but he has the second gear to take the top off the coverage.

Callaway grades out as a dangerous slot receiver and return man who makes an immediate impact based on his tape and testing. However, his off-the-field decision making could cause teams to take him off their boards.

Callaway is a dangerous slot receiver who makes the first defender miss and has the explosive acceleration to threaten after the catch. He could make an immediate impact at the next level based on his talent and testing.

Jewell is an instinctive run defender who does an above-average job of sifting through blocks and he always to seem to be around the ball at the end of the play. He has short arms (32 inches) and gets engulfed at times, but he tends to get his hands inside and makes it tough for blockers to get into his frame. Jewell is an excellent football player with the instincts, work ethic and toughness to overcome his physical limitations to develop into an effective starter and possibly a core special teams player. Jewell is an instinctive run defender and an excellent football player with the instincts, work ethic and toughness to overcome his physical limitations to develop into an effective starter and possibly a core member of special teams.

Herndon started 23 games over the past two seasons, catching 68 passes for 811 yards and six TDs during that span. He tore the MCL in his left knee in the Pitt game and had season-ending surgery in 2017. He's a smooth route-runner with the quickness to separate from man coverage who grades out as an F tight end with the tools to make an impact as a receiver. He could be an excellent value early on Day 3 if he's able to make a full recovery from the knee injury. Herndon had season-ending surgery on his left knee in 2017 (torn MCL). He's a smooth route runner with the quickness to separate and grades out as a flex tight end with the tools to make an impact as a receiver if he makes a full recovery.

Lauletta has adequate size and speed, and appears on tape to have fast eyes and move through his progressions well. Good mental clock and feel inside the pocket. At his best making quick decisions and getting the ball out quickly. Really good at selling play-action and reportedly interviewed very well at the Senior Bowl and combine.

The more tape I study the more I like Lauletta as a pro prospect, and his strong Senior Bowl showing (game MVP) helped open some eyes to his potential. Lauletta grades out as a potential NFL backup and he's likely to be a drafted on Day 3, which would make him the first Richmond QB drafted since 1975 (Harry Knight).

Lauletta has adequate size and speed, and appears on tape to have fast eyes and move through his progressions well. He's at his best making quick decisions and getting the ball out quickly, and reportedly interviewed very well at the Senior Bowl and combine.

Apke's combine performance makes him one of the most intriguing prospects in this draft. That natural ability shows up on tape as he covers a lot of ground and flashes above-average man-to-man cover skills. However, he overreacts to double-moves, can be late diagnosing in deep coverage and is not a playmaker (2 career picks). There's no question that he has the tools to start in the NFL but he's a better athlete than football player and there are enough concerns to cause him to drop to Day 3. Apke covers a lot of ground and flashes above-average man-to-man cover skills, but he can be late diagnosing in deep coverage and is not a playmaker (only two career picks). There's no question he has the tools to start in the NFL, but he's a better athlete than football player at this point.

Nelson is a big corner with the movement skills, ball reaction and run support skills to eventually push for a starting job in the NFL. He loves the game and works his tail off. The biggest concerns are that he gets too grabby in coverage (which will only be magnified with NFL passing game rules) and he needs to improve his hands. Nelson projects as a Day 2 pick. Nelson is a big cornerback with the movement, ball reaction and run-support skills to eventually push for a starting job. The biggest concerns are that he gets too grabby in coverage and needs to improve his hands.

Allen is a 2017 captain and true senior who started 28 consecutive games to close out his career. He is an alpha leader with a professional work ethic and is a fundamentally sound run-blocker.An overachiever, he has outstanding football intelligence.Allen doesn't project as a starter at this point, but has the smarts, toughness and enough tools to develop into an effective backup with the ability to play guard in a pinch. Allen is a 2017 captain and true senior who started 28 consecutive games to close out his career. Walton got off to a fast start in 2017 (averaged 7.6 yards with three TDs on 56 carries) before suffering a season-ending right ankle injury in Week 4. He is quicker than fast, showing good short-area burst and the low center of gravity to make violent cuts and bounce off arm tackles. However, he lacks size and doesn't have the brute strength to push the pile. He is a reliable check-down option and has talent, but is an undersized back coming off a season-ending injury. He grades out as a rotational back who will likely need to make contributions on special teams to stick. Hamilton, a team captain, is Penn State's all-time leader in receptions (214) and No. 2 in receiving yards (2,842). He doesn't have great burst, but is an above average route-runner with an NFL frame. His ability to get open stood out the week of the Senior Bowl, where he really boosted his stock.

He has longer arms and flashes the ability to come down with 50-50 balls, but he doesn't always field the ball cleanly, has the occasional drop and didn't catch the ball consistently as well on tape as he did in Mobile.

Hamilton is not a big-time playmaker and doesn't have the burst to regularly pull away after the catch or stretch the field in the NFL. He projects as a sub-package slot receiver with the skills to quickly develop into a productive No. 3.

Hamilton, a team captain, is Penn State's all-time leader in receptions (214) and No. 2 in receiving yards (2,842). But he is not a big-time playmaker and doesn't have the burst to regularly pull away after the catch or stretch the field in the NFL.

Hand looks the part with a long frame and above average natural athleticism for his size, but never reached his potential at Alabama. He grades out as an NFL backup as a base 4-3 LDE, but has the versatility to playoutside and inside along a defensive front. Hand is likely to be drafted early on Day 3. Hand has a long frame and above-average natural athleticism for his size but never reached his potential at Alabama. He grades out as an NFL backup as a base 4-3 LDE with the versatility to play outside and inside.

Iyiegbuniwe was a four-year player and two-year starter. He missed most of his freshman year (2014) due to injury. In 27 starts out of 48 games played, Iyiegbuniwe recorded 191 tackles, 6.5 sacks and 22.5 TFL. Iyiegbuniwe was a four-year player and two-year starter at Western Kentucky. He's an undersized linebacker with above-average range, tested well at the combine and projects as a special teams contributor early in his career.

Armstrong flashes the ability to get off blocks when teams run at him and he chases with above-average effort. The sack production (1.5) last season is a concern and he doesn't show elite burst or closing speed coming off the edge. While he needs to flesh out his pass-rush moves and improve his ability to counter, he does have the violent hands, bend and change-of-direction skills to get there. Armstrong may never develop into a Pro Bowl player but he grades out as an above average backup 3-4 OLB who could grow into a starting role over time. Armstrong has the violent hands, bend and change-of-direction skills for a team to develop. There's a lot to like about Whitehead's physical style of play, as he looks to punish receivers in coverage and he flashes above-average stopping power when closes on balls in front of him. He has the enough range to cover a deep half and hold up in underneath zone. However, he's an undersized safety whose frame and playing style raises concerns about his long-term durability.

A tweener safety/corner, Whitehead has the ceiling of a No. 3 sub-package defensive back. He projects as a Day 3 pick.

Whitehead has enough range to cover a deep half, but is an undersized safety whose frame and physical playing style raise concerns about his long-term durability. A safety/corner tweener, he has the ceiling of a No. 3 sub-package defensive back.

Averett is an underrated cover corner with below-average size but good length and very good combination of quickness, body control and speed. He displays fast eyes and very good reaction quickness. Well-respected by teammates and coaches, he's also clean off the field. Averett has the tools to develop into an NFL starter and should come off the board on Day 2. Averett is an underrated cover corner with below-average size but good length and very good combination of quickness, body control and speed. Averett has the tools to develop into an NFL starter.

White has the size, length and upper-body strength to stack blockers and hold his own when he lines up in the box. He chases with excellent effort and he closes well. While he fails to wrap and slides of the occasional tackle he flashes above-average stopping power and he rarely fails to get the ball carrier on the ground when his technique is sound. He's at his best in underneath zone where he has the instincts and quickness to jump routes

White grades out as a No. 3 safety that contributes on special teams early on but has the potential to develop into an effective starter. Some teams could consider playing him at nickel linebacker considering his size, strength and toughness.

White grades out as a No. 3 safety who contributes on special teams early on with the potential to develop into an effective starter. He also has the potential to play at nickel linebacker given his size, strength and toughness.

Dissly was a defensive lineman his first two seasons (2014-15) before converting to tight end in 2016. Slightly below-average in height with a thick build, he has average arm length, hands and top-end speed. His best trait might be his ball skills as he did not drop a catchable pass in 2017 and shows strong hands on contested catches.

He has very average athletic traits and is still developing as a route-runner, but has good focus in traffic. He's a strong and tough run blocker -- arguably the bestrun-blocking tight end in the 2018 class.

Dissly is a team-first, hard-nosed tough guy with excellent football character. He grades out as a backup Y-TE in the NFL who could eventually start. He will likely be selected in the middle rounds.

Dissly did not drop a catchable pass in 2017 and is arguably the best run-blocking tight end in the 2018 class. He's a tough guy with excellent football character and very average athletic traits who grades out as a backup Y-TE who could eventually start.

Johnson was a team captain and four-year starter who finished his career with 172 tackles, 48 pass deflections and six interceptions. He doesn't have the size/length to regularly match up on the outside but he has the balance and short area burst to blanket slot receivers in man. He grades out as a No. 3 corner who contributes on special teams. He's a better football player than athlete and he has the potential to turn into an excellent Day 3 value. Johnson, a better football player than athlete, doesn't have the size or length to regularly match up on the outside but has the short-area burst to blanket slot receivers. He grades out as a No. 3 cornerback who contributes on special teams.

Young was a four-year player and three-year starter at UCLA, appearing in 50 games and making 43 starts. In 2017, he led the team in tackles with 110. He finished his career with 304 tackles, 6.5 sacks, 22 TFL and 1 INT. Young has good instincts and outstanding top-end speed, but he's on the lighter side and there are concerns about his combine testing. His three-cone (7.38) is a red flag and his short shuttle (4.48) is a borderline red flag for an inside linebacker.

Smythe injured his shoulder and torean MCL three games into the 2015 season  both required surgery. He caught 24 passes for 356 yards and five TDs while starting all 25 games over the past two seasons. Though his short shuttle time (4.23) is outstanding for a tight end, he's not fast enough to run by linebackers and not a threat after the catch. He grades out as a potential No. 3 blocking tight end who needs to contribute on special teams to stick. Heprojects as a late-round pick. Though his short shuttle time (4.23 seconds) is outstanding for a tight end, Smythe is not fast enough to run by linebackers and not a threat after the catch. He grades out as a potential No. 3 blocking tight end who needs to contribute on special teams to stick.

Watts was a team captain and four-year starter. He is an aggressive run defender who shows above-average stopping power for his size. He reads the quarterback and flashes the ability to get an early break on short-to-intermediate routes. He tracks the ball well and shows above-average ball skills on tape. He appears to have enough range to cover a deep half but he wasn't as effective in coverage in 2017 as he was in 2016 and his combine performance was underwhelming. Watts grades out as a No. 3 safety who makes substantial contributions on special teams. Watts is an aggressive run defender who appears to have the range to cover a deep half, but he wasn't as effective in coverage in 2017 as in 2016, and his combine performance was underwhelming. He grades out as a No. 3 safety who contributes on special teams.

Maddox is a quick-twitch corner with the burst and balance to blanket receivers. He's fast enough to run with just about anyone and he has above-average recovery speed. His size and injury history will likely drop him into the early Day 3 range but he has the tools to become an above average nickel corner with the toughness to hold his own against the run. Maddox is a quick-twitch corner with the burst and balance to blanket receivers. He has above-average recovery speed and the tools to become an above-average nickel corner with the toughness to hold his own against the run.

Smith's pass-catching ability out of the backfield gives him a shot of making a 53-man roster as a reserve running back. He projects as a late-round pick or priority free agent. Smith's pass-catching ability out of the backfield gives him a shot of making a 53-man roster as a reserve running back.

Leonard moved from defensive end to right tackle in 2016. He lost his starting job after three games but started the final three games of the season and all 13 games in 2017. He's an athletic positional blocker who grades out as a developmental reserve tackle. A team could draft him late or sign him as a rookie free agent and stash him on the practice squad with the hope he gets stronger and adds weight. Street grades out as a reserve NFL edge defender who lacks a true fit on defense and will need to contribute on special teams to stick. He is a likely Day 3 pick. Street grades out as a reserve NFL edge defender who lacks a true fit on defense and will need to contribute on special teams to stick.

Richardson grades out as a tackle with the natural tools to quickly develop into a No. 3 swing tackle and an effective starter on the right side, making him an intriguing option in a weak tackles class. He projects as a fringe Day 2 pick based off the tape but concerns about the off-the-field decision could cause him to fall to Day 3. Richardson has the the natural tools to quickly develop into a No. 3 swing tackle and eventually an effective NFL starter on the right side, making him an intriguing option in a weak tackles class.

Sweat had 29 TFL and 14.5 sacks in three seasons. Naturally gifted with explosive traits, he produced elite results at the combine but his production does not match his testing. As a pass-rusher he uses mostly swipe, slap and swim moves and really struggles when he can't win with outside speed. Sweat is scheme versatile with the tools to play RDE in a base 4-3 or OLB in a base 3-4. He has a lot of raw ability, will be a 21-year old rookie and grades out as a rotational edge defender with enough upside to develop into a starter.If cleared medically (he had 2016 surgery to repair a meniscus tear in his left knee) he has a chance to be a Day 2 pick. Ballage was a four-year player and two-year rotational starter at ASU. He played in 47 career games with 12 starts (six in each of his last two seasons). Ballage split carries at ASU, but he was very productive in the passing game and also contributed as a kickoff returner. He has an outstanding combination of size, speed and lower-body explosion, but he also lacks some elusiveness as a runner, his vision is inconsistent and pass-blocking technique needs work. He might be best suited to serve as a hybrid RB/slot-WR, similar to Christian McCaffrey's role with the Panthers as a rookie.

Ballage grades out as a versatile rotational weapon but likely isn't a bell-cow back in the NFL. He has Day 2 value.

Ballage has an outstanding combination of size, speed and lower-body explosion, but he also lacks some elusiveness as a runner, his vision is inconsistent, and his pass-blocking technique needs work. Scott is fast enough to threaten vertically and he's good at his competing for 50-50 balls downfield. He doesn't waste any time getting north-south and he's fast enough to pick up some yards when gets a seam after the catch. He doesn't have the second gear to get behind NFL corners or pull away after the catch, though. He's a big target with the potential to develop into an effective zone buster and productive red zone weapon. Moore grades out as a sub-package receiver with the potential to develop into an effective No. 2. Edmonds is a twitchy runner at his best pressing the line and bouncing back or to the outside. He makes defenders miss in the hole and in space, but isn't much of a threat to pull away and grades out as a No. 3 change-of-pace back who potentially returns kickoffs.

Haynes is a disruptive run defender with the closing speed and motor to chase down backs in pursuit. He's a relentless pass-rusher who closes well and flashes a quick inside move. However, position fit is a substantial concern. He has good size, length and speed for an off-the-line linebacker but he's a college defensive end whose short shuttle (4.45) is a red flag. He projects as a Day 3 pick and he'll need to contribute on special teams as he tries to grow into a defensive role. Haynes is a relentless pass-rusher and disruptive run-defender with good size, length and speed for an off-the-line LB. However, he's a college DE whose short shuttle (4.45 seconds) is a red flag. He'll need to contribute on special teams as he tries to grow into a role.

Schultz caught 55 passes for 555 yards and five TDs in three seasons. He has the potential to develop into a reliable check-down option, but there are concerns about his ability to hold up as an in-line blocker. Madison started all 47 games he played at right tackle, though he's built more like a guard. Highly efficient in pass pro, he's light on his feet with very good lateral agility to mirror, butnot as effective as a run blocker. He's at his best in the run game when he's on the move andcould convert to guard in the NFL. He will need to get stronger to improve as a run-blocker and anchor against NFL pass-rushers, and projects as a Day 3 pick. Highly efficient in pass protection, Madison is light on his feet with very good lateral agility to mirror, but is not as effective as a run-blocker. He could convert to guard but will need to get stronger to anchor against NFL pass-rushers.

McIntosh flashes the ability to slip blocks and disrupt plays in the backfield. As a pass-rusher he flashes effective swim and spin moves, but gets overwhelmed when he doesn't keep his pads down. He doesn't have elite first-step quickness or closing speed for a three technique and projects as a rotational 4-3 DT or 3-4 DE with some upside.
