He also has effective swim and spin moves but doesn't have elite first-step quickness or closing speed for a three technique and projects as a rotational 4-3 DT or 3-4 DE with some upside.

Hurst started all 13 games in 2017, finishing with 5.5 sacks. He is an undersized defensive tackle with short arms, but has the quick hands and explosive first step to disrupt plays in the backfield. He has all the tools to be a productive pass-rusher and is expected to emerge as an effective starting three-technique or nose tackle in a 4-3 scheme. Hurst projects as a top-40 pick. Hurst has the quick hands and explosive first step to disrupt plays in the backfield despite being an undersized defensive tackle with short arms. He has all the tools to be a productive pass-rusher and is expected to emerge as an effective starting three-technique or nose tackle in a 4-3 scheme.

Griffin has an outstanding motor and elite first-step quickness as an edge rusher. He does have physical limitations due to his left hand amputation, including getting off blocks and wrapping up as a tackler, but he's fast, athletic and instinctive enough to contribute on special teams and as a sub-package defender in the NFL. He's a likely late-round pick. Griffin has an outstanding motor and elite first-step quickness as an edge rusher. He does have physical limitations due to his left hand amputation -- including getting off blocks and wrapping up as a tackler -- but he's fast, athletic and instinctive enough to contribute on special teams and as a sub-package defender in the NFL.

Reed flashes above-average quickness and balance in underneath man, and reads routes and anticipates breaks in off and zone coverage. He's a ball hawk with big hands (10 inches), long arms (31 5/8 inches) and an above-average vertical (3.65 inches). He's fast enough to turn and run with most receivers but he has average recovery burst and there's little room for error. Reed flashes above-average quickness and balance in underneath man and reads routes and anticipates breaks in off and zone coverage. He's a ball hawk and fast enough to run with most receivers but has just average recovery burst.

Bentley is a powerful interior run-stopper with the size and strength to clog up the middle. He's not a sideline-to-sideline player and he's not nearly as effective in space as he is in close quarters. Below average pass-rusher. Bentley projects as a two-down linebacker who will need to contribute on special teams. Bentley is a powerful interior run-stopper with the size and strength to help clog up the middle when teams run inside. He takes too long to get off some blocks, but he has the upper body strength to improve in this area. He projects as a two-down linebacker with limitations in coverage at this point.

Watson is a big receiver with an excellent catching radius. He tested better than expected at his pro day, where he ran in the 4.4s with an outstanding 10-yard split and had an outstanding vertical jump (40 inches). He didn't run great routes, but he made some impressive catches the week of the Senior Bowl.

Nicholshad his best season in 2017 with 6.5 tackles-for-loss and 5.5 sacks. He pulled a hamstring at the combine, but has the length and upper-body strength to stack and shed blocks as s a two-gap run defender. Nichols grades out as a rotational 3-4 DE or NT with the potential to develop into a starter, but doesn't offer much as a pass-rusher at this point and projects as a Day 3 pick. Nichols pulled a hamstring at the combine but has the length and upper-body strength to stack and shed blocks as a two-gap run defender. He grades out as a rotational 3-4 DE or NT with starter potential but doesn't offer much as a pass-rusher at this point.

Flowers is an above-average tackler who flashes good stopping power filling in run support and limits production after the catch in coverage. He has the instincts and range to cover a deep half of the field and hold up in underneath zone. His greatest asset is his rare length (34-inch arms) as he doesn't have to be in perfect position to get his hands on the ball carrier in run support or get his hands on the ball in coverage.

However, he's a lean high-cut safety who lacks the change of direction skills to regularly match up with slot receivers and the strength to regularly match up with tight ends in man coverage. He grades out as a backup free safety who makes his biggest impact on special teams.

Flowers has the instincts and range to cover a deep half, but is a lean, high-cut safety who lacks the skills to regularly match up with slot receivers and tight ends. He grades out as a backup free safety who makes his biggest impact on special teams.

Kiser is a sound tackler with the motor to make more plays in pursuit than linebackers with similar top-end speed and an immediate impact on special teams. He's at his best attacking gaps and slipping blocks in the move. He flashes the ability to get downhill and jar blockers on contact, but he tends to launch with shoulder instead of staying square, delivering punch and snapping hips on contact.

Kiser projects as a rotational MLB, WILB, or SLB who makes his biggest contributions on special teams.

Kiser is a sound tackler with the motor to make more plays in pursuit than linebackers with similar top-end speed. He projects as a rotational MLB, WILB or SLB who makes his biggest contributions on special teams.

Allen was a 2017 team captain and four-year starter at Penn State. He doesn't have ideal size or length for a box safety and he misses the occasional open field tackle but he's still an above-average run-stopper. Allen projects as a defensive reserve who potentially contributes in select situations but is unlikely to develop into a starter. Allen doesn't have ideal size or length for a box safety and misses the occasional open-field tackle but is still an above-average run-stopper. He projects as a reserve who contributes in select situations but is unlikely to develop into a starter.

Dickson is an Australian who played Australian Rules Football in high school and didn't move to America until the summer of 2015. He's a true junior who finished his career as Texas' all-time leader in punting average (45.3 yards per punt) and he had a 44.2 net punting average in 2017. He averaged 47.4 yards per punt and had 61 punts that went 50 yards or farther over the past two seasons.

Dickson grades out as a potential All Pro punter and he projects as a Day 2 pick as a result.

Dickson is an Australian who played Australian rules football in high school and didn't move to the United States until the summer of 2015. He grades out as a potential All-Pro punter.

Avery played four seasons at Memphis and played in 50 games (34 starts). He recorded 232 tackles, 45 TFL and 21.5 sacks. Avery has an excellent blend of size and top-end speed. He also ran an outstanding three-cone (6.90) at the combine but he's better defending the run than he is in coverage.

Harris was a three-year player and two-year starter, who started 24 out of 25 games. Harris collected 141 tackles, two INTs and 23 PBU. Harris is a confident player with good speed and size in addition to adequate length. He's versatile with some experience at free safety and was very good on special teams. He has smaller hands and he doesn't project as a playmaker in the NFL.

Cruikshank played two seasons at Arizona and started all 25 games. He recorded 135 tackles, 12 PBU, and five INTs. Prior to Arizona, he played DB at Citrus College in Azusa, California. Cruikshank is a big corner with shorter arms and very good speed. He's physical and smooth, but he's not twitchy and has adequate ball skills. Football character is a concern for some scouts.

Crosby, an every-game starter in 2017,has average height and bulk for a tackle with very long arms (35') and huge mitts (10 '). He is a high-level run-blocker with good initial quickness and the power to consistently get movement. Heis tough to get aroundand shows a solid anchor against power rushers. Crosby is body ugly, but don't be fooled by the packaging. He's a darn good player who projects as a No. 3 swing tackle early in his career, and he's talented enough to develop into a solid starter -- likely at right tackle. He projects as a Day 2 pick. Crosby is a high-level run-blocker with good initial quickness and the power to consistently get movement. He is tough to get around and shows a solid anchor against power rushers. He's a good player who projects as a No. 3 swing tackle early in his career, and is talented enough to develop into a solid starter -- likely at right tackle.

Neal is a versatile defensive back with experience playing safety and corner. A big and physical press corner who gets his hands inside and has the upper-body strength to disrupt and reroute receivers, Neil shows adequate closing speed and tends to limit production after the catch in off coverage. He's an above-average tackler who does a nice job of stepping up in run support and has the potential to develop into a core special teams contributor. He takes too long to get off blocks at times. Neal is a versatile defensive back with experience playing safety and corner. He's an above-average tackler who does a nice job of stepping up in run support and has the potential to develop into a core special-teams contributor.

Quessenberry took a medical redshirt year to recover from surgery in both shoulders and returned as UCLA's starting center the past two seasons. He has good size, and experience at center and guard. He usually does a good job against a power rush and has outstanding awareness in pass protection. Quessenberry doesn't consistently drive defenders off the line and is not a great athlete, but has a solid combination of size, initial striking power and toughness. He grades out as a versatile backup interior linemanwith a shot of emerging as an adequate starter. He projects as a Day 3 pick. Quessenberry has good size and ample experience at center and guard. He doesn't consistently drive defenders off the line and is not a great athlete but has a solid combination of size, initial striking power and toughness.

Fumigali is a limited athlete, but he has worked hard to develop into a productive player. He is crafty short-to-intermediate route runner with excellent ball skills, and he continues to improve as a blocker. Fumagalli grades out as a backup tight end who can contribute in two-tight end sets. Fumagalli is a limited athlete, but he has worked hard to develop into a productive player. He is a crafty short-to-intermediate route runner with excellent ball skills, and he continues to improve as a blocker.

Conklin is an above average route runner with the ability to move around the formation. In particular, his size and ability to adjust to back-shoulder throws make him a tough matchup when he lines up on the outside. He's fearless working the middle of the field and he's a gritty runner who picks up yards after the catch.

Conklin grades out as a versatile F tight end with the frame and athletic ability to create matchup problems but has average top-end speed and is a below average blocker. He projects as a Day 3 pick.

Conklin's size and ability to adjust to back-shoulder throws make him a tough matchup when he lines up on the outside. Conklin grades out as a versatile tight end with the frame and athletic ability to create matchup problems but has average top-end speed and is a below-average blocker.

Brown recorded 84 tackles, 23.5 tackles for-loss and 9.5 sacks over the past two seasons. He fits best as a 3-4 DE or LDE, but could step in at defensive tackle in a pinch.He projects as a valuable reserve with the ability to provide quality depth regardless of the front and could develop into a serviceable starter. Brownprojects as an early Day 3 pick. Brown recorded 84 tackles, 23.5 tackles for loss and 9.5 sacks over the past two seasons. He projects as a valuable reserve with the ability to provide quality depth regardless of the front and could develop into a serviceable starter.

Underrated talent who was not invited to the NFL combine. Fountain has good size and speed to go with long arms (34") and big mitts (10 1/8"). He was a four-year player and three-year starter at UNI. In his final three seasons as a starter he hauled in 140 passes for 1960 yards (14.0 ypc) and 22 TDs -- and he had his best season as a senior, when he double his catch total from 2016. He also was an East-West Shrine game standout. Fountain is raw but he has explosive traits and shows the potential to develop into a vertical threat as a No. 3 or No. 4 WR in the NFL. Fountain is an underrated talent who was not invited to the combine. He has good size and speed to go with long arms (34 inches) and big mitts (10 1/8 inches). He is raw, but has explosive traits and shows the potential to develop into a vertical threat as a No. 3 or No. 4 WR in the NFL.

Okoronkwo started all 26 games he played during his final two seasons, totaling 147 tackles, 29.5 TFL, and 17 sacks. But he's undersized with average arm length and below-average speed. Although he was highly productive in college, he grades out as an NFL backup who will need to refine his skills in order to carve out a niche as a situational edge rusher. Okoronkwo is undersized with average arm length and below-average speed. Although he was productive in college, he grades out as an NFL backup who will need to refine his skills to carve out a niche as a situational edge rusher.

Carter is a two-time team captain who led Maryland in tackles the past three seasons. He's rangy and has the potential to develop into a core special teams player, but he's undersized with short arms.

A two-year starter, Lasley was suspended multiple times at UCLA, including one for three games in 2017 when he finished with 69 catches for 1,264 yards and 9 TDs. He has easy speed, is very natural tracking the deep ball and shows the ability to snatch on the run and quickly pivot/transition upfield. He also flashes the ability to make really difficult catches, but has too many drops on tape.

Lasley frequently makes the first defender miss, has a good feel as an open-field runner and generates a lot of yards after catch. Multiple scouts told us his immaturity and behavior issues are concerns that will likely cause his draft stock to fall a bit. However, many of those same scouts say he has done some growing up this past year.

On the field he can be a difference-making starter in the NFL, especially as a vertical receiver. For any team comfortable with his football character, he has value on Day 2.

A two-year starter, Lasley has a good feel as an open-field runner, generates a lot of yards after catch and flashes the ability to make really difficult catches. His immaturity and behavior issues are concerns, but on the field, he can be a difference-making starter in the NFL, especially as a vertical receiver.

Settle, who totaled 19.5 TFL and 4.0 sacks the past two seasons, has had trouble keeping weight in check. He is a less freakishly gifted version of Dontari Poe with limited experience (27 college games) and is still a bit raw, but has shown versatility. When he's in good shape he's a wide-bodied run-plugger with unique agility and power for his size. He's a 40-50 play-per-game starter with the potential to emerge as a pro-bowl caliber interior lineman. Settle is a less freakishly gifted version of Dontari Poe with limited experience (27 college games) and is still a bit raw, but he has shown versatility. When he's in good shape, he's a wide-bodied run-plugger with unique agility and power for his size.

Jamerson is a good athlete with some upside as a free safety. He has only 15 career starts and his development was stunted by stints at WR and CB. But he has enough size, athleticism, speed and toughness to contribute immediately on special teams while finding a niche as a sub-package contributor on defense. He could be a late-round value pick from the 2018 class. Jamerson is a good athlete with some upside as a free safety. He only has 15 career starts and his development was stunted by his stints at WR and CB, as well as missing six games in 2016 due to a leg injury. But he has enough size, athleticism, speed and toughness to contribute immediately on special teams while working to find a niche as a sub-package contributor on defense.

Samuels projects as a versatile fullback/H-Back/running back type with the ability to move-block, contribute as a pass-catcher, and also handle some short-yardage carries. He's an above-average route runner He's a likely Day 3 pick. Samuels projects as a versatile fullback/H-Back/running back type with the ability to move-block, contribute as a pass-catcher and also handle some short-yardage carries. He's an above-average route runner.

Teller gets above-average initial surge and he flashes the ability to drive defenders when he rolls his hips and keeps his feet under him. He gets set quickly and he anchors well in pass protection. He has below-average lateral mobility and his short shuttle time (4.84) is a red flag for an interior offensive lineman so he has some problems mirroring. However, he has excellent length (34" arms) and tends to push defenders out of their lanes when he's unable to stay in front.

Teller grades out as an above-average reserve guard with the potential to develop into an adequate starter.

Teller flashes the ability to drive defenders, gets set quickly and anchors well in pass protection. He does have some problems mirroring and grades out as an above-average reserve guard with the potential to become an adequate starter.

Carlson has the talent to develop into an NFL kicker and should get a look in a camp, but there's a good chance he doesn't get drafted following a disappointing senior season. Carlson broke the SEC career scoring record in 2017 and connected on 92 of his 114 field goal attempts at Auburn. He's coming off a disappointing season, but he has the leg strength to develop into an above-average NFL kicker if he's able to bounce back.

Jones started 27 consecutive games at left tackle the past two seasons. He's athletic enough to mirror and strong enough to anchor, but needs to increase his strength, fill out his frame and refine his technique.His tape isn't always pretty, but he almost always gets the job done.Jones' long arms make up for his lack of ideal height and he has the athleticism to develop into a starting left tackle. We think he's worth a Day 2 pick. Jones is athletic enough to mirror and strong enough to anchor, but needs to increase his strength, fill out his frame and refine his technique. His long arms make up for his lack of ideal height, and he has the athleticism to develop into a starting left tackle.

Wilkins is a patient runner with a good feel for cutback lanes. He has the foot speed and lateral quickness to bounce between gaps and make defenders miss. He takes care of the football as his career (0.6 percent) and 2017 (0.6 percent) fumble percentages are strong. He ran in the low 4.5s at his pro day, but he doesn't show great burst around the corner or the ability to pull away when he gets a seam on tape. He grades out as a reserve running back with limited upside and projects as a late-round pick or rookie free agent. Wilkins is a patient runner with a good feel for cutback lanes. He has the foot speed and lateral quickness to bounce between gaps. He flashes above-average ball skills, but he's not a big-play threat after the catch and has room to improve as a pass-blocker.

Phillips was a three-year starter who had 12 career interceptions, including five he returned for touchdowns. He does gamble at times and gets caught out of position. He has the potential to develop into an effective No. 3 corner if he gets stronger against the run. He's also one of the most dangerous kick returners in this class. He projects as a Day 3 pick. Phillips was a three-year starter who had 12 career interceptions, including five he returned for touchdowns. He has the potential to develop into an effective No. 3 corner if he gets stronger against the run, and he's also one of the most dangerous kick returners in this class.

White has prototypical size with a big arm and when his footwork is correct he can be an accurate passer to all three levels. However, he's a slow processor with marginal mobility, which leads to a high percentage of negative plays. White grades out as a QB2 with some upside if he lands in the right situation. He's likely a mid-round pick. White has prototypical size with a big arm, and when his footwork is correct, he can be an accurate passer to all three levels. However, he's a slow processor with marginal mobility. He grades out as an NFL backup with some upside.

Scott has the leg strength to flip the field. He gets excellent hang time on his kicks and he does an good job of pinning teams deep. He grades out as an above-average punter with the ability to kick off, hold on place kicks and fill in at place kicker in an emergency. He projects as a Day 2 pick. Scott gets excellent hang time on his kicks and does a good job of pinning teams deep. He grades out as an above-average punter with the ability to kick off, hold on place kicks and fill in at place kicker in an emergency.

Townsend catches the ball and gets the punts off quickly. He's got the leg strength to flip the field and he tends to get good hang times on his kicks. He flashes the ability to rugby style kick. He's a self-motivator with a professional work ethic. Townsend catches the ball and gets his punts off quickly. He has the leg strength to flip the field and tends to get good hang times. He flashes the ability to rugby-style kick and is a self-motivator with a professional work ethic.

Valdes-Scantling has the second gear to run down the deep ball and take the top off the coverage. While he's not as dangerous after the catch, he flashes the ability to make the first defender miss and is a threat to pull away when he gets a seam. He's a raw route runner who doesn't show great acceleration transitioning out of breaks and doesn't run a complete route tree, but he's quick enough to improve his separation skills. Valdes-Scantling grades out as a sub-package receiver with the size-speed combination to add a vertical threat to an offense. Valdes-Scantling has the second gear to run down the deep ball and take the top off the coverage. He grades out as a sub-package receiver with the size-speed combination to add a vertical threat to an offense.

Ratley is a community college transfer who caught just 47 passes over the past three seasons with 30 catches coming in 2017, but he also averaged 23.1 yards per catch last season and has big-play ability. He had an outstanding pro day where he ran a sub 4.4 40 with an outstanding 10-yard split and recorded an outstanding broad jump.

Kelly's determination and aggressiveness are his greatest assets. He's a tough downhill runner who regularly picks up yards after initial contact and looks to deliver the blow at the end of runs. He misses the occasional seam and gets impatient at times, but he's a decisive between-the-tackles runner who doesn't dance.

There are understandably concerns regarding Kelly's subpar 40 (4.64 at pro day), maturity and production, but there's a lot to like about his tough running style. Kelly is a tough downhill runner who regularly picks up yards after initial contact and looks to deliver the blow at the end of runs. There are concerns regarding his subpar 40 (4.64 seconds at pro day), maturity and production, but there's a lot to like about his running style.

Ejiofor started 25 games over the past two seasons and totaled 93 tackles, 33.5 tackles-for-loss and 17 sacks. He has the size and length to set the edge, but he's not a physical tone-setter. The game is important to him, but he doesn't always chase with great effort and his work habits need to improve. Ejiofor is a crafty and productive pass-rusher with a good combination of length, power and hand quickness. He grades out as a rotational backup left defensive end with the versatility to kick inside on obvious passing downs. He will likely be drafted early on Day 3. Ejiofor has the size and length to set the edge, but he's not a physical tone-setter. He is a crafty and productive pass-rusher who grades out as a rotational backup LDE with the versatility to kick inside on passing downs.

Sam is a powerful wrap-up tackler who also has the lateral quickness, balance and active hands to slip blockers in tight spaces. He chases with good effort and makes plays outside the tackle box. But in coverage he gets manipulated by quarterbacks' eyes and his route recognition is below average. Sam grades out as a backup who contributes on special teams. Sam is a powerful tackler who has the lateral quickness, balance and active hands to slip blockers in tight spaces. However, he gets manipulated by QBs and his route recognition is below average. He grades out as a backup who contributes on special teams.

Nickerson has an above-average blend of balance, foot speed and burst. He's fast enough to run with receivers when left on an island and he has good recovery speed. His arm length (30 1/4 inches) is a red flag and he'll occasionally get beat in press because he whiffs. He's a playmaker with above-average ball skills even though his hands (8 1/4-inch hand span) are almost an inch smaller than average His size is a concern and he takes too long to disengage but he's an above-average tackler who chases the run with good effort.

Nickerson's length and frame will likely prevent him from developing into an effective starter on the outside but he grades out as an above-average No. 3 and he projects as a fringe Day 2 pick as a result.

Nickerson is a playmaker with above-average ball skills even though his hands (8 1/4-inch hand span) are almost an inch smaller than average. His size is a concern and he takes too long to disengage, but he's an above-average tackler who chases the run with good effort.

Fatukasi, who finished with 19 tackles-for-loss and 14 sacks, is an alpha leader with a good work ethic. He overpowers blockers, driving them into the backfield and has the length and upper-body strength (33 reps on the bench) to push the pocket. He had 7.5 sacks two years ago and flashes as a pass-rusher. Plus, he has a quick 10-yard split (1.76) and short shuttle time (4.53) for a DT his size. Fatukasi has flown under the radar and his tape is a little inconsistent, but he grades out as a future starting 3-4 DE, 4-3 NT or 3-4 NT based on his tape and testing. Fatukasi is an alpha leader with a good work ethic who overpowers blockers and flashes as a pass-rusher. He is a little inconsistent but grades out as a future starting 3-4 DE, 4-3 NT or 3-4 NT based on his tape and testing.

Fitts has intriguing first-step quickness and closing speed, but his inability to stay heathy appears to have stunted his growth over the past two seasons. While he chases with good effort and closes well, his pursuit angles chasing the run and the quarterback are inconsistent. He grades out as a high risk/high reward rotational end or outside linebacker in a 3-4 system and projects as a Day 3 pick. Fitts has intriguing first-step quickness and closing speed, but his inability to stay heathy appears to have stunted his growth over the past two seasons. He grades out as a high risk/high reward rotational end or outside linebacker in a 3-4 system.

Campbell is big, instinctive and tackles well, but he gets pushed around and is too grabby at times. He isn't the most fluid or explosive corner in this class and his lack of ideal starting experience is a concern. But he has the frame, length and enough top-end speed to develop into an effective press corner, making him an intriguing late Day 2 or early Day 3 prospect. Campbell isn't the most fluid or explosive corner in this class, and his lack of ideal starting experience is a concern. But he has the frame, length and enough top-end speed to develop into an effective press corner, making him an intriguing prospect.

Jones, who made 23 starts at left guard, is tall and lean with a thin frame. He's at his best on move blocks, lacks core strength to drive defenders off the line and is not a good fit for power-based run scheme. Jones is athletic enough to develop into a good backup interior lineman for a zone-heavy scheme, but he needs to add bulk and get stronger. He has late-round value. Jones is at his best on move blocks, as he lacks the core strength to drive defenders off the line and is not a good fit for power-based run scheme. He is athletic enough to develop into a good backup interior lineman for a zone-heavy scheme, but he needs to add bulk and get stronger.

Harris missed the entire 2017 season after tearing his Achilles in July. Rather than appealing to the NCAA for another season of eligibility, he chose to enter the 2018 NFL draft. He is an in-the-box safety who, when healthy, is good enough on special teams to push for a roster spot. Fully recovering from his Achilles tear and getting back into football shape will be the key. Harris is likely to be an undrafted free agent. Harris played sparingly as a reserve safety and contributed on special teams before racking up a team-high 73 tackles in 2016. Unfortunately, he tore his Achilles in July and missed the 2017 season. He's an in-the-box safety who, when healthy, is good enough on special teams to push for a roster spot.

Cain, who had 58 catches for 734 yards and six TDs in 2017, made strides as a route-runner. The testing -- his three-cone time (6.75) is outstanding for a receiver -- suggests he has the potential to develop above average separation skills. He has borderline outstanding top-end speed, tracks the deep ball well and is a threat to take the top off the coverage. Erratic quarterback play in 2017, a deep receiving corps that limited his touches in 2016, his strong results in some tests and mediocre results in others make Cain a difficult evaluation. Ultimately he grades out as a No. 3 receiver with the potential to develop into an effective No. 2. Testing -- his three-cone time (6.75 seconds) is outstanding for a receiver -- suggests Cain has the potential to develop above-average separation skills. He has borderline outstanding top-end speed, tracks the deep ball well and is a threat to take the top off the coverage.

Martin is a true junior and collegiate defensive end who had eight sacks and 11 tackles for loss last season. At 236 pounds with 32 5/8-inch arms, he projects as an outside linebacker in the NFL. He has the speed and athletic ability to make the transition.

In three seasons, McCloud caught 127 passes, rushed 18 times, returned 50 punts, and even played cornerback late in the 2017 NC State game. He is undersized, has had problems staying healthy and must grow as a route-runner. However, he has the quickness and toughness to make plays over the middle and grades out as a No. 4 or No. 5 slot receiver who could compete as a return man. A team could also bring him in as a developmental defensive back. He projects as a late-round pick. McCloud is undersized, has had problems staying healthy and must grow as a route runner. However, he has the quickness and toughness to make plays over the middle and grades out as a No. 4 or No. 5 slot receiver who could compete as a return man.

Thomas possesses a rare combination of height, length and top-end speed. He had a ridiculous 11-foot, 3-inch broad jump at his pro day. He's a developmental prospect who isn't a playmaker at this point.

Moore was a two-year starter at Boston College (46 games played, 29 starts). He displays quick feet, adequate hip fluidity, and shows good burst out of pedal, but has below-average ball skills and just two career interceptions. He has the instincts, cover skills and toughness to develop into a quality nickel corner in the NFL. He has value early on Day 3. Moore displays quick feet, adequate hip fluidity, and shows good burst out of pedal, but has below-average ball skills and just two career interceptions. He has the instincts, cover skills and toughness to develop into a quality nickel corner in the NFL.

Elliott is an in-the-box type of safety who is very active versus the run but needs to be protected in coverage. He grades out as a reserve safety who will need to increase his value with strong special teams contributions. Elliott is a likely Day 3 selection. Elliott is an in-the-box type of safety who is very active against the run but needs to be protected in coverage. He grades out as a reserve safety who will need to increase his value with contributions on special teams.

After redshirting in 2015 because of a back injury, Cantrell racked up 129 catches for 1,491 yards with 15 TDs over the past two seasons. He's a big-bodied possession receiver with impressive instincts as a route-runner and very good ball skills who compares to Denver's Jordan Taylor.

However, his lack of fluidity and top-end speed limits his big-play potential and makes him a likely Day 3 pick. He can make tough catches in traffic, find soft spots in zones and does a good job of using his big frame to gain late separation.

Cantrell is an above-average blocker and can beat press, but has some tightness in his hips and will never be a vertical threat. He grades out as a No. 3 or No. 4 big slot receiver who will need to contribute on special teams to make a roster.

Cantrell is a big-bodied possession receiver with impressive instincts as a route runner and very good ball skills. His lack of fluidity and top-end speed limits his big-play potential, and he grades out as a No. 3 or No. 4 slot receiver who will need to contribute on special teams to stick.

Demby, a four-year starter, played tackle in college but isn't quite long or athletic enough to play there in the NFL and had a harder time protecting the edge the week of the Senior Bowl than he did on tape. Demby's frame, length, intelligence and football character make him an intriguing Day 3 guard prospect, but he will need to refine his technique to make it in the NFL. He projects as a developmental prospect who likely spends time on a team's practice squad. Demby played tackle in college, but isn't quite long or athletic enough to play there in the NFL and had a harder time protecting the edge the week of the Senior Bowl than he did on tape. He could spend time on a practice squad.

Covington is a developmental prospect with an NFL frame and coming off a breakout senior season. He flashes good instincts for a former quarterback and one-year starter at linebacker. He has the tools to develop into a core special teams' player. Covington moved from linebacker to quarterback during the 2014 preseason and later tore an ACL. He moved back to linebacker in the spring of 2015 and broke out in 2017. He gets engulfed and takes too long to get off some block, but he flashes good instincts and the ability to stack tight ends. He also has the frame and enough length to improve.

Special teams ace. One of the best kickoff and punt cover players in the class. Adequate size and very good top-end speed. Solid route runner with reliable hands. Gage is a team captain and special teams ace who is one of the best kickoff and punt cover players in this class. He has adequate size and very good top-end speed. He's also a solid route runner with reliable hands.
Joseph is long, has above-average first-step quickness and runs well for his size.

Smith doesn't have ideal length and he needs to refine his technique but his speed, ball production and ability to help out in the return game make him an intriguing Day 3 prospect. Smith doesn't have ideal length and he needs to refine his technique but his speed, ball production and ability to help out in the return game make him an intriguing prospect.

Durability has been a problem for Hamilton, who played sparingly on Alabama's defense but has contributed on special teams. Lacks length and size but has good strength, quickness and athleticism. Grades out as a good backup or possible starter in the right system/situation. Likely a mid-round pick. Durability has been a problem for Hamilton, who played sparingly on Alabama's defense but has contributed on special teams. Lacks length and size but has good strength, quickness and athleticism.

McKenzie displays above-average first-step quickness and the ability to knock blockers back on contact. But he doesn't push the pocket, doesn't counter well and takes too long to close rushing the passer. McKenzie displays above-average first-step quickness and the ability to knock blockers back on contact. But he doesn't push the pocket, doesn't counter well and takes too long to close rushing the passer.

A former walk-on, Falk played in 43 career games (40 starts) and he completed 68-percent of his passes for 14,486 yards, and a 3.1-1 TD-to-INT ratio. He set Pac-12 and WSU career records for passing yards (14,496), total offense (14,086) and passing touchdowns (119).

Falk is a tall, lean rhythm passer with very good anticipation, accuracy, and pocket presence. He gets just average velocity on the ball but he does have excellent timing and a quick trigger. He will have an adjustment to make coming from Mike Leach's passer-friendly version of the spread offense. But Falk has excellent football intelligence and should be able to pick up an NFL offense quickly. He has an intriguing tool set to develop for teams that employ a precision-timing based offensive system.

Falk has starter potential in the NFL and projects as an early Day 2 pick.

Falk has NFL-starter potential. He's a tall, lean rhythm passer with very good anticipation, accuracy, and pocket presence. He has excellent football intelligence and intriguing tools to develop for teams that use a timing-based system.

Oluokun is an undersized linebacker who recorded 271 tackles in 42 games at Yale. He has outstanding top-end speed and could move to safety, where he briefly lined up in 2013. He missed most of the 2015 season with an injury.

Scott rushed for 1,040 yards and eight touchdowns last season. He's an undersized back with very good top-end speed and changes directions well, but he doesn't have great power, is a small target in the passing game and isn't big or strong enough to regularly hold up in pass protection.

Cichy is a former walk-on who earned his way onto the field by excelling on special teams early in his career. He's not very fast but he's a tough player with great football intelligence and leadership skills. When healthy, Cichy grades out as a potential starting linebacker in the NFL who can contribute immediately on special teams. However, with mounting injuries, Cichy's medical results will play a huge role in where he's drafted. At this point, he projects as a Day 3 pick. Cichy is not very fast, but he's a tough player with great football intelligence and leadership skills. When healthy, he grades out as a potential starting linebacker in the NFL who can contribute immediately on special teams.

Lee has the arm strength to thread the needle on intermediate throws and drive the ball downfield. He has experience dropping from under center and he flashes the ability to make accurate throws when his footwork is sound. But while he makes some impressive throws on tape, he's highly erratic. He makes too many questionable decisions and puts the ball in harm's way far too often. His career touchdown-to-interception ratio (46:37) raises a red flag. While his receivers dropped some passes on tape, his accuracy is too inconsistent due to poor footwork.

A quarterback prospect with a checkered medical history, Lee has below-average pocket awareness and holds onto the ball too long. An up-and down performance at the week of the Senior Bowl did little ease concerns about performance on tape.

Lee has an NFL frame with an outstanding hand span (10 1/8 inches) and the tools to develop into an effective backup, but concerns about his injury history and decision making are likely to cause him to fall to the late Day 3 range.

Lee has NFL arm strength, but he's highly erratic, and his career TD-to-INT ratio (46-37) is a red flag. His checkered medical history and inconsistency at the Senior Bowl did little to ease concerns, but he has an NFL frame with the tools to become an effective backup.

Cannon has the burst to turn the corner, the lateral quickness to make defenders miss and the second gear to pull away when he gets a seam. He's a decisive between-the-tackles runner with the balance to break initial contact. He's a threat after the catch and returned two kickoffs for touchdowns last year. He eased concerns about playing at the Division II level with an excellent pro day workout highlighted by a 4.4-second 40, 38.5-inch vertical and 10-foot, 9-inch broad jump.

Young broke out with 8.5 sacks in 2015, but missed the 2016 season with a broken hip. He returned in 2017 and his tape steadily improved, but he wasn't the same (4.5 sacks) and the hitch in his run is obvious on tape. When healthy, he has outstanding burst and athleticism as a pass-rusher with explosive first-step quickness, speed to threaten the edge and an excellent closing burst. He has NFL starter potential if he returns to form, which is why his medicals will play such a major role in his draft stock. When healthy, Young has outstanding burst and athleticism as a pass-rusher with explosive first-step quickness, speed to threaten the edge and an excellent closing burst. He has NFL-starter potential if he returns to form, which is why his medicals will play such a major role in his draft stock.

Pryor started 13 games at right guard in 2016, and 14 games in 2017 (six at right tackle, eight at guard). He has a massive frame with adequate mobility and is heavy-handed with long arms. He lacks ideal initial quickness out of his stance, but consistently gets movement as a run-blocker and compares to guard D.J. Fluker (Giants). Pryor has flown under the radar, but he's a massive right tackle or guard prospect with the potential to develop into an NFL starter. Despite not receiving a combine invitation, Pryor might be drafted as high as Day 2. Pryor has a massive frame with adequate mobility and long arms. He has flown under the radar, but is a huge right tackle or guard prospect with the potential to develop into an NFL starter despite not receiving a combine invitation.

St. Brown, who missed the final four games (shoulder surgery) in 2017, caught 91 passes for 1,476 yards and 13 TDs over the past two seasons. His production dipped in 2017 in part because of erratic quarterback play. He has the speed to threaten in the vertical passing attack andthe toughness to make plays over the middle. St. Brown grades out as a future starter who contributes as a slot receiver as he develops his route-running and fills out his frame. He projects as a Day 2 pick and potential top-10 receiver in this class. St. Brown has the speed to threaten vertically and the toughness to make plays over the middle. He grades out as a future starter who contributes as a slot receiver while he develops.

Wilson caught 139 passes for 2,640 yards and 18 TDs in his two seasons at Boise State. He returned 31 kickoffs (23.9 yards per return) and 10 punts (13.2). He is still developing as a route-runner, but is a hard worker and shows the ability to locate soft spots in zones.

Wilson doesn't have an elite second gear and he's not an ankle-breaker, but he flashes the ability to make big plays. He's an above average vertical threat with a knack for making one-on-one plays downfield, and he shows good quickness and open-field instincts. Wilson also has a wide catching radius and shows above average ball skills.

He grades out as a sub-package slot receiver who competes for the kickoff return role early in his career. If he fills out his frame and develops as a route-runner he could develop into an adequate No. 2 receiver.

Wilson is an above-average vertical threat with a knack for making one-on-one plays downfield. He shows good quickness and open-field instincts and grades out as a sub-package slot receiver who could become an adequate No. 2.
Armstrong's length (30 1/8-inch arms) is a red flag for a corner, and he's not a ball hawk, but he has average size and above-average top-end speed.

Berrios, who emerged as a full-time starter as a senior in 2017, is undersized but has the change-of-direction skills and enough burst to separate from man-coverage. He's also willing to do the dirty work over the middle, where he'll need to make his living in the NFL. He doesn't have an elite second gear and he's not as much of a threat in the vertical passing game, but ran a very good 40-time of 4.44 at Miami's pro day. Berrios grades out as a sub-package slot receiver who competes for the starting punt returner role. Berrios, who emerged as a full-time starter as a senior in 2017, is undersized but has the change-of-direction skills and enough burst to separate from man coverage. He's also willing to do the dirty work over the middle, where he'll need to make his living in the NFL.

Thomas has excellent size with average top-end speed, long arms and massive hands. He was moved to WR for a portion of the 2017 season out of necessity, but he's a much better blocker than receiver. He flashes the ability to make contested catches, but has remedial route-running skills and his ball skills are inconsistent.

Thomas has a basketball background and intriguing skills, but is an in-line TE prospect for the NFL. Scouts have voiced concerns about the ability to trust him and his NFL ceiling is to make a roster as a reserve Y-TE who contributes in jumbo packages and on special teams. His value is in the late rounds or as a priority free agent.

Thomas has a basketball background and an intriguing skill set. He was moved outside to receiver out of necessity in 2017, but the reality is he's an in-line tight end prospect. He has some splash plays on tape that draw you in, but there's not enough consistency to his game.

Senat played two seasons at Wagner and started all 22 games. He was also a four-year basketball player there. Senat, who played four years of basketball at Wagner, played tight end for two years in high school and offensive tackle for two years in college. He's raw and needs to work on his technique, most notably his footwork in the run game. But he has the length (34 7/8-inch arms) and athletic ability to develop into an above-average pass blocker and effective run blocker.

Gossett is a powerful drive blocker with a nasty disposition and the ability to move defenders off the ball. He gets set quickly and anchors well in pass protection. He grades out as a reserve guard with some upside but will have to play with better balance and develop as a hand fighter to realize his upside. He projects as a Day 3 pick. Gossett is a powerful drive blocker with a nasty disposition and the ability to move defenders off the ball. He grades out as a reserve guard with some upside but will have to play with better balance and develop as a hand-fighter to reach his potential.

Kalambayi was a five-year player at Stanford, redshirting his freshman year. He saw action in 54 games, collecting 190 tackles, 28 TFL and 18.5 sacks. He started all 13 games in 2016. Kalambayi is an above-average tackler with good length and excellent top-end speed for a 3-4 OLB, but he needs to improve his ability to get off blocks.

Bozeman, a captain and two-year starting center at Alabama, has very good size, but short arms. He has a strong anchor,but really struggles moving laterally against quicker pass-rushers. Coachable with a great work ethic, Bozeman is a big, strong college center who might fit better at guard in the NFL. He's a classic overachiever who is unlikely to develop into an NFL starter and must show versatility to make it in the NFL. He projects as a Day 3 pick or priority free agent. Coachable with a great work ethic, Bozeman is a big, strong college center who might fit better at guard in the NFL. He's a classic overachiever who is unlikely to develop into an NFL starter and must show versatility to make it in the NFL.

Victor was once a promising prospect that we thought was capable of developing into a starting NFL linebacker. However, things really fell apart when he was injured versus USC in 2016. Victor proceeded to get overweight and out of shape. He was suspended twice during the 2017 season (once for a DUI charge) and lost his starting job. He will get a shot to make an NFL roster during training camp but it will likely be as an undrafted free agent. Victor was once a promising prospect that we thought was capable of developing into a starting NFL linebacker. However, things started to fall apart when he was injured against USC in 2016. He became overweight and out of shape, and was suspended twice during the 2017 season (once for a DUI charge) and lost his starting job.

Bierria is undersized and has some athletic/speed limitations. On the positive side, he has been a durable and productive three-year starter, he's a team leader and he loves the game. Bierria grades out as a reserve NFL WLB or WILB and he will need to contribute on special teams in order to stick on a team's 53-man roster. Projects as a Day 3 pick. Bierria is undersized and has some athletic/speed limitations. He's a team leader who loves the game and grades out as a reserve NFL WLB or WILB and will need to contribute on special teams to make a roster.

Aruna is a difficult evaluation. He tested exceptionally well as his arm length (34 inches), top-end speed and vertical (38.5 inches) are all outstanding for a defensive end that weighs less than 265 pounds. His tape and production don't match up with the talent, though. He's a developing hand fighter who doesn't make the most of his length at this point. He needs to develop a quick inside move. He has the strength to stack blockers and get off blocks as a run defender but again his pads rise and he gets pushed around at times. He fits best at RDE or LDE with the ability to kick inside to rush the passer.

Aruna grades out as a developmental edge defender with a high ceiling but isn't ready to make an immediate impact and is coming off a disappointing senior season.

Aruna tested exceptionally well, as his arm length (34 inches), top-end speed and vertical (38.5 inches) are all outstanding for a defensive end who weighs less than 265 pounds, but his tape and production don't match up with the talent. He grades out as a developmental edge defender with a high ceiling but isn't ready to make an immediate impact and is coming off a disappointing senior season.

Etling went 16-7 as LSU's starter the past two seasons with a 27:7 TD:INT ratio. He'll win over some teams with his work ethic and the way he protects the ball, but LSU runs a lot of max protect, play-action and roll outs that simplified his reads. Etling has the raw tools to mold, so a team could take a chance on him late, but he grades out a developmental backup who is a ways away from effectively running a pro-style offense. Etling has an NFL frame with a professional work ethic and above-average arm strength. He grades out a developmental backup who is a ways away from effectively running a pro-style offense.

McGough is a four-year starter who threw for 9,091 yards and 65 touchdowns at Florida International. He's a good athlete with a good frame, though his hands (9 1/8 inches) are on the smaller side. His 30:19 touchdown-to-interception ratio over the past two seasons isn't ideal.
Adams is a two-year starter and alpha leader with excellent football character. He's an undersized linebacker with short arms but has excellent upper body strength and good straight-line speed.

Kelly is a Washington transfer who recorded 53 tackles, one interception and 12 pass breakups in 12 starts last year. He's tall with average top-end speed, but his short shuttle (4.68) is a glaring red flag for a corner prospect.

Taylor had had some problems staying healthy and he started only eight games at Temple. He's undersized but has very good length, above-average upper body strength, a quick first step and closes well for his size.

Wims transferred from Hines Community College to Georgia in 2016 and broke out as a senior in 2017 with 720 yards on 45 catches with 7 TDs. He's a big possession receiver with a large catch radius and soft hands. Quick to pluck and transition upfield, he shows the ability to extend and make tough catches.

Wims has the occasional focus drop, lacks ideal vertical speed and is a bit of an upright runner who needs to develop more craftiness as a route-runner. By no means is he a game-breaker, but he does often make the first man miss.

Wims was a late-bloomer but emerged as Georgia's top pass-catcher as a senior. He grades out as a reserve with enough size and ball skills to push for a roster spot if he can add some value on special teams. He projects as a late-round pick.

Wims is a big possession receiver with a large catch radius and soft hands. A late bloomer, he emerged as Georgia's top pass-catcher as a senior and grades out as a reserve with enough size and ball skills to push for a roster spot if he can add value on special teams.

Downs finished his senior season with 65 tackles, 5.5 tackles for loss, three sacks and two interceptions even though he missed five-plus games with a season-ending injury. He's big and strong enough to develop into an effective between-the-tackles run-stopper.

Williams is a big back and graduate transfer from South Carolina who led Arkansas in rushing yards with 656 and rushing touchdowns with eight last year. He ran well for his size at the Arkansas pro day, but he doesn't have great initial quickness.

Poling is a four-year starter and team captain who played through injuries at Ohio. He has average length and size in addition to outstanding top-end speed and his 6.88 pro day three-cone time is a remarkable time for a linebacker.

Ateman, who had 59 catches for 1,156 yards and eight touchdowns is likely to draw comparisons to Tampa Bay's Mike Evans. Both are massive targets with wide a catch radius and the frame/speed to make plays on 50-50 balls downfield and in the red zone.

They rely on their strength to separate and shield defenders from the ball underneath. However, Evans put up far better numbers at Texas A&M and has a better size-speed combination than Ateman, whose medical is more of a concern (he broke his foot in July of 2016 and redshirted that season).

Ateman has the potential to develop into an effective No. 2 in an offense that values size over quickness like San Diego. He's not going to make many defenders miss after the catch and his top-end speed is a red flag for receivers.

Ateman is a massive target with a wide catch radius, and he makes plays on 50-50 balls. He could develop into an effective No. 2 in an offense that values size over quickness, but his top-end speed is a red flag.
Sanders has been up and down. He had by far his best season in 2016, when he connected on 12 of his 13 field goal attempts. But he has a strong leg and can handle kickoff duties.

Jacobs is a 'toolsy' prospect who finally broke out at linebacker in 2017. He spent most of his career as a standout special-teams player, which is where he will likely make his biggest impact early in his NFL career. If given enough time and good coaching, he could develop into a defensive contributor as a versatile linebacker. Jacobs projects as a Day 3 pick. Jacobs spent most of his career as a standout special-teams player, which is where he probably will make his biggest impact early in his NFL career. If given enough time and good coaching, he could develop into a defensive contributor as a versatile linebacker.

Howard is the first player in TCU history to lead the team in tackles for three consecutive seasons, and he topped the 100 mark in all three. At 211 pounds, he's vastly undersized for a linebacker and has short arms. He ran a 4.56 at his pro day and that's fast enough to consider moving him to safety.

Smith is a tight-hipped but fast inside linebacker prospect with average size and long arms. He has good instincts and should be a thumper in the run game. Two concerns are durability (coming off season-ending knee injury) and coverage limitations. He will either be drafted late or signed as a priority free agent. Smith is a tight-hipped but fast inside linebacker prospect with average size and long arms. He has good instincts and should be a thumper in the run game. Two concerns are durability (coming off season-ending knee injury) and coverage limitations.

Franklin is the second three-time captain in the history of Syracuse football, and he started every game over the past three seasons. He has shorter arms but outstanding top-end speed and upper body strength.

Scarbrough came on strong in Alabama's final three games of the 2016 season games with 46 carries for 364 yards and seven TDs before suffering a leg injury in the CFP title game. A big back with good top-end speed for his size, he runs behind his pads and his balance-on-contact is outstanding. He's a pick-and-slide runner who bounces off a lot of tackles, rarely taking negative runs.

Scarbrough has a nose for the sticks and the end zone with a high percentage of his carries resulting in first downs or scores. He's never going to be a route-running mismatch (just 21 catches in three seasons), but is capable as an underneath receiver and in pass pro.

He grades out as a by-committee starter in the NFL, where he can provide the 'power' element to a backfield. Durability concerns could cost him a bit on draft weekend, but he projects as a Day 2 pick.

A big back with good top-end speed for his size, Scarbrough runs behind his pads and his balance-on-contact is outstanding. He's a pick-and-slide runner who bounces off a lot of tackles, rarely taking negative runs, and he has shown a nose for the sticks and the end zone, with a high percentage of his carries resulting in first downs or scores.

Bawden broke his right hand and played most of the 2017 season with it in a club. He also was diagnosed with a fracture in his foot and unable to work out at the combine. He grades out as a hard-nosed throwback fullback who is a reliable check-down receiver and pass-blocker. He will likely need to check out medically and contribute on special teams to make an NFL roster. Bawden is an aggressive lead blocker who seeks out contact and gets good initial pop. He's an above-average pass-blocker who shows good awareness and does an above-average job of staying in front of his assignments. He's a reliable check down who catches the ball well.

Sieler faces a steep learning curve as an underclassman jumping from Division II to the NFL, but his tape is impressive. He grades out as a developmental scheme-versatile defensive end with good upside. He's an effective two-gap run-defender with the length (33 .75-inch arms) and strength to press blockers off his frame. He locates and tracks the ball well. He also slips blocks and makes plays in the backfield.
Bradley is an accurate deep snapper who earned a scholarship in the fall of 2016. He sustained a season-ending injury early in the 2015 season.

James spent four seasons at MTSU, redshirted his freshman year and went on to play in 31 games making 26 starts. He battled injuries in 2017 and only played in 5 games. He ended his career first all-time in receiving yards, receptions, and touchdowns at MTSU. He pulled in 244 receptions, for 3,261 yards, and 23 TDs all through the air. James is a redshirt junior who battled injuries in 2017 and played in only five games. He's an undersized receiver who dropped too many passes, but he has good top-end speed.

Stroman was a four-year player at Virginia Tech, who spent most of his freshman year returning punts. He played in 50 games with 28 starts at defensive back, racking up 60 tackles, 27 PBU and nine INTs. Stroman also averaged 8.72 yards per punt return for his career. Stroman has above-average ball skills and top-end speed, plus he returned four punts for touchdowns at Virginia Tech. His length (29 7/8-inch arms) is a red flag for corners. He's light and a below-average run defender.

Norton has the frame, enough quickness and strength to develop into an effective interior run-stuffer, but runs out of gas quickly and he might be carrying too much weight on his frame. He is a gap-plugger who grades out as a base NT in a 4-3 or 3-4 front and is a likely Day 3 pick. Norton has the frame and enough quickness and strength to become an effective interior run-stuffer, but he tires quickly and might be carrying too much weight. He is a gap-plugger who grades out as a base NT in a 4-3 or 3-4 front.
Crossen is undersized and raw, but he has excellent movement skills and tested well at Wake Forest's pro day where he ran a 4.33 40 and a 4.01 short shuttle.

Lawler is a three-year starter who had 39.5 tackles-for-loss and 20.5 sacks over the past three seasons. He is relentless chasing the run and rushing the passer. His outstanding football character, non-stop motor and frame make him a potential priority free agent, but he might not have the raw tools to succeed in the NFL and it's unlikely he gets drafted. His top-end speed, vertical and arm length are all red flags, and those are the numbers that correlate best with defensive ends succeeding in the NFL. Lawler is a three-year starter who is relentless chasing the run and rushing the passer. But his top-end speed, vertical and arm length are all red flags, and he might not have the raw tools to succeed in the NFL.

Clapp started 13 games at center in 2017 after playing guard the previous two seasons. He's had surgeries to repair a sports hernia, a labrum injury in his hip and a shoulder injury. He looked like a natural in his first season lining up at center, but his medical history, length and short shuttle time (4.92) raise questions about his ability to succeed in the NFL. Clapp grades out a reliable interior reserve who is unlikely to develop into a starter. Clapp has had surgeries to repair a sports hernia, a labrum injury in his hip and a shoulder injury. He looked like a natural in his first season lining up at center, but his medical history, length and short shuttle time (4.92 seconds) raise questions about his ability to succeed in the NFL.

Frazier was a four-year player who saw time in 42 games at Alabama. In 2017, he played in all 14 games of his senior season. In four seasons at Alabama, Frazier recorded 28 tackles, 2 sacks and 4.5 TFL. Frazier recorded 27 tackles, 3.5 tackles for loss and one sack over the past three seasons. But making plays isn't his game. He's a massive space-eater with the size and length to stack blockers and bolster a team's run defense.
Cooke is a big punter with enough leg strength to flip the field as a punter and drive the ball out of the end zone on kickoffs.

Donnerson possesses outstanding top-end speed and initial quickness in addition to good length. However, he should have dominated at the FCS level and his 2017 production doesn't match up with his natural ability.

Woodside was a three-year starter at Toledo. He's an underrated prospect because he's coming from the MAC and has below-average size. he's a highly competitive and tough QB with fast eyes, good accuracy, above average athleticism and adequate arm strength. Woodside grades out a solid NFL backup and he should prove to be a Day 3 value pick. Woodside is an underrated prospect because he's coming from the MAC and has below-average size. He's a highly competitive and tough QB with fast eyes, good accuracy, above-average athleticism and adequate arm strength.

Izzocaught 54 passes for 761 yards and six touchdowns in three full seasons. He's an aggressive blocker who struggles to separate and grades out as a No. 3 blocking tight end. He projects as a Day 3 pick. Izzo caught 54 passes for 761 yards and six touchdowns in three full seasons. He's an aggressive blocker who struggles to separate and grades out as a No. 3 blocking tight end.

Hill has the physical tools to develop into a starting cornerback in the NFL -- particularly in a press-man heavy scheme  but maturity issues will likely cause him to slip a bit in this year's draft. Has a little bit of ankle and hip tightness, but he's a sudden athlete with quick feet and enough top-end speed to offset. He's a second-round talent who will likely slide to the third or fourth round. Hill has the physical tools to develop into a starting cornerback in the NFL -- particularly in a press-man-heavy scheme. Has a little bit of ankle and hip tightness, but he's a sudden athlete with quick feet and enough top-end speed to offset.

Harrison appeared in seven games at Texas in 2013, where he was suspended multiple times (he reportedly failed multiple drug tests). He is a high risk-reward prospect with the tools to develop into a starting left tackle if he keeps his weight up, stays out of trouble, stays healthy and refines his technique. Harrison appeared in seven games at Texas in 2013, where he was suspended multiple times (he reportedly failed multiple drug tests). He didn't return to football until 2017 at West Georgiaand he turns 25 in October. Hereportedly lost substantial weight because of the flu leading up to the Senior Bowl and was unable to participate. Harrison is a high risk-reward prospect with the tools to develop into a starting left tackle if he keeps his weight up, stays out of trouble, stays healthy and refines his technique. He projects as a Day 2 pick.

Lazard is a two-time captain and four-year starter who caught 241 passes for 3,360 yards and 26 touchdowns. He also averaged 10.1 yards on 21 punt returns. He is a big target with slightly-above-average length, the strength to box out defenders and the body control to adjust to the ball while it's in the air.

Lazard can make contested catches and has a good feel for locating windows in zones. A strong blocker with a professional work ethic, he runs hard and has above average open-field instincts, but doesn't have the second gear to win a lot of foot races. As impressive as his hands are at times, he has a few too many focus drops.

Lazard is a big possession receiver who projects as a sub-package contributor in the NFL. He can create matchup problems in the red zone and will likely be picked early on Day 3.

Lazard can make contested catches and is a strong blocker who runs hard but doesn't have the second gear to pull away. He is a big possession receiver and projects as a sub-package contributor who can create matchup problems in the red zone.

Toliver has the size, speed and versatility to emerge as a contributing backup in the right scheme in the NFL. He needs to work on his recognition skills and technique in order to overcome some tightness in his hips. If based purely on talent, Toliver would project as a mid-round pick but durability and football character concerns will likely cause him to slide a bit on Day 3. Toliver has the size, speed and versatility to emerge as a contributing backup in the right scheme. However, he has some football character concerns and needs to work on his recognition skills and technique.

Jackson flashes the ability to smother receivers when he gets his hands on them at the line of scrimmage. But his technique and footwork are inconsistent. While teams will have questions regarding his dismissal from Florida and off-the-field decision-making, he has good football character. He has the potential to overcome his flaws and develop into an effective No. 2 corner, but he needs to get stronger in run support and will have problems with bigger receivers. Teams will have questions regarding his off-the-field decision-making, but Jackson has good football character and the potential to become an effective No. 2 corner. However, he needs to get stronger in run support and will have problems with bigger receivers.

Mata'afa finished his career with 47 tackles for loss (22.5 in 2017) and 22.5 sacks. He is a highly disruptive one-gap penetrator with an explosive first step, violent hands and lateral quickness. He projects as a fringe Day 2 pick and at 252 pounds he's expected to move to end or linebacker. Mata'afa finished his career with 47 tackles for loss (22.5 in 2017) and 22.5 sacks. He is a highly disruptive one-gap penetrator with an explosive first step, violent hands and lateral quickness.

Wadley is one of four backs in school history to rush for more than 1,000 yards in consecutive seasons, compiling 2,190 yards and 20 TDs over the past two years. He doesn't appear to have elite top-end speed but shows elite short-area quickness and lateral mobility on tape.

He explodes through creases, shakes defenders in the hole and flashes the ability to make multiple defenders miss in space.

He can improve his routes, and his size hinders him in pass pro, but he projects as a change-of-pace back who could develop into a dangerous weapon in the passing game and make the most of limited touches in a No. 2 role. He can also return kickoffs, making him a fringe Day 2 pick.

Wadley explodes through creases and can make multiple defenders miss. He projects as a change-of-pace back who could develop into a weapon in the passing game and make the most of limited touches in a No. 2 role.

McFadden grades out as a No. 3 or No. 4 corner in a press-heavy scheme at the next level, but he must stay on the outside. McFadden has exceptional size and length but just average athletic ability and marginal speed. His inconsistent focus, competitiveness and confidence are concerning. He's a likely early Day 3 pick. McFadden projects as a No. 3 or No. 4 corner in a press-heavy scheme who must play on the outside. He has exceptional size and length, but average athletic ability and marginal speed. His inconsistent focus, competitiveness and confidence are a concern.

Holland was a one-year starter who excelled at pressuring quarterbacks but he lacks some traits the vast majority of productive NFL edge defenders possess. He will likely get a chance as a late-round pick to be a back-end-of-the-roster type who contributes on special teams and carves out a niche as a situational pass-rusher. Holland started all 14 games in 2017 where he recorded 71 tackles, 18.5 TFL and 13 sacks. Holland was a one-year starter who excelled at pressuring QBs, but lacks some traits the vast majority of productive NFL edge defenders possess. He will likely get a chance to contribute on special teams and carve out a niche as a situational pass-rusher.

Coming off shoulder surgery, Thompson started just three of 13 games played in 2017and finished with 3.5 TFL and zero sacks. When healthy he can be a disruptive run-stopper who is at his best shooting gaps and slipping blocks. He has some upside as a pass-rusher, is versatile and in our opinion he's worth a gamble in the middle rounds if he checks out medically. Thompson can be a disruptive run-stopper who is at his best shooting gaps and slipping blocks. He has some upside as a pass-rusher, is versatile and could be worth a gamble in the middle rounds if he checks out medically.

Cobbs was suspended for Indiana's first game of 2016, then suffered a season-ending ankle injury in the second. He returned in 2017 with 72 catches for 841 yards and eight TDs. Tall, long and thickly built, he's a physical receiver who does a good job of using his long frame and hands to generate separation.

Cobbs has excellent body control and ball skills, shows really good focus and has an outstanding catch radius. He lacks suddenness and won't make many miss, but is strong runner after the catch. The biggest concern is his limited route tree, and he will need a lot of work to refine those skills.

Cobbs comes with some risk (off-field issues and raw routes) but has the talent and love for the game to develop into a good starter. He's a likely second-round pick.

Tall, long and thickly built, Cobbs is a physical receiver with excellent body control and ball skills, really good focus and an outstanding catch radius. He comes with some risk (off-field issues and raw routes) but has the talent and love for the game to develop into a good starter.

Johnson allows some initial separation at the top of the stem but he recovers well and he has the foot speed/burst to develop above-average short-area man cover skills. He's fast enough to turn and run with most receivers and he's effective playing trail technique. He reads the quarterback and shows good feel for route combination in off and zone coverage.

Johnson grades out as an above-average No. 3 CB, who can compete for the return roles and has the tools to develop into an effective cover man on special teams.

Johnson is fast enough to turn and run with most receivers and effective playing trail technique. He grades out as an above-average No. 3 CB who can compete for the return roles and become an effective cover man on special teams.

Kelly is a versatile defensive back who reads the quarterback, tracks the ball well and tends to make the most of his opportunities to make a play. He flashes the ability to get an early break on the ball, but he's overaggressive at times and vulnerable to double moves. He fits best in a zone-heavy scheme as his top-end speed is a red flag for a corner and he's too tight to mirror receivers getting in and out of breaks. Kelly is a versatile defensive back who reads the quarterback, tracks the ball well and tends to make the most of his opportunities to make a play. He flashes the ability to get an early break on the ball, but he's overaggressive at times and vulnerable to double-moves.

Welsh is a captain who started at both guard spotsand right tackle. He's been open about his battle with depression and missed 2015 spring drills to get help. He doesn't have great athletic ability or core strength, and his frame and length raise legitimate concerns about his ability to develop into an NFL starter. His best fit is at center as he's light for a guard and doesn't have the length to regularly play on the outside. Welsh doesn't project as an NFL starter, but could become a serviceable reserve in a zone-heavy scheme. His best fit is at center as he's light for a guard and doesn't have the length to regularly play on the outside.

Igwebuike is an interchangeable safety with good length and an NFL build. He has above-average straight line closing speed and he does a good job of limiting production after contact. He's not an elite playmaker, but has the smarts and skill set to develop into an effective No.3 and he projects as a core special teams' player. Igwebuike is an interchangeable safety with good length and an NFL build. He's not an elite playmaker but has the smarts and skill set to develop into an effective No. 3, and he projects as a core special-teams player.

Bellamy grades out as a backup 3-4 OLB in the NFL but he does play with good effort and discipline, and his special teams experience will help his cause. He projects as an earlier Day 3 pick. Bellamy grades out as a backup 3-4 OLB in the NFL, but he does play with good effort and discipline, and his special-teams experience will help his cause.

DeLuca is an instinctive inside linebacker who reads his keys and quickly locates the ball as a run defender. He reads the quarterback and shows above-average route recognition in underneath coverage. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks quicker and his performance on the bench (18 reps) at the combine is a red flag, but he plays outside the tackle box thanks to his instincts and effort. However, below-average closing speed and inconsistent pursuit angles lead to some missed tackles and missed plays.

DeLuca grades out as a reserve MLB or SILB with the potential to develop into a core special teams' player and he projects as a Day 3 pick.

Weathersby has the size and length to play guard and tested well for a guard in most areas, but his short shuttle (5.38) is a glaring red flag. He grades out as a backup guard in a run-heavy offense. Sullivan, a team captain, has shown the ability to disrupt receivers getting off the line, but he has marginal top-end speed. He has good balance and quick feet but doesn't have the burst or fluidity to regularly match up in underneath man. He grades out as a reserve corner in a zone heavy scheme and he'll need to make contributions on special teams. Scales is built like a weakside outside linebacker and plays like an inside linebacker. His frame and length will likely prevent him from developing into a starter but he has a chance to be an above-average backup WILB or WLB and core special teams contributor. In three seasons at Notre Dame, Adams rushed for 3,198 yards and 20 TDs and caught 41 passes for 336 yards and two TDs. He has a professional work ethic, quick feet for his size and flashes the ability to make effective jump cuts between the tackles. His vision is a question mark and he produced just 133 yards on 51 carries (2.6 yards per carry) with no TDs against Miami, Stanford and LSU late in the 2017 season. Adams grades out as a rotational back and will most likely need to contribute on special teams to make a roster. He projects as a Day 3 pick. Adams has a professional work ethic, quick feet for his size and the ability to make jump cuts between the tackles. His vision is a question mark, and he grades out as a rotational back who will most likely need to contribute on special teams to stick.

Wade shows above-average route recognition and he does an good job of limiting production after the catch in off and zone coverage. He has the length (32 3/8-inch arms) to effectively jam receivers at the line of scrimmage. He plays a little faster than his timed top-end speed, but he has average recovery speed and he risks getting beat over the top when he doesn't get safety help.

Wade grades out as an above-average No. 3 corner who fits best in zone-heavy scheme and has the potential to develop into a playmaker in the NFL.

Hearns had 24.5 TFL, 15 sacks and forced nine fumbles over the past two seasons. He's a good pass-rusher, but just an adequate run defender. Though he lacks ideal height, he has long arms, good stamina and in tapes we studied he played with a solid motor considering his high volume of snaps. He grades out as a sub-package contributor in the NFL. He could serve as a rush-end specialist in a 4-3, but his measurables are best suited for 3-4 OLB and he's at his best rushing the QB. Character concerns will likely push him to the final few rounds of the 2018 draft. Haley has above-average short-area man cover skills and is fast enough to run with receivers. His size is an obvious concern when it comes to matching up with bigger receivers but he's a scrappy competitor who doesn't back down. He shows good timing breaking up passes. He's an adequate tackler who chases with good effort and doesn't shy away from contact. Haley grades out as an above average sub-package corner who contributes on special teams.
