Roberts was a four-year player and two-year starter at Auburn, seeing action in 51 games and making 30 starts. He collected 2 INTs, 135 tackles and 12 PBU. He is a bit of an underrated prospect. He could provide versatility as a reserve free safety/cornerback. Though he's undersized, he has the quickness and speed needed to cover kickoffs in the NFL. He will either be a late-round selection or get a camp invite as an undrafted free agent. Roberts is a bit of an underrated prospect who could provide versatility as a reserve free safety/cornerback. Parris grades out as a versatile backup with enough foot speed to provide depth at both tackle spots and guard but is unlikely to develop into a starter on the outside. He has the potential to develop into a starting guard but his technique needs work, his tape is inconsistent and he's coming off a season-ending injury so he projects as a Day 3 pick. Burnett (team-high 86 catches last season) is a quicker-than-fast possession slot receiver who features good routes, soft hands and excellent ball skills. He grades out as a No. 3 or No. 4 receiver who flashes the ability to make tough, diving/extended catches and does a good job of plucking on the run.

He has an average catch radius, but doesn't win a high percentage of 50-50 balls and needs to get stronger. Burnett can make the first guy miss, but struggles at times to beat press and can be pushed around.

He doesn't show much elusiveness or top-end juice and needs to work on ball security. He projects as a mid-round pick.

Burnett is a possession slot receiver who runs good routes and displays soft hands and excellent ball skills. Though he can make the first guy miss, Burnett struggles at times to beat press coverage, and he can be pushed around.

Irwin is a three-year starter at left tackle who received a sixth year of eligibility after tearing an ACL in 2015. He grades out as a developmental guard with good size, length and range. However, his testing raises concerns about his ability to make the transition inside, he turns 26 in July and his injury history is a concern, He projects as a late-round pick or more likely a rookie free agent. Blanding has enough range to cover a deep half and he's big/fast enough to compete with tight ends in man coverage. He does a good job of locating the ball as a run defender and he does an average job of wrestling ball carriers to the ground. However, he's tight in his hips, which hinders his ability to match up with slot receivers and make one-on-one plays in space.

Blanding's frame, experience and production make him an intriguing Day 3 prospect but he projects as a reserve safety who will have to make considerable contributions on special teams.

For team's looking for bigger press-man cornerbacks, Meeks grades out as a backup who will need to also contribute on special teams to add value. Meeks projects as a Day 3 pick. Allen is understandably one of the most underrated prospects in this class due to his lack of game experience (only 15 collegiate starts) and unusual college path. For a team with a good quarterback coach and the ability to work with him as a QB3 for a while, Allen has intriguing upside. If not drafted in the late rounds, Allen will get a shot as a priority free agent. Fant has a lot of the tools you would find in a No. 3 NFL cornerback but his small frame and lack of length will be difficult to overcome. Fant's balance, foot speed and recovery burst make it tough to shake him at the line of scrimmage. He's fast enough to run with most receivers and he appears comfortable playing with his back to the line of scrimmage. We think he's worth the value of a Day 3 pick. Henderson is a versatile safety who tracks the ball well and changes directions well for his size but can be overaggressive and gets caught peeking into the backfield at times. He grades out as an interchangeable reserve safety and special teams' contributor with some upside. Teuhema played left tackle last year but he's a better fit at guard, which is where he's expected to line up in the NFL. Wells caught 34 passes for 427 yards and six TDs over the past two seasons. He has the size, strength and toughness to develop into an adequate in-line blocker with the ball skills to be a reliable check-down option. He grades out as a No. 3 blocking tight end. Adenyi grades out as a potential high-energy rotational RDE or more likely 3-4 OLB who has a knack for getting to the quarterback but his frame, length and below-average top-end speed for his size will almost certainly prevent him from developing into a starter -- and could prevent him from making an NFL roster. He projects as a late-round pick or rookie free agent. Adeniyi grades out as a potential high-energy rotational RDE or more likely 3-4 OLB with a knack for getting to the quarterback. However, his frame, length and below-average top-end speed for his size will likely prevent him from becoming a starter.

Weah caught 77 passes for 1,568 yards and 14 TDs over the past two seasons and led the team in receiving yards (698) and receiving TDs (4) in 2017. He has the size and enough speed to threaten vertically and flashes a second gear.

Though not an ankle-breaker, he's a smooth open-field runner who flashes the ability to make the first defender miss. Weah has a wide catching radius and knows how to box out, but is too inconsistent tracking the deep ball and on contested throws.

A captain, Weah is a developmental receiver with the frame and top-end speed to contribute in the NFL. He's proven capable of covering kicks, which he will need to do to keep a roster spot while he works on his route-running and ball skills. He compares favorably to the Bengals' Brandon LaFell and is a likely Day 3 pick.

Moore is a three-year starter who led the team in tackles all four seasons he played. He grades out as a backup weakside linebacker who will need to emerge as a core special-teamer in order to stick to a 53-man roster. Intangible and medical concerns will work against him, but he still could be drafted on Day 3. Moore grades out as a backup weakside linebacker who will need to emerge as a core special-teamer in order to stick on a 53-man roster. His intangibles and medical concerns will work against him.

Phillips is a redshirt senior who has played all five offensive line positions.He flashes a powerful punch, plays with an edge and shows the ability to bury his defender. However, he's also a below-average athlete who struggles to adjust to moving targets in space and mirror in pass pro. Phillips projects best at center andhas the potential to develop into an adequate reserve interior lineman, but he doesn't project as a starter. Joseph is a physical corner who limits production after the catch and plays downhill in run support. While he gets overaggressive and bites on the occasional double move, he shows above-average overall route recognition and he plays the ball not the man. A strong overall week at the Senior Bowl helped ease concerns about the level of competition he faced at Division III Dubuque. He's physical and tough competing for 50-50 balls, but he's lean with short arms so there are naturally concerns about ability to match up with bigger receivers in the NFL. Reaves is a three-year starter who had 20.5 tackles-for-loss, 1.5 sacks and eight interceptions. He moved from corner to safety in 2017 and fills hard against the run, but isn't big enough to play in the box on a consistent basis. He doesn't have the burst and fluidity to blanket slot receivers and is not fast enough to play centerfield in the NFL. Reaves has the toughness, work ethic and enough size to develop into a core special teams' player and provide depth in a press/zone heavy-scheme. He projects as a late Day 3 pick. Atkins is a thick, stout run-stuffer at his best occupying blockers. He has a strong anchor and is tough to move, but lacks suddenness and doesn't get much push as a pass-rusher. He has the ability to develop into a one-or-two down NT in the NFL, but offers next to nothing as a pass-rusher and is likely to be drafted on Day 3. Wallace grades out as a reserve cornerback who will need to continue to get stronger, refine his technique and demonstrate special teams value in order to stick in the NFL. Grayson is an unpolished route runner but he has the burst to separate from man. He's tough and quick but he's not an ankle breaker and he's not much of a threat to pull away after the catch. Webb is an opportunistic playmaker who tracks the ball well and a downhill run stopper who fills with purpose and tends to wrap when he's able to square up. Litton is a throwback pocket passer with above-average arm strength and an NFL frame. He's decisive and he gets the ball out of his hands quickly when his first option is there. He flashes above-average accuracy and drops hurt his completion percentage, but he's inconsistent with his placement and misses occasionally.

Litton grades out as potential backup with some upside based on the tape but could go undrafted considering his limited mobility, inconsistent decision making, medical history and off-the-field concerns.

Mahon has starting experience at both tackles and guards, but his versatility doesn't translate well to the NFLbecause he doesn't have the length or athleticism to regularly line upoutside. He's a grinder and has shown the ability to compete with talented defensive linemen like Michigan's Mo Hurst and Ohio State's Dre'Mont Jones. Mahon fits best in a power-heavy scheme and might never develop into a starter, but he has the tools to become a reliable interior backup. Benkert is a big-armed developmental project who makes some beautiful throws and flashes some playmaking ability on the move but his accuracy and decision-making are too erratic for our liking. He is not likely to develop into a good NFL starter and we think his upside is as a solid NFL backup. Benkert is likely to be a Day 3 selection. Flowers' versatility might be his biggest strength. Flowers, who didn't miss a game in four seasons, is a better football player than athlete and could develop into an effective lead blocker who makes an impact on special teams.

Lotulelei is a stout interior run-stuffer whose low center of gravity and size make it tough to move him off the ball with one man. Gates rarely takes false steps, is athletic and quick enough to cut off linebackers, gets set quickly and has an effective kick step. Lingen is a true senior and two-time team captain who finished his career with 47 catches for 558 yards and five TDs. He missed several games over the past three seasons with various injuries. Lingen is a tough receiver andfights for yards, but is not much of a big-play threat for an F prospect and lacks the size and power to be an effective in-line blocker. Lingen could go undrafted considering his lack of production over the past two seasons and his medical history, but the promise he showed as an F tight prospect early in his career should earn him a chance to compete in an NFL training camp.

Lingen is a true senior and two-time team captain who finished his career with 47 catches for 558 yards and five TDs. Lingen is a tough receiver and fights for yards but is not much of a big-play threat for an F prospect and lacks the size and power to be an effective in-line blocker.

Jones-Smith suffered a traumatic leg injury that forced him to miss the 2015 season and he started just one game in 2016. In 2017 he started nine of the 12 games he played, all at right tackle. He has above average sizes for a tackle with excellent length (37') and big hands (10 3/8'). He also has adequate first-step quickness but doesn't move defenders off the ball and he struggles to adjust to moving targets in the run game.Jones-Smith's knee injury and lack of starting experience will likely cause him to go undrafted, but a team could draft him late or sign him a rookie free agent because he has rare upside. Jones-Smith has adequate first-step quickness but doesn't move defenders off the ball, and he struggles to adjust to moving targets in the run game. A knee injury and lack of starting experience are concerning, but he has upside.

Dooley has athletic limitations but he has enough size, strength, toughness and football intelligence to compete for a reserve OLB job in a 3-4 front in the NFL. His best chance of making a 53-man roster spot will be with his special teams contributions, which is an area he excelled in at Wisconsin. Dooley is likely to be drafted in the late rounds. Dooley has athletic limitations, but he has enough size, strength, toughness and football intelligence to compete for a reserve OLB job in a 3-4 front in the NFL. His best chance of making a 53-man roster spot will be with his special-teams contributions, which is an area he excelled in at Wisconsin.

Wicker was a three-year starter who has experience lining up on the outside and the inside. He has a low center of gravity and flashes the ability to get under blockers, but gets overwhelmed and pushed around at times. He's a better football player than athlete but concerns about his frame and position fit will likely cause him to drop to the late Day 3 range. Wicker was a three-year starter who has experience lining up on the outside and the inside. He's a better football player than athlete, but there are concerns about his frame and position fit.

McDermott started the final 34 games of his career with 17 starts at left tackle, 15 at left guard and two at right tackle. He doesn't have the length or athletic ability to hold his own working against edge rushers and grades out as a potential interior backup who is unlikely to develop into a starter. McDermott started the final 34 games of his career with 17 starts at left tackle, 15 at left guard and two at right tackle. He doesn't have the length or athletic ability to hold his own working against edge rushers and grades out as a potential interior backup who is unlikely to develop into a starter.

Chandler grades out as a reserve safety with the potential to develop into a core special teams player. His combine testing and frame could result in him going undrafted, but his toughness and determination on and off the field make it difficult to rule him out from finding a way to make an NFL roster. Chandler grades out as a reserve safety with the potential to develop into a core special-teams player. His combine testing and frame could result in him going undrafted, but his toughness and determination on and off the field make it difficult to rule him out from finding a way to make an NFL roster.

Bright started 16 games at left guard, one at right guard, six at right tackle and two at left tackle over the past two seasons. He's a grinder who missed time with injuries in 2016 and did not work out at the combine. He doesn't have the length or athletic ability to regularly protect the edge in the NFL and grades out as a reserve guard. He projects as a Day 3 pick. Bright is a grinder who missed time with injuries in 2016 and did not work out at the combine. He doesn't have the length or athletic ability to regularly protect the edge in the NFL and grades out as a reserve guard.

Davis is an instinctive playmaker who reads quarterbacks, plays the ball not the man and has above average ball skills. But he doesn't play quite as fast as his timed top-end speed -- he ran a 4.44 40 at his pro day -- and his short shuttle time (4.50) is a red flag for a corner. Worley's ceiling appears to be a backup who provides depth on the outside in a base four-man front or at WILB in a base three-man front. He also has the mentality to become a core special teams contributor. His football character, experience lining up at several positons and tackling give him late-round value. Wieneke lacks initial burst off the line, but has build-up speed. He is worth a late-round pick as a developmental matchup piece  possibly as a slot receiver  with excellent size. Wieneke lacks initial burst off the line, but has build-up speed. He is worth a pick as a developmental matchup piece -- possibly as a slot receiver -- with excellent size.

Facyson's size and length gives him value for certain NFL teams. He will need to play in a scheme that highlights his ability to press and re-route wide receivers, while also protecting him vertically with over-the-top safety help. For those teams, Facyson will have Day 3 value. Facyson's size and length gives him value for certain NFL teams. He will need to play in a scheme that highlights his ability to press and reroute wide receivers, while also protecting him vertically with over-the-top safety help.

Henderson is a disruptive run defender with good initial quickness and active hands. He tends to shoot his hands inside, he does an above average job of locating the blocks and he gets off some blocks in time to make the play but his arms (32 3/8') are on the shorter side and he gets engulfed on some plays. He flashes some upside as a pass rusher. He grades out as a one-gap 3-technique with the potential to develop into an effective rotational player. He projects as a fringe Day 2 pick based on the tape. However, medical, behavioral and testing red flags drop him into the late-round/rookie free-agent range. Hearn is a two-year starter at left guard. He is a durable college player with average size and good football intelligence. His testing results raise concerns and he grades out as a backup offensive guard who projects as a late-round pick or rookie free agent. Hearn is a durable college player with average size and good football intelligence. His testing results raise concerns, and he grades out as a backup offensive guard.

Allen, a four-year starter, gets into position and flashes the ability to generate above average initial surge in the run game but has an average overall powerbase and falls off blocks. His arm length (32 5/8') and short shuttle (4.82) are red flags but he's a better football player than tester. Matthews is a good-sized strong safety who is at his best supporting the run, but there are some red flags regarding his personal and football character. He grades out as a potential reserve strong safety in the NFL but will likely only stick if he provides contributions covering kicks on special teams. He's a likely late-round pick or priority free agent. Matthews is a good-sized strong safety who is at his best supporting the run, but there are some red flags regarding his personal and football character. He grades out as a potential reserve strong safety in the NFL but will likely only stick if he provides contributions covering kicks on special teams.

Pringle lacks ideal polish at this point, but has the change of direction and quickness to develop above-average separation skills. He flashes the ability to snatch the ball out of the air and make contested catches. The problem is he drops passes that he gets his hands on and he didn't look like a natural pass-catcher on tape or at the combine. He has enough top-end speed to threaten vertically and he reaches his top-end speed quickly after the catch.

He projects as a Day 3 pick based on the tape and whether or not teams feel that his off-the field problems are behind him will play a big role in where he gets taken.

Shelton grades out a backup center. Concerns about his frame and ability to play guard could cause him to go undrafted. Shelton grades out a backup center. There are concerns about his frame and ability to play guard.

Reyes is a four-year starter who finished his career with 225 tackles, 19 TFL and 5 INTs. He has the range to cover a deep half but doesn't have the fluidity or burst to mirror quick-twitch slot receivers. He's an above-average tackler who provides a physical presence over the middle. His injury history could cause some teams to take him off their boards but he grades out as an above average backup safety with the potential to develop into a starter based off the tape. He projects as a Day 3 pick. Reyes, a four-year starter, is an above-average tackler who provides a physical presence over the middle. Wilson has the initial quickness, lengthand enough size to develop into a disruptive interior run defender, and heflashes as a pass-rusher. There's a lot to like about his upside as arotational three-technique, he has experience playing on the outside and hasthe frame to move to 3-4 DE. However, his sub-par production and inconsistenttechnique are enough to push him into the late Day 3 range. Wilson has the initial quickness, length and enough size to develop into a disruptive interior run-defender, and he flashes as a pass-rusher. There's a lot to like about his upside as a rotational 3-technique, he has experience playing on the outside and has the frame to move to 3-4 DE.

Baugh missed three games early in his career because of suspensions following two separate charges for underage drinking, and scouts have concerns about his accountability, work ethic and maturity.

He is a big target with big mitts, but he's average at best as a route-runner and we question his ability to separate from NFL man coverage. He's fast enough to make the occasional play downfield, but a marginal in-line blocker.

Baugh is a developmental F prospect with the potential to progress into an adequate No. 3 tight end. He projects as a late-round pick or rookie free agent.

Baugh is a big target with big mitts, but he's average at best as a route runner, and we question his ability to separate from NFL man coverage. He is a developmental F prospect with the potential to progress into an adequate No. 3 tight end.

Dickerson played four years at UCLA and appeared in 44 games, making 16 starts. He saw most of his time at the latter end of his career when he started 15 of 19 games. He tallied 95 tackles, 1.5 sacks and 7 TFL. Dickerson played four years at UCLA and appeared in 44 games, making 16 starts, and tallying 95 tackles, 1.5 sacks and 7 TFL. He saw most of his time at the latter end of his career when he started 15 of 19 games.

Richard is a shifty runner with a good center of gravity and quick feet who can string multiple cuts together. Quicker than fast, he's a smaller back with marginal power and goes down too easily. He's a tough and willing blocker but lacks the size and strength to sustain.

Richard has some immaturity and entitlement issues according to multiple scouts and grades out as a fringe reserve who is likely to get a shot as a priority free agent.

Cothran has the quick first step and length to develop into a disruptive run-stopper and adequate pass-rusher. However, he gets pushed around at times in the run game. He doesn't show a variety of pass-rush moves and struggles to counter when he doesn't win with his first move. He grades out as a potential reserve and projects as a late-round pick or rookie free agent. Cothran has the quick first step and length to develop into a disruptive run-stopper and adequate pass-rusher. However, he gets pushed around at times in the run game and doesn't show a variety of pass-rush moves.

Goolsby caught 68 passes for 724 yards and five TDs over the past three seasons. He blocks to the echo of the whistle, but is not much of a big-play threat. Florida's sub-par quarterback play hurt his production, but he's an F tight end who isn't enough of a receiving threat to overlook his deficiencies as a blocker and projects as a Day 3 pick or rookie free agent. Goolsby caught 68 passes for 724 yards and five touchdowns over the past three seasons, but he doesn't have the burst transitioning out of breaks to regularly separate from man coverage. He's an F tight end who isn't enough of a threat as a receiver to overlook his deficiencies as a blocker.

Jackson played three seasons at Jacksonville State. He started in 22 out of 38 games and recorded 128 tackles, 20.5 sacks, and 40 TFL. Jackson earned Ohio Valley Conference defensive player of the year award in 2017. Jackson played three seasons at Jacksonville State and started in 22 out of 38 games and recorded 128 tackles, 20.5 sacks and 40 TFL. He earned the Ohio Valley Conference defensive player of the year award in 2017.

Williams has shown above average stopping power as a tackler, but he doesn't have the change-of-direction skills to regularly match up with backs in man coverage and he doesn't offer much as a pass rusher. An undersized prospect with below average length and durability concerns, he has the potential to develop into a core special teams' player and adequate reserve. Williams has shown above-average stopping power as a tackler, but he doesn't have the change-of-direction skills to regularly match up with backs in man coverage, and he doesn't offer much as a pass-rusher. An undersized prospect with below-average length and durability concerns, he has the potential to develop into a core special-teams player and adequate reserve.

Gilmore had 12.5 TFL and 9.5 sacks (7.5 in 2017) over the past three seasons. He's a big-bodied Day 3 NT prospect with good size and adequate strength, but marginal speed and athleticism. He lacks range as a run defender and offers very little as a pass-rusher, but could compete for the backup nose tackle spot in a 3-4 defense. Gilmore is a big-bodied nose tackle prospect with good size and adequate strength, but marginal speed and athleticism. He lacks range as a run defender and offers very little as a pass-rusher but could compete for the backup nose tackle spot in a 3-4 defense.

Lampkin is a massive interior run-stopper with outstanding length (35 ') but two suspensions, just two years of college football and his ability to control his weight are all concerns. He's shown the ability to overpower centers and collapse the pocket but he's a better run defender than pass-rusher. Lampkin is a massive interior run-stopper with outstanding length (35 .25 inches) but two suspensions, just two years of college football and his ability to control his weight are all concerns. He has shown the ability to overpower centers and collapse the pocket, but he's a better run-defender than pass-rusher.

Lundblade developed into a very efficient and reliable three-year starting center at Oklahoma State. A former walk-on, he had his best season as a senior in 2017. Unfortunately, his upside is limited due to a combination of below-average size and mobility. He is likely to sign as a priority free agent. Lundblade, a former walk-on, developed into a very efficient and reliable three-year starting center at Oklahoma State. Unfortunately, his upside is limited due to a combination of below-average size and mobility.

DiLauro primarily played tackle, but lined up at every positon except center as a senior andwas also usedas a blocking tight end. As versatile as he was, the biggest concern is position fit as his arm length (33 3/8') is a red flag at tackle.He projects as a versatile reserve and ideally he learns to snap, so he can also provide depth at center for a zone-heavy scheme. Di Lauro is a better fit at guard than tackle, and it's unlikely he develops into a starter. He's a late-round prospect or priority free agent. DiLauro primarily played tackle but lined up at every positon except center as a senior and was also used as a blocking tight end. As versatile as he was, the biggest concern is position fit as his arm length (33 3/8 inches) is a red flag at tackle.

Nall is a big back with the strength to push the pile when he doesn't get a seam. He's by no means an ankle-breaker, but has quick feet for his size. His test results are quick for the position and an accurate reflection of what he shows on tape. He's a reliable check-down option and an above average pass-blocker who grades out as a complementary backup with the skills to contribute in short-yardage situations and in the passing game. Nall is a big back with the strength to push the pile when he doesn't get a seam. He's a reliable check-down option and an above-average pass-blocker who grades out as a complementary backup with the skills to contribute in short-yardage situations and in the passing game.

Fatu grades out as a backup nose tackle in the NFL. He can be effective versus the run but does not offer much as a pass rusher and projects as a late-round pick. Fatu grades out as a backup nose tackle in the NFL. He can be effective versus the run but does not offer much as a pass-rusher.

Pierce, a two-year starter, is quick to diagnose run and step up but his height hinders his ability to track the ball and recognize play-action. He reads the quarterback when he drops into coverage but he doesn't have the fluidity or burst transitioning out of breaks to match up with backs in man coverage. Pierce, a two-year starter, is quick to diagnose run and step up, but his height hinders his ability to track the ball and recognize play-action. He reads the quarterback when he drops into coverage, but he doesn't have the fluidity or burst transitioning out of breaks to match up with backs in man coverage.

Bennett, who has started every game the past three seasons, is an adequate positional blocker who rarely takes false steps and fights to sustain in the run game. He's capable of making the line calls and does a good job of picking up blitzes in pass protextion, but his weight raises concerns about his ability to anchor in the NFL. Bennett, who has started every game the past three seasons, is an adequate positional blocker who rarely takes false steps and fights to sustain in the run game. He's capable of making the line calls and does a good job of picking up blitzes in pass protextion, but his weight raises concerns about his ability to anchor in the NFL.

O'Connell started all 26 games during his final two seasons at left guard. He has a massive frame and looks like a tackle playing guard. College opponents struggled to get around him, but more powerful NFL pass-rushers will chew him up.O'Connell is a college guard with exceptional height, bulk and length, but can he develop into an NFL right tackle? If not, it seems unlikely that he will fit at guard. He grades out as a late-round developmental prospect. O'Connell started all 26 games during his final two seasons at guard, and he has exceptional height, bulk and length. While college opponents struggled to get around him, more powerful NFL pass-rushers will chew him up, so he'll need to develop into a right tackle to play at the NFL level.

Ferguson flashes above-average touch and he displays good overall accuracy. He's mentally tough and he has delivered multiple times in the clutch. However, he's an erratic decision maker who puts the ball in harm's way too much. He faces a steep learning curve as he plays in a passer-friendly shotgun heavy spread scheme that simplifies reads and doesn't ask him to make a lot of adjustments at the line of scrimmage. He has below-average arm strength, and while he has the athletic ability to buy time in the pocket he can improve his ball security.

Ferguson doesn't have a high ceiling but his potential to develop into a serviceable backup in a West Coast scheme makes him a potential Day 3 pick.

Ferguson shows above-average touch and good overall accuracy, but he's an erratic decision-maker who puts the ball in harm's way too much. He doesn't have a high ceiling but has the potential to develop into a serviceable backup in a West Coast scheme.

Badet has the tools to become a sub-package receiver who competes for the kickoff return role (he returned 30 in college, averaging 21.9 yards). Badet's outstanding burst and top-end speed make him a threat to take the top off the coverage and pull away after the catch.

However, he's a lean receiver with below-average ball skills, and there's room for improvement with his routes. He runs hard after the catch and gives adequate effort as a blocker, but ball security is a concern.

Badet is a candidate for the practice squad as he needs to fill out his frame and improve his ball skills, but his explosiveness could get him drafted late.

Badet's outstanding burst and top-end speed make him a threat to take the top off the coverage, but he's a lean receiver with below-average ball skills, and ball security is a concern. He has the tools to become a sub-package receiver who competes for the kickoff return role (he returned 30 in college, averaging 21.9 yards).

Toth grades out as a potential reserve tackle or blocking tight end. His two-year commitment to the Army, below-average measurables and the scheme he played in could cause him to go undrafted. However, his toughness, work ethic and impeccable intangibles could cause a team to draft him on Day 3.

Cabinda is a captain who takes a professional approach to preparation. He is a downhill run-stopper who wraps and drives though contact when he's able to square up. He grades out as a reserve who bolsters a team's short-yardage and goal line defenses while making his biggest impact on special teams.

Thomas grades out as a reserve weakside linebacker in a 4-3 scheme and he will need to make significant contributions on special teams to maintain a roster spot. Likely a late-round pick or priority free agent.

LaCouture, who had 8.5 TFL and 6 sacks in 2017, is tall with a somewhat lean frame, big hands but short arms for a DT. He has good awareness but is a limited athlete. An overachiever, he grades out as a fringe reserve best suited to play 5-technique in an odd front. He will need to show his worth on special teams to compete for a roster spot and will either be a late-round pick or a priority free agent.

Williams was overshadowed sharing the backfield with Leonard Fournette and Derrius Guice, but did rush 145 times for 820 yards and nine TDs and catch 23 passes for 331 yards in 2017. He was LSU's co-MVP despite not being a starter and is a better football player than tester. Williams is an effective short-yardage runner who grades out as No. 3 back with limited upside. He will likely need to contribute on special teams to make a roster, and projects as a late-round prospect.

Malone started 18 games at left tackle over the past two seasons and missed six with a knee injury in 2017. The son of NBA Hall of Famer Karl Malone, he put off his goal of becoming a U.S. Marshal to return to LSU in 2017 and there's some concern that he'll opt for a career in law enforcement over the NFL. His performance on the bench (15 reps of 225 pounds) is a glaring red flag and he projects better on the inside than he does at tackle. Malone grades out as a potential versatile interior reserve.
Summers grades out as a versatile reserve defensive back that needs to make substantial contributions on special teams to make an NFL roster.
Rotimi played four seasons at Old Dominion and appeared in 46 games making 33 starts. In 46 games, Rotimi piled up 139 tackles, 26.5 TFL and 19 sacks.

Carrington caught 15 TD passes in parts of three seasons at Oregon, where he was suspended for the championship game of the 2014 season and the first six games of 2015 following a positive drug test. Oregon then dismissed him after an arrest for allegedly driving under the influence before the 2017 season. He transferred to Utah where he caught 70 passes for 980 yards and six TDs. He didn't run at the combine, but has the playing speed to threaten vertically. Carrington grades out as a No. 4 or No. 5 NFL receiver and his tape warrants Day 3 consideration from teams that feel he's put his off-field troubles behind him. Carrington didn't run at the combine but has the playing speed to threaten vertically. He grades out as a No. 4 or No. 5 NFL receiver, and his tape warrants consideration from teams that feel he has put his off-field troubles (multiple suspensions, arrest for allegedly driving under the influence) behind him.
Quiero is a strong safety prospect whose ball skills, frame, strong 2017 campaign and potential to develop into a core special teams contributor could persuade a team to take him late.

Henderson averaged 26.6 yards on 73 kickoff returns with four TDs, and 13.4 yards on 37 punt returns with three TDs for his career. However his carries dropped from 60 in 2016 to 36 in 2017, and one of the reasons he declared for the draft is he didn't want to risk seeing his production drop again next year.

He is a dangerous return man with an above average blend of burst, open-field instincts and balance -- a threat when he gets the ball in space. The downside is he's a small target and a raw route-runner with some tightness in his hips, and he's not much of a vertical threat.

Henderson hasn't shown enough to feel comfortable with him making significant contributions on offense and he needs to do a better job of taking care of the ball, but he has value as a return man and could be drafted late.

Phillips was a productive college receiver who showed the ability to break initial contact after the catch. But he is a better route runner than athlete and he doesn't appear to have the burst or fluidity to regularly separate from man coverage at the NFL level. He grades out as a sub-package receiver with a low ceiling and medical concerns.

Nicknamed the Hammering Panda, Hill is an aggressive lead blocker with the size and strength to knock defenders back. He moved from tight end to fullback before the 2016 season and scored 16 TDs (13 rushing) over the past two seasons. He drops passes that he gets his hands on and runs high, but he runs hard and has the strength to pick up tough yards.

Hill has the potential to be an effective fullback and the versatility to line up at tight end, but will need to contribute on special teams. He projects as a late-round pick or priority free agent.

Jones was a five-year player at Arkansas State, who redshirted his first season due to injury. Jones played in 48 games with 36 starts. He was active, bringing in 180 tackles, 44.5 TFL, 42 sacks and forced 10 fumbles. Jones nearly broke the FBS sack record (44).

Allen finished 9-12 as a starter over the past two seasons with a 35:20 TD:INT ratio. He is an undersized quarterback who takes some big hits and suffered an injury to his throwing shoulder last year, plus he has below average arm strength and just functional pocket mobility. Allen projects as an undrafted free agent.

Hicks, a two-year starter, is an undersized back with average speed. He has very good ball skills, snatching it away from his frame like a receiver, and runs above average routes for a running back. He's a bit of a finesse runner, but is a twitchy athlete with elusiveness who can make defenders miss in the hole.

Hicks has inconsistent vision, can be impatient and does not do a good enough job of sensing cutback lanes or setting up blocks. He grades out as a backup who will need to contribute on special teams to stick and is a likely Day 3 pick.

Gives solid effort as a blocker, but his technique can improve. Good football intelligence and an excellent student. Capable of competing for a roster spot as a No. 3 TE. Keizer will likely be a late-round pick or priority free agent in the 2018 draft.

Murray finished the 2018 season with a 12-2 record as a starter, completing 69 percent of his passes en route to the 2018 Heisman Trophy. Murray was the No. 9 overall pick by the Oakland Athletics in the 2018 MLB draft. If selected in the first round of the NFL draft, Murray would become the first athlete to be selected in the first round of both drafts. He is an aggressive playmaker but also displays good overall decision-making skills and shows poise under pressure. Murray has fast eyes when making full-field progression reads. He displays natural touch and timing as a passer, throwing accurately from a variety of different arm angles. He really excels at off-balance throws but he gets into trouble when he falls off of throws, typically when the pocket is collapsing. He has a quick trigger and a strong arm. There is an elite combination of quickness and speed, and he is arguably the most explosive QB prospect since Michael Vick. He does an excellent job of sensing defenders and protecting his undersized frame by sliding. His eyes drop when scrambling at times, which leads to him missing some open targets. In the right system, Kyler can be a good NFL starter and an electrifying playmaker at the quarterback position. But there are unique risks if using a first-round pick on Murray, including his lean frame, his lack of experience and his option to bail on football in pursuit of a promising baseball career at any moment. -- March 19, 2019 Murray is an aggressive playmaker with a strong arm, quick release and elite quickness, yet he is also a sound decision-maker who stays poised under pressure and isn't easily rattled by mistakes. He throws the ball accurately from a variety of arm angles and excels at making off-balance throws. Arizona hired Kliff Kingsbury to fix the NFL's worst offense, and he has a reputation for developing young quarterbacks, most notably Patrick Mahomes at Texas Tech. While there's an argument for sticking with last year's first-round pick (Josh Rosen) with that in mind, giving Kingsbury the player who best fits his system makes more sense -- and Kingsbury has long been enamored with Murray's skill set. Kingsbury will adapt his offense to his quarterback, so the more dynamic the QB, the more dynamic the offense -- and Murray is the most dynamic QB in this class. Still, the offensive line needs to play better than it did last season for Murray to realize his considerable potential. -- Steve Muench

Bosa is long and powerful, with the same great torso flexibility of his brother, Joey of the Los Angeles Chargers. He has a natural feel as a pass rusher and knows how to rush half-a-man. He plays with shock in his hands, even if he isn't yet at his brother's hand usage level. Bosa is very active versus the run -- he is quick into the blockers' pads, locks out, locates and then disengages in a flash. The former Buckeye has a great motor and just outstanding natural football instincts, knowing where the ball is at all times. He is an elite talent, projecting best as a 4-3 DE, but he's scheme versatile. Bosa is highly likely to be a top-10 pick. -- May 10, 2018 Bosa is an outstanding run-defender and pass-rusher with good shock in his hands. He gets into the blockers' pads, locks out, locates and disengages in a flash. He has great natural feel as a pass-rusher and shows the ability to win in many ways. San Francisco tied for 22nd in the NFL with 37 sacks last season, and the defense allowed 35 passing touchdowns compared to two interceptions -- the worst ratio in a season in NFL history. Solomon Thomas (2017 first-round pick) is reportedly on the trading block after failing to live up to expectations the past two seasons. Adding the most talented pass-rusher in this class to line up opposite trade acquisition Dee Ford fills a pressing need as a result. The 49ers get the top prospect on our board with the second pick. -- Steve Muench

Williams dominated some really good offensive linemen and his best performances were in Alabama's biggest games (LSU, Georgia, and Oklahoma). He dominated arguably the best offensive line in the country (Oklahoma) before re-injuring his hand prior to halftime. He is stout versus the run and shows the ability to anchor versus double teams. He grades out as an immediate NFL starter and should quickly develop into an interior menace. He's a likely top-5 pick in the 2019 NFL draft. Williams is a well-built defensive tackle with the first-step quickness and strength to advance as a pass-rusher while engaged with an offensive lineman. He rarely loses one-on-one and shows the ability to anchor against double-teams in the running game. He played his best against the best competition in Alabama's biggest games. Taking the best available player and pairing him with a respected defensive coordinator like Gregg Williams is a good way to address a defense in need of an overhaul. Gregg Williams is reportedly staying with the 3-4 base defense, so Quinnen Williams likely will take over as the starter at nose tackle. If that's the case, he will bolster the run defense, and he should be able to win one-on-one matchups on downs with pass-heavy tendencies. Steve Muench

Ferrell started all 44 games the last three seasons, collecting 167 tackles, 50 tackles for loss and 27 sacks. He has an above average size-speed combination with average arm length and bigger hands. Hand usage is Ferrell's special trait. He shows enough strength and flexibility to advance rush while engaged, but rarely overwhelms OTs with speed-to-power moves. Ferrell has good closing burst to the QB. He's a solid run defender who sets a hard edge and flashes the ability to make plays in the backfield. Clemson drops him into coverage enough to get a good feel for his ability to move in space and he moves well enough to transition to 3-4 OLB in the NFL. Ferrell plays a lot of snaps and displays a good motor. He's an edge-rusher with very good -- but not elite -- physical tools. He grades out as an every-down NFL starter who's scheme versatile (4-3 DE and/or 3-4 OLB). -- Feb. 26, 2019 Ferrell is an efficient and effective hand fighter. He has the initial quickness, flexibility and closing speed to stress the offensive tackle as a pass-rusher. He sets a hard edge and flashes the ability to disrupt plays in the backfield as a run-defender. He's versatile enough to play defensive end and/or 3-4 outside linebacker. Addressing the defensive end position and the pass rush makes sense considering the Raiders were dead last with 13 sacks last season -- 17 fewer than any other team. In fact, six individual players had more sacks than the Raiders as a team in 2018. The argument also can be made that Ferrell is a better fit for the Raiders' scheme than Kentucky's Josh Allen. Ferrell is the 21st-ranked player on our board, though, so this is a bit of a reach here. -- Steve Muench

White was a standout LB for three seasons at LSU, recording 286 tackles, 29 tackles for loss and 8.5 sacks. He also had nine career pass breakups, four forced fumbles and one interception. He has solid height and bulk with excellent straight-line speed for the position. White is a smooth mover with very good body control and change-of-direction skills. He's a naturally instinctive player and quick reactor who always seems to be around the ball. He's not overpowering at the point of attack but knows when to give up leverage in order to get off blocks. White has very good range in coverage, is instinctive in space and also as a blitzer. His NFL comp is Redskins ILB Zach Brown. White is one of the top rated off-the-line linebackers in the 2019 class. He grades out as an every-down starter in the NFL and he's a likely top-40 draft pick. -- Feb. 26, 2019 White is a sideline-to-sideline linebacker with solid instincts and excellent top-end speed. Although he isn't overpowering at the point of attack, he has good size and knows when to give up leverage to get off blocks. He's smooth in changing directions and shows great range in coverage. Value plus filling a need equals a strong pick. The departure of Kwon Alexander and the transition to new defensive coordinator Todd Bowles' 3-4 defense made linebacker a pressing need. Athleticism and speed were priorities considering that the Buccaneers gave up an NFL-worst 82 percent completion percentage when the linebacker was the nearest defender, according to NFL Next Gen stats last year. -- Steve Muench

Jones was a three-year starter at Duke, missing two games with a broken clavicle in 2018. He finished his career completing 59.9 percent of his throws. Jones is a good-sized quarterback with a slightly above-average hand span. He's mentally and physically tough, taking poundings in multiple games and he kept competing. Jones has good timing as a passer and is precise in the short game. He has a great feel for the timing of back-shoulder throws and generally shows good ball placement, but a high percentage of his throws are in the short game. He does not throw many deep balls. Pressure really starts to affect his accuracy during the course of a game. He's inconsistent on other intermediate routes and also erratic on vertical throws. He has to really stress to drive the ball vertically and it affects his mechanics/accuracy. Jones has average arm strength and good pocket presence. He marries his eyes to his feet and is unusually fast once he catches stride but lacks ideal quick-twitch athleticism in the pocket. Jones grades out as a backup NFL quarterback and should be selected on Day 2. -- March 6, 2019 Jones is a well-built quarterback with average arm strength and good pocket presence. He gets the ball out on time and is precise in the short game. He has a great feel for timing of back-shoulder throws. He has to really strain to drive the ball vertically, and it affects his mechanics/accuracy. He has a longer delivery and pats the ball before delivering. It's not the quarterback we would have taken (he was the No. 6 QB and 59th-ranked player overall), but the Giants needed to get the heir apparent to Eli Manning and you can't criticize them for pulling the trigger on Jones here if they feel he's that player. Playing behind Manning should give Jones valuable time to learn the scheme and see the way Manning prepares before he has to take the reins. -- Steve Muench

Allen was a four-year player and three-year starter at Kentucky, racking up 215 tackles, 39.5 tackles-for-loss, 31 sacks, 11 forced fumbles and one interception. He has the ability to play on outside or inside regardless of the front. He has outstanding speed, running a 4.63 40-yard dash with a 1.61 10-yard split at the combine. His best trait is his ability to get home as a pass-rusher. He has a quick first step and shows good torso flexibility when bending the edge. He's a rangy run defender with above-average closing speed. As a tackler, he plays with good body control and wrestles ball carriers to the ground. Allen is big and athletic enough to compete with tight ends in man coverage, but he has some tightness when it comes to quickly changing directions in space. He has the potential to develop into an above-average starter early in his career. -- March 12, 2019 Allen has a quick first step, good torso flexibility and outstanding closing speed. He made substantial strides as a hand fighter in 2018 and looks to cause turnovers when he gets to the quarterback. He's a good tackler and rangy run-defender. Jacksonville makes the wise move and overlooks more pressing needs in favor of talent and value (Allen was our No. 5 prospect). With Calais Campbell turning 33 this year, and last year's first-round pick Taven Bryan potentially moving to 3-technique, look for Allen to make an immediate impact as a pass-rusher and push for a three-down role in time. -- Steve Muench

Hockenson is the most complete tight end in the 2019 draft class, with an outstanding combination of height, weight, speed and strength. One of a very few two-way TE prospects coming out of college football. He grades out as an impact starter and should be ready to contribute immediately, despite his lack of ideal game experience. Hockenson projects as a first-round pick. Hockenson is the rare tight end coming out of college who is a weapon in the passing game and as a blocker. He's a naturally instinctive route runner with an outstanding combination of height, weight, playing speed and strength. He has exceptional ball skills. The Lions came into the draft looking to add weapons for quarterback Matthew Stafford and improve a running game that ranked 23rd in rushing yards per game last year. Adding Hockenson accomplishes both. Look for him to win the starting job early. -- Steve Muench

In his first two seasons at Houston, Oliver racked up 139 tackles, 39.5 tackles for loss, and 10.5 sacks, while also forcing five fumbles. In 2018, Oliver battled a lingering knee injury and finished with 54 tackles, 14.5 tackles for loss and three sacks. He's an undersized one-gap DT or 4-3 NT with elite first-step quickness and speed. Oliver is a disruptive pass-rusher but needs to develop better counter moves. He has tightness when working the edge of a blocker and won't be able to rely on quickness and power as much in the NFL. Oliver is a highly disruptive one-gap run defender with excellent range and closing burst. He plays with a good motor and makes a lot of plays in pursuit, but struggles to anchor versus a double-team. He needs to be on the move to be effective. Falcons DT Grady Jarrett is a better NFL comp than Rams DT Aaron Donald. Oliver grades out as a high-end NFL starter in a one-gap scheme (as a three-technique or 4-3 NT). He's a plug-and-play starter with upside to improve as a pass-rusher with refined hand usage. He projects as a top-20 pick in 2019. -- Feb. 26, 2019 Oliver is a highly disruptive, one-gap run-defender with good instincts and elite first-step quickness. He has excellent range and makes plays in pursuit. He has violent hands but is undersized with shorter arms and needs to play in a one-gap scheme to be at his best. He hasn't realized his considerable potential when it comes to getting to the quarterback. Oliver is an outstanding value at this spot, as he was our third-ranked player overall. He should fill a need by winning the starting spot vacated by Buffalo legend Kyle Williams. He complements Star Lotulelei well, as he has the burst to excel at the 3-technique while Lotulelei has the size and strength to hold up at nose tackle. -- Steve Muench

Bush was a two-year starter at Michigan who totaled 203 career tackles, 19 tackles for loss, nine sacks, 14 pass breakups and one interception. He's an undersized WLB prospect with outstanding quickness, athleticism and speed. Bush is quick to change directions, very adept in man-to-man coverage and has good range in zone coverage. He has good instincts as a pass-rusher. Bush closes quickly when he gets a line to the QB but struggles to counter when reached by bigger blockers. He has outstanding range versus the run and is a sideline-to-sideline run defender. The weakness in his game is defending the inside run. He has adequate tackling skills and was the alpha dog of Michigan's defense. Bush is a plug-and-play starter. He is one of the top off-the-ball linebackers in the 2019 class. He's an every-down player and should be a first-round pick. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Bush is a three-down linebacker with outstanding quickness, athleticism and speed. He's adept in man-to-man coverage, shows good range in zone coverage and is an instinctive pass-rusher with excellent closing burst. He's a sideline-to-sideline run-defender. Pittsburgh's defense has understandably not been the same since losing inside linebacker Ryan Shazier, whose recovery from a spinal injury continues to inspire. With that in mind, they fill a pressing need and get excellent value by trading up for Bush, who is a plug-and-play starter. -- Steve Muench

Williams was a dependable three-year starter at Alabama with experience at both tackle spots. He played his final two seasons at left tackle but could possible move to right tackle or guard in the NFL. He handles speed off the edge relatively effortlessly, but occasionally will get beat by edge rushers with sharp outside-in moves. He grades out as a plug-and-play starter and should be a first-round pick in 2019. Williams gets set quickly and handles speed off the edge relatively effortlessly, even though he has below-average arm length for an offensive tackle. He does a good job of sinking his hips and anchoring against speed-to-power. He gets into sound position and gets good initial pop in the running game. The Bengals spent some money on the offensive line in free agency, but more help was needed as they haven't had much recent success drafting O-linemen. Cincinnati still needs competition at right tackle where Bobby Hart has been inconsistent, and Williams started 15 games there as a freshman. -- Steve Muench

A former No. 1 overall recruit in the country, Gary was a two-year starter at Michigan. He missed four games in 2018 due to a shoulder injury. He finished his three-year career with 134 tackles, 24.5 tackles for loss and 10.5 sacks. Gary went from six sacks in 13 games played in 2017 to 3.5 sacks in nine games played in 2018. He has an outstanding combination of size and speed for the position. Gary can play on both sides as a DE, can hold up as a five-technique if necessary and can also rush from the inside in sub package. He has an explosive first step and excellent suddenness for his size. Gary is capable of converting speed to power as a pass-rusher but is still too raw with his technique and array of moves. He has very good closing burst and his motor runs hot. Gary's production at Michigan never met his skill level. However, he is a highly-gifted athlete with scheme versatility, which is why he projects as a top-15 pick in the 2019 NFL draft. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Gary's production at Michigan never met his skill level, but he's a versatile defensive lineman with an outstanding combination of size, length and speed. He's a powerful run-defender with the upper-body strength to stack and shed blockers. He has the tools to develop into a productive and disruptive pass-rusher at the NFL level. Muhammad Wilkerson, Kenny Clark and Mike Daniels all ended the season on injured reserve and Wilkerson is unsigned, making defensive end a need. The Packers could also take advantage of Gary's versatility and line him up at outside linebacker in their base 3-4 defense. -- Steve Muench

Wilkins was a three-year starter at Clemson, racking up 243 tackles, 41 tackles for loss and 16 sacks. He's an average-sized interior defensive lineman with shorter arms and smaller hands. Wilkins is at his best as a three-technique but he's scheme versatile and has experience playing inside and outside. He has a quick first step, very quick hands and is a high-motor pass-rusher. He knows how to work the edges of blockers. Wilkins has fast eyes to locate the ball as a run defender and also has great awareness and discipline as a pass-rusher. He has excellent range for a player with his size and chases the run with great effort. He will get ragdolled on occasion and also leaves his feet too quickly at times and misses tackles. He plays every facet of special teams and also contributes as a lead blocker in short-yardage and goal-line packages. Wilkins fits best as a three-technique in the NFL but he's a scheme versatile defensive lineman who projects as a three-down starter. Wilkins is a likely top-20 selection in 2019. -- Feb. 26, 2019 Wilkins is a polished pass-rusher with quick hands and an excellent motor. He is an active and disruptive run-defender who slips blocks and makes plays in pursuit. He plays in every facet of special teams and contributes as a lead blocker in some short-yardage packages. Miami is looking to improve a defense that ranked 31st in rushing yards allowed per game last season. The Dolphins should know how to make the most of Wilkins' skill set, as defensive line coach Marion Hobby worked with Wilkins when he was Clemson's DE coach early in Wilkins' career. -- Steve Muench

Lindstrom is a versatile offensive lineman with an excellent football IQ. He gets set quickly and is tough to shake when he has his hands inside in pass protection. His footwork is inconsistent, and he occasionally has problems mirroring when he doesn't win with his hands. He is on the lighter side and gets pushed around at times. He is long enough to push speed rushers past the pocket at offensive tackle. He is an athletic run-blocker who fits best in a zone-heavy scheme and is at his optimum pulling around the corner. He gets into position and fights to sustain, but he is a top-heavy drive blocker who plays on his toes and ends up on the ground occasionally. He is not a mauler but blocks to the whistle and looks for work when nothing comes to him. He's a grinder who works hard at his craft and leads by example. Lindstrom grades out as a versatile reserve who provides depth at right tackle and at guard early in his career and has the potential to develop into a starter in time. -- Oct. 16, 2018 Lindstrom is a versatile offensive lineman who primarily played right guard but saw time at right tackle at Boston College. He tested exceptionally well at the combine and has a high ceiling. He gets set quickly, has good length and moves well laterally. He's an athletic run-blocker who gets into position and fights to sustain his block. Quarterback Matt Ryan was sacked 42 times last season -- the second most of his career -- and six different players started at guard. While the Falcons addressed the position in free agency, Lindstrom is the best guard in this class. Atlanta isn't taking any chances when it comes to protecting its franchise quarterback. -- Steve Muench

Haskins was a one-year starter at Ohio State, but finished the 2018 season with a 13-1 record and completed 70 percent of his passes. He is a gifted pocket passer with prototypical size and very good arm strength and accuracy. He shows excellent natural touch and anticipation as a passer and can also throw accurately on the run and from multiple arm angles. Haskins can sense pressure and knows when to climb and when to slide while keeping his eyes downfield. He shows consistently good touch and trajectory on deep rail shots, and he has good zip on the ball. Haskins has some ability to extend plays but his decision-making skills begin to diminish under pressure. He comes with just decent speed and below-average elusiveness. He lacks experience but he is the most complete quarterback prospect in the 2019 NFL draft. He projects as a first-round pick and should be the first quarterback off the board. -- March 19, 2019 Haskins is a gifted pocket passer with prototypical size and very good arm strength. He has excellent natural touch and anticipation and throws receivers open. He senses pressure and knows when to climb and when to slide while keeping his eyes downfield. He lacks ideal experience but is the most complete quarterback prospect in this class. Alex Smith could miss the 2019 season, and Colt McCoy and Case Keenum aren't long-term answers at QB for the Redskins. They get the second-best quarterback on our board and a potential franchise QB without having to trade up. And they don't have to rush him into the lineup. -- Steve Muench

Burns was highly productive during his three seasons at Florida State, totaling 124 tackles, 39.5 tackles for loss and 24 sacks. He also had three forced fumbles and three blocked kicks. Burns led all freshmen nationally with 9.5 sacks in 2016. Burns is tall with a narrow frame and has room to add bulk. He has long arms and outstanding speed. He's versatile with experience on both sides, as well as with his hand in the dirt and standing up. He has experience dropping into coverage and is athletic enough to do so in the NFL. Burns is a highly productive pass-rusher but has room to grow. He consistently wins with his snap awareness and elite initial burst off the edge. He shows adequate body control when bending the edge and has elite closing burst to the quarterback but will need to develop his array of pass rush moves. As a run defender, he needs to continue to get bigger and stronger. Burns is an inconsistent finisher and falls off a few too many tackles. He plays a lot of snaps and gives good effort when he thinks he can make the play but saves himself at times. Burns will likely begin his NFL career as an edge rush specialist but is gifted enough to develop into a three-down starter. He's a top-50 prospect in the 2019 draft. -- March 6, 2019 Burns is a productive pass-rusher with room to grow. He consistently wins with his snap awareness and elite initial burst off the edge. He needs to develop his array of pass-rush moves and add more power elements. He has experience dropping into coverage and is athletic enough to do so in the NFL. Carolina ranked 27th in sacks with 35 last season. Julius Peppers retired this offseason, Mario Addison is in a contract year and Bruce Irvin signed a one-year deal, so help is needed here. Burns is a great value at this point, as he was our 14th-ranked player. He gives the pass rush an immediate boost, and he has the frame to develop into a three-down player for the Panthers. -- Steve Muench

Lawrence was a three-year starter who tallied 155 tackles, 20 tackles for loss and 11 sacks. He was suspended for both CFP games during the 2018 season (failed drug test for a banned muscle-growth supplement). Lawrence is a massive interior defensive lineman with unique speed for his size. He has long arms and bigger hands. He's still developing as a pass-rusher but has overwhelming power as a bull-rusher. Lawrence doesn't seem to have a plan at times and lacks a counter-punch when initially reached. He needs to continue to work on pad level, but single blockers rarely get movement on him and he's capable of anchoring at the point of attack versus double-teams. His instincts and ball recognition are still developing. Lawrence's NFL comp is Eagles DT Haloti Ngata. Lawrence is a project but should be an immediate difference-maker as a starting DT/NT in the NFL and has a very high ceiling. He is a likely top-20 pick in the 2019 NFL draft. -- Feb. 26, 2019 Lawrence is a massive interior defensive lineman with excellent length and good quickness for his size. He rarely gives ground one-on-one and is capable of anchoring against double-teams. He's a developing pass-rusher who flashes the ability to collapse the pocket but lacks a counter move. The Giants dealt Damon Harrison to the Lions in October and finished the season ranked 20th in rushing yards allowed per game. Lawrence is an excellent fit at nose tackle in New York's base 3-4 defense and he should immediately bolster the interior run defense. -- Steve Muench

Bradbury was a three-year starter (50 games, 39 starts) at center (2017-18) and guard (2016) after entering the NC State program as a tight end and also played some defensive tackle early in his career. He has average height and weight with shorter-than-average arms but big hands and excellent speed for the position. Bradbury has great quickness, agility and mirror-slide skills. He is a very sudden athlete and a natural knee-bender. And there is some upper body pop (34 reps on 225-pound bench press). He shows outstanding awareness in pass pro, but will occasionally need help versus powerful bull-rushing nose tackles. Bradbury is at his best in a zone-blocking run game, as he is quick off the ball and takes excellent angles. Bradbury is the top center prospect in the 2019 draft and should be a first-round selection. -- March 19, 2019 Bradbury is a natural knee-bender with excellent quickness and agility. He's an outstanding pass-blocker who has great awareness and mirrors well. Although he isn't a powerful drive blocker and fits best in zone-heavy schemes, he is tough and technically sound. He's a leader with a professional work ethic. The Vikings are looking to improve a run offense that ranked 30th in rushing yards per game last season. Guard is a more pressing need than center, but Pat Elflein played some guard in college and Bradbury is a good value here. The Vikings can line up two solid picks and figure out where each of them plays at a later date. -- Steve Muench

Simmons has good gap-discipline as a pass-rusher and shows above-average awareness. He has excellent upper-body pop and is stronger than his frame indicates. He should be an immediate impact starter at the DT position in the NFL. He fits best in a one-gap heavy scheme. If teams are comfortable with Simmons' personal character, he is one of the 10 best football players in the 2019 class. Simmons is a well-built defensive tackle who plays with natural leverage and is stout for his size. He has long arms and above-average upper-body strength. He made strides as a hand fighter in 2018. He tore the ACL in his left knee while training for the draft in February. On tape, this is one of the best players in the entire draft, and Tennessee decided to make the move even with more pressing needs. It's a classic "best player available" move. That said, there are reasons he was available. Simmons tore an ACL during a February workout, so he's unlikely to make an impact early. And there was a video from his high-school years showing him striking a woman during an altercation. Potentially great player? Check. Plenty of risk? Also, check.-- Steve Muench

Fant was a three-year player who led the nation's tight ends with 16.5 yards per catch and 11 touchdowns in 2017. He is essentially a bulked up slot-WR with the size, speed and athleticism to create mismatches in the passing game. But he's a marginal blocker who lacks the strength and physicality to hold up as an-line blocker. He grades out as one of the top tight ends in the class and projects as a Day 2 pick. Fant is essentially a bulked-up slot receiver with the size, speed and athleticism to create mismatches in the passing game. He's fast enough to stretch the field and has the quickness to threaten after the catch. He's a natural hands catcher with above-average body control, but his focus is a bit inconsistent. The Broncos re-signed Jeff Heuerman, but he has had problems staying healthy and hasn't been much of a threat in the passing game. Fant gives offensive coordinator Rich Scangarello and QB Joe Flacco a tight end who can stretch the middle of the field and help draw attention away from the receivers on the outside. -- Steve Muench

Savage is an undersized safety with below-average length and outstanding timed speed. He excels at reading receivers and breaking on the ball. He's a ball hawk who jumps routes and has good hands. He's an aggressive run-defender who closes well and always seems to be around the ball. With 36-year-old Tramon Williams potentially returning to corner, Green Bay needed a free safety to complement free-agent signee Adrian Amos. The Packers have now added two talented defensive backs with sub-4.4-second speed in Round 1 of the past two drafts with CB Jaire Alexander and Savage. -- Steve Muench

Dillard was a five-year player and started all 39 games during his final three seasons. He has good size and unique athleticism for the position, which is why he's capable of developing into a very good pass-blocker in the NFL. He has shorter arms but does a good job with his hand placement and has adequate snap. He gets set quickly and mirrors effortlessly. In the run game, he's an effective zone and positional blocker with outstanding balance and agility. He has the range and athletic ability to cut off linebackers at the second level. He's quick off the ball and gets good initial pop, but he doesn't regularly drive defenders off the ball, and he needs to improve his core strength. Dillard should quickly emerge as a starting left tackle in the NFL. Dillard has good size and unique athleticism, which is why he's capable of developing into a very good pass-blocker, despite having shorter arms. He gets set quickly, gets his hands inside and mirrors effortlessly. He's an effective zone and positional blocker with outstanding balance and the range to cut off linebackers at the second level in the running game. Left tackle Jason Peters is 37 years old, suffered a season-ending knee injury in 2017, and he returns on a restructured one-year contract. The Eagles get the heir apparent to Peters in Dillard -- and a player capable of protecting franchise QB Carson Wentz, who is coming off consecutive season-ending injuries. -- Steve Muench

Howard has a good blend of size, length and athletic ability. He's tough to beat when his hand placement is sound in pass protection, and he held his own against Auburn early in the 2018 season. Howard flashes the ability to move defenders off the ball in the run game. He has the potential to develop into an effective zone blocker. Houston has allowed 116 sacks -- 12 more than any other team -- over the past two seasons. The Texans signed Matt Kalil this offseason, but he missed the 2018 season with a knee injury and it's only a one-year deal. This is early for Howard (our 47th-ranked player), but it's unlikely he would've been there when the Texans pick in Round 2. Protecting QB Deshaun Watson is the priority and Howard should help. -- Steve Muench

Despite never emerging as a fulltime starter at Alabama, Jacobs has the traits to develop into a difference-maker in the NFL. He is a complete back who runs violently and rarely goes down easily. He's a tough and powerful blocker -- both in pass protection and in the run game -- who also offers versatility in the pass game and on special teams. Jacobs grades out as a top-50 prospect in the 2019 draft class. Despite never emerging as a full-time starter at Alabama, Jacobs has the traits to develop into a difference-maker in the NFL. He's a complete back with good instincts, quick feet, above-average burst through the hole and the strength to pick up yards after contact. He's an above-average receiver and a tough pass-blocker. The Raiders ranked 25th in rushing yards per game last season and Marshawn Lynch just retired, leaving Isaiah Crowell atop the depth chart. Jacobs is the best back in this class and has the potential to develop into a weapon for QB Derek Carr in the passing game. -- Steve Muench

Brown is an undersized burner with an elite combination of speed and quickness. He explodes out of breaks and consistently generates separation as a route runner. But he is not very strong and can get pushed around at times by bigger press-man corners. Durability is a concern, as he had leg injuries and cramping in multiple games in 2018. He projects as an immediate starter and big-play receiver in the NFL. He's a likely first-round pick in 2019. Brown explodes off the line and is one of the fastest wide receiver prospects we've ever evaluated in terms of game speed. He has the burst to separate, plucks the ball on the run and is a big-play threat after the catch. He lacks ideal size for a vertical threat, yet has the speed to get over the top of cornerbacks and does a solid job tracking the deep ball. Baltimore's pass-catchers combined for only 10 receptions of 30-plus yards in 2018 (tied for last in the league) and free-agent departure John Brown had five of them, so the Ravens needed a big-play threat at receiver. Offensive coordinator Greg Roman can make the most of Marquise Brown's ability to create after the catch and help quarterback Lamar Jackson by getting Brown the ball on quick hitters. -- Steve Muench

Sweat is a flexible athlete who gets offensive tackles off balance with his elite speed off the edge. He has a surprisingly powerful upper body and displays very good change-of-direction skills on outside-in pass rush moves. He stood out as one of the top players at the Senior Bowl. He grades out as a future NFL starter but may need to be used as a pass-rush specialist early in his career. He is a likely first-round pick. Sweat is a flexible athlete with the ability to bend, and he frequently gets offensive tackles off balance with elite speed off the edge. He displays very good change-of-direction skills on outside-in pass-rush moves. He has excellent length and good upper-body strength. He's a disruptive and rangy run-defender. Preston Smith signed with the Packers this offseason and Ryan Anderson has just 2.0 sacks in two seasons, making defensive end a top-three need for the Redskins. Sweat fell because of concerns about his heart condition. He is potentially an excellent value here and gives the Redskins an explosive edge rusher to complement Ryan Kerrigan. -- Steve Muench

Abram is an intimidator safety who highly aggressive in run support and has an explosive closing burst. He usually takes solid angles and has above-average tackling skills. He grades out as a future starting strong safety in the NFL. He also has the skill set and aggressive mentality to excel as a core special-teamer. If he is cleared medically (failed Senior Bowl physical) Abram will be off the board in the first two rounds of the 2019 NFL draft. Abram is an intimidating, hard-hitting safety with good size and speed. He takes sound angles filling in run support, has explosive closing burst and is a good tackler. He's capable of matching up with some detached tight ends and bigger receivers in the NFL. The Raiders signed Lamarcus Joyner and 2016 first-round pick Karl Joseph made strides last year, so it will be interesting to see how the Raiders use all three safeties. That said, Abram is an excellent value here as our top-ranked safety and adding a player with his skill set is always a positive. A good pick. -- Steve Muench

Tillery was a full-time starter his final three seasons and combined for 123 tackles, 22.5 tackles-for-loss and 12.5 sacks. He has an elite combination of height, weight, arm length and speed. He flashes as a pass-rusher but his inconsistency is frustrating. He's not as effective getting off blocks as a pass-rusher as he is defending the run, and he doesn't regularly collapse the pocket with power. In the run game, he's typically stout one-on-one defender, but he has some problems holding ground against double teams and angle blocks. Tillery has versatility to play multiple spots in multiple fronts. But his production frequently fails to match his skill set and he has questionable football character. -- March 19, 2019 Tillery's production frequently fails to match his skill set, and his inconsistency is frustrating, but there's a lot to like about his upside. He's a well-built defensive tackle with excellent length and top-end speed. His vertical jump (32 inches) and short shuttle (4.33) results were outstanding, and those tests tend to correlate with defensive tackles succeeding in the NFL. He flashes as a pass-rusher and stacks blockers in the running game. The Chargers had four defensive tackles who played at least 192 snaps last season enter free agency, and 34-year-old nose tackle Brandon Mebane is the only one who re-signed. Tillery is a perfect fit for defensive coordinator Gus Bradley's scheme and he's got the talent to push for a starting DT job as a rookie. -- Steve Muench

Collier is a prototypical 4-3 LDE with excellent length and power. He improved his ability to locate the ball and get off blocks in 2018. He turned heads with his ability to overwhelm tackles and interior offensive linemen as a pass-rusher during Senior Bowl week. He chases with good effort and plays faster than timed speed. Defensive end was a need before the Seahawks traded Frank Clark to the Chiefs, and bolstering the run defense was critical. The Seahawks allowed 4.95 yards per rush last season, which ranked 30th in the NFL and was the most in franchise history. Collier is an excellent run defender who should step into a starting role as a rookie. -- Steve Muench

Baker notched 116 tackles, 24 passes broken up and seven interceptions while at Georgia. He comes with average size and good quickness. He is at his best in man-to-man coverage but does have some experience in zone and can play on and off the line of scrimmage. Baker is just a naturally instinctive corner. He does a good job reading routes in man and does an excellent job with route combinations. He possesses quick feet and fluid hips, and he shows good body control. He has occasional lapses in concentration and gets a little loose with his pre-snap stance and in his pedal; he really needs to clean up his footwork, especially when playing off.
