Baker is also slow to disengage at times but shows no hesitation mixing it up in run support as a wrap-up tackler. And his ball skills are better when he's coming forward to attack than when tracking over his shoulder. Baker grades out as an eventual NFL starter and can compete immediately for playing time in sub-packages. -- March 19, 2019 Baker is a naturally instinctive corner who does a good job reading receivers and has an excellent feel for route combinations. He has quick feet, fluid hips and good body control. He has above-average length and ball skills. He's tough and wraps up in run support. Janoris Jenkins is 30 years old, B.W. Webb signed with Cincinnati and 2018 supplemental draft pick Sam Beal missed the 2018 season with a shoulder injury. Baker is an instinctual corner and a good fit for defensive coordinator James Bettcher's scheme. -- Steve Muench

McGary was a four-year starter at right tackle with 46 career starts. He never missed a game during his four seasons at UW. He is a very good run-blocking tackle who gets into position and shows great initial pop. He's also strong enough to move defenders off the ball when he keeps his pads down. He's efficient on combination blocks, but his awareness and ability to hit moving targets as a second-level run-blocker is average at best. In pass protection, he is adequate; he has a quick set and a lot of shock in his hands. But he's more of a striker than a "sticky" pass-protector. His arm length is a concern and he struggles to sustain at times. And when he gets in trouble, it's usually due to lunging. McGary should emerge as a starting right tackle in the NFL within a year or two. -- April 5 McGary is a tall, well-built right tackle prospect with short arms, especially for his height. He is a very good run-blocker who gets into position and moves defenders off the ball when he keeps his pads down. He has a quick set and a lot of shock in his hands, but he lunges at times, and his arm length is a concern. Atlanta isn't messing around when it comes to protecting quarterback Matt Ryan. They trade back into Round 1 here to further bolster a run offense that ranked 25th in rushing yards per game last season. McGary has the skill set to push Ty Sambrailo for the starting job at right tackle as a rookie. -- Steve Muench

Harry was a three-year starter who caught 213 passes for 2,889 yards and 22 touchdowns during his career. He is a big target with good body control, and he consistently rewards his quarterback for throwing him 50-50 balls. He doesn't have an elite second gear, but his size-speed combination and ball skills make him a threat in the vertical passing game. He has the strength to beat press coverage and separate with his upper body, but he lacks the burst and change-of-direction skills to regularly separate from man-to-man coverage at the NFL level. Harry grades out as a potential No. 2 starter in the NFL. He compares favorably with former Clemson receiver Mike Williams, who was a first-round pick in 2017. Harry is a likely second-round pick in 2019. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Harry is a big target with good body control, and he consistently rewards his quarterback for throwing him 50-50 balls. He doesn't have an elite second gear, but his size-speed combination and ball skills make him a threat in the vertical passing game. He flashes the ability to make the first defender miss and is an above-average threat after the catch for a player his size. New England needs playmakers with tight end Rob Gronkowski retiring, Josh Gordon suspended indefinitely, Chris Hogan signing with Carolina and Cordarrelle Patterson signing with Chicago. Harry has the talent to make an immediate impact, but he has to learn the system and earn the trust of quarterback Tom Brady first. -- Steve Muench

As a one-and-a-half year starter, Murphy combined for 74 tackles, 20 passes broken up and seven picks. Murphy is slightly undersized with shorter arms and smaller hands than desirable. He also has just average top-end speed. But he's highly instinctive with elite ball skills. He's a natural hands catcher who played receiver in high school and may have the best ball skills out of any defensive back in the country. He reads the quarterback, has a good feel for route combinations and is not afraid to come off his assignment to play the ball. Murphy is a little inconsistent when it comes to giving up separation at the top of receivers' stems, and his frame can also be an issue when it comes to matching up with bigger receivers. But he has the balance, recognition skills and athletic ability to develop above-average cover skills. Plus, he's a physical player who flashes above-average stopping power and the ability to lower the boom on the ball carrier. He's a ready-made starter who will excel in a zone-heavy defensive scheme. -- March 22, 2019 Murphy has the balance, recognition skills and athletic ability to develop above-average cover skills. He's a ball hawk who reads the quarterback, he isn't afraid to come off his assignment to play the ball, and he might have the best ball skills of any defensive back in the country. He's a physical player who flashes the ability to lower the boom on the ball carrier. Murphy projects as the Cardinals' nickel corner and he has the skills to excel in that role. He also has the potential to develop into a starter early in his career, which is important considering free-agent signing Robert Alford is coming off a disappointing 2018 season and was released by Atlanta. Arizona has struggled to find help at CB opposite star Patrick Peterson. -- Steve Muench

Ya-Sin is a physical, instinctive corner with average size and speed in addition to above-average length. He's a natural hands catcher with big hands, and he tracks the ball well. He's a willing and effective tackler. The Colts were carved up by tight ends last year, allowing the most receptions (103) in the NFL, and at a frighteningly high rate -- 79.8 percent of throws to tight ends were caught. Ya-Sin is a physical corner who can cover and tackle. The Colts might have been surprised to find him here. He'll factor into sub packages immediately. -- Chris Sprow

Taylor was a three-year player who started 36 games at Florida (34 at right tackle and two at left tackle). He has average upper-body power and size. In pass protection, he gets set quickly and uses his long arms and natural strength to ride speed rushers past the quarterback. He rarely struggles versus power, but he does play a bit upright and struggles to mirror-and-slide versus pass-rushers with sudden change-of-direction skills. As a run-blocker, he has the quickness and athletic ability to develop into an effective zone blocker with good initial pop. He has good range but needs to improve angles and play with better body control when climbing to the second level. Taylor grades out as a starting right tackle or guard in the NFL. -- March 12, 2019 Taylor gets set quickly and uses his long arms to ride speed rushers past the quarterback. He rarely struggles versus power rushers. He gets good initial pop as a run-blocker and has the athletic ability to develop into an effective zone blocker. Our top-ranked tackle and No. 10 player overall, Taylor is an outstanding value at this point and fills a pressing need. The key will be that they're comfortable with the medicals. Jacksonville started three different players at right tackle last year and released Jeremy Parnell. -- Steve Muench

Samuel is electric with the ball in his hands. There's a noticeable second gear and he flashes the ability to run away from pursuit when he gets a crease. He makes defenders miss without making violent cuts that cause him to lose momentum. While he's not an elite vertical threat, he is fast enough to take the top off the coverage. Samuel has room to grow as a route runner but he has above average potential. He flashes the ability to stick his foot in the ground at the top of his stem and he has the burst to quickly separate from man coverage. He traps passes but he shows good focus looking the ball in and he flashes the ability to make tough catches. Samuel grades out as a dangerous slot receiver and kickoff return man. -- July 30, 2018 Samuel is electric with the ball in his hands, whether it's after the catch, running the ball or returning kickoffs. He's built like a running back and excels at picking up yards after contact. He's fast enough to stretch the field and does an above-average job of creating late separation. He has room to grow as a route runner but has above-average potential in that area. Jimmy G. needed a touchdown-maker. Enter Deebo. Since joining the 49ers, Garoppolo has thrown seven TDs and eight INTs when targeting wide receivers. Samuel is electric after the catch, leading the SEC with 600 yards after the catch in 2018. He's also a weapon in the return game. -- Chris Sprow

Little was the No. 1 high school offensive lineman prospect in the 2016 class and started five games his freshman year at Ole Miss. He started all 24 games at left tackle the next two seasons. He is thick and sturdy with long arms and big mitts. Little is a really smooth mover for his size. If he improves his hand placement, he can be outstanding in pass protection. He has good first-step quickness as a run blocker and takes quality angles. Little's inconsistent finishing ability and lack of toughness are concerning. On the positive side, he has the size, agility and pass-protection skills to develop into a solid starting left tackle in the NFL. He projects to be a second-round pick in 2019. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Little has good size and excellent length. He's a smooth mover, and he can be outstanding in pass protection if he improves his hand placement. He takes sound angles and shows good quickness in the running game. He's not a mauler, and his lack of a nasty disposition is frustrating. Carolina released Matt Kalil, and Daryl Williams played in only one game last year because of a knee injury and re-signed for one year. Little has the tools to compete for the starting left tackle job immediately and improve the Panthers' ability to protect quarterback Cam Newton. -- Steve Muench

Ford is a nasty offensive lineman who can be overpowering at the point of attack. He rarely gives ground to bull rushers, and has strong hands to control defenders in the run game. He grades out as a starting NFL right tackle or guard. He should be ready to win a starting job as a rookie. He projects as a top-50 pick in the 2019 NFL draft. Ford is a massive, overpowering drive blocker with a nasty disposition. He plays with good balance and rarely gives ground to bull-rushers but is a better run-blocker than pass-blocker. He's a little heavy-footed sliding laterally, and his hand placement is inconsistent. He has starting experience at guard and tackle. What do you do when you're the 30th-ranked offensive line in terms of run-blocking by DVOA in 2018? A mauler like Ford can't hurt, as the Bills look to milk more out of an aging backfield in 2019. LeSean McCoy and Frank Gore turn 31 and 36, respectively, this offseason. Here's a push, fellas. -- Chris Sprow

Bunting is lean press corner with good length and above-average top-end speed. He has good man-to-man cover skills, and he flashes the ability to blanket receivers underneath. Bunting needs to fill out his frame and get stronger against the run. The Bucs started seven different players at corner and ranked 26th in passing yards allowed per game last year, so help was needed. Bunting is an excellent fit for defensive coordinator Todd Bowles' man-heavy scheme. Look for him to push for a starting role early in his career. -- Steve Muench

Mullen was a two-year starter at Clemson, totaling 76 tackles, six pass breakups and four interceptions during his final two seasons. He has good height with adequate bulk but shorter arms and average top-end speed. He's a smooth athlete with good length. Mullen shows the ability to open his hips and run with vertical receivers, but he's not as sudden as he is smooth. His instincts and recognition skills need to improve. He struggles a bit with leverage as a zone defender. Mullen's ball skills are better than his ball production indicates and he does a solid job on 50-50 balls. He gives decent effort in run support and has adequate tackling skills but he's not very physical or aggressive. Mullen's well-respected and a leader in the DB room with a good work ethic. -- Feb. 26, 2019 Mullen is a smooth athlete with good top-end speed and shorter arms. He shows the ability to open his hips and run with vertical receivers. He was not targeted very much in 2018 and has better ball skills than the numbers suggest. He's an adequate tackler who gives decent effort in run support. The last time you saw Trayvon Mullen on a football field he had a sack, an INT and a forced fumble in Clemson's demolition of Alabama. One thing Chucky loves is a versatile corner, and if you played the Raiders last year, you killed their slot corners to the tune of 9.2 yards per catch. Mullen should help clean up that mess.-- Chris Sprow

Risner's arm length is a red flag for an offensive tackle, and his lack of ideal length is an issue at times on tape, as edge defenders have some success getting into his frame in run and pass-blocking. He's a better fit at center, where he has some upside. He's quick enough to get into position and plays with a wide base. He flashes the ability to extend his arms and lock out. He's light and plays high, so he gets stood up at times. He also gets caught leaning and ends up on the ground too much. He gives too much ground to speed to power in pass protection. He doesn't have the lateral quickness to consistently mask his below-average length when matching up against speed rushers. He's a two-time team captain with above-average character. Risner grades out as a backup center with the potential to develop into a versatile backup interior offensive lineman if he gets stronger at the point of attack. -- July 30, 2018 Risner is a three-time team captain with outstanding character and good football smarts. He looks to bury defenders and regularly blocks to the echo of the whistle in the running game. He has average length and gets set quickly in pass protection. He has experience playing center, and he's versatile enough to play guard. Denver made free-agent signing Ja'Wuan James the highest-paid right tackle in the NFL but still needed to address the interior offensive line. Risner is versatile enough to develop into a starter at center (where he started his college career) or guard, and he can kick outside to right tackle if needed. -- Steve Muench

Lock took over Missouri"s starting quarterback job five games into his freshman year in 2015 and started all 46 games from that point on (2015-18). During his final three seasons as a full-time starter (38 games), Lock completed 61.4 percent of his throws with 95 TDs and 31 interceptions. Lock is a good-sized, big-armed QB with above-average athleticism and speed for the position. But he does have unusually small hands for his size. He"s a supremely confident player, which is an underrated trait when evaluating quarterbacks. Lock has a big-time arm and a smooth delivery -- the ball jumps off his hand and he effortlessly drives the deep out on a line. He has a natural feel for comebacks and out-breaking routes, displaying good overall deep ball trajectory and placement. His footwork is inconsistent, as he has a tendency to open his front hip -- and when that occurs, his ball tends to sail. When his feet are right, he can be very accurate. One of his special traits is his ability to throw accurately from many different arm angles and when completely off-balance. He will hang tough in the pocket, but he"s also highly capable of extending plays with his feet. Lock has the tools to develop into a quality NFL starter. -- March 19, 2019 Lock has ideal size with athleticism and speed. He has a big-time arm and a smooth delivery. The ball jumps off his hand. His best traits are his ability to throw accurately from different arm angles and when completely off balance. Joe Flacco is set to earn $18.5 million in his age-35 season in 2019, and played only nine games in 2018 after getting hurt. If the Broncos want to avoid paying Flacco over $20 million in 2020 -- he could be cut with no dead cap money -- the development of the strong-armed but enigmatic Lock is, well, key. -- Chris Sprow

Tavai is a big linebacker with slightly below-average length and top-end speed. He's got experience lining up on the inside and the outside. He sets the edge when he lines up the outside and he anchors well between the tackles. He chases with good effort and takes sound pursuit angles. He flashes as a pass-rusher and he shows good awareness in underneath zone. Jarrad Davis (2017 first-round pick) is an erratic tackler and has struggled in coverage at times. The Lions get a linebacker capable of pushing Davis and in time supplanting him as the starter in Tavai. Tavai also has great versatility. -- Steve Muench

Jenkins is tall with long arms and adequate bulk for the center position. He is a right-handed snapper with adequate accuracy, and he is very good in pass protection. Agile and quick, Jenkins is a natural knee bender and rarely has trouble versus speed. He's light on his feet and shows good awareness with quick hands -- but he lacks shock. He's a solid anchor versus bull rushers, as he is stronger in his lower body than his upper. Jenkins excels on combination blocks. He has played all five offensive line positions but his best fit in the NFL is likely at center. He grades out as a quality NFL starter and he should be a plug-and-play draft pick. -- March 22, 2019 Jenkins is a taller center with good size and length for the position. He's a natural knee-bender and outstanding pass-blocker with decent foot speed. He's an athletic run-blocker with good range. He isn't overpowering but is strong enough to sustain blocks. When Mississippi State ran inside the tackles last season, it averaged a whopping 5.99 yards per rush, and Jenkins was a big reason why. He won't be catching passes, but he offers Green Bay either insurance or an immediate starter at center or guard depending on how things shake out in camp. He's also a very good pass-blocker. -- Chris Sprow

Williams is strong with good balance, and he does an above-average job of rerouting receivers. He rarely gets caught out of position and plays the ball, not the man, in zone. He plays faster than timed speed, and he makes it tough for receivers to stack him with his body position, but he's still vulnerable to getting beat over the top. Jason McCourty re-signed for two years, and undrafted rookie J.C. Jackson exceeded expectations last year, but McCourty turns 32 this year. More importantly, adding Williams makes a great deal of sense from a scheme fit and value standpoint. -- Steve Muench

Greedy Williams played two full seasons at LSU, compiling 71 tackles, 20 pass breakups and eight interceptions. Williams is a tall, somewhat angular corner with very good size potential and shorter arms. He's an outside cover corner who has lined up predominantly on the left side at LSU. Williams is at his best in press-man coverage. He has quick feet and smooth hips for his height with excellent top-end speed and closing burst. He will avoid contact unless absolutely necessary. Williams grades out as a starting NFL cornerback in the future but needs to become more physical and consistent when the ball is in the air. He's a likely first-round pick in 2019 but not a complete enough cornerback to gamble on in the top 20. -- March 6, 2019 Williams has excellent top-end speed and is at his best in press-man coverage. He has quick feet and smooth hips for his height. He has above-average ball skills and baits quarterbacks into making mistakes. He's a below-average run-defender. The Browns could have a ferocious pass rush in 2019. Errant tosses or bad reads from early pressure could find their way into the arms of Williams, who greedily swiped an SEC-high eight INTs over the past two seasons. Expect to see him early on third-down situations; last year, he didn't allow a single completion on 13 attempts his way. -- Chris Sprow

Blair is a tall and lean free safety with marginal length and above-average top-end speed. He closes well and limits production after the catch. He does an above-average job of squaring, wrapping and driving through contact in one-on-one situations. He flashes above-average stopping power. Earl Thomas is with the Ravens now, and Delano Hill replaced Tedric Thompson at free safety at the end of the 2018 season. Blair is an excellent fit for Seattle's scheme and should push for immediate playing time. -- Steve Muench

McCoy is very good in pass protection and efficient as a run blocker. He consistently gets good initial positioning and understands angles well. He shows high-level football intelligence and leadership. An inconsistent shotgun snapper, McCoy needs to solve his issues if he's to remain at the center position in the NFL. But if he doesn't, he will still be a good starting guard at the next level. He projects as a Day 2 draft pick. McCoy was named a team captain as a redshirt junior and is one of the smartest offensive linemen in his class. He's an above-average pass-blocker and outstanding run-blocker. He has experience playing guard, is big enough to play the position in the NFL and might be a better fit there, considering that he's an inconsistent shotgun snapper. ESPN's Pass Block Win Rate metric tells us the Saints sustained pass blocks for 2.5 seconds on just 46 percent of dropbacks last season, worst for any playoff team and a Drew Brees endgame scenario waiting to happen if not fixed. McCoy's strength? How about the fact that he had a blown pass block on a microscopic 0.4 percent of attempts last season. Some potential spackle in a leaky situation up front. -- Chris Sprow

As a pass-rusher, Banogu shows good takeoff quickness and above-average speed off the edge. He has torso flexibility and the body control to turn the corner while engaged but doesn't have enough sting in his hands and needs to diversify his array of pass-rush moves. As a run defender, he's an upfield player who does an OK job of locating the ball. He's at his best squeezing down and chasing from the backside, where he flashes above-average closing speed. However, he gets moved off the ball when teams run at him and gets pushed around too much in the run game. He doesn't chase with same effort versus the run as he does versus the pass, and his overall motor is average. He wraps and rides QBs to the ground but wraps too high at times and can be too quick to leave his feet. He has experience dropping into coverage and can be effective in underneath zone -- and in some one-on-one running back matchups. Banogu is an undersized edge defender who projects much better as a 3-4 OLB in the NFL than he does as a 4-3 RDE. -- May 30, 2018 Banogu is an athletic edge defender with good length and speed. He slips blocks and disrupts plays in the backfield. He has a quick first step and good flexibility for a speed rusher. Banogu played outside linebacker during Senior Bowl practices and appeared to get more comfortable as the week progressed. His 40-yard dash, short shuttle and three-cone times were all above the average for an OLB prospect. The Colts signed Justin Houston but that hasn't stopped them from continuing to upgrade a pass rush that tied for 19th in the NFL with 38 sacks last year. Banogu has the tools to develop into every-down player in time, most likely at outside linebacker. -- Steve Muench

Smith has big-play ability as a pass-catcher. He shows the speed to separate from linebackers vertically and he's dangerous after the catch. He has emerged as a feisty blocker with solid technique. He is one of the top 3 tight end prospects in the 2019 class and he grades out as a starting F-tight end in the NFL. He is a likely top-50 draft pick. Smith is a big-play threat with the speed to separate from linebackers vertically and threaten them after the catch. He does a good job stemming his routes and has above-average ball skills. He's a competitive blocker who has made strides in that area. Kyle Rudolph turns 30 this season and will be an unrestricted free agent after 2019, and No. 3 wide receiver Laquon Treadwell had the highest drop rate in the NFL last season. So here's a fresh, big-bodied target who can do more than work the flats or post up inside. Smith ranked first in the FBS among all tight ends last year with a chunky 12.0 yards per target. Reporting for duty, Captain Kirk. -- Chris Sprow

Brown made 29 starts in 36 career contests during his three seasons at Ole Miss. As a true freshman in 2016, he totaled 29 catches for 412 yards and two touchdowns. During his final two seasons, he combined for 160 catches, 2,572 yards and 17 scores. He's thickly built with above-average height and at his best working in the slot. Brown has a good catch radius and makes tough catches in traffic. He has the fluidity and suddenness to develop as a route runner but his attention to detail is lacking. Brown has above-average size and speed but he's not big, strong or fast enough to separate in the NFL without improved route-running skills. He frequently makes the first defender miss after the catch and is shifty for his size. Brown grades out as a future NFL starter but he's still a work in progress. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Brown is a big slot receiver who is shifty for his size and frequently makes the first defender miss after the catch. He has a wide catching radius and makes tough catches in traffic. He has the fluidity and suddenness to develop as a route runner. A Tennessee offense that ranked 27th in scoring and 29th in passing yards per game last year adds a weapon. It will be interesting to see how they use Brown considering that he's a slot receiver and they signed slot receiver Adam Humphries, but he's a talented player and a good value here. -- Steve Muench

Sample's unique traits are his ball skills and his blocking. He is one of the best blocking tight ends in this class, both as a run-blocker and in pass pro. He has a lot of tightness, which is seen in his route-running. He is slow in and out of his breaks, and he rarely gets separation with his cuts at the top of his stem. He comes with good football intelligence, work ethic and toughness. Sample has value as a backup tight end because of his outstanding blocking and ball skills, but he will never be a good starter in the NFL. -- April 5 Sample is a reliable receiver with outstanding ball skills. He didn't drop a pass in the eight games I studied from the past two seasons. He is one of the best blocking tight ends in this class, both in the run game and in pass protection. Sample is a deliberate route-runner, but he struggles to separate and is not much of a big-play threat. C.J. Uzomah gave the Bengals 43 receptions in 2018 at tight end, but Tyler Eifert was able to pull in only 15 catches as injuries cut short yet another season. Sample could be a viable second option as an underrated athlete who arguably rates higher in other tight end classes. Unfortunately for him, the 2019 draft class is loaded. The Bengals might stand to benefit. -- Chris Sprow

Sanders was a three-year player who spent his first two seasons at Penn State as Saquon Barkley's backup. In his one season as a full-time starter in 2018, Sanders carried the ball 220 times for 1,274 yards (5.8 yards per carry) and nine touchdowns. He also caught 24 passes for 139 yards (5.8 yards per catch) last season. Sanders has solid size and good, but his top trait is his contact balance. He's not a pile pusher but he runs low to the ground, has excellent body control and a powerful lower body. He shows above-average patience running between the tackles, but there are occasions when he tries to make too much happen and/or cuts back too soon. But he has good open field instincts. He has the agility to make defenders miss in the hole and in space. His burst through the hole is above-average. He's not an elite breakaway running back by any stretch, but he does show a second gear if he's able to bounce a run into daylight. Mostly an underneath outlet in the passing game, he has been mostly reliable as a pass-catcher and he's smooth transitioning upfield after the catch. Ball security has been a serious problem for Sanders. He should quickly emerge as a solid No. 2 running back in the NFL with the potential to develop into a starter (if he can improve in the pass game and better protect the ball). Sanders has a good blend of size and top-end speed. His top trait is his contact balance. He isn't a pile pusher, but he runs low to the ground, has a powerful lower body and can make defenders miss in the hole and in space. He has been mostly reliable as a receiver, and he's smooth transitioning upfield after the catch. The Eagles traded for Jordan Howard, but he's in a contract year -- and Jay Ajayi and Darren Sproles remain unsigned. Sanders will be an excellent complement to Howard in 2019, and he has the talent to take over as the primary back early in his career. -- Steve Muench

Johnson is a big corner with above-average length. His technique needs work, but he has the potential to develop into an effective press corner. He closes well and limits production after the catch in off coverage. His footwork is inconsistent, and he allows too much separation at times. While he runs well for his size, he doesn't have an elite second gear and occasionally gets beat late on vertical routes. He's willing to step up in run support, but there's room for improvement when it comes to his tackling. -- Aug. 5, 2018 Johnson is a big press/zone corner with above-average length and average top-end speed. He has the strength to disrupt receivers getting off the line, and he flips his hips well for a player with his size. Johnson has picked off just one pass the past two seasons. He's not a ball hawk. The Texans needed to come away from this draft with at least one cornerback, and Johnson might be pushed into a big role early. Houston gave up 11.6 yards per pass attempt last season and lost three of their top five defensive backs this offseason, based on snapcount. Johnson has length and strength to be useful in press early. -- Chris Sprow

Scharping's footwork is sound, and he tends to get his hands inside in the run game. He has the lateral quickness and balance to succeed in a zone-heavy scheme. He drives once in position and flashes the ability to generate push, but he is not an overpowering drive blocker. His pads rise, and he has an average overall power base. He is not a violent finisher and lacks a nasty disposition. He does a good job of climbing combo blocks and picking up linebackers. He tends to take sound angles releasing to the second level, gets set quickly and protects inside out in the passing game. He gets good depth and width when he kicks out, but his arm length is a red flag for an offensive tackle, raising concerns about his ability to protect the edge in the NFL. He gets caught playing on his toes and lunging. He sets high and gives too much ground on occasion. Scharping grades out as a versatile reserve with the potential to develop into a starting offensive guard. -- July 19, 2018 Scharping has the frame, lateral quickness and balance to succeed in a zone-heavy scheme. He does a good job of climbing combo blocks and picking up linebackers. He has below-average length, and he may have to kick inside to guard where he played early in his college career, but he gets set quickly and he tends to get his hands inside. He plays with adequate bend and anchors well. Right tackle Seantrel Henderson missed the final 15 games because of a broken ankle last season and hasn't played in all 16 games of a season since his rookie campaign in 2014. The Texans picked a left tackle in the first round and a right tackle in the second in this scenario. -- Steve Muench

Hardman is undersized but carries elite top-end speed. His best trait is his ability to contribute in the return game, as he's at his best with the ball in his hands. Hardman has excellent intangibles. He grades out as a No 4 or No. 5 WR. -- March 19, 2019 Hardman is a speedy undersized receiver and return man with smaller hands and a small catching radius. He's at his best with the ball in his hands, and he's dangerous returning kicks, after the catch and running the football. Hardman has excellent intangibles. Hardman runs a 4.33 40-yard dash and is raw as a pass-catcher but is an angle-destroying nightmare with the ball in his hands. If that sounds familiar, it's similar to the discussion we had around Tyreek Hill when he entered the league. With Hill's future clearly in doubt, Hardman doesn't offer insurance so much as a developmental option in that multipurpose/decoy role. -- Chris Sprow

Arcega-Whiteside was a two-year starter who led the team in receptions (113 combined), receiving yards (1,840 combined) and receiving touchdowns (25 combined) while averaging 16.3 yards per catch. He is a natural pass-catcher with above-average body control. His above-average top-end speed and ability to come down with 50-50 balls downfield make him a threat in the vertical passing game. He doesn't have great explosiveness or change-of-direction skills but he separates with savviness and physicality. Arcega-Whiteside has experience lining up wide and working out of the slot. He grades out as a No. 3 receiver with the tools to develop into an above-average No. 2 early in his career. -- March 28, 2019 Arcega-Whiteside is a natural receiver and a big target with good body control. His above-average top-end speed and ability to come down with 50-50 balls make him a threat in the vertical passing game. He runs hard and picks up yards after contact. Receiver isn't a pressing need with the Eagles trading for DeSean Jackson to complement Alshon Jeffrey and Nelson Agholor (though Agholor is in a contract year). This is still a very good pick, as Arcega-Whiteside is an excellent value at this point in the draft. -- Steve Muench

Hill was a starter in 2016 and 2017 but was reduced to a rotational role under new defensive coordinator Randy Shannon in 2018. He is a highly gifted defensive tackle with a very good combination of height, weight and speed. There's excellent first-step quickness, and he explodes off the ball. But he can be late locating the ball and appears to lack natural instincts. He's a one-gap penetrator. As a run defender, he needs to be on the move to be effective. He does not anchor well and is not suited to serve as a two-gap space-eater. -- March 28, 2019 Hill is a highly gifted defensive tackle with a good combination of height, length, weight and speed. He has excellent first-step quickness and explodes off the ball. He does not anchor well and is not a two-gap space-eater. He plays hard but he's inconsistent and his impact doesn't always match his talent. He's late locating the ball and appears to lack natural instincts. The Cowboys needed depth along the interior of the D-line, and this is an upside play for a disruptor who won't see a ton of snaps. To wit: Hill started just once at Central Florida last season. But plug the "upside" label into the Rod Marinelli D-line development machine and you have a good shot to churn out an effective menace. -- Chris Sprow

Campbell hauled in 53 passes for 705 yards and three touchdowns combined in 2016-17 before exploding as a senior in 2018. He led the Buckeyes with 90 catches for 1,063 yards and 12 touchdowns in his final season. Campbell also broke the state record in the 60-meter dash at 2014 indoor state championships. Campbell has average size with exceptional speed and is a highly-explosive athlete whose natural traits do not always show up on tape. He runs a limited route tree (mostly crossers, screens and vertical routes) but possesses the speed to threaten vertically. Campbell can get in and out of breaks quickly and developed more savvy as a route-runner in 2018. He has the versatility to serve as a return specialist in the NFL as well. Campbell grades out as a future NFL starter. He will likely need time to develop as a route-runner but his speed and big-play potential add to his value as a versatile wide receiver with return capability. -- March 19, 2019 Campbell is a highly explosive athlete with the second gear to threaten vertically and after the catch. He ran a limited route tree at Ohio State but developed more savvy as a route runner in 2018 and is quick transitioning out of breaks. The Colts signed Devin Funchess this offseason, but it's a one-year deal and they needed to continue to add depth. Campbell -- and his 4.33 40 speed -- gives QB Andrew Luck a big-play threat with the potential to develop into an excellent complement to T.Y. Hilton. -- Steve Muench

Adderley is a versatile defensive back with a strong blend of balance, fluidity and better closing burst than his 40 time would suggest. He's a ball hawk who plays the ball, not the man, and he has excellent overall ball skills. There's an edge to his game. Adderley doesn't shy away from contact in run support, and he flashes the ability to separate receivers from the ball. Yes, even a secondary with star rookie Derwin James and ball-hawking corner Casey Hayward still needs real help. We note a safety and a corner because Adderley could be either, though an attempt to stick at CB seems likeliest, as the Chargers gave up 14 touchdowns and picked off only three balls thrown to wide receivers last year, the second-worst ratio in the NFL.-- Chris Sprow

Rapp was a three-year player at Washington who started 32 of 40 games played. He totaled 170 tackles, seven passes broken up and seven interceptions during his three seasons. Rapp has prototypical size and above-average top-end speed. But his arm length and hand-span are below average. What stands out about his measurables are his outstanding three-cone (6.82) and short-shuttle (3.99) results at the combine. He is a highly athletic and instinctive safety who excels in coverage but also has excellent tackling skills in run support. Rapp spent a lot of time as the high-safety in Washington's base 4-2-5 scheme, and he's capable of handling the single-high safety responsibilities in the NFL. He's also twitchy and crafty enough to handle some one-on-one matchups over the slot. He tracks the ball well and flashes the ability to pluck it out of the air. Rapp grades out as a starting safety early in his career and he's one of the top-three safeties in the 2019 class. -- March 22, 2019 Rapp's pro day 40 time is a concern. That said, he's an instinctive safety who plays faster than his timed speed and is an excellent athlete. His three-cone (6.82) and short shuttle (3.99) results at the combine were outstanding times for a safety. He tracks the ball well and has above-average ball skills. He's an above-average open-field tackler. The Rams replaced free-agent departure Lamarcus Joyner with six-time Pro Bowler Eric Weddle, and John Johnson III had a breakout year. This is still a great pick, as Weddle is 34 and Rapp is an excellent value at this point. He provides depth at safety as well as nickel and has the potential to develop into a starter early in his career. -- Steve Muench

Isabella is an undersized receiver with short arms, small hands and excellent top-end speed. He has the burst to develop into an above-average route runner, and he's willing to work the middle of the field. He's a slippery open-field runner with good explosiveness after the catch and running fly sweeps. One great way to help a rookie QB: find a receiver who can create separation in under a second. That's Isabella, who was nearly impossible to cover at UMass and piled up a whopping 1,698 yards last season, more than any wide receiver in the FBS. Larry Fitzgerald turns 36 in August, and this team is dying for playmakers for Kyler Murray. -- Chris Sprow

Thornhill is a versatile defensive back who has experience at both corner and safety. He has good size, solid top-end speed and below-average length. He is a playmaker who picked off six passes last season, and no one jumped higher than he did at the NFL scouting combine. Thornhill is a willing run-defender who does a good job of sifting through traffic. Thornhill will most likely compete for the safety spot opposite Tyrann Mathieu. The Chiefs could also play him at the corner opposite Kendall Fuller as Steven Nelson signed with Pittsburgh and Bashaud Breeland, who is playing for his third team in as many years, signed a one-year deal. -- Steve Muench

Metcalf was awarded a medical redshirt for his 2016 freshman season after breaking his foot in early September. In 2017, Metcalf started all 12 games and caught 39 passes for 646 yards and seven touchdowns. In 2018, he started all seven games he played and caught 26 passes for 569 yards and five touchdowns before suffering a season-ending neck injury. The son of former NFL OL Terrence Metcalf, he's built like Tampa Bay's Mike Evans. Metcalf has an elite combination of height, weight and speed with long arms and big hands. He's quick off the line of scrimmage and accelerates in a hurry. He's savvy as a route runner and has very good ball skills. Metcalf shows strong concentration in traffic and is outstanding on 50-50 balls. He's a strong runner after the catch and will break tackles. He's a hard worker, vocal leader and handles his business like a pro. Metcalf has the physical tools to become a featured starter in the NFL. If he checks out medically, he should be a top-40 pick and one of the first few wide receivers off the board. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Metcalf has an elite combination of height, weight and speed in addition to long arms and big hands. He shows strong concentration in traffic and is outstanding in 50-50 situations. He's a powerful open-field runner with the second gear to pull away when he gets a seam after the catch. Seattle partied like it was 1975 on offense in 2019, with a run-pass ratio that would make Darrell Royal proud. But baked into that equation was the poor health of top receiving option Doug Baldwin, who is facing an offseason of recovery and uncertain future in Seattle. Metcalf looks built for American Gladiators and can flat-out fly, but the question is whether he has the short-space agility to shake NFL defensive backs. At worst, he's an immediate deep threat to keep safeties honest, and if he ever puts it all together, watch out. -- Chris Sprow

Sudden with a quick first step, there's a lot to like about Allen's lateral agility. He's quicker than he is fast, converting speed-to-power as a pass rusher. As a run defender, he has a quick take off, gets into the lineman's pads in a flash, shows the length and strength to lock out and then does a good job locating the ball and disengaging in time to pursue. Allen plays with good discipline and sets a hard edge in the run game. His motor runs hot. You see some Cameron Jordan in him. Allen is a scheme versatile defensive end with the potential to play LDE in a base 4-3 front and/or 5-technique in a 3-4 front. -- May 24, 2018 As a run-defender, Allen gets into the lineman's pads, uses his long arms to lock out, locates the ball and disengages in time to pursue. He's more quick than fast and converts speed to power as a pass-rusher. He's a scheme-versatile defensive end with the potential to play LDE in a base four-man front and 5-technique in a base three-man front. The Cardinals were expected to bolster the defensive line in this draft, especially with Robert Nkemdiche tearing his ACL in December. Allen is a perfect fit at defensive end in Vance Joseph's base 3-4 defense and has the potential to develop into an effective interior pass-rusher who kicks inside in Joseph's sub-packages. -- Steve Muench

Johnson is undersized with shorter arms and average-sized hands and top-end speed. He tested poorly at the combine, but he's much quicker on tape. He is a quick-twitched receiver with very good burst off the line. He has developed into a crafty route-runner with very good quickness in-and-out of breaks. However, his ball skills are erratic. He shows the ability to adjust to poor throws and track the ball vertically but he has too many focus drops on tape. Johnson should contribute early as a No. 4 WR (outside and/or in the slot) and on special teams. His upside is likely as a No. 3 WR and he could push for a job as a return specialist. -- April 5 Johnson is undersized with decent speed, and he tested poorly athletically at the combine. He has developed into a crafty route runner who is much quicker on tape, but his combine numbers are still concerning. Johnson plucks passes with his hands, but he had several focus drops on tape. Well, lookie there. The Steelers used a pick acquired in the Antonio Brown trade to draft a wide receiver from the MAC. Pittsburgh has drafted four future Pro Bowl wideouts outside Round 1 since 2009, two more than any other team. JuJu Smith-Schuster and James Washington are arguably an underrated 1-2 combo, but Johnson could weave his way into the mix. -- Chris Sprow

Hurd is a big slot receiver with natural hands and slightly above-average length. He's got a good feel for windows in zone coverage but he's a developing route runner who doesn't show great burst or change of direction at the top of his breaks and struggles to separate from man coverage. He's a long strider with enough top-end speed to threaten down the seam and is smooth transitioning upfield after the catch but he's not an ankle breaker in space and not much of a threat to break away when he gets a crease. He runs hard and he's not afraid to work the middle of the field. While he primarily lined up at wide receiver, he showed a willingness to take some snaps at running back at Baylor. Hurd is a huge slot receiver with big hands and good length. He's not afraid to work the middle of the field, and he hasn't reached his potential as a route runner yet. Hurd started his college career at Tennessee where he lined up at running back. He carried the ball 48 times at Baylor last season, and he's versatile enough to play there at the next level. The 49ers continue to add weapons for Jimmy Garoppolo. It will be interesting to see how creative head coach Kyle Shanahan uses Hurd, who is a big slot receiver with plenty of experience playing running back. -- Steve Muench

Polite was a three-year player and one-year starter at Florida. In 2018, he racked up 45 tackles, 17.5 TFL, 11 sacks and six forced fumbles. He comes with a shorter frame and arm length but bulked up to 258 pounds at the combine in March. Polite is a twitched-up edge rusher with speed, change-of-direction quickness and closing burst. He gets moved too easily when teams run at him and is inconsistent with gap discipline. He is also late to diagnose the play and locate the ball too often. Polite is at his best when turned loose as a pass-rusher and has the potential to develop into an every-down starter (better fit as a 3-4 OLB than a 4-3 RDE). But he's likely to serve as a pass-rush specialist early in his career. -- March 12, 2019 Polite is a twitched-up edge rusher who has an explosive first step with good change-of-direction quickness and closing burst. A nagging hamstring adversely affected his combine testing. That said, he gets moved off the ball when teams run at him, and his motor is inconsistent. Only two players in FBS had 10 or more sacks, four or more forced fumbles and four or more pass breakups. One was Josh Allen, who went No. 7 overall, and the other was Polite, who could be a productive steal here. He had 11 sacks last season and joins a Jets' pass rush that beat its blocks in under 2.5 seconds just 18 percent of the time last season, according to ESPN's Pass Rush Win Rate metric. That was good for 23rd in the NFL among DE/OLB combos. -- Chris Sprow

Oliver is an F tight end with average size. He can also line up in the slot and out wide. He has the burst to threaten down the seam and pick up yards after the catch. Oliver has big hands, a wide catching radius and good body control. Jacksonville got only 530 receiving yards from its tight ends, which ranked 28th last year. Oliver gives new QB Nick Foles another weapon and a player with the potential to develop into a playmaker over the middle. -- Steve Muench

Henderson finished his college career with 421 carries for 3,545 yards and 36 touchdowns while also averaging 12 yards per catch on 63 catches with eight TDs. Yes, he has a shorter frame but also adequate bulk. He is a quick and decisive runner with good vision and feel. There's a good second-gear when he hits daylight and he doesn't go down very often on first contact. Catching the ball, he runs mostly outlet and underneath routes but is effective plucking on the run and quickly transitioning up-field. Henderson does struggle in pass pro, but he has the run skills and pass-catching reliability to be part of a two-back rotation in the NFL. -- March 19, 2019 Henderson is a quick and decisive runner with good vision and feel. He plays faster than his timed speed and shifts into another gear when he hits daylight. He runs hard and has above-average leg drive for his size. He's a reliable receiver, but he's a below-average pass-blocker at this point. Henderson averaged a whopping 8.9 yards per carry in 2017, and thus defenses were geared up to stop him in 2018. So much for that plan -- he averaged yet again an absurd 8.9 yards per carry. Todd Gurley led the NFL in touches by a running back over the past two seasons with 658, which perhaps led to his reduced role -- and C.J. Anderson's increased role -- in the playoffs. Henderson has a chance to help, and soon. -- Chris Sprow

Jones has a quick first step. He has good quickness and straight-line speed for size, but he has some tightness. He lacks a consistent plan as a pass-rusher. He has quick hands and flashes some violence but is still learning how to use his hands as a pass-rusher. Jones' feet and hands are not consistently tied together. He has only one sack in his first two seasons (2016-17). Jones has enough size and strength to anchor versus single blocks but struggles to keep his shoulders square and hold his ground against double-teams. He has a solid motor. Jones is an ascending talent but is still a work in progress. His best NFL fit is as a 3-technique tackle, but he has some scheme versatility. He grades out as a potential future NFL starter and projects as a Day 2 selection. -- May 10, 2018 Jones is an undersized defensive tackle with above-average length and a quick first step. He's a disruptive one-gap run-defender. He has heavy hands and flashes some violence with his initial punch rushing the passer. His best NFL fit is at 3-technique, but he could play defensive end in a base three-man front. Defensive ends Adam Gotis and Derek Wolfe are both entering contract years, so depth is needed. Jones helps with that and has the skill set to develop into a starter when he gets the chance. He should help fortify a Broncos defense that ranked 21st in rushing yards allowed per game last season. -- Steve Muench

Pratt is a rangy run-defender who closes well, takes sound pursuit angles and chases with good effort. He does a good job of sifting through traffic and knocks blockers back when he plays downhill. He's a former safety with the athletic ability and speed to compete with tight ends in man coverage. The Bengals are desperate for a rangy linebacker who can help against the run but also cover tight ends (who torched Cincy last season for 10 TDs, tied for the most given up in the NFL). The Bengals didn't get Devin Bush at No. 11 overall when Pittsburgh swept into the No. 10 spot to nab him, but Pratt could be a productive consolation and compete for a starting role. The former safety can definitely cover. -- Chris Sprow

Montgomery is a shifty between-the-tackles runner. He has above-average open-field instincts, and he flashes the ability to make multiple defenders miss when he gets into space. He's quick enough to turn the corner and shows good burst through the hole, although he doesn't have the second gear of a true breakaway threat. Montgomery runs with great effort and enough balance to pick up yards after contact. He's an above-average route runner with experience lining up wide and in the slot. He catches the ball well and is a threat after the catch. Montgomery grades out as a complementary back with the skill set to contribute on third down and potentially develop into an effective No. 2 in time. -- July 24, 2018 Montgomery is a big, shifty runner who can sift through traffic running between the tackles. He has good balance, runs with outstanding determination, catches the ball well and is a solid pass-blocker. The Bears' running backs averaged just 3.8 yards per carry last year and they traded Jordan Howard to the Eagles. Montgomery is a good fit for Chicago's scheme and has the potential to develop into an excellent complement to Tarik Cohen. -- Steve Muench

Singletary is a smaller back with above-average foot speed and burst. He makes defenders miss in the hole and flashes the ability to make multiple defenders miss when he gets into space. He is quick to and through the hole and turning the corner, and he has above-average speed, but not elite speed. He is at his best bouncing outside and cutting back. He doesn't have great brute strength, but he is a slippery runner who rarely takes clean hits; and he has above-average balance. He runs with above-average perseverance and effort. He doesn't always keep the ball high and tight. He is not a polished route runner, but he catches the ball well when given the chance and is dangerous after the catch. -- July 24, 2018 Singletary is an undersized back with below-average timed speed, but his tape is impressive. He's a relentless runner with great contact balance, and he excels at picking up yards after contact. He's more quick than fast and he shows good burst through the hole. He's a small target with small hands, and he caught just six passes in 2018. The Buffalo production of Grumpy Old Running backs gets a supporting actor who might score a few lines. LeSean McCoy and Frank Gore are 31 and 36, respectively, and Singletary is a Plinko runner who will bounce off contact and continue downhill. He's not a burner, but was extremely productive, topping 1,000 yards in three straight seasons. -- Chris Sprow

Sternberger is a really good athlete who's at his best working in the slot but has experience in-line. As a pass-catcher, he's reliable, has a big catch radius, and makes tough catches in traffic. He gives effort as a blocker b isn't good. He grades out as a backup and projects as a mid-round pick. Sternberger looks like a bulked-up receiver, and though he has experience playing in-line, he's at his best in the slot. He shows some craftiness as a route runner. He's a reliable pass-catcher and makes plays in traffic. He's a below-average blocker, but he's tough, and he competes. Jimmy Graham's production didn't match his contract last year, and Marcedes Lewis, who signed a one-year deal, turns 35 in May. Sternberger gives quarterback Aaron Rodgers a reliable pass-catcher with some big-play ability. -- Steve Muench

McLaurin was a three-year player and two-time team captain. He has very good top-end speed and was the fastest player at the Senior Bowl. He is a vertical receiver and special teams ace who has shown a willingness to block. He loves the game, has a great work ethic, and will learn to play all three wide receiver spots on offense in order to add to his value. He should be a mid-round value pick. McLaurin, who is extremely fast, is at his best running vertical routes. He tracks the deep ball well. He's a work in progress as an intermediate route runner, however. McLauring is a willing blocker who loves the game and gives great effort. He's going to be great on special teams. Washington wide receivers had a league-low 145 receptions last year, including just eight TD catches, the second-fewest total in the NFL. Don't let McLaurin's 35 receptions fool you, as he was part of a crowded Ohio State pass-catching unit that often hit for big plays. McLaurin has sub-4.4 speed -- which could help the fact that Washington receivers had only 525 yards after the catch last season -- and he's a brilliant special-teams gunner. Oh ... and we're fairly certain he's familiar with one Dwayne Haskins. -- Chris Sprow

Deiter absorbs the initial surge and anchors well. He's playing out of position at left tackle. He's quick and agile enough to cut off speed rushers, but his arm length is a red flag for an offensive tackle, and he gets pushed around when defenders get into his frame. He plays with good pad level and gets good push in the run game. He flashes the ability to press defenders once in position, but his base narrows and he falls off some blocks. Deiter's ability to line up at a number of different positions is a testament to his football intelligence. He's a team captain with excellent football character. Deiter grades out as a versatile reserve interior offensive lineman with the skill set to develop into an effective starting center or guard early in his career. -- May 11, 2018 Deiter is a versatile interior offensive lineman prospect with experience lining up at center, left guard and left tackle. He plays with good pad level, and he gets good initial push in the running game. He shows some shock in his hands, and he does an adequate job of anchoring in pass protection. When you have obvious needs at three different O-line positions, it can't hurt to draft an O-lineman whose position could be tabbed: All. The dude started an incredible 54 games in college. The Dolphins allowed a Pass Block Win Rate (see: pressure allowed in under 2.5 seconds) that had them 24th in the NFL last season. Deiter is part of more work to be done up front. -- Chris Sprow

As a two-year starter at Michigan, Long played all 26 games and totaled 39 tackles, 14 pass breakups and three interceptions. His coverage efficiency percentages were outstanding, which played a role in his average ball production. Long is a press-man corner with above-average height and length. He is a physical corner with adequate hip fluidity and top-end speed. He relies heavily on his very strong instincts in coverage and ability to reroute receivers. He gives up too much separation versus quicker WRs on double moves and sharp-cutting routes. He's a good tackler for the position and tough. Long grades out as a future NFL starter. He is a likely Day 2 pick in 2019. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Long is a physical and instinctive press-man corner with average size, below-average length and above-average top-end speed. He has good body control and does a good job of rerouting receivers despite his shorter arms. Long is a good tackler who is willing and physical in run support. Corner isn't a pressing need right now, but Long is a great fit for the Rams' scheme and he's an excellent value here. In addition, 33-year old Aqib Talib and Marcus Peters are both entering contract years. -- Steve Muench

Takitaki is well built with above-average top-end speed and adequate length. He gets stuck on some blocks, but he flashes a strong punch and he's stout. Takitaki closes well and he flies around. He's more effective in zone than he is when matching up in man coverage. The Browns gave up 78 rushes over 10-plus yards last year, including nine rushing touchdowns, a Tecmo Bowl-esque big play problem area that can't continue in 2019 if they want to unleash a potential takeaway combo of a great pass-rush and ball-hawking secondary. Takitaki adds competition at linebacker, where run stops will be a clear focus. -- Chris Sprow

Harris is an interchangeable safety with excellent timed speed and good size with slightly below-average length. He's a downhill run-defender who flashes good stopping power. He's big and instinctive enough to hold up in the box. He's strong and athletic enough to match up with tight ends. Detroit cut Glover Quin, but adds a player here capable of pushing 2018 third-round pick Tracy Walker for the starting job. Harris should also make an immediate impact on special teams. -- Steve Muench

Davis has got the first-step quickness and power base to move defenders off the ball when his technique is sound. He's got a wide frame, he gets set quickly and he anchors well in pass protection. His hand placement needs to get better, and he needs to play with better pad level at times. The dirty secret for the Titans last year was they gave up a ton of pressure on the inside and also didn't create adequate push. Josh Kline and Quinton Spain ranked last and fifth worst among guards in ESPN's Pass Block Win Rate, respectively, and the Titans' run game also was last in the NFL in average yards before contact. Davis could be asked to provide immediate help. Kline and Spain are gone. -- Chris Sprow

Layne is a taller corner with excellent length, above-average instincts and slightly above average speed. He does an above-average job of turning and running with receivers in press. He's a willing run-defender who shows the ability to square and wrap. The Steelers signed Steven Nelson, but Joe Haden is entering the final year of his contract and former first-round pick Artie Burns hasn't lived up to expectations. Coty Sensabaugh remains unsigned. Layne is a good fit for this scheme and an excellent value pick. -- Steve Muench

Saunders has a good blend of size, top-end speed and athletic ability. He stands up blockers and is strong enough to protect his linebackers by occupying double teams when he stays low. He has some upside as a pass-rusher, where he is strong enough to push the pocket and flashes the ability to win with his hands. The Chiefs had needs in the secondary, but does anyone realize they were dead last in the NFL in run defense DVOA last season? Saunders adds more fortification behind (or in between) Chris Jones and Derrick Nnadi on an interior that, while occasionally disruptive, gave up far too much last year. This mix could be elevated by more of a rotation, and Saunders could help. -- Chris Sprow

Ferguson racked up 187 tackles, 66.5 tackles-for-loss, 45 sacks and eight forced fumbles. He explodes off the ball and threatens with a combination of speed and power (more upper-body shock than lower drive). He has active hands but struggles to counter when he doesn't win with his first move. He's a disruptive run defender but not overly stout. Ferguson is at his best when he can stay on the move and pursue in space; he closes well chasing from the backside. He needs to get stronger and learn to do a better job of disengaging from blocks. While he fits best at base 4-3 DE, his frame and range make him a 3-4 OLB conversion candidate. Ferguson should be able to contribute as a pass-rush specialist early in his career, and he has the skill set to develop into a solid starter -- likely as a RDE in a base 4-3 scheme -- in a couple seasons. -- March 28, 2019 Ferguson is long and explodes off the ball. He threatens with a combination of speed and power rushing the passer. He has active hands but struggles to counter when he doesn't win with his first move. He's a disruptive run-defender who closes well chasing from the backside. There's room for improvement when it comes to stacking and shedding blocks. Baltimore lost its two best edge rushers to free agency with Terrell Suggs signing with Arizona and Za'Darius Smith signing with Green Bay. Ferguson should make an immediate impact as a pass-rusher and has the potential to develop into a three-down player. -- Steve Muench

Warring is a developmental tight end with average size, slightly below-average length and excellent top-end speed. He flashes as a route-runner and has the natural ability to develop superior separation skills for a tight end. He's a natural hands catcher with the frame to win 50-50 balls. His speed makes him a threat down the seam and after the catch. He flashes the ability to pick up yards after contact. Full name: Kahale Kuio Kalani Michael Wodehouse Warring. Now that you have that memorized, please note the fact that DeAndre Hopkins accounted for a league-high 38 percent of all Texans' passing yards last season, Demaryius Thomas is gone and Will Fuller is coming off a torn ACL. This is an upside play, but Warring is the type of natural you bet on. -- Chris Sprow

Harris is one of the top-five running back prospects in the 2019 class. He has good size and an explosive initial burst to-and-through the hole, but he struggles when forced to stop-and-start before the line of scrimmage. He's a decisive runner with outstanding vision. He grades out as a potential NFL starter but he is best suited to be used in a two-back committee. Harris projects as a Day 2 draft pick. A strong and competitive runner, Harris has good size. He is decisive with outstanding vision and good burst through the hole. Harris shows good contact balance in space, but he is not a big-play weapon as a pass-catcher. He does have reliable hands, though, and he is a strong pass-blocker. The Patriots already have a crowded backfield and they ranked fifth in rushing yards per game last year, but Harris is a good value at this point in the draft. -- Steve Muench

Barton is an average-sized linebacker with below-average length and very good top-end speed. He's a developing hand-fighter with excellent upper-body strength and can get off blocks. He's a rangy run defender with good closing speed and a good motor. He lines up over the slot at times and matches up well with tight ends. He shows good awareness and range in zone. The Seahawks gave up a very un-Seahawk-like 4.95 yards per rush last season, the third-worst mark in the NFL, and the worst mark in franchise history. Injuries and suspensions played a role, and Barton could be asked to step in soon. On paper, the fit is clear: He's a solid run defender with coverage range that Pete Carroll can work with. -- Chris Sprow

Okereke is an above-average tackler who plays with good body control. His fits are sound, and he rarely gets caught out of position as a run defender. He has good balance and flashes the ability to slip blocks in tight spaces but tends to take too long to get off blocks. He is on the lighter side and gets pushed around at times. He tends to take sound pursuit angles and chases with good effort. He does a good job of picking up linebackers and tight ends releasing into the flat. There's room for improvement when it comes to winning one-on-one battles, but he shows good timing and chases with above-average effort while rushing the passer. He's a natural leader with good character. Okereke grades out as a reserve linebacker with some upside. He likely will make his biggest impact on special teams early in his career, but he might never develop into a starter. -- June 9, 2018 Okereke is a versatile linebacker with excellent length and top-end speed. His pursuit angles are inconsistent, but he closes well. He does a good job of picking up backs releasing into the flat, and he matches up well with tight ends. He shows adequate awareness in underneath zone. There's room for improvement when it comes to winning one-on-one battles, but he closes well and he chases with above-average effort rushing the passer. General manager Chris Ballard hit a home run when he took Darius Leonard last year, and he takes another long linebacker with good range on Day 2 here. Okereke has the tools to push for the starting outside linebacker spot opposite Leonard early in his career. -- Steve Muench

McGovern was a three-year starter at Penn State who spent two seasons at right guard and one season (2017) at center. He has good upper-body strength but lacks some snap in his hands. Elite initial quickness will stress him in pass pro, but if he's able to get set with balance, he rarely loses. His long arms help him to overcome some mismatches. He doesn't have jarring pop in his punch, but he has solid lower-body strength and rarely gives up ground versus bull-rush. Plus, he's a highly-effective run-blocker. McGovern takes great angles, does a good job of latching on and shows above-average leg strength to drive defenders off the line. McGovern grades out as a backup interior offensive lineman in the NFL. He's a better fit at guard, but his experience and versatility at center adds value. McGovern is a tall interior offensive lineman with adequate bulk and long arms. He's a highly effective run-blocker who takes great angles, does a good job of latching on and drives defenders off the line. Elite initial quickness will give him some problems in pass protection, but he rarely loses once he locks on. The Dallas need on the offensive line is two-fold: On the immediate level, the Cowboys have a need at guard, which is where McGovern excels as a run-blocker in particular. On the secondary level, this group is pricey. Dallas spends $10 million more on their current O-line than any team in the league. This guy can help. As they say, first you get the money (discount), then you get the power (run game). Or something like that. -- Chris Sprow

Pipkins is an athletic offensive tackle with below-average length. He dominated Division II competition and played well at the East-West Shrine game, but there are still concerns about his ability to make the jump to the NFL. He's wide with his hands and needs to do a better job of keeping his hips under him. We expected the Chargers to bring in competition for Sam Levi at right tackle spot so this pick makes sense from a need standpoint. However, he was outside our top 300, so this a substantial reach. -- Steve Muench

Edoga was a four-year player and two-year starter at OT for USC. He finished with 43 games played and 26 starts (missed five career games due to injuries). He's shorter than an average tackle with solid bulk and good arm length. He's an easy mover with the ability to handle speed rushers off the edge and adjust to quick double moves. Edoga is a natural knee-bender with flexibility. He starts to get in trouble when his hands get too high and he gets lazy with his feet. As a run-blocker, he's quick out of stance, but is inconsistent with angles and overextends too often. He has the power to jolt defenders off the line, but if he is forced to latch and sustain, he becomes an erratic finisher. His legs die on contact too often. Edoga is a tough evaluation because he has the feet, power and natural pass protection skills to quickly develop into a starting NFL tackle. However, scouts have significant concerns about his football character, he's just an average run blocker and he's highly penalized. Edoga has some boom-or-bust potential. Edoga is a shorter-than-average tackle with solid bulk and good arm length. He gets set quickly and has a powerful punch. He's an easy mover with the ability to handle speed off the edge and adjust to double moves. As a run-blocker, he has the power to jolt defenders, but he becomes an erratic finisher and his legs die on contact too often. He lacks discipline and he's been highly penalized. The Jets lost both James Carpenter and Spencer Long in free agency, though "lost" perhaps overstates the impact, as New York's guards and center ranked 27th in ESPN's Pass Block Win Rate. Kelechi Osemele has been added, and now they have another guard prospect to, hopefully, help plug the interior and help Sam Darnold with better down-and-distance scenarios in 2019. -- Chris Sprow

Boykin is a big receiver who turned heads with an impressive workout at the combine. At 220 pounds with long arms and big hands, his numbers in the 40-yard dash, vertical, three-cone and broad jump were all outstanding for a receiver of his size. He's an immediate threat to take the top off the coverage, and he has some upside as a route runner. A Baltimore offense that added Marquise Brown in the first round adds another big-play threat here. Boykin's big frame and wide catching radius means quarterback Lamar Jackson doesn't need pinpoint accuracy when he throws Boykin the ball. -- Steve Muench

Dean initially signed with Ohio State before transferring to Auburn. He redshirted in 2015 and missed the following season with an injury. Dean played in 26 games the last two seasons (2017-18) and totaled 73 tackles, 17 pass breakups and two interceptions. Dean is a tall, long cornerback with speed. Durability has been a significant problem throughout Dean's career. But when healthy, he's a very good-sized cornerback prospect. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Dean is a tall, long and well-built corner with outstanding speed. He's at his best in press-man, in which he can use his length to reroute receivers. He uses his long arms to bat the ball down at the last second. He's long and strong enough to get off blocks, but his effort in run support is spotty. This was a good spot to go back to back. It wasn't just that Tampa Bay was 26th in passing yards allowed, it was how easy it was. Consider a 73 percent completion percentage allowed, the 8.2 yards per throw, and the 65.0 Total QBR. Stack the cornerbacks up. Dean can fly, but the technique needs to match the wheels. -- Chris Sprow

Ximines was a five-year player and four-year starter at Old Dominion, where he recorded 176 tackles, 51.5 tackles-for-loss, 33 sacks and 11 forced fumbles. He has an average height-weight-arm length combination, and he ran a surprisingly average 40-yard dash time of 4.78 at the combine. He has a quick first step and flashes ability to generate a push with speed-to-power moves. He has fast eyes to locate the ball quickly. Ximines has snap in his hands and good upper-body power (24 bench press reps), shooting his hands inside and making it tough for blockers to lock on to him. He has good bend but average closing speed. As a run defender, he's at his best slipping blocks and shooting gaps. He plays with good pad level and flashes the ability to stack bigger blockers, but he gets engulfed and turned at times. Old Dominion occasionally asked him to pick up backs releasing into the flat, and he moves well enough to be considered a 34OLB conversion candidate. He grades out as a situational pass-rusher early in his career and has the potential to develop into a starter -- most likely at 3-4 OLB. -- March 28, 2019 Ximines has a quick first step, and he flashes the ability to generate push with speed-to-power moves. He has enough lateral quickness to cross the face of offensive tackles on outside-in moves. Ximines is at his best slipping blocks and shooting gaps in the running game. He has snap in his hands and good upper-body power, but he's light for a defensive end. The Giants had only 30 sacks last year and lack a proven edge rusher after trading Olivier Vernon to the Browns. Ximines is an above-average pass-rusher and a good fit at outside linebacker in defensive coordinator James Bettcher's 3-4 scheme. -- Steve Muench

Knox played in six games on special teams as a true freshman in 2016. The last two seasons, he played 22 of 24 games and finished with 39 catches for 605 yards. Has good length and bulk combination. Knox has good acceleration off the line and shows a quality second-gear when getting vertical. He needs to do a better job of using his frame to box out defenders and can also improve on 50-50 balls. He takes good angles as a run blocker and gives quality effort but lacks power at the point of attack and often struggles to sustain. Knox has upside due to his frame and speed, but he's an underdeveloped route runner with inconsistent ball skills. He grades out as a reserve TE early in his career and has potential to possibly develop into a starter. Knox is a likely mid-round pick. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Knox has a high ceiling, thanks to his excellent blend of size, length and top-end speed. He accelerates off the line, and he shows a second gear when getting vertical. He's an underdeveloped route runner with inconsistent ball skills. His effort is good as a blocker in the running game and in pass protection, but he needs to get stronger. The Bills ranked 30th in the NFL last season in yards after the catch, and despite the additions of Cole Beasley and John Brown in free agency, the team could still use an athletic difference-maker in the passing game -- or at least the upside of one. That's Knox, who didn't see big totals as part of a crowded passing game at Ole Miss but has that rare trait of explosiveness in a tight end frame. -- Chris Sprow

Evans has average size and top-end speed with decent length. He's a developing hand fighter who flashes the ability to shoot his hands, knock defenders' hands down and rewrap in pass protection. He's not as effective when he doesn't win with his hands. He does an adequate job of getting into position and steering defenders in the run game. Evans needs to play with better pad level and keep his hips under him. He has experience playing left and right tackle. Andrew Whitworth continues to play at a high level, but he is 37 years old and is in a contract year. Evans improves depth and gives the Rams a potential heir apparent to Whitworth. -- Steve Muench

Williams is a tweener outside linebacker/safety with very good length. While he played linebacker in college and he's tough, his frame raises his concerns about his ability to play there in the NFL. He's fast enough to play safety but he's tight in space. A rangy run defender, he tracks the ball well and chases with good effort. Has the tools to develop into a core special teamer. The Jaguars have other needs that are arguably bigger than linebacker, but Williams is a play for depth in sub packages and perhaps more. Yes, he is the brother of No. 3 overall pick Quinnen Williams.

Edwards is a shorter safety with good top-end speed, average bulk and below-average length. He plays bigger than his size and shows good balance and physicality matching up with tight ends. He's an above-average tackler who takes sound pursuit angles. His instincts and ability to beat blockers to the point makes him effective for his size in the box. He's a hands catcher who tracks the ball well. The Buccaneers continue to address the secondary, taking their third defensive back of Day 2. Edwards is a good value at this point in the draft and he's capable of pushing for a starting role early in his career. -- Steve Muench

Grier has below-average height and size. He has good short-to-intermediate accuracy but struggles with deep accuracy. He frequently throws off-balance and has a bad habit of falling off his downfield throws. Grier likes to see his receiver come open before throwing and lacks consistent anticipation as a passer. He makes too many poor decisions under pressure. He does get the ball out quickly in the quick game. He has average zip on intermediate throws but can drive the ball vertically, although it requires full-body effort. Grier is a good athlete who extends a high percentage of plays with his feet. He's competitive and tough, but durability is a concern. Grier is a productive and athletic college quarterback with mechanical flaws as a passer. If developed properly, he has enough talent to emerge as a solid NFL backup quarterback. He projects as a mid-round pick. -- May 30, 2018 Grier has a quick release, above-average foot speed and an adequate frame. He finds checkdowns given time and space.
