He's willing to take a hit to make a play. He's an above-average athlete capable of extending plays and scrambling for first downs. He has adequate arm strength and needs to step into his throws to drive the ball. Grier is not being brought in as a good angel on Cam Newton's shoulder, a reminder not to drop your pads when he could instead slide, because "Hey, I might take over." What he does offer is immediate high-upside backup potential if Newton misses any time -- Newton has missed multiple starts in two of the past three years -- and the long-term possibility of more. -- Chris Sprow

Cajuste has a wide frame, above-average initial quickness and good overall athletic ability. He's quick enough to get into position and strong enough to wall off defenders in the running game. He has average length for a tackle, and he gives up the edge at times. He might be a better fit on the inside as a result. Trent Brown signed with Oakland and a torn Achilles sidelined 2018 first-round pick Isaiah Wynn for his entire rookie season. Cajuste might be a better fit at guard than tackle where he played in college, but offensive line coach Dante Scarnecchia is the best in the business and will maximize Cajuste's natural ability. -- Steve Muench

Mattison was a two-year starter at Boise State who averaged 4.9 yards on 581 carries and 8.5 yards on 60 receptions. He has ideal size, very good strength and lower-body explosiveness but below-average agility and top-end speed. He has been durable throughout his career but also has taken a considerable beating the last two seasons as Boise State's workhorse back. Mattison runs with solid pad level and shows good contact balance. He has a powerful lower body and consistently finishes runs falling forward. He's a highly competitive runner who shows great toughness. Mattison lacks ideal lateral agility and elusiveness. He has adequate initial burst but lacks a second gear. He's a very reliable pass-catcher but not much of a route-running threat. He's big, strong and aggressive in pass protection with a powerful upper body. He shows exceptional ball security, losing just one fumble on 654 career offensive carries. Mattison grades out as an NFL No. 2 or No. 3 back and is likely a Day 3 pick in 2019. -- March 6, 2019 Mattison is a big back with exceptional strength and below-average top-end speed. He's highly competitive, running with good pad level and contact balance. He consistently finishes runs falling forward. He lacks ideal elusiveness and a second gear. He's a reliable pass-catcher but not much of a route-running threat. He's big, strong and aggressive in pass protection. Dalvin Cook has played in a total of 15 games over two NFL seasons. You can imagine why Rick Spielman might consider running back a need area even if Cook is comfortably flipping monster truck tires up hills this offseason. Mattison is productive -- a proven runner and pass-catcher who can provide immediate depth. He won't out-fox linebackers at this level with quickness, but he can play. -- Chris Sprow

Butler is a vertical threat with an excellent blend of size and speed. He's more than fast enough to take the top off the coverage and he wins one-on-one downfield. His top-end speed and ability to break tackles make him dangerous after the catch. He has a high drop rate but he's a massive target with the body control and length to make spectacular catches. He's not an overly explosive or polished route runner but he flashes the ability to change speeds and separate with strength at the top of his routes. -- November 9, 2018 Butler is a big target with excellent length, big hands and good top-end speed. He has the frame and body control to win one-on-one downfield. He isn't as dangerous after the catch, but he's a powerful open-field runner. Butler flashes the ability to make the first defender miss, and he's a threat when he gets a chance to build speed.

Finley started all 29 games during the past three seasons at NC State and completed 64.5 percent of his attempts. He has adequate-to-good delivery quickness with an over-the-top stroke, but velocity is average on "zip" throws. Still, he shows very good touch and anticipatory accuracy, and is adept at leading receivers and getting the ball out on time. Finley has fast eyes in getting through progressions quickly with very good poise and feel inside the pocket. He senses pressure and knows when to climb and when to slide laterally, all while keeping his eyes downfield. Mobility is above-average. However, Finley will make two or three poor decisions per game and occasionally misses easy throws. Finley has the potential to develop into a solid NFL starter. -- March 19, 2019 Finley is a tall and lean quarterback who has fast eyes and gets through his progressions quickly. He has very good touch and is adept at leading receivers. Finley keeps his eyes downfield and his feet married to his eyes while maneuvering inside the pocket. He has average arm strength. He also makes two to three questionable decisions per game. Andy Dalton has set franchise records in his eight seasons and he has two years left on his contract, but he's 0-4 in playoffs and there's no dead money if the Bengals release him. Last year he missed the final five games with a thumb injury and Jeff Driskel went 1-4 in his place. Finley gives new head coach Zac Taylor a quarterback to mold. -- Steve Muench

In three seasons at Florida, Gardner-Johnson played in all 37 games (25 starts) and racked up 161 tackles, 9 passes broken up and 9 interceptions. He has very good speed for his size and is a smooth mover with very good closing burst. He can handle deep-middle responsibility and also does a good job in the "overhang" role. Gardner-Johnson has adequate-to-good ball skills with good reaction quickness. He attacks the ball when given the opportunity. He's instinctive and understands concepts but is slightly more comfortable in man-to-man coverage than zone. There's great range in run support here, but he gets caught on blocks too long. When in position, he does a good job of coming to balance and wrapping up. Gardner-Johnson has the physical tools to develop into a starting safety in the NFL, and he's capable of handling a starting nickel role early in his career. -- March 12, 2019 Gardner-Johnson is an instinctive free safety with shorter-than-ideal arms and very good speed. He's a smooth mover with the range to play center field. He does a good job of coming to balance and wrapping up. He was a very good special-teams player early in his college career and is capable of contributing in that area in the NFL.

Crosby is a disruptive run defender with good first-step quickness and active hands. He closes well and makes plays in pursuit. He chases the quarterback with great effort, and he has the tools to develop into an effective pass-rusher but he's not there yet. He's light with short arms for a defensive end. He tested well and performed well during linebacker drills at the combine, making him an excellent 3-4 OLB candidate.

Nelson is a tall, well-built left defensive end with excellent length and average top-end speed for his size. He's got the size, strength and length to set the edge. He plays high and occasionally gives ground, though. He's a power rusher who flashes effective push-pull and long arm moves. He tracks the quarterback and falls back inside when the quarterback steps up. He doesn't bend or close well enough to regularly win with speed off the edge.

Love was a three-year starter for Notre Dame, racking up 176 tackles, 39 pass deflections and five interceptions. He's a versatile cornerback with experience on both sides of the formation as well as over the slot, and he has natural playmaking instincts. In coverage, he's at his best playing off-zone but he has enough athleticism to hold up in most man-to-man matchups. He has fast eyes, displays above-average balance and shows good short-area quickness. Love closes well when coming forward and limits production after the catch in off-coverage. He's not afraid to take chances and jump underneath routes. The downside is he gambles and then doesn't have the speed to recover when he gets caught out of position. His average-sized frame hinders his ability to compete with bigger receivers in 50-50 situations, and then his effort in run support is only adequate. Love grades out as an eventual No. 2 or No. 3 CB in the NFL and he's capable of contributing in sub-packages as a rookie. -- March 19, 2019 Love is a versatile corner with experience on both sides of the formation as well as over the slot. He has fast eyes, above-average balance and good short-area quickness. He closes well and limits production after the catch. He has natural playmaking instincts and good overall ball skills.

Willis is a thick safety with below-average length and average speed. He's a downhill run defender who takes sound angles and is effective playing close to the line of scrimmage. He's instinctive and runs well enough to cover a deep half. He limits production after the catch. He's not a centerfielder, he doesn't have the cover skills to regularly match up with slot receivers and his frame raises concern about his ability to cover tight ends.
Wishnowsky has the accuracy, leg strength, athletic ability and versatility to quickly develop into an above-average punter and effective holder.

Sheffield is an explosive athlete with good strength and excellent straight-line speed. He has limited starting experience, but his instincts improved with more playing time in 2018. The Alabama transfer likes to play physical, and he's at his best in press-man coverage.

Love broke out as a junior in 2017, when he finished first among Power 5 running backs in rushing yards (2,118), rushing yards per game (162.9), rushing yards per attempt (8.1) and 100-yard rushing games (12). He is an explosive runner with the burst to turn the corner and the speed to pull away when he catches a seam. He's got the foot speed to bounce between gaps and make defenders miss. Love is a patient runner who reads his blocks and shows a good feel for cutback lanes. He has the potential to develop into a weapon in the passing game, but he doesn't appear to be a natural pass catcher. His frame also hinders his ability to anchor in pass protection, but he has very good awareness and technique. Ball security has been above average. Love projects best in a rotational role in the NFL. -- March 28, 2019 Love is an explosive runner with the burst to turn the corner and the speed to pull away when he catches a seam. He has the foot speed to bounce between gaps and make defenders miss. He's an undersized back with slightly below-average power. He has had some problems staying healthy, and he tore an ACL in the regular-season finale.

Hill gets greedy and tries to make too much happen on occasion, but he tends to give his blockers time to get into position and reads his blocks well. He has a good feel for cutback lanes and above-average open-field instincts. He is quick to and through the hole. There's a noticeable burst when he gets a seam. He executes violent jump cuts and makes defenders miss. He doesn't have elite breakaway speed. He runs hard and picks up yards after contact due to effort and balance, but he is an undersized back with a below-average power base. He doesn't project as a short-yardage runner in the NFL. He flashes the potential to develop into a reliable safety valve in the passing game, but he hasn't been much of a threat after the catch and is a below-average pass blocker. Hill grades out as a complementary back who would boost his draft stock by making more of an impact as a receiver. -- June 27, 2018 Hill is an undersized back with outstanding explosiveness and top-end speed. There's a noticeable burst when he hits the hole between the tackles and is quick around the corner. He makes defenders miss in the hole and has the tools to develop into a weapon in the passing game.

Samia is an above average athlete with good foot speed for the position. He has adequate-to-good initial pop at the point of attack but is not a mauler. He has been a reliable, durable and versatile player throughout his career. He grades out as a starting guard in the NFL and could also serve as an emergency tackle. He is likely to be selected on Day 2 of the 2019 NFL draft. Samia is a long-levered guard with adequate bulk and good foot speed for the position. He's a fundamentally sound run-blocker who gets adequate-to-good initial pop. He gets good hand placement, mirrors well and shows good awareness in pass protection. He has experience playing right tackle and can fill in there in an emergency.

Miller had his best year as senior in 2018. Miller is a very instinctive pass rusher. He has a quality club move when turning the corner but needs to develop more effective counter moves. He projects best as a 3-4 outside linebacker in the NFL. He has enough talent and the right mentality to contribute on special teams early on, and eventually he should develop into a solid backup. His leadership and excellent football character increase his value. He is likely to be a Day 3 pick in 2019. Miller is an instinctive pass rusher with outstanding length, good speed and some natural bend. He lacks ideal redirect quickness and needs to develop more effective counter moves. He's lean and he struggles to anchor when teams run at him. He's a team leader with a professional work ethic and has the tools to make immediate contributions on special teams.

Hooker is a well-built, compact safety/nickelback with marginal length and above-average top-end speed. He's at his best lining up over the slot, where he's patient and doesn't overreact to the receiver's first move. He's a ball hawk with the hands and instincts to be a playmaker in the NFL. He closes well in run support.

Bryant was a two-year starter at Clemson and racked up 152 tackles, 35 tackles for loss and 20 sacks. He primarily plays LDE in Clemson's base 4-3 front. He has an excellent frame and carries his weight well. Bryant has average top-end speed with longer arms and average hands. As a pass-rusher, he has a quick first step. He can be slippery at times and occasionally advances his rush while engaged. He flashes at times as an interior pass-rusher in sub packages. However, he has a lot of tightness in his movement and he's not a smooth athlete. Versus the run, he shows enough size and strength to set the edge and gives good effort. He has good length and is a solid wrap-up tackler, but he plays too high at times and lacks explosive power. Bryant grades out as a backup DE (best suited as a base 4-3 DE) and his value will likely be early on Day 3. -- Feb. 26, 2019 Bryant has an excellent frame with outstanding length and he carries his weight well. As a pass-rusher, he has a quick first step, and he occasionally advances his rush while engaged. He is slow to redirect and his tightness shows up when he tries to bend the edge. He's big and strong enough to set the edge, but he plays too high a times. He chases the run and rushes the passer with good effort.

Froholdt is an athletic run-blocker with the initial quickness and lateral mobility to develop into an above-average zone blocker even though his footwork and angles are inconsistent. He's an above-average second-level blocker who shows good range when asked to pull. He gets off the ball and flashes the ability to drive defenders, but his feet stop and he fails to climb the defender more often than not. He has the quick first step to prevent penetration and the active feet to mirror in pass protection. He digs in and holds his ground in a shoebox, but his pads tend to rise and his feet come together, so he gets knocked off balance by club and slap moves. While Froholdt does an adequate job of rewrapping and fighting to get his hands inside, his below-average length makes it tough for him to maintain separation and keep defenders off his chest. He shows above-average awareness in pass pro and the run game, especially for a player who didn't grow up playing the game. He's not a mauler, but he doesn't back down; and he finishes when he gets his man on the ropes. He has a professional work ethic but is not an alpha leader. He fits best in a zone-heavy scheme, and his length raises concerns about his ability to develop into a starter. -- Sept. 1, 2018. Froholdt is an athletic run-blocker with the quickness, balance and lateral mobility to succeed in a zone-heavy scheme. His short arms hinder his ability to keep defenders off his frame, but he gets set quickly and does a good job of staying in front of his assignment for the most part in pass protection. He sinks his hips and anchors after giving ground initially.

Redwine was a two-year starter at safety for Miami and missed just two games throughout his career. During his final two seasons, he totaled 123 tackles, eight pass breakups and five sacks. Redwine has good height, adequate bulk and below-average speed. He also has solid arm length but smaller hands. He's not overly twitchy and lacks ideal recovery speed but is a smooth athlete. Redwine will struggle to match up one-on-one with WRs and most TEs in the NFL. He has average-at-best range in zone coverage. He matured a lot during his college career and is well-liked by teammates. Redwine grades out as a reserve NFL safety with the size and toughness to contribute on special teams. He projects as a Day 3 pick. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Redwine has good height and length and excellent top-end speed, although he doesn't play as fast as his timed speed. He has decent ball skills. Redwine takes sound angles and is a physical tackler in run support.

Jennings Jr. is a possession slot receiver with average size and below-average top-end speed. He isn't overly sudden and is more smooth than twitchy. He's willing to work the middle of the field and possesses above-average ball skills. He shows ability to pluck on the run, adjust to off-target throws and make tough catches in traffic. He isn't much of a vertical threat and doesn't consistently make the first defender miss after the catch. He has inconsistent aggressiveness as a blocker. -- May 30, 2018 Jennings Jr. is an above-average vertical route-runner who tracks the ball well and has the top-end speed to threaten downfield. He's not a sudden route-runner, and he struggles to separate from underneath man coverage. He has an above-average catching radius, and he catches passes away from his frame, but his hands are a little inconsistent.

Wesco is a natural hands catcher with the frame and toughness to make difficult grabs over the middle. He doesn't have the second gear to threaten down the seam or pull away from pursuit, but he's a slippery open-field runner with the balance to break initial contact after the catch. He has the frame to develop into an effective in-line blocker too. He's aggressive and gets good initial pop.

Snell is a powerful between-the-tackles runner with the core strength and balance to regularly pick up yards after initial contact. He lowers his shoulder to finish runs. He's quick enough to turn the corner and has enough top-end speed to rip off a chunk of yards, but he's not an explosive breakaway threat and is not an ankle-breaker in space. Snell's lack of production in the passing game is a concern, and he's a raw route runner. He flashes good ball skills when given the opportunity, however. There's room for improvement when it comes to technique, but there's a lot to like about Snell's size, awareness and willing to compete when it comes to pass protection. Snell is a big back who grades out as a complementary short-yardage and goal-line runner with some upside. He projects as a mid-round pick going into the 2018 season. -- July 23, 2018 Snell is a big back and powerful between-the-tackles runner with the core strength and balance to pick up yards after contact. He lowers his shoulder and delivers the blow to finish runs. He's not as effective running outside as inside. Snell is not a breakaway threat or an ankle breaker in space. His lack of ideal production in the passing game is a concern. He flashes good ball skills given the opportunity.

Powers is an experienced, tough and savvy player. He plays a little bit too high at times but otherwise displays good overall balance and technique. He doesn't overwhelm many pass-rushers with power but he uses balance, poise, awareness and hand-placement to win at a high rate. He has excellent football character. Powers has the potential to develop into a solid NFL starting guard and he projects as a mid-round pick in 2019. Powers is an experienced, tough and savvy guard with excellent football character. He plays with good overall balance and technique. Powers is an efficient pass-blocker who wins with poise, awareness and solid hand placement.

Haynes is a well-built guard with above-average length and top-end speed. He's strong enough to move defenders off the ball when he plays with sound technique. He gets set quickly and holds his ground in pass pro. He has excellent upper-body strength and defenders snap back when he lands his punch. He flashes a nasty disposition.

Wren has an excellent blend of size, length and top-end speed for a defensive tackle. He's versatile enough to line up on the inside in a four-man front and defensive end in a three-man front. He's a stout run defender with the size and strength to clog up the middle when he stays low. His pads rise and he gets washed out at times. He has some upside, but he doesn't win with his hands and frequently stalls out rushing the passer.

Ridley has good size with long arms and big hands. He lacks explosive burst off the line and has average top-end speed but is a savvy route runner who understands leverage and tempo. He drops his weight quickly when getting in and out of breaks and does a good job of generating late separation. Ridley has strong hands in traffic and shows good body control when adjusting to the ball. He's not much of a big-play threat and doesn't offer much run-after-catch production, but he isn't afraid to work the middle of the field. Ridley grades out as a possession No. 2 or No. 3 wideout in the NFL. -- March 19, 2019 Ridley has average size, long arms and big hands while being a savvy route runner. He has strong hands in traffic, shows good body control when adjusting to the ball and commits very few focus drops. He isn't, however, much of a big-play threat.

Marshall totaled 217 tackles, an impressive 36 passes broken up and six interceptions, but he did not have a pick the past two seasons. The only three games he missed in four seasons were in 2017. He has good height and bulk but short arms for his frame and just average top-end speed. His 4.39-second short shuttle is a red-flag. He is effective at times in press coverage but needs to be more consistent. While he shows good balance and body control, he has tightness and some athletic limitations. Plus, he doesn't trust his eyes and struggles to locate the ball. He will get caught staring down the QB and will lose track of the receiver, getting grabby and panicking when he's worried that he's lost. And he does not show an elite second gear to recover from mistakes. Still, when in position, he does show soft hands and he does a good job of getting his hand in late. And for a corner, he's pretty strong in run support. In all, he has the potential to develop into a No. 3 or No. 4 cornerback in the NFL and will need to carve out a niche on special teams in order to maintain a roster spot. -- April 5 Marshall is a big corner with below-average length and average top-end speed. He's aggressive, keeps contain and is a solid tackler in run support. He has good balance and is effective at times in press but needs to be more consistent. He's tight and his Pro Day short-shuttle time is a red flag. He flashes soft hands and does well getting his hands in late to break up passes.

Pollard has solid size, a muscular frame and very good top-end speed. He's a one-cut-and-go back with solid vision and very good acceleration, best suited for a zone-blocking scheme. He has good patience to wait for a crease, and then the acceleration to exploit that crease if it opens. He's an upright runner and more of a straight-line athlete. He has some tightness and doesn't show great lateral burst or the ability to consistently string multiple cuts together in tight spaces. You need to get him going downhill to maximize his tools. Pollard is basically a versatile matchup piece on offense who can lineup in the backfield and in the slot. He also has the potential to develop into an NFL starting kick returner. -- March 19, 2019 Pollard has a muscular frame and very good top-end speed. He's a one-cut-and-go type of back best suited for a zone-heavy scheme. He's got the patience to wait for creases to open, and he shows great burst through the hole. He's a versatile weapon who has excellent experience at receiver and returned seven kickoffs for touchdowns at Memphis. He's also been effective covering kicks.

Johnson moved from receiver to corner in the spring of 2017 and started five of the 12 games he appeared in that year, finishing with 45 tackles, nine pass breakups and two interceptions. In 2018, he finished with 66 tackles, seven pass breakups and two interceptions. Johnson is a tall and lean press/zone corner with the length, frame and toughness to make it tough for receivers to get off the line. He needs to fill out that frame, get stronger and improve as a hand fighter. He has above average top-end speed, closes well and limits production after the catch. He struggles in off-coverage. Johnson has limited experience and it shows up frequently in his recognition skills. He has smaller hands but the former WR has shown good ball skills for the position. Has good size and gives solid effort in run support, but his tackling skills need to improve. Johnson's an excellent gunner and jammer on special teams. Johnson has the tools to develop into a starter down the road but he needs refinement and will need to be in a press-zone heavy scheme. Early in his career, he should make an impact on special teams. Johnson projects as a Day 2 pick. -- Feb. 26, 2019 Johnson has the length, frame and top-end speed to develop into an effective press/zone corner. He has smaller hands, but he's a former receiver who flashes good ball skills for the position and doesn't have to be in perfect position to make a play on the ball thanks to his length. He's willing to step up in run support. He's an inconsistent tackler.

Tranquil is a well-built inside linebacker with outstanding top-end speed. He reads his keys, locates the ball and beats blockers to the point of attack. He has excellent upper body strength, yet there's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. Tranquill matches up well with tight ends.

Martin is a shorter guard with average bulk, average top-end speed and below-average length. He has excellent upper-body strength but his hand placement is inconsistent and at times he gives too much ground in pass pro. He has an average base and he flashes a mean streak in the run game.

Amadi is a free safety/nickelback prospect with slightly above-average length and above-average top-end speed. He's at his best playing over the slot where he's quick, balanced and fluid enough to match up. He tracks the ball well and has good hands. He's an above-average tackler who plays with good body control and wraps up.

Stidham began his career at Baylor but transferred to McLennan Community College. As the No. 1 ranked JUCO prospect in the country, he transferred to Auburn in 2017, where in two seasons, he completed 63.6 percent of his throws with 36 touchdowns and 11 interceptions. Stidham has adequate size and above-average mobility. He has good overall arm strength, can fit the ball into tight spots and shows the ability to drive the ball vertically. He has very good accuracy on underneath throws and does a great job of leading his receivers to yards after the catch, but he's inconsistent with ball placement on intermediate throws. The biggest concern with Stidham is his processing quickness. He locks onto his primary target too long and misses too many open receivers. He's a good athlete and capable of extending a lot of plays with his feet but his mental clock is inconsistent. While Stidham has natural talent as a passer, he will need the right system and coaching in order to develop into anything more than a NFL backup. He's a likely mid-round pick. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Stidham has adequate size, good arm strength and above-average mobility. He can fit the ball into tight spots and shows the ability to drive the ball vertically when he has space to step into his throws. He's accurate and does a great job of leading his receivers to yards after the catch. Tom Brady continues to play at a high level but he turns 42 in August and backup Brian Hoyer isn't the long-term answer. We had a late second-round grade on Stidham, making him an excellent value pick here. -- Steve Muench

Gaines started all 41 games during his final three seasons at Washington (2016-18) and recorded 120 tackles, 19.5 tackles-for-loss and 9.5 sacks during that time. He is a shorter, squatty nose tackle with short arms and average straight-line speed. He has active hands and average first-step quickness. He does a good job of setting up his spin move and he flashes the ability to get to the quarterback with effort but his lack of length makes it tough to get into the chest of offensive linemen. He is a stout run defender with a low center of gravity and good bulk. He has a powerful upper-body (30 bench press reps) and has shock in his hands. Gaines does an excellent job of locating and tracking the ball for an interior defensive lineman. He chases with above-average effort and is a powerful tackler who drives his legs through contact. Gaines grades out as a backup nose tackle who is unlikely to develop into a solid NFL starter. -- March 22, 2019 Gaines is a squatty nose tackle with short arms and average straight-line speed. He has active hands and average first-step quickness. He flashes the ability to get to the quarterback with effort, but he's a better run defender than pass-rusher. He's a stout run defender with a low center of gravity and good bulk. He has a powerful upper body and good shock in his hands. He does an excellent job of locating and tracking the ball for an interior defensive lineman.

Cominsky erased concerns about ability to make the jump from Division II Charleston to the NFL with an excellent combine workout and steady performance the week of the Senior Bowl. He's got the size, strength and length to set the edge. He's a better run defender on the outside than he is on the inside. While he has the potential to develop into an effective pass rusher, he had just three sacks in 2018.

Jordan was the first true freshman to start along the Ohio State offensive line since Orlando Pace in 1994. His excellent awareness really jumps off the tape. He knows when to come off initial blocks and when to give help. He uses good natural leverage to uproot DTs at the point of attack, and he keeps his legs driving. He should be a plug-and-play starter at either center or guard in the NFL and projects to be a Day 2 pick. Jordan is a well-built, versatile interior lineman with the size and length to play center or guard. He plays with good leverage and flashes the ability to uproot defensive tackles. His excellent awareness in pass protection and the run game jump out on tape.

He's an aggressive, physical lead blocker who isn't afraid to stick his face in the fan when he lines up at F and inserts between the tackles as a lead blocker. He's also a tough in-line blocker who gets off the ball and plays to the whistle. That said, he doesn't have great brute strength and struggles to sustain. He's a big target with the potential to develop into an effective zone buster, but he lacks the burst and athletic ability to regularly separate from man coverage. He has an above-average catching radius and flashes the ability to make plays in traffic but is not a natural pass-catcher and fights the ball at times. He doesn't have the second gear to take the top off the coverage or threaten after the catch. -- Oct. 22, 2018 Moreau has average size but better length and top-end speed. He's a competitive blocker, but he stalls out and falls off blocks. He had an excellent workout at the combine yet he didn't make much of an impact as a receiver at LSU. He's a big target with the toughness to work the middle of the field, but he doesn't separate well. He's a team captain and natural leader with a professional work ethic.

Miller is a lighter defensive end with good length and top-end speed. He dips his inside shoulder and reduces surface area rushing off the edge. He looks to work inside when the offensive tackle oversets. He's a disruptive run defender who tracks the ball, chases with above-average effort and closes well in pursuit. He flashes the ability to stack and shed, but he takes too long to get off some blocks.

Thompson is a rangy free safety with excellent athleticism and speed. He has flashed good ball skills but dropped an easy interceptions in the Orange Bowl and missed out on multiple other INT opportunities during the second half of the season. Thompson lacks ideal experience as a one-year starter at Alabama but he has the skill set to quickly emerge as a quality starting free safety in the NFL. He is a likely top-50 pick in 2019. Thompson is a tall and lean free safety with excellent range and excellent instincts. He's adept at reading routes and the eyes of quarterbacks. Thompson had multiple opportunities to intercept passes that he failed to cash in on. He takes sound angles and closes well in run support.

Armstead is a big back with excellent top-end speed for his size and is a threat to go the distance if he gets a seam. He's an overaggressive runner who doesn't gives his blockers time to get into position and misses some holes.

Gentry has a rare combination of height, weight and arm length. His size creates matchup problems as a F-TE. He is still a bit raw as a route runner and he lacks initial burst to drive defenders off the line but he does build speed and tracks the ball well downfield. There's too many focus drops on tape but he flashes the ability to win jump balls. He has a huge frame to wall-off as a blocker but he needs to improve his strength and technique, including hand placement. He grades out as a No. 3 TE at best early in his career. -- March 28, 2019 Gentry has a rare combination of height, weight and arm length, but he has marginal top-end speed. His size creates matchup problems and he'll have the ability to generate late separation with his massive frame if he continues to get stronger. He's not much of a threat after the catch and there are too many focus drops on his tape. He has the frame to wall off as a blocker, but he needs to improve his strength and technique.

During the past two seasons, Burr-Kirven totaled 260 tackles with 9.5 tackles-for-loss, three sacks, 12 passes broken up, three picks and six forced fumbles. He is slightly shorter than average, lacks ideal bulk and has average arm length and small hands. But he does show good straight-line speed on tape and confirmed it with a 4.56 second 40-yard dash at the combine. His instincts and locating the ball are his best traits, but take-on skills are a weakness. While he's tough and plays hard, Burr-Kirven is undersized and gets washed too easily. He shows some initial sting as a hitter but his lack of size/strength hurts him as a finisher at times. He also has a bad habit of launching and missing too often as a tackler. While he shows adequate range in zone, he's athletically limited and slow to redirect. He will be a liability in a lot of one-on-one matchups versus NFL running backs. As a pass-rusher, he struggles to counter when reached and his sack production has been marginal (just four career sacks in 52 games played) -- but he does bring speed and effort to the table. And the tape proves that he can be disruptive when turned loose. Burr-Kirven grades out as a reserve off-the-ball linebacker in the NFL and will need to create roster value on special teams. -- March 22, 2019 Burr-Kirven is slightly undersized with average arm length and good straight-line speed on tape. He reads his keys, locates the ball and chases with great effort. While he's tough and plays hard, there's room for improvement when it comes to stacking and shedding blocks. He's more effective rushing the passer and dropping into zone than he is matching up in man.

Connelly is a weakside inside linebacker who does an above-average job of reading his keys and flashes the ability to shoot gaps defending the run. He's high cut with a leaner lower body, so he has some problems holding his ground. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks when teams run at him. He tends to chase with good effort but has average top-end speed, and his angles are inconsistent. He tends to wrap on contact and flashes good stopping power. However, he's a below-average, open-field tackler whose athletic limitations get exposed in space at times. He closes and limits production after the catch in underneath zone. He appears to lack the change-of-direction skills and burst to regularly hold up in man at the NFL level. He's a hard charger and appeared to make strides with his hand fighting last season, but there's still ample room for improvement when it comes to winning with his hands as a pass-rusher. Connelly grades out as a reserve 3-4 weak inside linebacker or reserve 4-3 middle linebacker with the potential to develop into a core special-teams contributor. -- Sept. 5, 2018 Connelly has an above-average blend of size and top-end speed. He reads his keys and flashes the ability to shoot gaps defending the run. He's tough and willing to meet lead blockers in the hole. He has shorter arms, and there's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks when he gets reached. He chases with good effort and closes well in pursuit. He gets to depth and shows good awareness in underneath zone.

Tell was a four-year player and three-year starter for USC. He finished his career with 221 tackles, 13 passes broken up and five interceptions. He's a tall, long-armed free safety with adequate bulk and good speed and athleticism. He changes directions and closes quickly, making up ground when the ball is in the air. He shows good range in zone coverage. His eye discipline in coverage is inconsistent. He shows some pop at the point of attack but is a bit inconsistent with his angles and tackling skills. He grades out as a backup with the potential to develop into a solid NFL starter. -- April 5 Tell is a tall long-armed free safety with adequate bulk, average speed and good overall athleticism. He closes quickly and makes up ground when the ball is in the air. Tell has a wide catching radius and decent ball skills. He's a willing run defender whose angles and tackling are a little inconsistent.

Gay has above-average range and connected on 8-of-11 field goal attempts from 50 yards or farther over the past two seasons. He had three field goal attempts blocked in 2018 and needs to elevate the ball better at times. He kicked off last year and has the leg strength to do so at the NFL level.

Oruwariye is a bigger corner with above-average length and average playing speed. He is fluid enough to develop into an effective press corner but shows some tightness in space. He also needs an extra step to plant and drive on comeback routes. His instincts and recognition help mask some of his athletic deficiencies. He could be more aggressive at times, but he reads receivers and flashes the ability to jump routes in man coverage. His positioning and discipline in zone coverage are sound for the most part. He tracks the ball, shows the capacity to snatch it out of the air and has the frame to compete for 50-50 balls on the outside. He is a below-average tackler who frequently fails to wrap up, and he does a better job of limiting production after the catch than he does stopping the run. He has experience covering kicks. -- July 25, 2018 Oruwariye is a bigger corner with average length and above-average top-end speed. He's an opportunistic playmaker who has picked off seven passes the past two seasons. He's an adequate tackler who doesn't shy away from his responsibilities in run support.

Joseph is an undersized linebacker with below-average length but very good playing speed. He does a solid job of sifting through traffic, and he has the explosive burst to shoot gaps. He has to win with athletic ability and quickness as a run-defender. He's an erratic tackler who slips off too many tackles.

Greenlaw is a rangy run defender who plays faster than his timed speed. He looks smaller on tape than his combine weight, plus he weighed less at the Senior Bowl and his pro day. He gets engulfed and pushed around. His short-shuttle time is a red flag for an outside linebacker and raises concerns about his ability to match up in man at the NFL level.

Renfrow is a better football player than athlete. He's a smooth route runner with adequate burst and locates and exploits pockets in zone looks. He's a small target with shorter arms, and his hand span is more than 1 inches smaller than the five-year combine average for receivers, yet he doesn't drop many passes. He makes contested catches and adjusts to passes thrown outside his frame. He's not a big-play threat.

Keke is a versatile defensive lineman with excellent length. He shoots his hands inside and stacks offensive tackles. He flashes the ability to win with quickness when he lines up on the inside. He is athletic enough to develop into an effective interior pass-rusher.

Van Ginkel is an average-sized outside linebacker with excellent top-end speed. He flashes as a speed rusher thanks to his good first step, bend and closing speed. He has the lateral quickness to beat blockers to the inside. He takes too long to get off blocks and has a below-average anchor.

Ollison is a big back who runs hard and flashes the ability to deliver the blow on contact. He has the foot speed to press and bounce. He's fast enough to rip off chunk yards when he hits the hole at full speed. He doesn't have breakaway speed and is not an elusive runner. He's more effective running inside than he is attacking the perimeter. He has average ball skills and is not a big-play threat after the catch.

Ross is not a mauler but has very good awareness in pass protection. He senses blitzes and stunts also has a good feel for timing on combo blocks in the run game. But he shows below-average athleticism and lacks range as a puller and on second-level blocks. He grades out as a versatile backup interior offensive lineman who could possibly develop into an adequate starting center in the NFL. He's a Day 3 draft prospect. Pierschbacher is a versatile interior offensive lineman with starting experience at guard and center. He gets into position and walls off defenders in the run game. He shows good awareness but lunges and gets caught off-balance in pass protection.

Scarlett is well-built with very good speed. He has good contact balance and flashes the ability to run over defenders when he gets into the open field. He shows good burst through the hole and is fast enough to break long runs. He's not a natural pass-catcher. He waits on defenders instead of stepping up and meeting them in pass protection.

Wilson played in 42 of a possible 44 games during his three seasons at Alabama. He has very good speed and his best trait is his ability to cover. He plays with aggression and flashes some pass-rush ability with good instincts and timing as a blitzer. He needs to improve his ability to get off blocks but he has the speed and cover skills to contribute immediately in the NFL -- and eventually he should develop into a good every-down starter. He should be a Day 2 draft pick. Wilson was the quarterback of Alabama's defense. He understands concepts and gets players lined up correctly. He shows good range in coverage and has good ball skills for a linebacker. Wilson can get stuck on blocks, which knocks him off course in the running game, but he improved in 2018.

Hollins is a 3-4 outside linebacker with adequate size, good length and excellent top-end speed. He gets his hands inside and stacks blockers. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. Hollins has some upside as a pass-rusher. He has the length, speed and enough athletic ability to compete with tight ends in coverage.

Cashman is a rangy run defender with good size and excellent top-end speed. He gets stuck on blocks, and he has short arms and below-average upper-body strength. But he tested well at the combine and has the potential to develop above-average coverage skills.

Jackson was a four-year player and two-year starter at Miami who played in all 52 games. As a full-time starter the last two seasons, Jackson combined for 85 tackles, 15 pass breakups and four interceptions. Jackson is a press corner with good height, bulk and length. He's at his best in press coverage because he's long and physical but also because he has tightness in his hips, lacks foot quickness and has average top-end speed. Jackson is an above-average tackler who doesn't shy away from contact and flashes the ability to get off blocks quickly. He's a hard worker with good football character. Jackson grades out as a versatile reserve defensive back who fits best in a press-zone heavy scheme. His instincts, toughness and ball skills make him worthy of a Day 3 pick. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Jackson is a press corner with good height, bulk, length and top-end speed. He's long and physical but he's also tight and lacks ideal foot speed. He tracks the ball well and flashes the ability to catch with his hands away from his frame. He's a strong tackler who doesn't shy away from contact and flashes the ability to get off blocks quickly.

Cowart plays on the inside and outside. He's strong enough to set the edge and flashes the ability to push offensive tackles back into the backfield at defensive end. He's got the length and upper-body strength to stack blockers. His ability to locate the ball and shed in time to make the play is inconsistent. He's not as stout between the tackles. He has just average closing speed, initial quickness and agility for a defensive tackle, let alone a defensive end.

Mack is a squat nose tackle with a low center of gravity, short arms and good initial quickness. He's highly disruptive and flashes the ability to overwhelm blockers when he's fresh. He's strong and tough enough to occupy double-teams. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks and he's a better run defender than pass-rusher.

Omenihu has an NFL frame and rare length. He has the size and length to set the edge against the run when he plays low. He gives ground and gets pushed inside when he plays high. Omenihu tracks the ball and gets off blocks in time to make plays, but needs to be more consistent in this area though. He has good upper body strength, but his hands aren't violent enough. He has the frame and quickness to develop into a disruptive interior pass rusher, even without the flexibility or closing burst to regularly win with speed. But he's a developing hand fighter who flashes the ability to win with his hands and power coming off the edge. He some experience dropping and he's a good athlete for his size. Omenihu has an NFL frame and rare length. He's strong enough to set the edge when he plays low, and he flashes the ability to get off blocks in time to make the play. He gives ground and gets pushed inside when he plays high. He has the frame and quickness to develop into a disruptive interior pass rusher.

Smith was a four-year starter for USC with 47 career games played, including 45 starts. He tallied 354 tackles, 26.5 tackles-for-loss, 3.5 sacks, 14 passes broken up and four interceptions during his four seasons at USC. Smith is an experienced off-the-ball linebacker with average height, weight and arm length, along with good straight-line speed. But the more space he's in, the less effective he becomes. He has fast eyes when reading an initial key but he's inconsistent with ball reaction. He will take false steps if his initial key doesn't take him to the ball, and then he's slow to redirect. Smith is a solid wrap-up tackler when in position and he has good instincts in coverage, getting good depth on drops. Smith grades out as backup ILB in the NFL. -- April 5 Smith is a tough and steady inside linebacker with average size, average length and good straight-line speed. He has good core strength, and he does an above-average job of taking on blocks. He shows good instincts and range in coverage, but he's a straight-line player who is more effective dropping into zone coverage than matching up in man.

Bailey handled the punting and kickoff duties at Stanford. He gets the ball off quickly and he gets good hang time. He connected on 12-of-16 field goal attempts and made three field goals of 50 or more yards his senior year of high school.

Speed is a lean and athletic linebacker with excellent length and top-end speed. He closes well in pursuit and has some upside as a pass-rusher. He flashes the ability to stack and shed but he's inconsistent in that area and gives too much ground at times.

Jackson was a three-year player at Miami who totaled 138 tackles, 37.5 tackles for loss, 24 sacks and five forced fumbles. He has ideal size, good length and above-average closing speed. He presses offensive tackles with his long arms and strong hands, quickly locates the quarterback and flashes the ability to disengage in time to finish as a pass-rusher. His best fit is clearly at 4-3 DE. He flashes upside as an interior pass-rusher but he's too tight for a 3-4 OLB conversion. He chases the run and rushes the quarterback with good effort. He's a disruptive run defender with enough quickness to make plays in the backfield and deliver the initial blow but he plays high and gives ground at times. Jackson grades out as a rotational 4-3 DE and projects as a mid-round pick in 2019. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Jackson has ideal size, above-average length and good closing speed for his size. He presses offensive tackles, locates the quarterback and flashes the ability to disengage in time to finish as a pass-rusher. He has the size and length to develop into a solid run-defender if he plays with better pad level.

Stick is tough and stands in in the face of pressure. He gets through his progressions and locates the open man given time. He flashes the ability to pound the strike zone when he's in a rhythm but is a little streaky and North Dakota State's play-action package created big windows for him. He has adequate arm strength. Philip Rivers (37 years old) is coming off his 10th year with 4,000-plus passing yards and 25-plus passing touchdowns. The Chargers also signed Tyrod Taylor to a two-year deal so quarterback is not a pressing need. That said, taking a chance on a quarterback who they think has the skill set to develop in the middle rounds is a sound approach. Steve Muench

While his statistics are underwhelming, it should be noted that Thorson's completion percentage improved in each of the last three seasons and Northwestern was usually overmatched by Big Ten defenses. Thorson has an NFL frame, good-sized hands and above-average pocket mobility. He's a streaky passer who can make some really impressive anticipation throws at times, but he also misses within the strike zone too often. He has adequate-to-good accuracy on short and intermediate throws, but he struggles with timing and placement on the deep ball. Thorson flashes the ability to see the whole field and locate check downs, but he locks onto his primary too often and forces too many throws. He's also a split-second late pulling the trigger at times. Thorson grades out as a backup NFL quarterback with some upside. Thorson has an NFL frame and and above-average pocket mobility. He's a streaky passer who can get hot and make impressive anticipation throws but also misses within the strike zone at times. He has enough arm strength to get good zip on intermediate throws and get the ball downfield. He flashes the ability to locate checkdowns, yet he locks onto his primary receiver too often and forces too many throws. He has good football intelligence, and is tough and highly competitive. Carson Wentz missed most of the 2017 season with a torn ACL and end of last year with a spinal compression fracture. TThe Eagles didn't draft Thorson to push Wentz, but Nick Foles now in Jacksonville, so bringing in a quarterback to push Nate Sudfield for the backup role makes sense.

Walker is at his best when turned loose up-field. He flashes very good snap anticipation and has a quick first step, rushing the QB with a good forward lean. He does a good job of using his long arms to keep blockers off his body, and he flashes ability to convert speed to power (but needs to continue to improve his overall strength). He can be very slippery at times as a pass-rusher, showing natural instincts. Walker plays a bit high but can usually hold the point. He appears frequently late locating the ball and gets sucked inside too often. And there's some tightness as an open-field tackler but his long arms help to lasso ball carriers. Walker has the physical tools to contribute as a backup edge defender in the NFL but his best trait is his ability to rush the quarterback. -- March 19, 2019 Walker has a quick first step and excels at anticipating the snap. He rushes with good forward lean, uses his long arms to keep blockers off his body and flashes the ability to convert speed to power. He tends to hold his ground and set the edge even though he plays a little high.

Edwards has some problems handling speed rushing from the wide-nine alignment, but he appears to have the length to protect the edge for the most part, and he has the heavy hands to knock speed rushers off course when his punch lands. He sets high, but he's big and strong enough to get away with it for the most part. He has the lateral mobility to effectively zone block. Edwards grades out as a starting right tackle early in his career, and he hasn't even reached his upside at this point. -- May 11, 2018 Edwards has prototypical height and weight, but he has shorter-than-ideal arms for an offensive tackle. He has heavy hands, and he knocks speed rushers off course when his punch lands on opponents. He has enough lateral mobility to effectively zone block, but he needs to play with better pad level at times.

Seibert is a versatile kicker who was Oklahoma's place kicker and punter the past four seasons, and handled kickoff duties the past three seasons. His field goal percentage improved in each of the past three seasons and he connected on 16-of-17 field goal attempts from inside 40 yards in 2018.

Slayton was a three-year contributor and two-year starter at Auburn. His production increased each season and though he finished his career with just 79 catches, he averaged 20.3 yards per catch with 11 receiving touchdowns. Slayton is a good-sized wideout who has a lot of room to develop as an intermediate route runner, but he has explosive top-end speed and has proven to be a big-play threat. He has excellent body control and does a very good job of adjusting to the ball. Slayton excels at executing the back-shoulder fade. Slayton is a project but he's a big-play weapon with intriguing potential who could be a value pick in the middle rounds. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Slayton is a lean wide receiver with good length, big hands and explosive top-end speed. He has above-average body control and he excels at executing the back-shoulder fade. There's a lot of room for development when it comes to getting off press and his intermediate route running. His hands are inconsistent.

Miller is a press/zone corner with above-average height, arm length and speed. He's an instinctive corner who trusts his eyes. He closes well and limits production after the catch. He lacks elite change-of-direction skills but has good balance for his size. There's room for improvement when it comes to winning with physicality and strength. Miller shows solid overall ball skills and attacks the ball confidently, doing a good job tracking it vertically -- but he can improve defending 50-50 balls. He's also a tough run-stopper and an above-average tackler. Miller grades out as a reserve corner and special teams contributor with the potential to develop into a starter on the outside if he continues to get stronger and can stay on the field. Durability issues could affect his draft stock. -- March 22, 2019 Miller is an instinctive press/zone corner with above-average height, arm length and top-end speed. He closes well and limits production after the catch. He has good balance and feet for his size. There's room for improvement when it comes to winning with physicality and strength. He's a tough run-stopper and an above-average tackler.

Holcomb is a slightly undersized linebacker with below-average length, excellent top-end speed and very good athletic ability. Chases with good effort and closes well. He's late diagnosing some plays and there's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks.

Johnson tested poorly at the combine but had a much better workout at his pro day. He lines up out wide and in the slot. He's a smooth route runner with adequate burst. He catches the ball in stride and flashes the ability to make the first defender miss. He doesn't have the second gear to take the top off coverage, but he tracks the ball well and he's competitive fighting for 50-50 catches.

Smith has marginal length and size for an edge defender, but he's athletic, tough, closes well and chases with outstanding effort. He projects as a core special teams contributor who is going to have to find a role on defense.

Smith started 12 of the 24 games he played the past two seasons, totaling 70 catches for 1,049 yards (15 yards per catch) and seven touchdowns. Smith has prototypical size with smaller-than-average arm length and marginal top-end speed. He is a big target with above-average ball skills and the potential to develop into a zone buster. He excels working the middle of the field and on seam routes, and he does a great job of securing contested catches. He's an adequate route runner with average initial burst. Smith also has good experience running intermediate and vertical routes, and he has done a good job tracking the ball downfield. He gets into position and fights to sustain as an in-line blocker both in the run game and in pass protection, and he takes sound angles climbing to the second level. Smith grades out as a complementary No. 2 or No. 3 tight end at this point. -- March 28, 2019 Smith is a big target with good ball skills. He excels at working the middle of the field and does a great job of securing contested catches. He runs hard after the catch, and his play speed is faster than his 40-yard dash time. But at the end of the day, Smith is a tight end with 4.91 40 speed and below-average length. He is a decent inline blocker, however.

Hampton is an average-sized safety with decent length and top-end speed. He closes well when breaking on the ball. He allows too much separation transitioning out of breaks and gets grabby at times. He tracks the ball well and flashes the ability to snatch it out of the air even with smaller hands. He's willing to step up but he's an inconsistent tackler who takes too long to get off blocks.

Minshew completed 70.7 percent of his throws in 2018 and finished with a 4.2-to-1 TD-to-INT ratio. He excelled in the Air Raid offense as a rhythm passer who can be streaky at times. He has a quick release and can deliver from a lot of different arm angles. Minshew shows a good feel for timing, touch and trajectory. But below-average arm strength gives him some limitations when it comes to driving the ball vertically. He needs to get the ball out on time to overcome it. With fast eyes, he can make full field progression reads. Minshew has quick feet and good twitch to him -- he senses pressure but tends to drift in the pocket at times and gets himself into some unnecessary trouble. He's not a runner. Minshew grades out as a potential No. 3 quarterback early in his career with backup potential. Minshew is a rhythm passer who's streaky at times. He has a quick release and can deliver the ball from different arm angles. He understands coverages, has fast eyes and is decisive. He has below-average arm strength and has some limitations when it comes to driving the ball vertically. He has quick feet and senses pressure but drifts in the pocket and gets himself into unnecessary trouble at times. Look for Minshew to compete with fourth-year quarterback Cody Kessler (2-2 in four starts last year), for the backup role behind Nick Foles. Steve Muench

Gaillard has adequate size for a center with longer-than-average arms and big hands. Multiple scouts have raised red flags regarding his inconsistent work ethic and weight-room habits, but he has shown some maturation in those areas but still has room for growth. Gaillard shows good awareness while helping in pass protection but is a limited athlete who will be overmatched by quickness of many NFL DTs in one-on-one situations. He takes solid angles and gets good leverage in the run game and is very effective with timing and awareness on combo blocks. He shows toughness and an edge as a finisher with size but lacks explosive power. He also has limited range on pulls, traps and second-level blocks. Gaillard has some versatility as an interior offensive lineman with experience at center and guard. -- March 19, 2019 Gaillard has adequate size with above-average length and big hands. He has lined up at guard and center. Gaillard takes solid angles and gets good leverage in the run game. He's very effective with his timing and awareness on combo blocks. He's tough and flashes an edge as a finisher. He shows good awareness, but he's a limited athlete who will be overmatched by quickness one-on-one in pass protection.

Ballentine has average size, slightly above-average length and good top-end speed. He lines up on the inside and the outside. He's fluid with average quickness transitioning out of breaks. Playing speed matches timed speed, and he recovers well. He plays the ball, not the man in zone. His frame (5-foot-11, 196 pounds) raises concerns about his ability to match up with bigger receivers.

Johnson had a breakout junior season in 2017, recording 96 tackles, four interceptions, eight pass breakups, three forced fumbles and two fumble recoveries. In 2018, he finished with 92 tackles, two interceptions, one pass breakup and two forced fumbles. Johnson is an undersized safety who is at his best playing closer to the line of scrimmage. He's aggressive and tough and much better in run support than his frame indicates. Johnson has average top-end speed, tightness in his hips and shorter arms. In zone coverage, he's at his best covering underneath and can usually hold up in deep-half coverage but he's not reliable as a single-high safety. In man-to-man coverage, Johnson has a lot of limitations. He's a team captain with excellent football character. Johnson lacks ideal size, speed, fluidity and arm length, but he grades out as an above average reserve safety with the mental and physical toughness to develop into a core special-teams player. He projects as a mid-round pick. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Johnson is an undersized safety who at his best playing closer to the line of scrimmage and is much better in run support than his frame might suggest. He's more effective in underneath zone coverage than he is matching up in man-to-man coverage. He has the mental and physical toughness to develop into a core special-teams player.

Williams is an undersized but a tough and versatile back with proven production. He shows great vision as a runner and reliable hands as an outlet receiver in the passing game. He will need to be part of a multiple-back committee in the NFL but he's capable of contributing and making an impact. He projects to be a fourth- or fifth-round draft pick. Williams is a tough, undersized, versatile back with proven production at the highest college level. He has great vision as a runner. He doesn't create a ton of yards on his own, but he doesn't leave many blocked yards on the field, either. He has reliable hands as a receiver, and he's a willing pass-blocker.

Skule is an athletic tackle with good size, top-end speed and slightly below-average length. He moved from right tackle to left tackle in 2017 and has the potential to develop into a valuable No. 3 swing tackle.

Fulgham is a big receiver with excellent length and average top-end speed. He's a natural hands catcher with good body control. Though he doesn't have the second gear to take the top off the coverage, he uses his frame to shield defenders from the ball and he makes over-the-shoulder catches downfield. He's not as much of a threat after the catch.

Hollman has average size, below-average length and outstanding top-end speed. He has the upper body strength, speed and toughness to develop into an effective press corner, and is willing in run support. He had just two career interceptions.

Johnson runs hard. He's quick enough to turn the corner and has average playing speed. He doesn't miss many defined seams but has average overall instincts. He doesn't have the power to push the pile in short-yardage situations and goes down on initial contact a little too much. He lines up in the slot at times and is an adequate route runner yet caught just five passes last year. He shows adequate awareness and willingness but struggles to anchor and ducks his head in pass protection. Johnson grades out as a No. 3 back and special-teams contributor at this point. -- May 28, 2018 Johnson explodes though the hole and is a threat to pull away when he gets a seam. He's not an elusive open-field runner and doesn't have the power to push the pile. He picks up some yards after contact thanks to effort. He returned two kickoffs for touchdowns at Maryland.

Winfree has good size and average top-end speed. He tracks the ball well and adjusts to passes thrown outside his frame. He's had some problems staying healthy and finished his career with just 60 catches.

Long is an undersized linebacker with below-average length and top-end speed. He's an instinctive run defender who fills gaps and sifts through traffic between the tackles. He masks below-average speed by reading the play quickly and chasing with great effort. He shows adequate awareness in zone.

Forbes has average size, good athletic ability and excellent top-end speed but he has marginal arm length so he may have to kick inside. He's quick, gets into position he plays with good balance in the run game. He needs to improve his hand placement and lunges at times, but he has the potential to develop into an above-average pass-blocker.

Watts grades out as a rotational defensive tackle or 3-4 DE who locates and tracks the ball well. He has active hands and does an above-average job of slipping blocks. He flashes the ability to stack blockers, but his pads rise and he gets pushed around at times. Watts flashes the ability to win with his hands rushing the passer.

Epps is a smaller safety with short arms and slightly above-average top-end speed. He has big hands and while he didn't pick off a pass last year, he finished his career with nine INTs. He has the athletic ability to develop good short area cover skills, while his angles in run support are inconsistent.

Buggs is a scheme-versatile defensive lineman who will fit well as a five-technique DE in a base 3-4. He also made big improvements as a pass-rusher in 2018. He has the talent to emerge as a productive NFL contributor but only if his football character and work ethic improve. He's a mid-round talent who could slide due to those concerns. Buggs has average size with below-average length and average top-end speed for a defensive tackle. He has experience playing on the inside and the outside. He has good instincts and he does an above-average job of locating the ball. He's a power rusher with adequate closing burst. His snap awareness is inconsistent and he's late getting off the ball at times.

Udoh possesses a rare blend of length, size and athletic ability. He gets set quickly and anchors well. He played offensive line for just one year in high school, and his tape raises concerns about ability to pick up complicated pressure packages. He needs to do a better job of keeping his hips under him and sustaining in the run game. The flipside is he has the strength to develop into an effective drive blocker in addition to the foot speed to develop into an effective zone blocker.

Williams is an instinctive between-the-tackles runner who does a good job of following his blocks. He plays faster than his 40 time and flashes the ability to pull away when he gets a seam. His limited production in the passing game is a concern, but he flashed the potential to develop into an effective checkdown who picks up some yards after the catch on 2018 Southern Cal tape.

Crawford is an undersized corner with short arms who ran well at the combine and exceptionally well at his pro day. He reads the quarterback and plays the ball, not the man. He competes in press coverage, but his short arms make it tougher for him to gets his hands on receivers. Crawford is faster than he is quick, but he's an erratic tackler who gets stuck on blocks.

Austin is a tall, lean corner with above-average length. He's fluid and fast enough to turn and run with most receivers in press and press bail. He has above-average change-of-direction skills and short-area man-to-man cover abilities, especially for a player with his height. He gets pushed around at times and bumped off some routes. He gets too hands on at times, and there are occasions when he holds despite being in sound position. He flashes above-average ball skills, but just three interceptions in three seasons is a concern. He's an adequate tackler who takes too long to get off blocks. -- July 3, 2018 Austin is a tall corner with above-average length. He plays faster on tape and he may need more time to recover from consecutive season-ending knee injuries, but he did not run well at his pro day. He has above-average change of direction and short area man-to-man cover skills on tape. He's got the tools to develop into an effective press corner. He's got big hands and he flashes above-average ball skills.

McSorley started all 40 games during his final three seasons and finished with a 31-9 record, completing 58.8 percent of his passes. He is at his best using his athletic ability to extend plays and is accurate throwing on the move. McSorley shows the ability to climb the pocket, keep his eyes downfield and find the open man. He manipulates and freezes safeties with his eyes. However, his lack of height affects his ability to see the entire field from inside the pocket at times. He forces some throws in the face of pressure, and he's a streaky pocket passer who pounds the strike zone when he gets into a rhythm but then will go through some funks and lose control. He has marginal arm strength and his lower release point leads to some tipped passes. McSorley's lack of size and arm strength put a ceiling on his potential. He's also not accurate enough to overcome those limitations. However, his athleticism, competitiveness and football character make him intriguing as a late-round pick. The big question will be his willingness to contribute in other areas (special teams and possibly safety), while also serving as an emergency quarterback. McSorley is an undersized quarterback who is at his best when using his athletic ability to extend plays. He's accurate throwing on the move. He shows the ability to climb the pocket, keep his eyes downfield and find the open man. He's a natural leader with outstanding football character, toughness and competitiveness. But he's a streaky pocket passer who forces some throws in the face of pressure. He has marginal arm strength and his lower release point leads to some tipped passes.
Harris has had some problems staying healthy and is a little tight, but has an above-average blend of size, length and top-end speed. He's a good tackler and willing run defender.

Egbule totaled 131 tackles, 11.5 tackles for loss, four sacks, five pass breakups and two interceptions during his final two seasons at Houston. Egbule is a hybrid safety/outside linebacker. He has adequate size for his type of hybrid role and outstanding speed. He has experience lining up over the slot and spent most of his time in zone coverage. He reads the quarterback effectively in underneath coverage. Egbule's not an elite athlete but has outstanding straight-line speed. He flashes above average speed-to-power as a pass-rusher and the ability to put offensive tackles on roller skates, but he needs to add to his arsenal of pass-rush moves. He gets under bigger blockers, but he's inconsistent when it comes to disengaging from blocks in the run game. He could draw comparisons to former Clemson linebacker/safety and 2018 Chiefs third-round pick Dorian O'Daniel, but O'Daniel was a more consistent playmaker at the college level. Egbule grades out as a nickel linebacker and special-teams contributor who is unlikely to develop into an every-down starter but has the skill set, toughness and motor to carve out a role on defense/special teams. -- Feb. 26, 2019 Egbule possesses a superior blend of size, length and top-end speed. He flashes a strong punch and does a good job of setting the edge but he's inconsistent when it comes to disengaging from blocks in the run game. He closes well in pursuit. He has experience lining up over the slot and reads the quarterback effectively in underneath coverage. He did a good job covering kickoffs early in his career.

Fenton is a versatile defensive back who lined up on the outside, over the slot and at safety at South Carolina. He's got average size and top-end speed with shorter arms. He's tough with good balance in underneath coverage. He's a below-average run stopper.

Prince started 39 of 41 games during his final three seasons. He has excellent height, weight and arm length, but needs to work hard to trim fat and improve core strength. He shows good initial pop as a run blocker, but struggles to sustain too often and is not a finisher. He has upside but still has a lot of room to grow, especially in pass protection. He grades out as a possible NFL starter at right tackle but it will likely take time for him to develop. He projects as a Day 2 pick. Prince is a right tackle with good quickness and excellent arm length. He gets good initial pop and movement in the run game. There's room for improvement when it comes to staying engaged and finishing his blocks. His length makes it tough to get around him, but he's a work in progress in pass protection. His hand placement is high and he's a waist bender who struggles to redirect against quick outside-in moves.

Green is an undersized slot receiver with outstanding top-end speed. He's a threat to pull away after the catch, returning kicks and in the running game. However, his hands are inconsistent and he puts the ball on the ground too often.

Homer gives his blockers time to get into position, and he has a good feel for cutback lanes. He has above-average balance and rarely goes down on initial contact. He's quick enough to turn the corner and shows deceptive top-end speed when he gets a vertical seam. Homer has the lateral mobility to bounce between seams on inside runs and flashes the ability to make defenders miss. He drops some passes but flashes the ability to catch with his hands, and he has experience lining up in the slot. Homer's effort, technique and awareness in pass protection are all above average. Homer grades out as a No. 2 back with the ability to contribute on third down. If he builds on his 2017 performance, he could go on Day 2 of the draft. -- May 24, 2018 Homer has average height, below-average bulk and excellent top-end speed. He's an effective cutback runner with good feet running between the tackles. He shows a noticeable burst through the hole and he's a threat when he gets a seam, but he's not as much of a breakaway threat as his timed speed would suggest. He's an above-average pass blocker who steps up and meets defenders at the line of scrimmage.

Shelley is undersized corner with below-average length and very good top-end speed.  While he has small hands, he picked off eight passes over the past three seasons and returned two for touchdowns. He's coming off season-ending toe surgery.

Harmon broke North Carolina State's record for touchdown receptions by a freshman with five and averaged 17.1 yards per catch in 2016. In three seasons at NC State, Harmon caught 177 passes for 2,665 yards and 16 touchdowns. He has outstanding size and is a long strider with adequate top-end speed for his big frame. He might not be the most explosive route-runner and he will have some problems separating from man coverage, but he's a big target with an above-average feel for coverage and does a good job of finding pockets in zone looks. Harmon is a hands catcher who makes tough contested catches and holds on when he takes a big hit. He's willing to do the dirty work over the middle. He also tracks the ball well and he does an above average job of adjusting to back-shoulder throws. He's not very sudden or elusive after the catch, but he's a strong runner who will pick up some yards after contact. Harmon grades out as No. 3 wide receiver early in his NFL career and has enough natural tools to develop into an effective No. 2 in time -- he's best suited to play the X-receiver position. -- March 19, 2019 Harmon has outstanding size, and he's a long strider with adequate top-end speed for his frame. He tracks the ball well, and he does a good job of adjusting to back-shoulder throws. He makes contested catches. He's a big target with a real feel for coverage, and he can find pockets in zone looks.

Gilbert is an undersized outside linebacker with excellent top-end speed. He has the potential to develop into an effective Nickel linebacker and special teams contributor if he develops as a more consistent open-field tackler.
Miller is an undersized receiver with short arms and small hands, but he has outstanding quickness and top-end speed. He's quick to transition upfield and a threat to pull away after the catch.

Christmas possesses above-average height with average bulk for the position. He flashes power as a bull rusher but is more disruptive than productive as a pass-rusher. He occasionally gets the QB off his spot by driving the interior OL backward. Christmas has a thick trunk and adequate power, but he is not a two-gap type. His takeoff quickness is average at best, but he has a good motor; if he has a chance to make the play, he'll lay it all on the line. He has adequate toughness but is certainly not a glass-eater. Christmas grades out as an NFL backup, and his value will likely be on Day 3. -- June 9, 2018 Christmas is on the lighter side with below-average length and above-average top-end speed.
