He's rugged and plays bigger than his size. He stacks blockers, tracks the ball and gets off blocks in time to make plays. He's not a massive space eater, but he's stout one-on-one. He flashes the ability to push the pocket rushing the passer.

Davis was a three-year starter at WILB for Auburn, playing in 53 games with 37 starts. During his final three seasons, he racked up 261 tackles, 28.5 tackles for loss and seven sacks. Davis is an overachiever with below average size, length and playing speed. He shows good awareness in coverage but his frame and athletic limitations raise concerns about his ability to contribute on third down in the NFL. He's an instinctive run defender who shoots gaps and has a knack for sifting through traffic between the tackles. He doesn't show great closing burst but makes plays in pursuit because he tends to take sound angles and has an above average motor. He's a grinder and an alpha leader with excellent football intangibles. Davis grades out as a core special-teams player and reserve off-the-ball linebacker who is unlikely to develop a substantial role on defense but has the toughness, instincts and work ethic to possibly overcome his shortcomings and make an NFL roster. He projects as a Day 3 pick. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Davis is an overachiever with below-average size, shorter arms and average speed. He's an instinctive run defender who shoots gaps and has a knack for sifting through traffic between the tackles. He keeps his hips down and uncoils on blockers. He can also get overwhelmed in a phone booth. He shows good awareness in coverage but his frame and athletic limitations raise concerns about his ability to contribute on third down in the NFL.

Anderson exploded onto the scene during the second half of the 2017 season. He's a versatile back with good size, very good quickness, explosive speed and natural hands in the passing game. He has the physical tools to emerge as a good NFL starter (probably best suited for a back-by-committee situation) but durability and character issues will likely drop his stock to Day 3. Anderson is a versatile back with an impressive blend of size, quickness and playing speed. He falls forward at the end of runs, and has natural hands and the potential to develop into a three-down back. His injury history raises concerns about his ability to stay healthy and realize his considerable potential.

Daley has good size as a thick, wide-body college left tackle who might fit better on the right side or at guard in the NFL. He possesses below-average mobility and shorter-than-ideal arm length for an NFL left tackle. He is top-heavy and overaggressive, and he tends to lunge too much in pass protection, which makes him vulnerable versus skilled edge rushers. He plays too high and falls off too many blocks. Daley has good size and the potential to improve but currently grades out as an NFL backup -- likely at guard or right tackle. -- June 30, 2018 Daley's subpar length and average-at-best foot speed raise concerns about his ability to protect the edge at the NFL level. He might have to move inside to guard. Hands and effort help mask an adequate mirror in pass protection. He gets off the ball and into position in the run game. Daley is not a massive mauler who is going to regularly move defenders off the ball, however.

Wilson is a lean safety with outstanding length and average playing speed. He's a downhill run-stopper who plays with an edge and flashes good stopping power, but his angles are inconsistent, and he fails to wrap up at times. He's more effective in zone than he is in man. He tracks the ball well and flashes above-average ball skills.

Thompson runs hard, and he's built low to the ground and has the balance to pick up yards after contact. He's not a powerful short-yardage runner with the brute strength to push the pile. He shows good burst through the hole. Though he's a small target, he's twitchy enough to separate and flashes good ball skills.

Beckner is a tall defensive tackle with below-average weight, length and top-end speed. He's a disruptive run defender who slips blocks with his active hands and plays quicker than his times. He flashes good upper-body strength and the ability to get off blocks. Beckner is a better run defender than pass-rusher.
Allegretti has size, athletic ability and enough length to develop into a versatile interior offensive lineman who provides depth at guard and center.

Boyd is a physical corner who makes it tough for receivers to get off the line in press and doesn't back down in 50-50 situations. He runs well and angles receivers towards the sideline. He has above average recovery speed. He doesn't have elite size or length for a press/zone corner though. He closes well and limits production after the catch. He's tight and struggles to change directions quickly in space, yet flashes the ability to go up and get the ball. But he's not a ball hawk and has average overall ball skills. Boyd is a slightly above-average tackler for the position and he's willing in run support. Boyd is a physical corner with below-average length and very good top-end speed. He makes it tough for receivers to get off the line in press, he runs well and he doesn't back down in 50-50 situations. He struggles to change directions quickly in space, but he's an above average tackler who is willing in run support.

Weber is a good athlete with good vision as a runner. If there's a crease, he gets through it quickly but he struggles to string multiple cuts together and does not create a ton of yards on his own. He's limited as a route runner but has natural hands and can be a reliable outlet in the passing game. He projects as a backup running back in the NFL and he should come off the board earlier on Day 3. Weber is a well-built running back with excellent top-end speed and good burst through the hole. He runs hard and has adequate power, but his contact balance is inconsistent. He lacks ideal lateral quickness, and he doesn't create a ton of yards on his own. He has natural hands and has the potential to develop into a reliable outlet in the passing game. He's strong in pass protection.

Gray is a big-bodied offensive lineman with just decent mobility. He has slightly below-average arm length for a tackle but adequate for a guard in the NFL. He is strong at the point of attack and gets movement in the run game. The more space he's in, the less effective he becomes, as he is inconsistent hitting moving targets in the second level in the run game. He has a strong anchor in pass protection but needs to improve his footwork and hand usage. Gray was an underachiever early in his career, but the light has come on during the past two seasons. He's a college left tackle that projects as an NFL guard. He currently grades out as an NFL backup but has upside and brings some positional versatility. -- Aug. 6, 2018 Gray is a big-bodied offensive tackle with good length and average top-end speed. He flashes the ability to overwhelm and drive defenders off the ball but falls off too many blocks. He's long and wide enough to handle speed off the edge in pass pro. He'll be tougher to get around if he moves to guard as expected. He does not mirror well and overextends at times.

Gillaspia is a former walk-on who appeared as the Aggies' 12th man in every game over the past three seasons. He moved from linebacker to fullback in the spring of 2018 and he flashed as a receiver. That said, he's an outstanding special teams player, and that's where he's expected to make his mark in the NFL.

Lewis is a four-year starter with excellent football intangibles. He's a hands catcher who tracks the ball well and flashes the ability to jump routes. He sustained a Jones fracture in his left foot during a practice at the East West Shrine game and hasn't been able to run for teams. He's lean with short arms and gets pushed around at times.

Whyte is an explosive back with decent burst through the hole and around the corner. He's an effective cutback runner who flashes the ability to make the first defender miss. He hasn't played a big role in the passing game and he lacks the size for pass protection.

Brown is a tall, well-built corner with below-average length and average top-end speed. He reads the quarterback and plays the ball, not the man. He's a ball hawk who flashes the ability to jump routes and has above-average ball skills. He doesn't have ideal length for a press corner, but he's smooth when turning and running with receivers. He's more fast than quick and his hips are a little tight in space.

Nauta was a three-year player and two-year starter at tight end for Georgia (42 games, 27 starts). He never missed a game in three seasons and finished with 68 catches for 905 yards and eight TDs. Nauta's size isn't ideal but adequate. He is a smooth athlete and his play speed appears to be faster on tape than his 4.91 40-yard dash at the combine suggested. He lacks the acceleration to stretch the field and doesn't make defenders miss after the catch. Nauta shows savvy as a route-runner and has a good feel for locating soft spots underneath. Ball skills are Nauta's best trait. He displays very good body control adjusting to the ball and has good overall focus and hand-eye coordination. He also gives good effort as a blocker and is technically sound. He's at his best on the move, as he takes good angles, gets his hands inside and continues to drive his legs while latched on. Nauta lacks ideal measurables but is a versatile tight end who can contribute at both the Y and the F positions. -- March 19, 2019 Nauta is savvy as a route runner with good feel for locating soft spots underneath. He's not much of a big-play threat but he does play faster than his timed speed. He's a reliable receiver with excellent ball skills, and he's a fundamentally sound blocker who gives good effort.

Johnson is a lanky edge defender with good length and adequate top-end speed. He's a one-gap run defender with the active hands and quick first step to get into the backfield. He struggles to anchor when blockers get their hands on him. He has good initial burst and he flashes the ability to bend the edge as a pass-rusher.

Summers is a big linebacker with below-average length and excellent timed speed. He flashes good stopping power in a phone booth, but he's better defending the run than he is in coverage. He tested better than expected and might have some upside in that area.

Moreland is an undersized corner with average playing speed, and his arm length is a borderline red flag. He is a tough competitor who does not back down against bigger receivers and does an above-average job of using his off-hand to disrupt receivers in press coverage. However, he's too physical and is flagged for pass interference far too often. He gives too much cushion and allows too much separation in off-coverage. He gets caught peeking into the backfield at times and has average overall instincts. He has the ball skills and aggressive nature to develop into a playmaker despite his smaller hands. His size is a concern, and he tends to wrap high, but he's willing to step up in run support and tends to get the ball carrier on the ground. Moreland grades out as an undersized sub-package defensive back who needs to cut down the downfield contact and holding to improve his draft stock. -- May 17, 2018 Moreland has solid balance, closing burst and recovery speed. He plays with a chip on his shoulder and doesn't back down against bigger receivers, but he's undersized with short arms. He's a playmaker with a nose for the football and is a threat after the catch, with six career interception returns for touchdowns.

Johnson is a massive defensive tackle with average length and below-average top-end speed. He's a space eater who is tough to move off the ball even though he plays high. Limited upside as a pass-rusher.

Bell is a developmental edge defender who moved from receiver to defensive end in 2018, flashed as a pass-rusher and had an outstanding pro day. He needs to continue to get stronger and improve his ability to defend the run.

Mack moves around the formation and has the potential to develop into a matchup problem for defenses. He appears fast enough to stretch the middle of the field and pick up chunk yards when he gets a seam after the catch, but he doesn't make many defenders miss in space. He has the athletic ability and quickness to get better but is a below-average route runner who doesn't tempo his breaks well enough and telegraphs some routes. He doesn't regularly separate with size or strength, either. He's a big target with above-average body control, and he tends to attack the ball with his hands. However, his ball skills are inconsistent, and he drops too many passes. He's a functional move blocker who does a decent job of covering up defenders in space. He's a below-average in-line blocker who flashes the ability to stay in the way but needs to get stronger and play with better technique. He's still scratching the surface in terms of his potential, and his work ethic has been inconsistent. -- July 19, 2018 Mack has slightly below-average weight, above-average length and above-average timed top-end speed. He moves around the formation, and he has the tools to develop into a matchup problem. He's fast enough to work the seam, and he's smooth transitioning upfield after the catch. He is a natural hands catcher, and he flashes the ability to make tough catches, yet his hands are inconsistent.
Asafo-Adjei has a good size and top-end speed but below-average length for a tackle. He gets off the ball and flashes a nasty disposition in the run game.
Cox is an undersized fullback with average top-end speed. He's an aggressive and tough lead blocker who flashes as a receiver.

Gaskin was a four-year starter at Washington and rushed for over 1,250 yards in each of his four seasons. He finished his career with a remarkable 5,320 rushing yards and averaged 5.6 yards per carry. He also caught 65 passes for 465 yards (7.2 yards per catch) and five touchdowns. Gaskin is an undersized scat back with above-average burst to and through the hole and enough initial acceleration to turn the corner as an outside runner. But his top-speed levels off quickly. He's an effective between-the-tackles runner for his size thanks to his patience and instincts. He's built low to the ground and has surprisingly good contact-balance for his size -- but he's undersized and lacks core strength. As a receiver, he has the initial burst and agility to separate. He has above-average ball skills and he's a mild threat after the catch. In pass pro, he's willing, but he's just not big or strong enough to anchor and sustain. He projects as a complementary back with the potential to contribute in the return game in the NFL. -- April 5 Gaskin is an undersized scat back with good burst through the hole. He's an effective between-the-tackles runner thanks to his patience and instincts. He's built low to the ground and has good contact balance but lacks core strength. He's quick enough to separate from coverage, and he has above-average ball skills. He has average top-end speed, but he's not a threat to pull away. He's not big or strong enough to anchor in pass protection.

Russell was a four-year starter at Auburn who played in 54 career games (51 starts). He totaled 153 tackles, 17 tackles for loss and six sacks. Russell is a big interior run stuffer with the size and strength to win one-on-one and flashes the ability to hold his ground against double-teams when he stays low and square. He does an adequate job of locating the ball and flashes the ability to get off blocks in time to make the play -- but only in limited space. As a pass-rusher, he has adequate initial quickness and flashes ability to move the quarterback off his spot with a combination of short-area quicks and violent hands. But he does not have the change of direction skills or closing burst to get to the quarterback with any regularity. He's a good teammate but not a natural leader or grinder. Russell grades out as a reserve nose tackle in a 3-4 or 4-3 base front. It's unlikely he makes a substantial impact rushing the passer at the NFL level. He projects as an early Day 3 pick. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Russell is a big interior run stuffer with the size and strength to win one-on-one. He flashes the ability to hold his ground against double teams when he stays low and square. Russell is a much better run defender than pass-rusher.

Ursua is more quick than fast, a slot receiver who runs routes well and has a good feel for how to attack zone looks. He led the nation in receiving touchdowns in 2018 with 16. He's an undersized target with a small catching radius, and he lacks overall ball skills.

Godwin totaled 133 receptions for 1,785 yards and 11 touchdowns in his career. He has average height for a wide receiver and a lean frame. He has average top-end speed and lacks explosive acceleration but has good short-area quickness and is a smooth athlete who runs smart routes. Godwin's best trait is his ball skills, as he has very good focus in traffic and does a strong job of plucking on the run and transitioning quickly. He frequently makes the first defender miss and shows good field vision as a runner. Godwin maximizes his below-average physical tools and grades out as a potential No. 4 WR in the NFL. -- March 19, 2019 Godwin is an undersized receiver with average speed and less-than-ideal length. He lacks explosive acceleration, but he's a smooth athlete and smart route runner with good short-area quickness. His best trait is his ball skills. He does a strong job of plucking on the run and transitioning upfield. He frequently makes the first defender miss and shows good field vision as a runner.

Denmark possesses a rare blend of size, length and top-end speed. He's a developmental prospect who moved from receiver to defensive back in 2018. His potential to develop into a playmaker is intriguing.

Mitchell has the burst and change of direction to develop good separation skills. He's got the speed to take the top off the coverage. He makes defenders miss and is good at closing pursuit angles after the catch. He has the body control to make acrobatic catches but he doesn't have great length and his hands are a little inconsistent.

Barton is a tall left tackle with average length, average bulk and excellent top-end speed. He gives ground to power rushers but tends to recover. He's late reacting to inside moves and gets knocked off-balance by effective hand fighters. He flashes the ability to generate push but tends to stall out and falls off blocks in the run game. His wide hand placement makes it easier for defenders to get into his frame in the run game and pass protection.

Jelks is versatile enough to line up at 4-3 DE or 3-4 OLB, and his active hands and initial quickness make him an effective interior pass rusher. He reads the quarterback and gets his hands up in passing lanes, and he's a disruptive run defender at his best getting into gaps. He also shows the ability to stand up bigger blockers by exploding off the ball and shooting his hands inside. He fights through double teams rushing the passer and he chases the run with above average effort. One area that he needs to improve in is wrapping up and finishing both in run pursuit and rushing the passer. -- May 31, 2018 Jelks is a versatile defensive lineman with excellent length but only average top-end speed for an edge-rushing prospect. He's stout for a player with his frame. Jelks shoots his hands inside and locks out. His pursuit angles are inconsistent, but he chases with great effort and plays faster than his timed speed. He's a relentless as a pass-rusher.
Broughton is an undersized defensive tackle with below-average length and very good top-end speed. He's a disruptive run defender with some upside as a pass-rusher.
Scott is on the smaller side with below-average length but he has excellent top-end speed. He tracks the ball well and is an opportunistic playmaker even though he has small hands.

Ellis has a good blend of size, length and top-end speed. He's instinctive and flashes above-average stopping power. He can help out in certain packages on offense as he played some wide receiver and tight end.

Slayton has the length and upper-body strength to stack blockers. He flashes the ability to get off blocks and make plays when teams run at him, but he's late locating the ball at times and there's room for improvement in this area. He's a better run defender than pass-rusher.

Patterson was a three-and-a-half year starter at Ole Miss. He spent most of his time at left guard but has experience at all three interior positions. He has good size and adequate speed. He has adequate arm length but his hands are on the smaller side. Patterson has good short-area quickness and shows very good awareness in pass protection. Occasionally, he gets in trouble by lunging to get engaged. He has trouble versus powerful bull rushers at times. Patterson takes good angles as a run blocker and has solid range on pulls and movement blocks. The leader of the offensive line at Ole Miss, Patterson projects best at center in the NFL. His versatility helps his value, but he grades out as a reserve interior offensive lineman and is likely a late-round pick in 2019. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Patterson has good short-area quickness, and he mirrors well and shows awareness in pass protection. Powerful bull-rushers give him problems at times. He takes good angles and shows good range as a run-blocker. He's a position-and-wall-off blocker who doesn't consistently move defenders off the line.

Willis finally had a breakout season as a senior in 2018, recording 59 tackles, 18 tackles for loss and four sacks. Shorter than ideal with solid bulk and above-average speed, he's a violent interior defensive lineman with a quick first step and a lot of shock in his hands. Willis over-utilizes the arm-over move and will need to develop a better array of pass-rush moves in the NFL. He shows very good instincts to locate the ball while feeling his way through blocks. He has a good motor and makes a lot of plays in pursuit from behind. Willis is at his best in a one-gap scheme. He had off-the-field issues early in his career, but has cleaned up his life since 2017 and is well-liked by teammates. There's reasonable concern that his issues may resurface once he gets paid an NFL salary and gets into a new setting. If Willis can stay out of trouble and continues to work hard, he has the skill set to develop into an impact starter and an every-down player. Willis projects as a top-50 pick. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Willis is a highly disruptive interior defensive lineman with a quick first step and shock in his hands to quickly penetrate gaps. He locates the ball and chases with good effort. Willis overutilizes the arm-over move and needs to develop a better array of pass-rush moves in the NFL.

Hall caught 52 passes for 1,124 yards and 10 touchdowns in 2016-17. In nine games last season, he caught 37 passes for 828 yards and six touchdowns. Hall has above-average size with outstanding speed and leaping ability. He also had one of the best broad jumps in combine history. Hall is a major vertical weapon with an elite second gear. He's a smooth athlete who also has short-area quickness. He excels at getting over the top of coverage and adjusting to the ball over his shoulder. Hall needs refining as a route runner but shows flexibility and hip fluidity. He does a good job tracking the deep ball but his focus needs to improve. He makes too many easy drops and needs to aggressively high point the ball more. Hall has the size and strength to be a better blocker but needs to show more consistent effort and toughness. Hall is a big-time vertical weapon who grades out as a potential No. 3 receiver in the NFL. His talent warrants Day 2 consideration but character and durability issues could cause him to fall. -- March 6, 2019 Hall has excellent length, speed and leaping ability. He's a vertical threat with an elite second gear, and he excels at getting over the top of coverage. He flashes the ability to pluck on the run and away from his frame, but his hands are inconsistent.

Coney is an instinctive run-defender who locates the ball quickly and rarely gets caught out of position. He's an above-average tackler who plays with good body control and wraps on contact. He has above-average length for his frame and the position. He's inconsistent in this area but flashes the ability to shoot his hands inside and keep blockers off his frame. He chases with good effort and makes some plays outside the tackle box. However, he doesn't have sideline-to-sideline range. He doesn't appear to have the burst or change-of-direction to regularly match up in man coverage, and he isn't much of a threat rushing the passer. He made six special-teams tackles in 2015. There are concerns regarding his work ethic and football character. Coney grades out as a reserve inside linebacker who's at his best defending the run. -- June 4, 2018 Coney is a well-built inside linebacker with slightly above-average length and top-end speed. He's good tackler with good stopping power between the tackles. He tends to absorb the initial surge and get off blocks. He flashes good awareness in underneath zone but he doesn't have the burst or change of direction to regularly match up in man. He's not a sideline-to-sideline player.

Jackson is a massive quarterback prospect with a huge arm. His lower body mechanics and ball placement are inconsistent, and he needs to learn when to take speed off the fastball, but he flashes the ability to pound the strike zone and rarely flat-out misses his target. Although he doesn't have great pocket awareness and lowers his eyes to see the rush at times, he has quick feet for his size and is a threat to scramble. The biggest area of improvement needs to come in his ability to process more quickly and not get stuck on his primary target for too long. He also makes poor decisions in the face of pressure and puts the ball in harm's way too much. Jackson is a developmental project with an intriguing skill set. He projects as a Day 3 pick. -- May 16, 2018 Jackson is a tall well-built quarterback with big hands, outstanding arm strength and above-average athletic ability. He drives the ball downfield and threads the needle. He buys time in the pocket and makes impressive off-platform throws. He flashes the ability to get through his progressions and a willingness to throw the ball away when nothing is there, but he puts too much faith in his arm strength at times.

Hanks locates and tracks the ball well as a run defender. He tends to chase with above-average effort and has slightly-above-average playing speed. He slips blocks and shoots gaps between the tackles. He has long arms and flashes the ability to set the edge. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks, plus he occasionally gets overwhelmed between the tackles. He's an above-average pass-rusher who uses his length to get into the chest of blockers and flashes good speed to power. He regularly beats running backs in one-on-one situations. He's long and athletic enough to compete with tight ends in man, and he shows good range in zone. However, he's tight and gets too grabby in space. He has above-average stopping power but is an erratic tackler who lunges and gets into trouble when his angles aren't sound. He also fails to wrap up at times. Hanks grades out as a versatile reserve linebacker and a core special-teams player with the potential to develop into an effective WILB, SLB or MLB in time. -- Sept. 12, 2018 Hanks is a rangy run defender with good closing speed. He has the length and upper-body strength to stack bigger blockers. He gets stuck on some blocks though. He's more effective in zone than he is matching up in man. He flashes as a pass-rusher.

Hyatt is an athletic offensive tackle with the foot speed to get into position and seal off his assignment in the run game, as well as the quickness and balance to stay in front of his assignments when his footwork is sound in pass protection. He displays excellent awareness in pass protection and does a great job picking up stunts, blitzes, etc. His lack of bulk shows up on tape, as he gets stood up in the run game and pushed around in pass protection a little too much. He has a tendency to lunge, and there isn't enough pop in his punch. Hyatt grades out as a possible down-the-road starter in a zone-heavy scheme, but he is likely to serve as a backup early in his NFL career. -- May 10, 2018

Hart is an undersized slot receiver with slightly below-average top-end speed and shorter arms. He's quicker than fast, and he's more of a threat after the catch than he is in the vertical passing game. He flashes the ability to make the first defender miss, and he reaches his top-end speed quickly.

Bates was a three-year starter who has experience at both tackle positions. Bates has adequate size but short arms and smaller hands. He plays with solid balance and has a quick pass pro set, but his lack of arm length and lack of sting in his hands really shows up on tape. He's a position-and-wall-off run-blocker who gets out of his stance quickly and takes good angles but lacks the strength to drive defenders off the line of scrimmage. Bates grades out as a backup tackle/guard in the NFL and he projects as a Day 3 pick. Bates is a lighter offensive tackle with short arms and superior top-end speed. He gets set quickly and plays with good balance but his lack of arm length and sting in his hands show up on tape. He's a position-and-wall-off run-blocker who gets out of his stance quickly and takes good angles. He lacks the strength to drive defenders off the line of scrimmage.

Williams plays faster than his pro day 40. He's an above-average vertical route runner who stacks corners and manipulates safeties. He's a natural pass catcher who plucks balls out of the air and makes some difficult catches. He has long arms and an excellent catch radius. He has the burst to get off man coverage and he flashes as a short-to-intermediate route runner.

The Hawaiian-born Herbig was a two-plus year starter (36 games played, 26 starts at guard) who missed six games due to injury in 2018. He is a massive run-blocker with the power-base to move defenders off the ball and the nasty disposition to bury his assignment. He also moves well for his size and shows impressive flexibility and body control. He does a slightly above-average job of cutting off linebackers at the second level. The one issue is he gets caught overextending (due to marginal speed) and ends up on the ground on occasion. In pass pro, he doesn't have elite mirror skills but his wide frame makes it tough for interior pass-rushers to shake him. Herbig is a powerful and nasty guard with enough talent to emerge as a NFL starter early in his career. -- March 28, 2019 Herbig is a massive run-blocker with the powerbase to move defenders off the ball and the nasty disposition to bury his assignment. He does get caught overextending and ends up on the ground on occasion. Herbig doesn't have elite mirror skills, but his wide frame makes it tough for interior pass-rushers to shake him.

Johnson has good size but his top-end speed is below-average. He's a developing route-runner, as he still lacks acceleration off the line and relies on strength to get off press coverage. He's not very twitchy. Johnson tracks the deep ball well and wins a solid percentage of 50-50 balls. He also has good open-field instincts and attacks the ball with his hands. He's above average at adjusting to back-shoulder passes and he makes over-the-shoulder catches without breaking stride. However, he drops the occasional pass he should catch and needs more consistent focus. Johnson grades out as a No. 4 or No. 5 receiver early in his NFL career but has enough potential to develop into an effective No. 3 or No. 4 contributor in time. -- March 19, 2019 Johnson is a savvy route runner who does an adequate job of separating from man coverage despite having average burst, and he makes catches with defenders on his back. He locates pockets in zone looks. He doesn't run by corners, but he tracks the ball well, creates late separation with his upper body and makes contested catches downfield.

Hall is an undersized outside linebacker with long arms and above-average range. He's an aggressive run defender who reads his keys and quickly triggers downhill. He flashes a powerful punch, superior stopping power and the ability to de-cleat offensive linemen. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. He reads the quarterback getting to hook/curl and flat in coverage.

Benzschawel has the quickness to get into position and the wide frame to wall off his assignments in the run game. He has the range to reach second-level assignments and get around the corner when asked to pull. There's room for improvement when it comes to footwork and angles, but he has the potential to develop into a solid zone blocker. He flashes the ability to get movement but sometimes plays too high. Benzschawel gets set quickly and anchors well. He flashes ability to push pass-rushers past the quarterback with a strong punch. He needs to do a better job of keeping hips down and staying square when he shuffles. He has shorter arms and gets top-heavy at times. His father and his uncle played football at Wisconsin. His brother, Luke, is a tight end at Wisconsin. Benzschawel grades out as a backup offensive guard with the potential to develop into an effective starter. -- May 11, 2018 Benzschawel is a right guard with the initial quickness to get into position and the wide frame to wall off his assignments in the run game. He gets set quickly and is quick to rewrap with his hands, and he anchors well in pass protection. Benzschawel's pads rise and he gets top heavy at times, which causes him to struggle in the run game.

Smith is a tall, long-armed cornerback with a somewhat lean frame but has good top-end speed. He suffered a lower-leg injury in the CFP National Championship game and was carted off the field. He has experience playing a variety of different man and zone coverages. He has the length, athleticism, speed and ball skills to develop into a starting cornerback in the NFL. So long as Smith checks out medically, he projects to be a Day 2 draft pick in 2019. He's a tall, long-armed cornerback with a somewhat lean frame and below-average timed top-end speed. He has experience playing a variety of different coverages. He's well coached with his press technique and he understands leverage. He plays with good balance and body control. He has above-average ball skills, and he's willing tackler who is disciplined with perimeter contain.

Ledbetter is built like a 5-technique and possesses average top-end speed. He's a power-based player in run defense and pass rush with good initial pop and shock in his hands. He flashes the ability to move QBs off the spot with his tendency to walk offensive linemen back, but he is a much better run defender than a pass-rusher at this point. Strong at the point of attack, Ledbetter has longer arms and a strong upper body to control blockers. He was suspended for the first six games of 2016 because of two alcohol-related arrests prior to that season, the second of which was for DUI. Ledbetter fits best as a 5-technique in a base 3-4 scheme but has some scheme versatility. -- July 1, 2018 Ledbetter has excellent length and he anchors well. He locates the ball and gets off blocks, and he chases with good effort and makes some plays in pursuit even though he has below-average range. He flashes the ability to move quarterbacks off the spot but he's a much better run defender than pass rusher.

Autry is a massive interior offensive lineman with outstanding size and length. He plays with an edge, and he flashes the ability to throw defenders to the ground in the run game. He anchors well and his wide frame/long arms make it tough to get around him in pass protection.

Cheevers is an undersized corner with short arms and average speed. He's at his best reading receivers and breaking on the ball, and he's quick with good balance. His hands are on the smaller side yet he's a playmaker with a nose for the football, and no FBS player picked off more passes than he did in 2018. But he's an erratic tackler who has some problems getting off blocks.

Adams was a three-year starter who started all 37 games at right tackle for Missouri the last three seasons and was a two-time captain. He has an excellent height and weight combo with average speed and below-average arm length for an OT prospect. His short shuttle and broad jump were slightly above average for his size. In pass protection, he has good quickness in his set. Adams will give up initial ground versus power rush but is almost always able to re-sink his hips and anchor. His two biggest issues here are that he plays too high and his hand placement is too high/wide. As a run blocker, he has good initial quickness and consistently gets quality initial positioning. He's usually able to latch on and initially steer/scoop/seal a defensive lineman out of the way thanks to quality positioning, but he's not an overpowering drive blocker and will slip off blocks a bit too often. Adams' NFL ceiling is as a backup swing tackle. He needs refining but has good size and enough athleticism to work with. He projects as a Day 3 pick. -- March 6, 2019 Adams has an excellent height-and-weight combo with below-average arm length. As a run-blocker, he's usually able to latch on and initially steer/scoop/seal the defensive lineman out of the way thanks to quality positioning. He gets set quickly and although he gives ground initially, he almost always re-sinks his hips and anchors. His two biggest issues are playing too high, and his hand placement is too high/wide.

Worthington is a big and versatile safety with decent length but subpar timed top-end speed. He's a good tackler who limits production after the catch and steps up in run support. He does a good job of reading the quarterback and getting off the hash in Cover 2. Worthington runs well enough to compete with tight ends in man-to-man coverage. He lacks the closing speed to regularly play center field.

Ray is a lighter defensive end with below--average length and average top-end speed. He's a 3-4 OLB conversion candidate who has some experience dropping into coverage. He's got good upper-body strength, and he flashes the ability to lock out blockers. He's an athletic pass rusher who flashes effective inside-and-weave moves. His closing speed is just adequate, but he chases the run and rushes the passer with good effort.

Edwards is a stout, between-the-tackles run defender with the strength to hold his ground in a phone booth and get off blocks in time to make the play. He's a powerful, wrap-up tackler, but he's not as effective in space as he is in close quarters. While he chases with good effort and has the instincts to get an early break on the ball, he doesn't close well in pursuit and he struggles to recover when he overruns the play. He reads the quarterback, he shows a good feel for crossers and he flashes above-average ball skills in coverage. However, he doesn't have the burst or change-of-direction skills to regularly match up in man, and he's not much of a threat to get to the quarterback as a pass-rusher. -- May 21, 2018 Edwards didn't weigh as much as expected at the combine and he has short arms, but he does an above-average job of stacking and getting off blocks on tape. He chases with good effort, and he has the instincts to get an early break on the ball but he has below-average closing speed. He reads the quarterback, shows good feel for route concepts and flashes above-average ball skills in underneath zone coverage.

Thomas is a long and lean press corner with excellent length and very good top-end speed. There's room for improvement when it comes to his technique, but he gets his hands on receivers, is smooth flipping his hips and runs well. He gets muscled at the top of the stem and needs to get stronger to win 50-50 balls. He has big hands and he flashes good ball skills, yet he picked off just one pass last year.

Denis is an undersized but extremely athletic free safety who has excellent range in coverage. He's at his best playing the single-high safety spot. He has smooth hips, quick feet and very good change-of-direction skills. Denis is a former wide receiver with outstanding ball skills. He takes good angles, high-points the ball and is a natural pass catcher. He has good range versus the run and fills hard, but he's an inconsistent open-field tackler. Denis gets trucked by bigger ball carriers at times, but he doesn't shy from contact. The undersized but rangy free safety grades out as a future NFL starter and will have maximum value for NFL teams that employ a single-high zone heavy defensive scheme. Denis projects as a Day 2 pick. -- May 24, 2018 Denis is an undersized but athletic free safety with adequate top-end speed. He has some versatility as a free safety with experience playing corner and nickel. He's more quick than fast with smooth hips and good change-of-direction skills. He's a former wide receiver and natural pass-catcher. He's a willing run defender but an inconsistent open-field tackler who has some problems getting bigger ball carriers on the ground.

Raymond has average size, slightly below-average length and upper-level top-end speed. He lines up in the slot, in-line and at H-back. He's a natural hands catcher with big hands and good body control. He shows good burst after the catch and is fast enough to threaten down the seam. He's willing and does an adequate job of covering up defenders in space but does get overpowered as an in-line blocker at times.

Wingard is a versatile safety who lines up in the box, over the slot, in single high and in two high. He plays faster than his timed speed thanks to the way he reads quarterbacks and diagnoses plays, but he lacks ideal closing speed and length for a center fielder. He tracks the ball well and he has average ball skills even though he has small hands. He's an above-average tackler.

Hansen is an undersized linebacker with below-average length who has had problems staying healthy, didn't work out at the Combine and turns 26 in May. That said, he's instinctive, he closes well and he chases with good effort. He's tough for his size with above-average balance and active hands. He shows good awareness and range in underneath coverage

Holyfield possesses good size and strength but did not test well at the combine except for the bench press (26 reps of 225 pounds). Besides that, he ran 4.78-second 40-yard dash, had a 29-foot-5 vertical jump and a 9-8 broad jump. He's a patient runner with strong leg drive, runs behind his pads and almost always falls forward at the end of runs. He lacks elite, make-you-miss suddenness but shows good stop-start ability and has enough lateral agility to weave in and out of creases. He is more quick than fast and lacks a second gear when he hits daylight. But he has good awareness as a ball carrier. He will never be a home-run threat or dynamic weapon in the passing game but can be a reliable outlet. Holyfield doesn't have enough explosive qualities or experience in the passing game to grade out as a No. 1 back in the NFL but is a gifted runner with short-area quickness, patience and a physical play style. He should develop into a solid NFL backup. -- March 19, 2019 With the exception of the bench press, Holyfield did not test well at the combine, and he's not much of a big-play threat. He also lacks ideal experience in the passing game. That said, he's a patient runner with enough lateral agility to weave in and out of creases. He has strong leg drive and almost always falls forward at the end of runs.

Wesley is a tall and lean receiver with excellent length. He's a hand-catcher who elevates well and makes some highlight-reel catches. He's a matchup problem in the red zone. He has marginal top-end speed and he's not going to run by corners, yet he tracks the ball well and wins one-on-one downfield. He flashes some savvy as a route-runner but he takes too long to transition in and out of breaks.

Crawford is an interchangeable safety whose route recognition and discipline help mask his average burst change of direction in coverage. He tracks the ball well, flashes the ability to pluck the ball out of the air, and he picked off seven passes his first two seasons at Indiana. He's more of an opportunist than a ball hawk, though. He's an above average tackler who plays with good body control, wraps on contact.

James tends to get his hands inside and he's tough to shake once locked in pass pro. However, he has very short arms for an offensive tackle and his lack of length is an issue at times. He has some problems handling speed from wide alignments and keeping edge rushers off his frame. He gets into position and fights to sustain but he doesn't move defenders off the ball with any kind of consistency in the run game.

Carney plays with good pad level and shoots his hands inside as a run defender. He sheds in time to make the play at times, but he gets stuck on some blocks and gives ground. He chases with good effort. He's a developing pass-rusher who flashes as a hand fighter. He's versatile and moved around the formation at North Carolina, yet he arguably fits best at 3-4 OLB because of his frame.

Huggins was a career backup at Clemson. During his final three seasons, he finished with 63 tackles, 11.5 tackles for loss and seven sacks. He has a good height-bulk combination with average top-end speed, solid arm length but smaller hands. He will never be a great pass-rusher but can disrupt. Huggins has quick hands and flashes ability to win with arm-over and push-pull moves. He's not overpowering but has good natural strength and balance. He has solid instincts and does a consistently good job of locating the ball. Huggins is still maturing and has made strides throughout his career but needs to be more consistent with accountability. He grades out as a backup DT in the NFL and likely fits best in a one-gap heavy defensive scheme. He projects as a Day 3 draft pick in 2019. -- Feb. 26, 2019 Huggins has a good combination of size and length with average top-end speed. He has good natural strength and balance. He stays on his feet and doesn't get pushed around often. He will never be a great pass-catcher but has quick hands and flashes ability to win with arm-over and push-pull moves.

Knight gets set quickly and has enough length to push speed-rushers past the pocket. He flashes the ability to sink and recover but gives too much ground at times. He fits better in a zone-heavy scheme than a power heavy scheme. He doesn't generate much push but is quick and athletic enough to reach and seal defenders when his footwork is sound.

Smith is a big receiver with excellent length and decent top-end speed. He can line up on the inside or outside. He's a vertical threat who tracks the ball well, and has the frame to win 50-50 balls downfield. He's strong with good burst after the catch. He's not an elusive open-field runner. His hands are inconsistent, but he's a hands catcher with good body control. He's tight and not an explosive route runner.

West is a shorter safety with good bulk, average length and excellent top-end speed. His speed stands out when he's closing in run support and after the catch, yet he's a step late getting there in coverage at times. He's late recognizing some routes and not a center fielder despite that 40 time. His angles are inconsistent and he looks to rip the ball out instead of wrapping at times. He flashes good stopping power.

Tauaefa reads his keys and quickly diagnoses plays. He's an exceptional tackler who wraps on contact and flashes good stopping power. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks but he has active hands and good length and upper-body strength. Though he has below-average speed, he chases with effort and makes plays in pursuit. He reads the quarterback and shows a good feel for routes in underneath zone.
An LSU transfer, Okeke is a developmental left tackle with outstanding upside, shown in flashes on tape. He needs to be more consistent with his hand placement to realize his potential.

Peters is a versatile defensive back with a unique blend of size, length and top-end speed. He has tightness in coverage but he's instinctive, physical and strong in run support. He's an erratic tackler who needs to be more consistent in that area, especially if asked to play safety. He has the potential to develop into a starting nickel corner in a press heavy or zone heavy scheme. He projects as a Day 2 pick in 2019. Peters is a big defensive back with experience playing corner and safety. He has superior length and eased concerns about his top-end speed by running faster at his Pro Day than at the combine. He's at his best in press coverage. He allows separation when he doesn't win with his length. He's not a ball hawk. He's an erratic tackler who needs to be more consistent, especially if asked to play safety.

Gustin played four seasons but missed 16 games his final two years due to multiple injuries. He played in 37 career games (22 starts) and totaled 137 career tackles, 33 tackles-for-loss and 21 sacks. Gustin was a high school quarterback who converted to linebacker at USC. He has good size and very good speed for a 3-4 OLB type. While he primarily plays that 3-4 OLB role, Gustin has experience playing 4-3 DE, off-the-line LB and even some DT on obvious pass downs. He is an instinctive, active player who always seems to be around the ball. He shows the ability to advance his rush while engaged but he's slow to redirect on outside-in moves and lacks the body control to bend the edge tightly without losing footing. He has a powerful upper body and excels at stacking, locating, shedding and finishing versus the run. His biggest knock as a run defender is that he has some tightness that shows up when trying to redirect. Additionally, he shows solid awareness but coverage is not his strength. He's a good enough football player and pass-rusher to contribute as a situational player in the NFL. -- April 5 Gustin is an edge defender with good size and speed for a 3-4 OLB prospect. He's an instinctive and active player who always seems to be around the ball. He has good shock in his hands and shows the ability to advance his rush while engaged. He has a powerful upper body. He excels at stacking, locating, shedding and finishing as a run defender.

In his last two years as a starter, Higdon totaled 388 carries for 2,172 yards (5.6 per carry) and 21 scores. He also caught 15 passes for 174 yards (11.6). Higdon is slightly undersized but has above-average speed. A one-cut runner with good patience, vision and initial burst, he runs with good contact balance and shows a solid second-gear if he hits daylight. But the biggest negative is he just doesn't create enough yards on his own. He lacks elusiveness to make a lot of defenders miss in tighter spaces. He has reliable hands as an outlet in the pass and shows good awareness, toughness and technique in pass pro. Higdon grades out as a reserve NFL running back who contribute in a rotation. He simply lacks elite traits to emerge as a good full-time starting back at the next level. -- March 28, 2019 Higdon is slightly undersized with above-average speed, and he tested well at the combine. He's a one-cut runner with good patience and burst. He's tough and he runs with good contact balance, but lacks elusiveness. We did not see a drop on six tapes, and he has very reliable hands as an outlet in the passing game. He lacks ideal size to anchor but he shows good awareness, toughness and technique in pass protection.

Nijman is an athletic offensive tackle with average length and excellent upper-body strength. He's raw, especially for a three-year starter, and his tape is erratic. There are flashes that make it hard to deny his upside. He engulfs defenders and gets good push when his technique is sound in the run game. He has experience at left and right tackle, making him an intriguing swing tackle prospect.

Brown is taller corner who is at his best in off-man coverage and zone coverage where he closes well and limits production after the catch. He's fluid and fast enough to turn and run with most receivers in press-bail. He has average length and is not a physical press corner who shows the ability to disrupt receivers getting off the line. He has balance and enough quickness to develop man-cover skills, but he allows too much separation at times. Brown is lean and gets bumped off some routes. He's a better tackler after the catch than he is in run support, and he has a tendency to wrap high. His uncle is Herschel Walker. Brown has the potential to develop into an above-average starter within the time of his rookie contract. Getting stronger and adding some weight would boost his draft stock. -- July 1, 2018 Brown is a tall, lean corner with good length. He reads the quarterback and has a feel for route combinations. He plays the ball, not the man, and makes it tough for receivers to get a clean release in press coverage. He posted a faster time at his Pro Day than he did at the combine but has marginal top-end speed for a corner and he's tight in space.

Calhoun is a shorter guard with adequate bulk, average length and very good top-end speed. He gets into position and walls off defenders in the run game. He has an average power base and gets stood up at the times, but he has good foot speed and balance. Calhoun does an above-average job of staying in front of his assignment in pass protection.

Granderson has the get-off, bend and closing speed to win with speed off the edge. He has long arms and does a good job of extending when he gets his hands inside, but he has some room to grow as a hand fighter. There's also room for improvement when it comes to generating speed to power. Granderson gets off blocks and makes plays in the run game, but he occasionally gets pushed around. He closes well chasing from the backside. He lines up at both defensive end spots in Wyoming's scheme, and he's a candidate to transition to 3-4 outside linebacker. Granderson grades out as a developmental defensive end or 3-4 OLB with the skill set and frame to develop into a starter. He projects as a Day 2 pick heading into the 2018 season. -- May 22, 2018 Granderson flashes the ability to slip blocks and make plays in the backfield. He's a lean defensive end who is more than 13 pounds lighter than the five-year combine average for defensive ends. He struggles to anchor. While Granderson has some upside as a pass-rusher, he didn't look as explosive coming off the edge in 2018 as he did in 2017. He had just three sacks in 2018.

Moore is a well-built running back with quick feet and good burst between the tackles. He picks up yards after contact thanks to his aggressive running style, balance and effort. He's not a breakaway threat on tape and he hadn't recovered from a season-ending ankle injury so he couldn't run at the combine. He flashes the potential to develop into an effective third-down player even though he played in a run-heavy offense at Appalachian State.

Givens is an undersized defensive tackle at his best attacking gaps and playing on the other side of the line of scrimmage. He chases with great effort. He has strong hands and he flashes the ability to rush the passer. His frame is an obvious issue and he gets moved off the ball when he doesn't win with quickness. He's a one-gap three technique who doesn't have scheme or positional versatility.

Murray is an undersized receiver with excellent quickness and speed. He works mostly on the outside but has slot-receiver size. He has some experience working inside and is a smooth and savvy route runner. Murray explodes off the line and is quick in and out of breaks. He does have a small catch radius and is inconsistent in traffic. Murray is a willing blocker but struggles to win at the point of attack due to marginal size/strength. He is still maturing but has progressed in that area. Overall, Murray is an undersized receiver with explosive quickness and speed. He grades out as a No. 3 starter in the NFL and is a likely mid-round pick. -- Aug. 6, 2018 Murray is an undersized receiver who tested poorly at the combine. His 40 time is a red flag for a receiver and he doesn't have a second gear on tape, but he doesn't appear to be speed-deficient, either. His below-average 10-yard split and slow three-cone time are even more surprising considering his ability to get open. He's a savvy route runner who changes speed well. He has a good feel for coverage and how to attack zones.

Lamar was a two-year starter at Clemson, totaling 146 tackles, 13 tackles for loss and eight sacks. He has outstanding size with good speed, but his recognition skills are still developing. Lamar takes a few too many false steps, especially versus play-action. He has good closing burst for his size and solid range in zone coverage but gives up separation in man-coverage. Lamar flashes as an edge-rusher and has length and speed to continue to develop in that area. He shows good range in run support and packs a punch as a tackler. Lamar has the tools to develop into a starting off-the-ball linebacker in the NFL -- and he's also versatile enough to contribute as a 3-4 OLB -- but he's still a bit raw at this point. He projects as a Day 2 pick. -- Feb. 26, 2019 Lamar is a big inside linebacker who is strong at the point of attack and packs a punch as a tackler. There are concerns about his ability to hold up on passing downs at the NFL level. While Lamar plays faster on tape, he has marginal timed speed. He's much more effective rushing the passer than he is dropping in coverage.

An edge rusher with below average height, good bulk and explosive burst, Durham plays with good leverage. He has some shock in his hands and is a relatively polished pass-rusher with a fast dip-and-rip move. He shows adequate strength to advance his rush while engaged -- he's sudden and slippery. Durham may never be a full-time starter, but he has explosive qualities as a pass-rusher. -- Aug. 2, 2018 Durham is an undersized edge defender with below-average length and below-average speed for his size. He flashes the ability to slip blocks and disrupt plays in the backfield. He plays with good leverage and he's stout for his size, but he takes too long to get off blocks. He gets to the quarterback with effort. His speed-to-power tends to stall out and he doesn't have violent hands.

Woods has average size, slightly above-average length and outstanding timed speed. He's an above-average tackler who is willing in run support. Plus, Woods is athletic and fast enough to match up with tight ends, but he does get muscled at times. He doesn't play as fast as his timed speed.

Alaka is a tall inside linebacker with average bulk, above-average length and below-average speed. He's an instinctive between-the-tackles run-stopper who does an above-average job of sifting through traffic. He uses his length to keep blockers off his frame, and he anchors well. He plays faster than his timed speed, thanks to his effort and sound angles. But he's limited in coverage.

Meyers began his college career at quarterback before switching to wide receiver in the fall of 2016. Multiple injuries and the position switch resulted in Meyers essentially becoming just a two-year contributor and one-year starter at wide receiver. He had a breakout 2018 season with 92 catches for 1,047 yards and four TDs. Meyers has good size with average arm length and hand span, but poor top-end speed. He spent most of his time working in the slot at N.C. State and his size can help generate some mismatches versus smaller corners with crafty route running. He understands how to leverage his stem and set defensive backs up versus man-to-man coverage. And he shows the ability to drop weight quickly and gets in-and-out of breaks efficiently. Meyers has solid focus in traffic and does a plus job on contested catches. But he lacks the speed to threaten vertically in the NFL. He projects as a No. 4 or No. 5 receiver in the NFL. -- March 19, 2019 Meyers has good size with average arm length and poor top-end speed. He's a former quarterback who spent most of his time working out of the slot at North Carolina State and developed into a relatively crafty route runner in just two-plus years at receiver. He has good overall ball skills, and he does a good job on contested catches. He's not much of a big-play threat.

Dixon is a tough downhill run defender who doesn't shy away from contact. His frame and length raise concerns about his ability to play in the box at the NFL level. He's fluid but doesn't show great burst transitioning out of breaks. Dixon ran better at his pro day than he did at the combine, but he still has below-average top-end speed. He has the mentality to develop into core special teams player.

Scott is a shifty between-the-tackles runner with excellent patience and quick feet for his size. He runs with good forward lean but high and doesn't have great brute strength. He has below-average timed speed and is not a threat to pull away. He catches the ball well, flashes the ability to make the first defender miss and has upside in pass protection.

Dortch is an undersized slot receiver with short arms and below-average top-end speed. He's an above-average route runner with the quickness and change of direction skills to separate from man. He's tough over the middle. He doesn't catch every pass cleanly and he has a smaller catching radius, but he doesn't drop many passes he gets his hands on. He makes defenders miss, but he doesn't have breakaway speed and he doesn't pick up a lot of yards after contact.

Bars flashes a strong punch and tends to get his hands inside in pass pro. He's big and strong enough to anchor. He oversteps and struggles to recover on occasion, but he tends to mirror well once engaged. He's an effective positional blocker with an average power base, and he's not as consistent with his hands in the run game as he is in pass protection. He's a team captain who has improved his work habits during his time at Notre Dame. His length raises concerns about his ability to play tackle in the NFL. Bars grades out as a reserve guard with the tools to quickly develop into a starter. He projects as a Day 2 pick heading into the 2018 season. -- May 7, 2018 Bars gets into positon and plays with a wide base. He's more of a positional blocker than a mauler and doesn't generate push with any kind of consistency. He anchors well in pass protection but he bends at the waist and his hand placement is inconsistent, making him vulnerable to effective hand fighters. He struggles to power down and take away quick inside moves.

Williams was a four-year player who started 28 of the 50 games he appeared in at Auburn. During his final three seasons, he totaled 183 tackles, 14 tackles for loss, 1.5 sacks, four pass breakups and one interception. Williams has an NFL frame, good length and adequate playing speed. He flashes ability to generate pressure off the edge as a pass-rusher. He has length and enough strength to keep blockers off his frame but there's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. He chases with above average effort and makes plays outside the tackle box even though he has just average closing speed. He's a leader and a hard worker. Williams grades out as a reserve strongside linebacker and potential special-teams contributor. He projects as a later-round pick in 2019. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Williams is undersized with very good length but isn't fast. He chases with strong effort and makes some plays outside the tackle box even though he lacks closing speed. He does an adequate job of getting to depth and reading the quarterback but he's too tight to regularly match up in man and he gets grabby.

Wise doesn't have a natural position fit as he is undersized for a defensive tackle, and he doesn't have ideal length for a 34DE or LDE. Yet he's got the potential to develop into a versatile reserve. He's got the first-step quickness and active hands to develop into a disruptive interior pass-rusher. Wise has a low center of gravity and he's strong enough to set the edge when he fires of the ball and gets under offensive tackles. His length is an issue as he gets covered up at times, but he flashes the ability to slip blocks. He chases the run and the quarterback with above-average effort. Wise has a low center of gravity, and he's strong enough to set the edge when he fires off the ball and gets under offensive tackles. His length is below-average, and he gets covered up at times. But he has the active hands and enough quickness to develop into a disruptive interior pass-rusher. Wise chases the run and the quarterback with above-average effort.

Davis is a big target with big hands and a wide catching radius. He has good body control and he tends to snatch the ball out of the air. He's an above average vertical route runner with the ability to win 50-50 balls. He doesn't have an elite second gear, and he's not as much of a threat after the catch as he is downfield. He is coming off a torn Achilles that limited him to seven games in 2018.

An undersized edge defender, Jefferson is a college defensive end who likely will convert to 3-4 OLB in the NFL. He has excellent takeoff quickness and causes problems with his explosive first step. He is a sudden athlete with good change-of-direction skills and closing burst for size. He has quick hands but is still developing his pass-rush moves. He is not an overly powerful pass-rusher and struggles to advance while engaged, but he has upside because of his speed, hands and instincts. Jefferson is a tough player who appears capable of converting to OLB and handling spot-coverage duties. He won't win many phone booth battles, but he does a good job of keeping bigger blockers off his body. He's an aggressive, feisty player, but one area he can improve upon is tackling. He lacks ideal body control and can be an inconsistent finisher in space. Jefferson is an edge defender who grades out as rotational contributor early in his NFL career, but he has enough potential to develop into a starter in the right scheme. -- June 9, 2018 Jefferson is a short defensive end with average bulk, slightly above-average length and marginal top-end speed. He's big and long enough to set the edge. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. He's a limited pass-rusher who tends to stall out. His testing raises concerns about his ability to play 3-4 OLB.

Hartage is an average-sized corner with slightly above-average length. He reads the quarterback and plays the ball, not the man, in zone. He's tough for his size. He re-routes receivers and limits production after the catch. Hartage posted a marginal 40 time at the combine and a below-average 40 time at his pro day.

Wesley is a lean receiver with slightly below-average length and excellent top-end speed. He changes speeds well and flashes as a route-runner but he looks tight getting in and out of breaks. He tends to extend and catch with hands. He has the second gear to run under deep balls. His frame raises concerns about the ability to win 50-50 balls downfield. He's not a dynamic open-field runner after the catch.

Davis is a big corner with average length and top-end speed. He's slow to recover when he gets caught out of position and is not fluid or quick enough to mirror quicker receivers underneath. He doesn't shy away from his responsibilities in run support, but he's an inconsistent tackler who fails to wrap up at times. He takes some poor pursuit angles, which raises concerns for teams considering moving him to safety. He's not a ball-hawk or natural pass-catcher. Davis is a big corner with average length and below-average top-end speed. He doesn't shy away from his responsibilities in run support, but he's an inconsistent tackler who fails to wrap up at time. He's not a ball hawk or natural pass-catcher.

Dodson is an average-sized linebacker with slightly below-average length and very good timed speed. He closes well and makes plays in pursuit. However, he takes too long to get off blocks and is at his best beating blockers to the point of attack. He shows good awareness and range in underneath zone. But he is tight and allows too much separation in man coverage.

Bledsoe, who lined up on the inside and the outside at Oklahoma, projects best at 3-4 defensive end. Though he has marginal top-end speed and below-average length for a defensive end, he does a good job of shooting his hands inside and stacking blockers. He's a better run defender than pass-rusher.

Fields was a four-year player who only started six games at Clemson. During his final three seasons, he totaled 37 tackles, 11 pass breakups and one interception. He's shorter than ideal with below-average bulk and average top-end speed, but he is well-defined with a muscular build. Fields is quick and athletic with fluid hips in coverage. He doesn't have elite burst but is fast enough to stick with vertical receivers if he diagnoses properly. His poor recognition skills and inconsistent focus really stand out on tape. Multiple NFL scouts are concerned about his lack of maturity and below-average football character. Fields has enough physical talent to make an NFL roster as a No. 4 cornerback and special-teams contributor but needs to mature and improve his focus. He projects as a late-round pick. -- Feb. 26, 2019 Fields is a short corner with short arms but outstanding top-end speed. He's quick and athletic with fluid hips. He doesn't play as fast as his timed speed would indicate. He's an adequate tackler who takes inconsistent angles and loses contain at times.

Davis is a lean defensive end with excellent length and speed. He lost 10 pounds between the combine and his pro day. He gets overwhelmed when he doesn't win with quickness in the run game. With that in mind, he's expected to move to outside linebacker. As a pass-rusher, he tends to stall out and his production doesn't match his ability.

Sills has a tall and lean frame with average top-end speed. He has some experience working on the outside, but the majority of his snaps are from the slot. He needs to develop more savvy versus man-to-man coverage. He's a long strider who builds speed as he goes but lacks suddenness. He has to gear down too much getting in and out of breaks, and he struggles to gain separation on sharp-cutting routes. He has good ball skills, tracks the ball effectively, has good body control and shows ability to adjust to poorly thrown passes. He's a red zone threat. -- May 30, 2018 Sills has an NFL frame and he's versatile enough to line up on the inside or the outside. He's a zone-buster who excels at reading coverage and exploiting pockets. He's not a twitchy route runner, and he struggles to separate from man. He tends to catch the ball with his hands, has above-average body control and he makes some excellent catches. He has below-average top-end speed.

Baity is a taller and leaner corner with slightly above-average length and marginal top-end speed. He's at his best in zone and off-man, as he reads routes well and he limits production after the catch. He doesn't shy away from contact but he consistently hits high and he falls off some tackles in run support.

Barnes is a big back with the balance and lower-body strength to pick up yards after contact. He tends to follow his blocks and make the most of what he's given. His burst through the hole is average and he's not much of a threat to pull away when he gets a seam. He caught just 25 passes in three seasons at Kansas State.

Brady is a big receiver with excellent length. He tracks the ball well and wins one-on-one downfield. He fights for yards after the catch. He's an adequate route runner with a good feel for how to attack zone looks. However, his pro day time in the 40-yard dash is a red flag, and he tested poorly in other areas that correlate with receivers having success in the NFL.

McIntosh was a five-year player who started 40 games during his final three seasons at Washington. He recorded 173 tackles, six passes broken up, and just one interception during that span. He has very good size with longer-than-average arm length and average top-end speed. He has experience playing in-the-box and on the back of Washington's base 4-2-5 scheme. He has the instincts and enough range to cover a deep half but he's not capable of holding up as a Cover-3 centerfielder. He's generally a liability in man-to-man coverage. He has a lot of tightness in his hips, he is slow to redirect and he lacks speed if he gets beat early. McIntosh does track the ball well but he's not a playmaker. He's a tone-setter as a run-defender. He reads his keys and locates the ball quickly, and he fills the alley with a purpose. He's an above-average tackler with good stopping power, though he's tight and misses the occasional open-field tackle. McIntosh grades out as a reserve strong safety and above-average special teams contributor. -- March 22, 2019 McIntosh has average size, good length and below-average top-end speed. He's a tone-setter as a run defender. He's an outstanding tackler who locates the ball quickly and fills the alley with purpose. He has the instincts and enough range to cover a deep half. He's tight and generally a liability in man. He tracks the ball well, but isn't a ball hawk or playmaker.

Brown is short with below-average bulk and good top-end speed. He has long arms and a wide catching radius. He has good open-field instincts, he picks up yards after contact and he flashes ability to make defenders miss after the catch. He's a positional blocker who does an adequate job of locating second-level assignments.

Williams is an undersized back who is more quick than fast, catches the ball well and tends to make the first defender miss after the catch. He's not a powerful runner, and he's finished with more receiving yards than rushing yards the past two seasons.

Humphrey is a big slot receiver with good size and length. He locates soft spots in zone looks, he's willing to work the middle of the field and he's tough enough to hold on after taking a big hit. He's a powerful open-field runner. He has marginal top-end speed, and he's not much of a big-play threat.

Jones has starting experience both guard and both tackle positions. He has an adequate height-weight combination for an OG in the NFL and shows good initial quickness and plays with natural balance. Jones has adequate overall athletic ability and mirror-slide skills, but he lacks shock in his punch and will get driven back by powerful pass rushers. He lacks initial pop at the point of attack and has adequate toughness -- but he's not a classic glass-eater. He could do a better job of finishing more consistently. Jones is a dependable and versatile offensive lineman who projects best as a backup guard in the NFL. -- March 19, 2019 Jones has good initial quickness and plays with natural balance. He lacks shock in his punch and will get driven back by powerful pass-rushers. He takes sound angles and gets into position in the run game. He's not a glass-eater and he struggles to drive defensive linemen off the ball.

Pope is a massive offensive tackle who engulfs and moves defenders off the ball when his technique is sound. He tends to play high, though, and falls off blocks. He's got enough length to handle speed off the edge yet opens up and shortens the path to the quarterback at times. He's frequently wide with his hands and latches onto the outside of defenders' pads both in the run game and in pass protection.

Johnson is an undersized inside linebacker who reads his keys and locates the ball quickly. He chases with good effort and closes well on a straight line. He's significantly lighter than average and his frame raises concerns about position fit -- he has short arms and struggles to get off blocks once reached. He gets engulfed and pushed around in a phone booth. But he reads the quarterback and tracks the ball well in underneath zone, even though he lacks ideal man-to-man cover skills for a smaller linebacker. Johnson doesn't win one-on-one and needs a crease to be effective as a pass-rusher. His 2018 suspension warrants further investigation, but he's been a grinder with a professional work ethic and good overall football intangibles. Johnson is an undersized inside linebacker with outstanding top-end speed. He reads his keys and locates the ball quickly, and he chases with good effort and closes well. He's light with short arms and struggles to get off blocks once reached. Johnson is a straight-line player who lacks ideal man-to-man cover skills for a smaller linebacker.

Doss is an above-average route-runner who makes the most of his natural ability and settles into pockets working against zone looks. He lines up out wide and works out of the slot. He plucks the ball out of the air and makes contested catches, but his hands are a little inconsistent. He's fast and big enough to make the occasional play downfield. He's not as much of a threat after the catch.

Williams is a thicker corner with shorter arms and smaller hands. He lines up in the slot and is at his best in underneath zone coverage. He's a playmaker with a good nose for the ball. Williams doesn't always wrap up, but he's an active run defender who doesn't shy away from contact and is willing to sacrifice his body to make a play.

Glenn is a well-built safety with short arms and average top-end speed. He runs well with tight ends and he's effective in underneath zone. He doesn't have the range to play center field. He's an active and willing run defender but an inconsistent tackler.

Duck is a tough and instinctive playmaking corner. His frame raises concerns about his ability to play on the outside in the NFL, and his pro day results raised several concerns. His 40 time, arm length and short shuttle are all red flags for a corner. He has experience returning punts, but his speed raises concerns about ability to do so in the NFL.

Hager is an upfield edge defender at his best when using his first-step quickness to get under blockers and knock them back on contact. He has active hands and flashes the ability to slip blocks. He's on the lighter side and he gets pushed around when he doesn't win right off the snap. Hager has shorter arms and struggles to press blockers off his frame once reached. He arguably projects better at 34OLB than 43DE. While he's more effective attacking than he is in space, he has some experience dropping and appears athletic enough to occasionally hold up in underneath zone coverage. He flashes the ability to win with his hands, and he chases the quarterback with great effort. His motor is his greatest asset as a pass-rusher. He's not an explosive speed rusher and doesn't consistently win with speed to power. Hager is an edge defender at his best using his first-step quickness to get under blockers and knock them back on contact. He has active hands and he flashes the ability to slip blocks.
