He's light and gets pushed around when he doesn't win right off the snap. Hager shows the ability to win with his hands, but his motor is his greatest asset rushing the passer.

Burkett was a three-year starter at center (2016-18). He is a right-handed snapper who gets set quickly and does an adequate job of mirroring in pass pro. He's late delivering his punch at times and gets pushed around when interior pass-rushers get into his frame. But he's quick and athletic enough to develop into an effective zone blocker and second-level blocker in the NFL. He doesn't have the brute strength to drive defenders off the ball. His effort is sound but he's not a mauler. Burkett grades out as a versatile reserve interior offensive lineman. He will be best suited in a zone-heavy scheme. -- March 28, 2019 Burkett does an adequate job of mirroring in pass protection. He's late delivering his punch at times, has good length, but gets pushed around when interior pass-rushers get into his frame. He doesn't have the brute strength to drive defenders off the ball in the run game.

Johnson is big and strong but struggles to keep his hips down, so he gets stood up and falls off blocks in the run game. He takes too many false steps and doesn't deliver a violent initial punch. He has above-average range for his size and flashes the ability to overwhelm linebackers. He needs to play with better body control, though. His wide frame and excellent length make it tough to beat him clean, but he takes too long to redirect in pass protection. Johnson's length, size and experience lining up at tackle as well as guard make him an intriguing developmental prospect, but he's raw and doesn't appear to have a natural position. He's high-cut for a guard and lacks ideal change-of-direction skills for a tackle. -- June 15, 2018 Johnson is a massive guard with above-average length. He's big enough to engulf defenders but his higher center of gravity makes it tough for him to get under defenders and he gets stood up too often for a player with his size. He leans and falls off blocks. His wide frame and length make it tough to beat him cleanly but he's a waist-bender whose hand placement is inconsistent in pass protection.

Rypien was a four-year player with a 37-12 record as a starter at Boise State. He completed 64 percent of his passes. Super Bowl XXVI MVP Mark Rypien is his uncle. Rypien has below-average size and athleticism with a solid hand span. As a passer, he locks onto his first read too long and is late on too many throws. He's hesitant to pull the trigger too often. Rypien shows the ability to anticipate throws, but his ball placement is inconsistent. He has below-average arm strength and struggles to drive the ball vertically and needs to be on time with the deep ball. He also struggles to fit the ball into tight windows. Rypien stays poised and keeps his eyes downfield as he moves around the pocket but doesn't consistently sense pressure and takes too many hits. Pressure really affects his accuracy and overall play. He doesn't show enough quickness or elusiveness in the pocket. Rypien has below-average speed and does not offer much as a runner. He has good football intelligence and picks things up quickly. Rypien's NFL ceiling is as a reserve for a West Coast style offense. He will get a chance to compete for a practice squad role as a late-round pick or undrafted free agent. -- March 6, 2019

Bell is a bigger safety with long arms. He's not a center fielder and he does not recover well. He ran a substantially faster 40 at his pro day than he did at the combine, but his pro-day time is still slower than the five-year combine average for safeties. He tracks the ball well and he flashes the ability to high-point the ball.

Dineen is an active run-defender with good instincts and a nonstop motor. While he slips off on occasion, he's a slightly above-average tackler who wraps up and wrestles ball carriers to the ground. He has active hands and flashes the ability to slip blocks on the move but is undersized with short arms and tends to get covered up when blockers reach him. He has average closing speed, and his effort is the biggest reason he makes plays in pursuit. He reads the quarterback and limits production after the catch in underneath coverage. He's an average athlete with average top-end speed, so he's going to get exposed in some one-on-one matchups. He has the mentality to develop into an above-average special-teams player. -- June 25, 2018 Dineen reads his keys and rarely gets caught out of his gap. He chases with above-average effort and has decent closing speed. He's undersized with short arms, and he gets covered up. He reads the quarterback and limits production after the catch in underneath coverage. He has the mentality and tools to develop into a core special teams player.

Dixon was a five-year player who was slowed by injuries throughout his career. He has good straight-line speed and can take the top off a defense. But he's not very sudden and does not make many defenders miss in space. He is a reliable target who makes a lot of tough catches in traffic. Dixon grades out as a reserve wide receiver with some upside if he can stay healthy. He projects as a late-round pick. Dixon is a short receiver with below-average length and very good top-end speed. He tracks the deep ball well and is a threat to take the top off the coverage. But he's more fast than quick and does not make many defenders miss in space. He shows soft hands when plucking away from his frame and makes tough catches in traffic.

Lodge is a natural hands catcher with a wide radius and good body control. He's not the most explosive or fluid route-runner but he changes speeds and tempos his routes well. He doesn't have the second gear to take the top off the coverage and is not an explosive open-field runner.

Blanton was a five-year player and one-year starter at Missouri who finished his 43-game career with 44 catches for 476 yards and six touchdowns. He has excellent size with good arm length and big hands but marginal top-end speed. He's a strong blocker with size to shield defenders. Blanton has some initial shock but will fall off too many blocks. He's at his best blocking on the move. He has a limited route tree and lacks ideal production as a pass-catcher. Blanton does not have the speed to threaten vertically and will never be more than an underneath outlet, but he's a big target with reliable hands and better athletic ability than his 40 time indicates. Blanton has excellent size and has proven to be an above-average blocker with versatility. He has limited production as a pass-catcher and he's a raw route runner but has some upside in that area. Blanton is worth drafting in the final couple of rounds. -- March 6, 2019

Hodge is an instinctive run-defender who reads his keys and locates the ball quickly. He's gap-sound and rarely gets caught out of position. He does an above-average job of slipping blocks in tight spaces and flashes the ability to stack bigger blockers, but his arms are on the shorter side, and he takes too long to get off some blocks. He doesn't close well, yet he makes plays in pursuit thanks to instincts, effort and angles. He's an above-average tackler who almost always finishes when he's able to get into sound position but has some athletic limitations, so he isn't as effective in space as he is between the tackles. He isn't quick or fluid enough to regularly compete in man and has average range in zone. He times his blitzes well. He's an alpha leader with good mental and physical toughness. -- July 25, 2018 Hodge is a better football player than athlete. He's a decent tackler who locates the ball quickly and rarely gets caught out of position. He has marginal top-end speed yet makes plays in pursuit thanks to instincts, effort and angles.

Morgan doesn't run a complete route tree but has the quickness and change of direction to develop above-average separation skills. He has the occasional focus drop yet flashes the ability to make tough, contested catches and highlight-reel receptions. He shows good body control adjusting to the deep ball. He is fast enough to stretch the field and is at his best after the catch, where he's quick to reach his top-end speed. His focus drops appear to be a result of trying to create after the catch and not a lack of toughness, as he shows a willingness to do the dirty work over the middle. -- May 23, 2018 Morgan Jr. is a versatile receiver with experience lining up on the outside and the inside. He's a natural hands catcher and he's smooth getting in and out of breaks. He tracks the deep ball well and he's got enough speed to stretch the field. He looked like more of a threat after the catch in 2017 than he did in 2018.

Joseph was a three-year starter at Clemson, collecting 303 tackles, 23.5 tackles for loss eight sacks and three interceptions. He has adequate height but a smaller frame with below-average speed and shorter arms. Joseph was a highly-productive college linebacker who always seemed to be around the ball. He's an instinctive, intelligent player who knows his assignments and gets teammates lined up pre-snap. Joseph reads keys quickly and doesn't take many false steps but gets washed out too easily by bigger blockers. He flashes some pop as a tackler but is speed deficient and has severe limitations in man coverage. He doesn't offer much upside as a pass-rusher. Joseph grades out as a fringe NFL reserve linebacker who will need to carve out a niche on special teams in order to maintain a roster spot in the NFL. He's likely to be either a late-round pick or an undrafted free agent. -- Feb. 26, 2019

Hills is a Delaware transfer with excellent football intangibles. He runs hard and fights for yards after contact. He's not a big-play threat and there are concerns about his ability to contribute on passing downs.

Thompson masks his average explosiveness with crafty route-running and he locates pockets in zone looks. He's got the toughness to do the dirty work over the middle and make contested catches. He does a good job of stacking defenders on vertical routes but he lacks the second gear to take the top off the coverage and he's not an elusive or explosive open-field runner after the catch.

Helm was a three-year contributor at Duke, totaling 69 catches for 763 yards and six touchdowns. He has good size with adequate height and a thicker frame. He has adequate top-end speed but slow initial acceleration with average arm length and hand span. Helm is a savvy route runner who runs crisp routes and understands how to locate soft spots in zone but is a slow starter with tightness in his lower body. He's not overly physical in terms of using his body and boxing-out defenders. Helm catches most balls thrown within his frame but struggles to adjust at times and has a smaller catch radius. The biggest concern is that he loses focus when he knows he's about to get hit. He's not strong in traffic or on contested throws. He gives effort as a blocker and takes good angles. Helm works to finish but struggles to drive defenders off the point. He's very effective as a move blocker but will struggle to hold up physically as an inline blocker in the NFL. Helm is a late-round or priority free-agent prospect who could make an NFL roster because of his ability to block in space and contribute on special teams. He lacks ideal toughness as a pass-catcher in traffic and has little upside as a difference-maker in the passing game. -- March 6, 2019

Hester is an average-sized safety who is at his best in robber and underneath-zone coverages. He does a good job of reading the quarterback and playing the ball, not the man. He has enough range to cover a deep half and flashes the ability to deliver big hits over the middle but has average-at-best closing speed and is not a centerfield-type free safety. His frame raises concerns about his ability to compete with tight ends, and he isn't a quick-twitch athlete with the ability to regularly match up with slot receivers. He flashes the ability to extend his arms and snatch the ball out of the air. He's an erratic tackler who fails to wrap up at times and has a tendency to duck his head. He isn't big or strong enough to regularly line up in the box. Hester grades out as a potential reserve safety and special-teams contributor. -- July 3, 2018

Davis was a three-year starter at Auburn who finished his career with 178 catches for 1,555 yards and seven touchdowns. He also averaged 10.8 yards on 24 punt returns. Davis is an undersized slot receiver and punt returner with good twitchiness and initial acceleration. He separates quickly in the short game but ran a limited route tree at Auburn and has room to develop as a route runner. He's at his best with the ball in his hands and is very elusive in space. Davis works to get in position and tries to sustain as a blocker but he's just not big or strong enough at times. He does have very good short-area quickness, which gives him a shot to contribute as a punt returner in the NFL. He's likely a No. 4 or No. 5 WR who will need to prove his value on special teams in order to earn a roster spot. Davis is a late-round prospect. -- Feb. 20, 2019 Davis is an undersized slot receiver and punt returner with good twitchiness. He separates quickly in the short game. He ran a limited route tree at Auburn and has room to develop as a route-runner. He lacks top-end speed and is more of a threat after the catch than he is downfield. He flashes ability to pluck the ball out of the air and quickly transition upfield.

Alexander finished with 58 career tackles, 4.5 tackles for loss and two sacks at LSU. He's an early-entry prospect with outstanding size and pretty good quickness and agility. Alexander has a quick first step for his size but he's top-heavy and slow to redirect. He can be disruptive as a pass-rusher but frequently stalls out and fails to finish. He doesn't show much in terms of counter moves as a pass-rusher and needs to improve his power moves. Alexander has great size and strength versus the run but tends to play too high and doesn't have a lot of violence in his hands. He has good size and strength and is solid versus the run. He grades out as a backup NT who can contribute as a run stuffer but won't offer much as a pass-rusher. He projects to be a late-round pick. -- Feb. 26, 2019

Mustipher is a right-handed snapper who gets set quickly. He gives ground initially but tends to reset and recover working against bull rushers. He has shorter arms, and defenders have some success getting into his frame. He gets into position and fights to sustain but has an average-at-best powerbase and gets stood up a little too much in the run game. His hands aren't married with his first step, and he's late delivering initial punch. He leans and falls off blocks. He plays with an edge and leans on defenders when he's able to get them on the ground. He's a natural leader with excellent character. -- May 7, 2018

Patrick possesses a powerful punch and has snap in his hands. He has very good take-on skills. He disengages in a flash and plays with a mean streak. He has a high motor and leaves it all on the field. He's a powerful striker as a tackler but is speed-deficient and lacks closing burst. Patrick is a very good run-defender but is limited in coverage. -- June 6, 2018 Patrick is a big inside linebacker with long arms and marginal top-end speed. He's an instinctive run defender who plays downhill and flashes the ability to beat blockers to the point of attack. He shoots his hands and stacks bigger blockers. He chases with good effort and makes some plays outside the tackle box even though he has below-average closing speed. He's limited in coverage.

Johnson, a combine snub, is a lean receiver with below-average length. He posted an outstanding 40 time at Oklahoma State's pro day and tracks the deep ball well. He's not as dangerous after the catch but flashes the ability to make the first defender miss and fights to stay on his feet. He looks the ball in and he plucks some passes out of the air.

Ratliff-Williams is an undersized receiver with average timed speed and short arms. He's a hands catcher who tracks the ball well but he doesn't have the frame or the length to regularly come down with 50-50 balls. He has good open-field instincts and returned two kickoffs for touchdowns in 2017.

Holder isn't a quick-twitch cover corner and is going to have a difficult time limiting separation against explosive route runners, but he has the size, playing speed and length to compete with bigger receivers on the outside. He has the potential to develop into an effective press corner with added strength and improved technique. He has adequate closing speed and limits production after the catch in off coverage. He's a physical run-stopper and above-average tackler who doesn't shy away from contact. Holder grades out as a developmental press/zone corner who needs to stay healthy and show teams he can play the ball to improve his draft stock. He projects as a Day 3 pick. -- June 9, 2018

Brumfield is strong enough to hold his ground against bull rushers. He has some problems mirroring when he doesn't win with his hands. He's too quick to turn his shoulders and open the gate working against quick three-techniques. He flashes the ability to drive defenders into the ground in the run game but tends to turn his shoulders instead of staying square and giving the ball carrier a two-way go. He lunges and ends up on the ground when he tries to cut backside pursuit. He's a limited athlete in space and is not an ideal fit for a zone-heavy scheme. Brumfield grades out as a potential reserve offensive guard who is unlikely to develop into a starter. -- Oct. 22, 2018

Hall is an undersized and athletic linebacker with adequate length and average top-end speed. He chases with effort and makes plays closing from the backside. He takes too long to get off blocks and doesn't anchor well. He's a subpar open-field tackler. He gets depth, reads the quarterback and flashes excellent ball skills for a linebacker in underneath coverage.

Patrick is a big back with the strength, balance and determination to pick up yards after contact, even though he runs high and with a narrow base. He's a patient runner who recognizes cutback lanes and gives his blockers time to get into position. He has decent top-end speed for his size but appears more fast than quick on tape and is not going to make many defenders miss. He isn't a nuanced runner and hasn't proven to be a big-play threat after the catch. However, he catches the ball well enough to develop into a reliable checkdown and is an above-average pass-blocker. -- May 7, 2018

Ivey drives his legs and is strong enough to move to defenders off the ball, but he leans, gets top-heavy and ends up on the ground at times. He lacks ideal foot speed and fits better in a power-heavy scheme than he does on a zone-heavy scheme. While he has excellent length, he is a better pass blocker on the inside than he is on the outside. He has some problems staying in front of his man and handling speed off the edge. He doesn't jar defenders with a violent initial punch but locks on when he gets his hands inside. Ivey is big and strong enough to anchor. He's a hard worker and a self-starter with good overall awareness. He flashes an edge but doesn't play with same kind of nastiness on every play. -- June 15, 2018

Cotton has outstanding size and adequate arm length for a guard, but he displays below-average mobility and lacks initial quickness. He has a strong anchor in pass protection and has good upper-body pop as a run blocker. But he struggles to hit moving targets as a puller and on second-level blocks. He grades out as a backup guard in the NFL. He's a likely Day 3 pick.
Snyder is a graduate transfer from Iowa who plays hard and is an effective tackler in a phone booth. He flashes good ball skills but he has average-at-best playing speed.

Ejiya has average size and length with below-average timed speed. He's an aggressive run defender who shoots gaps while doing a good job of sifting through traffic on inside runs. He takes too long to get off blocks and gets overwhelmed in tight spaces.

Brossette is slightly undersized, with marginal top-end speed and change of direction. He locates seams between the tackles and shows adequate burst through the hole. He runs hard. He's not as effective running outside as he is running inside and he lacks the burst to pull away from defenders. He has limited experience as a receiver and is not a threat after the catch.

Burrow is an NFL-ready QB with excellent football intelligence. He has elite pocket presence, feeling the rush and maneuvering without compromising his progression reads. And he knows when to tuck and run. His accuracy is at the NFL level, as he throws receivers open with anticipation. But he also knows when to give his receivers a chance to make a contested catch, especially when the backs of defenders are facing him. He has adequate size, and good mobility and athleticism. And Burrow is extremely tough and durable. His pocket presence, accuracy and toughness stand out as his elite traits. -- March 2020 Burrow's pocket presence, accuracy and toughness are elite. His ability to throw receivers open and understanding of when to give receivers a chance to make contested catches jumps out on tape. He excels at recognizing when a defender has his back to him and won't be able to locate the ball. Burrow also has the athletic ability and speed to extend plays and scramble for first downs. -- Steve Muench

Read: Can Burrow lead the Bengals on another Ohio revival? Cincinnati scored 21-plus points an NFL-low four times last year, and while Andy Dalton certainly wasn't the only one responsible for the offensive struggles, he is coming off his worst season statistically. The Bengals can save $17.7 million on the cap by trading or cutting the 32-year-old veteran. They hired a young, offense-minded coach in Zac Taylor last year, and now they give him the best quarterback in this class to mold. -- Steve Muench

Read: Bengals take Burrow with No. 1 pick

More: Analysis for every Bengals pick

During his final two seasons, Young amassed 79 tackles, 35.5 tackles for loss, 26.5 sacks and seven forced fumbles. He has excellent height, bulk and length. He also has elite take-off quickness, speed and closing burst. Young is a flexible athlete with the ability to extend his rush while engaged with offensive linemen. His hand quickness is also outstanding. While he plays with good natural bend and shows good hand-fighting ability as a pass-rusher, he's not as refined there as Nick and Joey Bosa were at the same point in their careers. There's also room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks when teams run at him. That said, Young is big and strong enough to set the edge when his technique is sound. His best fit at 4-3 DE, but he's a potential 3-4 OLB conversion candidate with some experience dropping into coverage. Simply put, Young is the most physically-gifted player in the 2020 draft class. He is a day one starter and should develop into one of the premier edge rushers in the NFL. -- March 2020 Young is the most physically gifted player in the 2020 class. He should quickly develop into one of the NFL's premier edge rushers thanks to his elite get-off ability, active hands and closing speed. There's some room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks, but he's already a good run defender with the potential to get even better. -- Steve Muench

Read: 'He was a nightmare': Opponents tell all about facing Young The Redskins have to improve a defense that finished 27th in points allowed and yards allowed per game last year. They have greater needs than adding an edge defender, and they might have entertained trades with that in mind. But taking anyone other than Young would have been a mistake. He is the most talented player in the draft and too good a value to pass on. -- Steve Muench

Read: Redskins draft Young with No. 2 pick

More: Analysis for every Redskins pick

Okudah is a long corner with smooth hips, quick feet and very good playing speed. He lines up on both sides and over the slot. Though he occasionally lunges and his footwork is a little inconsistent, he's athletic and quick enough to recover in press coverage. Okudah is tough and a willing run defender but takes too long to get off blocks and is just an average tackler. He is mature and has an elite work ethic. Okudah compares favorably to Stephon Gilmore of the New England Patriots. He has outstanding physical tools and grades out as an immediate NFL starting cornerback. -- March 2020 Okudah is a big corner with smooth hips, quick feet and good playing speed. He played receiver in high school and flashes solid ball skills. He's an average tackler who takes too long to get off blocks, but he's tough and is willing in run support. -- Steve Muench The Lions get a good value and fill a pressing need. They allowed an NFL-most 284.4 yards per game and tied for last in interceptions with seven last year. They traded their best corner in Darius Slay to Philadelphia, and Rashaan Melvin signed with Jacksonville. While they signed Desmond Trufant to a two-year deal, he didn't play at a high level in 2019 and isn't considered a No.1 like Okudah. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Lions pick

Thomas has the ideal combination of height and weight with exceptionally long arms and big hands. And he shows good quickness and overall mobility. Thomas has a quick pass-protection set with long arms to get around, and he has explosive shock in hands. His technique continues to improve. As a run blocker, he does a good job with his first step, gets his hands in place and then brings his hips and feet around. And he works hard to finish. Thomas is a durable and reliable starter who missed only one game as a three-year starter (right tackle in 2017 and left tackle in 2018 and 2019). He grades out as a Day 1 starting left tackle in the NFL, and he has the tools to continue to develop into a high-level starter. -- April 2020 Thomas has outstanding length in addition to good size, quickness and overall mobility. He's an outstanding pass-blocker with explosive shock in hands. He gets his hands in place, brings his feet and blocks to the echo of the whistle in the run game. Thomas has experience lining up on the left and right sides. -- Steve Muench The pick makes sense from a need standpoint. Left tackle Nate Solder hasn't played up to expectations in his two seasons with the Giants. Right tackle Mike Remmers signed with the Chiefs, and free agent Cameron Fleming has never been a full-time starter. The Giants have to keep quarterback Daniel Jones upright and create seams for running back Saquon Barkley. Our biggest beef with the pick is that Thomas is the No. 4 tackle on our board. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Giants pick

Tagovailoa started 24 of 29 possible games over his last two seasons and completed 70% of his throws with 76 touchdown passes and nine interceptions (a ridiculous 8.4-1 ratio). While he lacks ideal height, he has fast eyes, outstanding field vision from inside the pocket and natural instincts. His release is quick and compact, and he with good arm strength. His touch and accuracy are elite on all three levels, and he displays rare anticipation and timing. Tagovailoa has a great feel for trajectory and throws a beautiful deep ball. He is also a twitchy athlete with a very good feel for pressure, and he has above-average mobility in the pocket and good quickness to tuck the ball and run for first downs. He has excellent poise under pressure, as the moment is never too big for him, and he bounces back from mistakes. Durability is obviously the biggest concern. He was not the same quarterback late in the 2018 season when dealing with lower-leg injuries. He has had a knee injury, two ankle surgeries and a season-ending hip injury in 2019. Tagovailoa is a special talent -- very similar to a left-handed version of Drew Brees. His field vision, suddenness and natural accuracy are unique traits. Ultimately, his medical reports will decide where he is selected. -- March 2020 Tagovailoa is a left-handed quarterback with excellent field vision, accuracy and athletic ability. He has a quick, compact release and good arm strength. He shows excellent poise under pressure and the moment is never too big for him. He compares favorably to Drew Brees. -- Steve Muench

Read: Tagovailoa could determine the NFL future of the lefty QB The Dolphins traded a second-round pick for Josh Rosen last year, but he lost the starting job to 37-year-old Ryan Fitzpatrick. Neither is the long-term answer. While Miami finished 12th in passing yards per game, it finished 25th in scoring offense and 27th in total offense. The return of Fitzpatrick means the Dolphins don't have to rush Tagovailoa. Most importantly, Tagovailoa is arguably the best quarterback in this class if he's healthy. You can't pass on him if you are comfortable with the medical. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Dolphins pick

Herbert was a four-year starter at Oregon and finished his career completing 64% of his passes. He has rare size, a rocket launcher for an arm and unique pursuit-busting speed in the open field. He has a smooth and quick stroke for a long-levered quarterback with elite natural arm strength -- he makes some deep comeback throws look seamless. He also has the arm to drive the ball vertically in all conditions. But he has struggled with consistency in his ball placement on deep throws. Herbert is tough inside the pocket but lacks ideal short-area twitch and has struggled under pressure throughout his career. He also needs to continue to refine his touch on underneath throws. Herbert will be a starting quarterback early in his NFL career, and there is no denying his physical tools. Developing short touch and more efficiency under pressure will be two defining areas. -- March 2020 Herbert has rare size, a rocket launcher for an arm and can beat pursuit angles with his speed and athleticism. He has a smooth and quick stroke for a long-levered quarterback. While he has the strongest arm in this class, he has struggled with the consistency of his ball placement on deep throws and needs to continue to refine his touch on underneath throws. Herbert is tough inside the pocket and will stare down the barrel, but he has struggled under pressure throughout his career. -- Steve Muench The Chargers have to improve an offense that ranked 21st in scoring last year, and Philip Rivers is a Colt. Tyrod Taylor, 30, has been a starter for three of his nine seasons in the league, and he never has played in all 16 games of a season. Offensive coordinator Shane Steichen is a former quarterbacks coach who should be able to tailor the attack to get the most out of Herbert. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Chargers pick

Brown was a solid contributor as a true freshman in 2016 before emerging as a full-time starter for his final three seasons, when he racked up 159 tackles, 32 tackles for loss, 13 sacks and five forced fumbles. He is tall with solid bulk and long arms, and he carries his weight extremely well. Brown is a really easy mover for his size with excellent straight-line speed. He has quick and active hands but needs to learn to be more efficient with them. Sack production has been average, but he is disruptive as a pass-rusher. Disruptive, quick and active against the run, Brown does a very good job of locating the ball. He has a great motor and is a powerful tackler. Brown is a versatile defensive lineman who likely fits best as a 3-technique in a one-gap-heavy NFL scheme but is capable of moving up and down the line of scrimmage. He is a plug-and-play NFL starter. -- March 2020 Brown is an excellent run defender who tracks the ball well, chases with great effort and finishes as a tackler. He might never develop into an elite pass-rusher, but he's a developing hand fighter who is highly disruptive in that area. He's versatile enough to play on the inside in a four-man front or the outside in a three-man front. Brown has long arms and is quick with excellent top-end speed for his size. -- Steve Muench Carolina gets the No. 3 player on our board and fills a pressing need. The Panthers gave up the most yards per carry in franchise history and ranked 29th in rushing yards allowed per game. Gerald McCoy, Dontari Poe and Vernon Butler have all left. Kawann Short missed 14 games last year, and he is coming off rotator cuff surgery. Adding a dominant interior lineman also should help a linebacker corps that lost one of the best in Luke Kuechly. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Panthers pick

Simmons has elite natural talent and is one of the most versatile defenders in the 2020 draft class. He's too tight to consistently match up with typical slot receivers but has the frame and athletic ability to hold up one-on-one against most tight ends. He also has the range, natural ball skills and experience to play in deep-half coverage in the NFL. Simmons shows first-step burst, bend and closing speed in getting to the quarterback off the edge, and he excels at spying quarterbacks. He's a sideline-to-sideline run defender, and Simmons does an above-average job of slipping blocks. He has the size and length to still improve taking on blockers, but he needs to get stronger at the point of attack and his instincts as an in-the-box run defender need to improve. Simmons is still developing his recognition and take-on skills, but he's a physical freak who provides versatility as an every-down player. During his final two seasons at Clemson (2018-19), Simmons amassed 191 tackles, 25.5 tackles for loss, 9.5 sacks, four forced fumbles and four interceptions. -- March 2020 Simmons is still developing his recognition and take-on skills, but he's a physical freak and one of the most versatile defenders in this draft. He's athletic enough to match up with tight ends, is an explosive pass-rusher and excels at spying quarterbacks. His interception against Oho State in the CFB Playoff is a testament to his range and ball skills. He's a sideline-to-sideline run defender. -- Steve Muench

Read: How Simmons became the linebacker of the future

Watch: Simmons says teams will benefit from his versatility The Cardinals ranked dead last in total defense last year, and coordinator Vance Joseph should be thrilled to get one of the most talented and versatile defenders in the draft. Simmons probably will supplant Jalen Thompson and Deionte Thompson as the starting strong safety, but he could see time at linebacker depending on the matchups that week. The idea of Simmons rushing off the edge opposite Chandler Jones also is intriguing. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Cardinals pick

Henderson played in 33 games (27 starts) during his three seasons at Florida and totaled 93 tackles, 22 passes broken up and 6 interceptions (two returned for TDs). He has above-average height and weight, and shows outstanding top-end speed. He is primarily an outside cornerback who is at his best in man-to-man coverage -- press or off-man. He has easy speed on tape and doesn't have to stress to stay in stride with vertical receivers. He shows smooth hips and does a very good job of getting his head around and locating the ball vertically. And his overall ball skills are very strong. Henderson needs to get stronger -- he tries to get physical at the line of scrimmage at times but bigger and stronger receivers will push him around. He's a buffet tackler -- he picks and chooses. It's his biggest weakness. Henderson grades out as a starter early in his NFL career. -- April 2020 Henderson is a big corner with average length who is at his best in man-to-man coverage. He has outstanding timed speed and "easy speed" on tape. He doesn't have to stress to stay in stride running with receivers, and he does a great job of getting his head around to locate the ball. Henderson needs to get stronger as bigger receivers will push him around. His biggest weakness is he's a buffet tackler -- he picks and chooses when to tackle. -- Steve Muench In addition to trading Jalen Ramsey during the season last year, the Jaguars traded A.J. Bouye and his big contract to Denver. Tre Herndon and free agent Rashaan Melvin, who signed a one-year deal, aren't shutdown corners. Henderson is a good fit for defensive coordinator Todd Wash's scheme and should help the Jaguars get back to defending the pass like they did in 2018. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Jaguars pick

Wills was a three-year player and two-year starter at right tackle for Alabama. He has a good combination of height and bulk, though just average arm length and hand span. In pass pro, he has adequate quickness in his set and is a natural knee bender. He has a powerful punch and rarely gives up ground versus power rushers. Wills shows adequate agility but occasionally will overset. But his overall balance is adequate-to-good, and he's wide-bodied mauler in the run game. He takes solid angles, has natural leverage, latches on with a strong grip and is a powerful finisher. Wills excels at executing combo blocks in the run game and plays with a mean streak -- he is a nasty finisher. His lower-body explosion on tape was matched by his 9-foot-5 broad jump, which is a measurement that correlates to NFL success. He also ran a 5.05 40-yard dash at the combine. Wills grades out as a plug-and-play starter at right tackle, though he also has the potential to kick inside to guard. -- March 2020 Wills is a mauler and natural finisher with the power to move defenders in the run game. He's an easy knee-bender with a powerful punch who rarely gives ground in pass protection. He oversets at times but he has enough balance and agility to stay in front of defenders when his footwork is sound. Wills grades out as a plug-and-play starter at right tackle, but he also could kick inside to guard. -- Steve Muench The Browns get the best tackle on our board at pick 10. It will be interesting to see where Wills plays, considering they signed Jack Conklin to play right tackle, and Wills played right tackle at Alabama. The Browns aren't going to re-sign Greg Robinson, who started 22 games at left tackle over the past two seasons, so Wills could move to the left side. It's worth noting that Wills protected left-handed Tua Tagovailoa's blind side. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Browns pick

Becton, a true junior in 2019, was a three-year starter with 21 starts at left tackle and 12 starts at right tackle. He has a rare combination of size, speed and length. He has the power to move defenders off the ball in the run game. He's smooth and he erases linebackers climbing to the second level. He has heavy hands and he knocks defenders off balance when he lands his punch. He has the potential to develop into an elite pass-blocker in the NFL. He has the length and width to take the corner away from speed rushers. He has excellent size and he bends well enough to anchor. His footwork is inconsistent, and he leans at times. -- March 2020 Becton has a rare combination of size, length and speed. He has experience lining up at left and right tackle. He has the power to move down linemen off the ball and erase linebackers climbing to the second level in the run game. Becton has the frame and athletic ability to develop into an elite pass-blocker. He has heavy hands and knocks defenders off balance when he lands his punch. -- Steve Muench At pick 11, Jets general manager Joe Douglas lands the No. 2 tackle on our board and bolsters an offensive line that allowed 52 sacks last year. Becton likely will start at left tackle, though he could line up on the right side. He should help keep Sam Darnold upright and give him time to make plays. Becton also should help create seams for running back Le'Veon Bell and improve a ground game that ranked 31st in the league last year. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Jets pick

Ruggs has average size with exceptional top-end speed. He explodes off the line of scrimmage and threatens defensive backs immediately. He has elite vertical speed and burst after the catch -- he ran the fastest 40-yard dash at this year's combine (4.27) and recorded 23-plus mph on the Catapult tracking system, the fastest since Alabama started using the technology. He is not afraid to work the middle of the field and shows good savvy (locating soft spots in zone and setting defensive backs up at the top of his stem). Ruggs also shows crispness getting in and out of breaks, but his lack of size affects him at the top of his stem and when attempting to gain late separation, such as when the ball is in the air. He will need to develop his ability to get off of press coverage. Ruggs displays outstanding ball skills within his frame (just one dropped pass in 2019 and just four in three seasons). He confidently plucks and transitions up the field. But he does not have a big catch radius and is inconsistent when it comes to adjusting to off-target throws. Ruggs is still developing as a route runner but has elite speed as a vertical weapon and after the catch. He's an alpha dog with surprising strength and toughness, which is seen in his blocking and kick coverage. Finally, he has the tools to win a starting kick return job as a rookie. Ruggs is one of the top four wide receivers in the 2020 class and will come off the board in Round 1. -- March 2020 Ruggs is still developing as a route runner but he has the elite speed to pull away after the catch and threaten vertically. He confidently plucks the ball out of the air and is smooth transitioning upfield. He's an alpha dog with surprising strength and toughness that shows up in his blocking and how he covers kicks. Ruggs has the tools to win a starting return job as a rookie. -- Steve Muench The Antonio Brown trade backfired, and Tyrell Williams was slowed by a foot injury last year. The Raiders signed Nelson Agholor but needed to do more considering that no receiver caught more than 50 passes last year. Coach Jon Gruden is all too familiar with how elite speed can change the complexion of a game after seeing Chiefs receiver Tyreek Hill the past two seasons. Ruggs has the potential to make a similar kind of impact. He's that explosive. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Raiders pick

Wirfs started 33 games at right tackle for Iowa. He missed only one game during his three seasons. He is tall and long, and he has rare athletic tools -- his combine workout was exceptional. In pass protection, he allowed only two sacks the past two seasons. He has adequate length with outstanding quickness and natural mobility. He has a powerful punch, is athletic enough to mirror when he wins with his hands and has sound footwork, though he oversets and loses inside-outside leverage at times. As a run-blocker, Wirfs fits best in a zone scheme. He moves well laterally and has elite range and mobility as a second-level blocker. He needs to improve his angles and play with better balance in the run game. He's not a mauler or consistent finisher. Wirfs has elite potential but is still a work in progress as a player. He is just 20 years old and is still developing but has exceptional physical tools. He should quickly develop into an adequate starter at tackle (or possibly even guard), but it might take him two or three seasons to maximize his potential. -- March 2020 Wirfs isn't a finished product, but he has elite potential. He has great size, rare athletic tools and good length. His footwork is inconsistent yet he rarely loses in pass protection and has the potential to develop into an elite pass-blocker. He shows good lateral mobility and range in the run game. He fits better in a zone-heavy scheme than he does in a power-heavy scheme. -- Steve Muench

Read: Wirfs ready to create 'holy crap' moments in NFL The run on offensive tackles continues, and the Buccaneers get one to help protect their 42-year-old future Hall of Fame quarterback, Tom Brady. Tampa Bay surrendered the 11th-most sacks in the league last year. Wirfs also should improve a run offense that ranked 24th in the league. He projects as the starting right tackle, with 35-year old right tackle Demar Dotson unsigned. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Bucs pick

During his three seasons at South Carolina (he transferred in from junior college), Kinlaw played in 37 of 38 games and totaled 93 tackles, 18 tackles for loss and 10.5 sacks. He is a physical specimen. He carries his weight beautifully, and he's a twitchy athlete with very good speed for his size. He has elite physical traits to develop as a pass-rusher. There is some inconsistency with snap anticipation, but he has a quick first step, he shows good initial power to jar linemen and he has quick hands to disengage. Kinlaw also displays good change-of-direction skills and a solid motor as a pass-rusher. However, he needs to do a better job of transferring speed-to-power effectiveness and needs to develop some better counter moves. Kinlaw possesses a powerful upper body to lock out as a run defender, and he has very good range as a run defender. Because he is very tall, he struggles to keep leverage while engaged, and will struggle to anchor when his pad level gets too high. Kinlaw fits best in a one-gap heavy scheme. He is at his best when active as a run defender, and he has upside as a pass-rusher. Keeping his weight in check and continuing to improve his counter moves will be important to his NFL development. Kinlaw is a plug-and-play NFL starter with upside. -- March 2020 Kinlaw has excellent size, long arms and carries his weight exceptionally well. He has the potential to develop into an elite interior pass-rusher. He has a quick first step, jars offensive linemen on contact and has the quick hands to get off blocks. Kinlaw has the upper-body strength to lock out and does a good job of locating the ball as run defender. He is tall for an interior defensive lineman and has some problems anchoring when his pads rise. -- Steve Muench

Read: From homeless to top draft prospect: Kinlaw's journey San Francisco had the top pass defense, second-best total defense and eighth-ranked scoring defense in the league last year. If the 49ers were going to go defense, taking a corner seemed more likely. But outstanding effort up front played a big role in the Super Bowl run last year, and the 49ers traded DeForest Buckner to the Colts. Kinlaw has the talent to fill the considerable hole Buckner leaves behind. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every 49ers pick

Jeudy has solid height with a somewhat lean frame but very good initial burst and top-end speed. His initial quickness gives cornerbacks a lot of problems. He's an exceptional route runner, and he is as smooth and polished as any college WR we've evaluated in 20 years. Jeudy exposes defensive backs with his savvy and hip flexibility at the top of stems. He has a great feel for locating soft spots in zone coverage and working back to his QB on scramble-drill situations. He shows soft hands and naturally tracks the ball vertically. Jeudy displays very good body control and shows the ability to adjust to balls outside his frame. But he does have some concentration drops and will body-catch at times. He brings outstanding football intelligence, too. Jeudy is a premier wide receiver prospect. -- March 2020 Jeudy is as smooth and polished of a route runner as any receiver we've evaluated in 20 years. He exposes defensive backs with his savvy, has a great feel for locating soft spots in zone and gets open on quarterback scramble-drill situations. He tracks the ball well and has the top-end speed to threaten vertically. Jeudy has soft hands and the body control to adjust to passes thrown outside his frame. -- Steve Muench

Read: How Jeudy overcame tragedy to become an elite NFL prospect Courtland Sutton is a star, but Denver needs to give second-year quarterback Drew Lock more weapons if the Broncos are to improve a passing offense that ranked 28th last year and get back into the playoffs. Jeudy's ability to get open underneath makes him an outstanding complement to Sutton's size and capacity to make plays downfield. Second-year tight end Noah Fant also should benefit from Jeudy helping to open up the offense. -- Steve Muench


More: Analysis for every Broncos pick

Terrell, a true junior in 2019, was a two-year starter who intercepted five passes over the past two seasons. He's an effective press corner with the frame, smooth hips and speed to compete on the outside. However, he's lean and he gets muscled off routes at times, and he gets beaten over the top despite that top-end speed. He flashes good burst transitioning out of breaks and closes quickly breaking on underneath routes. He flashes the ability to snatch the ball out of the air. He's late locating the ball at times, and he has slightly below-average length despite his frame. He's a willing run defender but an inconsistent tackler. -- March 2020 Terrell is an effective press corner with the frame, smooth hips and speed to compete on the outside. He closes quickly breaking on underneath routes. He's an inconsistent tackler. Terrell is lean and he gets muscled off routes at times. His tape is erratic -- he gets beat over the top despite that top-end speed. -- Steve Muench Atlanta made Desmond Trufant a cap casualty, and there are more questions than answers when it comes to the corner position. This is early for Terrell, and the Falcons could have done a better job of filling this need. But Terrell is a good fit for coach Dan Quinn's press-zone scheme, and he has the physical tools to grow into an effective No. 1 for Atlanta in time. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Falcons pick

Lamb has good height and solid bulk to go with his average hand span. He has above-average top-end speed, and his 10-yard split time of 1.46 seconds is exceptional. Lamb is a highly refined route runner. He knows how to get off the press, he knows how to leverage his stems, he knows how to set DBs up in man-to-man coverage and he is highly adept at locating soft spots in zone. He also shows very good ball skills, especially on contested catches, and is strong in traffic. But he really excels after the catch. He isn't the fastest receiver but has outstanding body control and stop-start ability. He is highly instinctive with the ball in his hands and breaks a lot of tackles. Vertically, Lamb tracks the ball well and is fast enough. He grades out as potential No. 1 receiver in the NFL. DeAndre Hopkins is a solid NFL comp. -- March 2020 Lamb is a refined route runner who knows how to get off press coverage, leverage his stems and set up defensive backs. He has outstanding body control and strong hands that helps him come down with contested catches. He excels after the catch. Lamb isn't the fastest receiver, but he's an instinctive open-field runner with the stop-start ability to make defenders miss and the strength to break initial contact. -- Steve Muench This pick doesn't fill a pressing need with Amari Copper re-signing and Michael Gallup coming off a breakout year. Need is overrated. Lamb is an outstanding value at this point, and adding his kind of talent is never a bad idea. He gives quarterback Dak Prescott and offensive coordinator Kellen Moore a potent No. 3 receiver who makes it tough to load the box to slow down running back Ezekiel Elliott. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Cowboys pick

Jackson, a true junior in 2019, was a two-year starter at left tackle. He gets off the ball and flashes the ability to move defenders in the run game. He flashes a violent punch. He has the potential to develop into an above-average pass-blocker. He's quick and long enough to handle speed off the edge. He does an above-average job of resetting his hands and recovering. He gives ground when he doesn't win with his hands initially. He oversets and gets beaten to the inside at times. The 2019 Notre Dame tape shows the good and the bad in pass pro. -- March 2020 Jackson gets off the ball and flashes the ability to move defenders in the run game. He has a violent punch and has the potential to develop into a good pass-blocker. He's quick and long enough to handle speed off the edge. He does an above-average job of resetting his hands and recovering. Jackson is inconsistent, however, and the 2019 Notre Dame tape shows the good and the bad in pass protection. -- Steve Muench Miami averaged a team-record low of 72.3 rushing yards per game and tied for last in the league in sacks allowed last year. Ideally, Jackson fills the void created by trading Laremy Tunsil to Houston last year. His tape is inconsistent, and he is a bit of a reach here. But there has been a run on offensive tackles, and Jackson has the tools to develop into a franchise left tackle by the time quarterback Tua Tagovailoa takes over as the starter. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Dolphins pick

Arnette has good size and above-average top-end speed. He is a naturally athletic CB with smooth hips and solid twitch. And he is physical in coverage, at his best in press-man. However, his instincts are inconsistent, and his ball skills are just average. A physical run defender and strong tackler, Arnette has some pop for his size and shies away from nothing. He needs to mature and prove that he's capable of handling himself as a pro, but from a physical tools standpoint, he's capable of developing into a No. 2 or No. 3 starting cornerback in the NFL. -- March 2020 Arnette has good size and slightly above-average top-end speed with smooth hips and good twitch. He's physical and is at his best in press-man coverage, but his instincts are inconsistent and he gets grabby when he's unsure. Arnette is an excellent run defender and strong tackler who flashes above-average stopping power and shies away from nothing. -- Steve Muench The Raiders ranked 25th in passing defense, and Daryl Worley is unsigned, creating a vacancy opposite Trayvon Mullen, who started 10 games as a rookie last year. The Raiders thought they had signed free-agent corner Eli Apple, but the deal fell through; they still could have taken a corner had they signed Apple. Again, the pick makes sense from a need standpoint, but we have a second-round grade on Arnette. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Raiders pick

Chaisson recorded 4.5 of his 6.5 sacks in 2019 during the last four games (when he was finally fully healthy). His best tape of the season was in the College Football Playoff semifinal against Oklahoma, with a season-high six tackles and two sacks. Chaisson has average height and adequate length. And he has excellent lower-body thickness for his size. He shows outstanding first-step quickness off the edge, good top-end speed and the ability to bend around the edge. But there is also shock in his hands as a pass-rusher, though he still has a lot of work to do with his hand-to-hand combat. Chaisson is much more powerful than he looks, and he sets a hard edge for his size while displaying upper-body strength to control blockers. He has explosive qualities as an edge rusher and is much more powerful versus the run than his frame might indicate. If he can kick the injury bug, Chaisson has the tools to quickly develop into an impact edge rusher in the NFL. -- March 2020 Chaisson has outstanding first-step quickness, great bend and good top-end speed. He has some shock in his hands but still has plenty of room for improvement when it comes to hand-to-hand combat rushing the passer. He's much more powerful than he looks, and he sets the edge against the run. Chaisson has the upper-body strength to control blockers and chases plays with good effort. -- Steve Muench Jacksonville placed the franchise tag on Yannick Ngakoue, but he has made it clear that he wants to be traded, and the Jaguars are looking to accommodate him. 2019 first-round pick Josh Allen led all rookies with 10.5 sacks last year. Adding Chaisson gives the Jaguars two young edge rushers to complement one another and helps ensure the pass rush stays potent with Ngakoue expected to move on. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Jaguars pick

Reagor, a true junior in 2019, was a two-year starter who broke out in 2018, catching 72 passes for 1,061 yards (14.7 yards per catch) and nine touchdowns. He played with a freshman quarterback and his production dropped significantly in 2019. He finished his college career with 35 carries for 324 yards (9.3 yards per carry) and two touchdowns. He averaged 20.8 yards per punt return and returned two punts for touchdowns in 2019. He's quick, makes defenders miss and has the contact balance to break tackles after the catch. He lacks the frame to regularly win 50-50 balls downfield, but he has the deep speed to threaten vertically. He has the natural ability to develop above-average separation skills, although he has room to grow as a route runner. He flashes the ability to exploit soft spots in zone looks. His hands are inconsistent. Ball security has been issue at times. -- March 2020 Reagor is a small receiver with short arms and good top-end speed. He's quick, makes defenders miss and has the contact balance to break tackles after the catch. He lacks the frame to regularly win 50-50 balls downfield but has the deep speed to threaten vertically. -- Steve Muench

Watch: Reagor has the most drip in the draft The Eagles' top two pass-catchers last year were their tight ends. Alshon Jeffery, 30, hasn't produced like a No. 1 wide receiver, and he is out until at least August after undergoing Lisfranc surgery. DeSean Jackson, 33, missed 13 games with a core injury, and Nelson Agholor signed with Oakland. Adding a young playmaker to help quarterback Carson Wentz was a must, and Reagor fits the bill. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Eagles pick

Jefferson, a true junior in 2019, was a two-year starter who was one of the most productive FBS receivers in the country last season. He tied for first in receptions, ranked second in receiving touchdowns and ranked third in receiving yards. He's a natural hands catcher with excellent length and above-average body control. There's some concern about his ability to separate on the outside, but he's an instinctive route runner with good quickness and the awareness to locate pockets in zone looks when he's given a two-way go working out of the slot. He's tough and willing to do the dirty work over the middle. He catches the ball in stride and has above-average burst after the catch. He flashes the ability to make the first defender miss and pick up yards after initial contact. He has the top-end speed to threaten vertically. -- March 2020 Jefferson is a natural hands catcher with excellent length and good body control. He catches the ball in stride and has above-average burst after the catch. He ran better than expected at the combine, and he has the speed to threaten vertically. There's some concern about Jefferson's ability to separate on the outside, but he's an instinctive route runner with the quickness to separate working out of the slot. -- Steve Muench Minnesota traded Stefon Diggs to Buffalo, and Adam Thielen is coming off a season in which he was hampered by a hamstring injury. Tight end Irv Smith Jr., a 2019 second-round pick, flashed last year and should be better this year. But the Vikings needed another difference-making pass-catcher. It will be interesting to see how offensive coordinator Gary Kubiak deploys Thielen and Jefferson, considering they are both at their best working out of the slot. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Vikings pick

Murray, a true junior in 2019, was a three-year starter. He's a rangy inside linebacker with excellent closing speed. He has the burst to disrupt plays in the backfield. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. He has above-average stopping power. He's tight in space and lacks ideal man-to-man cover skills. There's room for improvement when it comes to winning with his hands and fleshing out moves, but he flashes promise as a pass-rusher and he has good upside in this area. He's effective spying quarterbacks. He's a natural leader with a professional work ethic. -- March 2020 Murray is a rangy inside linebacker with excellent closing speed and good stopping power. He has the burst to shoot gaps and disrupt plays in the backfield. There's room for improvement when it comes to winning with his hands, but he flashes as a pass-rusher and is effective at spying quarterbacks. Murray is a natural leader with a professional work ethic. -- Steve Muench The Chargers released Thomas Davis, who led the team in tackles last year, and Denzel Perryman is in a contract year. Murray projects as a plug-and-play starter with the ability to help improve a run defense that finished 18th last year. Plus, the Chargers are building a young and talented defense after drafting a defensive player in the first round in four of the past five drafts. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Chargers pick

Ruiz started five games at guard as a freshman and then 26 consecutive games at center over the past two seasons. He has good height and bulk, and he has longer arms for an interior offensive lineman and massive hands. Ruiz moves very well and made huge improvements in pass protection during the past two seasons. He has very good balance and doesn't fall off many blocks. Ruiz is one of the top-three interior offensive linemen in the 2020 draft class and a plug-and-play starter in the NFL. -- April 2020 Ruiz is a well-built center with longer arms and massive hands. He has very good balance and rarely falls off blocks. He has made huge improvements and developed into an outstanding pass-blocker over the past two seasons. He projects as a plug-and-play starting center but also started five games at guard as a freshman and is versatile enough to play there in the NFL. -- Steve Muench This is one of the more surprising picks based on what we know. The Saints traded up to get center Erik McCoy in the second round last year, and he started 16 games. Guards Andrus Peat and Larry Warford both went to the Pro Bowl. Warford is entering a contract year, so the Saints could see Ruiz as his future replacement. Ruiz is good player, but this remains a curious pick. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Saints pick

Aiyuk is a junior college transfer coming off a breakout senior season. He tracks the ball well and is fast enough to threaten vertically. He makes defenders miss and breaks tackles after the catch. He's an above-average route runner with good burst. He has the occasional drop, but he has very good body control. He flashes the ability to pluck the ball out of the air. He's got an outstanding catching radius for his frame and the position. A groin injury prevented him from participating at the Senior Bowl. -- March 2020 Aiyuk is an above-average route runner with the burst to separate from man-to-man coverge, and he's dangerous after the catch. He's on the shorter side and his hands are a little inconsistent, but he has an outstanding catch radius for his frame, in addition to great body control. Aiyuk tracks the ball well and is fast enough to threaten vertically. He has the skill set to make an immediate impact in the return game, too. -- Steve Muench George Kittle is one of the best tight ends in the league. Deebo Samuel is a promising talent. And it's not clear what the 49ers have in 2019 third-round pick Jalen Hurd, who finished the year on injured reserve. So San Francisco has some talented pass-catchers. But Emmanuel Sanders' signing with the Saints creates a need at wide receiver, and Aiyuk projects as a rookie starter. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every 49ers pick

Love is a redshirt junior who started 32 games at Utah State. He has good size, a strong arm, above-average mobility and big hands. His touchdown-to-interception rate went from 32-to-6 in 2018 to 20-to-17 in 2019. He takes unnecessary chances, and there's room for improvement when it comes to reading the coverage. His overall decision-making needs to be more consistent. Inconsistent footwork leads to some missed throws. That said, he has a very high ceiling and flashes outstanding potential on tape. He creates and throws off platform as well as anyone in this class. He can drop his arm angle and adjust his release point to avoid pressure. And he has the arm strength to throw into tight windows. Love shows excellent touch on fades and lofting the ball over oncoming pass-rushers. He shows the ability to go through progressions and hit checkdowns given time. He shows above-average pocket presence and mobility. Plus, while not an explosive open-field runner, Love is capable of scrambling for first downs. It's also worth noting that he played under a new coaching staff in 2019, and there were nine new starters on offense. Love is a bit of a boom-or-bust prospect, but he grades out as one of the top quarterbacks in this class. -- April 2020 Love has good size, a strong arm, above-average mobility and big hands. His touchdown-to-interception went from 32-to-6 in 2018 to 20-to-17 in 2019, and his overall decision-making needs to be more consistent. He throws off platform as well as anyone in this class, he can adjust his release point to avoid pressure and he shows excellent touch. -- Steve Muench

Read: Love and the mystery of drafting a quarterback This is a controversial pick. On one hand, Love will turn into an absolute steal if he reaches his considerable upside. Aaron Rodgers is 36, and last year he had his lowest passer rating since 2015. On the other hand, Rodgers was playing for a new coach, he needs more weapons to complement Davante Adams and his window to win a Super Bowl is closing. So there's an argument for building for this year. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Packers pick

Brooks, a team captain in 2019 and a four-year starter, has good size, good length and above-average top-end speed. He's versatile enough to line up on the inside or the outside in a base four-man front. He's a rangy run defender with above-average closing speed. He has the burst to shoot gaps and had 20 tackles for loss in 2019. He's a powerful wrap-up tackler with the length and body control to make plays in space. He reads the quarterback and shows good range in underneath coverage. He flashes chops as a pass-rusher. -- April 2020 Brooks is versatile enough to line up on the inside or the outside in a base four-man front. He's a rangy run defender with good closing speed. He has the burst to shoot gaps and he had 20 tackles for loss in 2019. He's a powerful wrap-up tackler with the length and body control to make plays in space. Brooks reads the quarterback and shows good range in underneath coverage. -- Steve Muench The once-vaunted Seattle defense ranked 22nd in points allowed per game and 26th in total defense last year. The Seahawks could have addressed the defensive line, but there is a need at linebacker. Mychal Kendricks tore an ACL in the playoffs, and he is unsigned. Adding Brooks to complement Bobby Wagner and K.J. Wright potentially gives Seattle one of the best linebacker corps in the league. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Seahawks pick

Queen is an undersized, off-the-ball linebacker with excellent quickness, burst and lower-body explosion. He has great range in coverage, quick feet, fluid hips and quick redirection skills. And he shows very good recognition skills in coverage. An underrated blitzer, Queen has natural instincts, great burst and underrated power to knock offensive linemen back on their heels. In the run game, he diagnoses quickly and decisively fires through gaps. He shows outstanding closing burst to the ball carrier and is a lot more powerful as a tackler than his size indicates. His biggest weakness is when he gets isolated by bigger blockers in a short area. Queen is a plug-and-play starter as an off-the-ball linebacker in the NFL. He is the definition of an every-down linebacker in today's league. -- March 2020 Queen is an undersized three-down linebacker with good range and cover skills. He's an underrated pass-rusher and an instinctive run defender who locates the ball and closes quickly. He has decent stopping power for his size. Queen is a tempo-setter who brings great energy and played his best in LSU's biggest games. -- Steve Muench Inside linebackers Patrick Onwuasor and Josh Bynes left in free agency, so the Ravens fill arguably their most pressing need and get the top inside linebacker on our board. Queen projects as a Day 1 starter. He is an underrated pass-rusher who could help a rush that ranked 21st last year. As good as the Ravens' defense was, it could be even better after adding Queen and trading for defensive end Calais Campbell. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Ravens pick

Wilson is a massive right tackle with long arms and big hands. He is a natural knee bender with surprising flexibility and mobility for such a tall and massive lineman. He is strong at the point of attack and won't give up much ground if balanced, but he needs to improve his footwork and hand placement as both a run blocker and pass blocker. Wilson can be overpowering as a finisher in the run game, but angles, hands and footwork must continue to improve. He is loaded with potential and has solid football intelligence but needs a lot of refining. He has the tools to develop into a solid starting tackle in the NFL. -- April 2020 Wilson is a massive right tackle with excellent length and big hands. He's a natural knee-bender who is tough to beat around the corner and flashes an above-average mirror in pass protection. He has the potential to develop into an overpowering run blocker. He hasn't realized his considerable potential yet. Wilson needs to improve his footwork and hand placement as both a run-blocker and pass-blocker. -- Steve Muench Tennessee declined the option on right tackle Jack Conklin, who signed with Cleveland. The Titans re-signed swing tackle Dennis Kelly, but bringing in competition for the starting spot opposite left tackle Taylor Lewan makes sense. Wilson's ability to overpower defenders in the running game makes him a good fit for a Tennessee offense that ranked third in rushing yards per game last year. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Titans pick

Igbinoghene brings good size with average arm length and above-average top-end speed. He is a tough press-man corner at the line of scrimmage and does a good job of rerouting wide receivers. Igbinoghene is better in man than zone coverage and excels in reading receivers in their routes. He does struggle to locate the ball, and he is frequently late and loses track of his leverage. And while he is a former wide receiver with adequate ball skills, he did not intercept a pass in 26 starts at the cornerback position. Igbinoghene is aggressive against the run and a solid tackler in space. He is a likely No. 3 or No. 4 CB as a rookie and has the potential to develop into a No. 2 starter. -- March 2020 Igbinoghene has good size, decent length and great top-end speed. He's a tough press-man corner who does a good job of rerouting wide receivers. He's better in man coverage than he is in zone, and he failed to intercept a pass in 26 starts at corner even though he's a former receiver. He is a solid tackler and aggressive run-defender. -- Steve Muench The Dolphins have a talented corner tandem in Xavien Howard, who is the third-highest-paid corner in the league, and free-agent signee Byron Jones, who is the second-highest paid. Igbinoghene could push Nik Needham for the No. 3 spot, and he is good insurance for Howard, who missed 11 games with a knee injury last year. That said, Miami needs playmakers, and Igbinoghene picked off one pass over the past two seasons. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Dolphins pick

Gladney, a redshirt senior in 2019, was a four-year starter who finished his career with 146 tackles, 43 pass deflections and five interceptions. He has above-average short-area man-to-man cover skills. He lacks ideal size and bigger receivers give him problems, but he's tough with good length. He does a good job of reading the quarterback and playing the ball not the man in zone. He has good timing breaking up passes and he's opportunistic, but he's not a natural playmaker or hands catcher. He's versatile enough to line up on the outside and the inside. A sore knee prevented him from going to the Senior Bowl. -- March 2020 Gladney is undersized with good length and good top-end speed. He has above-average short-area man-to-man cover skills. Bigger receivers give him problems at times, but he's tough and he plays bigger than his size. Gladney does a good job of reading the quarterback and playing the ball, not the man, in zone coverage. He has good timing breaking up passes and is opportunistic but is not a natural playmaker. -- Steve Muench The Vikings probably aren't done addressing the corner position, considering that Trae Waynes, Xavier Rhodes and Mackensie Alexander have all departed. In addition, 2018 first-round pick Mike Hughes has landed on injured reserve in each of his first two seasons. Gladney is a little bit of a reach here, but he is the fourth-ranked corner on our board, and four corners had already been drafted. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Vikings pick

Edwards-Helaire started all 15 games in 2019, averaging 6.6 yards per carry and catching 55 passes. He is built low to the ground with a thick lower body. He lacks ideal top-end speed, but he's quicker than fast. Edwards-Helaire has excellent contact balance and is a great finisher. He has a very good center of gravity and quick feet. He starts and stops on a dime and possesses very good lateral agility. He makes defenders miss in small spaces, covers the ball up in traffic and does an excellent job with ball security. Edwards-Helaire is an instinctive runner with good patience. In the passing game, he is a very good route runner and reliable pass catcher. He gives decent effort in pass protection but has room to improve in this area. Additionally, he is a very good kick returner and could win a starting kick return job in the NFL. Edwards-Helaire compares favorably to Darren Sproles. He's a three-down starter in the NFL. -- April 2020 Edwards-Helaire is an instinctive back who is built low to the ground and has a thick lower body. He's a great finisher with excellent contact balance. He has below-average top-end speed but is quicker than fast and makes defenders miss with ease. Edwards-Helaire is a good route runner and reliable receiver. There's room for improvement when it comes to pass protection, however. -- Steve Muench The rich get richer. Kansas City didn't have a back rush for more than 500 yards last year, and LeSean McCoy isn't expected back, so the Chiefs figured to take a back at some point. There's an argument for selecting Georgia's D'Andre Swift over Edwards-Helaire, but Edwards-Helaire is an excellent fit for the Chiefs' high-octane offense. He represents an upgrade over Damien Williams. -- Steve Muench

More: Analysis for every Chiefs pick

Higgins, a true junior in 2019, finished his three-year career with 27 receiving touchdowns, tying DeAndre Hopkins and Sammy Watkins for the school record. He lines up on the outside and the inside. He's a big target with good body control and an outstanding catching radius. He's an above-average vertical route runner with good but not great top-end speed. He sits and boxes out defenders when working against zone looks, and he flashes some savviness as a route runner. He doesn't show great burst getting out of breaks. He's more of a threat downfield than he is after the catch. He drops some balls that he gets his hands on. -- March 2020 Higgins is a big target with good body control and an outstanding catching radius. He averaged 18.1 yards per catch at Clemson and is a good vertical route runner with decent playing speed. He flashes some savviness but is not an explosive route runner. Higgins is more of a threat downfield than he is after the catch. He's versatile enough to play both outside and inside. -- Steve Muench A.J. Green turns 32 years old in July, and he missed the 2019 season with an ankle injury and 29 games over the past four years. John Ross III made strides last season but he's more of an explosive No. 3 than a No. 2 receiver. Higgins would be a good long-term complement to Tyler Boyd and he would fit well with first-round pick Joe Burrow, who isn't afraid to give his receivers a chance to go up and win 50-50 balls. -- Steve Muench

Pittman, a team captain in 2019, is a sure-handed receiver with good body control. There is room for improvement when it comes to winning 50-50 balls. He gets north-south and flashes deceptive initial burst after the catch. He picks up yards after initial contact. He doesn't have an elite second gear but he's fast enough to threaten vertically. He does a good job of adjusting to back-shoulder throws. He locates windows in zone looks. He's not an explosive route runner. He has been effective covering kicks and he has flashed as a punt returner. His father, Michael, played running back for 11 seasons in the NFL and won a Super Bowl with Tampa Bay. -- March 2020 Pittman Jr. is a sure-handed receiver with excellent size and average top-end speed. He gets north/south and flashes deceptive burst after the catch. He's tough and picks up yards after initial contact. Pittman doesn't have an elite second gear, but he's fast enough to threaten vertically and does a good job of adjusting to back shoulder throws. He's not an explosive route runner. -- Steve Muench Philip Rivers thrived with some big-bodied wide receiver options with the Chargers, and Pittman, at 6-4, 224 pounds, offers him a sure-handed one in Indy. Colts wide receivers ranked 28th in receptions in 2019 (150) and 30th in receiving yards (1,841) last season. T.Y. Hilton and Zach Pascal were the only Colts WRs with at least 20 receptions last season, and -- feeling old? -- Hilton already is north of 30 years old. Pittman will be in the mix in Week 1. -- Chris Sprow

Swift has adequate height and is well-built with outstanding top-end speed. He pops off the field with an explosive initial burst. He's a better outside runner than inside runner but has solid vision and the ability to explode through the hole. He really excels as an outside zone runner -- he can stick his foot in the dirt and explode upfield. In the pass game, he is a solid route runner and shows soft hands. And he is tough and smart in pass protection. Swift is the best back in the 2020 class. -- April 2020 Swift is an explosive back with excellent burst through the hole and outstanding top-end speed. He's at his best getting outside, excelling as an outside zone runner, but he's also effective between the tackles thanks to his vision and speed. Swift is a complete back. He's a solid route runner with soft hands and the ability to threaten after the catch. He's tough and smart in pass protection. -- Steve Muench Kerryon Johnson underwent knee surgery and missed six games in 2019. Johnson also missed the final six games of the 2018 season with a knee injury. Swift is a versatile back who should help improve a run offense that finished 21st in the league and give quarterback Matt Stafford a valuable target.
