As the top back and 18th-ranked player on our board, he's an outstanding value at this point in the draft. -- Steve Muench

McKinney's versatility is his best trait. He allows his defense to be so multiple because of his ability to play two-high, single-high, in-the-box and as the overhang (slot). He has great natural instincts in both phases of the game, diagnosing quickly, taking great angles and making plays when around the ball. What stands out on tape is his prowess in off-coverage. He does a great job of reading the QB's eyes, staying in balance and then exploding forward with elite closing burst. McKinney fills hard in the run game and is a big hitter for his size. He is also an underrated pass-rusher when turned loose off the edge (six sacks in the past two seasons). McKinney is the most talented safety in the 2020 class. His versatility, instincts and force as a tackler are what stand out most on tape. McKinney grades out as a plug-and-play NFL starter. -- March 2020 McKinney is the most talented safety in the 2020 class. His versatility, instincts and force as a tackler are what stand out most when you throw on his tape. He can play two-high, single-high, in-the-box and as the overhang (over the slot). McKinney diagnoses quickly, excels in off coverage and is a playmaker. He fills hard in the run game and is a big hitter for his size. -- Steve Muench With veteran Antoine Bethea moving on and converted corner Julian Love shifting to the safety spot, McKinney can compete to start on day one in the Giants' secondary. With multidimensional traits, McKinney is a fit for the new Giants defensive scheme in the Patrick Chung role. -- Matt Bowen

Dugger, a four-year starter, won the Cliff Harris Award given to the best Division II, Division III and NAIA defensive player. He averaged 13.9 yards per punt return and returned six punts for touchdowns at Lenoir-Rhyne. He's a big safety with above-average range, and he's a physical presence over the middle. He has the speed to run with tight ends and most slot receivers. He's a playmaker with huge hands and above-average length. He's dangerous with the ball in his hands. He has above-average stopping power. He was a sixth-year senior who turned 24 in March. -- March 2020 Dugger has an excellent blend of speed, length, size and hand span. He covers a lot of ground and has the tools to match up with tight ends in coverage. He's a playmaker who picked off 10 passes and returned six punts for touchdowns in college. He's a good tackler with great stopping power. -- Steve Muench Devin McCourty and Patrick Chung return but they both turn 33 in August. While New England signed Adrian Phillips, he has never been a full-time starter, and the Patriots traded Duron Harmon to the Lions. They also frequently play three safeties at once and value players who can create turnovers like Dugger, who was a playmaker in college. He should also compete for the job of returning punts. -- Steve Muench

Gross-Matos, a true junior in 2019, was a two-year starter who recorded 94 tackles, 35 tackles for loss, 17.5 sacks, two forced fumbles and one fumble recovery over the past two seasons. He's an effective hand fighter with above-average length. He has above-average lateral mobility and he does a good job of falling back inside once he's even with the quarterback. He's a problem for offensive guards when he kicks inside. He rarely overwhelms blockers with speed to power. He has the length, size and strength to set the edge against the run. He needs to play with better pad level at times. He locates and tracks the ball well. He chases with good effort and closes well in pursuit. -- March 2020 Gross-Matos is an effective hand fighter with excellent length who does a good job of falling back inside when he's even with the quarterback. He's a problem for offensive guards when he kicks inside to rush the passer. He has the size and strength to set the edge against the run. Gross-Matos needs to play with better pad level at times. He chases with good effort and closes well in pursuit. -- Steve Muench The good: Carolina had seven players with more than 3.0 sacks last season. Yikes: Only one of those players is back in 2020. So when you allow a disastrous 29.4 PPG in 2019, you get to work on that D-line, and the Panthers now have one immediate starter on the inside in No. 7 overall pick Derrick Brown and a true pass-rusher in Gross-Matos. Matt Rhule has no interest in Teddy Bridgewater carrying a crummy D, and it shows. -- Chris Sprow

Hunt, a four-year starter, started 21 games at right tackle, 22 games at left guard and two games at left tackle. He's smooth getting set and flashes violent hands in pass pro. He anchors well. He has good body control and balance for his size. He has shorter arms for an offensive tackle and he projects better at guard. He plays with an edge and flashes the ability to overwhelm defenders in the run game. He missed five games with a groin injury in 2019 and did not work out at the combine. He played basketball in high school and averaged 18.9 points and 11 rebounds per game as a junior. -- April 2020 Hunt is a four-year starter who started 22 games at left guard, 21 games at right tackle and two games at left tackle. He's smooth getting set, and he flashes powerful hands in pass pro. He plays with an edge and shows the ability to overwhelm defenders in the run game. He has shorter arms for an offensive tackle, and he projects better at guard than tackle. -- Steve Muench The Dolphins continue to address the offensive line and an offense that ranked 25th in scoring last season. Hunt likely will get a chance to win the starting tackle spot opposite first-round pick Austin Jackson and he could develop into an effective starter there even though we think his best fit is at guard. The worst-case scenario is that the Dolphins kick Hunt inside and get an above-average starting guard. -- Steve Muench

Blacklock missed the 2018 season with an Achilles tendon injury. He rebounded to start all 12 games in 2019 as a redshirt junior and finished with 40 tackles, nine tackles for loss and 3.5 sacks. He has the size and strength to stack and shed blockers one-on-one. He does an above-average job of splitting double-teams. He's got the quick hands and feet to slip blocks and disrupt plays in the backfield. He's much more of a threat to get to the quarterback than sack production -- 5.5 sacks in 26 games -- would suggest, and he has the potential to develop into a productive interior pass-rusher in the NFL. He has above-average quickness, lower-body flexibility and closing burst. There's room to improve when it comes to counter moves. He's a hard worker who reportedly lost 25 pounds while he was out with the Achilles injury. -- March 2020 Blacklock is a taller, leaner defensive tackle with below-average length and solid top-end speed. He's an outstanding run defender with the strength to stack and shed blockers one-on-one in addition to the quick hands and feet to disrupt plays in the backfield. Blacklock is more of a threat to get to the quarterback than his sack numbers would suggest, and he has the potential to develop into a productive interior pass-rusher at the next level. -- Steve Muench Blacklock fills a need on the Texans' defensive front after they lost D.J. Reader in free agency. In 2019, Houston allowed 3.2 yards per rush before first contact, third worst in the league. Blacklock has the athletic traits, technique and lateral movement skills to develop into an interior disruptor in the NFL with pass-rush upside. -- Matt Bowen

Taylor is the only player in FBS history to rush for more than 1,900 yards in three consecutive seasons. He is a tightly-packed RB with a great combination of height, bulk, quickness and top-end speed. His vision is outstanding, and he shows excellent burst to and through the hole. He's a sudden runner with the ability to make sharp cuts on the move, and he can string together multiple moves in tight spaces. Taylor also has breakaway speed in the open field. He runs with good forward lean and lowers his pads on contact. He doesn't have great brute strength but keeps moving his feet and fights for yards after contact. As a pass-catcher, Taylor's production improved last season (26 catches after only 16 his first two seasons). He's an adequate route runner but is at his best on shorter routes, struggling to adjust down the field. His biggest weakness is in pass protection; he needs to be more consistently aggressive and fight harder to sustain. Ball security has also been an issue. Taylor compares favorably to Ezekiel Elliott (Dallas Cowboys) as a runner, but Elliott was a more physical blocker and has more natural ball skills. Taylor should quickly develop into a starter in the NFL but will need some complementary help. -- March 2020 Taylor is a tightly packed runner with a great combination of bulk, quickness and top-end speed. His vision is outstanding, and he shows excellent burst through the hole. He's a sudden runner with the ability to string together moves in tight spaces and is a threat to pull away when he gets a crease. Taylor made strides as a receiver last season, but he's still not a natural receiver. Pass protection is his biggest weakness. -- Steve Muench Marlon Mack topped 1,000 yards for the first time in his career in 2019 and the Colts ranked seventh in rushing yards per game last season, but Mack is going into a contract year and Taylor is a very good value pick at this point in the draft. Taylor running behind mauling left guard Quenton Nelson is a match made in heaven. While Taylor needs to make strides as a receiver, the Colts' play-action package should create big windows for Philip Rivers. -- Steve Muench

Shenault, a true junior in 2019, caught 142 passes for 1,775 yards (12.5 yards per catch) and 10 touchdowns over the past two seasons. He carried the ball 40 times for 276 yards (6.9 yards per rush) and seven touchdowns during that span. He's a well-built and versatile weapon who moves around the formation and lines up at Wildcat quarterback at times. He flashes skills as a route runner, and his ability to move around makes it easier to create favorable matchups. He's an instinctive runner who picks up yards after initial contact and flashes the ability to make defenders miss. He runs hard and he's willing to do the dirty work over the middle. He's quicker than fast and more of a threat after the catch, but he tracks the ball well and displays the ability to make plays downfield. -- March 2020 Shenault has excellent size, average length and below-average timed speed. He's a versatile weapon who's ability to move around the formation makes it easier to create favorable matchups. He's at his best with the ball in his hands, whether that's after the catch or on a carry. He's an instinctive open-field runner who picks up yards after initial contact and has the ability to make defenders miss. -- Steve Muench Shenault has the versatile traits to be utilized on multiple levels in Jay Gruden's offense. With the ability to stretch the field, run after the catch on shallows and carry the ball on fly sweeps, Gruden can manufacture touches and high-percentage throws for Shenault as a matchup piece in the game plan. -- Matt Bowen

Kmet has excellent size with average arm length and big hands. He is very adept at locating soft spots in zone coverage but struggles at the top of his route to generate separation versus man-to-man coverage. He does a very good job on contested catches and has solid speed for his size, flashing the ability to make some plays vertically down the seam. But he will never be an elite deep threat at the tight end position and does not offer much after the catch (outside of some power to break occasional tackles). Kmet is not an overpowering blocker but does a solid job with his angles and can use his big frame to wall off defenders in the run game. -- March 2020 Kmet is a big tight end with average length, big hands and good top-end speed. He has the ball skills, frame and athletic ability to come down with contested catches. He's a zone buster at his best locating and settling into pockets. He flashes the ability to make plays vertically down the seam. Kmet isn't an overpowering blocker but he gets into position and walls of defenders. -- Steve Muench Chicago got 416 receiving yards from its tight ends, which ranked 31st in the NFL last season. Kmet should help improve that production and he should also help improve a rushing attack that finished 27th in the league. The Bears signed veteran Jimmy Graham but Graham is 33 years old and he's on his third team in four years, plus they cut Trey Burton. -- Steve Muench

Delpit, a true junior in 2019, was a three-year starter. He's competitive lining up over the slot and matching up with tight ends. He has the instincts and enough range to play center field. He picked off seven passes over the past two seasons. He shows excellent focus when the ball is in the air. He's an active and aggressive run defender with very good size and he flashes above-average stopping power, but he misses too many tackles and needs to become a more consistent finisher. He did not work out at the combine. A high ankle sprain hindered him for the second half of the 2019 season. Delpit took a step back in 2019, with the ankle injury likely playing a big role, and his inability to run for teams is a concern, but he has shown enough over the course of his career to be one of the first safeties drafted. -- March 2020 Delpit missed too many tackles and didn't play as well last season as he did in 2018 with a high ankle sprain playing a big role. That said, he's a well-built safety who is competitive lining up over the slot and matching up with tight ends. He picked off seven passes over the past two seasons, has a nose for the football and shows excellent focus when the ball is in the air. And while Delpit needs to be more consistent, he's an aggressive run-stopper. -- Steve Muench

Read: Delpit and the city that's long been calling his name The Browns' problems at offensive tackle -- hopefully solved by a combination of free agency and with their Round 1 pick -- obscured the fact Cleveland also had the No. 22 defense in 2019 by DVOA, and second-level tackling was often a nightmare. Delpit is a big-time playmaker in the secondary who can move around and simply isn't available in Round 2 if he hadn't played hurt in 2019. A potential steal in Round 2. -- Chris Sprow

Winfield is a short safety with shorter arms, but he's quick, agile and fast for the position. And his instincts and recognition skills are elite. Just like his father, Antoine Winfield, those exceptional instincts and his toughness make up for size limitations. A true ball hawk, Winfield locates the ball in the air and shows strong hands to pluck. He's tough and aggressive versus the run, and he has good natural striking ability as a tackler. Winfield looks for contact and is a feisty wrap-up tackler. Injuries were setbacks early in his career, so can he hold up physically with his size and aggressive style in the NFL? Winfield is a plug-and-play starter at safety, and if he does hold up physically, he should emerge as a high-level starter for a long time. -- March 2020 Just like his father, Antoine Winfield, a first-round pick by the Bills in 1999, Winfield is an instinctive defensive back with excellent toughness for his size. He's a ball hawk, is competitive when the ball is in the air and has above-average hands. Winfield is an aggressive run defender who looks for contact and has good stopping power. -- Steve Muench

Read: Winfield's unique draft path: 5-foot-9 with first-round bloodlines The Buccaneers ranked 29th in scoring defense and 30th in passing defense last season. Justin Evans missed the 2019 season and is coming off two foot surgeries. Jordan Whitehead is coming off a season-ending hamstring injury. Defensive coordinator Todd Bowles is aggressive and blitzed 39.5% of the time, which was the second-highest rate in the league last season. Winfield's ability to move around and compete in man coverage makes him a perfect fit for Bowles' scheme and approach. -- Steve Muench

Hamler, a redshirt sophomore in 2019 who turns 21 in July, averaged 16.9 yards per catch over the past two seasons. He's an undersized slot receiver with the burst to separate from man coverage and develop into an above-average route runner. He tweaked a hamstring in training and didn't run at the combine, but he looks dangerous on tape. His top-end speed makes him a threat to take the top off the coverage, after the catch and in the return game. He's a small target with a small catching radius. He traps and drops passes. He has started every game over the past two seasons. -- March 2020 Hamler is an undersized slot receiver with the burst to separate from man and develop into an above-average route runner. He tweaked a hamstring and didn't run at the combine, but he's dangerous on tape. His top-end speed makes him a threat to take the top off the coverage, after the catch and in the return game. He's a small target with a small catching radius. Hamler traps and drops passes. -- Steve Muench Hamler gives the Broncos instant juice from the slot on verticals, deep overs and crossers. He can scoot. And after drafting Jerry Jeudy in the first round, the Broncos are suddenly stacked with talent in the passing game. Veteran Courtland Sutton is a playmaker, and tight end Noah Fant can stretch the seams. In short, the table is set for second-year quarterback Drew Lock. -- Matt Bowen

Davidson was a four-year starter at Auburn who recorded 175 tackles, 29.5 tackles for loss, 17 sacks and four forced fumbles. He also blocked three kicks in 2018. Davidson is a well-built defensive end who is versatile enough to kick inside to rush the quarterback. He has very good size and lateral agility, and he shows an explosive rip move on tape. Davidson is at his best rushing the QB off the edge. His focus should be keeping weight down and improving his foot quickness. His ability to use power to drive offensive tackles back and then efficiently bend the edge while engaged is terrific. He has the frame and strength to set a hard edge against the run, and he shows some snap in his hands. He gets off of blocks with relative ease and possesses adequate range against the run. Thought he plays high at times, Davidson has good anchor ability for a base 4-3 DE. He pursues the run and chases the quarterback with above-average effort. Davidson should quickly emerge as a starting DE and is best suited as an LDE in a 4-3 base front. -- March 2020 Davidson is an end who is built like a tackle, and he sets a hard edge against the run. He has violent hands and gets off blocks with ease. Davidson is versatile enough to kick inside to rush the passer, but he's at is best overpowering offensive tackles coming off edge. -- Steve Muench The Falcons were tied for the second-fewest sacks in the NFL and ranked 22nd in pass defense last season. They signed Dante Fowler, but Vic Beasley and Adrian Clayborn aren't coming back, plus Takkarist McKinley had a career-low 3.5 sacks. It will be interesting to see where Atlanta plays Davidson. We think he's at his best rushing the passer off the edge, but the Falcons could kick him inside. -- Steve Muench

Taylor was a team captain who recorded 16.5 sacks and four forced fumbles over the past two seasons. He's quick and he bends well for his size. He flashes an effective long-arm move. He has a good change-of-pace inside move. He does a nice job of keeping his hips down and getting his hands inside as a run defender. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. He has experience dropping and he could play 3-4 OLB, even though his best fit is arguably at defensive end. He reportedly underwent surgery on his left leg in January and did not work out at the combine. -- March 2020 Taylor has average size and slightly below-average length. He's quick and bends well for his size. He flashes effective long-arm and change-of-pace inside moves. He does a good job of keeping his hips down and getting his hands inside as a run defender. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. -- Steve Muench John Schneider and Pete Carroll calm the "We need a pass-rusher!!" riots that formed after the Round 1 selection of Jordyn Brooks. Deep breaths, Seattle. Taylor is a raw but explosive pass-rusher badly needed on a unit that ranked 30th in the NFL in pressure rate (sack or hurry) in 2019 and has only one player under contract who averaged more than 0.5 pressures per game in 2019. Now ... what's up, Jadeveon? -- Chris Sprow

Claypool is a big target with elite speed for his size. He became just the second wideout to measure at least 6-foot-4 and 235 pounds and then run a sub-4.45 in the 40-yard dash at the combine since 2003 (Calvin Johnson). He lines up outside and inside, and he is a long strider with good buildup speed. He has the wide frame to make contested catches and wins a high percentage of jump balls. Claypool really improved as a red zone threat in 2019, too. A straight-line athlete who struggles to smoothly get in and out of breaks, he rarely gains separation with his feet, but he runs hard after the catch and breaks more tackles than most receivers. However, he doesn't show much wiggle and rarely makes multiple defenders miss. Claypool is tough over the middle, is an above-average blocker and has good experience on special teams. Claypool grades out as an eventual No. 3 or No. 4 NFL wide receiver. -- March 2020 Claypool is just the second wideout to measure 6-foot-4, 235 pounds or bigger and run a sub-4.45 in the 40-yard dash at the combine since 2003. The other is Calvin Johnson. Claypool is a long strider with good build-up speed. He has the wide frame to make contested catches, and he wins a high percentage of jump balls. He struggles to get in and out of breaks. He led his team in kickoff coverage and punt coverage tackles in 2017. -- Steve Muench JuJu Smith-Schuster dealt with foot and knee injuries last season; he's in a contract year and might be too expensive to retain. Diontae Johnson, the Steelers' 2019 third-round pick, led the team in catches while James Washington paced the squad with 735 receiving yards, but they aren't No. 1 receivers. Claypool has rare upside; his ability to stretch the field should open up the passing attack and the ground game. -- Steve Muench

Johnson, a true junior in 2019, is an effective press corner with good balance and speed. He does a good job of breaking on underneath routes in off coverage. He reads the quarterback and plays the ball not the man in zone. He has average size and recovery speed. His footwork is inconsistent, and he allows separation transitioning out of breaks at times. He flashes the ability to pluck the ball out of the air, but he doesn't always catch the ball cleanly. -- March 2020 Johnson has average size, length and top-end speed. He's an effective press corner with good balance. He does a good job of breaking on underneath routes in off coverage and plays the ball not the man in zone coverage. His footwork is inconsistent -- he allows separation transitioning out of breaks at times. -- Steve Muench With the Bears letting Prince Amukamara go, there is a need for depth here at the cornerback position. Johnson has the physical traits and competitive play style to fit in Chuck Pagano's defense as a press corner, with the ball skills to finish. He's a first-round talent. Put Johnson in the mix here to compete with Artie Burns and Kevin Toliver for that starting gig opposite Kyle Fuller. -- Matt Bowen

In 18 starts over his final two seasons at Alabama, Diggs combined for 57 tackles, 14 passes broken up and four interceptions. He is a versatile athlete with great size and length, and possesses solid straight-line speed. The majority of his experience is at left CB, but he also has played the "overhang" and free safety, in addition to his return experience. Diggs has some tightness in his hips and will give up separation against quicker receivers out of their breaks, but if used properly -- he is at his best in press-man and Cover 3 -- he is highly effective in coverage. A former wide receiver with natural ball skills, Diggs is very effective when contesting bigger wideouts for the ball, timing his jumps well and showing an ability to high point in traffic. His recognition skills continue to improve with more experience, though he can be inconsistent with eye discipline when playing off-coverage in zone. He has good closing burst for his size and does a good job of limiting yards after the catch. Diggs is also aggressive in run support. -- March 2020 Diggs is a versatile athlete with good size, long arms and solid straight-line speed. The majority of his experience is at corner, but he has also played the overhang and free safety in addition to returning kickoffs and punts. There's some tightness in his hips and he will give up separation versus quicker receivers, but Diggs is highly effective in press-man coverage and Cover 3. He's a former wide receiver with good ball skills. -- Steve Muench

Read: Diggs embarks on NFL path paved by brother, father figure Stefon Byron Jones signed with Miami and Chidobe Awuzie is entering the final year of his contract. The Cowboys re-signed Anthony Brown, but he's coming back from a season-ending injury. Dallas tied for an NFL-low seven interceptions and got just five from its defensive backs last season. Diggs is a former wide receiver with above-average ball skills and projects as a day one starter. He's an excellent value pick at this point. -- Steve Muench

Akers was a three-year player and two-and-a-half-year starter at FSU. He averaged 4.9 yards per carry and caught 69 passes during his career. He has good size and very good timed speed. He shows very good burst to and through the hole, and he is an instinctive between-the-tackles runner with good patience. He's not a pile pusher but has very good contact balance and fights for yards after contact. Akers is more of a threat after the catch than yards per catch numbers would suggest, and he's an adequate route runner with experience working out of the slot. He flashes a willingness to step up and meet defenders in pass protection, too, but his technique and recognition are issues at times. Akers is one of the most complete and underrated running backs in the draft class and grades out as a future NFL starter. -- April 2020 Akers is one of the most complete and underrated running backs in this class. He has good size and great speed. He is an instinctive between-the-tackles runner with good patience. He's not a pile pusher, but he has very good contact balance and he fights for yards after contact. Akers is more of a threat after the catch than YPC numbers would suggest. He flashes a willingness to step up and meet defenders in pass protection. -- Steve Muench The CIA-level intrigue into the weekly status of Todd Gurley's knee has departed, but with that departure lingered this reality: Oh yeah, the Rams have zero proven backs. Well, they now add Cam Akers, who once broke Dalvin Cook's rookie rushing record at Florida State. He had a pair of 1,000-yard rushing seasons, and behind an oft-dreadful offensive line. Akers has serious juice, and is a competitor to get his share of carries in Year 1. -- Chris Sprow

Hurts played 56 career games with 42 starts at Alabama and Oklahoma. He is shorter than ideal but has a strong build and an average hand span. His timed speed (4.59) lines up with what he shows on tape. Hurts is physically and mentally tough, but he is slow to process and holds on to the ball entirely too long. He has done a good job of protecting the football throughout his career. Hurts has average release quickness, showing a little bit of a longer delivery with a high release point. But he displays good overall velocity and the ability to drive the ball vertically. Ball placement is highly inconsistent, especially outside the numbers and on downfield throws. Hurts' pocket presence is very erratic, but he does have very good agility to extend plays and is a high-level running threat. He just needs to do a better job of understanding his protection and learning to maneuver inside the pocket, rather than bailing once the picture gets muddied. Hurts grades out as a backup NFL quarterback with some versatility to contribute in certain situations. -- March 2020 Hurts is a shorter quarterback with good arm strength, a strong build and excellent top-end speed. He's physically and mentally tough. He takes care off the football. He's slow to process and holds onto the ball entirely too long. His ball placement is highly inconsistent, especially outside the numbers and downfield. Hurts' pocket presence is erratic but he can extend plays. He's a high-level running threat.

Read: Hurts has captivated two of college football's most rabid fan bases Carson Wentz just signed a four-year deal and is the clear starter. That doesn't make this a bad pick. Coach Doug Pederson will use Hurts in specific packages that make the most of his skill set. Pederson and his staff will develop Hurts as a No. 2 in a heavily schemed system based on run-pass option (RPO) pass attempts behind a quarterback in Wentz who has had some problems staying healthy. -- Steve Muench

Epenesa is a big defensive end with average initial quickness and top-end speed. He's an active hand fighter with good length rushing the passer. He looks to force fumbles when he gets to the quarterback and gets his hands up in passing lanes. He's not as much of a pass-rushing prospect for the NFL, with below-average lower-body flexibility and closing speed, but he's a high-effort player who chases hard in pursuit and plays with good technique. Against the run, Epenesa has the size, length and upper-body strength to set the edge. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks and finishing. Epenesa grades out as a sub-package contributor as a rookie with the upside to develop into a full-time starter in the NFL. He fits best as a 4-3 LDE but is big enough to play some five-technique at times and is capable of kicking inside as a three-technique on obvious passing downs. -- March 2020 Epenesa is a big defensive end with the frame and strength to set the edge. He has marginal top-end speed and doesn't project as an elite pass-rusher at the NFL level despite his impressive sack production over the past two seasons, but he gets the most out of his ability. Epenesa is an active and effective hand fighter with outstanding length who chases with excellent effort. -- Steve Muench Epenesa's power, technique and versatility are a fit for a coverage-based Buffalo defense that needs to create pressure with its front four. In 2019, the Bills ranked 20th in pressure percentage when sending four or fewer rushers. Epenesa can rush off the edge or bump inside, where the Bills can create interior matchups for the Iowa product. -- Matt Bowen

Dobbins finished his Ohio State career with 725 carries for 4,469 yards (6.2 yards per carry) and 38 TDs. He also caught 71 passes for 645 yards and 11 TDs. He has a short, squatty build with very quick feet, and he shows great burst toandthrough the hole. Dobbins also has fluid hips and can make defenders miss in the short area. He runs hard and will break some arm tackles, but he's not an overpowering runner. Dobbins has very good acceleration to turn the corner as an outside runner and shows above-average elusiveness in space. His hands are adequate -- he's a body catcher who is at his best when facing the quarterback and on screens. There's room for growth in pass protection, but he's willing to step up and meet defenders face-up. He only allowed four pressures on 140 pass protection opportunities last year, according to ESPN Stats & Information. Dobbins also showed outstanding durability as a three-year starter, and he takes care of the football. Dobbins grades out as a high-level starting NFL running back. -- March 2020 Dobbins is a short and squatty back with quick feet and great burst through the hole. He's an elusive open-field runner. He runs hard and breaks arm tackles. He allowed four pressures on 140 pass pro opportunities last year (according to ESPN Stats & Info), which is far and away the best percentage and most attempts by any of the top four backs in this class. He's not a natural receiver, though. -- Steve Muench Baltimore led the league in rushing in 2019 and set the record for yards per carry in a 16-game season. Mark Ingram is 30 but rushed for over 1,000 yards in his first season with the team, and Gus Edwards added 711 yards. In other words, running back sure doesn't seem like a need, but the Ravens get a talented back and excellent value in Dobbins, who was the 27th-ranked player on our board. -- Steve Muench

The past three seasons (2017-19), Davis has been a full-time starter and has played in 41 of 43 games, combining for 171 total tackles, 18.5 tackles for loss and 11.5 sacks. A tall, powerfully-built defensive end who carries his weight extremely well, Davis has heavy and quick hands. He flashes the ability to jar offensive lineman with initial contact and frequently gets pressure when turned loose. But he lacks some body control and can be slow to redirect, which leads to some sacks being left on the field. Davis is a highly-gifted and scheme-versatile defensive lineman with a strong combination of size, length, quickness and power. He had a breakout season in 2017, took a step back in 2018 and then rebounded in 2019. He will never be an elite pass-rusher but has the tools to continue to improve. He's also a highly-effective and versatile run defender. The biggest challenge in the NFL will be making sure he has a strong support system and leadership around him. -- March 2020 Davis is a highly gifted and scheme-versatile defensive lineman with a strong combination of size, length, quickness and power. He's an effective run stopper with the upper-body strength to stack and control blockers when he keeps his pads down. Davis will never be an elite pass-rusher, but he has violent hands and frequently gets pressure when turned loose. -- Steve Muench The Dolphins already added a CB to help the NFL's 32-ranked pass defense, but -- psst -- the run defense was also a brutal 27th in DVOA in 2019. That could be where Davis adds more immediate impact, because his pass-rush upside is a question. What he can do is provide immediate depth inside in a 3-4 scheme and hold up blockers. If Miami gets the best version of Davis, it got a Round 1 player here. -- Chris Sprow

Jefferson began his career at Ole Miss before transferring to Florida in 2018. He led the Gators in receiving yards each of the past two seasons (2018-19), combining for 84 catches, 1,160 yards and 12 touchdowns. A combine physical revealed Jefferson has a Jones fracture in his right foot, and the initial prognosis is that he will likely be sidelined for eight weeks. He has good size, he's twitchy in the short area, and he appears on tape to have average top-end speed. Sudden getting off the line of scrimmage, Jefferson is adept at beating press coverage. He possesses very good technique and footwork, and he shows elite route running skills. He knows how to leverage his stem and how to set up defenders, and he does an excellent job of locating soft spots in zone coverage. His ball skills are outstanding -- he is a hands catcher who attacks the ball and high-points it. Jefferson is strong in traffic and shows good body control to adjust. His biggest weakness is a lack of vertical speed. He runs hard and shows good vision after the catch but doesn't have explosive agility to make many defenders miss. Finally, he is an adequate blocker in the run game. Jefferson has the ability to develop into a good No. 3 starter in the NFL, but his foot injury is obviously a setback. He would have been a Day 2 pick had it not been for the injury, but he's now likely to come off the board on Day 3. -- April 2020 Jefferson is an elite route runner with average size. He's sudden getting off the line and adept at beating press coverage. He knows how to leverage his stem and set up defenders. He locates soft spots in zone. Jefferson has outstanding hands and the body control to adjust. Biggest weakness is he lacks the top-end speed to threaten vertically. -- Steve Muench Robert Woods and Cooper Kupp both finished with more than 1,100 receiving yards last season, but the Rams traded Brandin Cooks to Houston, plus Josh Reynolds is entering a contract year and has yet to catch more than 29 passes in a season. Jefferson's ability to make an immediate impact fills the Rams' need for a No. 3 receiver and gives quarterback Jared Goff a reliable safety valve. -- Steve Muench

Cleveland, a redshirt junior in 2019, was a three-year starter at left tackle. He has shorter arms for a left tackle, but he gets set quickly and he doesn't lunge or chase with his hands. He has the body control and foot speed to mirror. He wrestled in high school and he has very good upper-body strength. He's an effective positional blocker with the skill set to excel in a zone-heavy scheme. He's smooth climbing and covers up linebackers at the second level. He plays high and battles to a stalemate at the line of scrimmage. -- March 2020 Cleveland has shorter arms for a tackle, but he gets set quickly and doesn't lunge or chase with his hands. He has the body control and foot speed to mirror. He wrestled in high school and has very good upper-body strength. He's an effective positional blocker with the skillset to excel in a zone-heavy scheme. He's smooth climbing and covers up linebackers at the second level. -- Steve Muench Veteran Riley Reiff is the anticipated starter at left tackle, but Cleveland gives the Vikings more depth on the offensive line and is a good fit for the zone run game in Minnesota. With ascending traits at the position, Cleveland should be viewed as a future starter on the Vikings' offensive front. -- Matt Bowen

Mims was a three-year starter who caught 182 passes for 2,901 yards and 28 touchdowns over the past three seasons. He has an excellent combination of size, speed and length. He has the second gear to take the top off the coverage, and he does a nice job of stacking defenders on vertical routes. He runs hard and flashes the ability to break tackles after the catch. His frame and body control make him a threat in the red zone. He flashes the ability to make highlight-reel catches, but his hands are inconsistent. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off press coverage. -- March 2020 Mims has a rare blend of size, top-end speed and length. He has the second gear to take the top off the coverage and does a nice job of stacking defenders on vertical routes. He runs hard and flashes the ability to break tackles after the catch. His frame and body control make him a threat in the red zone. -- Steve Muench

Watch: Mims thinks he has always been underrated Robby Anderson signed with Carolina and Quincy Enunwa is coming off his second major neck injury. Free-agent addition Breshad Perriman is coming off his best season and Jamison Crowder is a good slot receiver, but Perriman's ability to have continued success remains to be seen. Mims gives the Jets a receiver with the talent to improve a passing attack that finished 29th in the league in yardage. QB Sam Darnold should be pleased with what general manager Joe Douglas has done with his first two picks. -- Steve Muench

Uche was a four-year player but only a one-year starter at Michigan. He did not see much action until 2018, and all 10 of his starts came as a senior in 2019. During his final two seasons, Uche recorded 50 tackles, 19.5 tackles for loss and 15.5 sacks. He is an undersized edge defender with long arms and a good combination of initial quickness, bend and closing speed. He's twitchy and has a quick inside move. He's a developing hand fighter who flashes the ability to counter, and he flashes some speed to power. He does need to get stronger against the run, but Uche has an intriguing skill set to contribute as a situational pass-rusher early in his career. His ceiling is to develop into a starter at outside linebacker (SAM in a 4-3 or a 3-4 OLB). -- April 2020 Uche is an undersized edge defender with long arms and the skill set to make an immediate impact rushing the passer. He has a good combination of initial quickness, bend and closing speed. He's twitchy and has a quick inside move. Uche is a developing hand fighter who flashes the ability to counter. He's relentless. He needs to get stronger versus the run. -- Steve Muench The Patriots got after the passer at a pretty high rate last season (a pass rush sixth in DVOA), but there's a problem: Kyle Van Noy and Jamie Collins ranked first and third in pressures, respectively, and they've departed. Uche in Round 2 as an upside pick fits the classic Patriots program, because he's a developmental pick more than a proven commodity, the kind of player you feel more optimistic about because of where he just landed. -- Chris Sprow

Fulton is a two-year starter with average size and above-average top-end speed. He gives up separation at the top of routes and gets boxed out working against bigger receivers. He lines up over the slot on occasion and might be a better fit on the inside. He made a highlight-reel interception against Georgia in 2018, but he picked off only two passes in 28 career games. He fights to get off blocks and doesn't shy away from contact in run support. He missed the final three games of the 2018 season with an ankle injury. He served 18 months of a two-year suspension for allegedly using another person's urine during a February 2017 drug test. He practiced with the team but did not play in 2017. Fulton has the work ethic, cover skills and enough size to quickly develop into an excellent No. 3 and potentially develop into an effective No. 2 in time. -- March 2020 Fulton has average size, below-average length and good top-end speed. He's at his best in press coverage. He's not a playmaker. He picked off just two passes over the past two seasons. However, Fulton deflected 25 passes during that span and is competitive at the catch point. -- Steve Muench Tennessee ranked 24th in passing defense last season and needed to address the cornerback position. Logan Ryan remains unsigned, Malcolm Butler has a big contract and the Titans have a decision to make about picking up Adoree' Jackson's fifth-year option in 2021. LeShaun Sims and Tramaine Brock were not re-signed. Fulton faced some tough competition in the SEC and he has the talent to push for a starting job as a rookie. -- Steve Muench

Dillon, a true junior in 2019, broke Boston College's records for rushing yards and rushing touchdowns. No running back jumped further or higher at the combine. He's a big, strong back with a thick lower body. He's tough to stop even when you know what's coming. He has good build-up speed. He has the size and strength to develop into an effective pass-blocker. He looks the ball in and shows the ability to catch away from frame. He's not a natural hands catcher though, and he had just 21 career catches. Wear and tear is a concern. He ranked third in the FBS in rushing attempts two of the past three seasons, and he carried the ball 845 times (24.1 carries per game) in three seasons at Boston College. -- March 2020 Dillon is a massive back with a thick lower body and very good top-end speed for his size. He excels at picking up yards after initial contact and is tough to stop even when the defense knows what's coming. Dillon is fast enough to pick up chunks of yards when he gets a seam. He's not a natural receiver, and he averaged 24.1 carries per game over the past three seasons, raising concerns about wear and tear. -- Steve Muench With veteran running backs Aaron Jones and Jamaal Williams entering their contract years, the Packers add depth here. Dillon fits as a complementary piece in the Green Bay backfield. He's a downhill hammer, a closer who can handle volume and run between the tackles. -- Matt Bowen

Gay has a rare combination of size, length and speed. He's a rangy run defender with the burst to shoot into gaps and chase down backs in pursuit. He closes well and flashes talent as a pass-rusher. He reads the quarterback, covers ground quickly and flashes good ball skills in coverage. An NCAA violation related to a tutor completing classwork for Gay and other players led to an eight-game suspension for him last year, and his production never matched anticipated talent at the college level, but he has the potential to be more productive in the pros. -- Steve Muench The Chiefs need to get stronger against the run after finishing 26th in the league in rushing yards allowed per game last season. Damien Wilson is going into a contract year, plus the Chiefs didn't re-sign Reggie Ragland or Darron Lee. Gay has the talent to win a starting job, help stabilize the run defense and stay on the field on third down. -- Steve Muench

Chinn was a team captain and four-year starter who finished his career with 13 interceptions. He has the size, length and speed to check tight ends in coverage. He has above-average range and flashes the ability to play center field. He's a playmaker who tracks the ball well and has good hands. He has the frame and leaping ability to win 50-50 balls. He's versatile enough to play deep, line up over the slot and line up at linebacker depth. He's an above-average tackler who flashes the ability to get off blocks and closes quickly. -- March 2020 Chinn is a team captain and four-year starter with an outstanding blend of size, speed and length. He's a playmaker who tracks the ball well and has good hands. He has the frame and leaping ability to win 50-50 balls. Chinn is versatile enough to play deep, line up over the slot or play at linebacker depth. He's an above-average tackler who flashes the ability to get off blocks and closes quickly. -- Steve Muench Listed as a safety, Chinn actually has the length and athleticism of a big cornerback. That's a need for Carolina, but if he settles at safety who can cover the slot, you'll take it. The 6-foot-3, 221-pound Chinn went 4.45 with a 41-inch vertical in Indy to match tape that shows a versatile defender who could line up at a few spots for Matt Rhule. -- Chris Sprow

Wilson, a redshirt senior in 2019, is a four-year starter and one of two Wyoming players to be named a captain three times. There's room for improvement, but he has active hands, and he flashes the ability to quickly shed blocks. He closes well and chases with good effort. He flashes good stopping power and wraps in a phone booth. Bad angles occasionally lead to missed tackles. He played defensive back in high school and has above-average cover skills. He's fast enough to carry tight ends down the seam. He reads the quarterback and shows good awareness in zone. He has solid ball skills as evidenced by 10 interceptions at Wyoming. -- March 2020 Wilson, one of two Wyoming players to be named a captain three times, has the potential to develop into a four-down player. He has active hands and showed the ability to shed blocks quickly. He closes well and chases with good effort. He flashes good stopping power. He played defensive back in high school and has good cover skills. Wilson has some ball skills, picking off 10 passes at Wyoming, including two that he returned for touchdowns. -- Steve Muench 2019 third-round pick Germaine Pratt took over as a starter after the Bengals released Preston Brown last year, but Nick Virgil signing with the Chargers created a void at the Bengals' other linebacker spot. Look for Wilson to beat out Jordan Evans for that job and quickly develop into a three-down linebacker. Wilson is an excellent value pick at this point in the draft. -- Steve Muench

Gibson transferred from East Central Community College (where he played receiver) to Memphis, where he played more of a hybrid running back/receiver role in addition to returning kickoffs. He averaged 124.9 all-purpose yards per game and racked up 13 touchdowns in 2019. He has above-average burst through the hole and after the catch. His top-end speed makes him a threat whenever he gets daylight, and he has the size and strength to pick up yards after initial contact. Gibson carried the ball just 33 times at Memphis and needs more reps at running back to get clearer evaluation of vision/instincts, but he flashed good patience and instincts on tape and at the Senior Bowl. He has small hands and is a below-average route runner for a receiver. That said, there's a lot to like about his ability to move around the formation, and he's an above-average receiver for a running back. Gibson grades out as a dangerous kickoff returner and versatile offensive weapon with the big-play ability to make an immediate impact for a team willing to scheme for him. He also has upside at running back. -- April 2020 Gibson is a hybrid receiver/back who shows solid burst through the hole and after the catch. His top-end speed makes him a threat when he gets the ball in space. He has the strength to pick up yards after contact. He carried the ball 33 times at Memphis but flashed good patience and instincts. He's not a great route runner for a receiver, but there's a lot to like about his ability to move around the formation. -- Steve Muench Second-year man Terry McLaurin is a rising star, but the wide receiver depth in Washington needed some serious juice. Enter Gibson, who played both running back and wide receiver at Memphis. He has explosive play traits, position versatility and can be utilized in the slot or out of the backfield. -- Matt Bowen

Okwara moved to the United States from Nigeria as a third-grader. He's the younger brother of former Irish defensive line standout and current Detroit Lions defensive end Romeo Okwara. He is a tall, long-armed and athletic hybrid edge prospect with speed off the edge and good flexibility to bend and turn the corner efficiently. He also shows good closing burst to the quarterback. Okwara flashes an outside-in move but needs to develop better counterpunches and improve his ability to win with speed-to-power moves. He has good range versus the run but has a lean lower body and gives up too much ground. He also has the length, speed and enough athletic ability to hold up in underneath coverage, and he stacks tight ends as a run defender. Okwara has upside, but his best role as a rookie will be likely as a situational edge rusher. He needs to get stronger versus the run and continue to improve his power elements as a pass-rusher in order to earn a full-time starting job. Okwara projects best as a 3-4 OLB but could also develop as a 4-3 RDE. -- March 2020 Okwara is a tall, long and athletic hybrid EDGE prospect. He has the get off, bend and closing burst to win with speed off the edge. He flashes an outside-in move but needs to develop better counterpunches and improve his ability to win with speed-to-power. Okwara is a rangy run defender, but he has a lean lower body and gives too much ground. -- Steve Muench The Lions tied for 29th with 28 sacks last season, with Trey Flowers getting seven of them after signing a five-year, $90 million deal. Romeo Okwara, Julian's older brother, saw his sack total drop from 7.5 in 2018 to 1.5 in 2019, his second season in Detroit. Julian has the potential to develop into an explosive edge rusher and excellent complement to Flowers. The Lions are also getting a player versatile enough to play defensive end or OLB in 3-4 alignments. -- Steve Muench

Davis, a sixth year senior in 2019, was a four-time All-American hurdler for the Cal track program. He walked onto the football team in the spring of 2015. In addition to starting 33 games on defense he was the team's primary kickoff returner in 2017 and 2018. We don't have an official 40-time, but he closes well and looks to have the potential to develop into a center fielder based on tape. He started three games at corner in 2016 and has above-average man-to-man cover skills for a safety. He allows separation at top of stem working against physical tight ends, and he gives receivers too much of a cushion at times. He had only two picks in 2019, but he showed impressive ball skills on the UCLA pick and he had four picks in 2018. He misses too many tackles at this point, and there's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. He missed two games with injury in 2019, he was unable to participate in the Senior Bowl, and he didn't work out at the combine after undergoing a surgical procedure to repair a groin injury. He turns 24 in October. -- March 2020 Davis didn't run at the combine, but he's rangy and has the potential to develop into a center fielder based on the tape. He started three games at corner in 2016 and has good cover skills for a safety. He had seven solo tackles against Oregon, flashing the potential to develop into an effective run-stopper, but he needs to be more consistent. -- Steve Muench The first two Jets picks were all about helping QB Sam Darnold, whereas Davis adds a wrinkle to what is an increasingly, oh, let's call it "interesting" situation in the defensive backfield, as Jamal Adams' long-term future with the franchise remains a question. Davis is a safety with the track-star athleticism of a cornerback, so he's not some Adams doppelganger but is more a high-upside play for Gregg Williams to develop. You'll see Davis return kicks, too. -- Chris Sprow

Lewis is a short interior offensive lineman with slightly below-average length and good upper-body strength. He generally anchors well in pass pro and is an effective run-blocker who flashes above-average power. He's a finisher who plays with an edge. -- Steve Muench The Seahawks need a starter at left guard, Lewis was the best guard left on the board and he's a mauling run-blocker who is a good fit for Seattle's offense. He could go through some growing pains in pass protection, but he'll get better in time and quarterback Russell Wilson's mobility will help bail him out. -- Steve Muench

Jones, three-year starter and a team captain in 2019, is an above-average tackler who is active in run support and chases with excellent effort. He plays bigger than his size and looks to separate receivers from the ball in coverage. He has enough speed to cover a deep half. He doesn't have the playing speed or the instincts of a true center fielder. He's opportunistic, but he's not a ball hawk. He has short arms and small hands. He's a fearless punt returner who averaged 11.5 yards per punt return. He underwent shoulder surgery following the 2019 season. -- April 2020 Jones is an excellent tackler who is active in run support and chases with effort. He plays bigger than his size and looks to separate receivers from the ball in coverage. He doesn't have the playing speed or the instincts of a true center fielder. Jones is opportunistic but not a ball hawk. He's a fearless punt returner who averaged 10.8 yards per punt return. -- Steve Muench With the Dolphins cutting veteran Reshad Jones this offseason, Miami needed to address the safety position. Brandon Jones has the physical play traits to get on the field early as a rookie for a Miami team that has focused on upgrading the secondary through free agency and the draft. -- Matt Bowen

Madubuike is an undersized 3-technique prospect with the quickness to disrupt plays in the backfield and the strength to hold his ground one-on-one. He flashes the ability to battle to a stalemate but gets collapsed by double-teams at times. He has great upside as an interior pass-rusher ? he shows outstanding athletic ability and closes well. But there's room for improvement when it comes to his hand-to-hand combat skills. -- April 2020 Madubuike is an undersized 3-technique prospect with the quickness to disrupt plays in the backfield and the strength to hold his ground one-on-one. He has great upside as an interior pass-rusher with outstanding athletic ability and good closing speed. There's room for improvement when it comes to his hand-to-hand combat skills, but he has good length and excellent upper-body strength. -- Steve Muench Ravens general manager Eric DeCosta continues to get excellent value in the second round, as Madubuike was the 40th-ranked player on our board. DeCosta is also staying true to his team's identity by reinforcing the ground game and defense. The Ravens traded for Calais Campbell and signed Derek Wolfe to a one-year deal, but Campbell is 33, Wolfe is 30 and nose tackle Brandon Williams is 31. -- Steve Muench

Jones, a team captain and redshirt senior in 2019, was a four-year starter at left tackle. He's an above-average pass-blocker with good body control and athletic ability. He locks on and stays in front when he gets his hands inside. He flashes the ability to move defenders off the ball, he's an effective zone blocker and he excels at climbing to the second level in the run game. His footwork and overall technique are inconsistent, particularly for a four-year starter. He flashes a nasty disposition and a finisher's mentality. Jones lacks ideal length for an offensive tackle prospect and some teams might project him at guard, but his tape suggests he'll be able to overcome that deficiency and develop into a starting tackle early in his career. His floor appears to be an above-average starting guard capable of providing depth at tackle. He projects as an early-round pick. -- March 2020 Jones is a team captain and four-year starter at left tackle. He lacks ideal length for an offensive tackle and some teams could project him at guard, but his tape suggests he'll overcome that deficiency and develop into a starting tackle. He's a good pass-blocker with solid body control and balance. He flashes the ability to move defenders off the ball and excels at climbing to the second level in the run game. -- Steve Muench There was some thought that Arizona would get a much-needed offensive tackle inside the top 10, but when Isaiah Simmons was sitting there at No. 8, well, plans change. Now the Cardinals add a potential starter at tackle to a unit that ranked 22nd in sustaining its blocks through 2.5 seconds last season, according to ESPN's pass block win rate metric, which kept QB Kyler Murray on the move. Jones needs polish, but so does this line as a whole. -- Chris Sprow

Hamilton has average height and good bulk. He has good short-area quickness but marginal top-end speed and lateral agility. He made significant strides as a pass-rusher in 2019 (six sacks compared to one sack his first three seasons, albeit as a backup/rotational player). He has a quick swim move and shows some power as a pass-rusher but needs to develop better counter moves. He stalls out too frequently. Hamilton is a better run defender than pass-rusher, with heavy hands and strength at the point of attack. He does a nice job of getting off blocks and improved his ability to locate the ball in 2019. But he is slow to redirect and has some range limitations. Hamilton is likely to contribute in a rotation in the NFL but will need time to continue to develop, especially as a pass-rusher. -- March 2020 Hamilton has excellent size, average length and average top-end speed. He's strong at the point of attack and does a nice job of getting off blocks. He's a good tackler, and he improved his ability to locate the ball in 2019. Hamilton is a better run defender than pass-rusher, but he flashes good power and made significant strides as a pass-rusher in 2019. -- Steve Muench The Jaguars needed to improve a run defense that ranked 29th in the league last season; they didn't pick up Marcell Dareus' option, and former first-round pick Taven Bryan hasn't played up to expectations. Hamilton is an above-average run defender who will make it tougher for teams to run between the tackles. -- Steve Muench

A former highschool quarterback turned college outside linebacker, Baun has average height and bulk combination with shorter-than-ideal arms and average top-end speed. But he has an excellent motor as a pass-rusher, showing top-end closing burst when getting after the QB. A natural finisher with good sack production, Baun has shock in his hands and should continue to improve hand-to-hand combat skills. However, his power rush frequently stalls, and his tightness prevents him from bending the edge tightly at times (often losing footing when trying to run a tight loop around the OT in pursuit of a climbing QB). He lacks ideal flexibility and can be slow to redirect, but he's a high-effort player with good play speed on a straightline and possesses solid instincts in zone coverage and quick feet in his drops. He will have some man-to-man coverage limitations in the NFL. Baun is also a strong tackler -- though he has some space limitations -- and shows very good power at the point of attack. Baun is an underrated prospect with some position versatility. -- March 2020 Baun is a relentless pass-rusher who shows top-end closing speed when he gets a path to the quarterback. There's some shock in his hands and he should continue to improve his hand-to-hand combat skills. He covers ground and shows good instincts in coverage. Baun is a rangy run defender and strong tackler. -- Steve Muench In defensive coordinator Dennis Allen's defense, Baun can be utilized as both a stack linebacker and in pass-rush situations in schemed matchups. The Saints return All-Pro linebacker Demario Davis, but with A.J. Klein leaving in free agency, there was a need here to add a linebacker in the draft. -- Matt Bowen

Jackson is a versatile offensive lineman with good size, length and upper-body strength. He's a strong run-blocker who plays with an edge. He anchors well, but he doesn't bend well, he lunges at times and there's room for improvement when it comes to his hand-to-hand combat skills in pass pro. -- Steve Muench The Lions did a good job of addressing their ground game by taking the best running back in the draft in the second round, and adding Jackson is another step in the right direction. Jackson should compete for the right guard spot vacated by Graham Glasgow, and he's also versatile enough to provide depth at center for the Lions. -- Steve Muench

Vaughn transferred to Vanderbilt from Illinois and sat out in accordance with NCAA rules in 2017. He rushed for 2,272 yards and 21 touchdowns while averaging 6.4 yards per carry over the past two seasons. He caught 42 passes for 456 yards and three touchdowns during that span. He's a decisive between-the-tackles runner with good quickness and forward lean through the hole. He has the lateral mobility to make defenders miss in the hole, and he flashes the ability to slip defenders in space. He has above-average top-end speed, and he's a threat to rip off chunk yards when he gets a seam. He runs hard and he has good contact balance, but he's not a bulldozing short-yardage back with a great power base. He has above-average ball skills, and he flashes as a route runner. He has experience lining up wide and in the slot. He flashes in pass pro, but there's room for improvement. 2019 (1.32) and career (1.25) fumble percentages are a little concerning. -- March 2020 Vaughn is a decisive between-the-tackles runner with the lateral mobility to make defenders miss in the hole. He has above average top-end speed and is a threat to rip off chunk yards when he gets a seam. He runs hard and has good contact balance. Vaughn is not a bulldozing short-yardage back. He has good ball skills and can run routes. -- Steve Muench The current Tampa backfield is Ronald Jones II and We'll See. Vaughn fills a void and comes in with enough chops to push for early action. Vaughn breaks tackles and offers a different style than Jones, and -- no surprise -- he knows what he's doing in pass protection, which is a good thing for that Bucs QB you might have heard of. -- Chris Sprow

Hennessy, a redshirt junior in 2019, gets set quickly. He tends to get his hands inside, and he anchors well in pass pro. He's an above-average zone blocker with good quickness and lateral mobility in the run game. He has shorter arms and lunges in space at times, but he has the athletic ability to develop into an effective downfield blocker. He's not an overpowering mauler, and he falls off some blocks late. -- April 2020 Hennessy gets set quickly, he tends to get his hands inside, and he anchors well in pass pro. He's an above-average zone blocker with good quickness and lateral mobility in the run game. He has the range to develop into an effective downfield blocker. Hennessy has shorter arms and lunges at times. -- Steve Muench Falcons center Alex Mack has been durable, but he is 34 and going into the final year of his contract. So the addition of a center who profiles as a backup now with starting upside makes a lot of sense for the Falcons, who saw Matt Ryan sacked a career-high 48 times last season. Can Hennessy move people in the run game? That's a question he'll need to answer. -- Chris Sprow

Zuniga redshirted in 2015 and played in 48 of 55 possible games during the past four seasons at Florida (2016-19). He totaled 109 tackles, 35 tackles for loss and 19.5 sacks. Zuniga has average height and is well-built with outstanding initial burst and top-end speed for the position. He has a lot of snap in his hands and consistently stands linemen up with initial contact. He also has quick feet as a twitchy and powerful player. But he lacks some lower-body flexibility, which leads to him failing to finish as a pass-rusher at times. As a run defender, he has a quick first step and does a good job of establishing initial positioning. When he locates the ball on time, he consistently shows the ability to quickly disengage and pursue. He has very good range versus the run for a lineman. Zuniga has experience playing 4-3 DE, 3-4 DE and reducing to 3-technique on some obvious passing downs. He has an impressive natural skill set and provides versatility, and while he's not a finished product, he's capable of developing into rotating backup. -- April 2020 Zuniga is well-built with outstanding initial burst and top-end speed. He has a lot of snap in his hands and consistently stands up offensive linemen on contact. He's twitchy and powerful, but he lacks some lower-body flexibility, which leads to him failing to finish as a pass-rusher at times. He's a rangy run defender who shows the ability to disengage and pursue. He leaves it all on the field. -- Steve Muench The Jets' defense ranked 23rd in sacks with 25 last season and would have ranked lower if it weren't for defensive coordinator Gregg Williams' aggressive approach. Jordan Jenkins had a team-high eight sacks, but no other linebacker or defensive lineman had more than three. Jenkins re-signed for a year, but the Jets needed to add a young edge rusher to help bolster their pass rush and improve the pass defense. -- Steve Muench

Bowden is a versatile offensive weapon who took over as the team's starting QB during the secondhalf of 2019 so the team could get the ball in his hands more frequently. He accelerates quickly off the line but lacks ideal top-end speed and struggles to track the ball vertically. He has a small catch radius, but once the ball is in his hands, he shows good vision and elusiveness in space. He has suddenness and flexibility as a route runner but is frequently sloppy at the top of his stem and inconsistent in getting separation out of his breaks. Bowden is undersized and is an unpolished route runner but has very good agility and run-after-catch potential in the NFL. As a rookie, he should contribute as a No. 4 slot receiver and on special teams. His upside is as a No. 3 slot guy with special-teams value. -- March 2020 Bowden is a versatile offensive weapon who took over as the team's starting quarterback during the second half of the 2019 season. He's an elusive open-field runner with good vision. He returned two punts for touchdowns in 2018. He's quicker than fast and he's not as much of a threat downfield as he is after the catch. He has a small catching radius. -- Steve Muench

Read: How Bowden became one of the NFL draft's most intriguing players Bowden has a unique skill set to play multiple roles in a pro offense given his open-field vision and ability to run with the ball after the catch. With the Raiders, Bowden projects as a wide receiver who can align inside, where Jon Gruden can also manufacture touches for the Kentucky product on screens and jet sweeps. -- Matt Bowen

Edwards is a bigger receiver with average length and top-end speed. He's a smooth route runner who locates pockets in zone looks. He's instinctive and runs hard after the catch, but he lacks an elite second gear -- though he flashes the ability to make plays downfield. His hands are inconsistent, but he does have the ability to make highlight-reel catches. -- Steve Muench The Raiders did well to land Henry Ruggs III in the first round, and it's not surprising that they've further bolstered the receiving corps by adding Edwards here. Edwards is talented enough to push for a top-three role as a rookie, and he provides excellent insurance for Tyrell Williams, who was slowed by a foot injury last season. -- Steve Muench

Gallimore, a redshirt senior in 2019, was a two-year starter. He's stout at the point of attack and he flashes the ability to drive interior offensive linemen back. He tracks the ball and flashes the ability to get off blocks in time to make the play. He's tough and strong, but he plays high. He's doesn't have great athletic ability and he stalls out at times as a bull rusher, but he's an above-average hand fighter and he closes well in a straight line rushing the passer. -- March 2020 Gallimore flashes the ability to drive interior offensive linemen back and is stout for his size when he keeps his pads down. He tracks the ball well and has the ability to get off blocks in time to make the play. He doesn't have great athletic ability and stalls out at times, but Gallimore is a good hand fighter who closes well when rushing the passer. -- Steve Muench Gallimore is a reminder that 40 times don't always equal production. He comes in as an athletically gifted but inconsistent player with upside, a potential rotational disrupter on the inside of a Dallas defensive line that was addressed in free agency, but with aging veterans Gerald McCoy and Dontari Poe. And that 40 time? Under 4.8 at over 300 pounds. -- Chris Sprow

Cushenberry was a four-year player and two-year starter at LSU. He started his final 28 games at center for the Tigers. He is long and well-built, and he has excellent arm length, big hands and good overall mobility. Cushenberry is a natural knee bender with a quick set and quick hands, but he needs to get a little stronger in order to anchor better against bull rushers. As a run blocker, he takes good angles and is very effective on combo blocks and at the second level. Cushenberry is an underrated prospect who grades out as a plug-and-play NFL starting center. -- April 2020 Cushenberry is long and well-built with big hands and good overall mobility. He's a natural knee-bender with quick hands and outstanding awareness in pass pro. He needs to get a little stronger in order to anchor better versus bull-rushers. He does a good job of working up to the second level on combination blocks in the run game. -- Steve Muench You can get starting centers at this point in the draft, and that's the profile for Cushenberry, who has been a well-respected SEC starter for several years. Does he start immediately in Denver? It's possible, depending on how things play out as Cushenberry works his way in with Graham Glasgow, who plays both center and guard and came over in free agency. -- Chris Sprow

Lewis played in 11 games as a freshman in 2016, before an arm injury limited him to four games in 2017 and a torn ACL cost him the 2018 season. Lewis returned as a starter in 2019 and finished with 31 tackles, 11.5 tackles for loss and six sacks in 11 games. He has elite speed and athleticism for his size. He shows an explosive first step, has shock in his hands, displays torso flexibility and can run a tight loop. His speed-to-power moves frequently stall out, and he lacks some sand in the trunk -- but he does a good job of setting the edge with his long arms and powerful upperbody. Lewis is physical and aggressive against the run, and he gives good effort in pursuit. Lewis' game tape is limited due to multiple injuries, but when healthy, he has been a productive edge rusher and edge setter. He's a bit underrated at this point, and he can develop into an impact three-down starter in the NFL. -- March 2020 Lewis has long arms, powerful hands and elite speed and athleticism for his size. He has an explosive first step and the flexibility to run a tight loop rushing the passer. He's a physical and aggressive run defender who gives good effort in pursuit. Lewis was considered a team leader at Alabama even though he missed most of the 2017 season and all of 2018 with injuries. -- Steve Muench Lewis is a value pick late on Day 2 with the physical makeup and athletic traits to rush off the edge. The Rams added veteran Leonard Floyd on a one-year deal, but the key here is finding a replacement for Dante Fowler, who signed with the Falcons in free agency. -- Matt Bowen

Blackmon, a true senior in 2019, was named an All-Pac-12 corner twice and an All-Pac-12 safety in 2019. He plays the ball not the man in zone and has enough range to cover a deep half. He's not a center fielder. He lacks ideal recovery speed. He picked off nine passes over the past three seasons. He flashes above-average ball skills. He's willing to square up in run support and he tends to limit production after the catch. Sub-par angles lead to some missed tackles. He sustained a noncontact knee injury in the Pac-12 championship game and did not work out at the combine. -- March 2020 Blackmon has enough range to cover a deep half, but he's not a center fielder. He lacks ideal recovery speed but flashes very good ball skills -- he picked off nine passes over the past three seasons. Blackmon is willing to square up in run support, though subpar angles lead to some missed tackles. -- Steve Muench Blackmon jumps into the mix with safeties Malik Hooker and Khari Willis in Indianapolis. And he fits the scheme for the Colts, with range, the ability to play in split-safety looks and the coverage traits they want. -- Matt Bowen

Moss is the first player in Utah history with three 1,000 rushing-yard seasons. He's a big back with the power, balance and determination to regularly pick up yards after first contact. He does not have elite playing speed, but his playing speed is better than his timed speed. He flashes the ability to pick up chunk yards. He has above-average hands, and he's tough to bring down when he gets the ball in space. He's a below-average route runner. He's a willing pass blocker with the size and strength to hold his ground. Career fumble percentage (1.03) is somewhat concerning, but he did a good job of taking care of the football for the most part in 2019. -- March 2020 Moss is a big back with the power, balance and determination to regularly pick up yards after first contact. His playing speed is a little better than his timed speed. He has solid hands and is tough to bring down when he gets the ball in space. He's a willing pass-blocker with the size and strength to hold his ground. -- Steve Muench The Bills might have just created one of the more promising young RB pairs in the NFL, and with a pair of third-rounders. (Hm. Sounds very 2020.) They nabbed Devin Singletary last year, and he averaged 5.1 yards per rush, tops among qualified rookies. The other three Bills running backs currently under contract for 2020 combined for 29 rushes. Moss adds a power element and fills a clear void. -- Chris Sprow

In four seasons and 54 games played at Alabama (2016-19), Jennings has totaled 193 tackles, 34.5 tackles for loss and 15.5 sacks (14.5 of which were his past two seasons). Jennings is a powerfully-built edge defender who is stout versus the run and can set a hard edge. He will never be an elite pass-rusher in the NFL, but he has an underrated combination of quickness, change-of-direction ability, power and instincts. He has a nose for the ball, shows snap as a tackler and is a strong finisher. And his motor and toughness stand out. Jennings is a solid every-down player with NFL starting potential. -- March 2020 Jennings is a stout run defender who sets the edge, has a nose for the ball and shows good snap as a tackler. He will never be an elite pass-rusher in the NFL, but he has an underrated combination of quickness, change-of-direction ability, power and instincts. He's tough and has an outstanding motor. -- Steve Muench Edge defenders are a big need in New England, and Jennings could work his way into the rotation given his experience and that he possesses a trait Bill Belichick likes: He's a strong edge defender who plays his assignment -- think Rob Ninkovich. So what you won't get in sack totals you get back in defending the run. -- Chris Sprow

Elliott, a redshirt junior in 2019, transferred to Missouri from Texas in 2017. He shoots his hands inside, locates the ball and flashes the ability to get off blocks in time to make the play. He has the first-step quickness and agility to make plays in the backfield. He's inconsistent taking on double-teams. He flashes above-average power rushing the passer. There's still some room for improvement in this area, but he flashes potential as a hand fighter. He closes well and tends to chase with above-average effort. -- March 2020 Elliott shoots his hands inside, locates the ball and gets off blocks in time to make the play. He has the first-step quickness to make plays in the backfield. He flashes good power and the ability to win with his hands rushing the passer. He closes well and tends to chase with above-average effort. -- Steve Muench Elliott provides more defensive line depth for the Browns to shore up the interior with Larry Ogunjobi entering his contract year. Elliott has the upside of a disruptive defensive tackle, with the active feet and hands to win at the point of attack. -- Matt Bowen

Dantzler was a four-year player and two-year starter at Mississippi State. Over the past two seasons, he combined for 83 tackles, 17 passes broken up and four INTs. He has very good height with adequate bulk but short arms, especially for his frame. He also has below-average speed for the position (his 4.64 at the combine was the second-slowest 40 time of all the cornerbacks). He is very instinctive in man and zone coverage, and he shows quick feet and smooth hips. While he lacks ideal top-end speed, he does a good job protecting himself. Dantzler also gets his hands on a lot of balls. He takes good angles and shows solid timing when attacking the ball -- but those ball skills are inconsistent, and he has some drops on tape. Dantzler is not very strong but has average open-field tackling skills. He has the instincts and coverage skills to develop into a solid NFL starting cornerback, ideally in a zone-heavy scheme. -- April 2020 Dantzler has short arms, and he ran the second-slowest 40-yard dash time out of the all the corners at the combine, but he has excellent instincts, quick feet and smooth hips.
