While his hands are inconsistent, he gets them on a lot of passes, picking off four over the past two seasons. Dantzler is a solid open-field tackler. -- Steve Muench We said the Vikings probably weren't done addressing the cornerback position when they took Jeff Gladney in the first round, and general manager Rick Spielman adds an intriguing corner here. Dantzler fell because he didn't run well, but he's a tough press corner, making him a good fit for the Vikings, and he has the confidence to push for early playing time. -- Steve Muench

Greenard was a four-year player at Louisville before transferring to Florida. At Florida in 2019, Greenard totaled 52 tackles, 15.5 tackles for loss, 9.5 sacks and three forced fumbles. He has average height, solid bulk, long arms and average top-end speed. He shows good short-area quickness and power. Greenard is naturally instinctive and knows how to finish. He lacks elite speed and will never be a high-level NFL pass-rusher. He has a great motor, and he's a tough and physical player. He grades out as a backup edge rusher. -- April 2020 Greenard has average height, solid bulk, long arms and below-average top-end speed. He shows good short-area quickness and power. He's instinctive and knows how to finish. He's a tough overachiever with an excellent motor. Greenard's upside as a pass-rusher is limited by his below-average closing speed. -- Steve Muench Greenard is a developmental edge defender with power and heavy hands on contact. And that will be his path to earning reps as a rookie in the Houston scheme. Without high-end athletic traits and closing speed, Greenard will have to rely on his technique to produce sack numbers in the pros. -- Matt Bowen

Asiasi is a redshirt junior who transferred to UCLA from Michigan in 2017. His production exploded over his last three games at UCLA, and he flashes on tape. He lines up in-line and works out of the slot. He's athletic for his size and he flashes as a route runner. He's a natural hands catcher with above-average length and body control. He's fast enough to get behind linebackers and threaten vertically. He needs to get stronger at the point, but he gets into position and fights as a blocker. He's also tough over the middle and runs hard after the catch. -- March 2020 Asiasi has a good blend of size, speed and length. He's athletic for his size and shows some upside as a route runner. He's a natural hands catcher with above-average body control. He's fast enough to get behind linebackers and threaten vertically. He needs to get stronger at the point of attack, but he gets into position and fights as a blocker. -- Steve Muench New England tight ends combined for a league-low 37 catches and tied for last with two touchdowns last season. Rob Gronkowski is a Buccaneer and Ben Watson retired. The Pats haven't drafted a tight end earlier than the fifth round since they took Gronkowski in the second round in 2010. Asiasi is the best tight end on the roster day one, and he has good upside. -- Steve Muench

Duvernay, a true senior in 2019, was a two-year starter who broke out in 2019, catching 106 passes for 1,386 yards (13.1 yards per catch) and nine touchdowns. He ranked second in the FBS in catches and fifth in receiving yards. He's a slot receiver built like a running back. He has the contact balance and burst to threaten after the catch. He tracks the ball well, and he's more than fast enough to threaten vertically. He's a natural hands catcher and he flashes the ability to make contested catches even though he has a smaller frame and shorter arms. He's tough working the middle of the field. He's not a complete or polished route runner. His cousin is Cardinals quarterback Kyler Murray. -- March 2020 Duvernay is a slot receiver built like a running back who has excellent top-end speed. He has the contact balance and burst to threaten after the catch. He has the second gear to threaten vertically. Duvernay has a smaller frame and shorter arms, but he's a natural hands catcher. He's not a complete or fluid route runner. -- Steve Muench The Ravens lack depth at wide receiver. Their wide receivers had the fewest receiving yards (1,419) in the league last season, 228 fewer than the next-closest team. Yes, they could run the ball. Yes, QB Lamar Jackson got a lot out of his tight ends. And yes, a well-built, productive, experienced (likely) slot WR who runs 4.39 and offers consistent hands is going to help. Possibly early. -- Chris Sprow

Evans is slightly undersized with outstanding explosiveness and top-end speed. He shows good burst through the hole. He's an instinctive open-field runner with good elusiveness, and he's tough for his size when he gets into space. He's got experience lining up at receiver, and he's a threat after the catch. -- Steve Muench Derrick Henry is expected to work out a long-term deal in Tennessee, but he caught just 18 passes in 2019 and the Titans made Dion Lewis a cap casualty. Evans projects as an above-average No. 2 back who has experience lining up at receiver and is dangerous after the catch, making him a good complement to Henry. Evans is also a dangerous kick returner capable of helping the Titans in that area as well. -- Steve Muench

Deguara is a lighter tight end with short arms, smaller hands and slightly above-average top-end speed. He flashes as a vertical route runner, and he's fast enough to make plays down the seam. He's not as much of a threat after the catch. He has good hands. He's not big enough to hold up as an in-line blocker. -- Steve Muench The Packers have yet to address the wide receiver position in this draft, but they add a pass-catching tight end in Deguara. Paired with second-year man Jace Sternberger, Green Bay now has two tight ends to stretch the seams and run crossers for quarterback Aaron Rodgers off play-action in Matt LaFleur's offense. -- Matt Bowen

Agim has good size and length, and flashes above-average initial quickness and the ability to blow up plays in the backfield. He chases the run with above-average effort and finishes. There's room for improvement when it comes to his hand-to-hand combat skills, but he flashes skills as a pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench Denver did well to get Jurrell Casey for a seventh-round pick, but the Broncos have several players on one-year deals, plus Derek Wolfe left for Baltimore and Adam Gotsis is unsigned. Adding Agim improves the Broncos' depth and gives them a player capable of pushing for the starting role opposite Casey in time. -- Steve Muench

Niang, a true senior in 2019, started 28 games at right tackle over the past three seasons. He played left tackle in high school. He's massive with very good length. He walls off defenders and flashes the ability to move defenders off the ball in the run game. He's athletic enough to get into position and overwhelms linebackers when climbing to the second level. He has the length, width and enough foot speed to develop into an elite pass-blocker. He lacks polish, particularly for a three-year starter. He's frequently high and wide with his hands in the run game. His footwork is inconsistent. His killer instinct is inconsistent. There are concerns about his ability to keep his weight down, although it's worth noting that he weighed in at 315 pounds at the combine. -- March 2020 Niang walls off defenders and flashes the ability to generate push in the run game. He's athletic enough to get into positon and big enough to overwhelm linebackers climbing to the second level. Niang has the length, width and enough foot speed to develop into an elite pass-blocker. His hand placement and footwork are inconsistent. -- Steve Muench The Chiefs have Eric Fisher and Mitchell Schwartz at left and right tackle, respectively, and both are signed through 2021, which makes Niang a developmental play and immediate depth as well as a decent value given he's ranked a tad ahead of where the Chiefs were able to scoop him up. Starting upside at tackle isn't a bad play knowing whom the Chiefs need to protect for years to come. -- Chris Sprow

Phillips is tall and lean with good speed and explosive lower-body strength. He has average quickness and change-of-direction skills in coverage, and he is at his best in underneath zone coverage. But he is too limited to be consistently trusted in man-to-man coverage against NFL running backs. Phillips also does not offer much as a pass-rusher and is moved too easily by bigger blockers. He grades out as a backup off-the-ball linebacker and will need to contribute on special teams. -- March 2020 Phillips is a tall and lean linebacker with good speed and explosive lower-body strength. He's a disciplined run defender who understands fits, but he gets moved too often by bigger blockers. He is at his best in underneath zone coverage. He's too limited to be consistently trusted in man coverage, and he does not offer much as a pass-rusher. He has experience covering kicks and punts, too. -- Steve Muench Joe Schobert signed with Jacksonville and Christian Kirksey with Green Bay after the Browns cut him. So Cleveland had to address a run defense that ranked 30th in the league last season. Look for Phillips to compete for a starting outside linebacker job flanking Mack Wilson and make an immediate impact on special teams. -- Steve Muench

A former high school quarterback, safety and punter, Harrison racked up 156 tackles, 25 tackles for loss, 7.5 sacks and two interceptions in his final two seasons. He has an outstanding combination of size and straight-line speed, but he is a better pass-rusher than coverage linebacker. He has the power to knock offensive linemen back onto their heels but needs to develop better counter moves. Harrison has some tightness in his hips and will struggle to lock down NFL running backs one-on-one. He has explosive initial pop but overall take-on skills need to improve in the run game. And he is inconsistent with recognition skills and angles. Harrison has matured but multiple scouts and coaches have said he needs to be motivated. Harrison has the physical tools to develop into a starting NFL linebacker (best suited for SILB or MLB), and he is a likely Day 2 prospect. -- March 2020 Harrison has an outstanding combination of size and speed. He flashes explosive pop taking on blockers as a run defender and rushing the passer, but he needs to improve his hand-to-hand combat skills. He's more effective rushing the passer than he is dropping into coverage. -- Steve Muench In 2019, Baltimore allowed 4.4 yards per carry -- the most in a season in franchise history. How do you fix that? Add two young linebackers who can track the ball in the run game. The Ravens grab Harrison here, with his 6-foot-3, 247-pound frame, after drafting LSU's Patrick Queen on Day 1. -- Matt Bowen

Peart, a team captain and four-year starter, played on the left side for two seasons and on the right side for two seasons. He possesses a rare blend of size, speed and length. He flashes potential on tape. He wins with natural ability but technique needs to improve for him to reach considerable upside in pass pro. His hand placement is inconsistent, and he doesn't jar defenders with initial punch. His footwork is good initially but gets sloppy. Quick inside moves give him some problems. He has the size and athletic ability to develop into an above-average run blocker. There are similar technique issues, though. His pads rise and he loses his base. He lunges at times and he needs to tighten up his footwork. His effort is good but he's not a glass-eater. -- April 2020 Peart was a team captain and four-year starter and has a rare blend of size, speed and length. He has exceptional upside and flashes on tape. He needs to improve his overall technique, notably his hand placement in pass pro and his pad level in the run game. Peart's effort is good, but he's not a glass-eater. He has experience playing on the right and left sides. -- Steve Muench Getting Andrew Thomas in the first round didn't prevent general manager Dave Gettleman from taking a developmental tackle with high upside and experience playing on both sides here. Even with Thomas ideally locking down one tackle spot, the Giants will likely try to upgrade over Nate Solder, and Cameron Fleming isn't a long-term starter. Peart could be the player to supplant Solder in time. -- Steve Muench

Muse, a redshirt senior in 2019, was a three-year starter who turned heads by posting the second-fastest 40 time for the safety group at the combine. He reads the quarterback and rarely gets caught out of position. He runs well in a straight line but he's tight and struggles to change directions quickly on tape. He tracks the ball and flashes opportunistic ball skills. He's a hard-nosed run defender who doesn't shy away from contact and chases with good effort. -- March 2020 Muse turned heads by posting the second-fastest 40-yard dash time for the safety group at the combine. He reads the quarterback and rarely gets caught out of position. He runs well in a straight line but is tight and struggles to change directions quickly on tape. He tracks the ball and flashes opportunistic ball skills. And he's a hard-nosed run defender. -- Steve Muench The Raiders allowed 8.3 yards per attempt (worst in the NFL) and 33 passing touchdowns in 2019, so for the second time in this draft they've added secondary help to a unit that was, overall, arguably the worst pass defense in the NFL. The question on Muse is whether he's a true safety and actually sticks in the secondary in a classic sense, or if he moves into more of a linebacker role, because the 4.41 speed screams safety, but he's an effective run defender. -- Chris Sprow

Keene is versatile enough to line up in-line, in the slot and in the backfield. He gets north-south and he runs hard after the catch. He's not much of a big-play threat on tape, and he's a below-average route runner. He tested better than expected at the combine and has the tools to get better in both areas. He's tough and he frequently battles to a stalemate as an in-line blocker. He has the potential to develop into a reliable safety valve in the passing game. -- March 2020 Keene is versatile enough to line up in-line, in the slot and in the backfield. He gets north-south and he runs hard after the catch. He's not much of a big-play threat on tape and he's a below-average route runner but he tested better than expected at the combine and has the tools to get better in both areas. He's tough and he frequently battles to a stalemate as an in-line blocker. -- Steve Muench It's not surprising that the Patriots took tight ends with consecutive picks considering how much of a need they had at the position and the success they've had when they have had depth there, i.e., Rob Gronkowski and Martellus Bennett. But it is surprising that they took Keene over Dayton tight end Adam Trautman. Keene is a good player who will help New England, but Trautman is the better prospect. -- Steve Muench

Highsmith, a two-year starter and former walk-on, broke the 49ers' single-season school record for tackles for loss with 17.5 in 2018, then broke his own record with 21.5 in 2019. He has good initial quickness and closing speed in addition to flashing violent hands and an effective inside move. He's a disruptive run defender with good range but lacks ideal length and size for a defensive end. He projects best at 3-4 OLB. -- Steve Muench Highsmith's disruptive play style is a fit for the Steelers' 3-4 front, where the Charlotte product can develop behind starters T.J. Watt and Bud Dupree. He's an ascending prospect with pass-rush upside at the pro level. -- Matt Bowen

Taylor's mother is a member of the Seventh-day Adventist Church, which is distinguished by its observance of Saturday -- so he did not participate in sporting activities from Friday night until Sunday morning during high school. He got her blessing to play on Saturdays after high school and walked on at a junior college. He transferred to Colorado in 2018 and turned into a two-year starter. He was an All-Pac-12 sprinter thanks to his sixth-place finish in the 100-meter dash at the 2018 Pac-12 outdoor championships. Taylor is a hybrid linebacker/safety with very good top-end speed and below-average length. He has the burst and athletic ability to compete in man, as well as the speed to carry tight ends down the seam. He closes well and limits production after the catch, breaking on plays in front of him. Taylor wraps on contact and flashes above-average stopping power. He doesn't always appear to chase the run with great effort, and he doesn't cover as much ground as his timed speed would suggest, but he has the potential to develop into a sideline-to-sideline player. Taylor fights through blocks in space and flashes the ability to stack blockers -- but he gets pushed around and takes too long to get off blocks. He grades out as a sub-package linebacker and special-teams contributor with some upside. -- April 2020 Taylor is a hybrid linebacker/safety with less-than-ideal size, very good top-end speed and below-average length for a linebacker. He has the burst and athletic ability to compete in man coverage. He wraps on contact and flashes very good stopping power. He doesn't cover as much ground as timed speed suggests, but he has the potential to develop into a sideline-to-sideline player. -- Steve Muench The Eagles declined Nigel Bradham's option and Kamu Grugier-Hill signed with the Dolphins. Nathan Gerry missed too many tackles last season, free-agent acquisition Jatavis Brown makes more of an impact on special teams than on defense, and 2019 undrafted free agent T.J. Edwards played just 110 snaps. So the Eagles had a pressing need at linebacker. Taylor should make an immediate impact on third down and develop into a starter in time. -- Steve Muench

Burgess, a true senior in 2019, plays high, drops into the box and lines up over the slot. He's competitive matching up with tight ends and slot receivers. He has the range to cover a deep half. He's not a ball hawk or a natural hands catcher. He's an above-average tackler who closes in a flash. He flashes the ability to slip blocks in the box. He has very short arms, and it's an issue at times, most notably in his ability to break up passes and keep blockers off his frame. -- March 2020 Burgess is versatile enough to play high, drop into the box or line up over the slot. He's competitive matching up with tight ends and slot receivers. He's an above-average tackler who closes in a flash, and he shows the ability to slip blocks playing close to the line of scrimmage. But he's not a ball hawk or playmaker. -- Steve Muench Nickell Robey-Coleman left the Rams for the Eagles this offseason after allowing just 5.4 yards per target in the slot last season. That ranked second among 27 players with at least 40 slot targets in 2019, trailing only Tyrann Mathieu (4.9). Good company. Burgess could see slot time as a college safety with cornerback traits. He offers versatility the Rams could need early in his career as a nickel defender. -- Chris Sprow

Trautman, a team captain and four-year starter, broke the school's season record for receptions with 70 in 2019 and eased concerns about the level of competition he faced at Dayton with a strong Senior Bowl showing. He ran the third fastest three-cone time at the combine, he's quicker than fast, and he flashes as a route runner. He drew a lot of attention and got mugged when he wasn't doubled against San Diego. He's not a track star, but he plays a little faster than timed speed and has the frame to win 50-50 balls downfield. He flashes after the catch. He elevates well and high-points jump balls. Dayton split him out wide and threw fades to him. His technique is inconsistent, but he's a willing blocker who plays with an edge. -- March 2020 Trautman ran the third-fastest three-cone time at the combine, is quicker than fast and flashes as a route runner. He's not a track star, but he plays a little faster than his timed speed and has got the frame to win 50-50 balls downfield. Trautman is good after the catch. His technique is inconsistent, but he's a willing blocker who plays with an edge. -- Steve Muench Trautman is an absolute steal this late in the draft, and while tight end might not be a pressing need for the Saints, adding one makes some sense with Jared Cook turning 33 earlier this month. Trautman can make an impact in a limited role and give coach Sean Payton yet another weapon as a rookie, developing into a starter over time. -- Steve Muench

Phillips is a massive tackle with big hands and outstanding length. He's a powerful run-blocker with the size to engulf defenders and move them off the ball, but he's a limited athlete who fits better in a power-heavy scheme than in a zone scheme. His big frame and length make it tough to get around him in pass pro. He has some problems mirroring and needs to improve his hand-to-hand combat skills. -- Steve Muench With Ronnie Stanley entering his contract year, Phillips fits in Baltimore as a developmental tackle. Phillips has a massive frame, with the ability to move people off the ball in the Ravens' run-heavy system. -- Matt Bowen

Davis-Gaither is a two-year starter who racked up 209 tackles and 24.5 tackles for loss over the past two seasons. He's a rangy outside linebacker with a good motor. He's light with short arms so there are naturally concerns about his ability to hold up against the run in the NFL. However, his take-on skills aren't a concern on tape. He plays with good pad level and understands how to leverage blocks. He has active hands and he slips blocks. He has above-average cover skills and he flashes potential as a pass-rusher. He has the skill set to develop into a core special-teams player. He did not run at the combine, where the NFL Network reported that he would undergo surgery to repair a partial stress fracture in his right foot. -- April 2020 Davis-Gaither is rangy outside linebacker with a good motor. He's light with short arms, so there are naturally concerns about his ability to hold up against the run in the NFL, but his take-on skills aren't a concern on tape. He plays with good pad level and understands how to leverage blocks. He has good cover skills and could help as a pass-rusher. Davis-Gaither has the skill set to develop into a core special-teams player. -- Steve Muench

Charles was a three-year player at LSU who played in 32 games (28 starts). He played mostly at left tackle but also started games at right tackle and guard. He's physically gifted but still raw and will need time to develop in the NFL. He is strong with a good center of gravity in the run game, and he moves well on screens and as a second-level blocker. But he has shorter arms and has a lot of work to do with his hand placement and overall technique. It was surprising that he left LSU early -- he needs more seasoning. Charles has raw talent with upside if properly developed. -- April 2020 Charles is strong run-blocker who moves well climbing to the second level. He's a developmental prospect who is physically gifted but has shorter arms for a tackle and has a lot of work to do with his overall technique. Charles primarily lined up at left tackle, but he also started games at right tackle and guard. -- Steve Muench

Simpson was a four-year player and two-year starter at guard for Clemson. He is tall with good bulk and long arms. Simpson has average top-end speed for a guard but a marginal 20-yard shuttle result (4.87 is a red-flag number). The only position he played in college was guard, but he has the potential to play right tackle or possibly center in the NFL -- but he is definitely best suited to play guard. In pass protection, he shows adequate short-area quickness and above-average awareness. Simpson struggles to mirror at times and tends to lunge when stressed, though. As a run blocker, he's not a mauler but takes good angles and has average overall mobility. Simpson grades out as a potential starting guard in the NFL and is likely to be drafted in the middle rounds. -- April 2020 Simpson is a big guard with long arms and slightly above-average top-end speed. He has the quickness, length and wide frame to compete but struggles to mirror in pass pro. He's an average positional blocker who takes sound angles in the run game. Guard is the only positon Simpson played in college, but he has the potential to play right tackle or center.

Holmes, a true junior in 2019 and a three-year starter, has below average size, short arms and slightly above average top-end speed. He stays low in pedal, he closes well breaking on passes in front of him, and he flashes good stopping power after the catch. He shows good awareness and plays the ball not the man in zone. He's undersized for an outside corner. He lacks ideal change of direction and burst for a nickel. He doesn't play as fast as his timed top-end speed and he gets beaten over the top. He has very short arms and he's not a natural hands catcher, yet he tracks the ball well and finds ways to come down with it. He's tough for his size and willing in run support. He struggles to get off blocks and slips off some tackles. -- April 2020 Holmes is undersized with short arms and good timed speed. He closes well breaking on passes in front of him, and he flashes good stopping power after the catch. He shows awareness in zone. Holmes is undersized for an outside corner, and he lacks ideal change-of-direction for a nickel. He doesn't play as fast as timed top-end speed and he gets beat over the top. -- Steve Muench

Kindley played in 42 games with 32 starts, all at guard. He is wide-bodied with average arm length and big hands. He shows good awareness in pass protection but limited range. He's more country strong than powerful, and he ends up on the ground too often and falls off too many blocks. Kindley grades out as a backup guard with enough potential to possibly develop into a starter in the NFL. -- April 2020 Kindley is a massive guard with below-average arm length, He's a strong run-blocker but falls off blocks and ends up on the ground too much. He shows good awareness but doesn't mirror well in pass pro. He has started at left and right guard. -- Steve Muench

Kelley is the eighth running back in UCLA history to record back-to-back 1,000-yard rushing seasons. He's a shifty between-the-tackles runner with good patience. He's built well and he runs with good forward lean. He doesn't play quite as fast as timed speed and he's not an ankle-breaker in space, but he's fast enough to rip off chunk yards when he gets a seam. He's willing to step up and he flashes the ability to anchor in pass pro. He's effective chipping defensive ends. He caught just 11 passes in 2019, but he appears capable of developing into an effective receiver. He has a professional work ethic. -- March 2020 Kelley is a shifty between-the-tackles runner with good patience. He's built well and runs with good forward lean. He doesn't play as fast as his timed speed but is fast enough to rip off chunk yards when he gets a seam. Kelley is willing to step up in pass pro and appears capable of developing into an effective receiver. -- Steve Muench

Pride was a four-year player and two-year starter at Notre Dame. During his final two seasons, Pride recorded 87 tackles, 18 pass deflections and three interceptions. He was also a sprinter on the track team in 2018. Pride has solid size and excellent top-end speed but shorter arms. He has experience playing outside and inside. He has really strong instincts, he does a good job of reading the quarterback's eyes, and he consistently gets early jumps on the ball in zone coverage. Pride can run with any receiver in the NFL if his feet are right. He has easy speed and never looks as though he's laboring to match speed vertically. He shows good balance but does have some tightness in his hips and will give up some separation man-to-man against quicker receivers. He gets grabby at times, and his lack of ideal length will put some limitations on his ability to regularly match up with bigger receivers. But Pride has soft hands and has flashed the ability to pluck, though he struggles to track the ball vertically and will occasionally get in trouble when the ball is in the air. He is inconsistent with his aggressiveness against the run -- he wraps high but tends to wrestle ball carriers to the ground. Pride grades out as sub-package corner with the ability to develop into a solid No. 3 starter in the NFL. -- March 2020 Pride has average size and excellent top-end speed. He does a good job of reading the quarterback's eyes and gets early jumps on the ball in zone coverage. He can run with any receiver in the NFL if his feet are right, but he struggles to track the ball vertically. He has soft hands and shows the ability to pluck the ball out of the air. He has shorter arms and a smaller catching radius. -- Steve Muench

Fotu, a team captain in 2019, was a two-year starter. He's a massive interior run stuffer with the ability to clog up the middle when he plays with sound technique. His pad level is inconsistent, and he gives ground at times. He's a limited pass-rusher who tends to stall out and doesn't show the ability to win with his hands with any consistency. -- March 2020 Fotu is a massive interior run-stuffer with the ability to clog up the middle when he plays with sound technique. His pad level is inconsistent, and he gives ground at times. He's a limited pass-rusher who tends to stall out and doesn't show the ability to regularly win with his hands. -- Steve Muench

Bryant, a three-year starter, became just the third Florida Atlantic player to surpass the single-season 1,000-yard receiving mark in 2019. He's an instinctive and slippery open-field runner with the strength to pick up yards after initial contact. He has enough top-end speed to make plays down the seam. He made some tough catches, but we also counted three drops against Ohio State in 2019. He lacks the size and core strength to hold up as an in-line blocker. He tends to get into position and wall off his assignment as a lead blocker and in space. He's a persistent blocker, he runs hard, and he's tough over the middle. -- April 2020 Bryant is a light receiving tight end with below-average length and good top-end speed. He's an instinctive and slippery open-field runner with the strength to pick up yards after initial contact. He's fast enough to make plays down the seam. Bryant made some tough catches, but we also counted three drops against Ohio State in 2019. -- Steve Muench

Bartch is a Division III player who moved from tight end to left tackle, where he started 27 games over the past two seasons. His arm length is a red flag for a tackle, and he projects best at guard in the NFL. He tends to get his hands inside, and he's tough to shake once he locks on in pass pro. He is a glass-eater and overpowering run-blocker on tape. He showed that he can compete at a much higher level the week of the Senior Bowl. -- Steve Muench

In four seasons, Wonnum combined for 137 tackles, 29.5 tackles for loss and 14 sacks. Wonnum is a tall, high-cut and somewhat lean edge rusher with long arms. As a pass-rusher, he has the length and agility to continue to develop. He has quick hands but needs to develop more effective counter moves when reached and a power element. As a run defender, he uses his long arms to lock out but typically gives too much ground when isolated, even against some tight ends. Wonnum is at his best when he is able to stay on the move and pursue. He plays with a good motor but could use a little more nastiness at times. Wonnum has the tools to develop into a contributing backup edge defender in the NFL -- possibly a RDE in a 4-3 but he could also fit as a 3-4 OLB. -- March 2020 Wonnum is a high-cut and somewhat lean EDGE with long arms. He has the quick hands, length and agility to develop into a disruptive edge rusher. He needs to develop counter moves and add a power element to his game. Wonnum flashes the ability to lock out and keep defenders off his frame, but he typically gives ground when he's isolated in the run game. -- Steve Muench

Okwuegbunam is a redshirt junior whose production didn't match his talent at the college level. He has the natural ability to make more of an impact in the NFL. He has a rare combination of size, speed, length and hand span. He lines up wide, in the slot and in line. He has the potential to develop into a zone-buster and he flashes the ability to settle into windows. He's a below-average route runner who struggles to separate without pushing off. He has the speed to threaten vertically and after the catch, yet he averaged 11.8 yards per reception in 2019. His biggest weakness is as an in-line blocker. He needs to get stronger and more aggressive. He missed the final four games of the 2018 season and missed some time in 2019 with shoulder injuries. -- March 2020 Okwuegbunam has a rare combination of size, speed, length and hand span. He lines up wide, in the slot and inline. His tape and production did not match his talent. He's a below-average route runner who struggles to separate without pushing off. Okwuegbunam has the speed to threaten vertically and after the catch, yet he averaged just 11.8 yards per catch last season. -- Steve Muench

Walker has good speed and length with adequate size. He's a rangy run defender and above-average tackler. He's tough and flashes the ability to stack blockers. He shows good awareness in coverage and as a pass-rusher. He's a versatile player who lined up at inside linebacker, outside linebacker and defensive end his senior year. He has the potential to make an immediate impact on special teams. -- Steve Muench

A patient, physical runner with a strong center of gravity, Perine has a sturdy build with average timed-speed. He shows adequate acceleration to and through the hole but lacks lateral quickness to create a lot of yards on his own. He also lacks a second gear when he hits daylight. He does have reliable ball skills, he covers up the ball in traffic, and he transitions quickly upfield. He is solid underneath option but will never be a dynamic route runner or home-run threat in the pass game. Perine has size and strength as a blocker, but he's not as aggressive as he needs to be in pass protection. He grades out as a rotational backup in the NFL. -- April 2020 Perine is a patient and physical runner with average size and a strong center of gravity. He has the potential to develop into a reliable checkdown in the passing game and an effective pass-blocker, though he's not as aggressive as he needs to be in pass pro at this point. He shows adequate burst through the hole but lacks the lateral quickness to create yards on his own and the second gear to pull away when he hits daylight. -- Steve Muench

Stenberg was a five-year player and three-year starter at Kentucky. He started all 39 games over the past three seasons. He has outstanding size and good strength but only marginal speed and overall athleticism. He's a glass-eater with an ideal temperament and a nasty mauler. In pass protection, he has a powerful punch to jar defenders and doesn't give up much ground versus bull rushers. But he struggles to mirror versus quick-twitch interior pass-rushers. As a run blocker, he plays angry, takes great angles and has very good hand placement. He latches on and is strong enough to bring his hips and feet around, though he struggles to reach as a second-level blocker and gets off-balance in space. Stenberg grades out as a backup guard early in his NFL career and has enough upside to potentially develop into a starter. -- March 2020 Stenberg is a nasty mauler with good size and strength. He takes great angles, he latches on with strong hands, and he's strong enough to generate push in the run game. He flashes a powerful punch and anchors well in pas pro. Stenberg has marginal athletic ability, and he struggles to mirror quick-twitch interior pass-rushers. -- Steve Muench

Eason started 12 games at Georgia as a true freshman in 2016 but lost his starting job to Jake Fromm after hurting his knee in 2017. He transferred to Washington and redshirted in accordance with NCAA rules in 2018. He started all 13 games in 2019 and finished with the fourth-highest single-season passing-yard total in school history. Eason is a tall, well-built quarterback with a slightly below-average hand span and slightly below-average top-end speed. He has the arm talent to drive the ball into tight windows and outside the hashes. He flashes the ability to drop the ball in the bucket and displays good touch on downfield throws. He misses within strike zone, and there's room for improvement when it comes to leading receivers on short-to-intermediate throws. Eason is an erratic decision-maker and doesn't perform well enough under pressure at this point. He gets caught locking on. He flashes the ability to spin away from pressure and step up in the pocket but shows just average pocket presence and mobility. Eason grades out as an intriguing quarterback prospect with great size and arm strength but needs to be more consistent in terms of his accuracy and decision-making to realize his considerable upside. -- April 2020 Eason has excellent size and the arm strength to drive the ball into tight windows and outside the hashes. He's a streaky passer who misses within the strike zone, and there's room for improvement when it comes to leading receivers on short-to-intermediate throws. He's an erratic decision-maker, but he has adequate pocket mobility (though he's not much of a threat to run). -- Steve Muench

Robinson has excellent size and top-end speed. He reads the quarterback and shows good instincts in off coverage. He has small hands, but he breaks up a lot of passes. He had four interceptions last year. He flashes good stopping power for a corner. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. -- Steve Muench

McFarland, a redshirt sophomore in 2019, set Maryland's single-season freshman record for rushing yards and rushed for 298 yards against Ohio State in 2018. He has good burst through the hole and around the corner. He has the second gear to pull away when he gets a crease. He's a tough runner who fights for yards after contact and flashes above-average finishing power. He flashes above-average ball skills, and he's a threat after the catch. Tape raises concerns about awareness and consistent willingness to mix it up in pass pro. He did a better job of taking care of the ball in 2019, but career fumble percentage (1.49) is concerning. -- March 2020 McFarland shows good good burst through the hole and around the corner. He has the second gear to pull away when he gets a crease. McFarland is a tough runner who fights for yards after contact and flashes good finishing power. He has solid ball skills and is a threat after the catch.

Morgan is a natural leader with good toughness and size. He has a quick release and a strong arm. He flashes the ability to manipulate the coverage with his eyes, and his touchdown-to-interception ratio greatly improved over the past two seasons. He will force throws when he gets pressured. He's a streaky passer with below-average touch. He has adequate pocket mobility, but he's not much of a threat as a runner. -- Steve Muench

Heck was a three-year starter who moved from right tackle to left tackle in 2019. He has a smooth kick step and enough length to push speed rushers past the quarterback. He rewraps and works hands back inside when he misses with initial punch. He does an adequate bend of sinking and anchoring, particularly for a player his size. He oversets and gets beaten to the inside. He gets into position and walls off defenders in the run game. He's late shooting hands, and hand placement is inconsistent. His pads rise and he falls off blocks late. He's not a glass eater. His father, Andy, was a first-team All-America offensive tackle for Notre Dame and is the offensive line coach for the Kansas City Chiefs. -- April 2020 Heck has a smooth kickstep and enough length to push speed rushers past the quarterback. He re-wraps and works hands back inside when he misses with his initial punch. He also gets into position and walls off defenders in the run game. But his pads rise, and he falls off blocks late. -- Steve Muench

Wallace, a team captain in 2019 and two-year starter, is at his best lining up over the slot, where he has the instincts and athletic ability to compete. He's not big or long enough to regularly match up with tight ends, and he doesn't have center-field range. He's tough and he's an adequate tackler for the position. He's an instinctive pass-rusher who finds seams in protections and closes well. -- March 2020 Wallace is a safety/nickel corner at his best lining up over the slot, where he has the instincts and athletic ability to compete. He's not big or long enough to regularly match up with tight ends and he doesn't have center fielder range. Wallace is tough and is an adequate tackler for the position. -- Steve Muench

Davis, a true junior in 2019, was a three-year starter who averaged 16.1 yards per catch at UCF. He tracks the deep ball well, he creates late separation without blatantly pushing off, and he makes over-the-shoulder catches. He lacks the second gear to run by NFL corners and pull away after the catch. He's a natural hands catcher with good length and body control. He's not a complete route runner at this point, and he doesn't have great change-of-direction skills, but he flashes savviness and he's physical. -- March 2020 Davis is a bigger receiver with average timed speed and length. He tracks the deep ball well, creates late separation without blatantly pushing off and makes over-the-shoulder catches. He lacks the second gear to run by NFL corners and pull away after the catch. He's a natural hands catcher with good body control. Davis is not a complete route runner. -- Steve Muench

Clark was a two-time team captain and three-year starter. There's some shock in his hands and he jars defenders with a violent punch. His technique is spotty and he fits better in a power-heavy scheme than he does in a zone-heavy scheme, but he has the strength to develop into an above-average drive blocker. He has enough length to ride speed rushers past the quarterback. He doesn't play with great bend, and his hand placement is inconsistent. There's an edge to his game and he blocks to the echo of the whistle. -- April 2020 Clark is a two-time team captain and three-year starter. There's an edge to his game, and he blocks to the echo of the whistle. There's some shock in his hands, and he jars defenders with a violent punch. He fits better in a power-heavy scheme than he does in a zone-heavy scheme. He has the potential to develop into an solid drive blocker. He has the length to ride speed rushers past the quarterback. -- Steve Muench

Lynch is a true junior and two-year starter who recorded 81 tackles, 28.5 for loss, 19 sacks, three forced fumbles, two fumble recoveries, seven pass deflections and three blocked kicks over the past two seasons. He's a big defensive end who excels at setting the edge. He tracks the ball well and flashes the ability to get off blocks in time to make the play. He's an above-average hand fighter with good power rushing the passer. He has the potential to develop into an effective interior pass-rusher. He chases the run and the quarterback with good effort. Position fit is an issue. He tested poorly at the combine and has very short arms for a defensive end. He worked out with defensive tackles at the combine and is probably a better fit there, but he's light for a defensive tackle. -- March 2020 Lynch is a big defensive end who excels at setting the edge. He tracks the ball well and flashes the ability to get off blocks in time to make the play. He's a decent hand fighter with good power rushing the passer. He has the potential to develop into an effective interior pass-rusher. Lynch chases with good effort. He has very short arms and marginal top-end speed for an end. -- Steve Muench

Lawrence was a three-year starter and three-time team captain. He's a versatile defensive lineman who played on the outside and inside in LSU's scheme. He projects best at nose or 3-technique in a base four-man front. He tracks the ball well and flashes the ability to make plays in the backfield. He has the low center of gravity and upper-body strength to stack offensive linemen one-on-one. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks, and he gives too much ground to double-teams. He flashes violent hands and the ability to generate push as a pass-rusher. He's not a polished hand fighter, and he needs to develop a counter move. He missed three games with an injury in 2019. -- March 2020 Lawrence was a three-time team captain. He has average size, good length, big hands and very good top-end speed. He tracks the ball well and flashes the ability to make plays in the backfield. He has the low center of gravity and upper-body strength to stack offensive linemen. He flashes powerful hands, but he's not a polished hand fighter and needs to develop counter moves. -- Steve Muench

Dye was a four-year starter and the only player in Oregon history to lead the team in tackles four consecutive seasons. He's a taller linebacker with above-average instincts and range. He broke his right thumb and played the final eight games of the 2019 season with a cast. He still showed good strength at the point of attack and flashed the ability to get off blocks. Injury appeared to have bigger impact on his ability to finish as a tackler. He also needs to clean up angles and do a better job of breaking down as an open-field tackler. He reads the quarterback and shows good overall awareness in coverage. He tracked the ball and snatched a 2019 Utah pick out of the air even though he had the cast on his hand. He's an instinctive pass-rusher who flashes the ability to slip blocks and closes well. He played with a partially torn meniscus in his right knee in 2019, and he underwent arthroscopic surgery following the season. -- March 2020 Dye is a taller linebacker with good instincts and range. He showed decent strength and flashed the ability to get off blocks despite playing with a cast on his hands for the final eight games of the 2019 season. He reads the quarterback and shows good overall awareness in coverage. He's an instinctive pass-rusher who flashes the ability to slip blocks and closes well. -- Steve Muench

Parkinson, a team captain and true junior in 2019, was a two-year starter. He's a big target with a wide catching radius. He makes tough contested catches over the middle. He makes one-handed catches. Stanford took advantage of his ability to win 50-50 balls by isolating him out wide. He's a zone buster. He's fast enough to make plays down the seam. He's a competitive blocker with the frame to get better. He needs to get stronger at the point as an in-line blocker and improve his footwork in space. -- March 2020 Parkinson is a team captain and big target with a wide catching radius. He makes tough catches over the middle, and Stanford took advantage of his ability to win 50-50 balls by isolating him out wide. Parkinson is fast enough to make some plays down the seam. He's a competitive blocker with the frame to get better. -- Steve Muench

Hawkins, a three-year starter, is a tough run stopper with above-average stopping power. He gets grabby in coverage, and he lacks the range to play center field. He was recruited to Cal to play wide receiver. He picked off 10 passes over the past three seasons. He has good length and flashes the ability to snatch the ball out of the air. -- Steve Muench

A combine snub, Dotson was a four-year starter and 2019 Associated Press first-team All-American. He flashes a nasty disposition and the ability to move defenders off the ball. His hand placement is inconsistent and he can do a better job of keeping his hips under him. He's competitive and finds ways to win in pass pro even though he has below-average length and athletic ability. -- April 2020 A combine snub, Dotson, a four-year starter, has a nasty disposition and the ability to move defenders off the ball in the run game. Hes competitive and finds ways to win in pass pro even though he has below-average length and just adequate athletic ability. His hand placement is inconsistent, and he can do a better job of keeping his hips under him. -- Steve Muench

Hopkins, a redshirt senior and team captain in 2019, lined up in the slot and in-line in Purdue's scheme. He has the burst to make plays down the seam, and he's an above-average runner after the catch. He flashes chops as a route runner and has the quickness in addition to the change of direction to continue to get better. He's tough over the middle. He has big hands and flashes the ability to make difficult catches, but high drop rate is a concern. He lacks the strength to sustain blocks and regularly hold up as an in-line blocker at the NFL level. -- April 2020 Hopkins is a team captain with the burst to make plays down the seam. He's a good runner after the catch. He flashes as a route runner and has the athletic ability to get better. He's tough over the middle. Hopkins has big hands and flashes the ability to make difficult catches, but high drop rate is a concern. He lacks the strength to sustain blocks. -- Steve Muench

Scott is an undersized corner with very short arms and small hands but very good top-end speed. He covers a lot of ground quickly, and he's athletic enough to mirror receivers underneath. He competes on the outside but projects as a slot corner in the NFL. He's opportunistic and had seven picks in three years. -- Steve Muench

Sneed is a big defensive back who moved from corner to safety in 2019 and intercepted six passes over the past two seasons. He's at his best in underneath zone. He posted the fourth-fastest time at the combine and runs well in a straight line. He's tight and gets grabby when he starts to lose. He?s an effective wrap-and-drag tackler. He's not a downhill thumper, and ideally he fills out his frame if he plays safety in the NFL. -- March 2020 Sneed is a big and versatile defensive back who moved from corner to safety in 2019. He ran the fourth fastest 40 at the combine. He runs well on a straight line, but he's tight and gets grabby at times on tape. He's an effective wrap-and-drag tackler. He's not a downhill thumper and ideally he fills out his frame if he plays safety full time in the NFL. -- Steve Muench

Robertson, a true junior in 2019, was a three-year starter who finished his career with 14 picks, including three he returned for touchdowns. He's an undersized corner with above-average foot speed, balance and closing burst. His size raises concerns about his ability to match up on the outside, but he's physical in press coverage, and he plays bigger than his size. He's a playmaker with excellent overall ball skills. He's tough and he flashes above-average stopping power for his size. He's an inconsistent finisher as a tackler. He reportedly underwent surgery in January to repair a groin injury, and he did not work out at the combine. -- March 2020 Robertson is an undersized corner with good foot speed, balance and closing burst. His frame and short arms raise concerns about his ability to match up on the outside, but he's physical in press coverage and plays bigger than his size. Robertson is a ball hawk with excellent overall ball skills. He finished his three-year college career with 14 interceptions. He's tough and he flashes excellent stopping power for his size. -- Steve Muench

Quarterman, a true senior in 2019, was a four-year starter who finished his career with 356 tackles, 46.5 tackles for loss, 13 sacks, two forced fumbles, five fumble recoveries, 14 pass deflections and one interception. He's a gap-sound run defender who flashes the ability to shoot gaps and makes plays in the backfield. He has slightly below-average speed and closing burst, but he plays with a nonstop motor and always seems to be around the ball at the end of the play. He wraps on contact and flashes good stopping power between the tackles. He's an erratic open-field tackler with athletic limitations. He's instinctive in zone coverage. He?s tight and lacks the quickness to regularly match up in man. -- March 2020 Quarterman, a four-year starter, finished his college career with 356 tackles, 46.5 tackles for loss and 13 sacks. He's a gap-sound run defender who flashes the ability to shoot gaps and make plays in the backfield. He plays with a nonstop motor and always seems to be around the ball at the end of the play. He wraps on contact and shows good stopping power between the tackles. -- Steve Muench

Reid, a redshirt senior in 2019, was a three-year starter. He lines up on the outside and the inside. He's an above-average athlete with good quickness and slightly above-average top-end speed. Physical route runners have some success creating separation at the top of stem. He's opportunistic and he picked off seven passes at Penn State, but he's not a natural hands catcher. His average size and below-average length put him at a disadvantage in jump-ball situations. He's an inconsistent tackler who struggles to get off blocks. -- March 2020 Reid has good quickness and above-average top-end speed. He's light and physical route runners have some success creating separation. He's opportunistic and picked off seven passes at Penn State. His frame and below average length put him at a disadvantage in jump-ball situations. He's an inconsistent tackler who struggles to get off blocks. -- Steve Muench

Gandy-Golden, a three-year starter and two-year captain, is Liberty's all-time leader in receiving yards, receptions and receiving touchdowns. He's a natural hands catcher who flashes the ability to make highlight catches. His timed top-end speed is a borderline red flag. He's not going to run past corners but he's a long strider who plays a little faster and makes one-on-one catches downfield. He's not as dangerous after the catch. That said, he runs hard and he's strong enough to break initial contact. He flashes potential as a route runner and he's a big target who settles into windows working against zone looks. He lacks the burst and fluidity to develop above-average separation skills. -- April 2020 Gandy-Golden is a big target and natural hands catcher who has the ability to make highlight catches. His timed top-end speed is a borderline red flag, but he's a long strider who plays a little faster and makes one-on-one catches downfield. Gandy-Golden lacks the burst and fluidity to develop decent separation skills. -- Steve Muench

Watch: Meet Gandy-Golden, the uncut gem who does it all

Bredeson is a true senior and enters his fourth season as the starting left guard. His teammates made him a captain as a junior. He gets adequate hand placement and anchors fairly well. He's at his best jump-setting, but he's overaggressive and lunges at times. He has a wide frame but short arms and below-average lateral mobility. He gets into position and walls off defenders. He's not a powerful drive blocker. He lacks ideal athletic ability for a zone-heavy scheme. Bredeson grades out as a reserve offensive guard and projects as a potential late-round pick. -- June 2019 Bredeson, a two-time team captain and four-year starter, has good size but poor length. He gets into positon and walls off defenders in the run game. He's a better run-blocker than pass-blocker. He gets adequate hand placement and anchors well, but he lunges a times and lacks lateral mobility. -- Steve Muench

Dallas was a true junior and team captain in 2019 who led Miami in rushing. He averaged 17.4 yards per punt return and returned a punt 61 yards for a touchdown in 2018. He runs with great effort and has above-average contact balance. He flashes the ability to make the first defender miss and he plays a little faster than timed speed. He moved from receiver to running back midway through the 2017 season and he flashes good ball skills. He's a below-average pass-blocker at this point. His career (1.37) fumble percentage is a concern, but he did not fumble in 2019. He suffered a dislocated left elbow against Florida International and missed the final two games of the 2019 season. -- April 2020 Dallas runs with great effort and has above-average contact balance. He shows the ability to make the first defender miss. He plays a little faster than timed speed. He moved from receiver to running back midway through the 2017 season. Dallas flashes good ball skills. He's not a good pass-blocker. He averaged 17.4 yards per punt return and returned a punt for a touchdown in 2018. -- Steve Muench

Driscoll primarily lined up at right tackle in college, but the grad transfer and two-year starter at Auburn played some guard at Massachusetts. He projects best at guard, where he has adequate size, slightly below-average length and excellent quickness. He gets good hand placement and adequate bend in pass sets. He's not an overpowering run-blocker, but he walls off and plays with an edge. -- Steve Muench

Kareem was a four-year player and three-year starter who started all 39 games his last three seasons at Notre Dame. During those three years, he collected 109 tackles, 26 tackles for loss and 13 sacks. Kareem looks the part physically with very good height, bulk, length and overall strength. He is NFL-ready because of his size and technique, and he could do an adequate job as a two-down starter in the NFL if inserted today. He's capable of setting a hard edge, he locates the ball quickly enough and he will offer solid production versus the run. However, his lack of redirection quickness and closing burst are concerning. Kareem also lacks flexibility and bend as a pass-rusher, which is why we don't see much upside in his game in that area. Kareem could serve as a rotational defensive end in the NFL, best suited at 4-3 LDE and some 5-technique or even some 3-technique on obvious passing downs. But his upside as a pass-rusher is limited. -- March 2020 Kareem has a good blend of size, length and overall strength. He's capable of setting a hard edge, locates the ball quickly enough and offers solid production versus the run. He might never develop into a three-down player. His lack of lateral quickness and closing burst are concerning. Kareem also lacks ideal flexibility and bend for an edge rusher. -- Steve Muench

Robinson, a true senior in 2019, has the potential to develop into an effective edge rusher. He has above-average initial quickness. He ran the third-fastest 40 out of all the defensive linemen at the combine. He flashes an effective inside move. He doesn't counter well when he doesn't win with his first move. His sack production dipped and two of his sacks came against Western Michigan in 2019. He's a disruptive run defender who flashes the ability to slip blocks and closes well chasing from the backside. He gives ground at times, and there's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. He has shorter arms for an edge defender and may be a better fit at 3-4 OLB than defensive end. -- March 2020 Robinson has above-average initial quickness, and he ran the third-fastest 40 out of all the defensive linemen at the combine. He doesn't counter well when he doesn't win with his first move. He's a disruptive run defender who has the ability to slip blocks and closes well chasing from the backside. Robinson gives ground at times and there's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. -- Steve Muench

Pinter played tight end for his first three seasons at Ball State and then started 24 games at right tackle the past two seasons. He has short arms for a tackle so he projects better at guard than he does at tackle. He tested well for a guard at the combine. He's got the athletic ability to develop into a good zone blocker and pass blocker on the inside. -- Steve Muench

Lemieux was a five-year player and four-year starter at Oregon. He started most of his career at left guard and never missed a game (51 consecutive starts). Lemieux has very good height and solid bulk. He also displays above-average speed, though he has some athletic limitations against quick three-technique types in pass protections. But he knows the angles and shows savvy. He shows snap in his hands and has very little trouble holding ground versus power rushers. A solid run blocker with initial quickness and striking power to win early, Lemieux also has a strong lower body to generate some push. He grades out as a potential starting guard. -- March 2020 Lemieux, a four-year starter, lined up at left guard and never missed a game. He has some snap in his hands and he has little trouble holding his ground versus power rushers in pass pro. He's an effective run blocker with good quickness and the lower body strength to generate some push. He's a leader and hard worker. -- Steve Muench

Reed, a true senior in 2019 and a three-year starter, holds the school records for career kickoff return yardage, with 3,042 yards, and kickoff returns for touchdowns, with five. He averaged 103.2 all-purpose yards and scored 22 touchdowns over the past three seasons. He's a versatile weapon who lines up out wide, in the slot and in the backfield. He did the bulk of his work within 5-10 yards of the line of scrimmage and averaged just 8.8 yards per catch in 2019, so he's not a proven vertical receiver. That said, his combination of size and speed gives team some reason to believe he can improve in that area. He's a threat to break out after the catch, like when he turned a 4-yard route into a 43-yard gain early in the 2019 Notre Dame game. He's one of the most dangerous kickoff return men in the country. Virginia did a good job of scheming to get him open, and there's plenty of room for improvement when it comes to route running. -- April 2020 Reed is a versatile weapon who lines up out wide, in the slot and in the backfield. He's a threat to break out after the catch. He's one of the most dangerous kickoff return men in the country. Virginia did a good job of scheming to get him open. There's plenty of room for improvement when it comes to route running. Reed finished his college career with 17 tackles and has good kick coverage potential. -- Steve Muench

West Virginia dismissed Robinson for an academic violation in the summer of 2019 and he decided to play in the XFL instead of transferring to another school. He's a playmaker who picked off seven passes in two seasons at West Virginia and two passes in five games in the XFL. He's active in run support and he flashes good stopping power. -- Steve Muench

McKivitz, four-year starter, moved from right to left tackle in 2019. He rewraps and gets his hands inside in pass pro. He flashes the ability to stay in front of his assignments, but he loses inside leverage and gets beaten to the inside at times. He's late delivering punch. He doesn't bend well and has below-average length, making him vulnerable to long arm moves and speed to power. He gets off the ball and generates good initial push in the run game. His pads rise and he falls off blocks late. -- April 2020 McKivitz is on the lighter side with below-average length and top-end speed. He rewraps and gets his hands inside in pass pro. He loses inside leverage and gets beat to the inside at times. He's late delivering punch. McKivitz gets off the ball and generates good initial push in the run game. His pads rise and he falls off blocks late. He has starting experience at both tackle spots. Best fit may be at guard. -- Steve Muench

Strowbridge was a three-year starter. He does an above-average job of tracking the ball, and he flashes the ability to slip blocks. He fights to hold his ground and to get back into the play when he loses initially, but he gives ground at times and his weight raises concerns about his ability to hold up between the tackles in the NFL. His snap anticipation is inconsistent, but he flashes excellent initial quickness and he tested well. He has the potential to develop into a disruptive interior pass-rusher. He flashed explosive upper-body strength and the ability to clear his hips the week of the Senior Bowl. He struggles to counter when offensive linemen get their hands inside on him. He chases with above-average effort. Position fit is a concern. He's light for a defensive tackle. He has short arms and below-average speed for a defensive end. He blocked three kicks at North Carolina. -- March 2020 Position fit is a concern. Strowbridge has short arms for a defensive tackle let alone a defensive end, plus he's lean for a tackle and has below-average speed for an end. That said, he flashed explosive upper-body strength and the ability to clear his hips as a pass-rusher the week of the Senior Bowl. He has upside as an interior pass-rusher. He tracks the ball well and can slip blocks as a run defender. -- Steve Muench

Gipson, a two-year starter, has good size, length and speed. He flashes violent hands and an effective inside move rushing the passer. He's a disruptive run defender with the quickness to shoot gaps and make plays in the backfield. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks when he doesn't win with his initial move. -- Steve Muench

Ismael, a redshirt junior in 2019, was a three-year starter who moved from left guard to center as a redshirt freshman. He's a technically sound pass-blocker who works his hands inside and plays with a wide base. He fights to stay in front of assignments. He has shorter arms and doesn't jar defenders with a violent punch. He's quick and he tends to take sound angles climbing to the second level in the run game. He fits better in a zone-heavy scheme than he does in a power-heavy scheme. He leans and falls off blocks. He blocks to the whistle and flashes a mean streak. -- April 2020 Ismael is a technically sound pass-blocker who works his hands inside and fights to stay in front of his assignments. He's quick and tends to take sound angles climbing to the second level in the run game. He's tough and blocks to the whistle, but he fits better in a zone-heavy scheme than he does in a power-heavy scheme. Ismael has some experience playing guard. -- Steve Muench

Thomas, a team captain and two-year starter, has average size and speed. He's a nickel/safety prospect who reads the quarterback and flashes good instincts in underneath coverage. He's not rangy enough to play center field. He doesn't have great ball skills but he's opportunistic. He finished his college career with five picks. He's an active and tough run defender. -- Steve Muench

Hall was a team captain and three-year starter who led the nation with 22 pass breakups in 2018. He's a big corner with the frame, length and enough fluidity to develop into an effective press corner. He plays the ball not the man in zone. He closes well and limits production in off coverage. He is high cut with below-average change of direction, and he gets grabby at times. His length is an asset when it comes to breaking up passes. He played receiver in high school, and he has big hands. He gets nosy and takes unnecessary chances at times. He's a willing run-stopper who gets off blocks, but he's a bit of a submarine tackler. He missed seven games after fracturing his left ankle and undergoing season-ending surgery in 2019. -- March 2020 Hall, a team captain and three-year starter, has the frame, length and playing speed to develop into an effective press corner. He closes well and limits production after the catch in off coverage. He is high cut with below-average change of direction, and he gets grabby at times. Hall has big hands and played receiver in high school. -- Steve Muench

Rohrwasser is a big kicker who was the Conference USA special teams' player of the year in 2019. He has the leg strength to connect from long distance. His accuracy improved last year. He also handled the kickoff duties for the Herd. -- Steve Muench

Harris started 15 games at right guard and two games at left guard in his first two seasons at Washington but has been the Huskies' starting center the past two seasons. Harris is a shorter center with below-average length, good bulk and excellent quickness. He's a wall-off blocker with the initial quickness to get into position. He has the potential to develop into an above-average second-level blocker but stops moving his feet and whiffs too much at this point. Harris fits best in a zone-heavy scheme. He gets set quickly and he's athletic enough to mirror in pass pro. There's not much pop in his punch, and he's a waist-bender in pass pro. Harris grades out as a reserve interior offensive lineman. -- April 2020 Harris is a wall-off blocker with the initial quickness to get into position. He's got the potential to develop into an above-average second-level blocker. He gets set quickly and is athletic enough to mirror in pass pro. There's not much pop in his punch, and he's a waist-bender in pass pro. He's tough and he fights, but he gives ground to power rushers at times. -- Steve Muench

Johnson was a four-year player and three-year starter at Minnesota. In his last two seasons, he caught 164 passes for 2,487 yards (15.2 yards per catch) and 25 touchdowns. He missed the final two games of the 2017 season due to a hand/wrist injury but started all 26 games over the past two years. Johnson has solid height and good bulk. He did not run at the combine and has just average top-end speed on tape. Despite lacking great physical tools, he is a refined route runner and just knows how to separate. He has small hands and a lot of drops on tape but has also been one of the most productive receivers in college football during the past two seasons. He catches the ball in stride and turns into a running back after the catch. He makes defenders miss and runs hard. Johnson doesn't have the second gear to run away from pursuit or regularly take the top off the coverage. He grades out as a No. 3 or No. 4 slot receiver who is at his best working the middle of the field and picking up yards after the catch. -- April 2020 Johnson is a refined route runner who knows how to separate. He turns into a running back after the catch. He doesn't have great speed. He has smaller hands and there are a lot of drops on tape, but he's still been one of the most productive receivers in college football the past two seasons. -- Steve Muench

Hudson is undersized with very short arms but very good timed speed. He is a rangy run defender and flashes good pop when he plays downhill. He flashes active hands and good closing burst rushing off the edge. -- Steve Muench

Vildor was a team captain and two-year starter. He closes well breaking on plays in front of him. He has good length even though he's short, and he flashes the ability to disrupt receivers. He has below-average change of direction, and he doesn't play as fast as timed speed. He finished his college career with nine picks, he has big hands, and he flashes good ball skills. He's an inconsistent tackler, and there's room for improvement when it comes to fighting through blocks. -- April 2020 Vildor has good length even though he's short. He flashes the ability to disrupt receivers getting off the line. He has below-average change-of-direction and doesn't play quite as fast as timed speed. He finished his college career with nine picks. Vidor has big hands and good ball skills. He's an inconsistent tackler, and there's room for improvement when it comes to fighting through blocks. -- Steve Muench

Weaver, a redshirt junior in 2019, became the Mountain West's all-time sacks leader, passing BYU's Jan Jorgensen and TCU's Jerry Hughes. He recorded 128 tackles, 46.5 tackles for loss, 34 sacks, three forced fumbles, one fumble recovery, two interceptions and eight pass deflections over the past three seasons. He's an effective hand fighter and he flashes an effective inside move rushing the passer. He doesn't have elite first-step quickness or closing speed. He's a disruptive run defender who slips blocks and makes plays in the backfield. He tends to shoot his hands inside, and he flashes the ability to control blockers at the point of attack. He's big and strong enough to hold his ground, but his pad level is inconsistent. He's a versatile college player who lines up in a two-point stance, has experience dropping into coverage and can kick inside to rush the passer. He has below-average length for a defensive end and tested better than expected in the agility drills at the combine. -- March 2020 Weaver doesn't have elite first-step quickness or closing speed, but he's an effective hand fighter who flashes an effective inside move rushing the passer. He's a disruptive run-defender who slips blocks and makes plays in the backfield. Weaver tends to shoot his hands inside and has the ability to control blockers at the point of attack. His pad level is inconsistent. -- Steve Muench

Johnson, a team captain in 2019, was a three-year starter who caught 160 passes for 2,309 yards (14.4 yards per catch) and 12 touchdowns over the past three seasons. He's a big target and natural hands catcher with the frame and body control to regularly come down with 50-50 balls. His average playing speed and his ability to win one-on-one make him a downfield threat. He's smooth transitioning upfield, and he picks up some yards after contact after the catch. He's not an explosive route runner, but he is smooth getting in out of breaks. He has a professional work ethic. He missed six games with a hamstring injury in 2019. A hip injury prevented him from running at the combine. -- March 2020 Johnson is a big target and natural hands catcher with the frame and body control to come down with 50-50 balls. His average playing speed and ability to win one-on-one make him a downfield threat. He's smooth transitioning upfield after the catch and he picks up some yards after contact. Johnson isn't an explosive route runner, but he's smooth getting in and out of breaks. -- Steve Muench

When on the field, Cephus has been very productive. Cephus has average height and good bulk with a chiseled frame. He has slightly above-average top-end speed but is not a burner. He's at his best running short-to-intermediate routes. He has some tightness but explodes off the line -- he is quicker than fast, and a strong runner after the catch. Cephus has strong hands and is competitive in traffic. He shows very good body control to adjust but has a few too many focus drops. As a run blocker, Cephus is tough, competitive and effective. Cephus was suspended from the Wisconsin team in August 2018 (missed the entire season) and later expelled from UW after an investigation determined he had violated the school's non-academic misconduct code. But he was reinstated after being found not guilty of two criminal sexual assault charges. He is a talented receiver with the potential to play inside and outside in the NFL. -- March 2020 Cephus has average height and good bulk with a chiseled frame. He's a strong runner after the catch. He shows good body control and is competitive in traffic, but he has small hands and drops passes too often. Cephus has marginal initial quickness and top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

Fromm earned the starting QB job as a true freshman in 2017 and led Georgia to a 36-7 record as a starter over the past three seasons. He completed 64% of his passes with a 4.3-1 TD-to-INT ratio. He has adequate height with a solid build and just average mobility. He sees the entire field and makes full-field reads. Fromm is tough and will hang in the pocket, but he knows his limitations and plays within himself. He displays very good timing, touch and accuracy. He possesses a quick release but a lack of arm strength is his biggest weakness. His pocket mobility is average at best. But Fromm thrives on the big stage. And while he has physical limitations, he's a proven winner with exceptional football intelligence and work ethic. Fromm grades out as a good NFL backup and could possibly develop into a solid starter if placed in a great situation. -- April 2020 Fromm is a smaller quarterback with average mobility, and his lack of arm strength is his biggest weakness. That said, he's a proven winner with exceptional football intelligence and work ethic. He has a quick release in addition to solid accuracy and touch. -- Steve Muench

Hightower, a junior college transfer, is coming off a breakout senior season and a strong combine workout. He's dangerous with the ball in his hands. He's explosive after the catch. His hands are inconsistent, and he doesn't have the frame to consistently come down with 50-50 balls. He played some Wildcat quarterback. -- March 2020

Hand, a true junior in 2019, transferred from Baylor to Temple to be closer to family and was granted immediate eligibility in 2019. He reads the quarterback and plays the ball not the man in zone. He has average top-end speed and he can get beat over the top. He's not a natural hands catcher, but he flashes the instincts of a ball hawk and the ability to make plays. He misses some tackles and he takes too long to get off blocks. That said, he's a tough run defender who fights to get to the ball and flashes good stopping power. -- March 2020 Hand reads the quarterback and plays the ball not the man in zone. He has average top-end speed and can get beat over the top. He's not a natural hands catcher but has good instincts and flashes the ability to make plays. He's a tough run defender who fights to get to the ball and flashes good stopping power. -- Steve Muench

Washington, a two-time team captain and three-year starter, has a low center of gravity and the strength to stack blockers one-on-one. He's not a massive two-gap space-eater. He's a relatively one-dimensional power rusher. He does do a good job of getting his hands up in passing lanes. -- Steve Muench

Coulter has above-average top-end speed, and he tracks the deep ball well. He's lean and ideally he adds weight, but he has good body control and flashes the ability to win 50-50 balls downfield. He's a big-play threat after the catch. There's room for improvement when it comes to his route running. -- Steve Muench

Huntley is an undersized back with very good top-end speed. He's a dynamic player who rushed for over 1,000 yards last year. He finished his college career with 134 catches for 1,119 yards and had five touchdowns on kickoff returns. -- Steve Muench

Mooney is an undersized slot receiver with outstanding top-end speed, above-average initial quickness and big hands for his frame. He has the second gear to pull away after the catch and take the top off the coverage. He has inconsistent hands, and he doesn't have the frame to regularly come down 50-50 balls. -- Steve Muench

Murchison is a redshirt senior and two-year starter at North Carolina State. He lines up on the inside and the outside. He tends to shoot his hands inside and he tracks the ball well. He flashes the ability to get off blocks. He's an inconsistent finisher. He gives ground at times. He has active hands and he closes well rushing the passer. He's faster than quick and he's tight, especially for an undersized defensive tackle. He's a tweener who is light for a defensive tackle and lacks ideal length for a 3-4 DE. -- March 2020 Murchison tracks the ball well and shows the ability to get off blocks as a run defender.
