He gives ground at times and is an inconsistent finisher. He has active hands and closes well rushing the passer. He feasted on poor pass protection in 2019 -- 5.5 of his seven sacks came against Florida State and Syracuse. Murchison is a tweener who is light for a defensive tackle and has short arms for a 3-4 DE. -- Steve Muench

Martin was a four-year player and three-year starter at Minnesota. He did not work out at the combine but appears to have average speed on tape. Martin does a good job using his long arms to keep blockers off of his pads. He shows good recognition skills and really excels at ball location while engaged with blockers. And he's also a solid wrap-up tackler, though not an explosive striker. Martin is good in zone coverage -- instinctive, with a good feel for crossers. But he has some tightness and will have some man-to-man coverage limitations in the NFL. Martin has the potential to develop into a starting off-the-ball linebacker, but early in his career, he's likely to serve as a versatile backup and special-teams contributor. -- March 2020 Martin has good height, a thick build and long arms. He does a good job of keeping blockers off his pads, and he excels at locating the ball while engaged with blockers. He's a solid wrap-up tackler. He's instinctive and shows a good feel for crossers in zone coverage. Martin will have some man-to-man limitations in the NFL. -- Steve Muench

Osborn, a grad transfer from the University of Buffalo, led the Hurricanes in receiving and averaged 15.9 yards per punt return in 2019. He finds windows in zone looks. He's not a complete or explosive route runner. He runs hard and flashes good burst after the catch, but he doesn't play as fast as timed speed and averaged 10.9 yards per catch in 2019. He's not a natural hands catcher. He's a competitive blocker.?-- April 2020 Osborn is built well and runs hard after the catch. He flashes good burst after the catch, but he doesn't play as fast as timed speed and averaged 10.9 yards per catch in 2019. He does a good job of finding pockets in zone looks He's not a natural hands catcher. He's a competitive blocker. -- Steve Muench

Danna spent his first three seasons at Central Michigan before transferring to Michigan in 2019. He shoots his hands inside and flashes the ability to walk offensive tackles back to the quarterback as a pass-rusher. He needs to develop better counter punches, and because he is on the lighter side, he gives ground at times. But he does have quick hands and fast eyes, and he gives good effort in pursuit. Danna grades out as a reserve edge defender in the NFL who will need to carve out a role on special teams. -- April 2020 Danna chases the run and the quarterback with good effort. He flashes the ability to slip blocks but he's undersized for an edge defender and needs to get stronger against the run. He's a Central Michigan transfer who only had three sacks as a rotational edge rusher at Michigan in 2019 and needs to improve his hand-to-hand combat skills rushing the passer. -- Steve Muench

Strnad is versatile enough to line up on the inside or the outside in a base four-man front. He's a taller inside linebacker who locates and tracks the ball well for the most part. He shows good lateral mobility scraping down the line and sifting through traffic. He gives ground and takes too long to get off blocks once reached. He chases with good effort and has average closing speed. He shows good awareness and range in underneath zone. -- April 2020 Strnad is a taller inside linebacker who locates and tracks the ball well for the most part. He chases with good effort and has average closing speed. He shows good awareness and range in underneath zone. -- Steve Muench

Anae, a team captain in 2019, was a three-year starter who broke Utah's career record for sacks with 30. He's a tactician with a good motor rushing the passer. He makes up for below-average quickness by keeping blockers off his frame and clearing his hips as a speed rusher. He's an above-average hand fighter with an effective inside move. He has below average closing speed. He shoots his hands and flashes the ability to stack bigger blockers. He's light with short arms for a defensive end, and combine testing raises concerns about his ability to play linebacker in the NFL. -- March 2020 Anae is a tactician with a nonstop motor rushing the passer. He's a solid hand fighter with an effective inside move. He shoots his hands inside and flashes the ability to stack bigger blockers as a run-defender. He's a team captain and overachiever with below-average size, short arms and marginal top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

Adeniji, a four-year starter, started games at left tackle and right tackle. He has below-average length for a tackle, but he gets set quickly. He tends to shoot his hands inside. He's an effective positional blocker in the run game. He has the potential to develop into a valuable No. 3 swing tackle who provides depth on both sides. -- Steve Muench

Muti, a captain and redshirt junior in 2019, lined up primarily at guard but played two games at left tackle in 2018. He benched 225 pounds seven times more than any other player at the combine, and his weight-room strength translates to the field. He knocks defenders off balance with a violent and powerful punch. He gets his hands inside and stays in front of his assignment once locked on. He's a finisher with a nasty disposition in the run game. He anchors well in pass pro. He's short with very short arms, which affects his ability to stay engaged, particularly in pass pro, and forces him to play with forward lean to be effective. He missed most of the 2019 season with a Lisfranc injury. -- April 2020 Muti missed most of the past two seasons with injuries and has short arms, but his tape is impressive. A team captain, he's a mauler in the run game who benched 44 reps of 225 pounds. That tied for fourth-most in combine history. The weight room strength translates to the field, where he knocks defenders off balance with a violent punch. Muti needs to be aggressive to mask his length, but he tends to stay engaged in pass protection. -- Steve Muench

Onwenu is a massive guard with excellent length and big hands. He overwhelms defenders in the run game plus he anchors well and he's tough to get around in pass pro. He's not a great athlete so he fits best in a power scheme. Athletic interior pass-rushers will give him some problems. He primarily lined up at right guard, but he did start a game left guard in 2017.

Brown, a team captain in 2019, was a two-year starter. He's a tall and long linebacker who plays on the inside and the outside. He has average playing speed and he chases with good effort. He has some problems keeping blockers off him despite his long arms. He flashes good stopping power, but he's an inconsistent finisher with limitations in space. He's high cut and tight so he has limitations in coverage. Cousin Andre' Davis was a wide receiver at Virginia Tech and played for eight seasons in the NFL. -- March 2020 Brown, a team captain and two-year starter, is a tall and long linebacker who plays on the inside and the outside. He has average playing speed but chases with good effort. He flashes solid stopping power, but he's an inconsistent finisher. He's high cut and tight so he has limitations in coverage. -- Steve Muench

Roy is a big nose tackle coming off a breakout senior season. He stacks blockers and tracks the ball well. He did a better job of getting off blocks and making plays in 2019. He had a career high 5.5 sacks last year, but he's a better run defender than pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

Ferguson, a two-time team captain, has been LSU's long snapper the past four seasons. He's undersized with a good hand span and slightly below-average top-end speed. He gets good zip on his snaps. He finished his career with three tackles. His brother Reid is the Bills' long snapper. -- Steve Muench

Gilman has adequate size, shorter arms and below-average timed speed. He's smooth and athletic, but he lacks range and burst. He is not a ball hawk but flashes good ball skills. He looks to rip the ball out and forced six fumbles over the past two seasons. -- Steve Muench

Peoples-Jones caught 81 passes for 1,050 yards (13 yards per catch) and 14 touchdowns over the past two seasons. He is a well-built receiver who both lines up on the outside and works out of the slot. He is a natural hands catcher who snatches the ball out of the air and adjusts to passes thrown outside his frame. Peoples-Jones is smooth transitioning upfield after the catch and a tough open-field runner who lowers his shoulder and delivers the blow on contact. He tracks the deep ball well but lacks an elite second gear. But he's a physical route runner with adequate burst transitioning out of breaks. Peoples-Jones grades out as a No. 3 receiver and potential punt returner in the NFL. -- April 2020 Peoples-Jones has a good blend of size, length, hand span and top-end speed. He's a natural hands catcher who snatches the ball out of the air and adjusts to passes thrown outside his frame. He's smooth transitioning upfield after the catch. Peoples-Jones doesn't play as fast as timed top-end speed and production doesn't match talent.

Bass is a smaller kicker who had a better season in 2018 than he did in 2019. He hit the game-winning field goal in the second overtime at South Alabama in 2019. He handled the kickoff duties and finished his college career with 11 tackles. He also punted five times at Georgia Southern.-- Steve Muench

Luton, a team captain and sixth-year senior in 2019, started his career at Idaho before transferring to a junior college and then Oregon State, where he started 21 games over the past three seasons. He's a sound decision-maker who threw 28 touchdowns to three interceptions last season. He's accurate when he gets the ball out quickly and in rhythm. His downfield accuracy is erratic but he flashes good touch. He has adequate foot speed and he does a good job of keeping his eyes downfield climbing the pocket. He's not much of a threat when he scrambles. He sustained a thoracic spine fracture against Washington State and missed the final eight games of 2017. He missed most of the 2018 season with an ankle injury. He missed the 2019 Oregon game with an injury. He received a sixth year by the NCAA and he turns 24 in April. Luton has the frame in addition to enough arm strength and mobility to develop into an effective backup, but there are obvious concerns regarding his injury history and ability to stay healthy. -- March 2020 Luton is a sound decision-maker who threw 28 touchdowns compared to three interceptions last year. He's accurate when he gets the ball out quickly and in rhythm. His downfield accuracy is erratic, but he flashes good touch. He has adequate foot speed, and he does a good job of keeping his eyes downfield climbing the pocket. He's not much of a threat when he scrambles. -- Steve Muench

Woerner is a leaner tight end with average speed, big hands and below-average length. He never caught more than 11 passes in a season, and he finished his college career with one touchdown catch. He's a tough and aggressive blocker who gets into position and fights to sustain. -- Steve Muench

Mann was a team captain and is a right-footed punter who set the NCAA record for the highest punting average in a game (60.8 yards at Alabama) and 60-plus yard punts in a season (14) in 2018. He's undersized, but he finished his college career with 13 tackles. He gets good distance on kickoffs. Mann has an average hand span. -- Steve Muench

Runyan is a redshirt senior and the son of former Michigan offensive lineman and NFL Pro Bowler Jon Runyan. He kicks well enough to take away the edge from speed rushers, but he doesn't bend well and he gives too much ground to speed to power. He does a good job of getting some push and snapping back on linebackers on combo blocks. He's an adequate positional blocker with an average power base one on one. His footwork is inconsistent and he doesn't always keep his hips under him. He's playing out of position at tackle and projects better at guard, where his athletic limitations are less likely to be exposed. He looks like a Day 3 pick. -- June 2019 Runyan started at left tackle the past two seasons, but he has also played right tackle and right guard. He has below-average length for a tackle and projects best at guard. He tested well in areas that correlate with success for interior offensive linemen at the combine. His 40 time, short shuttle and broad jump results were all above-average for a guard. -- Steve Muench

Windsor, a redshirt senior in 2019, was a two-year starter who recorded 79 tackles, 16 tackles for loss, 11 sacks and two forced fumbles over the past two seasons. Penn State suspended him for the Citrus Bowl against Kentucky following the 2018 season for a violation of team rules. He's a lighter defensive tackle with good initial quickness and athletic ability. He's at his best slipping blocks and knifing into the backfield as a run defender. He flashes the ability to stack and shed, but he's inconsistent in this area and he tends to get overwhelmed by double-teams. He flashes upside as a pass-rusher. He has active hands and he closes well. He's strong enough to push the pocket. He chases the run and the quarterback with above-average effort. He needs to win with initial quickness and gets caught trying to guess the snap count. He widens out at times and is versatile enough to play end in base three-man front. -- March 2020 Windsor is a lean defensive tackle with good length in addition to excellent lateral quickness and top-end speed. He's at his best slipping blocks and knifing into the backfield as a run defender. He's inconsistent at getting off blocks and gives ground at times. Windsor flashes as a pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

Davis had his best season as a senior and he turned heads when he ran 4.75 40 at 308 pounds at the combine. There's a lot to like about his upside and motor. He's far from a finished product. He takes too long to get off blocks and gives ground in the run game. He's not a polished hand fighter rushing the passer. -- Steve Muench

Herron, a sixth-year senior and team captain in 2019, was a four-year starter who turns 25 in November. He has some shock in his hands. He did not test well in terms of change-of-direction skills at the combine, and his footwork is inconsistent, but he gets set quickly and flashes the ability to mirror. He's a waist bender with below-average length. He's an adequate positional blocker in the run game. He's not a powerful drive blocker, and he lacks ideal foot speed for a zone-heavy scheme. -- March 2020 Herron, a team captain and four-year starter, has some shock in his hands. He did not test well in terms of change-of-direction skills at the combine. His footwork is inconsistent, but he gets set quickly and flashes the ability to mirror on tape. He's a waist bender with below-average length. He's an adequate positional blocker in the run game. -- Steve Muench

Bradley, a three-year starter, ran the fifth-fastest 40 for the linebackers at the combine. He does a good job of sifting through traffic between the tackles, and he's quick enough to knife into the backfield. He has good range, but he doesn't close as fast as timed top-end speed would suggest. He's an inconsistent tackler. He runs with backs and tight ends in coverage. -- March 2020 Bradley, a three-year starter, ran the fifth-fastest 40 for the linebackers at the combine. He does a good job of sifting through traffic between the tackles, and he's quick enough to knife into the backfield. He has good range, but he doesn't close as fast as timed top-end speed would suggest. He's an inconsistent tackler. He runs with backs and tight ends in coverage. -- Steve Muench

Penisini started 20 games in his three seasons at Utah after transferring from junior college. He has above average size and strength with a low center of gravity. He flashes the ability to stack and shed blockers in time to make plays. He's a far better run defender than pass-rusher though he flashes violent hands and the ability to push the pocket. -- March 2020 Penisini has above average size and strength with a low center of gravity. He flashes the ability to stack and shed blockers in time to make plays. He's a far better run defender than pass-rusher, though he flashes violent hands and the ability to push the pocket. -- Steve Muench

Brooks, a three-year starter, averaged 5.8 solo tackles per game in 2019. That led the Big Ten and ranked ninth in the country. He's a hybrid linebacker/safety who moves around the formation. He's effective for his size playing close to the line of scrimmage. He does an above-average job of sifting through traffic, and he's quick enough to shoot into the backfield. He chops the legs out from under ball carriers. He has below-average range and he's tight in space. He's opportunistic with adequate ball skills, but he's not a ball hawk. He has the potential to develop into an effective cover man on special teams. -- April 2020 Brooks is a hybrid linebacker/safety who moves around the formation. He does a good job of sifting through traffic, and he's quick enough to shoot gaps playing close to the line of scrimmage. He chops the legs out from under ball carriers. His range isn't great, and he's tight in space. He's opportunistic with adequate ball skills but he's not a ball hawk. -- Steve Muench

Fuller has good height, bulk and length. His play speed on tape is solid, but his timed speed is below average. And he lacks ideal twitchiness. Still, Fuller is a leader and has great football intelligence. He is highly instinctive in coverage, spending a lot of time as a single-high safety and getting quick jumps on the ball. He clearly knows his assignments and opponent tendencies. Fuller shows solid closing burst to the ball, too. But he has some tightness, which limits his man-to-man coverage ability. He doesn't shy away from contact as a run defender and is a solid open-field tackler, taking very good angles. He isn't an overpowering striker but is technically sound as a wrap-up guy. He has some physical limitations, but he will find a way to contribute on special teams and serve as a quality reserve safety in the NFL. He will be a Day 3 draft pick. -- March 2020 Fuller has good size and plays faster than his timed speed. He's highly instinctive and gets early breaks on the ball. He's tight with below-average man-to-man cover skills, and he's an effective run defender who takes sound angles and wraps up. -- Steve Muench

Watkins ran the third-fastest 40 at the combine, and his playing speed matches his timed speed. He reaches his top-end speed quickly, and he has the second gear to take the top off the coverage. He's a threat to go the distance when he gets a seam after the catch and in the return game. He lines up on the inside and the outside. He's lean and he gets pushed around. He has good length and flashes the ability to snatch the ball of the air, but his hands are inconsistent. There's room for improvement when it comes to winning 50-50 balls. He lost two fumbles after the catch last season. Southern Miss sat him for the first two games of the 2019 season for undisclosed reasons. -- April 2020 Watkins ran the third-fastest 40 at the combine, and his playing speed matches his timed speed. He has the second gear to take the top off the coverage, and he's a threat to go the distance when he gets a seam after the catch and in the return game. He has good length and shows the ability to snatch the ball of the air, but his hands are inconsistent. There's room for improvement when it comes to winning 50-50 balls. -- Steve Muench

Proche, a team captain and four-year starter, led the FBS in receptions with 111 and ranked fourth in receiving touchdowns with 15 in 2019. He lines up on the inside and the outside. He's a natural hands catcher with big hands for his frame. He's a shorter target with very short arms and average leaping ability yet he makes contested catches. There's still room for improvement and he doesn't have great natural separation skills, but he flashes as a route runner and he locates pockets in zone looks. He did not run the 40 at the combine, and he doesn't show a second gear on tape. He's smooth transitioning upfield, but he's not an ankle breaker after the catch. -- March 2020 Proche was a team captain and four-year starter. He's a smaller target with short arms and average leaping ability, yet he's a natural hands catcher who makes contested catches. He shows upside as a route runner and is smooth transitioning upfield after the catch. He did not run the 40 at the combine and doesn't show a second gear on tape. -- Steve Muench

Weaver, a team captain and two-year starter, led the FBS in tackles and broke Hardy Nickerson's 34-year-old school record for tackles. He's a strong, square-up tackler who tracks the ball well and does an above-average job of sifting through traffic between the tackles. He chases with excellent effort, but he has slightly below average top-end speed and his angles are inconsistent. He's an inconsistent open-field tackler. He flashes the ability to carry tight ends down the seam, but he doesn't do a great job of getting his head around to locate the ball. He tested better than expected at the combine, but he's tight on tape, and he has limitations in coverage. He moved from defensive end to linebacker in 2017. -- March 2020 Weaver is a strong square-up tackler who tracks the ball well and does an above-average job of sifting through traffic between the tackles. He has slightly below average top-end speed, but he chases with excellent effort. He has the tools and the mentality to develop into a core special teams' player in the NFL. -- Steve Muench

Brandel, a team captain and four-year starter, has adequate size and below-average length. He primarily lined up at left tackle, but he started nine games at right tackle in 2016. He tends to shoot his inside, lock on and lock out in pass protection. He's more of a positional blocker than a mauler in the run game. He may be a better fit at guard in the NFL. -- Steve Muench

Maluia, a three-year starter, has very good speed. He's a rangy run defender who closes well in pursuit. He reads the quarterback and flashes above-average ball skills in underneath coverage. He has the potential to develop into a valuable special teams contributor. He's slightly undersized. -- Steve Muench

Metellus was a four-year player and two-year starter at Michigan, and in the past two years, he combined for 172 tackles, 19 passes broken up and five interceptions. He is a well-built safety with longer arms and big hands. He has average top-end speed for the position. He frequently matches up with tight ends and receivers working out of the slot. Metellus masks his tightness and average burst with physicality and instincts. But he has athletic limitations in coverage. He doesn't have center-fielder range but runs well enough to cover a deep half, and he's effective in underneath zone. Plus he possesses above-average ball skills and is a sure tackler. Metellus shows solid aggressiveness in run support. He grades out as a backup safety in the NFL, and while he has been very solid at the college level, he simply doesn't have any elite physical traits. He will need to carve a niche on special teams to remain in the league. -- April 2020 Metellus is a well-built safety with longer arms, big hands and average top-end speed. He masks OK burst and fluidity with physicality, instincts and length in coverage. He doesn't have center fielder range. Metellus has very good ball skills. He's a willing run defender and sure tackler. -- Steve Muench

Davis has average size, average length, big hands and good top-end speed. He has the frame and ball skills to win 50-50 balls when you split him out wide and isolate him in the red zone. He flashes as a route runner and gets north-south after the catch. -- Steve Muench

Hodgins, a true junior in 2019, is the son of former NFL fullback James Hodgins. He shows excellent focus, he snatches passes out of the air, and although he traps some passes, he rarely drops balls that he gets his hands on. He has long arms and good body control. He's an adequate route runner and he locates soft spots in zone, but he's tight and he doesn't show great burst transitioning out of breaks. He's not much of a threat after the catch, and he lacks the second gear to take the top off the coverage. -- March 2020 Hodgins shows excellent focus, he snatches passes out of the air, and though he traps some passes he rarely drops balls he gets his hands on. He has long arms and good body control. He's an adequate route runner. Hodgkins locates soft spots in zone, but he's tight and doesn't show great burst transitioning out of breaks. He's not much of a threat after the catch and he lacks the second gear to take the top off the coverage. -- Steve Muench

Hanson, a four-year starter, has average size and length but below-average quickness for the position. He's an overachiever and technician who gets into position and fights to sustain in the run game and in pass pro. Athletic interior pass-rushers will give him problems in pass pro, and he's not an overpowering run blocker. -- Steve Muench

Stepaniak is a redshirt senior and two-year starter at right guard. He has adequate initial quickness and fights to stay in front of his assignment, but he gets overwhelmed and is beat clean at times in pass protection. There are questions about his ability to stay square and drive defenders off the ball. Stepaniak grades out as a reserve guard. -- June 2019 Stepaniak, a team captain and three-year starter at guard, has excellent upper-body strength, and he anchors well. He lunges and gets beat clean at times in pass pro. He's a tough run blocker who blocks to the whistle and fits best in a power-heavy scheme. -- Steve Muench

Wanogho is a native of Nigeria and entered the United States when he was 16 years old. He was a five-year player and two-and-a-half-year starter who started 32 games at left tackle. He has a big frame with adequate bulk but below-average arm length for the position. He has adequate initial quickness in set but lacks ideal balance, athleticism and speed. And he lunges too often. Wanogho plays with too wide of a base and frequently overextends. He does show good initial pop if he lands his punch but needs to be more consistent with hand placement. He struggles to sustain blocks in the run game, and the more space he's in as a second-level blocker, the less effective he becomes. Wanogho is a developmental prospect who has shown significant improvement from his first season playing tackle in 2016 (after switching over from defensive end during his redshirt season in 2015). He has the tools to develop into a starting tackle or guard in the NFL but will likely need time. -- April 2020 Wanogho has a big frame with adequate bulk and initial quickness. He falls off blocks and is a below-average second-level blocker in the run game. There's some pop in his punch, but his hand placement is inconsistent and he lunges too much. He has below-average length and athletic ability for a tackle. Wanogho might be a better fit at guard as a result. -- Steve Muench

Rodgers, a four-year starter, is an undersized corner with good speed. He's a playmaker who picked off 11 passes and returned three for touchdowns in college. He returns kickoffs and punts. He needs to get better against the run. -- Steve Muench

Patmon has an outstanding blend of size, speed, length and hand span. His speed and his ability to win 50-50 balls make him a vertical threat. His hands are inconsistent, and he drops some passes. He's more of a threat downfield than he is after the catch. -- Steve Muench

Glasgow is a former walk-on and hybrid linebacker/safety who is relentless chasing the ball. He is undersized for a linebacker, and he lacks the range to play safety in the NFL. But he has the mentality and enough talent to develop into an outstanding special teams player just like he was in college. -- Steve Muench

Swain is a lean receiver with excellent top-end speed and some upside as a slot receiver. He's not a complete or polished route runner. He returned a punt 85 yards for a touchdown in 2018 and has the ability to push for a punt returning job as a rookie. -- Steve Muench

Bailey, a four-year starter who had 82 solo tackles in 2018, raised red flags with a poor combine performance on the bench (15 reps). Still, he rarely stays blocked and does a nice job on tape of meeting lead blockers in the hole. He's an above-average tackler who plays with good body control and wraps. He chases with good effort. He takes good angles and shows good awareness in coverage. He gets grabby at times. He flashes the ability to win one-on-one battles rushing the passer. He sustained a season-ending knee injury in 2019. He underwent hip surgery during the 2019 offseason. -- April 2020 Bailey is a solid tackler who plays with good body control and wraps up. He chases with effort. He takes proper angles and shows good awareness in coverage. He gets grabby at times. He flashes the ability to win one-on-one battles rushing the passer. -- Steve Muench

Curl has good size, long arms and below-average top-end speed. He's a versatile defensive back who has lined up at corner and safety. He's an active run defender and good tackler with the potential to contribute on special teams. He's instinctive, but he has below-average range and change-of-direction skills in coverage. -- Steve Muench

Jennings was a standout high school quarterback but made the move to wide receiver as a freshman. He had his best season as a senior in 2019 with 59 catches for 969 yards and eight TDs. He possesses excellent size but marginal speed (a red flag 40-yard dash of 4.72 at the combine). His unique trait is the ability to break tackles after the catch. He's a powerful runner with outstanding contact balance, and he has strong hands in traffic. His body control is very good, and he adjusts well to balls thrown outside his frame. Jennings grades out as a No. 4 WR in the NFL. -- April 2020 Jennings was a standout high school quarterback but made the move to wide receiver as a freshman. He has marginal top-end speed but excellent size. He's a powerful runner with outstanding contact balance. He shows good body control and adjusts well to balls thrown outside his frame. -- Steve Muench

Coughlin was a four-year player and three-year starter, and during his final three seasons combined for 134 tackles, 36 tackles for loss and 20.5 sacks. He also forced seven fumbles. He has solid size, and his combine workout was outstanding, including elite results in the 40-yard dash (4.57), 10-yard split (1.54) and broad jump (10-6). He has upper-body pop and typically controls tight ends at the point of attack. Coughlin has straight-line speed and explosive initial power, but he needs to develop better counter moves when reached. And while he shows recovery speed in coverage, he also takes a lot of false steps. He is much more natural as a pass-rusher than in coverage. Coughlin has intriguing physical tools and was highly productive throughout his career at Minnesota, and he grades out as a backup linebacker who will need to create value on special teams early in his career. -- March 2020 Coughlin had an outstanding combine workout. He has good upper-body pop and typically controls tight ends at the point of attack. He has good recovery speed but is more natural rushing the passer than he is in coverage. -- Steve Muench

In his final two seasons, Stone finished with 109 tackles, seven passes broken up, five interceptions and four forced fumbles. He has solid size and below-average top-end speed. A naturally instinctive player, Stone shows good recognition skills and fast eyes, and he does well when working forward. Quicker than fast, Stone has adequate range in zone coverage, and he is at his best in two-high zone and when working underneath as an in-the-box safety. He struggles to handle single-high responsibility and has some tightness and will be limited in many man-to-man coverage situations in the NFL. Stone has soft hands and shows an ability to pluck away from frame. But he really struggles to locate the ball vertically and is frequently late getting his head around. Against the run. Stone is decisive. Stone projects as a backup SS and core special-teamer in the NFL. -- March 2020 Stone has good size, short arms and so-so straight-line speed. He's a naturally instinctive player with good recognition skills and fast eyes. He's at his best in two-high zone and in the box. Stone isn't rangy enough to handle single-high responsibility, and he has below-average man-to-man cover skills. He's a tough run defender who fills hard and chases with good effort. -- Steve Muench

During his final three seasons, Hill caught 181 passes for 2,045 yards (11.3 per reception) with 19 TDs. He also averaged 5.7 yards on 45 puntreturn attempts. Hill is a slightly undersized slot receiver with average playing speed. He's smooth with average burst getting in and out of breaks. And he's an instinctive runner who flashes the ability to make the first defender miss. Hill has a good catch radius for his size and will make tough catches in traffic, but he still has too many focus drops. He lacks deep speed and will never be a big-play vertical threat. Hill grades out as a sub-package slot receiver and potential return man. -- March 2020 Hill is an undersized slot receiver who is smooth with average burst getting in and out of breaks. He's an instinctive runner who shows the ability to make the first defender miss after the catch. He lacks deep speed and will never be a vertical threat. Hill was pound-for-pound one of the toughest players on the Ohio State team. -- Steve Muench

Thomas-Oliver III has the frame and speed to develop into an effective press corner. He does an adequate job of transitioning out of pedal for a taller corner, and he closes well breaking on passes thrown in front of him. He's not a playmaker despite hand span. He had two passes go off his hands in the 2019 Miami game. He's a below-average tackler who takes too long to get off blocks. -- Steve Muench

Benjamin, a team captain, rushed for 2,725 yards and 26 touchdowns over his final two seasons. His ability to shift gears jumps out on tape, and he has the foot speed to bounce between seams. He's a fearless between-the-tackles runner who takes some big hits. He runs hard and flashes good contact balance so he picks up some yards after contact even though he doesn't have a great power base. He's got the tools to develop into a productive receiver, but he drops some passes. He's a below-average pass-blocker at this point. Benjamin grades out as a rotational back with some upside in the passing game. -- March 2020 Benjamin was a team captain who didn't test as well as expected, but his ability to shift gears jumps out on tape. He runs hard and flashes good contact balance so he picks up yards after contact even though he doesn't have a great powerbase. He has the tools to develop into a productive receiver but drops some passes. -- Steve Muench

Claybrooks is undersized with good speed. He moved from receiver to corner in 2018 and he's still learning the position. He has some upside. He's a dangerous kickoff returner who took one back 94 yards for a touchdown in 2019. -- Steve Muench

McDonald was a two-year starter at Hawaii. He has good height and bulk with solid hand span. His pocket presence is impressive. And while he possesses a long delivery, he has solid arm strength, and he puts good ball placement on short and intermediate throws. McDonald has some intriguing traits but grades out as a career reserve QB. -- April 2020 McDonald has good height and bulk in addition to a solid hand span. He has a long delivery but good arm strength, and he has solid ball placement on short and intermediate throws. He has excellent timed speed and his pocket presence is impressive. -- Steve Muench

Willekes does a good job of knocking blockers' hands down and quickly slipping blocks while rushing the passer. He has an effective inside move. Initial burst and closing speed appear average. He's not a natural interior pass-rusher. He's a disruptive run defender who makes plays in the backfield. He presses and sets the edge working against tight ends. There's room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks. Willekes grades out as a No. 3 defensive end with the potential to develop into a starter early in his career. He projects as a Day 2 pick. -- June 2019 Willekes was a team captain and was once a walk-on. He has average size, below-average top-end speed and short arms. He has good upper-body strength, and he's an effective hand fighter rushing the passer. Willekes is a disruptive run defender who slips blocks and makes plays in the backfield. He's relentless chasing the run and rushing the passer. -- Steve Muench

Hambright is quick with average size. He has lined up at guard and tackle. He projects best at guard. He gets set quickly and flashes a strong punch in pass pro. He fires off the ball and gets good initial push in the run game. -- Steve Muench

Simmons has good size and long arms. He's a versatile offensive lineman who has lined up at left guard, right guard, left tackle and right tackle. He's not a finished product, but there's a lot to like about his upside. -- Steve Muench

Smith-Williams, a team captain and two-year starter, has an NFL frame, good length and ran the fastest 40 out of all the defensive linemen at the combine. He flashes considerable upside on tape. He's strong enough to stack blockers and set the edge against the run. He flashes the ability to win with power and has the tools to develop into an effective edge rusher. However, he has struggled to stay healthy, and it has hindered his progress. He sustained season-ending injuries in 2015 and 2016. He missed five games in 2019. North Carolina State recognizes a player for his work ethic, character, leadership and accomplishments by giving them the No. 1 jersey and gave it to him in 2019. -- March 2020 Smith-Williams, a team captain and two-year starter, has an NFL frame, good length and ran the fastest 40 out of all the defensive linemen at the combine. He flashes considerable upside on tape. He's strong enough to stack blockers and set the edge against the run. He flashes the ability to win with power and has the tools to develop into an effective edge rusher. -- Steve Muench

Woodward is a four-year starter who has played all three positions along the interior offensive line. He's an undersized overachiever with below-average length, but he gets into position and blocks to the echo of the whistle. -- Steve Muench

DiNucci is a Pitt transfer who lit it up over the past two seasons at James Madison. He has good arm strength. He flashes good pocket presence and the ability to climb the pocket. He's a threat to take off and run. He's lean and ideally fills out his frame. -- Steve Muench

Davis ran a 4.82 40 at 313 pounds at the combine and like his brother he has some upside. He has good upper-body strength and flashes a strong punch. He needs to play with better pad level and improve his hand-to-hand combat skills. He's a better run defender than pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

Toohill is coming off a breakout redshirt season and tested well at the combine. He lined up as a standup outside linebacker, at defensive end and over the slot at Stanford. He projects best at 3-4 OLB in the NFL. He has the burst, bend and closing speed to develop into a disruptive edge rusher. He needs to develop as a hand fighter and flesh out his pass-rush arsenal. He's not as effective dropping and in space as he is attacking upfield. He's 17 pounds lighter than the five-year combine average for defensive ends, and he gets moved off the ball too much. He closes well chasing from the back side. -- March 2020 Toohill is coming off a breakout redshirt season and tested well at the combine. He lined up as a standup outside linebacker, at defensive end and over the slot at Stanford. He projects best at 34OLB in the NFL. He has the burst, bend and closing speed to develop into a disruptive edge rusher. He needs to develop as a hand fighter and flesh out his pass-rush arsenal. -- Steve Muench

Johnston has had some problems staying healthy. He's undersized with short arms, but he has been productive when he able to play. He's instinctive, he chases with great effort, and he's an above-average tackler. There's a lot to like about his upside on special teams. -- Steve Muench

Cornell is a one-year starter who played defensive tackle and defensive end at Ohio State. He's big enough to set the edge against the run and has some upside as an interior pass-rusher, but he projects as a rotational defensive lineman not a starter. -- Steve Muench

Scott is a versatile defensive back with experience lining up at corner and safety. He has good cover skills for his size and is active in run support. He had two career picks, and he's not a ball hawk. He's a one-year starter. -- Steve Muench

Keyes has the size and length to match up with bigger receivers on the outside. He lunges and his footwork needs work, but he has the tools to develop into an effective press corner in time. He flashes the ability to get off blocks and make plays in run support. -- Steve Muench

Brunson, a two-time team captain and three-year starter, is a hard-nosed, between-the-tackles run defender and sure tackler. He's not a sideline-to-sideline run defender, and there are concerns about his ability to hold up in coverage at the NFL level. -- Steve Muench

Jackson, a team captain and three-year starter, has below-average top-end speed, weight and length. He's tough, he shows good awareness, and he limits production after the catch. He's tight, he has below-average recovery speed, and he gets grabby. He picked off one pass over the past two seasons and a receiver threw the ball. He has short arms and small hands. He takes too long to get off some blocks, but he doesn't shy away from contact in run support. -- March 2020 Jackson is a three-year starter with below-average size, length and timed speed. He's tough, he shows good awareness and he limits production after the catch. But Jackson is tight, he has below-average recovery speed and he gets grabby. He's also not a ball hawk. -- Steve Muench

Stevens is a graduate transfer from Penn State who was named a team captain in his only season at Mississippi State. He's got an outstanding combination of size and speed. He's a streaky passer and a better athlete than quarterback at this point. -- Steve Muench

Russell was a three-year starter. He's versatile enough to line up on the inside and the outside. He's at his best shooting gaps and disrupting plays in the backfield when he lines up between the tackles. He flashes the ability to stack and shed despite average size and speed. He chases with good effort and he plays a little faster than timed. He runs well and shows better awareness in coverage than he does as a run defender. He started every game over the past two seasons. -- March 2020 Russell is a three-year starter with average size and speed. He's versatile enough to line up on the inside and the outside. He's at his best shooting gaps and disrupting plays in the backfield when he lines up between the tackles. He chases with good effort, and he plays a little faster than his timed speed. -- Steve Muench

Garvin is a promising pass-rusher with good length, bend and initial quickness. He flashes the ability to slip blocks with his hands, and he plays a little faster than his timed top-end speed. He frequently stalls out when he doesn't win with his first move, and his motor is inconsistent. He has an NFL frame, he has some explosive power and he flashes the ability to set the edge, yet he needs to get stronger and more consistent in this area. He gives ground too much at this point. -- March 2020 Garvin has a good frame, long arms and average top-end speed. He has good initial quickness and flashes the ability to slip blocks rushing the passer. He frequently stalls out when he doesn't win with his first move. He has some explosive power and shows the ability to set the edge against the run. -- Steve Muench
Jackson is a four-year starter with below-average size but average length and excellent top-end speed. He's got small hands, but he flashes the ability to make plays in coverage. -- Steve Muench

Stanley comes from a pro-style system and has prototypical size, but he's not nearly as agile or mobile as most top quarterback prospects entering the NFL in recent years. He has very good arm strength and shows an above-average command of the offense. He locates the open man and gets though his progressions. He also made huge improvements in his decision-making late in his college career. But he's streaky with his accuracy and struggles with touch throws and under pressure. Stanley does fit the ball into some tight spots that many QBs cannot, and his deep-ball accuracy is outstanding. He takes too long to get to the top of his drop, and he doesn't have the foot quickness to sidestep interior pressure. He appears faster than quick and can scramble for the occasional first down. Stanley grades out as a pocket passer with good size and arm strength but needs to be more accurate and take better care of the football. -- March 2020 Stanley has prototypical size and good arm strength. He showed above-average command of a pro-style system and made strides in terms of his decision-making at Iowa. He's streaky with his accuracy and struggles with touch throws. He's not nearly as agile or mobile as most of the top quarterback prospects in recent years. -- Steve Muench

Calais is an undersized back with very good initial quickness and top-end speed. He never led the team in rushing while he was at Louisiana, but he averaged 91.5 all-purpose yards per game. He was a productive kickoff returner who returned two kickoffs for touchdowns in 2017 and averaged 28.5 yards per kickoff return in 2019. He lacks the power to regularly break initial contact. He's a small target with shorter arms. He lacks the size and strength to anchor in pass pro. Career (1.58) and 2019 (1.57) fumble percentages are concerns. -- April 2020 Calais never led the team in rushing while he was at Louisiana-Lafayette, but he averaged 91.5 all-purpose yards per game. He's an undersized back with very good initial quickness and top-end speed. He lacks the power to regularly break initial contact. He's a small target with shorter arms in the passing game. -- Steve Muench

Perry is small, will have to move from quarterback to receiver or running back and didn't test well at the combine -- but he rushed for more than 2,000 yards in Navy's run-heavy scheme last season. You should watch his highlights before you count him out. He's tough, he plays faster than his timed speed, and he has a way of making defenders look silly when he gets into space. -- Steve Muench

Adams started 44 games at left tackle. He is a tall offensive tackle with above-average length and good size but marginal top-end speed. He gets into position and walls off defenders in the run game. He also does an adequate job of climbing up to the second level and covering up linebackers. He leans and falls off some blocks late, but he's quick, long and wide enough to handle speed off the edge when his technique is sound. His initial hand placement tends to be strong, but there's room for improvement when it comes to resetting and his overall hand-to-hand combat skills. He does an adequate job of anchoring but has a high center of gravity and gives up ground at times. He's not an elite athlete, so inside and weave moves give him problems. Adams grades out a backup tackle with the potential to develop into a starter in time if he can stay healthy. -- April 2020 Adams gets into position and walls off defenders in the run game. He does an adequate job of climbing up to the second level and covering up linebackers. He's quick, long and wide enough to handle speed off the edge when his technique is sound. His initial hand placement tends to be strong, but there's room for improvement when it comes his overall hand-to-hand combat skills. -- Steve Muench

Bryant is a smaller F tight end with short arms, massive hands and slightly above-average top-end speed. He's at his best lining up at H-back, fullback and in the slot. He tracks the ball well and plays a little faster than his timed speed. He's an above-average open-field runner after the catch and flashes as a route runner. He's a natural hands catcher who makes tough contested catches over the middle. Bryant is also a willing blocker, though he lacks the size and strength to be an effective in-line blocker at the NFL level at this point. Bryant grades out as an H-back with the versatility to move around the formation and make an impact as a receiver. -- April 2020 Bryant tracks the ball well and plays faster than his timed speed. He's an above-average open-field runner. He has the occasional drop, but he has big hands and makes tough contested catches. He's a willing lead blocker, too. He lacks the size and strength to be an effective in-line blocker at the NFL level. -- Steve Muench

Hill was a four-year player and three-year starter (47 career games played) at Michigan who has recorded 55 tackles, 25 passes broken up and six interceptions (two returned for TDs) in his final three seasons. Hill is a shorter, lean corner with shorter arms. He has experience lining up on the perimeter and in the slot. He has the quick feet and fluid hips to mirror receivers underneath. He shows above-average instincts in man, and he plays the ball -- not the man -- in zone. The biggest concern outside of his marginal size is his grabby style; he had 15 penalties in the past two seasons. He also struggles to get off blocks. In run support, he is tough and physical but falls off too many tackles. Hill grades out as a No. 3 or No. 4 slot corner in the NFL. -- April 2020 Hill is a shorter, lean corner with shorter arms. He has the quick feet and fluid hips to mirror receivers underneath. He shows good instincts in man, and he plays the ball rather than the man in zone. Biggest concern outside of marginal size is grabby style -- 15 penalties the past two seasons. Hill is tough, but he falls off too many tackles. -- Steve Muench

Lipscomb appeared poised for a breakout senior season after catching an SEC-best 87 passes for 916 yards (10.5 yards per catch) and nine touchdowns in 2018, but his production dipped substantially in 2019. Vanderbilt had a new offensive coordinator and new quarterback plus he missed the South Carolina game due to personal reasons. He lines up on the inside and the outside in Vanderbilt's scheme. He's a savvy route runner with just adequate burst transitioning out of breaks. He could have some problems separating from NFL corners on the outside. He's a natural hands catcher with long arms. He's an instinctive open-field runner who picks up some yards after contact after the catch. He's not a smooth ankle-breaker with pull away speed. He lacks the second gear to take the top off the coverage. -- March 2020 Lipscomb is on the shorter side with good bulk, above-average length and below-average timed speed. He's a natural hands catcher with a wide catching radius. He's a savvy route runner with adequate burst. He's an instinctive open-field runner who picks up some yards after contact. He lacks the second gear to take the top off the coverage and pull away after the catch. -- Steve Muench

Coe has outstanding size for a DE prospect and shows average initial quickness but marginal top-end speed. His vertical jump of just 29 inches at the combine is also a red flag. His first step and upper-body strength make him a threat to get to the quarterback when he kicks inside. He's a developing hand fighter who doesn't counter well and makes it a little too easy for offensive tackles to get their hands on him, but he has the tools to develop into a productive edge rusher. His pads rise, and he gives ground on occasion, but he's got the bulk and strength to set a hard edge against the run. He closes well chasing from the backside. Coe plays on the inside and the outside. He's a 3-4 OLB candidate, but his best fit is at defensive end as he shows some tightness on space. Coe grades out as a developmental edge defender some upside. -- March 2020 Coe has outstanding size and average length but below-average speed for a defensive end prospect. He has the bulk and strength to set a hard edge against the run when he keeps his pads down. He lacks upside as an edge rusher. Coe's first step and upper-body strength make him more of a threat to the get to the quarterback when he kicks inside. -- Steve Muench

Davis is an undersized corner with short arms, small hands and outstanding top-end speed. He has above-average burst, and he's smooth, but he's not big enough to match up outside. He finished his career with eight picks and flashes good ball skills. He's a willing run defender who shows good stopping power for his size, but he's an inconsistent finisher. -- Steve Muench

Mack has above-average size and adequate top-end speed, but he's definitely quicker than he is fast. He played mostly outside at Ohio State but has quickness and toughness to also play in the slot at the next level. He is quick off the line, shows suddenness in and out of breaks and has a good feel for locating holes versus zone coverage. Mack also does a good job of setting up defenders and leveraging his stem. He has a quick transition upfield after the catch and shows good body control to adjust. He does have a few drops on tape, but they were mostly focus drops. Mack tracks the deep ball well and does a good job adjusting. And while he lacks a top gear as a vertical route runner, he shows good vision and some shiftiness after the catch -- but he will never be a home-run hitter. In the run game, he is aggressive and a strong blocker. Mack has outstanding intangibles and work ethic. Durability has been an issue, but he showed toughness throughout his career. -- March 2020 Mack has good size with adequate top-end speed. He's quicker than fast, and he's sudden getting in and out of breaks. He plucks the ball with his hands and quickly transitions upfield after the catch. He shows good vision and some shiftiness after the catch but will never be a home run hitter. He has outstanding intangibles and work ethic. -- Steve Muench

Pinkney enjoyed a breakout season in 2018 when he had the most catches for a Vanderbilt tight end in one season since 1984. His production dropped substantially in 2019, although it's worth noting that there was a new quarterback and new offensive coordinator. He lines up in-line and in the slot. He has big hands and good body control. He has the occasional focus drop, and there's room for improvement when it comes to using his frame to shield defenders from the ball. He plays faster than his timed speed, but he's not going to run by many linebackers, and he's not much of a threat after the catch. He's an adequate positional in-line blocker who flashes the ability to generate some push. He can get stronger and improve his hand placement. He's smooth climbing and walling off linebackers at the second level. -- March 2020 Pinkney has good size, massive hands but poor top-end speed. He plays a little faster than his timed speed and is quicker than fast, but he's not going to run by many linebackers. He looked like more of a threat after the catch in 2018 than he did in 2019. He's an adequate positional inline blocker who flashes the ability to generate some push. -- Steve Muench

Davis has good size and average top-end speed with slightly below-average length. He flashes as a route runner, is smooth transitioning upfield and shows good instincts after the catch. He doesn't have the second gear to take the top off the coverage or pull away from pursuit. And he's at his best working out of the slot. -- Steve Muench

Steele, a two-time team captain and four-year starter, moved from left tackle to right tackle late in his redshirt freshman season. He has outstanding length. He doesn't bend well, and he's vulnerable to speed to power. He ducks his head and lunges at the top of his set. He gets caught flat-footed and loses to the inside. He's a better run-blocker than pass-blocker though he fits better in a power-heavy scheme than a zone-heavy scheme. -- April 2020 Steele is a developmental prospect with good size in addition to excellent length and quickness. He has experience lining up on the right and left sides. He's a better run-blocker than pass-blocker at this point and he fits better in a power-heavy scheme than a zone-heavy scheme. -- Steve Muench

Victor has excellent frame and length but just marginal initial burst and top-end speed. His best trait is his ball skills. Victor is a hands catcher and makes tough contested catches. As a route runner, he is instinctive and does a good job of getting late separation. He possesses a good feel for finding holes in zone coverage. But he's not a sudden athlete, he lacks flexibility, and he's slow in and out of breaks. Victor rarely separates with burst out of his breaks. He will struggle to get off press coverage at times as well. While he averaged 16 yards per catch, he doesn't project as much of a vertical threat in the NFL and doesn't offer much after the catch. Victor has the length and hands to develop into a good No. 3 option in the NFL but needs to get stronger. -- March 2020 Victor has an excellent frame and length but he's lean with marginal top-end speed. His best trait is his ball skills. He's a hands catcher with soft hands who makes tough catches. He's an instinctive route runner with a good feel for finding holes in zone coverage. Victor is not a sudden athlete getting in and out of breaks. He doesn't project as a big-play threat despite averaging 16.1 yards per catch in college. -- Steve Muench

Bassey, a team captain in 2019 and a three-year starter, reads the quarterback and tracks the ball well in zone coverage. He gets overaggressive and bites on receivers' first moves in man. He's quick with good change of direction and above-average speed. Frame and below-average length raise concerns about his ability to match up with bigger receivers in the NFL. He broke up 40 passes over the past three seasons. He has very small hands, and he's not a natural hands catcher. He squares and wraps up when action comes his way in run support. He struggles to get off blocks. -- April 2020 Bassey has below-average size, shorter arms and very good top-end speed. He's quick with good change-of-direction. Frame raises concerns about ability to match up with bigger receivers in the NFL. He broke up 40 passes over the past three seasons, but he has very small hands and he's not a natural hands catcher. Bassey squares and wraps up when action comes his way in run support. -- Steve Muench

Green, a team captain in 2019, was a three-year starter. He gets early breaks on underneath routes and tends to limit production after the catch. He's a big corner and he does a decent job of rerouting receivers in press coverage. He lacks ideal fluidity and gets grabby transitioning out of breaks. His timed top-end speed is a borderline red flag for a corner, and he has below-average recovery speed on tape. He had four picks in 2017 and he flashes above-average ball skills -- see his 2018 interception against Texas Tech. He has two picks total over the past two seasons, and he has short arms for his frame and the position. He flashes in run support but he takes too long to get off some blocks. -- March 2020 Green is a bigger corner with marginal top-end speed, shorter arms and smaller hands. He breaks on underneath routes and tends to limit production after the catch. He had four picks in 2017 and flashes above-average ball skills - see his 2018 interception against Texas Tech. He's tight and gets grabby transitioning out of breaks. Green flashes in run support, but he takes too long to get off blocks. -- Steve Muench

The son of Randy Moss, Thaddeus began his career at NC State before transferring to LSU in 2017 (he sat out 2017 due to transfer rules and redshirted in 2018, so he was a one-year starter at LSU). He is a short but thickly built tight end with shorter arms and average hand size. He shows below-average top-end speed on tape and did not participate in workouts at the combine. But he has very good ball skills -- he did not have a dropped pass in 2019. As a blocker, he is competitive, tough and strong. Moss shows some savvy as a route runner but has below-average athleticism. He seemed to play his best in the biggest games. Moss grades out as a No. 3 TE in the NFL. -- April 2020 Moss is a short, thickly built tight end with shorter arms and average hand span. He did not drop a pass in 2019. He's a competitive, tough and a strong blocker. He shows some savvy, but he's not a fluid or explosive route runner. Moss shows below-average top-end speed on tape and he did not participate in workouts at the combine. -- Steve Muench

Taylor is a tall and lean offensive tackle with excellent upside. He has outstanding arm length and borderline outstanding initial quickness. He can be dominant on tape but is not a finished product. He lunges at times in pass pro, has some problems keeping his pads down and is not a consistent finisher in the run game. -- Steve Muench

Williams, a redshirt senior, holds his ground, tracks the ball well and flashes the ability to get off blocks in time to make the play. He has the ability to skip blocks and make plays in the backfield. He's not a space-eater who occupies multiple blockers and frees up his linebackers. He chases with good effort. He's not a great hand fighter. and he needs to develop a counter move rushing the passer. He stalls out as a bull-rusher. He projects better at 3-4 DE and DT than he does at NT where he frequently lines up in Michigan State's scheme. Williams grades out as a rotational defensive tackle and he projects as a mid-round pick. -- June 2019 Williams is a taller, leaner defensive tackle with good length and above-average timed speed. He's a better run defender than pass-rusher. Williams can play on the inside in a four-man front and the outside in a three-man front. -- Steve Muench

Johnson has exceptional size and length for a wideout, and his 40-yard dash time and 10-yard splits were well aboveaverage for the top-tier NFL starters at the position. Ball skills are Johnson's biggest weakness. But he shows solid initial acceleration off the line, especially for such a big target. While he struggles to generate separation out of breaks at the top of his stem, he has the built-in frame to create late separation. He has never been a great vertical threat and doesn't offer much elusiveness or suddenness after the catch. He is also surprisingly ineffective in the red zone for such a massive target. But Johnson has a unique combination of size, length and acceleration. His ability to generate mismatches in the passing game makes Johnson an intriguing Day 3 prospect in 2020. -- March 2020 Johnson has exceptional size and length with good speed for his size. He struggles to separate getting in and out of breaks. Ball skills are his biggest weakness. -- Steve Muench

Robinson was a three-year starter who finished his career ranked second in the Illinois State record books in rushing yards, rushing touchdowns, all-purpose yards and total touchdowns scored. He's built low to the ground, runs hard and has above-average contact balance. He's not an ankle-breaker but has a knack for making the first defender miss and avoiding big hits. He's quicker than fast and doesn't project as a breakaway threat at the NFL level. Robinson is a small target with short arms and small hands, yet he flashes good ball skills. He's not much of a big-play threat after the catch, though. Robinson didn't run well at the combine but has the potential to develop into an effective rotational back based off the tape. -- April 2020 Robinson is built low to the ground, runs hard and has above-average contact balance. He has a knack for making the first defender miss and avoiding big hits. He's quicker than fast. He's a small target with short arms and small hands, yet he flashes good ball skills. Robinson is not much of a big-play threat after the catch. -- Steve Muench

Taumoepeau, a three-year starter, is a hybrid tight end /slot receiver. He locates pockets in zone looks and he has the change-of-direction skills to develop into an above-average route runner. He's smooth transitioning upfield and fast enough to make plays down the seam. He doesn't practice good ball-security habits. He has shorter arms and he has the occasional focus drop. He's a competitive blocker in space. He lacks the size and strength to hold up as an in-line blocker at the NFL level. -- April 2020 Taumoepeau is a hybrid tight end/slot receiver. He locates pockets in zone looks and has the change-of-direction skills to develop into a solid route runner. He's smooth transitioning upfield and fast enough to make plays down the seam. Taumoepeau has shorter arms and has the occasional focus drop. He lacks the size and strength to hold up as an in-line blocker. -- Steve Muench

Galeai is an undersized edge defender with explosive get-off, good bend and above-average closing speed. He has above-average lateral mobility. He flashes violent hands and an effective long arm. He has good length for his frame and the position. He's a disruptive run defender with the hands and feet to slips blocks quickly. He flashes the ability to stack blockers. His 2019 Wake Forest tape is impressive. However, he's light and he gives ground at times. He has more upside as a 3-4 OLB than a DE. He's more effective rushing the passer, but he has experience dropping. He was not allowed to participate in on-field drills or interviews with media at the combine because of a 2017 misdemeanor assault charge. He transferred from TCU to Utah State in 2017 and sat out the season in accordance with NCAA transfer rules. He can serve as a long-snapper. -- March 2020 Galeai is a lean edge defender with good length. He's got the explosive get-off, bend and closing speed to develop into a disruptive edge rusher. He flashes the ability to stack blockers but gives ground and is a better pass-rusher than run defender. -- Steve Muench

Ahmed is a leaner back with below-average timed speed, short arms and small hands. He's a patient runner who is quicker than fast and shows good burst through the hole. He's not much of a threat to pull away when he gets a seam and doesn't have great power. Ahmed is a small target with a small catching radius but flashes soft hands and the ability to adjust to passes thrown outside his frame. Ahmed grades out as a rotational back. -- April 2020 Ahmed is a patient runner who is quicker than fast and shows good burst through the hole. He's not of a threat to pull away when he gets a seam, and he doesn't have great power. He's a small target with a small catching radius but flashes soft hands and the ability to adjust to passes thrown outside his frame. -- Steve Muench

Charlton is a right-footed punter who owns the school records for career (45.5 yards) and single-season (47.7) yards per punt averages. He had a school-record 27 punts go 50 yards or farther and 28 were marked inside the 20-yard line in 2019. He holds on place-kick attempts but doesn't kick off. -- Steve Muench

Taylor rushed for 1,122 yards and 16 touchdowns in 2018 while splitting carries with 2019 third-round pick Darrell Henderson. He appeared poised for a monster 2019 after rushing for 128 yards and a touchdown against Ole Miss in the season opener, but missed the next eight games with a foot injury. He runs with good forward lean and lowers his shoulder on contact. He's high cut and runs with a narrow base. Taylor has average burst and below-average elusiveness but above-average hands and the potential to develop into a reliable receiver. He can work out of the slot and flashes the ability to make plays over the middle. And he can step up and meet defenders in pass pro. Taylor grades out as a rotational back with some third-down value. -- April 2020 Taylor runs with good forward lean and lowers his shoulder on contact. He's high-cut and runs with a narrow base, and he has average burst and below-average elusiveness. He has above-average hands, though, and the potential to develop into a reliable receiver. He can work out of the slot and flashes the ability to make plays over the middle. -- Steve Muench

Mack was a team captain and four-year starter. He has the size and strength to hold up between the tackles. He's an above-average tackler with good stopping power. He has average closing speed and chases with good effort. He shows adequate awareness and range in coverage. He flashes the ability to run over offensive linemen, but he doesn't win enough battles with his hands rushing the passer. He shows adequate awareness and range in underneath coverage. He missed the Orange Bowl after having season-ending surgery on a lower extremity injury that hampered him the last four games of the 2019 season. -- March 2020

Leake, a true junior in 2019, was the Rodgers-Dwight Big Ten Return Specialist of the Year. He tied the school record for kickoff return touchdowns with three and averaged 25.2 yards per return in his three seasons at Maryland. He's a dangerous kickoff returner who plays faster than his timed speed. He's faster than quick. He doesn't show great burst through the hole. He has decent contact balance despite a higher center of gravity and leaner lower body. He's not a power back who can push the pile in short-yardage situations. He's not a natural receiver. He appears willing, but there's room for improvement when it comes to technique and awareness in pass pro. Ball security habits will have to improve for him to play any kind of role on offense in the NFL. Of the 31 backs we tracked he has the worst 2019 (3.6) and career (4.5) fumble percentages. -- March 2020 Leake is a dangerous kickoff returner who plays faster than his timed speed and finished his college career with three kickoff returns for touchdowns. But he had the worst 2019 and career fumble percentage of the 29 backs we tracked. -- Steve Muench

Wilcox, a redshirt senior in 2019, was a four-year starter who owns almost every school record for tight ends including all career and season receiving marks. He plays with an edge. He's at his best releasing up to the second level and covering up defenders in space. His technique is a little inconsistent, and he misses on occasion. Ideally he gets bigger and stronger. Battles to stalemate and falls off blocks as an in-line blocker. He's competitive in pass pro. He moves around the formation. He locates windows in zone looks, and he's tough over the middle. He's an adequate route runner with below-average burst. He has good body control and he flashes the ability to make contested catches. He snatches some passes out of the air. He was more consistent on 2019 tape than 2018 tape, but he doesn't catch everything clean plus he has smaller hands and below-average length. He has below-average playing and timed speed. -- March 2020 Wilcox is slightly undersized with less-than-ideal length and timed speed. He plays with an edge. He's at his best releasing up to the second level and covering up defenders in space. Ideally bulks up and gets stronger. He locates windows in zone looks and he's tough over the middle. He's an adequate route runner with not much burst. -- Steve Muench

Jones is a three-year starter with good size, a low center of gravity and shorter arms. He's stout taking on blockers one-on-one, and he has active hands and flashes the ability to push the pocket. But he tends to stall out when he doesn't win with his first move. -- Steve Muench

Roach played defensive end and linebacker at Texas. He's a tweener with below-average length for a defensive end and below-average weight for a defensive tackle. He has active hands and flashes the ability to slip blocks in the run game. He has the size and low center of gravity to set the edge, but he has very short arms and can give ground when blockers get into his frame. He's a relatively one-dimensional power rusher with average initial quickness, though he flashes an effective inside move coming off the edge. He has some upside as an interior pass-rusher. -- April 2020

Taylor is undersized but runs with violence and a great center of gravity. He is willing in pass protection but has obvious limitations. And he is a natural pass-catcher with good vision and quickness after the catch. Additionally, Taylor has been very productive as a kick returner and has the potential to win a starting job in that role in the NFL. Taylor is best suited to play in a rotation but offers value as a runner, pass-catcher and special-teams player. He is an underrated prospect who should come off the board early on Day 3. -- March 2020 Taylor is vastly undersized with short arms, small hands and below-average timed speed. He's a violent runner with a low center of gravity, as well as a natural pass-catcher with good vision and quickness after the catch. He's a productive kick returner, too, and has the potential to win a starting job in that role in the NFL. -- Steve Muench

Coatney has average size, short arms and below-average top-end speed. He flashes the ability to stack blockers and set the edge, but he takes too long to close, and he's a better run defender than pass-rusher. -- Steve Muench

Higby, a redshirt senior, does an adequate job of getting his hands inside, and he's quick to reset when his initial placement isn't good in pass pro. He does a job of staying in front of his assignment. He's light for a guard yet he does an adequate job of anchoring. He's not as effective at tackle as he is on the inside. His angles and initial footwork are inconsistent but he has the frame, initial quickness and athletic ability to develop into an effective zone and wall-off blocker. He gets some push and picks up linebackers on combo blocks. He doesn't have the power base to drive defenders off the ball in one-on-one situations. Higby grades out as a versatile backup interior offensive lineman who could develop into a functional starter in time. He projects as a mid-round pick. -- June 2019

Samuels is an early-entry prospect who was a three-year player and two-year starter at Florida State. During the past two seasons, he notched 118 tackles, 11 passes broken up and six INTs. He has good height, adequate bulk and average arm length. But he ran the slowest 40-yard dash time (4.65) of any cornerback at this year's combine. He does have quick feet when backpedaling, and he is smooth for a taller corner. He can open seamlessly, has good redirection quickness and shows solid ball skills. But again, the lack of top-end speed is a major concern. Samuels has a somewhat lean frame and lacks strength in run support. He grades out as a No. 4 or No. 5 cornerback in the NFL and will need to contribute on special teams in order to keep a roster spot. -- April 2020 Samuels has good height and adequate bulk with average arm length. He has big hands and good ball skills. He's smooth for a taller corner, but speed is a major concern. He ran the slowest 40-yard dash time (4.65) of any cornerback at this year's combine. Samuels is somewhat lean and needs to get stronger against the run. -- Steve Muench

Montez, a redshirt senior in 2019, was a three-year starter. Colorado's record was 15-21 over the past three seasons. He completed 62.7% of his passes for 8,632 yards and close to a 2-1 (54-28) touchdown-to-interception ratio during that span. He finished his career with 958 rushing yards and 11 rushing touchdowns. He played the final game of the 2019 season with a broken rib. He's a right-handed quarterback with an NFL frame and above-average arm strength. He flashes the ability to extend plays with his feet and make off-balance throws. He has the strength and top-end speed to scramble for first downs. Tape raises concerns about his ability to decipher coverage and see the whole field. He tends to hold onto the ball too long when his first read isn't there. His footwork in the pocket needs work, and he's not as accurate as his completion percentage would suggest. -- March 2020

Throckmorton was a five-year player and four-year starter at Oregon. He played all five offensive line positions during his career at Oregon. Throckmorton has good height and weight but short arms for the OT position. He also has marginal speed and lower-body explosion. He struggles to bend and lacks overall flexibility. But he does show some shock in his hands, which gives him a chance against more athletic and twitchy pass-rushers. He has good awareness and angles as a run blocker, and he does a good job with hand strength to control defenders when he latches on. But he really struggles with moving targets and maintaining balance in space. -- March 2020

Jones possesses good size but below-average speed. He is a big, one-cut, downhill runner with good vision. However, Jones lacks some lateral agility and doesn't have a second gear when he hits daylight. He continues to improve as a route runner and has been a reliable pass-catcher underneath. Jones has excellent ball security, with zero fumbles on 298 career offensive touches. He covers it up in traffic and carries it high and tight. He has size and lower-body strength to anchor in pass protection but could use more aggressiveness and better technique. Jones should be a contributor in a rotation but does not project as a featured back in the NFL. -- March 2020 Jones is a big back with below-average timed speed. He's a one-cut downhill runner with good vision and lower-body strength. He lacks lateral agility and doesn't show a second gear when he hits daylight. He's a reliable receiver who continues to improve as a route runner, and he has the potential to develop into an effective pass-blocker. -- Steve Muench

Fuller is undersized with below-average timed speed, small hands and short arms. He's a savvy and smooth route runner who knows how to get open despite average burst. But there's room for improvement when it comes to coming down with contested catches. He traps and drops some passes, and he's not much of a big-play threat. Fuller grades out as a sub-package slot receiver with limited upside. -- April 2020 Fuller is undersized with below-average timed speed, small hands and short arms. He's a savvy and smooth route runner who knows how to get open despite average burst. There's room for improvement when it comes to coming down with contested catches, and he traps and drops some passes. He's not much of a big-play threat. -- Steve Muench

Bandy is a true junior and two-year starter. He's a versatile defensive back who lines up on the outside and inside. He's undersized and projects best at nickel in the NFL. He flashes good short-area quickness and balance. He's late reacting to some breaks and he reacts more than he anticipates.
