He's not a ball hawk and had no interceptions in 2019, but he's flashed above-average ball skills, most notably in the 2018 Virginia game. He's an inconsistent tackler. -- March 2020

Cervenka was a five-year player and two-year starter at Clemson. He has experience at guard and center. He has adequate height with a thick build and average top-end speed. He lacks agility in pass pro, but he's strong as a run blocker, though he has limited range. Cervenka possesses good awareness and toughness. He grades out as a possible reserve lineman. -- April 2020

Hamilton has active hands and flashes the ability to slip blocks. He has very short arms for an edge prospect and some problems getting off blocks once reached. Plus, he gets pushed around at times. But he chases with outstanding effort and does a good job of working back inside once he's even with the quarterback. Hamilton has below-average closing speed. He lines up on the inside and the outside at North Texas, and he flashes potential as an interior pass-rusher. He's tight in space and doesn't appear to be an ideal 3-4 OLB conversion candidate. Hamilton grades out as a rotational 4-3 DE with limited upside. -- April 2020 Hamilton has active hands and flashes the ability to slip bocks. He has short arms for an edge prospect, he has some problems getting off blocks and he gets pushed around at times. He chases the quarterback with outstanding effort and flashes as an interior pass-rusher. But he shows below-average closing speed and limited upside as an edge rusher. --Steve Muench

Woodward, a redshirt junior in 2019, was a two-year starter. He chases with good effort and plays a little faster than timed speed. He's light with shorter arms. He's an inconsistent open-field tackler. He shows good awareness in coverage. He's tight in space. He flashes as a pass-rusher. -- March 2020

Lima is an athletic nose tackle who plays with a low center of gravity and flashes above-average upper body strength. There's some room for improvement when it comes to getting off blocks, but he tracks the ball and has the ability to shed in time to make the play. He's not a two-gap space-eater who protects linebackers by anchoring against double-teams. He's an active hand fighter, but he's not a powerful bull-rusher and he doesn't close well chasing the quarterback. Lima grades out as a rotational defensive tackle and he projects as a potential Day 3 pick. -- June 2019

Carter is an undersized free safety/nickel corner prospect. He is an instinctive player who overcomes tightness in his hips with great recognition skills, technique and angles. His top-end speed appears to be adequate on tape, and he has flashed good ball skills in run support, his pursuit angles are inconsistent, but he does show good closing burst. Carter lacks ideal power at the point of attack but works to wrap up in space. He's a hard worker and clearly understands concepts, helping get the secondary in position. Carter grades out as a versatile backup defensive back in the NFL with the smarts and mindset to contribute on special teams. -- March 2020 Carter is a free safety/nickel prospect with average size and short arms. He's an instinctive player who overcomes tightness in his hips with great recognition skills, technique and angles. He has flashed good ball skills, and he's an adequate wrap-up tackler who chases with good effort. -- Steve Muench

Wood-Anderson started his career at Western Arizona before transferring to Tennessee in 2018. During his two seasons at UT, he had 38 catches for 308 yards and three TDs. He has solid height and bulk, and long arms but marginal speed. He is slow off the line of scrimmage and doesn't separate out of breaks, and he needs to learn to use his size and strength to get late separation. His ball skills are above average, and he displays strong hands in traffic. His best trait is blocking, where he is tough and competitive. Wood-Anderson grades out as a No. 3 TE and is best suited to play the ?Y' tight end position. -- April 2020

Renfro is a tall and lean press corner who appears to have above-average length on tape. He flashes the ability to effectively jam receivers, but his technique is inconsistent, he has below-average recovery speed and he gets grabby at the top of stem. Renfro is an adequate wrap-up tackler. He grades out as a developmental press/zone corner. -- April 2020 Renfro is a tall and lean press corner who appears to have above-average length on tape. He flashes the ability to effectively jam receivers, but his technique is inconsistent, and he has below-average recovery speed. He gets grabby at the top of stem. And he's an adequate wrap-up tackler. -- Steve Muench

Bachie has been a starter since his freshman season and was a team captain as a junior. He's an instinctive inside linebacker with adequate size. He gets covered up by interior offensive linemen. He chases with good effort but doesn't have great closing speed. He's an effective tackler in tight spaces. He shows average awareness in coverage. There are questions about his ability to match up in man and win one-on-one battles rushing the passer. Bachie grades out as a reserve inside linebacker who needs to make substantial contributions on special teams to make an NFL roster. He projects as a potential Day 3 pick. -- June 2019

Gonzalez, a redshirt senior in 2019, was a three-year starter. He's a massive guard who walls off defenders in the run game and does an adequate job of anchoring in pass pro. His feet don't hold up and he steers defenders instead of driving them off the ball. He falls off blocks late and ends up on the ground too much. He fails to extend arms and create separation in pass pro. -- March 2020

Lewerke is a redshirt senior and team captain with an NFL frame, above-average athletic ability and above-average arm strength when he's healthy. He manipulates safeties with his eyes and gets through progressions, yet he also takes unnecessary risks and makes some poor decisions in the face of pressure. His ball placement is inconsistent, and he misses too many throws within the strike zone. He has the straight-line burst to run away from pursuit and scramble for first downs, plus he's strong enough to shake off pass-rushers who fail to wrap up. He's too quick to evacuate the pocket on some plays, though toughness doesn't appear to be an issue. He might not trust his protection which, in fairness, is inconsistent at best. He shows a willingness to take big hits to make plays. He's also shown the willingness and ability to play with a hurt shoulder. Lewerke grades out as an above-average backup with the tools to develop into an effective starter in the NFL if he does a better job of taking care of the ball. He projects as a mid-round pick at this point. -- June 2019

Hasty, a redshirt senior in 2019, finished his career with 386 carries for 1,998 yards (5.2 yards per carry) and 15 touchdowns. He caught 79 passes for 485 yards (6.1 yards per catch) and one touchdown. He's a between-the-tackles runner with a good feel for cutback lanes and good burst through the hole. He flashes the ability to make defenders miss in the hole. He's not an ankle breaker in space, and he doesn't have pull-away speed, but he's an instinctive open-field runner. He's undersized and he doesn't regularly pick up yards after contact. He's an above-average receiver, and while there's room for improvement, he is willing in pass pro. -- March 2020

Bryant is a former walk-on and three-year starter. He's a nickel prospect with above-average instincts and change of direction. He has below-average speed and he's not rangey enough to play deep like he did at Washington. He has very short arms, and his size is an issue when it comes to winning 50-50 balls. He's tough, and he chases with good effort, but he's an inconsistent tackler. -- March 2020 Bryant is a former walk-on and nickel prospect with above-average instincts and change-of-direction. He's tough and chases with good effort, but he's an inconsistent tackler. He has outstanding intangibles. He's vastly undersized with very short arms and marginal top-end speed. -- Steve Muench

Elliott has good size but just average arm length and marginal top-end speed. The one positive combine result was his above-average time in the three-cone drill (6.87). In coverage, Elliott is at his best working underneath zone or in man-to-man against some tight ends. His lack of speed is a real issue when it comes to covering the deep half, and he's simply not fast enough to hold up in center field in the NFL. But he's opportunistic with above-average ball skills. Elliott fills hard against the run, though his angles can be inconsistent. He's a solid wrap-up tackler when in position and has enough size and length to compete in the box occasionally. Elliott has exceptional football and personal character. He grades out as a backup safety (or possibly even as a press corner) in the NFL, and he has the right mentality and energy to become a core special-teamer. -- March 2020 Elliott has good size but average length and marginal top-end speed. He's at his best in underneath zone and matched up with tight ends in coverage. He's not fast enough to hold up as a center fielder in the NFL, but he's opportunistic with above-average ball skills. He's a solid wrap-up tackler who fills hard against the run. -- Steve Muench

Pinckney is a downfield run defender who flashes the ability to shoot gaps and makes plays in the backfield. He has adequate range and he chases the run with great effort. He's undersized and gets covered up at times, but he flashes a strong punch and the ability to slip blocks. He's more effective blitzing than he is in coverage. He was suspended for one game in 2018 for taking a painkiller on the banned-substance list. He missed one game with an injury in 2019. He reportedly played with a torn labrum in 2019, he did not run at the combine and he was expected to undergo a surgery with a six- to nine-month rehab time. -- March 2020

Shackelford, a true senior in 2019, was a four-year starter. He is a right-handed snapper with a strong football IQ. He's an adequate positional blocker, and he tends to take sound angles climbing to the second level in the run game. He doesn't appear to have the core strength to drive defenders off the ball. He flashes the ability to mirror and stay in front of his assignment when he gets his hands inside, but he's a waist bender with short arms and he lunges. -- March 2020 Shackelford is a four-year starter with great awareness. He's an adequate positional blocker in the run game, and he flashes the ability to mirror when he gets his hands inside. But he's a waist bender with short arms and lunges in pass pro. -- Steve Muench

Olson, a two-year starter, was Montana's all-time leading tackler with 397 career stops. He tied for the second-highest vertical jump at the combine and one of the top three jumps of any linebacker in combine history. He wraps up and flashes above-average stopping power. He makes some plays in pursuit thanks to effort. He has below-average timed speed and closing speed. He takes too long to get off blocks, and his combine performance on the bench (15 reps) raises a red flag. He reads the quarterback and shows good awareness in underneath coverage. There are questions about his ability to match up in man at the NFL level. -- April 2020

Arnold was a redshirt junior in 2019 who led the Bears with six interceptions while recording 46 tackles, two pass breakups and a sack after switching from cornerback to safety in Baylor's 3-3-5 defense. He's an undersized defensive back, at his best when lining up over the slot. He did not test well at the combine but has fluid hips and quick feet on tape. His frame is a concern when it comes to matching up with bigger receivers and tight ends. He's a natural hands catcher who tracks the ball well and played receiver in high school. He has very short arms. He's a below-average tackler who takes too long to get off blocks. He missed most of the 2018 season with an injury, missed three games with an injury in 2017 and missed time with an injury in 2016. -- March 2020

A combine snub, Warrior was a team captain and three-year starter who picked off four passes in 2019. He breaks on underneath routes and tends to limit production after the catch, but he reacts more than he anticipates. He lacks the range to regularly play center field. He wraps and drags ball carriers to the ground. Poor angles lead to some missed tackles. -- March 2020

Guidry, a true junior in 2019, started 25 games at nickelback over the past three seasons. He posted the second fastest 40-time at the combine and speed shows up on tape where he closes quickly and shows above-average recovery speed. He flashes very good short-area cover skills. He's frequently a step late making a play, and he reacts more than he anticipates. He's not big enough to regularly play on the outside. He's willing and he's an adequate tackler, but he gets covered up a lot in the run game. -- March 2020

Dowdle is a well-built back with average speed. He has decent balance and picks up some yards after initial contact. He's not much of a big-play threat, but he flashes as a receiver. He needs to be more consistent and improve in pass pro. Ball security and injuries have been issues, too. -- Steve Muench

Mayden has good size and very good straight-line speed. He has the physical tools to develop but lacks ideal game experience, and his recognition skills get him into trouble. He is at his best working forward in coverage. He has some tightness in his hips that gets exposed when opening to turn and run. Mayden showed improved ball skills in 2019 and is a playmaker when in position. He takes inconsistent angles in pursuit but shows some pop as a tackler and fills hard once he diagnoses. Mayden has value because of his versatility (FS/SS) and developmental upside. He will need to contribute on special teams -- and he has the right skillset and mindset to do so -- to keep a roster spot early in his career. -- March 2020

Colon-Castillo, a redshirt junior in 2019, was a three-year starter. He fights to stay in front, but he's a below-average athlete for the position, and there's no room for error when it comes to footwork in pass pro. He gets overwhelmed by power rushers at times. He's late delivering his punch and gets beat cleanly at times. He's an adequate zone blocker who fights to sustain once in position. He ducks his heads and whiffs climbing to the second level. -- March 2020 Colon-Castillo is a big center with very short arms. He fights to stay in front of his assignment, but he's a below-average athlete, and there's no room for error when it comes to footwork in pass pro. He gets overwhelmed by power rushers at times. He's an adequate zone blocker in the run game. -- Steve Muench

Bernard played two seasons and started 16 games at Utah after transferring from BYU, where he played running back as a true freshman. He shows good pop taking on blockers in the hole and he flashes the ability to shed in time to make plays. He's a sure tackler who tracks the ball well and flashes good stopping power. He masks below-average speed with effort and sound angles. He reads quarterbacks and shows good awareness in underneath zone. He's limited in man. -- March 2020

Breeland has a very good combination of height and weight at the position but lacks top-end speed. Ball skills are his best trait. But he really struggles to separate off the line, and he will never be a difference-maker after the catch or as a deep-seem route runner. Breeland grades out as a fringe reserve TE in the NFL. -- March 2020

Patterson, a true senior, was taken by the Texas Rangers in the 39th round of the 2018 MLB draft even though he hasn't played competitive baseball since his junior year of high school. He is an undersized quarterback with above-average arm strength and mobility. His short to intermediate accuracy is above average. He rarely misses when his footwork is sound. He falls off some throws and misses on occasion. His downfield touch is erratic. He drops the ball down the back chute but still has a quick delivery, and the ball jumps off his hand. He's tough and more than willing to take a hit to make a play, but we would like to see him hang in the pocket longer and not let oncoming pass-rushers affect his delivery/follow-through as much. He extends plays and has above-average accuracy throwing on the run. He's a threat to scramble for first downs. Patterson grades out as an NFL backup with some intriguing tools. He projects as a mid-round pick with the potential to move up boards with a strong showing in 2019. -- June 2019

Braun, a graduate transfer, started 32 games at Georgia Tech and 13 games at Texas. He's effective when asked to pull. He gets off the ball and flashes the ability to move defenders, but he loses his base and falls off blocks. He tends to take sound angles and he flashes the ability to overwhelm linebackers when climbing to the second level. There's room for improvement when it comes to tightening his footwork and playing with better body control in space. He struggles to bend and he lunges in pass pro. His footwork is inconsistent and he gets overwhelmed at times. -- March 2020

Dowell is instinctive, fluid and long enough to compete with slot receivers and tight ends in man. He doesn't have the closing burst or top-end speed of a true center fielder, but he's rangy enough to cover a deep half. He's a playmaker who has above-average hands. He does not shy away from contact in run support. There's room for improvement when it comes to his angles and finishing as a tackler, but neither is a glaring weakness. Dowell grades out as a No. 3 safety with the tools and instincts to develop into a starter early in his career. He projects as a Day 2 pick. -- June 2019

Hill is an undersized edge defender who is at his best knifing into the backfield and chasing from the back as a run defender. He takes too long to get off blocks once reached and he gets moved off the ball. He flashes good quickness and bend when rushing the passer. He doesn't convert speed to power, and there's room for improvement when it comes to winning with his hands. He's vastly undersized, with very short arms for a defensive end prospect, and he did not run well at the combine. He transferred to Miami after Virginia Tech dismissed him from the team in the fall of 2018. -- March 2020 Hill is an undersized edge defender at his best knifing into the backfield and chasing as a run defender. He takes too long to get off blocks and gets moved off the ball. He flashes good bend rushing the passer. He doesn't convert speed to power and there's room for improvement when it comes to winning with his hands. Hill has very short arms for a defensive end prospect and his 40 time at the combine raises a red flag for a defensive end with his size. -- Steve Muench

Anderson is an aggressive, downhill, between-the-tackles runner with good burst through the hole. He has excellent contact balance when he's able to build a head of steam. He ranked first in FBS in third-down rush conversion rate (87.5%) in 2019. He's quicker than fast, with average elusiveness. He doesn't have the size or brute strength of a traditional short-yardage back. There's room for improvement when it comes to pass pro. He will duck his head and lead with his shoulder. -- March 2020

Clarke is a competitive press corner who crowds receivers underneath. He reads the quarterback and flashes good route recognition in off coverage. He gives up too much separation at the top of the stem and will grab when he starts to lose. He has average playing speed and doesn't locate the ball well when he's forced to turn and run. He's not a natural hands catcher. He has slightly above-average length, and he does a good job of reaching in to break up passes. He's an inconsistent tackler. -- April 2020

Thomas, a true junior in 2019, averaged 24.6 yards per punt return and returned a punt for a touchdown in 2018. He didn't put up big receiving numbers, but he averaged 84.2 all-purpose yards at Miami. His explosive burst makes him a threat to go the distance any time he gets a seam, and he has the second gear to get behind the coverage. He's not going to win many 50-50 balls downfield. He's a small target and body catcher with small hands and shorter arms. He said he would leave the Hurricanes and transfer to Illinois late in the 2018 season. He missed the final two games of the season, but he ended up staying at Miami following a coaching change. Miami suspended him for two games for a violation of team rules in 2019. -- April 2020
